Researchers conducted a genomic survey of transcript ends in lymphoblast cells from genetically distinct human individuals to investigate the role of RNA 3'-end processing in gene regulation. They mapped the cis-regulatory architecture of 3 gene ends and found that transcript positions did not fall randomly in untranslated regions, but preferentially flanked locations of 3 regulatory elements, including miRNA sites. The usage of transcript forms and motifs varied across individuals, and polymorphisms in polyaden signals and 3 motifs were significant predictors of expression of genes. Single-gene experiments confirmed the effects of polyaden variants on steady-state expression and validated regulatory function of 3 cis elements. Focusing on IR5, they established the effect of variation on response to antigen stimulation. The study highlights the importance of mechanisms in genetics of 3-end variation: usage of distinct 3- signals and effects of 3 elements that determine transcript fate. The findings suggest integrating 3 positions with 3 motifs will be a tool in continued efforts to interpret human variation. The relationship between sequence and expression did not manifest for mi sites, highlighting the relevance of 3 motifs as predictors across individuals when integrated with transcript forms. The study validates genome analyses and speculates many variants biologically mediated by 3-end remain to be discovered. Polymorphisms in 3 that govern fate can serve predictors of steady levels of genes.
Researchers investigated the mechanisms behind the effectiveness of the SIVΔne vaccine, a live attenuated simian immunodeficiency virus vaccine that provides strong protection against wild-type lentiviral challenge. They used deep sequencing and CD8 cell epitope mapping to analyze the CD8 T cell response, identifying regions of immune pressure and viral escape, and the effect of epitope escape on the evolution of the CD T cell response in SIVne-vaccinated animals. The study found that the initial CD8 cell response in the acute phase of SIVne infection targeted variable epitopes, followed by widespread viral sequence evolution and escape. Epitope escape expanded the CD8 cell repertoire to target conserved epitopes, defined anropic specificity, and generated de novo responses to escaped variants during vaccination. These results correlated SIVne-induced protection with anropic specificity and increased response depth. The study demonstrated rapid escape of variable epitopes and maintenance of CD8 cell responses to conserved epitopes in SIVne infection, as well as de novo CD8 cell responses to escaped variants during chronic infection. SIV-specific CD8 cell responses were maintained as central memory CD cells, contributing to the cumulative breadth of the CD8 response at 20 weeks post-vacc with SIVne. Epitope escape and de novo CD8 responses to variants deepened the CD repertoire. High-throughput sequencing quantified SIVne variants and frequencies in vaccinated animals, including undetectable viral loads, and fine-mapped CD8 responses at epitope at 5 and 20 weeks postacc. Longitudinal study of vaccinated animals showed concurrent evolution of virus and CD8 specificity, resulting in a CD8 repertoire with anropic, wider breadth, rearranged immunodance, and enhanced depth.
Researchers investigated the role of interleukin-1 (IL-1) in the immune response to Candida albicans infections in the oral mucosa using a mouse model of oropharyngeal candidiasis. They found that IL-1 receptor (IL-R) signaling is critical for controlling the onset of infection through its impact on neutrophils at two levels: recruitment of circulating neutrophils to the site of infection and mobilization of newly generated neutils from the bone marrow. IL-1 deficient mice displayed impaired chemokine production at the site of infection and defective secretion of granocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) in circulation in response to C. albicans. Endothelial cells were identified as the primary source of G-CS during OPC, responding to IL-α released from keratinocytes in infected tissue. A link between IL-1 and granopoies was established in vitro using a murine-derived kerocyte line and endothelial cell line. Two mechanisms coordinating neutil response in oral mucosa were identified, crucial for preventing fungal growth and dissemination and protecting the host from disease.
Between 2000 and 2007, the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filari (GPE) delivered over 1.9 billion treatments to nearly 570 million individuals via mass administration of anti-filar drugs (albendazole, iverectin, diethylbamazine) in at-risk areas for 4-6 years. The economic benefits of this achievement were quantified by calculating the number of clinical manifestations averted and associated with disease prevention in the context of direct costs, indirect labor, and healthcare for affected individuals. Estimated US$21.8 billion in economic benefits will be gained over the lifetime of 31.4 million treated during the first 8 years of GPE, with US$2.3 billion from protection of nearly 3 million newborns and individuals from acquiring lymphatic filari as a result of being born in areas of transmission. Additionally, 28 million already infected with LF benefit from GLF halting progression, resulting in US$19.5 billion lifetime benefit. At-risk individuals decreased services with LF morbidity save health systems approximately US$2.2 billion. The Programme offers significant economic benefits, with favorable implementation largely due to donated drugs from the pharmaceutical industry, indicating a high return on investment.
Gaucher disease, the most common lysosomal disorder, is caused by homozygous mutations in the glucocerebrosidase (GBA) gene, leading to decreased enzymatic activity of glucerebrosidase (GCase) and accumulation of its substrates, glucerebroside and glucosylsphosine. The study generated GBA mutant medaka, completely deficient in GCase activity, to investigate how G mutations cause Parkinson's disease (PD). Contrary to perinatal death in humans and mice lacking G activity, GBA medaka survived months, enabling analysis of pathological progression. G med displayed neuronopathic phenotypes, including Ga cell infiltration into brains, progressive neuronal loss, and gliosis. Detailed findings revealed lysosomal abnormalities in neurons and alpha-syn accumulation in axonal swellings autophagosomes. Unexpectedly, disruption of alpha-s did not improve lifespan, axonal swellings, neuronal loss, or neuroinflamm in G medaka. The study revealed G med as a neuronopathic model, pathological mechanisms alpha-s caused by G deficiency, and minimal contribution alpha-s to pathogenesis neuronopathic.
Listeria monocytogen, a facultative intracellular pathogen, induces a robust cell-mediated immune response upon subthal infection. However, its ability to escape the phagosome and enter the host cytos is crucial for induction of long-lived CD8 T cell-mediated immunity. Research shows that impaired T response to L monocogen confined within phag is not due to inefficient antigen presentation, but direct suppression of the adaptive response. This suppression affects not only adaptive response to vacu-confined L monocogen but negates response within cytos. Co-infection with phosome-conf and cytos L monocogen prevents acquired immunity and expansion of antigen-specific T cells relative to cytos L monocogen. Bacteria confined phag suppressed pro-inflammatory cytokines and rapid MyD-dependent IL-10 production. Block IL-10 receptor or MyD during infection restored immunity. Studies demonstrate microbes within phosome impact innate and adaptive response by antagonizing inflammation and CD8 cell generation pathways.
A recent genome-wide association study identified a significant link between primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) and the SIX locus, with an odds ratio of 1.32 and a p-value of 3.87 x 10^-11. The SIX gene plays a role in ocular development and has been associated with the morphology of the optic nerve. Researchers sequenced the SIX coding and regulatory regions in 262 PO cases and 256 controls and identified six nonsynonymous variants, including five rare and one variant AsnHis (rs12345), which was associated with PO in the NEIGH/GLUG datasets. These variants were tested in an in vivo Danio rerio (zebrafish) complement assay to evaluate ocular metrics such as eye and optic structure. Five variants, primarily in PO cases, were hypomorphic or null, while the sixth, found in controls, was benign. One variant in the SIX enhancer increased expression SIX and disrupted its regulation. The study found a clinical feature in PO patients dependent on SIX genotype: those homozygous for the SIX risk allele (His) have a thinner retinal nerve layer than homozyg for the non-risk (As) allele. The results, combined with previous SIX work, suggest SIX variants disrupt the development of the retina, leading to reduced retinal ganglion cells, increasing glcoma vision loss.
Researchers have identified a genetic switch, known as the "flagellar switch," that controls the production of flagella and glucosyl toxins in the human pathogen Clostridium difficile. The flag switch is a 154-base pair invertible sequence flanked by 21-base pairs of inverted repeats and is located upstream of the flB operon, which contains early flagellar genes. When the flag switch is in the "ON" orientation, bacteria produce flagella and secrete toxins, while in the "OFF" orientation, they are attenuated for flagellar gene expression and toxin secretion. The orientation of the switch is reversible in vitro and occurs post-transcriptionally, requiring a C. difficile-specific factor to destabilize or degrade early flagellar mRNA. The tyrosine recombinase RecV, which catalyzes inversion at cwp switch, is also responsible for inversion at the flagellar switch in both directions. The flag switch affects transcription of toxin genes via σD, impacting glucyl toxin production and cytotoxicity of C. difficile. RecV also controls variation of cell wall protein cV and is the recombinase for inversion at flagellar in both directions. Flagellar ON bacteria and recV mutants with flag switch in ON display perich flagella, swim and produce glucyl toxins, while flag OFF and rec mutants with switch in OFF are attenuated for flagellar transcription and toxin production.
Researchers investigated the sporulation pathway in Clostridium difficile, an obligate anaerobic pathogen that relies on endospores for its infectious cycle. They studied the four cell-specific RNA polymerase sigma factors σF, σ, σE, σ, and σK, which control gene expression during spore development in Bacillus subtilis, and found deviations from the B. subtilis paradigm. While the main periods of activity of the factors are conserved, σE activity is partially independent of σF, σ activity is not dependent on σ, and σ activity does not require σK. σ is not strictly required for heat spore formation. The results indicate reduced temporal segregation between early and late sigma factors and reduced requirement for σ-to-σ, σ-to-σ, and σ-to- cell signaling. The study supports the view that the sporulation network is conserved in evolution, with sigma factors acting as key regulators established 2.5 billion years ago at the base of Firmic Phylum.
Researchers have developed a framework to model the behavior of allosteric multisite proteins using a single variable, which closely replicates the steady-state behavior of multisite systems such as the Monod-Wy-Change alloster model. This framework is useful for modeling and analyzing biochemical systems where multis proteins interact simultaneously. They applied this tool to a newly discovered checkpoint pathway in yeast, which monitors cell growth by signals at the plasma membrane. The pathway's components form a hysteretic switch, incorporating a signal proportional to growth, a mechanism to read the signal, and an all-or-no response when the signal reaches a threshold indicating sufficient growth. The model assumes a protein is activated by phosphorylation of several, but not all, sites, becoming increasingly precise with more sites, with good estimates for four or more. This mechanism is a one-variable, quasi-stead state reduction of the Mon-WChange alloster system. Multisite phosphorylation can give ultrasensitive responses, not possible in single-site systems. The framework can be extended to other types of multis modification, such as ligand binding, transcription, methylation, acetylation, or ubiquination. A mechanistic model of a cell checkpoint was described, assuming sequential phosphorylation by a kinase and dephosphorylation by a phosphat, with different phosphforms and large number of sites.
Researchers employed a combination of experimental and mathematical approaches to investigate the quorum sensing (QS) system in E. coli, specifically the autoinducer-2 (AI-2) signaling pathway. The study aimed to elucidate the mechanistic underpinnings of genetic "switch" phenomena, which enable bacterial populations to communicate and gain a selective advantage. The researchers separated the network into sub-networks to examine negative and positive feedback mechanisms, discovering a new negative feedback interaction and revealing the importance of the Lsr regulator in the E. coli QS "switch. A simple model was developed to understand the interplay among regulatory substructures and their contributions to the native network. This "bottom-up" approach will unravel complex QS architectures and lead to emergent behaviors. 

The AI-2 QS system in E. coli consists of an auto-regulatory network with a double negative motif, providing a population-based response. The researchers studied network connectivity and signal propagation of AI-2, constructing mutant strains to represent the system as a complete network. Analysis of this architecture shed light on regulatory pathways within bacterial metabolic networks, guiding new phenotypes and biotechnological applications. A model was built incorporating the new element, capturing predictions and simulating the intact and sub-systems. The mechanistic basis for Lsr-mediated "switch" of E. coli circuit was revealed, buried in the native system but effective.
In a study conducted in rural Gabon, researchers investigated the effect of Schistosoma haematob infection on Plasmod falcum infection in school-age children. The study found that Schosias increased the risk of Plmod infection, especially when combined with Trichuris trichi or hookworm infection. The incidence of malaria was higher in Schos-infected children compared to non-infected, with a significant delay in time-to-malaria event in children aged 6-10 years. Results suggest STH enhances risk for P falcum in Schos-positive children, and Schos enhances susceptibility to malaria in young children but not older. The study highlights the need to consider STH and schosias control in malaria programs in areas where both infections are endemic.
Researchers investigated the role of IRF-5-mediated inflammation in regulating CD8+ T cell responses during Leishmania donovani infection. IRF-5 is responsible for activating genes encoding pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6 and TN. The study found that IRF-5-induced inflammation limits CD8+ cell expansion and induces HIF-1 in dendritic cells. Ablation of H-1 in dendritic cells resulted in higher frequency of short-lived effector CD8 cells, enhanced CD+ cell expansion, and increased IL-12 expression by splenic DCs. Mice with targeted H-1 in dendritic cells had lower splenic parasite burden, suggesting H-1 induction may be an immune evasive mechanism by Leish to establish infection. IR-5 is involved in transcriptional activation of Type I IF genes and pro-inflammatory cytokines. IR-/- mice showed IR- essential for protective Th1 responses. CD+ cell depletion caused mild increase in parasite burden in Cre mice, while CD+ cells controlled parasite growth in H- conditional mice, indicating H- in DC responsible for limiting CD+ responses. H- induction in DC represents immune mechanism by Leish to establish chronic infection.
A systematic review of 14 studies conducted in Latin America on prognostic factors for adverse outcomes in American visceral leishmanias (VL) identified jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrhage, HIV coinfection, diarrhea, age <5 and >40 years, severe neutropenia, dyspnea, bacterial infections, edema, and low hemoglobin concentration as predictors of unfavorable outcomes. These factors were determined through meta-analysis of variables grouped by strength of evidence, heterogeneity of effect sizes, and multivariate analyses. Leishmanias-HIV coinfection was a significant prognostic factor for adverse evolution, with coinfected individuals having higher risk of poor outcomes. The review highlights the need for development of externally validated prognostic models, as current models lack validation. The Brazilian Ministry of Health recommends platelet transfusion for VL patients with counts <10,000 platelets/mm3. The lack of reduction in fatality rates in Brazil is attributed to therapy limitations, diagnosis delay, and inadequate management of high-risk individuals. Identification of prognostic factors is a valuable tool for clinical practice. Undernutrition is not a risk factor for severity, but rather a consequence of wasting in VL, and Leish replication control by Th1 cells in undernourished patients explains the lack of association.
Researchers in Algeria investigated the susceptibility of Leishmania isolates to antimony over a 30-year period. The study aimed to determine the level of antimony susceptibility amongst Leish transmitted in Algeria, which is crucial for public health policy development. A total of 106 isolates were analyzed, including 88 collected between 1976-2013 from humans, dogs, rodents, and phleomines, and 18 from dogs in France. The 50 inhibitory concentrations (IC50) of antimony tartrate (Sbivalent) and sodium stibogluconate (pentavalent) were determined in promastigotes and intramacroph amastigotes, respectively. The epidemiological cutoff (EFCO) allowed differentiation between Leish species causing cutaneous or visceral leishmanias susceptible (S) or insusceptible (S) to trivalent antimony was determined. The IC50 values were 23.83μg/mL and 15.91μg for VL and CL, respectively. A trend of increasing antimony susceptibility in VL isolates was observed during the 30-year period, in contrast to an increase in frequency S-phenotypes in CL isolates. The emergence of S-phenotypes correlated with L. kili (L. trop) isolates causing cutaneous leishias that emerged in Algeria during the last decade. The study provides insight into spatiemporal dynamics of Leish antimony in Algeria, highlighting the need for effective methodology to determine susceptibility to detect emergence and prevent dissemination of drug-resistant strains.
Researchers investigated the relationship between acute gastroenteritis and the development of Crohn's disease (CD), a chronic inflammatory condition of unknown etiology. They developed two models to study the comorbidity of acute gastroenteritis caused by Salmonella Typhimium or Citrobacterium in mice colonized with adherent-invasive Escherichia (AIE), a pathion linked to CD. The study found that disease activity in the post-infectious period after gastroenteritis was driven by the tissue expansion of the AIE pathion, with an increase in immunology defects, barrier, and delays in mucosal restitution following path clearance. These features required AIE resistance to host peptides and amin inflammatory response to enteric path. The results suggest that individuals colonized by AIE at the time of infectious gastroenter may be at risk for CD onset. The study also identified AIE as a tractable disease modifier, a finding that could be exploited in the development of interventions following infectious gastroitis at-risk individuals.
In flowering plants, the female gametophyte of Arabidopsis consists of two gametic cells, the egg and central cell, flanked by five accessory cells, all of which are vital for fertilization. However, the mechanisms underlying the formation of gametic versus accessory cell fate are unknown. A screen for regulators of egg cell fate isolated the lach (lis) mutant, which forms supernumerary egg cells. In lis mutants, accessory cells differentiate gametic fate, indicating LIS is involved in a mechanism preventing accessory cells from adopting gametic fate. Temporal and spatial of LIS expression suggest this mechanism is generated in gametic cells. LIS is homolog to yeast splicing factor PR4, indicating components of splice apparatus participate in cell decisions. The lis mutant reveals two levels of cell regulation, between gametic and accessory, and between egg and central cells. The initiation of cell-specific genes indicates Arabid distinct fates only after cellular formation.
A qualitative study was conducted in a rural highland Ethiopian community endemic for podoiosis, a neglected tropical disease caused by exposure to irritant soils, to explore the role of footwear in disease prevention. Using the PRECE-PRO model, social, behavioral, environmental, and ecological factors influencing shoe-wearing were assessed. 242 respondents participated in focus groups, semi-structured interviews, and case studies. Results showed shoeearing norms were changing, with going barefoot seen as shameful, and shoes conferring dignity and protection against injury and cold. However, practical and social barriers prevented desire to wear shoes from being translated into practice. Limited resources meant people could not purchase more than one pair, ensuring longevity or afford quality shoes. As a result, shoes were preserved for special occasions and not provided for children until a certain age. Underlying barriers related to poverty, such as price, unsuitability, and low perception, are likely relevant to range of NTDs. Established models of health behavior adoption identified barriers amenable to intervention, anticipated to benefit NTD prevention through shoe distribution.
Pseudorabies virus (PRV) Us protein plays a crucial role in targeting viral capsid and glycoproteins to axons of infected sympathetic neurons, with Us null mutants defective in anterograde transmission in vivo. The mechanism of Us-mediated axonal sorting of viral proteins is unclear. Glycoproteins B, C, D, and E are associated with lipid rafts on infected cells and directed into axons in Us-dependent manner. This study determined Us association with lipid rafts critical for Us-mediated sorting of structural proteins. Non-polarized and polarized PC12 cells, a ratheochromocytoma line acquiring sympathetic neuron characteristics in NGF, showed Us enriched detergent-resistant membranes (DR). Reducing Us affinity for lipid rafts inhibited antograde transmission from neurons to epithelial cells in vitro. Us association with rafts key for targeting proteins axons, directional spread PR from pre-synaptic to postynaptic neurons mammalian nervous system.
Researchers investigated the genetic heterogeneity in growth rate and stress tolerance of Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a model organism that exhibits phenotypic variation under constant conditions. They found that heterogeneity in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels through the conserved Ras/cAMP/protein A (PKA) pathway and its transcription factors M2 and M4 underlies this heterogeneity. Lower cAMP levels correspond to slower growth, shown by direct comparison of c concentration in subpopulations enriched for slower and faster cells. An endogenous reporter of this pathway's activity correlates with growth in individual cells. Paralogs M2 and M4 differ in roles in heterogeneity in a way that demonstrates slow growth and stress are not linked. Heterogeneity in rate requires M2, whereas M4 is required for heterogeneity expression of T1, subunit trehalose synth that contributes to acute-stress. Perturbing heterogeneity by mutating genes in pathway or culturing wild-type with cell-perable cAMP 8romoAMP or PK inhibitor H89 impacts survival acute stress. Perturbations increase c levels reduce slower subpopulation and increase susceptibility heat, whereas PK slows growth and decreases susceptibility. Loss M2 reduces but not eliminates correlation individual between rate and stress, suggesting major role M2 in heterogeneity but residual slow growth.
Researchers conducted a whole-genome sequencing analysis of the Chikungunya virus (CHV) from the 2013 outbreak in the Caribbean to understand its evolutionary genomic elements. CHV, an alphavirus and member of the Togaviridae family, caused severe febrile disease in humans and rapidly spread from Asia to the Americas. The study analyzed viral diversity in infected individuals from Guadelou and Martinique, two islands in the epicenter of the epidemic, using deep-sequencing and bioinformatics. Changes in consensus and minority variants were observed at various levels, with reduced diversity after single passages in cell lines. An infectious clone was constructed and a novel 3' untranslated region (UTR) structure, not found in nature, was identified, leading to increased replication in insect cells. Intrahostasis analysis of the new CHV outbreak in the Caribbean revealed novel variants and a new 3'UTR, suggesting rapid evolution in a short time. The study highlights the need for continued viral surveillance to understand CHV's evolutionary potential.
Researchers have identified a previously unannotated gene, UOR, as a functional player in regulating cell growth and mTOR signaling. UOR depletion in cultured hippocampal neurons and PC cells promotes neurite outgrowth, while UOR overexpression suppresses colony formation in cancer cell lines. Mechanistic studies in cells revealed UOR stabilizes DEOR, a component of the mTOR complex, to inhibit m signaling. In zebraf models, UOR disruption upregulates m signaling and promotes HRAS (12) mediated tumor formation. UOR stabilizes DEOR and regulates DE's ubiquitination, while U disruption increases m activity and aggravates HR (12) neoplas in animals. UOR depletion promotes growth and m signaling in xenograft mice. UOR is an unannot gene present in vertebrates, encoding a protein without known domains. UOR depletion promotes growth in HEK and UMG cells, while overexpression suppresses colony in HE and T cells. UOR reduction promotes m signaling. U interacts with DEOR and m complexes. UOR depletion promotes growth and m in xenograft.
Researchers have created a comprehensive map of protein interactions in the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma brucei, responsible for African trypanosomiasis. Using biochemical fractionation, they identified 128 high-confidence complexes involving 716 proteins, including 635 with unknown functions. The map correlates with known pathways and co-expressed proteins across the parasite's life cycle, providing potential functions for uncharacterized proteins. Novel proteins associated with RNA editing machinery were validated, including a candidate involved in post-transcriptional regulation. This study presents the largest proteomics interaction map of tryosid parasites to date, providing a resource for new hypotheses and experimental leads. The map was used to reveal factors in post-transcription regulation of T bruce, validated by independent experiments.
Researchers studied the dynamics of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection in lymph nodes (LNs) of macaques, focusing on thoracic LNs, which are commonly infected in humans. They analyzed PET scans, bacterial burden, and immune function of LNs in M-infected cynolgus andhes macques and found that LNs have different trajectories of increasing or decreasing activity over time within the same animal. Rhes macques are more susceptible to M infection than cynolg macques due to extensive LN pathology. Mtb grows to the same level in cynolg andhes mac LNs, but cynolg macques control M at later points post-infection while rhes macques do not. Granulomas in LNs are poor at killing Mtb, even with treatment, due to lack of B-rich structures, disruption of LN structure, and introduction of macrophages that serve as niches for M, and destruction of vasculature. The study shows that Ls are not only sites of antigen presentation and immune activation but also persistence of significant numbers of M bacilli.
A collection of novel nematode-infecting microsporidia and their diverse interactions with Caenorhabitis and other nematodes. Microsporidia are fungi-related intracellular pathogens that infect virtually all animals, but are poorly understood. Caenorhabitis elegans has become a model for studying microidia through identification of its microidian pathogen Nematida paris. However, it was unclear how widespread and diverse microidia are in C elegans or other nemat in the wild. We describe isolation and culture of 47 nemodes with microidian infections. N. paris is most common microidian infecting Cans in the wild. Six new species in Nematida genus are described. Phylogenetic analysis identifies two subclades distinct from Nematida, named Entersect and Ptospora. Unlike Nemat, these belong to main clade microidia includes human pathogens. All microidia are horizontally transmitted and infect intestinal cells, except Ptos that replicates in epidermis of Caenor host. Subcellular in infected cell, spores Entersect show apical distribution and exit via budding, unlike Nemat exit via exocytosis. Host specificity is broad for some microidia, narrow for others. Some microidia infect Osche but not sister Osche, and vice versa. Nauseli fails to induce C eleg transcription genes induced by Nemat species, suggesting mechanisms to prevent host response. Newly isolated illustrate diversity and ubiquity microidian in nemodes and provide resource investigate host-paras coevolution in nemodes.
Chemokine receptors, a subclass of G protein-coupled receptors, play crucial roles in the human immune system and are involved in cancer metastasis and HIV infection. Studies have shown that homo- and heterodimers of chemine receptors CXCR, CCR, and C2 modulate receptor function, and membrane cholesterol affects chemine activity. However, structural information on homo and heterodimers of chemine receptors and their interaction with cholesterol is limited. This study reports homo and heterod configurations of chemine receptors CXCR, C, C, and C at atomic detail from molecular simulations. Homodimer patterns were similar for closely related chemine receptors, yet differed between CCR and CX4. Cholesterol modulated homod interfaces in subtype-specific manner. Chemine heterod display distinct dimer patterns CX4/5 and CX/2. Associations between CX and C reveal increased cholesterol sensitivity compared to CX/2 heterodimer patterns. This work provides a comprehensive overview of interaction between chemine receptors and how heterodization and interaction with environment diversifies function of related GPC.
Researchers have identified an "atypical" form of systemic leishmaniasis, a disease caused by Leishmania parasites, in patients presenting with depressed immunity. This form is distinct from the classical presentation of fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and wasting, and a subclinical form with one or two of these symptoms and lymphadenopathy and anemia. In a study of 160 patients referred to an immunology laboratory, 19.4% had normal laboratory profiles but macrophages laden with Leish parasites. This atypical form presents as a masquerading condition where the immune system is non-functional, predisposing patients to recurrent infections with various symptoms. The findings indicate systemic leishias has a wider spectrum of signs and symptoms than previously suspected and is more common than diagnosed. Among 31 patients, adults were affected, showing the disease is not limited to the pediatric group. The authors recommend considering atypical leishiasis in patients with unexplained immunity and no obvious immunologic defect.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide analysis to investigate the relationship between disease-causing variants and their locations in paralogous proteins. They found that variants at homolog positions in paralog proteins are correlated, and if one member of a variant pair is disease-causing, the other is likely to be disease-causing as well. This information can be used to identify potentially disease-causing variants, extend existing procedures for polymorphism prioritization, and provide candidates for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. A dataset of known disease-causing variants from OMIM and HGMD was used to identify and characterize pairs of variants at homolog positions in human genes. Results show that variants co-occur at aligned amino pairs more frequently than expected, suggesting functional constraints on paralog sequences result in coordinated distributions of disease and non-disease variants. This approach can be used for hypothesis generation and departure for clinical research, and to identify new disease candidates and uncharacterized variants likely to have phenotyp consequences. A collection of disease-causing variations from OM and HG was mapped to gene and protein sequences, suggesting algorithms for disease identification based on sequence conservation may miss instances. Paralog genes and variantairs can provide additional information for in silico characterization, complementary to approaches like SIFT and PolyPhen. Rare disease variants in paralog proteins tend to pair, and alignments provide a resource for genomics.
Researchers analyzed the gene expression of the malaria parasite Plasmodium falcum in 44 isolates from patients with severe and uncomplicated malaria in Papua New Guinea using RNA sequencing. The results showed that parasites causing severe malaria had altered expression of genes involved in glycolysis, chromatin structure, and transcription regulation, and surface antigens. Specifically, they had reduced expression of PfEMP1, a major target of protective immunity, and down-regulated multiple chaperone proteins. The study also found associations between disease severity and Pf1 transcripts, domains, and confirmed previous associations between expressed Pf1 sequences and disease. These findings will inform vaccine targets for severe malaria and how parasites adapt to the host environment in severe malaria.
Researchers used an adeno-associated virus (AAV) vector to deliver anti-SIV monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) to rhesus monkeys, achieving persisting levels of mAb as high as 270 μg/ml. However, host responses to the delivered antibody were observed in 9 of 12 monkeys, limiting the concentration of delivered antibody that could be achieved, with a range of 1-270 μ/ml. Following repeated intravenous challenge with the difficult-to-neutralize SIVmac, six monkeys in the AAV-5 Ig1 group showed protective effects despite absence of detectable neutralizing activity against the virus. Protective effects included lowering of viral load peak, lowering viral set point, and delay in time to peak load from exposure. All effects were statistically significant. The monkey with highest delivered 5m resisted six successive SIV challenges, including a final challenge of 10 infectious units. Results demonstrate continued promise for prevention of HIV-1 infection. However, antibody responses need to be understood for this approach to be realized.
Researchers investigated the conformational motions of two motor proteins, myosin and kinesin K1A, using a coarse-grained elastic network approximation. They found that the assumption of linearity in response to thermal or structural perturbations, such as ligand binding or detachment, is deficient and can be violated even for thermal fluctuations. This is particularly pronounced in kines K1, where the normal mode description fails to describe mechanochemical motions. The study suggests that the theory of protein dynamics may need to be reconsidered, as neither a single mode nor a superposition of modes can approximate nonlinear dynamics. Conformation relaxation associated with ligand binding and hydrolysis in myos can be qualitatively characterized by normal modes, but the description breaks down for kines K1. Despite this, ordered and robust mechchemical motions are present in both proteins, which cannot be described by linear response. Large conformation changes due to lig binding are often considered in linear theory and normal approximation, but this study reveals nonlinearity in both proteins.
Researchers have investigated the interaction between clathrin-independent endocytic pathways and found that specific caveolar proteins, specifically Cavin-1 and Cavin-3, act as negative regulators of the clath-independent carriers/GPI-AP enriched endosomal (CL/GEE) endytic pathway. This regulation occurs independently of caveola formation. Caveolin-1 and Cavin-3 inhibit the CL/GEE pathway, while Cavin-2 and Cavin-4 do not. Overexpression of caveolar leads to a reduction in CL/GEE carrier formation, detected by electron microscopy. The CLEE pathway is upregulated in cells lacking CAV/Cavin-1 or with reduced Cavin-1 and Cavin. Inhibition by caveins can be mimicked by the caveolin scaffolding domain, associated with perturbed lipid diffusion, revealed by fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) studies. Without caveins and caveae, CAV is endocytosed through the CLEE pathway, but loses polarization and sorting, affecting membrane dynamics and endytic in migrating cells and muscle tissue. Non-cave Cavin-1 acts as a modulator for the regulator of the CLEE pathway, C42. This study provides insights into regulation of nonave clrin-independent endocyt by caveolar proteins, illustrating multiple levels of crosstalk between pathways.
Researchers have identified a subset of Receiver (REC) domains in bacteria and Archaea that lack the conserved aspartate (Asp) residue, which is typically phosphorylated by a histidine kinase to initiate signaling. This subset, named Aspart-Less Receiver (AL) domains, comprises approximately 4% of all REC domains and are found in 2% of bacterial genomes. Analysis of AL structures and biochemical data revealed that AL domains have reorganized their active sites to accommodate signals other than phosphorylation, while retaining canonical post-phosphorylation mechanisms and dimer interface. Some AL domains have diversified to bind small molecules, such as antibiotics, and Ser-Thr phosphorylation through eukary-like kinases and PP phosphatases, regulating cell envelope functions and virulence in microbes. The most common AL substitutions at the conserved phospho-As site are Ser, Thr, and Tyr, which are known for phospho-regulation by bacterial kinases. Other AL domains have Arg or Cys at the phosph-As position, capable of phospho-reg by kinases and phosphatases. These findings define AL as an atypical REC subclass and provide insights into activation mechanisms between AL and REC domains.
Oncolytic herpes simplex viruses (HSVs) have shown efficacy in clinical trials, but most are attenuated due to deletions/mutations that counteract the host response and selectively grow in cancer cells with defective anti-viral response. Next-generation HSVs with no delet/mutations and cancer-specific retargeting to tumor receptors, such as HER2 (human epidermal growth factor receptor 2), are fully virulent in cancer cells. The immunotherapy elicited by these viruses is unpredictable, as non-attenuated HS dampen the innate response, deleted/attenuated fail to induce it, and retargeted HS replicate in tumor cells but spare others. This study reports the first efficacy of HER2-targeted, fully-virulent HS in immunocompet mice. Both unarmed RM and IL-12-armed R115 inhibited primary HER2-Lewis lung carcinoma tumor growth, with R115 being more efficacious. Mice not dying from primary tumors were protected from contralateral growth. Long-term survivors were protected from secondal tumor, indicating absc immunotherapeutic effect. Analysis showed R115 unleashed immunosuppressive tumor environment, inducing immunomodulatory cytokines and Th1 polarization. Tumor-infiltrating cells, such as CD4, CD335, were increased in responders, whereas CD8, Fox3, CD141 were increased and CD11 decreased in R115 mice. Response included break of tolerance to HER and wt cells, underscoring systemic immunotherapeutic response.
Researchers investigated the susceptibility of CD4 T cells induced by different HIV vaccine vectors to HIV infection. They found that CD4 cells induced by the Adenovirus 5 (Ad) vector in the RV144 trial were susceptible to HIV, but those induced by the ALVAC vector in the RV144 trial were less susceptible to both R5 and X4 HIV in vitro. The lower susceptibility of ALAC-specific CD4 cells was associated with reduced expression of HIV co-receptors CCR5 and CXCR4 on these cells. Phenotypic analysis showed ALAC CD4 cells displayed a Th1 phenotype, producing high levels of IFN-γ and CCL4 (M-β) but little IL-17. In contrast, ALAC and Ad vectors induced distinct profiles of vector-specific CD8 vs CD4 T-cell proliferative responses in PB, with ALAC preferentially inducing CD8-cell proliferation while Ad induced CD4-cell proliferation. Depletion of ALAC but not Ad CD8 cells in PB led to a modest increase in HIV infection of vector-specific CD cells, suggesting a role of ALAC-specific CD8 cells in protecting ALAC CD4 cells from HIV. The study highlights the importance of evaluating anti-vector responses in HIV vaccination.
Researchers investigated the evolution of X chromosome inactivation strategies in mammals, a process where one X chromosome is silenced in female somatic cells. The choice of which X to silence varies among species, ranging from paternal X-inherited inactivation (PX), rendering females haploid for maternal alleles, to random X-inactivation (RX), equalizing maternal and paternal allele expression in each tissue. Theoretical analysis considered conditions of dominance, linkage, recombination, and sex-differential selection's influence on X inactivation evolution. Results show a critical interaction between allelic dominance and sex-differential selects a broad range of inactivation strategies, including unequal rates between maternal and paternal X chromosomes. RX is favored over PX when deleterious alleles to females are recessive, and criteria for RX evolution is more restrictive with sexually antagonistic variation. Evolution from PX to RX increases female fitness at the expense of male fitness. Species properties and genetic variation predict patterns of selection for different inactivation. Sexual and sex-based mutation rates vary, influencing transmission of deleterious alleles between maternal and paternal X. Selection favors preferential inactivation of the chromosome with more deleterious alleles. An analysis shows evolutionary stability of X strategies. Sex-differential selection, where fitness differs between males and females, influences large fractions of genomes, affecting X diversification. Stronger selection against deleterious in males decreases proportion on paternal X.
Researchers investigated the antiviral potential of the host protein ZAP against Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), dengue virus (DENV), and Zika virus (ZIK). They found that overexpression of ZAP blocked JEV infection, but not DENV or ZIK, and depletion of endogenous Z enhanced JEV replication. Z hampered JEV translation and targeted viral RNA for 3-5' exosome-mediated degradation. The zincinger motifs of Z were essential for RNA targeting and antiv activity against JEV. The 3'-UTR, especially the region with dumbbell structures and high content of dinucleotide, was mapped to bind Z and confer sensitivity to Z. JEV was identified as the first Z-sensitive flavivirus. Z may act as intrinsic antiv factor through RNA binding against J infection. The study suggests that 3-5 RNA degradation by exosome is involved in antiv mechanism of Z against JEV.
Rift Valley fever virus (RVV) is a significant pathogen causing severe disease in humans and animals, particularly in Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. This study investigated the host response to wild-type RVV strain Z501 and vaccine strain MP12 in C57/BL6 mice. Mice infected with attenuated MP12 survived with minimal disease and cytokine response, whereas Z501 infection was lethal, causing lymphocyte and platelet depletion and a strong cytokine response correlating with high virus titers and tissue pathology. Lymphopenia and platelet depletion indicated disease onset, with lymphocyte recovery correlating with G-CS production. RVV is hepatotropic, with significant clinical and histological data supporting findings, but no pro-inflammatory response in liver, instead a chemokine response with neutrophil infiltration. Brains of Z501 infected mice showed chemokine and inflammatory response with little pathology, indicating meningoencephalitis. Data suggest RVV pathogenesis in mice is liver dysfunction due to necrosis and hepatitis, with long-term disease being neurologic, supported by human and BAL/c mouse observations.
Researchers investigated the role of C motif chemokine ligand 20 (C20) in taxane chemoresistance in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). They found that C20 was significantly elevated in patients with non-pathologic response to taxane-containing chemotherapy. C20 promoted self-renewal and maintenance of breast cancer stem cells (BCS) through activation of protein kinase Cζ (PKζ) and p38 mitogen-activated protein (MAP) mediated p65 nuclear factor B (NF-κ) pathway, increasing taxane resistance in BC. Additionally, C20 increased ATP-binding cassette subfamily member 1 (ABCB1)/multidrug resistance (DR) expression, leading to extracellular efflux of taxane. A positive feedback loop between NF-κ and C20 pathways sustained chemoresistance in cancer cells. The study suggests C20 as a predictive marker for taxane response and blockade of C20 or its pathway may reverse tax resistance in breast cancer. Tax-induced C20 activated NF through PKζ or 38 and promoted expression of AB1, leading to chemoresistance in breast cells. NF-κ increased C20 expression, forming a positive feedback loop between NF-κ and C pathways, providing impetus for chemoresistance in cancer cells. C20 stimulated proliferation, invasion, and anchorage growth in TNBC and promoted tumor growth in vivo. It also exhibited resistance to taxane, demonstrating its role in regulation of breast malignancy.
Toxoplas gondii, an obligate intracellular parasite, infects virtually all nucleated cells in warm-blooded animals. Its ability to infect and manipulate host cells depends on transporting GRA proteins from secretory organelles called dense granules into host cells. GRA proteins have diverse roles in Toxopla's intracellular lifecycle, including hijacking host functions such as cell cycle and p38 MAP kinase. Some GRAs, like GRA16 and GRA24, are secreted into parasitoph vacuole (PV) within Toxla replicates and transported across PV membrane (PVM) into host, but translocation process and machinery not understood. TMY1, cleaved by TASP into fragments, localizes PVM and essential for GRA transport into host. To identify additional proteins for effector transport, Toxla mutants defective in cyc-regulation screened for ability export GRA and GRA to host nucleus. Novel MY2 and MY3 play crucial role in translocation subset GRAs into host. MY2 and MY3 secreted PV, co-localize with PVM and MY1. Consistent predicted transmembrane domains, all proteins membrane-associated, MY3 but MY stably with MY1, N-terminal C-terminal disulf-linked. Fusing intrinsically disordered effectors structured DH domain blocks transport effectors, consistent translo model effector transport.
Researchers have investigated the role of the origin recognition complex (ORC) in the replication of papillomavirus (PV), a DNA virus that resembles a mini-chromosome in infected cells. They found that the E2 protein of PV binds to OR2, but OR2 is not present at the viral origin of replication. Depletion of OR2 enhanced replication in a transient model and keratinocyte cell line, but had no effect on a cell line with integrated genomes. This suggests OR2 suppresses E2 replicative function. Overexpression of E2 decreased OR2 occupation at mammalian origins, implying E restricts pre-RC assembly that competes with host replication complexes for viral amplification. The study suggests OR2 restricts viral replication in the maintenance phase and elevated E levels during differentiation subvert OR loading and DNA synthesis at cellular origins.
A study was conducted in the urban and peri-urban area of Dush, Tajikistan to investigate the presence of Brucella DNA in bovine milk. Bruc DNA was detected in 10.3% of 564 milk samples by IS-based real-time PCR. The finding is concerning as unpasteurified dairy products are common in the region. Bruc DNA was detected in the milk of seropositive cows, but 8.3% of seronegative cows also showed Bruc DNA. Sequence analysis of the rB gene suggests one cow was infected with B. abortus and another was likely infected with B. melensis. Discrepancies between serology and real PCR highlight the need for complementary diagnostic strategies to detect seroneg individuals in Bruc surveillance and control. Vaccination of cattle with S and small ruminants Rev may be needed to control Bruc infections. Further research on Bruc isolation is required to understand Bruc spp in the region.
Researchers investigated the role of histone H3 lysine methylation in chromosome stability in the pathogenic fungus Zoseptoria trici, which has eight accessory chromosomes that are highly unstable during meiosis and mitosis and transcriptionally repressed. They deleted genes encoding the methyltransferases responsible for H3me9 and H27, Kmt1 and K6, respectively, and generated a double mutant to determine the impact on chromosome and genome stability in vitro and in planta. Whole genome sequencing, ChIP-seq, and RNA-seq were used to compare changes in genome and chromatin structure and gene expression between mutant and wild-type strains. Results showed dramatic chromatin reorganization in H9-deficient strains, with H27me mostly localized to regions enriched in H9 in wild-type, and many rearrangements and formation of new chromosomes in absence H9, accompanied by activation of transposable elements. In contrast, loss of H27 increased stability of accessory chromosomes under normal conditions in vitro, without large changes in gene activity. H9 is important for maintaining genome stability by disallowing H27 in constitutive heterochatin, while H27 reduces overall stability of accessory, creating a "metastable" state for quasi-essential genome regions.
Researchers evaluated the cost-effectiveness of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for rabies vaccination in low-income countries, where life-saving vaccines are often inaccessible and unaffordable to those most at risk. They analyzed different P regimens and their costs, finding P to be an extremely cost-effective intervention ($200-$60/death averted). Switching from intramuscular (IM) to intradermal (ID) administration resulted in significant savings, mitigating vaccine shortages and reducing costs. To make P more accessible, financing mechanisms could subsidize costs for those in need and support existing prevention programs. A universal switch to ID delivery would improve affordability and accessibility, leading to reduced rabies deaths and economical healthcare costs. 

The study examined costs of IM versus ID administration under realistic constraints, demonstrating ID to be more cost-effective in averting cases and lives. Clinic capacity affects vial sharing and cost-effectiveness relative to IM. Rabies-exposure is essential but out of reach for many, vaccine shortages common in developing countries, victims incurring costs and facing delays, resulting in avoidable deaths due to poor access. Changes in P costs could improve affordability, providing incentives without compromising budgets. Issues should be considered in P policy design to reduce rabies burden by increasing availability for the poor who bear the brunt in developing countries. Incremental cost-effectiveness ratios (ICER) in dollars/death averted were calculated, including direct costs from the provider's perspective.
Toxoplas, an obligate intracellular parasite, replicates within mammalian cells in a parasitophorous vacuole (PV) that does not fuse with host organelles. One mechanism for nutrient acquisition is attraction of host organelles to PV. This study examines lipid droplet (LD) exploitation by Toxoplas. Toxoplas replication is reduced in cells depleted of LD or impaired lipolysis/fatty acidolysis. In infected cells, host LD number and LD-associated gene expression (ADP, DG2) increase until parasite replication onset. PV are surrounded by host LD. Tooplas accesses host lipids in LD and incorporates into its membranes/LD. Exogenous oleic acid stimulates LDogenesis in host, resulting in neutral lipid accumulation in large LD inside parasite. Toop intercepts and internalizes LD within PV, some associated with Rab7, wrapped by intravacolar network (IV) membranes. Mutants impaired IV display diminished lipid uptake from LD. Parasites lacking IV-localized phospholipase2 are less proficient in salvaging lipids from LD PV, suggesting IV major contribution to LD processing and lipid release. Gavage parasites unveil presence of endytic structures containing lipid material from PV lumen. This study highlights Tooplas reliance on LD for intracellular development and scavenging lipids from LD.
Researchers have identified chalcon compounds as potential inhibitors of Fasciola hepatica catheps, enzymes responsible for liver fluke infections in cattle and sheep. Fasciola hepatica and Fasciola gigantica are zoonotic diseases, with chemotherapy being the main control measure, and tricendazole the preferred drug. However, resistance to tricendazole has been reported, prompting the search for new molecules to control fluke infections. A library of flavonoids was screened for inhibitors of Fasciola cystine proteases FCL and FCL. Chalcones with phenyl and naphthyl groups emerged as cathein inhibitors, interacting with two binding sites within the active site of the enzymes. One compound, C34, bound to juvenile FCL with an IC50 of 5.6 μM. C34 is a slow-reversible inhibitor interacting with the Cys catalytic dyad and S2 and S3 residues, determinants of substrate specificity of cystine proteases. C induced reduction in NE ability to migrate through gut and loss of motility, leading to NE death in vitro, without cytotoxicity to bovine cells. This is the first report of non-peptide inhibitors of Fasciola catheps in vitro. Chalcones are novel inhibitors of main catps secreted by juvenile and adult liver flukes, with C34 highly active against juvenile, reducing larval ability to penetrate gut and viability in vitro. These findings open avenues for novel agents to control fluke and helminthic diseases.
Researchers investigated how the visual system transmits information about fast and slow changes in light intensity through separate neural pathways. They used in vivo imaging to study how bipolar cells transmit signals to the retina and found that the volume of the synaptic terminal is an intrinsic property that contributes to different temporal filtering. Individual cells transmit through terminals of varying size, with smaller terminals generating faster and larger calcium transients to trigger vesicle release with higher gain, followed by more adaptation. Smaller terminals transmit higher frequencies more effectively. Modeling calcium dynamics of ves release indicated that variations in presynaptic compartments contribute directly to these differences in response.

Measurements of presynaptic calcium showed a strongly rectifying function of light, increasing with graded contrast. Voltage-dependent channels in terminals were responsible for non-linear transformation of the signal. Variations in presaptic signal impact output, with smaller terminals responding to step light with higher release rates. However, resolution was too low to detect modulations at frequencies >1 Hz. The next compartment in the pathway, synaptic terminals of bipolar cells, showed rectification due to increase in stimulus causing increase in release rate even with constant luminance.

To quantify time-dependent changes, an "Adapt Index" was used, calculated as ratio of peak to steady-state response. Assuming constant vesicles in terminals, predicted rate would depress more in smaller terminals. Whole-cell recordings from goldfish retina showed presaptic signals in large and small compartments while controlling the terminal. Introduction of Ca+ indicator allowed comparison of signals while achieving electrical control.
Researchers have developed a novel probabilistic method for detecting synapses from multiplex fluorescence microscopy (FM) images, which combines the advantages of fluorescence microscopy's high speed and low cost with electron microscopy's reliability. The method uses conjugate array tomography (AT) data, which provides both fluorescence and electron microscopy images of the same synapses. The algorithm accepts morphological synaptic models as queries and delivers a volumetric probability map of each voxel being part of a synapse. Compared to electron microscopy-annotated data, the method detects synapses from FM images as accurately as human annotators and reproduces known features of cortical syn distributions. This approach enables data-driven discovery of new synapse types and density. The probabilistic synapse detector is also applicable to standard confocal and super-resolution FM images where EM validation is impractical.
Researchers have investigated the mechanism of action of ZnT, a zinc transporter responsible for accumulating zinc in secretory vesicles during lactation. They found that Zn2 is a proton-coupled zinc antiporter, meaning it uses a proton gradient to transport zinc into vesicles. This was demonstrated through experiments using Bafomycin A, a specific inhibitor of vacuolar protonase, which alkalizes vesicles, abolishing Zn2-dependent zinc transport. Additionally, using Lyso Red and Ly-pfluor, they showed that Zn2 overexpression in intracellular vesicles and addition of exogenous zinc resulted in vesicular alkalization due to proton-zinc antiport, which was reversed by TP, a zinc chelator. Computational calculations suggest Zn2 functions as an antiporter with a stoichiometry of 2+/Zn+ ion. This indicates Zn2 is a motive-driven electrutral ves zinc exchanger, concentrating zinc in vesicles at the expense of proton extrusion to cytoplasm.
Researchers have identified a new role for 14-3 proteins in regulating the processing of stalled replication forks, which is essential for maintaining genome stability. They found that 14-3 proteins interact with Exonuclease 1 (Exo), an enzyme that processes stalled forks in checkpoint-deficient cells. In yeast cells lacking 14-3, Exo is hyperphosphorylated and accumulates ssDNA gaps at forks, leading to persistent checkpoint activation and recovery. Using DNA electrophoresis, they show 14-3 proteins promote fork progression under limiting nucleotide conditions. This suggests 14-3 assist in controlling Exo phosphorylation and other targets, promoting fork stability and restart in response to DNA stress. The study sheds light on processes at stalled forks, proposing 14-3 as central regulators of fork stability and processing.
Researchers investigated the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC) in human immunodeficiency virus 1 (HIV-1) infection and pathogenesis using a humanized mouse model. They developed a monoclonal antibody that specifically depletes humanDC in lymphoid organs and found that depletion prior to HIV-1 infection abolished induction of type I interferons (IF-I) and interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) during acute HIV-1 infection. This resulted in increased HIV-1 replication. However, cell death induced by the highly pathogenic HIV-1 isolate was reduced in p-depleted mice. During chronic HIV-1 infection, depletion of p also reduced IF-I and IS, associated with elevated HIV-1 replication. Surprisingly, HIV-induced immune cell death in lymphoid organs was reduced despite increased replication. The study suggests p play opposing roles in suppressing HIV-1 replication and promoting HIV-induced immunogenesis. Findings indicate p-depletion and IF-I blockade as novel strategies for treating HIV-1 non-responsive patients with persistent immune activation despite antiretroviral treatment.
Sulforaphane (SF) inhibits HIV infection in macrophages through Nrf2. SF, a compound found in cruciferous vegetables after mechanical damage, mobilizes Nrf to reprogram cellular expression. This study shows SF blocks HIV infection in primary macrophages but not in primary T cells. SF also blocks infection in PMA-differentiated promocytic lines but not in other cell lines. RNA-mediated depletion of Nrf boosts HIV infectivity in primary macroph and reduces anti-viral effects of SF treatment. This supports a model where anti-viral activity is mediated through Nrf after mobilized by SF. SF treatment blocks infection after reverse transcription but before 2-L circle formation, similar to type I interferon-induced proteins SAM1 and MX. However, neither SAM1 nor MX are upregulated. Nrf action potently blocks HIV and highlights a novel way to trigger inhibition. Nrf is detrimental to HIV in macroages and basal level sufficient for anti-v activity. SF triggers block in macroages through Nrf.
A cross-sectional study conducted in rural western Kenya investigated geohelth infections among pregnant women. Among 390 participants, 76.2% had at least one geelth infection, with Ascaris lumicoid (52.3%), hookworm (39.5%), and Trichuris trichi (29%) being the most prevalent. Infection with at least geel species was associated with use of unprotected water source (adjusted odds ratio 1.8, 95% CI 1.1-3) and lack of water treatment (adjusted ratio 1.8, 95 CI 1.1-3). Geel infections were not associated with clinical symptoms or body mass index. Hookworm infection was associated with lower upper arm circumference (adjusted decrease 0.7 cm, 95 CI 0.3-1.2). Hookworm with egg count ≥100/gram was associated lower hemoglobin (adjusted decrease 1.5 g/dl, 95 CI0.3-2.7). Among gravid 2 and 3 women, Ascaris lumicoid was less likely to have malaria (OR 0.4, 95 CI 0.2-0.8) compared to without Ascaris lumoid. Geel infections were common in this population, but few detrimental effects observed. Routine antelmin treatment during antenatal visit recommended, but evaluation of impact on pregnancy, malaria, and outcome useful.
Mycolone, a macrolide produced by the pathogen Mycobacterium ulcerans, has been shown to have cytotoxic, analgesic, and immunomodulatory properties. This study investigated its effects on the inflammatory responses of nervous cell subsets involved in pain perception and transmission, as well as neuroinflammation associated with chronic pain in vivo. Sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia were isolated from mice for ex vivo assessment of mycolone cytotoxicity and immunomod activity. Prolonged (>48h) exposure to mycolone induced cell death at concentrations >10ng/ml, while nanolar concentrations suppressed pro-inflammatory mediator production without affecting viability. Notably, myone prevented pro-inflammatory polarization of microglia, which contribute to neuroflammation. In a rat model of neuropathic pain induced by sciatic nerve constriction, myone injected daily for 3 days in spinal canal decreased local inflammatory cytokine production without detectable cytotoxicity. This study provides evidence that myone suppresses inflammatory responses of sensory, Schw cells and microia without affecting viability, supporting previous studies using peripheral leukocytes that myone-mediated analgesia may be partially explained by anti-inflammatory properties.
Researchers investigated the relationship between genetic variations in human genes and the outcome of African trypanosomiasis (AT), a disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambense, in West Africa. They analyzed 425 individuals from Guinea, including 232 with AT, 79 with long-term positive serology but negative parasitology, and 114 controls. Twenty-eight single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in eight genes passed quality control and were used for association analysis. The study found that the IL6 rs1819 allele was associated with a lower risk of progressing from latent to active disease (p=0.0001, OR=0.39, 95%CI[0.24-0.63, BF=0.003). The MIF36071 allele was associated with increased risk (p=0.023, OR=1.65, 95%CI[1.07-2.53, BF=0.669) but not significant after Bonferr correction. MIF12459 allele was associated with latent infections (p=0.007, OR=1.86, 95%[1.18-2.95, BF=0.215). The AP1G2 allele (DEL) was associated with higher risk (p=0.001, OR=2.70, 95%[1.49-4.91, BF=0.01) and AP1 polymorphism with lower risk (p=0.000, OR=0.45 95%[0.29-0.70, BF=0.012). No associations were found with other genes. The study shows host genes modulate Tryosoma bruce gambense infection in Guinea individuals, with IL1819 associated with lower risk of progressing to AT.
Researchers conducted whole-genome sequencing of 38 individuals from the Singapore Indian population, part of the Singapore Sequencing Indian Project (SSIP), to investigate the genetic diversity of South Asians. The samples were compared to those from the Sequencing Malay Project and Phase 1 of the 1,000 Genomes Project. SSIP exhibited greater intra-population genetic diversity and higher heterozygous-homozygous genotype ratio than other Asian populations. When compared to a panel of well-defined Indians, the genetic makeup of SSIP was closely related to South Indians, but clustered distinctly from Europeans in autosomal SNPs. Eight samples were assigned to mitochondrial haplogroups predominantly present in Europeans, with higher European admixture than remaining samples. Analysis of relatedness to archaic homins (Denisovan, Neanderthal) showed higher ancient admixture in East populations than SSIP. The resource is publicly available and complements South Asian samples in Phase 3 of 1,000 Genomes. 

The SSIP sequenced genomes of 36 South Indians at 30X coverage, complementing 96 Southeast Malays and 1,092 samples from Phase 1 of 1,000 Genomes. Principal Component Analysis revealed greater heterogeneity in Indians from northern India, while those from south were more homogeneous. Independent analysis with Gujarati Indians from Genome Project found a third clustered with Singapore Indians. The majority of Singapore Indians descended from south India, settling after Singapore became a trading center in the 19th century. The SS aims to whole-genome sequence 38, providing insights into genetic diversity of Indians in Singapore.
Researchers investigated the molecular basis of aminoglycoside susceptibility in Burkholderia pseudallei isolates from Thailand, specifically strains 708, 218, and 379. They found that strain 708 was intrinsically resistant to aminlycosides and macrolides due to the absence of amr transcripts, whereas strains 218 and 379 had reduced levels of amr. Serial passage on gentamicin yielded mutants of 218 and 379 that were resistant to other aminlycos and macrolides, but not 708. Transcript analysis revealed that resistance in 218 and 379 was due to upregulation of amr-opA expression by unknown mechanisms. PCR walking revealed that the am-opA operon was missing in 708, associated with a deletion of over 70 kb genetic material. Rescue of the amB region from a fosmid and sequencing showed a large deletions of 131 and 141 kb compared to K43 and 10. This deletion removed the amA operon and entire clusters for malleactin and cobal synthesis genes, as well as anaerobic arginine deiminase, type 1 fimbria, and secreted chitin. Whole genome and PCR confirmed absence of these genes in 708. Despite missing putative virulence genes, 708 was fully virulent in murine meloid model. Strain 708 may be a candidate for genetic manipulation and validates use of laboratory-constructed ΔA mutants.
Researchers studied the early differentiation of CD4 T helper cells into Th1 and Th2 states by examining the expression of transcription factors and cytokines in individual cells. Contrary to the expectation of mutually exclusive expression, they found co-expression of antagonistic transcription factors Tbet and Gata in cells at high levels, distinct from basal levels during priming. Cytokines were expressed in a small subpopulation of cells, independent of transcription factor expression in these cells. Cell-to-cell variation in cytokine expression during early differentiation was larger than in the fully differentiated state. Inhibiting cytok signaling led to mutual exclusion of antagonistic transcription factors, revealing an intracellular network overruled by extracellular signals. Results suggest CD4 cells acquire a mixed Th1/2 state early, instructed by extracellular cytokines. The interplay between extracellular and intracellular components in Th2 differentiation may be a strategy for mammalian cells to buffer against noisy cytokine expression.
In the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans, the PAQR-2 protein plays a crucial role in adapting to low temperatures by regulating fatty acid desaturation. PA-2 is homologous to the insulin-sensitizing adiponectin receptors in mammals and is essential for growth at 15°C, a low temperature that is usually acceptable for the organism. By screening for PA-2 suppressors, researchers identified genes involved in phosphatidcholine synthesis and fatty acid metabolism. They found that PA-2, phosphidcholines, and Δ-9 desaturases form a pathway that regulates the increase in unsaturated fatty acids necessary for membrane fluidity at low temperatures. This is supported by observations that PA-2 suppressors normalize saturated fatty acid levels and low concentrations of detergents that increase fluidity can rescue the PA-2 mutant. The study establishes a novel pathway connecting PA-2, phosphcholine, and regulation of FA desaturation to increase fluidity during cold adaptation. PA-2 increases unsaturation is essential for adaptation to 15°C in C. elegans.
Researchers have used cryo-electron microscopy to study the structure of human herpes simplex type-1 (HSV-1) virions, revealing a previously unknown feature at the portal vertex of the virus. The portal is connected to the viral tegument, a protein layer surrounding the capsid, and the viral membrane, suggesting it plays a role in genome release into the nucleus and virion architecture. This finding is consistent with evolutionary and structural links between herpesviruses and tailed bacteriophages, which share a common origin. Tailed bacterophages have a tail at the portal that mediates interactions with cellular components during the viral life cycle. Herpesviruses cause various diseases, including cold sores, chickenpox, congenital defects, and cancer. HSV-1 is a well-characterized virus with a 200 MD icosahedral capsid containing dsDNA, surrounded by tegument and glycoprotein lipid envelope. The lack of evidence for a tail in herpesvirions suggested it was unnecessary due to the eukotic cell environment. However, DNA delivery by herpesviruses may be analogous to tailed bacterophages. The HSV-1 particle varies in size, but the capsid has a constant diameter of 125 Å. The capsid features pentons, hexons, and triplexes.
Researchers investigated the effects of Schistosoma mansoni soluble egg antigen (SEA) and recombinant Omega-1 (r-1) on CD4+ T-lymphocyte responses and HIV-1 infection in vitro. They found that SEA, specifically through kappa-5, potently binds to DC-SIGN and blocks DC-S mediated HIV-1 transfection, while not affecting cis-infection. DCs exposed to SEA under Th2 conditions induced T-cells that were less susceptible to HIV-1 R5 infection compared to unexposed DCs, whereas HIV-1 X infection was unaffected. This was not observed in DCs exposed to SEA under Th1 or Th1/Th2 conditions. T-cells induced by SEA-exposed DCs showed reduced IFN-γ and MIP-1 production. Infection of T-cells with HIV-1 R was associated with downmodulation of CCR5 surface expression. Recombinant r-1 demonstrated similar functions to natural-1, inducing T-cells that were less susceptible to HIV-1 R5 infection but not X virus. This was associated with reduced IF-γ and M-1 expression and CCR expression. The study suggests that parasite antigens, specifically r-1, modulate HIV-1 infectivity and may influence disease course in coinfected individuals.
Researchers investigated the phenomenon of neural activity-induced shrinkage of the extracellular space (ECS) between neurons and astrocytes in grey and white matter. They found that neuronal stimulation causes a 30% shrinkage of the ECS. A dynamic model was developed to account for this phenomenon in wild-type and gene knockout individuals. The model suggests that neuronal release of potassium and uptake of sodium during stimulation, astrocyte uptake of potassium, sodium, and chloride, and passive channels of the Na/K pump, and osmotically transport of water through the astrocyte membrane are sufficient for ECS shrinkage. However, taking into account ECS and astrocy ion concentrations with neuronal stimulation, the actions of the Na+/Cl (NKCC) and Na/HCO (NBC) cotransporters are critical for achieving observed levels of ECS shrink. The model is sufficiently detailed to guide future experiments and pave the way for comprehensive astroglia-neuron models in normal and pathophysiological situations.
In Arabidopsis thalian, transposons and repetitive DNA elements can be detrimental to the organism if expressed, and their expression is suppressed by the establishment of repressive chromatin modifications. The siRNA-mediated transcriptional silencing pathway in Arabidopsis involves non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) produced by RNA Polymerase V (Pol) guiding ARGONAUTE (AGO) to chromatin and enzymes that establish repressive chrom modifications. However, it is unknown how chromatin enzymes are recruited to chrom. This study shows that SPTLTF1, a silencing factor and homolog of SPT elongation factors, binds chromatin at loci subject to transcription silencing. SPTLTF binding occurs downstream of Polymer V but independently of the presence of 24-nt siRNA. Additionally, SPTLTF and AGO are recruited to chrom in parallel and independently of each other. Using methylation restriction enzymes, binding of AGO and SPTLTF is required for DNA methylation and repressive histone modifications at several loci. The study proposes that coordinate binding of S and AGO creates a platform for direct or indirect recruitment of chrom modifying enzymes.
Researchers have investigated the role of the Rpo regulon in the tick phase of the Borrelia burgdorferi life cycle, specifically during transmission from tick to mammal. They found that Rpo-dependent gene expression is necessary for spirochete transmission by nymphs, as Rpo-deficient organisms are confined to the midgut and transform into round bodies during the later stages of the blood meal. Round body formation is reversible and appears to be due to reduced Coenzyme disulf reductase levels, which provides NAD for glycolysis. The study established the importance of the Rpo regul during the tick phase of the enoot cycle and demonstrated that spirotes default to an Rpo-independent program for round formation when transmission energetics are unfavorable. Rpo is induced during the nymph blood meal but not in larvae or unfed nymphs, indicating a Rpo ON/OFF regulation. Expression of Rpo-dependent genes in the tick is more complex than a simple ON/OFF regulation. The findings reveal a new role for RSB in physiological adaptations for tick-mamm transmission and a default survival mode (round formation) whenirotes unable to produce energy for dissemination.
Researchers investigated the relationship between gibberin (GA) and jasmonate (JA) hormones in regulating stamen development in Arabidopsis. They found that GA promotes the expression of MYB21, MY24, and MY57 genes, which are involved in stamen elongation. Loss-of-function of DELLA proteins, which are inhibited by GA, restored the expression of these MY genes and restored stamen growth in GA-deficient plants. The myb21 my24 my57 triple mutant exhibited a short stamen phenotype leading to male sterility. Genetic and molecular studies showed that GA suppresses DELs to mobilize the expression of the JA biosynthesis gene DAD, consistent with lower JA content in GA-deficient flower buds. The study established a hierarchical relationship between GA and JA, where GA promotes JA biosynthesis to control the expression of MY21, MY24, and MY57, a prerequisite for normal st development in Arabidopsis.
Researchers investigated the role of hypoxia inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) in modulating lifespan extension by dietary restriction (DR) in Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that H-1 deficiency resulted in extended lifespan, overlapping with inhibition of the RSK-1/S6 kinase, a component of the target of rapamycin (TOR) pathway. Using a modified DR method based on varying bacterial concentrations on agar plates, H-1 modulated longevity in a nutrient-dependent manner, with loss-of-function mutants extending lifespan under rich conditions but failing to show extension under DR. Conversely, a mutation in egl-9, increasing H- activity, diminished lifespan under DR, which was rescued by tissue-specific expression in neurons and muscles. Increased lifespan by H-1 was dependent on the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress regulator inos-requiring protein-1 (IRE-1) and associated with lower ER stress. The study suggests a tissue-specific role for H- in lifespan extension by the IRE-ER pathway.
Researchers have investigated how human keratinocytes, a type of skin cell, transition between two states: differentiation and migration. They found that when keratinocytes differentiate or migrate, they form unique enhancers and super-enhancers that are specific to each state. These super-enhancers are linked to genes that confer functions associated with the respective state and are enriched with disease variants. GR3, a transcription factor that promotes differentiation and migration, binds to super-enh in differentiating keratinocytes and to promoters in migrating keratinocytes, repressing expression of migration inhibitors. GR3 is located in super-enh and binds to regulate them, also repressing formation of progenitor and non-keratin super in differentiating keratin. Chromatin rearrangements of GR3 binding and enhancers regulate irreversible commitment of progenitor keratin to differentiation and reversible transition to migration.
Researchers investigated the co-evolution of endogenous and exogenous retroviruses in sheep, using the species as a model. Endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) are remnants of ancient retroviral infections transmitted vertically from generation to generation, and some are hypothesized to be used by the host as restriction factors to block pathogenic retroviral infections. The study isolated and characterized the evolutionary history and virology of 27 endogenous sheep retroviruses (enJSRVs), which have been in the host genome for 5-7 million years.
