Two JSRVs, JS56 and JS-20, acquired a defective gag protein resulting in a dominant phenotype able to block replication of related exogenous retroviruses, and became fixed in the genome before sheep domestication (9,000 years ago). A JS escaping dominant JS has emerged recently, likely in the last 200 years. The study reveals sequential events indicative of antagonism between endogenous and exogenous retroviruses. Data suggest ERs have been used by the host to fight retroiral infections. The dominant proviruses may have been selected to defend against ERs colonizing the genome rather than pathogenic exogenous retroviruses. Phylogenetic analysis of JSs and exogenous JS/ENT divided retrovir into two clades, JS-A and JS-B.
Researchers evaluated the performance of real-time PCR (polymerase chain reaction) for diagnosing schistosomiasis, a parasitic infection caused by Schistosoma mansoni and Schistoma haematobium. Current diagnosis relies on microscopic detection of eggs in stool or urine and serological assays, but these methods have low sensitivity. The study aimed to assess two in-house real-time Schos PCRs targeting S. mansoni and S. haematob in stool, urine, and serum samples as tools for diagnosing active infections and monitoring treatment efficacy. 412 samples (124 urine, 86 stool, 8 biopsies, 194) from suspected schistosiasis patients before antiparasitic treatment were analyzed. Results were compared to microscopic and serological assays (ELISA, HA, and WB). Compared to microscopy, PCRs increased sensitivity from 4.5% to 10.5% and 33.7 to 48.8% for S. in urine and S. stools, respectively. Serum PCR sensitivity was 72.7% and 94.1 in patients with positive microscopy. Specificity was 98.9. After treatment, PCR positivity declined from 93.8 at 30 to 8.3 at 360, while antibodies remained positive 1 year. Schos PC outperformed microscopy on stools and urine and could be part of reference methods with WB-based serology, a gold standard for diagnosis. When serology is positive and microscopy negative, PC provides information for further exploration.
Researchers have successfully applied machine learning to estimate the conformational energies of complex molecules, specifically the natural product Archazolid A, a potent inhibitor of vacuolar-type ATPase from myxobacterium Archium gephy. They used Gaussian process regression, a non-parametric machine learning method, to model the relationship between molecular structure and quantum mechanical properties. A simple molecular representation was used, sensitive to structural variations in geometries, enabling correlations between conformations and computed energy values at the density functional theory level. This approach is similar to cheminformatics, where experimentally determined properties are estimated. Machine learning has been used in various quantum mechanics contexts, including density theory, prediction of atomization energies, and transition states. Estimators of potential surfaces have been pursued since the 1990s using artificial networks. The study integrated machine learning with molecular dynamics, providing access to long simulations of challenging systems. A model was trained to capture the relationship between Archolid conformations and DFT energies. Conformations were encoded using a matrix based on nuclear charges and interatomic distances. Semi-empirical simulations were carried out with VAMP using the AM Hamilton. A structure of Archolid was modeled using NMR constraints, then minimized and refined to match the conformation of N-derived Archolid structure. The model achieved mean absolute errors of less than 1 kcal/mol for energies of relaxed conformations. This demonstrates machine learning can be developed for structurally complex, pharmaceutically relevant compounds, enabling speed in simulations of larger structures.
Researchers have developed a non-invasive method to detect Ebola virus antibodies in great ape feces, providing insight into wild ape Ebola infections and surveillance. This approach allows for identifying immunologically naïve populations at-risk for vaccination and tracking vaccine efficacy. The study found 10% of gorillas in the Democratic Republic of Congo had Ebola antibodies, indicating exposure or infection is not uniformly lethal in this species. Evidence of antibodies was also found in gorillas previously thought to be unexposed, protected by geographical barriers of transmission. This method will contribute to protecting apes from future Ebola infections by detecting early exposure, identifying at-risk populations, and tracking vaccine efficacy. Since human Ebola is linked to contact with infected carcasses, identifying ape outbreaks impacts public health in local communities where case-fatality rates reach 88%. The study is the first to detect Ebola antibodies in wild ape fecal samples, relevant for ape management and survival. Strategies to protect apes against Ebola are being explored, including vaccination, as vaccines have shown to protect monkeys from disease.
Researchers have identified a novel type III effector protein, Xop, from the plant pathogen Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicator, which exhibits E3 ubiquitin ligase activity in vitro and in planta, inducing plant cell death and subverting plant immunity. The E3 ligase activity is associated with the C-terminal region of Xop, specifically interacting with E2 ubiquitin conjugating enzymes and mediating K11-linked polyubiquitin formation. The crystal structure of the Xop C-terminal domain revealed a novel fold, termed XL-box, not present in any characterized E3 ligases. Mutation of amino acids in the XL-box disrupts E ligase activity and prevents Xop-induced cell death. The structure of the N-terminal of Xop confirmed a leucine-rich repeat (LRR) domain, potentially serving as a protein-protein module for ubiquination recognition. While E ligase is required for plant death, suppression of PAMP responses solely depends on N-terminal RR. The unique fold of E ubiquitin ligase within Xanthas Xop is unprecedented, highlighting variation in bacterial effectors mimicking eukary-specific activity.
Researchers studied the role of circulating follicular helper T cells (cTfh) in early HIV infection and the impact of antiretroviral treatment (ART) on T and B cell function in a cohort of 254 HIV-infected individuals in stages 1, 2, and 3. They found impaired cT cell function in stage 3 compared to 1/2, with lower B cell survival and IgG secretion, and increased IL-10 and TNF-α. Elevated viral load in stage 3 correlated with decreased cT-mediated B cell Ig production, indicating a role for viremia in cfh impairment and humoral response. Phenotypic perturbations were observed in the B compartment, with decreased resting cells in 3 compared to 1/2, coinciding with viremia. Cocultures suggested intrinsic B defects contributed to impaired response at lower levels. cfh B responses were altered in 3 compared 1/2, with increased inflammation and reduced memory cells. Data suggest early ART for HIV-infected individuals could prevent dysregulation while preserving cfh function and cell memory.
Researchers have developed a miniaturized screen for a Schistosoma mansoni serergic protein-coupled receptor (Sm5-HT) to identify novel parasite-selective inhibitors for the treatment of schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease affecting 200 million people worldwide. Current therapy relies on a single drug, praziquantel, with suboptimal features, necessitating next-generation anthelmintics. The study pharmacologically profiled Sm-HT as a modulator of praziquel efficacy in a miniaturized assay with high-content screening, employing a luciferase biosensor sensitive to cellular AMP levels. Data showed divergent pharmacological signature between paras serergic receptor and closest human homolog (5-HT7), supporting parasitic pharmacores optimization. New ligands and series with potency and selectivity for Sm-HT over 5-HT7 were identified in vitro and validated in vivo against schosomules and adult worms. Sm-HT displayed irreversible inactivation, a phenomenon at 5-HT, enhancing its appeal as a target for anthint design. The study underscores feasibility of flatworm GPCRs in high-throughput screening to resolve classes of modulators and Sm-HT as chemotherapeutic node for next-generation anthelmics.
During gastrulation, the formation of the three primary germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) is crucial for the development of the metazoan body. In some organisms, such as flies, fish, and amphibians, the ectodermesoderm boundary not only separates the layers but also serves as a substrate for mesoderm migration, requiring compatibility with cell attachment and detachment. Research has shown that localized contact-induced detachment at the boundary is key to ectodermeserm segregation. Cells alternate between adhesion and detachment, mediated by Ephrin/Eph signaling. Multiple Ephrin ligands and Eph receptors are expressed on each side of the boundary, with separation dependent on forward signaling in both directions, involving redundant ligands and receptors and activation of Rac and Rho. This mechanism differs from simple adhesion-based germ layer formation, involving localized responses to signals at the boundary and an attachment/detachment cycle allowing cell migration across a substrate.
Researchers analyzed blood samples from 83 children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and 76 age-matched neurotypical peers to identify biochemical markers of the disorder. Discriminant analysis correctly classified 96.1% of neurotypical participants and 97.6% of ASD participants. Additionally, partial least squares regression predicted adaptive behavior, measured by the Vineland Adaptive Composite score, using 5 metabolites of the folate-dependent one-carbon metabolism pathway with an R2 of 0.45 after cross-validation. This level of accuracy exceeds previous approaches in the field, indicating strong correlation between metabolites and ASD diagnosis. The study used advanced statistical tools to examine metabolite data from 3-10 year olds with ASD, neurotypical, and sibling participants. Oxidative stress was defined by DSM-IV, ADOS, and CARS score >30. Folate metabolism metabolites from 83,47,76, and 47 ASD, sibling, sibling, and age-matched neurotyp children were used for classification. 55 ASD participants had Vineland scores for regression (46-106). The Vin Adaptive Composite evaluates adaptive skills through semi-structured caregiver interview. Multivariate analysis provided unprecedented classification separating ASD and neurotyp cohorts based solely on biochemical data. Existing studies reported differences in mean metabol levels, but not designed for classification and failed to classify. Incorporating multiple measurements increased separability and predicted severity.
Researchers applied Bayesian geostatistical modeling to analyze the incidence of cutaneous and visceral leishmanias in Brazil from 2001-2010, focusing on spatial and temporal patterns. They used integrated Laplace approximations for fast Bayesian inference and variable selection to identify climatic, environmental, and socioeconomic predictors. Results showed precipitation and socioeconomic factors were significant for both types of leishiasis. Predicted cases for 2010 were 30,189 (SD: 7,676) for cutaneous and 4,889 (SD:288) for visceral leishias. Maps identified Minas Gerais and Para as high-risk states for visceral and cutaneous leishias, respectively. High-resolution maps pinpointed areas for targeted control efforts to reduce incidence. 

The study used Bayesian geostat models on available data from Brazil's Ministry of Health, employing variable selection to identify environmental and socioeconomic predictors. Previous analyses mapped leishias incidence at state level, but rarely used statistical approaches accounting for spatio-temporal correlations. This study analyzed data from 2001-201, employing geostat negative binomial models via INLA, predicting diseases using climatic, environmental, and socioeconomic covariates. High-resolution maps for leishias and estimated infected people at state level. The Ministry of Health reported country-wide maps without Bayesian approaches. Al et al. (2012) provided worldwide leish estimates and Brazil maps, aggregated by state. This study provided country-based maps for cutaneous and visceral leishias at 88km resolution, exploring spatial processes, risk, and high areas.
A study of 647 adults and 881 children with deng admitted to a hospital in Vietnam found significant differences in clinical and laboratory features between the two age groups. Adults experienced more severe thrombocytopenia and bleeding manifestations, while children had more severe vascular leakage and shock. Thrombocytopenia was associated with secondary infection and serotype, but age had a smaller effect. Adults had lower platelet counts than children, both during and after recovery. The study suggests age-dependent physiological differences contribute to the pattern of complications seen with deng infection.
Researchers have identified a novel mutation in the CCR5 gene in sooty mangabeys (SM) that results in a truncated protein that is not expressed on the cell surface and does not support SIV entry in vitro. This mutation is present in 26% of a large SM colony, along with a 3% for a C5Δ24 allele that also abrogates surface expression. 8% of animals are homozygous for C5 and 41% are heterozygous. The mutation is also found in wild SM in West Africa. CD8 and CD4 T cells display a gradient of C5 expression across genotype, highly significant for CD8 cells. The prevalence of SIVm infection is not significantly different in animals lacking C5 compared to heterozygous and homozygous wild-type. Animals lacking C5 have robust viral loads, modestly lower than wild-type. SIVm isolates infect homozyg mutant and wild PBMC in C5-independent manner in vitro and Envs from C-null and wild-type animals use CX6, G15, and G1 in addition to C5 in transfected cells. This indicates SIVm relies on C-independent pathways in SM homozy for C5 and alternative use in SM with C5 wild is uncertain, suggesting SIV tropism and cell targeting in vivo is defined by distribution and use of pathways in addition to C5. SIV entry through alternative in vivo raises possibility of C-negative cells may be more expendable than C+ and enable virus to replicate without disease in face restricted C expression in SM and other natural species.
Researchers have investigated the role of the transcription factor MEF2 in the development of tumors, specifically in leiomyosarcomas (LMS), a rare soft tissue cancer. They found that MEF can have both pro-oncancerous and tumor-suppressing activities, depending on its interaction with coactivators or co-repressors. MEF influences histone modifications, such as H3 methylation and H3 acetylation, which are critical for gene activation and repression. Class II HDs, a type of histone deacetylase, are overexpressed in 22% of L, where high levels of MEF, HD4, and HD9 inversely correlate with overall survival. Knockout of HD9 suppresses the transformed phenotype of L cells by restoring transcription of MEF-target loci. HD9 also demethylates H3me at promoters of M-target genes. Class II HDs do not bind regulatory elements bound by M2. M-targets can be both transcribed and repressed, but are poised in chromatin signature. The study suggests class II HD and HD9 as druggable targets for therapeutic intervention in L.
Researchers have used a combination of protein docking, molecular simulation, and cryo-electron microscopy to study the structure of hydrophobin films composed of two class II hydrophobins, HFBI and HFB, produced by Trichoderma rei. The results suggest a unit cell composed of six proteins with P6 symmetry, but experimental results show P3 symmetry with a unit size of 56 Å. Computational simulations indicate an alternate structure with P3 symmetry and a smaller unit size. A Monte Carlo simulation of a spin model representing the hydroobin film shows the alternate structure may play a role in increasing the rate of surface coverage by hydroob films, indicating a mechanism of significance to both biology and nanotechnology. The study used cryo-EM, protein-protein docking, and molecular dynamics to obtain atomic resolution of assembled hydroob films at air-water interface. The structures of HF and HFB of T. rei were studied, with high resolution structures available. The experimentally observed unit size of 2-D crystal of hydroob matches lattice of close-packed hexagonal arrangement of proteins, hosting seven molecules, but seen as uniform sheet by AFM. Macroscopic properties of hydroob films arise from cooperative stabilisation of film from interactions between interlocking proteins in surface network. Interfac assemblies of hydroob have industrial applications and biological significance.
Researchers have identified and characterized the threonine tRNA synthetase (Thr) enzyme in Leishmania donovani, a protozoan parasite causing visceral leishmaniasis. Recombinant Thr (rThr) was expressed in E. coli and purified, and its kinetic parameters were determined. Immunofluorescence analysis showed that Thr is localized in the cytosol and mitochondria. Heterozygous mutants of Thr were generated in Leish promastigotes, which showed a restrictive growth phenotype and attenuated infectivity, and were more susceptible to the Thr inhibitor borid. Several attempts to obtain Thr homozyg null mutants were unsuccessful, indicating its essentiality for Leish survival. Borid showed a strong affinity for Thr (KD: 0.04 μM) and inhibited aminoacylation activity (IC50:0.06 μM) and promastig (IC:21M) stage parasites. The study demonstrates Thr's potential as a target for antileman drug discovery. The enzyme's activity was 1.7 min-1, similar to Trypanosoma brucei, and Km 1.2 ± 0.23 μM for tRNThr. Immunofluores analysis showed cytosolic localization. Bioinformatic analysis predicted cytos localization. Gene knockdown of Thr in Trypanosoma bruce showed growth and phenotypic changes, suggesting potential for drug targeting. This is the first characterization of Thr from Leish donani, with catalytic efficiency similar to Trypanosoma bruce.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) RNA is recognized as non-self by the innate immune receptor RIG-I through the presence of a 5'-phosphate (5-pp) on viral RNA associated with a 3' poly-UUC tract. The study defines the HCV pathogen-associated molecular pattern (PAMP) and criteria for R-I non-discrimination of HCV by examining RNA-function attributes that impart AMP to the poly-UUC tract. A 34 nucleotide polyuridine core of the sequence is essential for R-I activation, and interspersed ribosine nucleotides between poly sequences in RNA are required for optimal R-I induction. 5-pp poly-U RNA variants stimulate R-I efficiently in vitro and interaction with the repressor and helicase domains of R-I is required for signaling. Appended to 5-pp RNA lacking AMP activity, the-UUC core confers non-recognition of RNA and innate signaling by R-I. Importantly, HCV-U variants strongly activated R-I triggered potent anti-H responses in vitro and hepatic immune responses in vivo using a mouse model. The study defines a multi-mot P signature of non-recognition by-I that incorporates 5-pp with polyuridine composition and length. This HAMP drives R-I signaling to induce the immune response to infection.
Researchers investigated the role of eosinophils in promoting the growth of Trichinella spiralis larvae in skeletal muscle tissue. They found that IL-4 and eosophils are necessary for normal larval growth and that eosophils from IL-4 competent mice are sufficient to support growth. The eosophil effect operates in the absence of adaptive immunity. Following invasion by larvae, host gene expression in skeletal muscle was compatible with a regenerative response and shift in source of energy in infected tissue. The presence of eosoph suppressed local inflammation and influenced nutrient homeostasis in muscle. Redistribution of glucose transporter 4 (GLUT4) and phosphorylation of Akt were observed in cells, consistent with enhancement of glucose and glycogen storage by larvae. The data suggest a mechanism in which eosoph promote larval growth by IL-4 dependent that limits interferon-driven responses that alter nutrient in muscle. 

Eosin-derived IL-4 activates GLUT pathway and translocation in infected cells, supporting a mechanism that enhances glucose uptake in host cells. This pathway requires further experimentation to confirm. Alternatively, glucose can be regulated by IL-4 indirectly. Results are consistent with a mechanism in which larval growth is supported when eosoph or eosoph-derived IL limits STAT signaling that inhibits glucose and lipid metabolism in muscle. Gene knockouts of eosoph or cells will clarify the mechanism. Eos derived from IL-4 mice were necessary for lar growth. Genome profiling identified genes altered in muscle during infection coinciding with eosoph requirement. Rag- mice were used to limit infiltrating cells in tissue. Observations support a model in which eosoph contribute IL- dependent regeneration in response to injury caused by NBL. Lar growth was supported when eosoph restored by transfer from IL or STAT- mice. Eos express IL receptor and may develop in presence IL to produce mediators that support growth. Lar growth not affected by absence I2. Transfer IL- eos failed to improve growth in mice.
A recent genome-wide analysis of DNA replication kinetics in human cells contradicts the view that mammalian chromosomes consist of megabase domains of coordinated origin firing separated by large originless regions. In HeLa cells, replication origins are spaced approximately 40 kilobases apart and fire in clusters, with increasing synchrony during S phase, while replication velocity remains constant at 0.7-2 kilobases per minute. A multi-scale analysis of genome-wide timing shows a broad distribution of replication gradients with no regions larger than 100 kilobases replicating at less than 2 kilobases per minute. HeLa cells lack large regions of unidirectional fork progression. Temporal regions are replicated by sequential activation of origins at an increasing rate during S, and timing is set by the delay and spacing between origin firings rather than velocity. Activation of internal origins in a temporal region is demonstrated by DNA combing of the IGH locus in He cells. Analysis of origin maps in He cells and published timing DNA comb data in other cell types corroborate findings, except embryonic cells where regions of unid fork seem more abundant.
Researchers investigated how the "temporal stability" or "slown" approach, which enables the nervous system to recognize objects despite changes in contextual variables such as perspective or lighting, can be implemented within biologically realistic learning rules. They showed that slow feature analysis, an algorithm based on slown, can be implemented in continuous neurons by a modified Hebbian learning rule, linking it to the trace rule, another slown learning implementation. Analytically, for Poisson neurons, slown learning can be implemented by spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) with a specific window. Studying STDP dynamics, they found that the learning outcome is governed by the convolution of the window with the postsynaptic potential, not the window alone. They derived STDP windows implementing slow analysis and the trace rule, compatible with physiological data in shape and timescale. Analysis showed the window can be split into reversible and irreversible components sensitive to input statistics. Irreversible statistics generate oscillatory weight dynamics. The study suggests STDP's functional role in neurons. 

In a continuous model, modified Hebb learning enables neurons to learn slown combination of inputs. This links SFA to the trace rule, another slown implementation. For a spiking neuron, Poisson, STDP can implement slown. A linear neuron's ensemble-averaged behavior can be reproduced by STDP. The outcome is governed by the convolution of the window with EP, relevant for ST interpretations. The window realizing SFA can be calculated analytically. Physiologically plausible parameters lead to a window in agreement with findings. A new interpretation of STDP as slown compensating neuronal filters is proposed.
Researchers have identified a new mechanism of resistance to chemotherapy in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCL) called cooperative adaptation to therapy (CAT), where cancer cells induce resistant phenotypes in neighboring cells exposed to therapy. Using a CRISPR/Cas toolkit, they engineered phenotypically diverse NSCL cells with mutations in Dicer, a type III cytoplasmic endonuclease involved in non-coding RNA genesis. In a three-dimensional growth dynamics, fluorescently-labeled mutant and wild-type cells were cultured individually or co-cultured under stimulated or unstimulated drug conditions. Mathematical modeling and flow cytometry characterized growth patterns of mono and co-cultures, revealing that combination of WT and mutants co-cult allowed beneficial growth in drug-sensitive cells despite pressure via cooperative game-theoretic change in fitness. An ex vivo human tumor model predicted clinical response to drug sensitivity and morphological heterogeneity correlated with prognostic failure of multiple-approved and off-label drugs in NSCL patient samples. This study presents a paradox in drug resistance implicating non-genetic cooperation among cells to thwart pressure, suggesting profiling druggable targets alone may be insufficient for effective therapy.
A cross-sectional seropreval study was conducted in the Mbeya region, South Tanzania, to estimate the serrevalence of IgG antibodies against Spotted Group (SFG) ricketiae and assess socioeconomic and environmental risk factors. A total of 1,228 persons above 5 years old were randomly selected from nine communities, stratified by age, altitude, and ownership of domestic mammals. Serology (indirect immunofluorescence) was performed at a dilution 1:64. SFG-serositivity in the cohort was 67.9% (range 42.8-91.4%). Multivariable analysis revealed associations with age (prevalence ratio per 10 years 1.08; 95 CI 1.06-1.10), warmer temperatures (per °C 1.38; 1.11-1.71), male gender (1.08;1-1.16), and low density (per 1,000/km² 0.96 0.94-0.99). At higher elevations, cattle density was associated with higher servalence. SFG ricketial seems common in rural population of Mb Region, spread limited by temperature and elevation. Examination of S contribution to febrile illnesses warranted in prospective study to estimate disease burden and causative pathogens.
Researchers have identified a crucial role for the monounsaturated fatty acid oleate in the innate immune response of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. Through an RNA screen of regulators of immune genes, they found two stoyl-CoA desaturases that synthesize oleate in C. elegans. The synthesis of oleate is necessary for the pathogen induction of immune genes, and C. elegans deficient in ole production are hypersusceptible to infection with diverse pathogens, which can be rescued by the addition of exogenous ole. However, ole is not sufficient to drive immune activation. This study adds to the health-promoting effects of monouns fatty acids and suggests a link between nutrient metabolism and susceptibility to bacterial infection. The researchers also found that ole and polyunsaturated fatty acids, γ-linolenic acid and stearic acid, have distinct effects on immune activation and resistance to infection. C elegans deficient in ole production are more susceptible to killing by pathogens Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Escherichia faalis, and Staphylococcus marces in a manner dependent on ole, which is the most abundant fatty acid in C. elegans. The effect of ole on immune activation is not through metabolism to γinolenic and stearic acid, as shown by path susceptibility and immune transcription profile of fat-2 mutants. Supplementation of exogenous ole rescued the immune defect in fat-6 RNAi animals in a dose-dependent manner. The study indicates ole and polyunsaturated fatty acids affect immune expression and pathogen resistance by different mechanisms.
Researchers have identified a novel pyrimidine compound, PC, which selectively inhibits the growth of a subgroup of bacterial species, including nosocomial pathogens, by targeting the guanine ribwitch, a regulatory element involved in purine metabolism. Guanine ribwitches modulate gene expression in response to specific metabolite binding and stabilize 5'-untranslated mRNA, causing transcription attenuation of the downstream reading frame. The compound PC shows bactericidal activity only when the guA, a gene for GMP synthase, is under the control of the ribwitch. Among tested strains, several clinical exhibiting multiple drug resistance were inhibited, suggesting PC targets a different metabolic pathway. A mouse model demonstrated a direct correlation between PC administration and reduction of Staphylococcus aureus infection in mammary glands. This work establishes the possibility of using existing knowledge to design guanine ribwitch-targeting antibiotics as selective antimicrobial compounds. Guanine ribwitches are part of the purine class, also comprising adenine and 2-deoxyguanine, and regulate transcription at high guanine concentration in Bacillus subtilis. The aptamer is organized around a three-way connecting helices, with a critical nucleotide involved in Watson-Crick base interaction with the ligand. Break group used purine derivatives to target guwitch and found molecules inhibited growth, with one repressing expression of a guwitch-controlled gene.
Researchers investigated how gaze influences the construction of mental space during navigation in primates by examining behavior, visual exploration, and hippocampal activity in macaque monkeys navigating a virtual reality maze for a reward. Cells sensitive to one or more variables like direction, point of gaze, or task fired at the sight and in anticipation of a landmark in a viewpoint-dependent manner, encoding the animal's situation within a set of actions leading to the goal. Hippocampal activity was best fit by a fine-grained space comprising current position, view, and context. The findings indicate that primate cells embody multidimensional task-situated knowledge to the target of gaze, supporting self-awareness in space construction. This type of coding is ubiquitous in mammals, consistent with encoding task-related hippocal neurons in rodents. 

The study probed the nature of hippocal coding in a goal-oriented task, separating goal and landmarks, and examined cells for position, direction, and target gaze. The goal setting enabled examining task-related context modulated cells. Previous primates, including humans, showed hippocal encoded spatial views, place, or a mixture of place and view. In a controlled VR setting, findings show hippocal display fine tuning preferentially one landmark being viewed and self-position relative to landmark. The results give a comprehensive analysis of variables controlling hippocal cells, bridging rodent and primate studies in real and virtual environments. Hippocamp cells code target gaze in informed, embedding-position respect elements and context. Data suggest primate place cells, compared rodents, expressed activity to point gaze with other navigation variables, position, and visual elements instants planning.
Researchers conducted a spatial analysis of gene expression patterns at the midbrain boundary (MHB) in mice to understand the regulatory interactions between transcription and secreted factors involved in its development. They employed Boolean logic minimization of functions to predict the interplay of regulatory interactions and found that fibroblast growth factor 8 (Fgf8) maintains, rather than induces, wingless 1 (Wnt) expression. Experiments using anterior neural tube explants confirmed that F8 maintains, but does not induce ectopic Wnt expression. The study constructed a regulatory network of key transcription and secret factors at the HB and analyzed Boolean differential equation and reaction-diffusion models to confirm its ability to explain the maintenance of the HB and expression patterns under wild-type and knockout conditions. The research demonstrates that spatial expression patterns can provide information about regulatory networks, revealing the maintenance of the HB on a systems level.
Theileria annulata, an apicomplex parasite, infects host cells by inducing uncontrolled proliferation and clonal expansion of the parasitized population. After sporozoite entry, the host cell membrane dissolves and an array of host microtubules (MTs) surrounds the parasite, which transforms into a schizont. The schizont remains tethered to host MTs during mitosis and cytokinesis, engaging the cell's astral and central MTs for distribution between daughter cells. The mechanism of schizont stabilizing host MTs is unknown. MT minus ends are anchored at the organizing center, while plus ends explore cellular space, switching between growth and shrinkage phases (dynamic instability). The schizont recruits end-binding protein 1 (EB1), a key regulator of host MT dynamics, by interacting with T. annata p104, a polymorphic antigen on the schizont surface. EB binding depends on a consensus SIP motif in p104's disordered C-terminal region. Interaction with host EB is cell cycle-regulated. This is the first description of a pathogen-encoded protein interacting with EB via a SIP motif. Theiler schizont taps into the host cytoskeleton network, interaction with host MT during mitosis and cytokinesis crucial for persistence. EB facilitates initial interaction of MT plus ends with schizont, but additional molecules required for stabilization. Preliminary observations suggest host CL1, a MT-stabilizing protein, contributes. EB association with sch surface not accompanied by loss of MT, sch remains associated with host MT throughout mitosis.
In yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, broken replication forks are normally repaired via homologous recombination or break-induced replication (BIR). A mutation in the replicase Cdc9 gene results in a population of cells with persistent DNA damage, likely due to broken forks, constitutively activating the DNA checkpoint and leading to longer telomeres. Telomere length requires functional telomerase, the DNA signaling cascade Mec1-Rad-Rad53, and BIR pathway components Rad51, Rad52, 32, and P1. The Mec-R53 phosphorylation of P1, necessary for inhibiting telomerase at double strand breaks, is also important for P1's role in BIR and telom elongation in c9 cells. Two other mutants, c44 and r3, similar to c9, have long telomeres dependent on P1 phosphorylation. A genome-wide screens for S cerevisiae deletions causing telom length or shortening found genes relevant to metabolism, replication, repair, and chromatin. We propose that like c9, telom effects may result from constitutive DNA damage generation. DNA-induced P1 phosphorylation promotes telom-stabilizing tel extension while repressing deleterious de novo telom events at breaks, funneling DNA into genome-preserving pathways.
Researchers investigated the use of luciferase immunoprecitation systems (LIPS) as a rapid, specific, and standardized assay for diagnosing Onchocerca volulus infection. Four recombinantly produced Onocerca volulus antigens (OvAR-1, API-1, Ov-MS-1, and OvPI-1) were tested on a large cohort of sera from uninfected controls and patients with proven parasitic infections, including Onoc volulus, Wucher bancrofti, Loa loa, Strongloides stercis, and other cross-reactive infections. Antibody responses to the four antigens allowed unequivocal differentiation between infected and uninfected sera with 100% sensitivity and 100 specificity. Analysis of antibody titers to each antigen in infected sera revealed they were markedly different and did not correlate with each other. Compared to infected, patients with W, L, S, and other conditions had lower geometric antibody titers to each antigen. A mixture of the four antigens in standard or 15-minute IPS showed 100% sensitivity and specificity distinguishing infected from unected sera. IPS had best performance with 76, 84, and 93 for distinguishing from W, L, and S-infected sera. The multi-antigen IPS can be a rapid, high-throughput tool for diagnosing individual infections and sensitive point-of-care for early detection recrudescence in areas control and mapping new transmission.
A 54-month iron-folic acid supplementation and deworming program was implemented in a rural area of northern Vietnam to evaluate its effectiveness in reducing anemia, iron deficiency anemia, and soil-transmitted infections in women of reproductive age. The study used a prospective cohort design and enrolled 389 participants prior to the intervention. After 54 months, 76% of participants were taking ironolic acid supplements and 95% had received deworming treatment. Hemoglobin levels rose from 122 g/L to 131/L and anemia prevalence fell from 38% to 18, with significant differences between ethnic groups. Iron deficiency decreased from 23% to 8 and iron deficiency anemia from 4%. Hookworm infection reduced from 76 to 11 and moderate or heavy infestation of soil-transmitted helth to less than 1%. The study found that population-based interventions can efficiently reduce anemia and eliminate iron deficiency anemia and moderate to heavy soil helth infections below public health concern levels.
Researchers have identified a novel immune evasion mechanism used by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), a type of herpesvirus, to avoid detection by the immune system. The virus encodes a protein called gp150, which is heavily glycosylated and forms a shield on the surface of infected cells. This shield impedes the presentation of antigens to immune cells, including HLA class I, H class II, and CD1 molecules. The mechanism does not involve degradation of antigen-presenting molecules nor requires the cytoplasmic tail of gp150. EBV gp150 is expressed during the late phase of replication, when most antigens are produced that could activate T and iKT cells. Infection with a gp-null mutant EBV showed rescued levels of antigen presentation by HLA I, H II, and CD, indicating an important role for iKT cells in fighting EBV. The study supports the notion that herpesviruses use diverse ways to evade not only T but also iKT immunity. EB gp150 prolongs the lifespan of viral offspring at the most vulnerable stage of the life cycle.
Researchers have identified a conserved actin binding domain in the translocated actin recruiting protein (Tarp) among pathogenic chlamydial species, which is essential for bacterial invasion of host cells. A peptide antibody specific to the actin binding domain inhibited actin polymerization in vitro and entry of Chlamydia trachomatis in vivo. Sequence analysis of Tarp orthologs from various chlamial species revealed multiple putative actin binding sites. GSTarp fusions from multiple chlamial species were examined for their ability to bind and nucleate actin, showing variable numbers of actin sites and promoted actin nucleation in vitro. A peptide antibody to the actin domain prevented T mediated actin nucleation and reduced host susceptibility to chlamial infection when delivered into cells. Some chlamial strains contain multiple actin domains on a single polypeptide, potentially utilizing a hybrid mechanism of actin nucleation involving multiple monomers and oligomerization by upstream proline domain. T mediated actin polymerization is conserved among diverse chlamial species, suggesting the actin domain plays a role in bacterial entry. All pathogenic chlamial strains harbor T effector, with divergent protein sequence but conserved actin domain. Chydia trachatis elementary bodies synthesize T effector, tyrosine phosphorylated upon translocation to host cytos, implicated in act recruitment at chlamial attachment site. T polymerizes act independently host factors vitro, distinct from eukaryotic nucleators.
Researchers have developed a new technique called formalin-ethylate sedimentation-digestion (F-SD) to precisely quantify Schistosoma japonicum eggs in bovine feces. This method is crucial for determining the prevalence and intensity of the parasite in mammalian hosts, such as water buffaloes, which contribute to 75% of human transmission in the People's Republic of China. The F-SD technique involves filtration, sedimentation, potassium hydroxide digestion, and centrifugation steps prior to microscopy. It removes 70% of debris from fecal samples, making it easier to visualize S. japon eggs and accurately estimate infection in boines and other ruminant hosts. The method is as effective as real-time PCR for determining schosome prevalence in boines but less costly to implement. It can be a valuable tool for surveillance in areas with low to high infection intensity or suspected schosiasis elimination.
Mutations in the genes encoding cartilage protein (CRTAP) and proly 3-hydroxylase 1 (P3H) encoded by LEP1 were first identified as causes of recessive osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). These proteins, together with cyclophilin (encoded PPI), form a complex that 3-hydroxylates a proline on the α1(I) chain (Pro986) and has cis-trans isomerase Pase activity for proper collagen folding. Recent data suggest proly 3-hydrolation of Pro is not required for collagen stability, but absence of this post-transl modification disrupts protein interactions for proper folding and leads to collagen overmodification. PH and CRTAP stabilize each other, and absence of one results in degradation of the other. Hypomorphic or loss of function of either gene causes loss of the complex and associated functions. The contribution of this complex's 3-hydrolysis versus Pase and chaperone activities to OI phenotype is unknown. To distinguish, knock-in mice were generated carrying a single amino substitution in the catalytic site of PH (Lep1H662). This abolished PH activity but retained ability to form complex with CRT and chaper function. Knock mice showed absence proly 3-hydrolation at Pro of α(I) and α(II) chains but no overmodification at other residues. They were normal in appearance, no growth defects and cartilage plate histology but decreased trabecular bone mass. This model recapitulates elements of O bone but not cartilage phenotypes caused loss proly 3-hydrolation complex. Observations suggest differential consequences due selective inactivation PH hydroxylase versus ablation proly 3-hydro complex.
Researchers have discovered that the P-element, a selfish genetic element, has invaded the Drosophila simul species, causing hybrid dysgenesis, a syndrome of abnormal phenotypes including sterility, similar to its invasion of Drosila melanogaster. A survey of 181 D simul strains found 20% induce dysgenesis. Genomic and transcript data show the dys-inducing phenotype is associated with the P-element invasion. The invasion occurred rapidly and simultaneously in regions, with strains containing P-elements rare in 2006 and common by 201. Strains from the latter phase of invasion have adapted to suppress the P-element's effects, evidenced by resistance to the dys phenotype. A hybridgenesis system was identified in D simul using next generation sequencing and PCR, with the P-element associated with the dys phenotype and spread across Europe, Africa, and America. Compared to D melanaster, the spread in simul is surprisingly fast. Both simul and melanaster have evolved to suppress the dys phenotype by the end of the study, suggesting strong selection to ameliorate the P's effects, underscoring the evolutionary challenge posed by selfish elements. simul has lower rates of P-induced gonadal dys than melanaster, with high sterility expected to hamper the P's spread.
Researchers have developed a method to use rhodamine B, a fluorescent dye, to mark the body and seminal fluid of male Aedes aegypti mosquitoes for mark-release experiments and estimate the efficacy of sterile male releases. The technique involves feeding males 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, or 0.8% rhamine in 50% honey solutions during flight, resulting in >95% transfer to females and successful marking after 4 days, with 0.4 and 0.8 solutions producing the longest body marking. Rhodamine marking had no effect on male competitiveness and proof-of-principle releases demonstrated transfer of marked fluid to females under field conditions and recapture of marked males. This method is useful for evaluation of male-based IT control strategies and a viable marking technique for male-release experiments without negative effects of traditional methods. Rhamine marking is less expensive than PCR and stable isotope labelling methods and less time-consuming than female fertility assays to assess competitiveness of sterilized males.
Bacterial superantigens, a diverse family of toxins, induce an inflammatory cytokine storm that can lead to lethal shock. CD28, a homodimer expressed on T cells, functions as the principal costimulatory ligand in the immune response through interaction with its B coligands. Research shows that to elicit inflammatory cytokine expression and toxicity, superigens must bind directly to the dimer interface of CD. Preventing access of superigen to CD suffices to block lethality. Mice were protected from lethal superigen challenge by peptide mimetics of the CD dimer interface and peptides to compete with superigen for binding in CD. Superigens use a conserved strand/helix domain of unknown function to engage CD. Mutation of superigen domain abolished inflammatory gene induction and lethality. Structural analysis showed when superigen binds to T receptor on cell and major histocompatibility class molecule on antigen-presenting cell, CD can accommodate as superigen receptor in ternary complex with CD dimer oriented towards strand/helix domain superigen. Findings identify CD homimer as critical receptor for superigens. Role of CD as receptor for class microbial pathogens, superigens broadens pathogen recognition mechanisms.
Researchers investigated the role of the Wnt/β-caten pathway in regulating the cell cycle and pluripotency of embryonic stem cells (ESCs). They found that activation of the Wnt pathway triggers the transcription of the Ink/Ar tumor suppressor locus through the recruitment of the transcription factor Tcf1, leading to a drastic reduction in cell proliferation without affecting pluripotency. This is in contrast to its mitogenic effect in somatic tissues. Tcf1, but not T3, is recruited to the promoters of cell cycle repressor genes such as p15k4, p16k4 and p19, mediating the W-dependent anti-proliferative effect in ES. Ablation of β-caten or T1 expression impairs W-dependent cell regulation. The W/βaten pathway downregulates some differentiation genes while expression of plurotency remains unpert. The cell effects are dependent on βaten and T1 but independent of T3, indicating non-overlapping functions of T/L factors in ES. T1 is enriched at the promoters of cycle genes such as the Ink/Ar locus. GSK inhibition or βaten transcriptionally regulates expression of the Ar family members in T3-independent manner. T1 KD lines show decreased expression of plurotent markers. Activation of W induces negative regulators of cell such as tumour suppressors Cn2 p16k, p19 and Cnb p15.
Researchers investigated the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) in dengue virus (DENV) infection. They found that pDCs from mildeng patients exhibited higher frequencies of membrane-bound TRAIL (mTR) compared to severe cases or healthy controls. Plasma levels of IF-α and soluble TR were increased in mild compared to severe deng patients, correlating with p activation. In vitro, exposure to DENV-2 induced mTR expression on p and relocalized it from the intracellular compartment to the plasma membrane. Chloroquine treatment inhibited DENV-induced mTR relocalization and IFα production by p. Endosomal degradation by chloro allowed viral antigens detection inside p, suggesting endocyt pathway activation by D-2 in p. Coculture of p/D-2-infected monocytes showed reduced antigen detection, which was also observed after exogenous IFα treatment, indicating p effect on viral load was mainly dependent on IFα production.
A study investigated the role of tumor necrosis factor (TN) in the immune response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection using a computational approach. TN plays a major role in host defense against Mtb in both active and latent phases of infection. TN-neutralizing drugs, used to treat inflammatory disorders, have increased the risk of tuberculosis (TB) in accordance with animal studies. The study extended previous mathematical models to investigate the roles of soluble (sTN) and transmembrane TN (tmTN) and analyzed the effects of anti-TNF therapy in virtual trials by simulating two commonly used therapies, anti-T antibody and TN receptor. The findings suggest that bioavailability of TN following anti-T therapy is the primary cause of reactivation of latent infection and that TN, even at low levels, is essential for control of infection. A mathematical model distinguished the mechanisms of action of anti-T treatments and provided insights into the role of TN in TB and pathology. The study suggests a TN-modulating agent could balance reduction of inflammation with maintenance of resistance to infection. Alternatively, the dose and timing of anti-T therapy could be modified.
Researchers investigated population differences in retrogene loss and expression in humans using data from the 1000 Genomes Project and RNA-Seq data from the Geuvis Consortium. They developed a new approach to detect novel retrocopies absent from the human genome and experimentally confirmed the existence of 193 retroduplication variations (RDVs) in 17 populations. Most RDVs resulted from retrocopy deletion, with a majority not previously reported. Expression of 11 ancestral retrogenes was confirmed in certain individuals, with low frequency of deletion, except for one. Expression and deletion rate of remaining retro may suggest functionality. Differences in retro expression between populations were also found, with 9 retrogenes undergoing significant differential expression.

The study analyzed 4,927 retrocopies from RetroDB and genomic data from 1,092 individuals from 14 populations, identifying 214 indels affecting 190 retrocopies. The role of retro polymorphisms as markers for population history is established, but findings suggest they also provide insight into ongoing evolutionary processes. RNA-Seq data from Geuvis allowed studying changes in retro sequences and potential implications.
A study investigated the effect of the location of Taenia solium cysticerci in the brain on the inflammatory response to praziquel treatment in pigs with neurocysticercosis. Histological specimens from 11 naturally infected pigs were analyzed, with cysterci located in the parenchym, meninges, or both. Pigs were treated with prazantel for 2 or 5 days, or left untreated. Evans blue dye was injected to assess blood-brain barrier disruption. Inflammation was scored based on photomicrographs. Parenchymal cysterci had higher inflammation after treatment compared to meningeal and corteningal cystic. Meningeal cystic inflammation was not affected by treatment. Corteningal cystic inflammation correlated with cystic proximity to parenym. Blood-brain barrier disruption was only in parenym tissue. Meningal inflammation was lower than parenymal.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in 30 communities in two districts of Ghana where azithrom mass administration for trach control had previously taken place. Children aged 5-17 with ulcerative lesions compatible with yaws were enrolled. Samples for treponemal serology and PCR were collected from all children. 90 with 98 lesions were enrolled. Syphilis serology was negative in all of them. PCR for T. pallum sp pertue was negative in children but Haemophil duyi DNA was detected in 9 lesions. In communities previously treated for trach, no evidence of ongoing y transmission was found. H. duyi was associated with a proportion of lesions but majority remain unexplained. Integration of diagnostic into pre and post-M surveillance is required for better y control.
Researchers have identified a potential new approach to combat HIV persistence by targeting the Jak-STAT pathway, a key regulator of T cell homeostasis, which drives HIV reservoir establishment and maintenance. Two FDA-approved Jak inhibitors, tofacitinib and ruxitin, were tested in vitro to block seeding and maintenance of the HIV reservoir. Results showed that Jak inhibitors reduced the frequency of CD4+ T cells harboring integrated HIV DNA and blocked viral production from infected cells, preventing transmission to bystander T cells. The study demonstrated that dysregulation of the Jak-STAT pathway is associated with viral persistence in vivo and that inhibitors target key events downstream of cytokine (IL-2, IL-7, IL-15) ligation to receptors, impacting the magnitude of the reservoir in all CD4 T subsets. In vitro and ex vivo, Jak inhibitors impeded cell activation and proliferation critical for HIV replication and reservoir seeding without affecting effector CD4 and CD8 responses. The Jak-STAT pathway was inhibited in all T subsets known to harbor HIV, and inhibitors conferred block STAT-mediated homeostatic proliferation and inflammation-driven reservoir expansion. In a cohort of aviremic participants, the association between Jak-STAT and HIV persistence was confirmed, with frequencies of cells with integrated DNA.
Researchers studied the immune response of Spodoptera exigua larvae to two different types of baculoviruses, SeNP and AcNP, using microarray analysis. Contrary to the expected transcription shutdown, the larvae showed a balanced number of up and down-regulated genes in the first 36 hours after infection. Immune-related genes, including pattern recognition, signaling, and effector proteins involved in melanization were downregulated. This downregulation was confirmed in the larval gut, where immune-related genes affect the gut microbiota, responsible for growth and development. The researchers hypothesized that this downregulation affects the gut microbiota load, observing an increase in bacterial load after infection. Experiments with and without microbiota revealed that bacteria enhanced baculirus virulence and pathogenicity. The study discusses host response pathways affected by baculiruses and the role of microbiota in infection.
Researchers have identified a novel gene that controls the transition from meiosis to mitosis in plants, a key component of apomix, a type of asexual reproduction. By combining this gene with two others that affect meiotic processes, they created a genotype called Mi, where meiosis is replaced by mitosis. Mi plants produce functional diploid gametes identical to their mother. This is a step towards understanding and engineering apomix. Apom can be separated into three components: absence or alteration of meiosis, fertilization-independent embryo development, and endosperm initiation without fertilization. In the Mi genotype, meiosis is completely replaced by mit-like division, resulting in fully penetrant apomesis. The Atspo-1 and At8 mutations lead to mit-like first meiotic division, while os1 prevents second meiotic division. Mi plants produce dyads and are fertile with quasi-wild levels of viable ovules and pollen. Previous apomesis in Arabidopsis was reported, but only 0.2% of dyadules generated viable gametes. In contrast, Mi plants produce quasi-wild levels of viable ovules and pollen. All gametes tested retained mother heterozygosity for genetic markers and were genetically identical to the mother. This confirms Mi undergoes mitosis instead of meiosis without affecting sexual processes. When meiosis is replaced by mitosis, ploidy doubles with each generation.
Researchers have developed a new approach to prioritize disease-causing genes by incorporating tissue-specific information into protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks. Current methods rely on a static picture of human PIs, which may not accurately reflect tissue-specific interactions. The study constructed tissue-specific PIs for 60 human tissues using gene expression data and found that they improve prioritization results compared to generic P networks. Tissue-specific PIs also predict novel disease-tissue associations, revealing subclinical effects that may be missed. In cases where the disease gene is expressed in the associated tissue, integrating tissue information into prioritization improves accuracy. Tissue-specific PIs were generated using gene expression data from healthy tissues and applied to prioritize genes for liver and brain diseases, despite their distinct molecular landscapes. The algorithm was applied to both original and tissue PIs in a cross-validation setting, showing tissue-specific PIs yielded higher area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve (AUC) and correct gene ranking. The method was extended to infer diseaseissue associations by constructing tissue PIs and using generic networks. A majority (71-83%) of known disease-causing genes are expressed in disease-associated tissues, supporting the hypothesis that a gene is likely expressed in a tissue for its mutation to manifest. Tissue information was added for various diseases, enabling tissue-specific inference of causing genes. The PRCE algorithm was used for prioritization and contrasted generic and tissue PIs, finding tissue-specific enhanced performance. Two methods for tissue P construction yielded different prioritization performance.
Researchers have developed a two-locus model to study the evolution of insecticide resistance in mosquito species that transmit human diseases such as malaria. The model accounts for differential exposure of males and females to high or low concentrations of insecticide and allows selection pressures and dominance to vary depending on the concentration encountered. They applied the model to investigate the merits of sequential versus mixture use of insecticides to minimize resistance spread. Results showed that mixtures outperformed sequential use in 24% of runs, while 56% favored sequential and 44 favored mixtures. Mixtures are favored when insect effectiveness is high and exposure is low. If insect does not reliably kill homozygous genotypes, sequential may be more robust. Resistance spreads slower with mixture, but may not outperform sequential. For example, a mixture may last 5 years while individual insecticides last 3-4 years, giving 7 years lifespan for sequential. The model can identify control strategies to minimize resistance spread. A decision may be made to delay new insect until another is available for a mixture with low resistance. A wider parameter space was investigated, indicating performance depends on insect, application, behavior, and genetics. Mixtures favored higher effectiveness and lower exposure. A metric was used to plot variables affecting time to resistance, showing separation between runs. The strategy is favored lower exposure and higher effectiveness.
Researchers have investigated the saliva of Rhodnius neglectus, a triatomine bug that transmits Chagas disease, to understand its role in vector-host interactions. Next-generation sequencing and mass spectrometry were used to identify proteins in the saliva. 4,230 DNA sequences were deposited in GenBank, and 636 coding sequences of putative secretory proteins were extracted, with 73 confirmed by proteomic analysis. The saliva of R. neglect was characterized by serine protease transcripts and presence of ubiquitous protein families, including lipocalin, serine protease inhibitors, antigen-5 metalloproteases, disins, and odorant binding proteins. These findings improve understanding of hematophagous arthropod saliva and interactions with vertebrate hosts. R. neglect is a secondary vector of T. cruzi, causative of Chagas disease, and analysis of salivary secret products may be involved in vector-host interactions similar to other triatine species. Deep sequencing increases possibilities of finding new molecules in saliva of blood-sucking insects, offering substances for further investigation. The study cataloged transcripts of R. neglect SG with probable function in hematagy using RNA and spectrometry. Secreted proteins were organized in subclasses, including known families in hematag saliva, such as lipin, nitroph, antigen-5, and families not reported in triine, such as serinease and disintegr.
Researchers used Caenorhabditis elegans as a model organism to study the interaction between nematodes and bacteria in soil. They employed transcriptional profiling to identify genes that are differentially expressed in response to bacteria isolated from grassland soils. Many of the identified genes are involved in metabolism and immunity, suggesting they may influence nemat community dynamics in natural systems. Mutations in 21 of these genes showed they contribute to lifespan and fitness in specific bacterial environments. Although the bacteria are not a natural food source for C. elegans, changes in food source due to environmental disturbance can affect gene expression and fitness. Regression analysis demonstrated that the degree of differential expression between environments predicts the effect of gene loss on life traits in those environments.
Researchers have investigated the role of gene expression noise in the development of the mammalian blastocyst, a critical event in mammalian embryo formation. Using multi-scale modeling, they found that stochasticity in gene expression promotes cell plasticity and plays a crucial role in accurately organizing the blastocyst. Asymmetry in the levels of variation of Cdx2 and Oct4 expression provides a means to benefit from noise-mediated plasticity while mitigating detrimental effects of stochasticity. By controlling the timing and pace of cell specification, the embryo modulates plasticity, creating a window for cells to continually read their environment and adjust fate. These results suggest noise has a crucial role in maintaining plasticity and organizing the blastyst.

 Combined results support the hypothesis that gene noise has a positive influence on TE/ICM organization and adds robustness to the correct arrangement of mouse blastysts. Studies indicate an inherent asymmetry in the system, with noise introducing perturbations leading to a switch from an undesirable to a more stable state. The regulatory model is a plausible mechanism to organize the embryo, but results indicate noise helps deal with ambiguities and imperfections central to it. Asymmetries in noise sources provide a mechanism to promote plasticity without overwhelming dynamics. Mammalian fate is a gradual process, providing a window for noise to fix errors. This suggests induced plasticity improves organization.

 Results are consistent with modeling that noise in C2 expression improves organization, while Oct expression does not. With modeling predictions, it is concluded that noise in the appropriate range promotes proper organization of the embryo.
Researchers have investigated the ability of germline-encoded antibodies to bind to diverse antigens. They found that germl-encoded antibodies can bind to multiple antigens due to their structural flexibility, which increases with somatic mutations in antigen-stimulated B cells. The study used the Rosetta multi-state design process to predict antibody sequences for the heavy chain region, including framework, CDR, and CDR mutations. Predicted sequences matched germl gene to a remarkable degree, revealing residues enabling polyspecific binding. In contrast, designing antibodies to bind a single antigen returned similar to mature sequence, mimicking natural maturation. The Rosetta design captures aspects of antibody-antigen recognition, while CDR mediates specificity, but VH, CDR, and immunoglobulin framework contribute to polyspecificity in germl antibodies. Designing antibodies to bind multiple antigens may retain polyspecific for diverse epitope binding.
Locusts exhibit two interchangeable behavioral phases: solitar and gregar. Solitar individuals are repelled by other locusts, while gregar insects are attracted to conspecifics and form large aggregations such as hopper bands. Biological experiments at the individual level have shown crowding biases towards the gregar form. To understand hopper band formation, a partial integrodifferential model was constructed incorporating interplay between phase change and movement at the individual level to predict population dynamics. Stability analysis revealed conditions for an outbreak, characterized by large transition to gregar phase. The model enabled quantification of temporal dynamics of each phase, proportion of population that will gregarize, and time for this to occur. Numerical simulations described aggregation's structure, revealing transient clumps of gregar insects. Predictions suggest possible biological experiments.

The problem was addressed via mathematical modeling to quantify collective gregar, a key process before destructive locust outbreak. A continuum model was constructed for phase interacting gregar and solitar locs, classifying dynamics in wide parameter space. In low densities, phases were uniformly spread and solitar dominated. For large populations, a dense gregar patch emerged, solitar became scarce. Clustering at high densities was identified with hop band onset. Analysis calculated critical density for gregar formation and final ratio gregar to solitar. Behavioral is plastic and dependent on density: gregar transitions to solitar in sparse, vice versa in crowded environments. This dependence is summarized in Fig.2. Analysis yielded most unstable spacing from wave modes. Numerical simulations illustrated rapid transitions once gregar initiated, dense gregar packs formed, sweeping sol in vicinity.
Researchers have characterized an intermediate structure in the fusion process of flaviviruses, a type of virus that causes diseases such as tick-borne encephalitis, by exposing virus particles to alkaline pH instead of acidic conditions. This allowed them to trap the virus in an intermediate conformation where the fusion protein E dimer dissociates and interacts with the target membrane, but does not proceed to merge the membranes. Further treatment to low pH leads to fusion, suggesting these monomers correspond to an elusive intermediate required to convert the pre-fusion dimer to post-fusion trimer. The use of non-physiological conditions enabled the dissection of the flavivirus fusion process and identification of two separate steps: membrane insertion of multiple E monomers precedes formation of hair-like trimers. This sequence provides new insights into the dynamic of viral membrane fusion.
Researchers have investigated the drivers of extinction risk in plants, focusing on the Cape of South Africa, a global biodiversity hotspot. They compared Red List data for the British and South African floras and found that taxonomic distribution of extinction risk differs between regions, inconsistent with a trait-based model of extinction. A phylogenetic analysis of the Cape flora revealed a phylogenetic signal in the distribution of plant risks, but most threatened species cluster at the tips of the phylogeny, opposite to trends in mammals. Analyzing 11 exemplar clades, they suggest speciation best explains the phylogenetic structure of extinction risks in plants of the Cape. Results show that extinction risk is higher for young and fast-evolving plant lineages, not explained by correlations with simple traits, and most vulnerable species are marching towards extinction at a rapid pace, independently from anthropogenic effects. The study has implications for conservation and casts doubt on the utility of Red List criteria for regions with rapid speciation, aiming to preserve the tree-of-life.
Researchers have identified two new proteins, Bruton's Tyrosine Kinase (TK) and Vav, that interact with the major phagoc receptor Dectin-1 in macrophages to facilitate the phocytosis of the opportunistic fungal pathogen Candida albicans. During phocytosis, TK and Vav are recruited to the phocytic cup surrounding the Candida hyphae, while Dect-1 lines the full length of the phagosome. TK and Vav colocalize with the lipid PI (3, 4, 5)P3 and F-act at the phocytic cup, but not with diacylglycerol DAG which marks mature phagosomes. A selective TK inhibitor showed that TK contributes to DAG synthesis at the phytic cup and subsequent recruitment of PKε. TK or Vav-deficient peritoneal macrophages display a defect in Candida albicans phocytosis and bone-derived macrophages lacking TK or V1 show reduced Candida uptake comparable to Dect1-deficient cells. TK or V1-deficient mice are more susceptible to systemic Candida infection than wild-type mice.
Rift Valley fever (RV) is a vector-borne disease affecting ruminants and humans, which heavily impacted Madagascar in 2008-2009. To optimize available resources for RV surveillance, identifying at-risk environments is essential. This study aimed to identify environmental and human factors favoring RV transmission in cattle and humans in Madagascar. Environmental factors were characterized using Multiple Factor Analysis (FA), and cattle and human serological data analyzed using Generalized Mixed Models. Cattle and human seroprevalence were positively associated with humid environments (p<0.001) and high cattle density (p<0.01, OR=2.6). Frequent contact with raw milk contributed to human infection (OR=1.6). The study highlighted eastern, western, and northwestern parts as high-risk areas for RV transmission in cattle. An integrated analysis of environmental and human datasets provided new insights on RV transmission patterns in Madagascar. The association between serrevalence, humid environments, and cattle density suggests conitant vector and direct transmissions are critical for RV enzotic transmission. In at-risk environments, western, northwestern, and eastern areas, suitable Cx Anopheles mosquitoes vector transmission occurs in cattle and humans.
Researchers investigated the transmission of the prion state between non-identical proteins, specifically between homologous proteins from different species, and found that transmission barriers are attributed to sequence differences in pr proteins but the underlying mechanisms are unclear. They used a yeast Rq1/PIN-based system to explore the nature of transmission. The prion form Rq is common in wild and laboratory yeast strains and facilitates the appearance of other prions. Rq's pr domain has four Q-rich regions, and multiple prion determinants can independently drive amyloid formation in vitro and transmit the prion state in vivo. Analysis of PIN transmission between Rq fragments with different pr determinants established that one Q-rich region is required and sufficient for transmission, but transmissions are impeded by barriers of different strength. The existence of barriers in the absence of amino mismatches in regions indicates complex pr domains pr determinants cooperatively attain the pr conformation and transmission determined by cooperative fold.

The PIN pr domain is located in the Q-rich C-terminus, but one Q region in Rq is not essential for the pr state, suggesting Rq carries multiple determinants capable of supporting pr. Bacterially expressed Rq fragments lacking three of four Q regions were tested for propensity to form amy in vitro. Q1's inability to maintain pr is not unexpected, as region corresponds roughly half other regions length lacks oligopeptide and residues hypothesized facilitate fragmentation amy aggregates. Pr strains manifest pr conformations same protein, despite sequence, have transmission barriers. In vitro and genetic data indicate large pr domains define differences. PIN stands among yeast as found industrial pathogenic isolates, while PSI and URE are common laboratory. Saccharomyces cerevisiae three epetic factors PSI, URE, and PIN manifest self-peruating amy conformations Sup, Ure and Rq, respectively. The pr nature factors established genetic criteria Wick, proof protein transmission obtained infecting cells vitro Sup, U or R amyloids.
Researchers have developed a novel, likelihood-free framework for inferring complex genetic models from genomic data using deep learning, a powerful machine learning technique. This approach bypasses the computational infeasibility of traditional methods by using multilayer neural networks to learn a feature function from input data (e.g., hundreds of summary statistics) to output (e.g., population parameters of interest). The method is demonstrated for jointly inferring natural selection and demography (population size history) in Drosila melanogaster from 197 African genomes, separating demography from selection without sequential steps. Demography and selection are confounded in Drosilaogaster, making joint inference challenging. The method finds regions of the genome under hard sweeps, soft, and balancing selection, with soft and balancing occurring closer to the centromere. Demographic inference suggests previously estimated bottlenecks for Dilaogaster are too extreme. Deep learning provides a way to distinguish informative from uninformative statistics and has been applied to neuroscience and biology, but not population genetics. It accommodates complex models and is a complimentary to likelihood-free inference in genetics. The method can be used to select statistics for ABC or other methods, such as hierarchical ABC or SVM. Other approaches are possible, and it is unclear which would produce most accurate results. Using deep to classify regions as neutral or selected is appealing for demographic inference.
High-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) oncogenes disrupt the Fanconi anemia (FA) DNA repair pathway by impairing localization and deubiquination of FANCD2. Persistent expression of high-risk HPV oncogen is necessary for the development of anogenital and oropharyngeal cancers. E6/E7 expressing cells are hypersensitive to DNA-damaging agent cisplatin and have defects in repairing interstrand crosslinks (ICL). The study elucidates how E/E7 attenuates the FA pathway. E7 activates the pathway by increasing FAN2 monoubiquination and foci formation but inhibits completion of repair by multiple mechanisms. E7 impairs FAN colocalization with double-strand breaks (DSB), hindering recruitment of downstream protein Rad51 to DS in E cells. Further, E causes delayed F deubiquination, an important for ICL repair. Delayed F deubination is associated with chromatin retention of F, hindering US1 deubiquinating activity and persistently activated ATR/CHK-1/p565 F signaling. E mediated p53 degradation does not hamper cell cycle process of F modifications but abrogates repair by disrupting deubination. E reduces and foci formation of Pal2, a protein downstream of F.
In the Southern Chiapas focus of Mexico, one of the major onchocerciasis foci in Latin America, 559 communities have undergone semi-annual ivermect treatment since 1998. In 50 communities, iverectin frequency shifted to twice a year in 2003, and an additional 113 communities were added to the quarterly regimen in 2009 to achieve rapid suppression. Epidemiologic and entomologic assessments were conducted in six sentinel communities with 2 rounds of iverectin per year and three extra-sent with 4 rounds per year. No Simulium ochum l collected during the dry season 201 were found to contain parasite DNA by PCR-ELISA, resulting in an upper bound of 95% confidence interval of infectivity of 0.06/2,000 flies. Serological testing on 4,230 children under 5 years old revealed 2/4,230 exposed to Ovolulus (0.05%). The findings meet the criteria for interruption of transmission developed by the international community. The Onchias Elimination Program aims to eliminate ocular morbidity and transmission in 13 foci in Latin America. The Southern focus population (114,024) comprises 21% of the Americas at-risk population. Annual iverect distribution began in 1994, modified to every 6 months in 1998. In Chiapas, iverect was initially offered to cases, then to eligible residents in hyperemic and hypoemic communities, and 40% in hypoemic from 1995-1997. 22 rounds reaching 85% of eligible have been provided over 11 years, with 85% coverage every year 199-201.
Listeria monocytogen, a Gram-positive facultative intracellular pathogen, invades mammalian cells and escapes from membrane-bound vacuoles to replicate within the host cytos. A transcription activator PrA regulates gene products for intracellular growth and bacterial spread. However, the signal stimulating PrA activation has not been defined. Here, evidence is provided for L monocytogen secretion of a peptide pherone, pA, which enhances escape from host vacoles and may facilitate PrA activation. pA pherone is generated via proteolytic processing of P lipoprotein signal. P lipop is dispensable for pathogenesis, but bacteria lacking pA pher are attenuated for virulence in mice with reduced efficiency of escape from vacoles of nonphagocytic cells. Mut activation of PrA restores virulence and eliminates need for pA signaling. Experimental evidence suggests pA may signal monocogen presence within vacole, stimulating expression of products contributing to escape and PrA to promote growth within cytos.
Researchers investigated how the bacterium Vibrio cholera, the causative agent of cholera, adapts to oxidative stress during infection in the host. They used a whole-genome transposon sequencing (T-seq) analysis to compare gene requirements for colonization in mice with and without antioxidant treatment, N-acetyl cystine. The study found that mutants of the methyl-directed repair system, such as MutS, showed significant colonization advantages in untreated, ROS-rich mice but not in N-treated mice. Further analysis suggested that accumulation of catalase-producing and rugose variants in N- mice was due to Mut mutant enrichment by oxidative stress during infection. Rugose variants could revert to smooth colonies in aerobic in vitro. Mutation rate of wildtype colonized in N- mice was higher than in N+ mice. The findings support a paradigm where Vibrio employs a temporal strategy to battle ROS during infection, resulting in enriched phenotypes. Additionally, Mut passage and complementation can model hypermutation in diverse pathogens to identify stress mechanisms.
Researchers studied the function of Mlh3 in baker's yeast, a protein involved in meiotic recombination and mismatch repair (MMR). They analyzed 6 new Mlh alleles, 5 of which disrupted MMR and 1 that specifically disrupted meiotic crossing over. The researchers purified and characterized 2 representatives of each class, Mlh-32 (MR+, crossover-) and Mlh-45 (MR-, crossover+). Both displayed wild-type endonuc activities in vitro, but M2sh, an M complex that acts with Mlh in MMR, stimulated the endon activity of Mlh-32 but not Mlh-45, suggesting M-45 is defective in M interactions. Whole-genome recombination maps were constructed for wild-type, M+ crossover, M- crossover, endonuc defective and Mlh mutants in S288/Y789 background. Compared to wild, all Mlh mutants showed increases in non-crossover events, consistent with recombination intermediates being resolved through alternative pathways.
