Four PYRs responded to one or more ligands, but NYR1 responded to Peptide as well as PF. Two PYR homologs in the disease vector Ix scularis were also sensitive to Peptide. Injection of synthetic Peptide and PF inhibited host-seeking in non-fed females, whereas buffer or inactive Pe[C10 had no effect. To determine if PY1 is necessary for host-seeking inhibition, zinc-fingerases generated five independent null strains and tested for abnormalities. Mutants displayed normal behavior in locomotion, egg, sugar, feeding, blood, and host-seeking, but not host-seeking after meal. This study identified four Ae aegi PYRs and PY1 as a candidate PF receptor sensitive to Peptide. However, PY1 alone is not required for host-seeking, suggesting other receptors, peptides, or both regulate this behavior.
A study was conducted to model the risk of schistosomiasis transmission in Akure Local Government Area, Ondo State, Nigeria, using satellite-derived environmental data. Schistomiasis is a parasitic disease influenced by environmental factors such as rivers, elevation, slope, land temperature, land use/cover, and rainfall. The study used multicriteria evaluation (MCE) and Sa's Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) to identify areas with suitable conditions for schosomias transmission. Factors considered were temperature, drainage, elevation, rainfall, slope, and land use/cover as controlling schosias incidence. These factors were reclassified and overlaid to identify areas vulnerable to schosias. Weighted analysis was done after each factor was given weight through AHP. The prevalence of schias in the area was determined by parasitological analysis of urine samples collected through random sampling. Results showed varying schias risk with 82% of the area falling under high and very high category. One community (Ole) had lowest schias risk while risk increased in four communities (ju, Igoba, It, Ogb, and Oese). Predictions by model correlated with field observations. High zones corresponded to endemic communities. Environmental factors can be used to identify and predict schias transmission as well as monitor disease in rural communities.
Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumoc) meningitis is a bacterial infection of the brain that causes significant morbidity and mortality, with 75% of patients surviving but half experiencing long-term disabilities. The disease is characterized by massive neuronal death, predominantly in the hippocampus. Pneumolysin (LY) is a pneumoccal pathogenic factor belonging to the cholesterol-dependent cytolin (CDC) group. This study demonstrates a pathogenic cascade linking LY with glutamate release and subsequent NMD-dependent dendritic and synaptic pathology in pneumoc meningitis. During meningitis, multiple factors contribute, including oxidative stress, brain ischemia, edema, immune-derived glutamate, bacterial products, and other toxins.

This study is the first to describe synaptic loss in neocortex in pneumoc mening autopsy cases and animal model, identifying LY as critical in this process. Cellular and molecular mechanisms of LY-induced dendritic and synaptic damage confirm its pore-forming capacity, glutamate release, and NMD receptor activation. LY induces glutamate from astrocytes in calcium-dependent manner, a major source of elevated glut in pneumoc meningitis and model. Long-term cognitive decline in survivors implies synaptic loss as reason for cognitive abnormalities, previously unproven. Long-term potentiation and depression correlate spine shrinkage with decreased numbers and impairment in neurological disorders. This study investigates neocortical synapses in pneumoc mening and LY's role in effects.
Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are DNA viruses associated with major human cancers, and developing new prevention methods such as vaccines and microbicides requires understanding of their life cycle. The HPV life cycle is linked to the state of the stratified epithelium it infects, with progeny virus made in the terminally differentiating suprab compartment. It has been recognized that HPV first establishes infection in the basal layer of stratified epithelium, but the reason is unclear. This might be due to specificity of entry receptors, but this does not explain differentiation restriction of HPV, as many cells can be infected in monolayer culture. Chemical approaches reveal that cell progression through mitosis is critical for HPV infection. Using HPV16 particles with intact genome, synchronized keratinocytes as hosts, and viral gene expression as readout, cells must enter M phase for infection to take place. Late phase inhibitors have no effect, whereas G, S, G, and M phase inhibitors prevent infection. Cells need to pass prophase for successful transcription of encapsulated genes. This provides reason HPVs establish in basal compartment of stratified epithel, as only this contains cycling cells. These findings have implications for HPV control.
Researchers have identified microRNA-like RNAs (milRNAs) in the dimorphic fungus Penicillium marneffi, which causes systemic mycosis in China and Southeast Asia. Using high-throughput sequencing, they found 24 potential milRNA candidates, with 17 in mycelial and 7 yeast phases. Two genes, d-1 and d-2, encoding Dicer-like proteins, and q-2 encoding Argonaute protein, were identified in P. marffei. Phylogenetic analysis showed d-2 of P. marffei is closely related to homologs in other dimorphic pathogenic fungi, suggesting co-evolution. d-2 among thermal fungi. d-2 demonstrated higher mRNA levels in mycel than yeast phase. Northern analysis confirmed expression of two milRN, PMil-M1 and PMil-M2, only in mycel. Using d-1, d-2, dDKO and q-2 deletion mutants, biogenesis of milRN was dependent on d-2 but not d- or q-. mRNA levels of predicted targets PMil-M were upregulated in knockdown PMil-MKD, supporting regulatory function milRN. This is the first report of milRN in a thermal dim pathogenic fungus and differential expression in mycel and yeast.
Zika virus (ZIK) emerged in French Polynes in 2013 and spread through the Pacific region between 2013 and 2017. Several Aedes mosquitoes may have contributed to ZIK transmission, including Aedes aegypt, the main vector in the region, and Aedespolensis, vector of lymphatic filariasis and secondary vector deng virus. This study analyzed the ability of these vectors to transmit ZIK at a regional scale by evaluating the competence of wild Ae.egi and Apolensis populations from Pacific for ZIK strain circulated during 2013-2017 outbreak. Field Aeegi (three populations) and Apolensis (two) from Pacific were collected. Female mosquitoes were exposed to ZIK (107 TCID/mL) isolated in 2014. At 6, 9, and 21 post-infection, mosquito bodies (thorax and abdomen), and heads were analyzed to measure infection, dissemination, and transmission rates, respectively. Results showed ZIK infection rates were heterogeneous between Aeeg populations, but dissemination rates were moderate and homogenous. For Apensis, infection rates were less heterogeneous between populations. Transmission efficiency revealed low vector competence for ZIK of different Ae populations. Results indicated low ZIK transmission by Aeeg and Apensis tested from Pacific. This was unexpected, suggesting other factors, such as vector density, lifespan, or immunologically naive fraction of population, contributed to rapid spread of ZV in Pacific during 201-2017.
Researchers have developed a new approach called Targeted StructureSeq to study the structure of long non-coding RNA (lnc) Xist, a key regulator of X-chromosome inactivation in mammalian cells. Targeted StructureSeq combines chemical probing of RNA in cells with massively parallel sequencing, enriching for signals from the RNA of interest to achieve high coverage with few reads, providing a targeted and scalable approach to analyze RNA conformation in cells. This method was used to probe the full-length Xist lncRNA, developing new models for functional elements within Xist, including the repeat element in the 5'-end of X. Analysis identified new structural elements X that are evolutionarily conserved, such as an element proximal to the repeats important for X function. The study demonstrates the utility of Targeted StructureSeq to compare RNA conformations in vitro and in cells, and identifies novel conserved elements potentially functional. The approach is expected to advance mechanistic understanding of lncRNAs and develop conformation models of full X.
Researchers have developed a new statistical framework to evaluate the predictive power of genetic variants for complex diseases. Current methods mainly use the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) to assess genetic tests, but it has limitations. The new framework connects various predictive indices, including AUC, mean difference between cases and non-cases, net reclassification improvement, proportion of cases at highest risk, variance of predicted risks, and risk at any percentile. It also provides graphs to visualize performance, such as ROC curve, density of risks, and predictiveness curve. Simulations match theoretical estimates. The framework was applied to nine diseases, evaluating genetic tests for known variants. The study aims to provide a comprehensive assessment of predictive models, complementing AUC with other indices and graphs, especially when risk thresholds exist. Genome-wide association studies have identified many genetic variants for complex diseases, raising hope for individualized risk prediction. However, a single marker's effect is typically small, but a collection may be promising. Established risk thresholds lead to a large part of the ROC curve from non-clinical cutoffs. The framework can estimate indices and graphs given disease prevalence and heritability explained by variants.
Researchers developed a new rapid diagnostic test for Trypanosoma brucei gambense infection using recombinant antigens, called SDOLINEAT 2.0, and compared its accuracy to the current rapid test using native antigens, SDOLAT, and the traditional Card Agglutination for Trypanosomias (CATT). The study involved 57,632 individuals in the Democratic Republic of Congo, with 260 confirmed cases of African trypanosomiasis. SDOLAT 2.0 had the highest sensitivity at 71.2%, followed by CATT 62.5% and SDOL 59%. CATT was the most specific at 99.2%, while SDOL and SDOL 2.0 were 98.9% and 98.1% respectively. The tests were more sensitive in passive screening than active. Combining two or three tests increased sensitivity, with SDOL and SD 2.0 reaching 98.4% and 83% in passive and active screening. The recombinant antigen test was as sensitive and specific as SDOL, but less specific than CATT. The study suggests using two or more tests could enhance diagnostic algorithms, but decrease specificity.
Researchers conducted a decade-long study in the municipality of Comapa, Guatemala, a region with persistent Triatoma infestation, to evaluate the effectiveness of Chagas disease control activities. Initially, entomological and serological surveys were conducted in 1999 and 2001-2002, followed by three rounds of insecticide applications from 2003-2005 and intermittent spraying of infested houses until 2012. Household inspections and entom indices were conducted in 2001, 2007, and 201. Serological surveys were conducted in school-aged children in 199, 2007, and 201, and women of childbearing age 15-44 in 201. The infestation index decreased significantly from 39% in 2001-2 to 27 in 201, and household materials predicted <10% of infested houses. Chagas seropreval in school-aged children declined 10-fold from 10 in 199 to 1 in 201. However, serreval in women of child age remained >10. After a decade of control, there is evidence of reduced transmission, but continued risk of vector-borne and congenital transmission poses a threat to the 202 Chagas elimination goal.
Citrobacterium is a natural pathogen that causes attaching and effacing (A/E) lesions in mice, sharing a virulence strategy with human pathogens Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) and Enterohaemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). The complete genome of Citrobium ICC168 was previously sequenced, displaying characteristics of a newly evolved pathogen. This study used PFGE sequencing, isolates variation, whole transcriptome analysis, and mobile genetic elements to show that Citium's genome is unstable due to repeat-mediated large-scale recombination and active transposition of mobile elements, such as prophages. An additional Citium strain EX-33 was sequenced, revealing that ICC168 is representative of the species, with most inactivating mutations common to both isolates occurring early in the pathogen's evolution. This parallels the evolution of other bacterial pathogens, suggesting Citium is a recently emerged pathogen alongside mouse development as a human disease model.

Citrobium isolates showed ICC features of bacteria passed through an evolutionary bottleneck, including pseudogenes and IS elements. This study investigates genomic flux in Citium, focusing on mobile elements' impact on evolution, demonstrating the pathogen's unstable genome. Citium shares virulence with EPEC and EHE, with isolates from mouse and hamster outbreaks in the 1960s, 70s 80s classified as atypical E. coli (M) or atypical Citacterii, later reclassified Citrob. Genetic and biochemical analyses suggested clonal origin, reclassifying Citrobium. The whole genome of Citium ICC168, from a 1972 outbreak, was sequenced, along with DB100 from the same source, most studied Citium isolates. Functions conferring Citium virulence to EPEC EHE are on horizontally acquired elements, with large genomic rearrangements and gene loss, suggesting Citium recently emerged as path, adapting lifestyle.
Researchers have developed a computational framework to analyze stochasticity in gene expression by inferring biochemical rate constants that govern chromatin modification, transcription, translation, and RNA and protein degradation from protein distributions. They derived analytical solutions for the first four moments of the protein distribution and found that these moments capture the shape of the protein distribution. An efficient algorithm was developed to infer gene expression constants from the moments of the protein distribution. The method was applied to a steady-state protein distribution and found that most distributions are consistent with a large number of biochemical constant sets, despite degeneracy, the solution space of constants always informs the underlying mechanism. The method distinguishes between transcriptional bursting and constitutive production regimes and agrees with the standard approach in the restrictive regime where it operates, also identifies constants not obtainable without assumptions. Estimates of individual rate constants or ratios were obtained in 91% of cases, and all underlying constants were identified in some cases. The framework will be a tool for deducing molecular contributions to patterns of gene expression.
Researchers have developed a new vaccine approach to protect against monkeypox (MPX), a disease caused by the monkeypox virus (MPV), using a recombinant bovine herpesvirus 4 (Bo-4) vector. The Bo-4 vectors express different MPV glycoproteins, A29, M1, and B6, and were tested for protection against lethal MPV challenge in STAT knockout mice. Three recombinant Bo-4 vectors, Bo-4-CMV-A29g106TK, Bo-4-E1-MR106TK, and Bo-4-E-BR106, were successfully constructed and shown to express their transgene. A small-scale study found the vectors safe with no adverse events after intraperitoneal administration. Bo-4-E1-MR106 alone or in combination with Bo-4-C-A29 and Bo-4-BR protected 100% and 80% of STAT(-) mice from mortality and morbidity, respectively. This demonstrates the efficacy of Bo-4 vectors as a vaccine platform. 

MPV is an emerging zoonosis in tropical Africa, endemic in Congo and sporadic in West Africa, and a neglected disease in rural areas. Human interaction with wildlife increases MPV infection and human-to-human transmission is possible. Smallpox vaccination provides cross-protection, but the campaign ended in 1980, leaving a large population unprotected. Current vaccines are limited due to safety concerns and no FDA-approved therapies exist. New studies on pathogenesis, prophylaxis, and therapeutics are of interest for the scientific community and governments, as MPV could be a bioterror agent.
In trypanosomes, the major mRNA decay pathway is 5'-3' decay, where deadenylated mRNAs are decapped by the nudix hydrolase DCP of the decapping complex and degraded by the 5'-3 exonuclease. Unlike other eukaryotes, trypanosomes lack homologues to subunits of the decapping complex, while deadenylation and 5'- degradation are conserved. This study shows that trypanosomes use ApH-like phosphatase AL1 (AL1) as their major decapping enzyme. AL1 was identified as a novel trypan stress granule protein and involved in mRNA binding. A fraction of AL1 co-localises with the trypan 5'- exonuclease X to a granule at the posterior of the cell, indicating a connection between the enzymes. RNA depletion of AL1 is lethal and causes a massive increase in mRNAs that are deadenylated but not started 5'- decay, suggesting AL acts downstream deadeny and upstream of degradation, consistent with decapping. In vitro experiments show recombinant N-terminally truncated AL1 protein, but catalytically inactive, sensitises capped trypan spliced RNA to yeast X1, only with 5 polyphosphate included, indicating decapping mechanism differs from D2 by leaving more phosphate at 5 end.
Researchers have discovered that inactivating the Arx gene in pancreatic α-cells is sufficient to trigger their conversion into β-like cells. This process involves the mobilization of ductal precursor cells to adopt an endocrine fate, with glucagon cells being converted into β-like cells upon Ar inhibition. Analysis of Ar and Pax double-mutants shows Pax is dispensable for regeneration, indicating Ar as the main trigger of α-cell β-cell neogenesis. Loss of Ar in α-cells regenerates functional β-cell mass and reverses diabetes-induced β-cell depletion. Strategies targeting Ar expression or its targets may treat diabetes. The β-cell regeneration is able to counteract toxin-induced diabetes, maintaining euglycemia. Inactivation of Ar in embryonic and adult α-cells induces similar outcome. Lineage tracing shows glucagon cells, even at advanced ages, can convert into β-like cells upon Ar inactivation. Loss of gluc-producing cells initiates endocrine regeneration, gluc+ acquiring β-phenotype, leading to islet hypertrophy due β-like hyperplasia.
Eukaryotic cells have mechanisms to prevent the initiation of DNA replication at thousands of origins in their genome to minimize the probability of genomic alterations. Global regulatory mechanisms reduce the activity of initiation proteins, but origins initiate with diverse efficiencies when these are disabled. This suggests an additional layer of control that differentially regulates initiation at distinct origins. Novel elements are necessary for preferential initiation of two origins and confer preferential initiation on heterologous origins when control is partially deregulated. These elements, termed replication initiation promoters (RIPs), do not enhance S phase timing or efficiency of adjacent origins and act specifically as initiation promoters. RIPs map to ∼60 bp AT-rich sequences in a distance and sequence-dependent manner. During replication, Mc2 associates with origins that preferentially initiate and those that do not, indicating RIPs can overcome the block to initiation imposed by Mc2 association. This identifies a local level of control in the block to initiation, creating a complex landscape of replication potential revealed when global mechanisms are compromised. If replication contributes to alterations, as speculated in cancer, some regions may be more susceptible than others.
A study of 170 HIV-1-infected men in Japan found that the clinical features of invasive amebias caused by Entamoeba histoly were similar to those in non-HIV infected individuals, with high fever, leukocytosis, and high CRP associated with extraintestinal ameb diseases. Two patients died from amebic colitis and three from unrelated causes. Treatment with metronidazole or tinidazole was successful in 165 cases, with luminal treatment provided to 83, but recurrence occurred in 6, similar to those without luminal treatment. Recurrence was more frequent in HCV-antib positive and syphilis acquired during follow-up. Various E histoly genotypes were identified but no correlation with clinical features or outcome. Metronidazole tinazole treatment of uncomplicated amebias was excellent in HIV-1 individuals, but luminal treatment post-treatment did not reduce recurrence in high-risk populations due to re-infection. A retrospective analysis of 170 HIV-1 patients showed no impact on immunocompromised status on amebias forms. Physical and laboratory findings showed fever, leukocyt, and CRP with extralinal ameb diseases. Results indicate excellent outcome for HIV-1 individuals with uncomplicated amebias treated metronazole tinidazole, in agreement with previous reports. Conventional management includes lum agent metronazole treatment to eradicate cysts.
Researchers conducted a study in the Mandoul area of South Chad to assess the impact of adding tset control to medical activities on the transmission of Gambian sleeping sickness, also known as African trypanosomiasis, caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambense. The area was a persistent focus of the disease with around 100 cases diagnosed and treated annually until 2013. The study aimed to determine if adding tset control to case detection and treatment could further reduce transmission and incidence. A census of the population was conducted and settlements mapped, followed by a pre-intervention survey of tse distribution and abundance in 2013. 260 targets were deployed in riverine habitats in 2014, 2015, and 2016. Impact on tse and incidence was assessed through nine surveys and medical surveys in 2014,201. Modelling was used to assess the relative impact of tset control on incidence compared to active and passive screening. The population of 74 inhabitants lived in the focus, with Glossina fuscipes and a mean catch of 0.7 tset/trap in 2013. Catch declined to 0.005set/trap after deployment. Modelling attributed 70.4% reduction in cases 2015 to vector control, 62.8% to tset, and 8.5 to enhanced detection. Predictions anticipate elimination by 2018 if control and screening continue, virtually no transmission since 201.
A retrospective study of 124 cases of imported strongyloidiasis in Spain from 2009-2017 found that most patients were immigrants (66.9%) from South America, with eosinophilia present in 82.2% of cases. Detection of larvae in stool samples was observed in 21.9% of patients, while serological tests made the diagnosis in the rest of the cases. Ivermectin compared to albendazole was the most strongly associated factor to achieve cure (OR 2.34). The study aimed to describe epidemiological, clinical, and microbiological characteristics of patients with imported strongyloidis in Spain and identify factors related to parasite burden and treatment. Results differ from previous studies in non-endemic areas, such as Buenos Aires, Argentina, where iverectin treatment showed 100% cure rate. Imported strongyloidis is increasingly diagnosed in non-endemic countries, especially in Spain receiving immigrants from endemic areas. The study suggests screening for S. stercoral infection should be mandatory in patients from or traveling to endemic areas, especially immunocompromised.
Researchers have investigated the impact of the inoculum dose, or amount of antigen or attenuated pathogen, used in vaccines on host immunity and morbidity, with the goal of informing vaccine design. A higher inoculum doses stimulate a stronger immune response but may cause more severe side effects and limit population coverage during shortages. A combination of mathematical models and experimental data can determine the optimal inoculum. Using data from influenza A virus (IAV) infection in mice and human parainfluenza (HIV) in rats at different inoculum doses, a model was fitted to map inoculum to immune protection and morbidity levels. The framework combines models with data to study inoculum's impact on outcomes such as protection and morbidity. Findings show inoculum's impact on protection and morbidity depend on the pathogen, and protection and morbidity do not increase monotonically with inoculum. Once protection and morbidity levels are specified, the framework can help design vaccines and determine the optimal inoculum. A modeling framework was developed to predict the optimal inoculum for a given vaccine setting, using data from live and inactivated vaccines. The framework can be applied to specific vaccine candidates to determine the optimal dose efficiently. The study contributes a conceptual, quantitative framework to rationally design and determine inoculum for any pathogen. Parameters were chosen to produce reasonable dynamics and explored inoculum's impact on protection and morbidity for a generic model.
Researchers studied the expression of the HetR gene, a transcription factor essential for heterocyst differentiation, in Anaba filaments under nitrogen-rich and nitrogen-poor conditions. They used a chromosomally encoded HetR-gfp fusion to analyze fluctuations in HetR expression at the individual cell level in wild-type and mutant filaments. Results showed that HetR fluctuations in nearby cells are coupled, with a characteristic range of two to three cells, setting the scale for cellular interactions along filaments. Correlations arise from intercellular molecular transfer and less cell division. Under nitrogen-rich conditions, basal HetR expression is influenced by the septal protein Sep and Het auto-regulation. A comparison of Het-gfp expression under nitrogen-rich and nitrogen-p conditions highlighted differences between Het inhibitors PatS and Het, and sept proteins Sep and Fra/Fra. The study found that proteins involved in Het regulation combine to control fluctuations in expression, giving rise to a one-dimensional pattern in Anena.
Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) genotype has shifted from genotype III (GIII) to I (GI) in China, as demonstrated by molecular epidemiological surveillance. A serological survey in non-vaccinated pigs confirmed the shift at the seroepidemiological level, with an average ratio of GI/GIII of 1.87, indicating co-circulation of GI and GIII infections, with GI being more prevalent in pigs. To investigate the reasons for this shift, the replication of seven recently-isolated JEV isolates, including three GI and four GIII strains, was compared in C/36 cells, chicken fibroblast (DF-1) and porine artery endothelial (PIE) cells. GI strains replicated more efficiently than GIII in DF- and PIE cells, particularly in DF- with titers 22.9-225.3 higher than GIII. This suggests enhanced replication of GI in avian cells. In vivo, young ducklings were inoculated with GI and GIII at day post-hatching, and GI-inoculated developed higher viremia and displayed longer vmic duration than GIII-inoc. These results support the hypothesis of enhanced efficiency for GI in birds. Thirty-six amino acids differ between GI and GIII, some may be responsible for the replication efficiency of GI in birds. The findings suggest enhanced replication of GI in birds results in higher exposure and infection in mosquitoes, increasing transmission in the birds-mosquito-bird enootic cycle, contributing to J genotype shift.
Candida albicans biofilm formation is a critical aspect of its pathobiology and is regulated by a network of six transcription factors: B1, B1, E1, N80, Rob1, Tec, and 1. To understand how these factors interact to regulate biofilm, researchers generated all possible double heterozygous mutants of the network and quantitatively analyzed interactions between them. The network is highly susceptible to genetic perturbation, with six heterozygous mutants showing alterations in biofilm formation (haploinsufficiency). Many double mutants are as affected as homozygous deletions, indicating a highly interdependent'small' network that is efficient but not robust. T1 is a component whose expression is sensitive to perturbations in other TFs. RO1 is dependent on auto-regulation and cooperative interactions with other TFs. Heterozygous N80 mutant is hyperfilous under bio and hypha-inducing in T-dependent manner. Genetic analysis provided insights into individual TFs and network topology in function.
Researchers investigated the role of asparagine synthase A (AS) in Leishmania infantum, a parasite responsible for sleeping sickness. AS converts aspartate to aspar in an ATP-dependent manner using ammonia or glutamine as a nitrogen source. There are two types of AS: ammonia-dependent and glutamine-dependent. AS is absent in humans but present in trypanosomes, making it a potential drug target. A previous study found AS was essential in Leish donani, making it a promising target. This study found that Leish infant AS uses both ammonia and glutamine as nitrogen sources. They generated AS null mutants by gene replacement in Leish and found no significant growth or infectivity defects. However, severe growth impairment was observed in aspar limiting conditions. Results show AS is not essential for parasite survival or infectivity in normal in vitro and in vivo conditions, excluding it as a drug target against Leish.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to investigate the association between toxocariasis and epilepsy. The study included 11 case-control studies from 13 countries with a total of 474 participants, 215 with epilepsy and 259 without. The pooled odds ratio (OR) was 1.69 (95% CI 1.42-2.01) for the association between toxocari seropositivity and epilepsy. Meta-regression showed no significant heterogeneity and no association between covariates and outcome. The analysis found a positive association in Western blot (WB) diagnostic or confirmatory test, population and population-based studies. The meta-analysis provides epidemiological evidence of a positive association between toxari seropitivity and epilepsy, mainly supported by population studies. Further research is needed to understand the physiopathological mechanisms of toxara-associated epileptogenesis.
Researchers have identified a new DNA damage response pathway mediated by the ATM protein, which plays a crucial role in repairing double-strand breaks (DSBs) in cells. When cells are exposed to ionizing radiation (IR), ATM is activated, leading to the downregulation of microRNA miR-335, which targets CtIP, a protein involved in homologous recombination repair (HRR). The study found that CREB, a transcription factor, is responsible for mi-335 expression by binding to its promoter region, and its activity is reduced after IR, consistent with previous studies showing ATM phosphorylates CRE to decrease its activity. Overexpressing mi-335 in HeLa cells resulted in reduced Ct levels and post-IR survival and BRCA foci formation. In two patient-derived lymphoblast cell lines with decreased post-IR survival, "radiosensitive" phenotype, mi-335 was elevated, Ct reduced, and BRCA foci. Colony survival, BRCA foci, and Ct levels were partially rescued by miRNA antisense AM-mi-335 treatment. The findings suggest an ATM-dependent CRE-mi-335-Ct axis influences HRR selection for certain DS lesions.
Researchers investigated whether sophisticated mentalizing, or attributing mental states to others, affects learning in social interactions. Participants played games against artificial agents with varying levels of sophistication, believing they were either playing against humans or in a casino. In the social framing, participants won against sophisticated agents, but lost in the non-social. Their choices were best explained by sophisticated mentalizing models in the social, but not non-social framing. This demonstrates the value of mentalizing in social interactions and shows intentional behavior can't be deciphered without attributing mental states to others. 

The study draws from behavioral economics and psychology, showing mentalizing enables adaptive skills like persuading and deceiving. Decisions in games involve recursive thinking, "I think you think I think...". Cognitive models of repeated games involve Bayesian recognition of others' intentions. The study extends this to mimic sophisticated mentalizing. Results align with social learning relying on specific processes predicting others' behavior. Social priors induce a sophisticated interpretation, involving mentalizing others, with recursive updates from observing behavior. The "social brain" hypothesis assumes others are Bayesian, implying mentalizing updates from observing behavior in mutual exchanges. The task-relevant information is identical in both framings. The prediction is that social framing induces mentalizing and recursive inference, while domain heuristics prevail in non-social are vulnerable to sophisticated agents.
Researchers have developed an efficient algorithm called FastGM for inferring Gaussian Graphical Models (GM) in biological networks. GM is a probability model that characterizes the conditional structure of a set of random variables by a graph, widely used in analyzing biological networks, such as inferring or comparing interactions. Current approaches are either statistically unsound or inefficient for high-dimensional data with thousands of variables. FastGM is based on a recent proposal by Ren et al. (2015) and estimates GM and p-value and confidence interval for each edge in the graph. Through simulations, it is shown to be faster by several orders of magnitude than the current algorithm by Ren et al without losing accuracy. It is applied to real data: transcriptomic from a childhood asthma study and proteomic from Alzheimer's disease, estimating global gene/protein networks for disease and healthy samples. The networks reveal interesting interactions and differential between cases and controls relevant to diseases. FastGM is a computationally fast and statistically sound procedure for constructing GM and inference with high-dimensional data, implemented in R package "FastGM".
Researchers investigated the optimal balance of striatal medium spiny neuron (MSN) network activity in the basal ganglia, a brain structure crucial for learning and executing movement sequences. They found that MSN population firing rates vary coherently on behaviorally relevant timescales. A model of the MSN network showed realistic activity only at certain connectivities and inhibitory post-synaptic potentials (IPs) sizes. The study examined how MSN population activity interacts with temporally varying cortical activity, as in a behavioral task. At high connectivity, a "winner-takes-all" regime was found, where activity separates into stimulus-dependent firing and quiescent components. Only a few population rate components interact with cortical variations. Around a transition to a more active regime occurs, where cells switch between activity and quies. In this regime, MS components wander and are independent of cortical variations. Only in this regime, changes interact with many components, allowing sequential assemblies to be reproducibly activated for hundreds of milliseconds after stimulus onset. Peristimulus histograms display strong stimulus and temporal specificity. This activity is maximized at striatal realistic connectivities and IP sizes. The MS network is optimized, not too stable to respond dynamically to cortical variations, nor too unstable to respond consistently. It generates stimulus-dependent patterns long after cortical excitation.
Researchers investigated the relationship between polarized exocytosis and endocyt in yeast cells, finding that the Rab GTPase Sec4 couples polarized exocyt with cortical actin polymerization, which induces endocyt. Using live cell imaging, in vitro binding assays, and actin polymerization assays, they showed that Sec4 binds to actin patch components Sla and Sla during assembly. Mutations in Sec4 or its GEF Sec2 inhibit actin formation, while activating Sec4L accelerates assembly. In vitro assays, GTP-Secp overrides Sla inhibition of Lasp-dependent actin nucleation. Sec4 transiently localizes to endytic sites, disrupts actin assembly, interacts with Lasp, and induces Arp/3-dependent actin polymerization, suggesting a role in endyt apart from exyt. In yeast, polar sites of exytic vesicle fusion overlap with nascent endytic sites, dependent on both exyt and endyt. Sec4 also regulates actin assembly and endytic internalization, co-localizing with actin subunits Sla, Lasp, and Abp. It is proposed that Secp plays a role in Sla/Las regulation of Arp/3-dependent actin polymer, working in parallel with other regulators.
Acetamin-induced liver injury in mice is a model for drug-induced liver injury in humans, and understanding the mechanisms behind this phenomenon is crucial for developing strategies to prevent or reverse damage. The prevailing hypothesis is that location-dependent differences in NQI (reactive metabolite) formation within hepatic lobules (NQonation) are necessary and sufficient to account for the phenomenon, known as the NZech hypothesis. However, this hypothesis is challenged by the inability to control influential variables and require sequential intracellular measurements at different locations within the same mouse. Virtual hepatocytes configured to exhibit location-dependent behaviors, employing NZ-mech failed to achieve the phenomenon, suggesting at least one additional feature, such as glutathione depletion or mitochondrial damage, is required. Including both features enabled achieving the phenomenon, providing a multile, multiscale explanation of key features of acetamin hepatotoxicity in mice. Variants of the merged mechanism provide plausible explanations for variation in necrosis among genetically diverse strains following a single acetamin dose.
Researchers investigated the relationship between conventional diagnosis methods and quantitative DNA amplification in congenitally infected children with Trypanosoma cruzi. The study aimed to understand why not all neonates born to infected mothers can be diagnosed by microscopy immediately after birth. Results showed that infants with high parasitemia can be diagnosed by parasitological screening at 1 month of age, with 94% sensitivity in a one-year follow-up. Three groups were analyzed: A) neonates diagnosed by microscopy at 1 month (n=19), B) infants diagnosed at 6 months (n=10), and C) babies diagnosed by serology at 1 year (n=22). Group A had a median parasitemia of 1700/mL, B had 20-500/mL at 1 and 6 months, and C had 5-800-20/mL at 1 and 6 months. Parasites were isolated from 19 congenitally infected children, 18 were genotyped as DT Tc, and one as T. This is the first study to quantify parasitemia in over 50 congenitally infected children at 3 diagnostic controls. Parasite burden in 22 children was below detection limit of microscopy. Current treatment proved effective, but sensitive methods should be developed for early diagnosis.
Researchers have developed a coarse-grained biophysical model of Escherichia coli that predicts growth rate and cellular composition based on a simplified representation of its genome. The model assumes E coli is in a state of balanced exponential growth in a temporally and spatially constant environment with rich resources. The model was applied to measurements of growth and rRNA-protein ratio in seven E coli strains with rRNA operon copy numbers ranging from one to seven, the wild-type number. Results showed growth decreased for strains with fewer copies. The model reproduced these measurements and suggested the fraction of macromolecules inside coli is not fixed when r operon number varied. Increasing beyond seven resulted in cytoplasm packed with ribosomes and proteins. Assuming overcrowding weakens binding affinities, the model predicted growth will not increase beyond wild-type rate, consistent with experiments. The model suggests changing r operon number in wild-type coli in constant environment does not increase growth. Other observations, such as nucle compaction and operon response, are qualitatively consistent. The model proposes principles and suggests further experiments to test its validity.
Arabidopsis thaliana MYB protein R1 (RSM) interacts with HY5/HY to modulate seed germination and seedling development in response to abscisic acid and salinity. MYB transcription factors are involved in various biological processes, including metabolism, development, and responses to biotic and abiotic stresses. RSM, belonging to the MY-related subfamily, plays roles in plant development, stress, and hormone signaling. Downregulation or upregulation of RSM expression alters sensitivity of seed germination and cotyled greening to abisic acid (ABA), NaCl, and mannitol in Arabidopsis. The expression of RSM is dynamically regulated by ABA and NaCl. Transcription factors ELONG HYCOTYL5 (HY) and HYHOMOLOG (HY) regulate R expression via the R1 promoter. Genetic analyses reveal R mediates multiple functions of HY in responses seed germination postgermination to ABA and abiotic, and seedling to salinity. Pull-down and Bi assays show R interacts HYHY in vitro and vivo. R and HY may as a regulatory module in responses A and abiotic. R binds the promoter ABI5, regulating its expression, while R interaction stimulates HY binding the ABI. However, no evidence found dualucifer transient assay to support R enhances ABI by HY. In summary, HYHY and R may converge ABI promoter independently or dependently regulate ABI and ABI downstream A and stress genes, adapting plants to environment.
Mitochondrial complex I, the largest and most complex proton pump of the respiratory chain, links electron transfer from NAD to ubiquinone to the pumping of four protons from the matrix into the intermembrane space. Recent X-ray analysis of prokary and eukotic complex confirmed that redox reactions are confined to the hydrophil peripheral arm of the L-shaped molecule and take place at a distance from the membrane. This implies that proton pumping within the membrane of complex is driven via long-range conformation coupling, but the mechanism, number, and identity, and localization of pump sites remain unclear. Deletion of the gene for a small subunit of complex I, a stable sub (nbmΔ) is formed, lacking the dist part of the membrane domain. Analysis of subunit composition of holo and sub by proteomics revealed two subunits (ND4 and 5) with homology to bacterial Na+/H antiporters, discussed as prime candidates for harboring proton pumps, are missing in nbm. However, nbm still pumps protons at half stoichi of complete. Results provide evidence that membrane of complex harbors two functionally distinct pump modules connected by long helical element identified by X-ray analysis.
Researchers investigated the effect of fever on the binding affinity of antibodies to malaria and deng antigens in vitro. They used isothermal titration calorimetry and ELISA to measure the binding of monoclonal antibodies to antigens at 37°C, 40°C, and 42°C. The results showed a marked increase in affinity of the antibody-antigen complexes at 40°C compared to 37°C or 42°C. Thermal equilibration of the proteins at these temperatures prior to measurements further increased binding. The study suggests a positive role for fever in vivo and highlights the favorable effect of thermal priming in enhancing protein-protein affinity for samples with limited availability.
Actomyos-based cortical flow is a fundamental process in cellular morphogenesis, generated by cross-linked actin filaments and myosin motors, where motor activity is opposed by network resistance to deformation. Continuous flow requires local remodeling through cross unbinding and/or filament disassembly. A computational model of a cross-linked network with active motors based on minimal requirements for production and dissipation of contractile stress was studied: asymmetric filament compliance, spatial heterogeneity of motor, reversible cross-links, and filament turnover. The production and dissipation of network depend individually on cross dynamics and filament turnover, and these combine to determine cortical flow rates. The model predicts turnover is required to maintain stress against resistance and steady flow in response to external stress. Steady stress increases with lifetime up to a characteristic time τ, then decreases above τ. Effective viscosity increases with lifetime up to characteristic τ, then becomes independent of lifetime and dependent on cross dynamics. Dependencies of stress and viscosity define multiple regimes of steady flow. The model predicts when lifetimes are shorter than both τ and τ, dependencies of viscosity and stress on turnover cancel, flow is insensitive to turnover and shows dependence on activity and dynamics.
A novel quantitative trait locus (QTL) analysis was performed on a Col-0/C24 population of Arabidopsis thalian to study seedling sensitivity to high sugar levels of glucose and fructose. A glucose and fructose-sensing QTL, GS11, was mapped through selective genotyping and confirmed in near-isogenic lines in Col and C24 backgrounds. Allelism and transgenic tests showed GS11 lies within the ANAC060 gene. The AN060 allele confers sugar insensitivity and is dominant over the sugar-sensitive C allele. Genomic and mRNA analyses revealed a single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in AN060 affects splicing such that 20 nucleotides are present in the mRNA, creating a stop codon, resulting in a truncated AN060 protein lacking the transmembrane domain (TMD) present in C060. The absence of T results in nuclear localization of AN060. The short version of AN060 is found in 12% of natural Arabidopsis accessions. Glucose induces GS11/AN060 expression in a process requiring abisic acid (ABA) signaling. Chromatin immunoprecipitation-qPCR and transient analysis showed ABI directly binds GS11/AN060 promoter to activate transcription. AN060 reduced ABA sensitivity and Gl-induced ABA accumulation, and ABI was reduced in AN060 lines. The sugar-ABA cascade induces AN060, but truncated AN060 attenuates ABA and signaling, resulting in insensitivity.
Researchers have investigated the role of cyclic di-GMP (c-di-G) signaling in Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a bacterium that regulates various behaviors such as biofilm formation and motility. They found that the c-di-G synthase gene, hD, is located near the hB and flagellar genes and controls biofilm and motility through interaction with the anti-sigma factor hA. The rewiring of c-G signaling into the h pathway relies on the interaction between hD and hA and control of h localization at the cell poles. The study shows that h cannot complement the lack of h in the h background, supporting this model. The acquisition of h in P. aeruginosa and reorganization of hD, hB, hA, and flag and chemotactic genes form a novel entity controlling motility and biofilm. This reveals a scenario on the evolution of c-G signaling. A single DGC can transmit c-G and trigger a subset c-regulated behaviors, avoiding cross-talk through interaction with a molecular network regulating P. aerugin behaviors, the h pathway. The pathway controls biofilm, twitch, swimming, swarming, and chemotaxis in P. H and hD contribute to h-dependent bioformation, but have different impact on h-mediated motility. They act distinct in the c-G network controlling P. A mutant is defective in bio and hyper-swarming, while defect in swimming or twitch is observed. A local action of h at the pole is proposed. Two Ds, h and Sad, intersect the same regulatory G/R in hierarchical order. The cascade contributes the c-G necessary for P bioformation. H subsequently binds anti-sigma FlM, inducing flagellar expression. In absence h or unphosphorylated, acts as kinase phosphorylating h. This results decrease swarming and increase bioformation observed. The control P bio by h occurs reduction levels RY small RNA.
Researchers investigated how humans learn and generalize visuomotor mappings, or associations between visual cues and motor responses, in a rapid pointing task. Participants learned to point to targets with varying shapes that were morphed between circular and spiky, with different visuotor mappings for each shape. Feedback was provided with horizontal offsets dependent on the target shape, requiring participants to use different visom mappings to hit the target. After training, performance was tested without feedback on novel shapes not learned. Two hypotheses were tested: explicit extraction of the relationship between shape and visom mapping and generalization, and an implicit Bayesian model predicting categorization. Results showed participants applied the mapping to the most similar trained shape, consistent with the Bayesian model. The model also predicted slower learning with increased training pairs, confirmed by results. A correspondence was found between the model and results, suggesting it as a mechanism for learning multiple visom mappings.
Researchers investigated the relationship between climbing fiber bursts and subthreshold oscillations in the inferior olivary nucleus, a key input to the cerebellum. Climbing fibers are believed to convey timing information for motor commands and learning, causing large-or-all action potentials in cerebellar Purkin cells, silencing them for a brief period. Empirical evidence suggests climbing fibers can transmit bursts of spikes following olary somatic spikes, increasing information transfer to the cerebell. A three-compartment model of the olary cell was used to examine factors determining climbing burst size. Findings indicate phase dependency of burst size is present but limited, with charge flow between soma and dendrite a major determinant. This suggests phenomena like cell synchrony can affect climbing burst through dendritic junction coupling between olary cells. The cerebellum relies on two inputs: mossy fibers and climbing fibers, with the latter carrying sensory information. It's proposed variability in olary spike shape allows transmission of more information than expected. Phase dependency of CF size and somatic spike count enables coarse encoding of temporal information. The model predicts phase dependency in a limited range of ST amplitudes and cell ensembles. IO cells fire at 1 Hz, limiting spike coding over multiple events, making machine learning less accurate. A deeper understanding of IO electrophysiology is needed to understand what it can transfer to the cerebell. The model predicts correlation between ST phase and spike count, consistent with Mathy et al. A quantitative estimate is required for cerebell models, hard to explain with IO data due to low firing rate. Simulations mimicking Mathy's experiment with 5 Hz ST imposed on the cell and control experiments with no current were run.
A computational model of liver metabolism has been developed to understand the regulation of iron in the body. Iron is essential for life but can be toxic in excess, and the liver plays a key role in maintaining safe levels. Misregulation is linked to various diseases, and understanding iron metabolism has led to a detailed map of its fate in the body. However, a quantitative understanding of how its components interact to produce regulation remains elusive. The model includes core components and was constructed based on known mechanisms and kinetic properties from publications. It was validated by comparing results with published data and reproduced multiple findings. A simulation of an oral iron dose was compared to a clinical study and recreated the dynamics and scale of response. A disease simulation of hereditary hemochromatosis was created by altering a reaction mimicking a mutation, providing a quantitative understanding of overload. The model supports the liver's role as an iron sensor and provides a framework for further modelling to identify targets and design experiments to improve knowledge.

The model allows "what-if" experiments leading to hypotheses to be tested. A comprehensive liver metabolism model does not exist, previous models cover specific events, such as iron loading in ferritin. A map of mammalian metabolism provides an overview of molecular interactions in metabolism, including cell types. Existing models are at extremes of detail, specific and generic, to address hepatic regulation, a balance is desirable. The model aims to address this. Quantitative modelling in detail is hindered by lack of values for interactions. The model and results predictions about regulation should be investigated. It is the most detailed model to date, allowing description of regulation, and can link genotype to phenotype, demonstrated with hereditary hemromatosis. Due to limited data, other sources, particularly in vitro and animal, were integrated for parameterisation. This modelling constitutes a clinical approach, enabling data to improve understanding metabolism. The involved iron, transport, and regulation form a complex network. The liver has a role in regulation through secretion of hepcid. The hepatic network in sensing and regulation was analysed through a model and simulation.
Researchers have developed a coarse-grained model of the nuclear pore complex (NPC) to simulate nucleocytoplasmic transport. The model takes into account the polymeric nature of FG-repeats on the NPC structure and the hydrophobic affinity between kaps and FG domains. Brownian dynamics simulations predict the first-passage time of a 15 nm cargo-complex to be 2.6 ± 0.13 ms with an inverse Gaussian distribution. The cargo-com is primarily attached to the wall and interacts with the FG-layer as it passes through the channel. Kap-FG hydrophobic interaction is dynamic and fast, ensuring efficient transport. Almost all hydrophobic spots on kap-β are occupied during transport. In contrast, cytoplasm filament-deficient NPCs show high permeability to cargos, indicating a role in selectivity. The model captures transient interactions between FG-re and cargo on the order of nanoseconds, resolving uncertainties in nucleocytoplasm transport. Simulations probe the NPC to examine events leading to the N cycle. The NPC is the gateway for material across the nuclear envelope, regulating transcription and protecting genetic material in eukary cells. The model corroborates findings for different cargo sizes, showing radial distribution and trajectory of a 15 nm-complex. FG-re are central in proposed models, with distinctions from speculations about properties and arrangement within NPC and interaction with kaps during transport.
Researchers have developed an optimized protocol to determine the optimal infectious dose of a pathogen for non-human primate (NHP) models, which are commonly used to test interventions against human pathogens such as HIV, tuberculosis, and malaria. The goal is to find the dose that infects 50% of animals (ID50), with other doses like ID80 easily calculated from the same data. This minimizes the number of animals and resources while estimating ID50 within 1.5-fold of true value. Ethical and economic constraints require using few animals to achieve significant biological results. In HP models, a limiting dose is desired, infecting a fraction of animals at exposure. Limiting dose requires titration: too high leads to false negatives, too low to insufficient infections. A 2-fold error impacts experiment power. The protocol enrolls 15-25 animals, 3-5 rounds, and estimates ID within 40% of true. It's generalizable to any pathogen and model, but critical in HP where animal use is minimized. ID50 is determined by iterative exposures to pathogen dilutions, adjusting dose between rounds to achieve 50% infection. The relationship between probability of infection (P) and dose (D) is understood.
Researchers studied the adaptation of a first-order auditory neuron (AN2) in crickets in response to amplitude-modulated sound stimuli and found that it adapts with a time constant of 1.5 seconds, shifting the stimulus-response curve towards higher intensities and reducing responses to low-intensity sounds. They investigated whether this adaptation improves signal representation by comparing it to two hypotheses: infom, which maximizes information across the signal range, and selective coding, which enhances foreground signals while suppressing background. The team tested adaptation's effect on input-response curves with signals having two or three peaks in amplitude, which infom and selective predict conflicting changes. Using Bayesian analysis, they quantified response shifts and found slight decreases in slopes and higher absolute thresholds than inf's predictions. Contrary to inf, adaptation reduced information across the signal's range. Response changes also didn't align with selective, as loudest signal's information didn't increase but remained constant, with less transmitted about lower-intensity signals.
Researchers investigated the role of polybasic domains in prion protein (Pr) in the propagation of disease-associated prion (PrSc). They created prion proteins lacking one or both polybasic domains, expressed in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells, and used them as substrates in serial protein misfolding cyclic amplification (sCA) reactions. After 5 rounds of sCA, PrSc molecules lacking the central poly domain (Δ) formed, but surprisingly, in contrast to wild-type prions, Δ-PrSc prions could bind and induce conversion of poly domain mutant substrates into PrSc molecules. Notably, Δ-PrSc and poly domain PrSc displayed diminished or absent infectivity relative to wild Pr, despite seeding normal brain homogen sCA ability. These results suggest a dissociation between seeding ability and infectivity, indicating that PrSc propagation may not depend on a single mechanism, and Pr/Sc interaction through poly domains may be required for infectivity. Studies of Pr fragments showed poly domains interact PrSc, and to investigate this in full Pr, mutant proteins were designed lacking one or both domains, which were detergent-sol and properly trafficked. A novel capture assay found both domains required optimal PrSc binding. Reconstituted sCA with wild and mutant substrates showed poly domains required for efficient PrSc propagation. PrSc lacking either domain did not bind or propagate wild efficiently, suggesting both domains contact PrSc for efficient propagation. Using CHO expression, purification, and reconstitutedCA techniques, PrSc lacking poly domains were engineered, which propagated robustly in vitro, allowing assessment of poly domains in PrSc docking and propagation. Results suggest N-terminal poly domain participates in wildSc binding and propagation. sCA seeded with wild pr were carried out 3-5, Δ-PC molecules converted to resistant digestion under stringent conditions.
Researchers developed an inverse reinforcement learning (IRL) framework to identify the behavioral strategies used by animals to control their movement in an environment. They applied this framework to Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans) thermotaxis behavior, where worms move towards or away from a temperature gradient. The IR approach revealed that fed worms used both absolute and temporal temperature information to control their movement, employing two strategies: directed migration (DM) towards the temperature and isothermal (IM) migration along a constant temperature. In contrast, starved worms used only absolute temperature information to escape the temperature. The researchers also investigated the neural basis of these strategies by applying the method to thermosensory-deficient worms. The IR-based approach is useful for identifying animal strategies from behavioral data and can be applied to various studies, including decision-making in other organisms.
Researchers have sequenced the genome of Chrychromina tobin, a type of alga in the Prynesiales order, and analyzed its transcriptome over a 24-hour light-dark cycle. The genome is 59 megabases in size, 40% of which is protein-coding, and encodes 16,777 genes. Genes involved in fatty acid synthesis, modification, and catabolism show distinct expression patterns over the circadian photoperiod. The genome harbors a hybrid polyketide synth/non-ribosomal synthase complex, anti-microbial peptides, and proteins for multidrug and toxic compound extrusion. A new alga xanthodin was identified, along with two RuBisCOases shared across algal lineages. The Chrychromina tobin genome provides information on evolutionary history, ecology, and economic importance of algaes. This is the second alga with both nuclear and chloroplast genomes sequenced. The genome is compact, gene-rich, and shows lateral gene transfer events contributed to its evolution. The chloroplast has small, inverted repeats, unlike chlorytic chloroplasts, and unique genes. Chrychromina is the second alga with both genomes sequenced. The nuclear and chloroplast have identical coding for activases, indicating co-dependence on ecoh for survival.
Research has shown that breast cancers lacking estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone (PR), and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) markers belong to the Basal molecular subtype, which is often associated with defective BRCA1 and p53 pathways. Studies in mice demonstrate that inactivation of both BRCA and p53 pathways is sufficient to suppress cell death in mammary epithelium, and concomitant inactivation of all three pathways in mammary epithium has an additive effect on tumor latency and predisposes highly penetrant metastatic adenocarcinomas. These tumors are poorly differentiated and have histologic features common to human BRCA-mutated tumors, including heterogeneous morphology, metaplasia, and necrosis. Gene expression analyses show that tumors share attributes of Bas-like and Claudin-low signatures, two subtypes encompassed by broader triple-negative class defined by clinical markers.

BRCA1 is mutated in 20-30% of human breast cancers and defective pathway intermediates increase breast cancer risk. Nearly all Bas-like cancers with BR1 have conitant p mutation. Gerine BR1 mutation predisposes early breast cancers that are triple-negative and correlate with Bas-like in microarray. Our results show conitant inactivation of three tumor suppressor pathways in mammary has additive effect on latency and predis highly malignant carcinomas. Although BR1 accelerated tumorigenesis compared TP, we observed no statistical difference chromosomal number in tumors or without BR1, despite extensive CNs by others BR1/p53.

Mouse models mimic complexity of TNBC are invaluable for defining cellular behavior and rigorously triaging new candidates. Bas-like cancers inactivate three suppressors infamous roles familial: RB, p53, and BR1. Others argued Bas-like and Claudin signatures reflect progenitor and cell phenotypes, consistent BR mediating stem/progen maturation. Loss BR activity alter phenotype deregulation EMT inducer SL. CG analysis revealed CN consistent mutations human surveys breast.
Researchers conducted a study in Kampha Phet, Thailand to model the production of Aedes aegypti, the primary vector of deng virus, from 2004 to 2007. They collected 84,840 water samples from containers and used regression modeling to assess the effect of larval site density, access to piped water, and seasonal variation on container productivity. A varying-coefficients model accounted for differences in productivity between container types, and a hurdle model accounted for zeroes and overdispersion in pupal counts. The study found that the number and density of larval sites were primary determinants of Aegypti distribution and abundance. Productivity of containers increased with habitat density. An ecological approach accounting for site density is suitable for predicting Aegi population and developing control programs. Aedesegi primarily develops in artificial water containers, and recapture studies indicate adults do not disperse long distances. Containers in high-density areas are likely oviposition sites and used more frequently than isolated ones. Accounting for container characteristics, frequently used sites produce adults at higher rates. Most Aegi studies ignore spatial larval site density.
Researchers investigated the role of the Target of Rapamycin complex 2 (TOR2) in mediating gut-to-brain signaling in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that TOR2 coordinates larval development and adult behaviors in response to environmental cues and feeding state. During larval development, pherom, food, and temperature regulate the expression of daf-7 TGF-β and d-28 insulin-like peptide in sensory neurons to promote a decision between reproductive growth and entry into the alternate dauer larval stage. TOR2 acts in the intestine to regulate expression of d-7 and d-28, reflecting bacterial-dependent feeding status, providing a mechanism for integration of food with external cues in regulation of neuroendocrine expression. In the adult, TOR2 acts in intestine to modulate food-regulated foraging via PDF-2/PDF-1 neuropeptide-dependent pathway. Genetic variation affects food-dependent larval and adult phenotypes and identifies quantitative loci (QTL) associated with traits. Results suggest TOR2 as a hub for communication of feeding information from gut to brain, contributing modulation of neuronal function by state.
Researchers analyzed the transcriptional profiles of mouse embryonic stem (ES) cells and primordial germ cells to identify genes upregulated in pluripotent cells in vitro and in vivo. These genes were enriched for roles in transcription, chromatin remodeling, cell cycle, and DNA repair. A novel algorithm, Compoby, was developed to predict short DNA motifs regulating gene expression by combining aligned and non-aligned sequences with a probabilistic segmentation model. Compoby identified conserved motifs in upregulated pluripotent cells, which were active in undifferentiated ES and embryonic germ cells in a sequence-specific manner and acted as enhancers with an endogenous promoters. Importantly, activity was conserved in human ES cells. Transcription factor-Y bound one motif, differentially expressed during ES differentiation and required for cell proliferation. This study provides insights into transcriptional networks of pluripotent cells, suggesting systematic approach can be applied to mammalian species.
Researchers have characterized the structure of a soluble heterodimer complex between a variant of vesicular stomatitis virus N protein (N) lacking its 21 N-terminal residues (ΔN21) and a peptide of 60 amino acids (P) encompassing the molecular recognition element (Mo) of P that binds to RNA-free N. The complex crystallized in a decameric form was solved at 3.0 Å resolution, revealing how Mo folds upon binding to N and competes with RNA binding and polymerization. Small-angle X-ray scattering and NMR spectroscopy confirmed the binding of Mo and indicated that flanking regions remain flexible in the complex. The structure suggests a mechanism for initiation of viral RNA synthesis.

The N-binding region is localized in the N-terminal disordered region and contains transient helical elements that constitute a molecular recognition element (Mo) that folds upon binding to partner. The reconstituted NΔ-P complex is a model for viral N-P in agreement with previous studies. Crystal and NMR experiments show Mo of P adopts conformation upon binding to N, including residues 6-35, corresponding to fragment essential for maintaining N in soluble (aa 11-30).

The heterodimer N-P crystallized under conditions assembled a decamer of heteromers similar to previously crystallized decam N-RNA. The structure of decam form N-P reveals mechanisms N-binding Mo attaches to N. A single VSV N variant incapable of binding crystallized decam assembly empty molecules.
Researchers investigated the role of gap junctions in the fly's visual system, specifically in the vertical (VS) network, which processes visual information. Gap junctions, or electrical synapses, are a type of connection between neurons that allows for direct electrical communication. The study found that gap junctions enable the VS to efficiently encode the axis of rotation, θ, of the fly's motion, within 10 milliseconds of visual input onset. This efficiency is near-optimal, meaning it reaches the physical limits set by the visual input's statistical structure. The VS is connected to downstream pathways via a subset of cells, and the subpopulation with gap junctions encodes θ more efficiently than the whole network, and is robust to various signal-to-noise ratios. This efficient encoding is necessary for the fly's visually guided behavior, such as banked turns in evasive maneuvers. Gap junctions only impact the system's readout, not the dendritic input, suggesting neural circuit principles may be richer than previously thought. The study shows how specific connectivity leads to efficient sensory encoding.
Researchers have identified human-select glycoprotein ligand-1 (PS-1) as a receptor for enterovirus 71 (EV) entry and replication in leukocytes. PS-1 is a sialucin on the surface of leukocytes, serving as a high-affinity counterceptor for selectins and mediating leukocyte rolling on endothelium. The PS-1-select interaction requires sulfation of at least one of three tyrosines and adjacent O-glycan sial Lewis in the N-terminal of PS-1. To elucidate the molecular basis of PS-1-EV interaction, researchers generated PS- mutants and identified post-translational modifications critical for PS binding to EV. They expressed PS mutants in 293 cells and transfected cells were assayed for abilities to bind EV by flow cytometry. O-glycosylation on T57, critical for PS-select interaction, was not necessary for PS binding to EV. Site-directed mutagenesis at one or more tyrosine sulfation sites in N-terminal PS significantly impaired PS binding to EV. Inhibitor of sulfation, sodium, chlorate, blocked PS-EV interaction and inhibited PS-mediated replication in Jurkat cells in dose-dependent manner. Tyros sulfation, not O-gcosylation, in N-terminal of PS may facilitate entry and replication of EV in leukocytes.
Researchers investigated the therapeutic potential of mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitors in controlling Leishmanias, a global health problem affecting millions worldwide. Current treatments are limited by toxicity and emergence of resistant strains. Inhibitors of mTOR have shown anti-parasitic properties. This study tested three mTOR inhibitors, rapamycin, G-645, and K-379, in BAL/c mice infected with Leish major. Foot swelling and parasite burden were assessed, and cytokine production by splenocytes and phenotypic changes in draining lymph nodes evaluated. Treatment with clinically relevant doses of rapycin or G-645, but not K-379, reduced foot swelling and parasite load in lymph nodes. Importantly, rapycin did not kill promastigotes in vitro. IL-4 production by splenocytes from rapycin-treated mice was reduced, and IFN-γ:IL-4 ratio elevated, indicating a Th1-skewed cytokine profile. Expression of CD, an activation marker, on splenic and node CD+ and CD+ T cells was enhanced in rapycin mice. Findings suggest mTOR inhibitors may be used in leishias management, proposing beneficial effects from immunomodulatory properties.
Researchers have investigated the relationship between DNA uptake sequence (DUS) and its cognate receptor ComP during natural transformation in Neisser species. Transformation is a biological process where competent bacteria take up free DNA, incorporate it into their genomes, and become genetically altered. To prevent deleterious transformation by foreign DNA, competent species preferentially take up their own DNA containing specific US marks. The study found that Com is the long US receptor in Neisser species, paving the way for functional analysis of US-Com interdependence. By modulating Com levels in Neisser meningidis, they showed that enhancement of transformation in presence of US is dependent on Com, which also controls transformation in absence of US. Inner bases of US are essential, as single mutations led to impaired interaction with Com and transformation. Naturally occurring US variants in human Neisser commens differing from US by one or two bases were impaired for transformation of N meningidis. By showing Com from N subava comm specifically binds cognate US and mediates US-enhanced transformation in com mutant N meningidis, they confirm similar mechanism used by Neisser species to promote their or closely related DNA.
In the process of cytokinesis in yeast cells, a contractile actomyosin ring (CAR) and septum formation are crucial for cell division. While many CAR proteins have been identified, how they interact with septum enzymes to form the septum remains unclear. This study shows that cooperation between Pxl, a paxillin homolog required for ring integrity, and B1, the enzyme for linear (1,3) glucan synthesis and septum formation, is necessary for CAR anchorage to the plasma membrane before septation and cleavage. Without Pxl and B1, ring contraction fails and cell overgrowth occurs without septum formation. Pxl concentration at CAR increases during cytokinesis, dependent on the SH domain of protein Cdc15. B1 depletion in cells with cdcΔ3 allele causes ring disassembly and sept block, as in P1 lacking cells. P1 absence is lethal when C15 function is affected, causing CAR sliding with septum deposition along cortex. Findings indicate CAR anchorage through C15 and Pxl, concom B1 activity necessary for CAR and septum formation in yeast. B1 and P1 cooperate to maintain CAR position and integrity during cytokinesis, essential for septum synthesis. Rho GTPase inactivation is required for septum in Saccharomy cerevisiae. P1 deletion increases R1 activity, impeding septum upon B1 repression in px1 cells. C15 through SH, likely Pxl cooperates with B1 to confer stability CAR and form sept during cytokinesis.
A recent outbreak of glanders, a highly infectious zoonotic disease caused by the gram-negative bacterium Burkholderia malle, occurred in Bahrain. To investigate the outbreak, researchers applied high-resolution genotyping (multiple locus number of variable tandem repeats, MLVA) and whole-genome sequencing to B. malle isolates from infected horses and a camel. The results were compared to samples from an outbreak in the United Arab Emirates in 2004 and placed into a broader phylogeographic context based on previously published B. malle data. The Bahrain samples separated into two distinct clusters, suggesting a complex epidemiological background and involvement of multiple B. malle strains. The samples from Bahrain were more closely related to B. malle isolated from horses in the UAE 2004 than other B. malle, suggesting repeated importation to the region from similar sources. High-resolution genotyping and whole-genome analysis revealed phylogenetic patterns among samples. The relationship of Dubai/UAE B. malle populations may indicate a similar geographic origin yet to be identified for infecting strains. The emergence of glanders with worldwide horse trading poses a risk for human infections.
A cross-sectional study of 43 patients with cutaneous leishmanias (ACL) who did not respond to treatment with Glucime (pentavalent antimonial) was conducted in three Colombian National Army reference centers. The study aimed to characterize clinical and parasitological features of these patients. Leishmania braziliensis was the predominant species (95.4%) and 35% of parasites showed decreased susceptibility to Glucime in vitro. Lesion size and infectivity were negatively correlated with Glime susceptibility (Spearman r=-0.548 and -0.726 respectively). A negative correlation between lesion size and resistance was documented. L. braziliensis was the main species associated with treatment failure or relapse. The study suggests a second round of treatment with pentavalent derivatives may not be effective for L. brazili. Inclusion criteria were male patients with at least one round of Glime 20mg/kg/day for 20 days, experienced relapse or ATF. Female, incomplete or unsupervised treatment were excluded. The study was conducted from June 2013 to March 2014 in three reference centers for complicated cutaneous leishiasis (CCL) of the Colombian Army. The new form of CL tends to be more severe and longer than the old. In Colombia, majority ACL cases are by Leish Viannia (V) subgenus. Species in this group are associated with MCL and prone to failure than Leish Leish (L) sub. Leish intracellular parasites to U-937 was determined for Glime concentration. IC50 was the concentration that reduced survival Leish by half using CONF function. Epidemiological, clinical, and parasitological characteristics of Leish spp associated with lesions, such as species, in vitro susceptibility and infectivity were analyzed.
Researchers investigated the interplay between the biosynthetic pathways of siderophores and colactin genotoxin in Escheria coli, focusing on the role of 4-phosphopantin transferase (PT) enzymes. Two PTases, EntD and Clb, have been identified, with Ent being part of the core genome and Clb encoded on a pathogenic island pks. The p island is associated with high pathogenic island H in highly virulent E coli strains, which carries genes for yiniact synthesis except its cognate PT. The study demonstrated Clb can contribute to siderore synthesis, and inactivation of both Ent and Clb abolished virulence of extra-intestinal pathogenic E coli (Ex) in a mouse sepsis model. Presence of either functional Ent or Clb was required for Ex survival in vivo. This is the first report of multiple phosphantin-requiring pathways leading to distinct metabolites in a microorganism. The association of p island with H in highly vir E coli may be due to Clb being a promuous PT contributing to genoto and siderores.
Researchers have developed a probabilistic model for multiple sequence alignment that accounts for insertion and deletion events in addition to substitutions, given a phylogenetic tree, using a rate matrix augmented by a gap character. Starting from a continuous Markov process, they constructed a non-reversible (birth-death) evolutionary model for insertions and deletions, assuming events occur one residue at a time. This model was applied to phylogenetic inference by extending the program dnaml in phyl. Benchmarking on simulated and real ribosomal RNA data showed that the extended dnaml improved accuracy relative to ignoring gaps while retaining Felsen peeling algorithm efficiency. A fundamental task in sequence analysis is calculating probability of multiple alignment given phylogen tree and evolutionary model. Widely used phylogen models only account for residue events, not insertions and deletions. Felsen pe algorithm efficiently calculates ungapped alignment probability given model and tree, scaling linearly with length and number of sequences. Its economy makes it basis for maximum likelihood methods in phylogen inference tools, including phyl, paup, and others. The new model describes single residue evolution in column given phylogen tree, with total alignment probability as product of column probabilities.
