Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) infects the mucosal epidermis before entering nerve endings, but the mechanism of immunity initiation is not fully understood. In mice, epidermal Langerh cells (LCs) are the first dendritic cells (DCs) to encounter HSV, but CD103+ dermal DCs carry viral antigen to lymph nodes for presentation, suggesting cross-talk in the skin. This study compared topically HSV-1 infected human skin explants with biops of initial genital herpes to show LCs initially emigrate into the dermis, forming clusters with BD3+ dermal DCs and DC-S+ macrophages. HSV-expressing LC fragments were observed inside dermal DC/macrophages and BD3 dermal DC upregulated damaged uptake receptor CLEC9. No epidermal cells interacted with dermal DCs. LC isolated from skin infected with HSV-1 in vitro underwent apoptosis and were taken by BD3 dermal DC and S+ cells. A viral relay takes place where infected LCs undergo apoptosis and are taken by dermal DC for antigen presentation. This provides rationale for targeting these cells with mucosal or intradermal immunization.

HSV-1 infects epidermal LCs, which then emigrate into dermis, forming clusters with BD3 dermal DC and S macrophages. BD3 dermal DC upregulate damaged uptake receptor C9. No epidermal cells interact with dermal DC. LC isolated from skin infected HSV-1 in vitro undergo apoptosis and are taken by BD3 dermal and S cells. A viral relay occurs where infected LC undergo apoptosis and are taken by dermal for antigen. This provides rationale for targeting cells with muc or intrader immunization.
Researchers studied the formation of parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) in mouse macrophages infected with Leishmania major or Leish major amastigotes using multidimensional imaging. They found that PVs housing one or two L major amastigotes were tight-fitting, while PVs housing many L amazon amastigotes were giant. The study characterized PV biogenesis and remodeling in macrophages hosting amigotes of L major or amazon and loaded with lysotracker, a lysosotropic probe. Three features of Leish amigote-hosting PVs were documented: entry of lysacker into tight-fitting, fission-prone L major PV, decrease in macrophage vesicles during L major PV and amazon PV enlargement, and amazon PV remodeling homotypic fusion. Multidimensional imaging provided new insights into Leish species differences in PV biogenesis and could be useful for studying other intracellular microorganisms.
Researchers investigated how chromatin structure influences the use of homologous sequences as donors for repair in homologous-directed repair using the chicken cell line DT40 as a model. Immunoglobulin genes in DT40 undergo sequence diversification through gene conversion templated by pseudogene donors. The immunoglobulin V pseudogene array is characterized by histone modifications associated with active chromatin. The study demonstrated the importance of chrom structure for conversion using a regulatable system where heterochrom protein1 (Drosoph melanogaster var205) was expressed as a fusion to Escheria lactose repressor, tethered to polymerase operators within the pseudoλ array. Tethered HP diminished histone acetylation within pseudoλ and altered the outcome ofλ diversification, favoring non-templated mutations over templated mutations. Chromatin regulates homolog-directed repair. Histone modifications may contribute to genomic stability by preventing recombination between repetitive sequences.
Researchers investigated the role of cerebellar climbing fibers in motor learning, specifically in a saccadic paradigm, a model of cerebell-based motor learning. Contrary to the assumption that climbing fibers only convey immediate error information for synaptic modification, the study found a clear spike signature of error at the time of occurrence and a reverberation of this signature later, before new behavior manifestation. This challenges the concept that climbing fibers' role is confined to instant error communication. A previous studies on short-term sacc adaptation (STSA) showed patterns inconsistent with this idea, indicating a shift between populations indicating alteration of sacc amplitude by CS in primary interval. Simple spike (SS) and complex spike (CS) firing patterns in motor learning are established, suggesting CS effects might be secondary to error changes in SS discharge. To address this, a random sacc adaptation paradigm was used, avoiding gradual behavioral changes and error obscuring electrophysiological fingerprint. Results showed statistically significant changes in CS rate, reflecting past errors before upcoming sacc. This contrasts with previous findings on climbing's role in sacc learning, characterized by seemingly incompatible results, assuming information for future behavior improvement is conveyed by climbing fibers from inferior olive.
Researchers used a yeast model of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) to study the effects of TDP-43, a protein associated with the disease. They found that overexpression of TDP-43 leads to cell toxicity and reduced ubiquitin-dependent proteolysis, a process that breaks down misfolded proteins. Overexpression of the heat shock protein S1 (Hsp1) reduced T-43's effects on cell toxicity and proteolysis. This effect was influenced by the presence of the endogenous yeast protein Pin1. Overexpression of S1 altered T-43's aggregation pattern, but no physical association between S1 and T-43 was detected. The mammalian S1 homologue, DNA1, also reduced T-43 mediated toxicity in rodent cortical neurons, suggesting S1 and its homologues may have neuroprotective effects in ALS. T-43 aggregation is associated with ALS and other diseases, and overexpressed T-43 forms cytoplasmic aggregates in yeast and mammalian neurons. The study found that T-43 inhibits clearance of misfolded protein by the ubiquitin proteome, consistent with some T-43 toxicity caused by proteolytic dysfunction. Many heat shock proteins have distinct functions in mammalian cells, one of which, DNA1, has similarity to S1. Overexpression of WT and mutant T-43 with familial ALS in rodent neurons showed DNA1 extended survival. The yeast model identified S1 as a modifier of T-43 toxicity, and mammalian S1 homologues may have neuroprotective effects in ALS.
A study was conducted to investigate the parasite load and molecular diversity of Trypanosoma cruzi in patients with Chagas disease from different regions of Brazil. Sixty-five patients with chronic Chagas disease were recruited, aged 26-76 years, with a median of 54, being 34 females and 31 males. Thirty-five (53.8%) presented positive amplification by real-time PCR, 20 (30.7%) with the indeterminate form and 15 (23.1%) the cardiac form of the disease. The parasite median load for all positive patients was 2.54 [1.43-11.14] parasite/mL, ranging from 0.12 to 153.66. The load was significantly higher in patients over 70 years old, median 20.05 [18.29-86] parasite/mL. Using guanidine-ED blood spiked with T. cruzi strains, it was possible to genotype up to 0.5 parasite/mL with high specificity. Twenty-eight (80%) of patients with positive PCR identified T. cruzi DT, while 20% had partial results. Analysis showed prevalence of TVI, TII, and mixed TVI+II equal 40%, 17.1%, and 14.3%, respectively. Two were infected by TV and one co-infected by III+VI, all in chronic chasic cardiomyopathy stage, born in Bahia, northeast Brazil. T cruz genotypes compared to load showed elevated loads in infected II (median 7.56 parasite/mL) compared to VI (2.35/mL). However, frequency of cardiomyopathy was 50% in VI and 16.7% in II.
A study on rabies in bats was conducted in Guatemala between 2009 and 2011, as part of a larger pathogen detection program. A total of 672 bats from 31 species were sampled and tested for rabies, with a low prevalence of 0.3% of rabies virus (RV) detection. Viral antigens and infectious virus were isolated from the brains of two common vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus). RV was also isolated from oral swabs, lungs, and kidneys of both bats, whereas viral RNA was detected in all tissues by hemi-nested RT-PCR except the liver of one. Sequencing of the nucleoprotein showed both viruses were 100% identical, whereas glycoprotein sequencing revealed one nonsynonymous substitution (302T). The two vampire RV isolates were phylogenetically related to viruses associated with vampire bats in eastern Mexico and El Salvador. 7% of sera from 398 bats demonstrated RV neutralizing antibodies. The proportion of seropositive bats varied across troph guilds, suggesting complex intraspecific compartmentalization of RV perpetuation. This is the first report of RV isolation from bats in Guatemala, with a low prevalence of 0.3% among all bats, and 1.3% among vampire bats. The RV isolates were related to viruses in eastern Mexico and El Salvador, due to geographic proximity. Viral RNA was detected in all tissues except the liver of one bat.
Researchers investigated the role of lamin A in herpes simplex virus (HSV) replication and found that it plays a crucial role in targeting the viral genome to the nuclear periphery and reducing heterochromatin on viral promoters. In lamin-deficient (Lna/−) murine embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs), viral replication compartments were reduced in size and failed to target the periphery as in wild-type (WT) cells. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and immunofluorescence studies showed HSV associated with increased heterochatin in Lna/− MEFs. Results suggest lamin A is required for viral expression, replication, and growth, with greatest effect on replication at low multiplicity of infection. Lamin/C serves as a scaffold for DNA and protein complexes regulating euchatin and heterochatin modifications. The study provides evidence for lamin-dependent targeting of HSV to the periphery associated with reduction of heterochatin on lytic genes, suggesting a role in lamin maintenance of heterochatin and silencing.
Researchers have investigated the structure of the translocase of outer membrane (TOM) complex in hydrogenosomes, a metabolically anaerobic form of mitochondria found in the excav Trichomonas vaginalis. They found that the highly divergent β-barrel TvTom-40 forms a translocation channel to conduct hydrogenosomal import and is present in high molecular weight complexes with four subunits. Two of these subunits, Tom36 and Tom46, have heat shock protein (Hsp) and tetratopeptide repeat (PR) domains that bind hydrogenosomal proteins and likely function as receptors. A third subunit Tom22 has a short domain and conserved transmembrane segment but lacks a domain. The fourth protein hydrogenosomal outer membrane 19 (Hom19) has no homology. Data also indicate that TvOM is associated with sorting and assembly (SAM) 50 involved in β-bar assembly. Visualization of TvOM by electron microscopy revealed it forms three pores with an unconventional skull-like shape. Although TvOM lacks Tom7, phylogenetic profiling predicts Tom in freeiving excavates. The study suggests that the tripletore TOM complex, composed of conserved subunits, was present in the common eukotic ancestor (LECA) while receptors for substrate binding evolved in eukotic lineages.
Researchers conducted a comparative eQTL analysis of CD4+ and CD8 T cells to investigate the pathogenic implications of autoimmune mechanisms. They found that inappropriate or inadequate regulation of these cells contributes to the initiation and progression of multiple autoimmune and inflammatory diseases. The study highlighted the importance of biological context for regulatory variants, particularly in understanding the immune system's genetic regulation and cellular phenotypes. The analysis revealed type-specific regulation of genes associated with autoimmune diseases in CD+ and CD8 cells, including a trans-regulatory locus on chromosome 12q13.2 containing the rs101 SNP in the R26 gene. A missense variant in IL27 was identified, associated with type 1 diabetes, resulting in decreased protein activity and expression of IR1 and STAT in CD+ cells. The results indicate that eTL mapping in purified cells provides novel insights into polymorphisms and pathways associated with autoimmune diseases. A missense variant in IL27 was found to affect the STAT and IR1 pathway in CD+ cells, conferring protection against type 1 through inhibited expression of IR1 and STAT. The study also suggests IL may promote autoimmunity towards pancreatic islets via upregulation of the STAT pathway. Regulatory CD+ T cells have a central role in controlling autoimmune and inflammatory diseases. Genome-wide association studies identified thousands of SNPs associated with immune-related diseases. The eTL in CD and CD cells revealed multiple effects on genes associated with autoimmune, demonstrating high specificity and sensitivity despite smaller sample sizes.
In the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), socio-economic factors and cultural barriers hinder the uptake of screening and treatment for Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT). A qualitative study was conducted in Bandu and Kasa Oriental provinces, two provinces lagging behind in H elimination efforts, to understand these barriers. Semi-structured interviews and focus group discussions were held with current and former H patients, healthcare providers, and program managers of the National Trypanosomiasis Control Program. Interviews and discussions were recorded and analyzed using ATLAS software. Participants mentioned taboos to be respected for six months after H treatment: no work, no sex, no food, and no sun exposure. Violating these restrictions is believed to cause severe and deadly complications. These tabos are well-known and lead people to avoid H screening due to fear of observing them upon diagnosis. Originally aimed to mitigate melarsol's adverse effects, they are not evidence-based and obsolete with new safer drugs. Health providers must address community perspectives to keep abreast of transformations. 

In DRC, understanding these tabos and their origin is crucial for H control as coordinated by the National Trypaniasis Program. Rhodesian H. Medical advice transformed into tabos entertained by providers and community in these regions. They determine suboptimal uptake of H screening. Tabos might be abandoned with safer options, observed with NECT. Restrictions negatively affected participation and adherence. Their origin unclear, whether self or provider-imposed and basis. Given impact, perceptions were explored in depth. Conducted in provinces with highest H prevalence, where tabos identified. Not explored in lower prevalence provinces. Follow-up after H no longer recommended by WHO. Non-participation compromises control objectives.
A cross-sectional survey was conducted in 45 villages of Al-Gedrisha locality, Eastern Sudan, to estimate the incidence of visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in the area. Between May 5th and June 17, 2011, door-to-door interviews were conducted in 17,702 households with a population of 94,369 inhabitants. The crude mortality rate over 409 days was 0.13/10,000 people per day, and VL was a possible or probable cause for 19% of all deaths. The VL-specific rate was estimated at 0.9/100 per year. Medical teams examined 551 individuals with fever for at least two weeks, out of which 16 were diagnosed with primary VL. The incidence of VL over the past year was 7.0/100 persons per year, or 7.9/100 per year when deaths or possibly due to VL were included. 12.5% of the population reported a past VL episode. VL represents a significant burden in Eastern Sudan. Active case detection had a low yield in this setting with access to care, suggesting it may not be a priority for control in similar contexts.
Rates of Gyrase Supercoiling and Transcription Elongation Control Super Density in Bacterial Chromosome

Gyrase catalyzes negative supercoiling of DNA in an ATP-dependent reaction that condenses bacterial chromosomes into a compact nucleoid. The super density (σ) of prokaryotic DNA occurs in two forms: diffusible supercoil (σD) that moves freely around the chromosome in 10 kb domains, and constrained supercoil (σ) resulting from abundant proteins that bend, loop, or unwind DNA at sites. Diffible and constrained supercoils contribute equally to the in vivo super density of cells, σ=σ+σ. Unexpectedly, Escherichia coli has a 15% higher level of σ compared to Salmonella enterica. To decipher mechanisms that change diffible supercoil density of chromosomes, strains of Salmonella were analyzed using a 9 kb supercoil sensor inserted at positions around the genome. The sensor contains a lac operon flanked by resolvase binding sites and can monitor supercoil and transcription elongation in WT and mutant strains. RNA transcription caused supercoiling to increase upstream and decrease downstream of highly expressed genes. Excess supercoiling was relaxed by Top I and gyrase replenished supercoil to maintain an equilibrium. Strains with gyrase mutations at permissive exhibited supercoil losses from 30% of levels to total σ at most locations. Coil were influenced by transcription addition rifampic (Rif) caused density to rebound throughout chromosome. Gyrase mutants caused supercoil also reduced elongation throughout genome. The link between polymerase elong speed and gyrase turnover suggests bacteria with growth may generate higher densities than slow species.

Three results show the density of Salmon DNA determined by mechanism links catalytic gyrase to elongation rate. TS of Gyr caused broad and depletion supercoil throughout genome. Effect was reversed by blocking transcription Rif. Most striking, gyr mutation caused fall to 1% while recombination 11 in upstream domain. Supercoil levels rose and fell opposite ends highly transcribed operon cells permissive. We measured chromosome levels and elongation using sensors at positions covering 6 domains. At 30 WT Salmon, elongates 45-60/sec different points genome, causing rotations 4-6 super/sec. Gyrase supercoils DNA 4-5/sec 30 (Rinsky and Higgins). Top removes super at single studies.
Researchers investigated the role of parasitophorous vacuole (PV) expansion in the intracellular growth of Leishmania amazonensis, a protozoan parasite that causes cutaneous leishmaniasis. They found that host cells infected with L. amazonensis upregulate the transcription of LYSTBeige, a protein previously shown to regulate lysosome size. Mutations in LYSTige caused PV expansion and enhanced L. amazon replication, while Lige overexpression led to small PV that did not sustain parasite growth. Treatment of Lige-expressing cells with vacolin reversed this phenotype, expanding PV and promoting growth. In contrast, E-64 reduced PV size in L-ige mutant cells and inhibited L amazon replication. Large PV appeared to protect parasites from oxidative damage, as inhibition of nitric oxide synthase had no effect on amazon viability within large PV, but enhanced growth within Lige-induced small PV. The study suggests that upregulation of Lige in infected cells functions as a host response to limit parasite growth by reducing PV size and inhibiting intracellular survival.
Researchers have developed a zebraf model of Allan-Her-Dandy syndrome (AH), a genetic disorder characterized by developmental delay, intellectual disability, muscle hypotonia, and spastic paraplegia, and disturbed thyroid hormone (TH) parameters. The study aimed to determine the pathophysiological mechanisms of AH by generating a monocarboxyl transporter 8 (M8) mutant zraf using zinc-finger nuclease (Z)-mediated gene editing. Elimination of M8 decreased TH levels, but not expression of other TH-related genes. Similar to patients, M8/− larvae exhibited neurological and behavioral deficiencies. High-throughput behavioral assays showed reduced locomotor activity, altered response to light and dark transitions, and increased sleep. These deficiencies were associated with altered myelin genes and neuron-specific circuit formation. Time-lapse imaging revealed reduced filopodia and axon branching in sensory neurons, decreased synaptic density in motor neurons. TH analogs restored myelin and axon growth in M/− larvae, suggesting M8 regulates neural assembly, mediating sensory and motor performance. Administration of TH analogs during development may reduce neurological damage in AH patients.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a widespread virus that primarily affects newborns and immunocompromised or immunosuppressed patients. It infects various cell types using distinct entry pathways involving different forms of the g/g glycoprotein: g/gL/g, gL, and g/UL-131, as well as the fusion glycoprotein g. The minimal fusion machinery for cell-cell fusion is g/g and g. This study demonstrates that CMV g and g/g form a stable complex early after synthesis in the absence of other viral proteins. g/g can interact with g mutants unable to mediate cell fusion. g-g/g complexes make up to 16-50% of total g in CM virus particles. In contrast, small amounts of g/gL and g/UL-131 complexes are associated with g. Herpesviruses express g and g/g molecules, and most models suggest g/g interacts g to mediate fusion, although there is no direct evidence. For herpes simplex virus (HSV-1), it has been suggested that after binding g/g binds g either before or coincident with membrane fusion. This study's results have implications for these models, demonstrating CM g and g/g form stable g-g complexes are incorporated in virions without receptor or membrane.
Researchers have identified a nuclear-encoded gene, Gimap, which regulates the segregation of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in leukocytes, a type of white blood cells. The study used a heteroplasmic mouse model to demonstrate that Gimap, an outer membrane protein, influences the rate of mtDNA segregation in hematopoietic tissues. Gimap is crucial for cell development and survival, suggesting that leukocyte survival may be a key factor in regulating mtDNA variants and modulating mitochondrial diseases. The study found that mtDNA segregation in hematopoiet tissues is a complex trait regulated by age, independent of mt copy number, and that altered splicing of the CASTi allele changes the G3 protein sequence, but not the transmembrane domain, which localizes it to the outer membrane. G3 regulates mtDNA segregation in hematopoiet tissues, but its role in younger mice is unclear. The protein does not directly interact with mtDNA, as it does not span the membrane to facilitate interaction. Retroviral overexpression of G3 in embryonic fibroblasts had no effect on heterlas levels, implying a cell-specific pathway is required for mt segregation. Mitochondrial copy regulation has been proposed to influence mtDNA segregation and human mutations.
Researchers investigated the incubation period of Buruli (BU) caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans in Victoria, Australia, where the disease is geographically restricted and primarily affects residents of endemic areas. However, a significant proportion of cases are acquired by visitors to these regions. A previous study on the Bellarine peninsula estimated a mean incubation period of 4.5 months, but cases declined and a new endemic area emerged on the Mornington peninsula. A retrospective review of 443 cases between 2013-2016 identified 20 short-term visitors, with a mean incubation period of 143 days (4.8 months), similar to the previous estimate of 135 (4.5) days. Despite the shift in exposure location, no association was found between incubation period and age, sex, exposure duration, or location of lesion. The study confirms the incubation period of BU in Victoria to be 4-5 months, guiding clinicians and suggesting similar transmission modes in different regions. The estimate of 4.8 months (2-9) months for BU confirms a previous study from a different location, indicating similar transmission modes in Victorian regions.
Researchers have identified a protein in the Toxoplas parasite that is related to the human Niemann-Pick Type 1 protein (NPC), which plays a crucial role in cholesterol regulation and lipid trafficking. The protein, named TCR1, shares significant identity with human NPC and contains residues implicated in human disease. TCR localizes to flattened vesicles beneath the parasite's plasma membrane, unlike mammalian NPC, which localizes to endo-lysosomes. When expressed in mammalian NPC mutant cells, TCR restores cholesterol and GM1 clearance from endo-lysosomes. Disrupting TCR in the parasite results in normal cholesterol levels but overaccumulation of cholesteryl esters, sphingomyins, and ceramides. The mutant parasites exhibit abundant lipid storage bodies and membranous tubules derived from parasitoph vacuoles. They replicate faster in vitro and are more virulent in mice than the parental strain. These findings suggest TCR's role in lipid homeostasis in Tooplas is to control intracellular lipid levels, leading to stimulation of lipid biosynthesis and division.
Ophthalmoacromelic syndrome (AS), also known as Waarden anophthalmia, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by bilateral anophthalmia and postaxial oligodactyly. Homozygosity mapping and targeted mutation analysis of locus 14q24 identified homozyg mutations in SMOC (SPARC-related calcium binding 1) in eight unrelated families. Four mutations are nonsense, frameshift, and missense, with missense mutations in the Thyrogulin-1 (T1) domain of the protein. The ortholog in mouse, Smoc, shows site and stage-specific expression during eye, limb, craniofac, and somite development. A targeted preconditional gene-trap mutation of Smoc (Sm1tm1) reduces mRNA to 10% of wild-type levels, resulting in highly penetrant hindlim postax oligodactly in homozyg mutant (Sm1/t1) animals. Eye malformations, most coloma and cleft occur in a proportion of Sm1/t1/t1 embryos. Loss of Sm-1 results in a convincing phenocopy of the disease. SM-1 is a mammalian paralog of Drosoph Pentone, an inhibitor of decaplegic. The orth in Xenopus, Sm- also functions as BMP antagonist in early embryogenesis. Loss of BMP antagon during mammalian development provides a plausible explanation for limb and eye phenotypes in humans and mice.
Researchers have identified a protein called TRIM22 as a key mediator of the antiviral activity of Type 1 interferons against HIV replication. They used transcription profiling to identify genes induced by interferon treatment and found TR22 as one of the most upregulated genes. Overexpression of TR22 inhibited HIV replication, confirming previous studies. To assess the role of TR22 under natural conditions, they compared the effects of interferon in cells depleted of TR22 using RNAi and found HIV release was significantly increased in knockdown, indicating TR22 acts as an antiviral effector. Further studies showed TR22 inhibited budding of virus particles containing Gag, indicating G was the target of TR22. TR22 did not block release of ML or EIA G particles. Inhibition was associated with cytoplasmic staining of G rather than accumulation at the plasma membrane, suggesting TR22 disrupts trafficking. Mutational analyses of TR22 showed catalytic amino acids Cys and Cys of the R domain required TR22 antiral activity. The data disclose a pathway by which Type 1 interferons obstruct HIV replication.
Researchers investigated the role of parasitic wasps in stabilizing the fig-pollinator mutualism, a symbiotic relationship between fig trees (Ficus) and their specific pollinators (Agonid wasps). In monoecious figs, pollinators oviposit into inner ovules, while avoiding outerules, suggesting a mechanism for mutual stability. However, the reason for this avoidance was unknown. The study found that in Ficus rubosa, outer ovules are vulnerable to parasitic wasps ovip from outside the sycon, with risk decreasing towards the center where innerules provide a safe space for pollinator offspring. This gradient in offspring viability likely selects pollinators to avoid outerules, forcing wasps to focus on a subset, reducing galling rates. This mechanism may contribute to mutualism persistence, independent of plant defenses against pollinator oviposition or physiological constraints preventing ovip in all ovules. In most Ficus species, sycon receive foundresses exploit more ovules than produce wasps, leaving unexplained seed production. Three hypotheses failed to explain stability, suggesting key lies in pollin favoring innerules ovip. Variance in morphology and externally ovipiting parasitic wasps indicate potential for parasitic contribution to stability. The fig-poll mutualism is an obligate, with wasps pollinating trees and providing resources for offspring. Parasitic wasps may contribute to maintenance by selecting innerules due to reduced parasitism. The study shows pollin was gain fitness by selecting innerules due to reduced vulnerability.
Researchers conducted six controlled growth trials on an interspecific Setaria italica x Setaria viridis recombinant inbred line population to investigate the genetic and environmental factors influencing plant height. Non-destructive measurements enabled monitoring of plant height throughout the life cycle in both field and controlled environments revealed that height is reduced under water limitation and high planting density, and affected by growth environment (field vs. chamber). Results support a model where height is a heritable, polygenic trait, with major loci influencing height independent of environment. Genetic loci contributing to height change dynamically throughout development, and reduction in water limited environments is due to delayed progression of genetic program establishing height in Setaria. In this population, alleles from weedy S. viridis parent increase height, while domesticated S. italica parent alleles collectively increase height in later development. Combining field and controlled analysis with genetics dissected genetic and environmental components of height in Setaria. Genetic components determining height in R population exhibit strong canalization, but loci influenced by temporal and environmental factors. A chronological model of height may explain differences in parental lines grown in controlled versus field settings. Experiments in controlled settings before effects of alleles at positions 2 and 9 may not materialize due to growth constraints. Thirty-seven QTL associated with height development in Setaria R population were identified across twelve experiments varying water and density. Analysis suggests known Poaceae genes account for a fraction of loci.
A study was conducted in the Ncolia sub-region of the Pantanal, Brazil to investigate the circulation of flaviviruses, including Ilus virus (ILV), which was previously detected through serological evidence in horses. Between 2005 and 2009, at least three flaviviruses, including ILV, circulated in the Pantanal. Mosquitoes were collected from the same region in 2009 and 2010 and tested for infectious virus and flaviral RNA. A pool of 50 non-engorged female Aedes aegypti tested positive for ILV by culture and real-time RT-PCR, indicating a minimum infection rate of 2.5 per 1,000. The full genomic sequence exhibited 95% identity to the only available ILV genome. The study confirms IL circulation in the Pantanal. The region hosts diverse wildlife and hematophagous arthropods, favoring zoonotic arvirus circulation. Despite scarce data on arvirus vectors, local mosquito species reported as vectors have been found in north and south Pant. A 2009, flavirusurvey in equines detected past infection with increasing seroprevalence, Cipore virus, West virus, Louis encephalitis, and IL. The Pant is a seasonally flooded 140,000 km. The reported prevalence of IL in horses combined with IL isolation in mosquitoes confirms an arv of medical importance.
A preclinical study was conducted to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and pharmacokinetics of single-dose mectin (MO) as a new oral treatment for scabies compared to two-dose ivermectin (IVM) in a porcine model. Scabies is a common dermatological condition with a significant public health burden, and current treatments are insufficient due to emerging drug resistance. MO, with a more favorable pharmacological profile, may be a promising alternative. Twelve pigs were randomly assigned to receive MO (0.3mg/kg once) or IV (0.2mg twice) or no treatment. Treatment efficacy was assessed by mite count, clinical lesions, pruritus, and ELISA-determined anti-S scabei Ig antibodies. Plasma and skin pharmacokinetic profiles were determined. At day 14 post-treatment, all MO-treated pigs were mite-free, while only two IV-treated were. MO efficacy was 100% and unchanged until study-end (47), compared to 62% (26-100) for IV, with one IV-treated remaining infected until 47. Clinical scabies, pritus, and anti-Sabei Ig antibodies disappeared in all MO-treated but 75% IV-treated. MO persisted 9 times longer than IV in plasma and skin, enabling long-lasting efficacy. The study demonstrates single-d MO was more effective than consecutive IV, supporting MO as a therapeutic approach for scabies.
Researchers investigated the minimal peptoglycan (PG) synthesis machine in Staphylococcus aureus, a Gram-positive pathogen known for its antibiotic resistance and hospital prevalence. They deleted seven of the nine genes encoding PG enzymes from the S. aureus genome, resulting in a strain capable of PG synthesis catalyzed by only two proteins, penicillin-binding protein (PBP1) and bi-functional BP2. However, this strain became highly susceptible to cell-wall targeting antibiotics and displayed impaired virulence in Drosophila infection, dependent on peptoglycan receptor PGRP-SA. The study shows that S. aureus can grow with two active PG synthesizing enzymes, indicating redundancy in vitro and identifies the minimal PG machinery of S. aureus. In clinically relevant environments, expend PG enzymes play a role in pathogenicity and antibiotic resistance of S. aureus. The researchers constructed a S. aureus strain with minimal PG enzymes required for survival, targeting the final stages of synthesis for antibiotic development. Interactions between PG enzymes have been suggested, but not biochemically confirmed. A mutant S. aureus (MIN) was generated by deleting seven genes with PG activity. The study demonstrates the plasticity of PG process, with S. aure synthesizing PG using two proteins, BP1 and BP, performing transpeidation and transglyylation. The strain MIN was viable in rich and minimal medium, with deletion of seven genes having little effect on viability, growth, morphology, or PG in rich medium.
Burkholderia pseudalle is a saprophytic bacterium that can infect humans, causing meloidosis, a difficult-to-manage disease. Despite proper diagnosis and treatment, mortality rates range from 20% in Northern Australia to 40% in Thailand. Little is known about how B. pseudalle infects, invades, and survives within hosts, and the role of nutrients like iron in its pathogenesis. It was assumed B. pseudalle used iron-acquisition systems found in other bacteria, such as siderophores. However, a clinical isolate with a chromosomal deletion of the malleactin cluster, encoding its major-affinity siderore, was still virulent in a murine meloid model, suggesting other iron-acquisition systems contribute to virulence. This study deleted major siderore mactin (ba) and pyelin (p) clusters in strain 171b, revealing residual siderore activity unrelated to known Burkia siderores, not due to increased chelators like citrate. Deletion of hem uptake loci, hmu and hem, showed Hmu required for hem and hem utilization, and could not complement H deficiency. Prolong incubation of h hem mutant in hem-containing medium yielded variants able to utilize hem and hem, suggesting alternate pathways for these sources. Lacterrin was dependent on mact, not pyelin synthesis/uptake. A pchmu h hem quadruple could use ferritin as source and was lethal in acute murine meloid model. Data suggest B pseudalle may employ ferritin-iron pathway to sustain in vivo.
Researchers have developed a new tool called COMM (COnsensus Metabolic Model GENeration) to improve the accuracy and usability of genome-scale constraint metabolic models (GSMs) by reconciling inconsistencies between multiple models of the same organism. These models are comprehensive representations of cellular function, integrating thousands of metabolites, reactions, and genes. However, their usability is often hindered by inconsistencies, particularly when combining multiple models. COMM automatically identifies and resolves these inconsistencies, creating a more accurate and comprehensive consensus model. Tests on four organisms showed that automatically generated models were predictive and increased knowledge representation coherence. This tool is particularly useful for complex scenarios where manual curation does not scale, such as eukaryotic organisms, microbial communities, and host-pathogen interactions.

 Genome-scale metabolic models are both knowledge repositories and predictive models. A consensus model should be more comprehensive than individual models due to shared and unique parts, and accurate due to reconciliation of inconsistencies. COMM identifies similarities, dissimilarities, and complements of metabolic networks based on classification problems arising during integration and novel algorithms to resolve. Identifying similar reactions in different compartments is difficult, but an extension could progress this by combining metabolite information prior to matching. COMM bridges automation and high-quality manualuration for consensus generation.

Automatically generated models have higher predictive power than manually curated models and comparable to manually constructed models. COMM increases biological coherence while maintaining predictive power, crucial for usability and reliability to elucidate interactions.
Researchers investigated the role of cartilage matrix in regulating chondrocy maturation and perichond development in zebraf mutants. They isolated a class of mutants with decreased cartilage and increased perichral bone, and identified mutations in two genes, famb and xylosyltransferase1 (xt), which encode enzymes for proteoglycan synthesis. Mutants lacked wild-type levels of chroit sulfate, abundant in cartilage and perichral bone, and initiated perichral formation earlier than wild-type siblings. Primary chrocy defects may induce the phenotype secondarily because mutant chrotes initiated maturation, showing increased expression of markers such as run2, collagen 1a, andh coorths, andha suppressed perichral bone in mutants. Ultrastructural analyses demonstrated aberrant matrix and cellular features of chro hypertrophy in mutants. Molecular and genetic studies showed chro Ih expression induced perichral in mutants. However, famb mutants exhibited perichral while loss of HG in chrotes. Data suggest defective cartilage synthesis alters transcription factors determining chro maturation, changing perichral timing. Mutations in famb and xyyl1 are associated with human diseases. Biochemical and histochemical analyses revealed CSP defects in mutants. Rescue experiments, expression, ultrastructural, and mutational analyses argue mutantrotes undergo precocious mat, inducing perichral. Findings are consistent with direct action inrotes producing mutant cartilage, indirectly causing elevated perral.
Researchers investigated the role of Topoisomerase II (Top) in the separation of heterochromatic regions during meiosis in Drosoph melanogaster females. They found that knockdown of Top II by RNA interference (RNAi) in later stages of meiosis resulted in defects in separation of heteroch regions after spindle assembly. Heteroch regions of achias and chias chromosomes failed to separate during prometaph I and metaph I, and were stretched into long projections with centromeres localizing near tips. Bipolar spindles formed in Top RNA-express oocytes, but achias chromosomes failed to move towards poles during promaph I. Bothias and chias chromosomes displayed defects in orientation. Euchromatic regions separated earlier in prophase, and no defects were observed in their separation upon Top knockdown at midphase. Embryos from Top RNA-express females failed to initiate mitotic divisions. The study suggests Topois II resolves heteroch DNA entang during meiosis, and these entang must be resolved to complete meiosis.
Researchers conducted a field study to evaluate the effectiveness of using deltamethrin-impregnated collars as a public health measure to prevent canine visceral leishmaniasis (CV) in a highly endemic area in Brazil. The study was conducted in two areas: an intervention area where seronegative dogs were collared and a control area with conventional CV control measures. Dogs were evaluated every 7-8 months for two years, with seropositive dogs removed and seronegative dogs included. In the first serological survey, seroprevalence was similar in both areas. At the second evaluation, significant reductions in serrevalence were seen in both areas, with 6.0% in the intervention and 11.0% in the control. The estimated relative risk (RR) indicated protection against CV in the intervention area. Although CV incidence did not differ, a tendency was observed in the control, possibly due to low seroconversion or loss to follow-up. Deltamethrin-impregnated collars likely provide protection over time in endemic areas, representing a challenge for local zoonosis control, indicating need for adjustments, including collar design.
Researchers investigated the notion that the mammalian X chromosome's gene content is biased due to limitations on gene expression caused by its haploid expression. They analyzed data from the Encyclopedia of DNA (ENCODE) and Functional Annotation of Mammalian Genome (FANT5) projects and found that human X-linked genes have lower maximal expression levels than autosomal genes, with an average expression three times lower on the X chromosome than autosomes. Autosome-to-X retroposition events are associated with lower maximal expression of retrogenes on the X than X-to-autosome retrogenes on autosomes. X-linked genes have a lesser increase in expression than autosomal ones compared to the human-chimpanzee ancestor, highly expressed but not lowly expressed. The "traffic jam" model explains the lower breadth of expression for genes on the X and Z chromosome, as broad expression is associated with high expression. Highly tissue-specific genes are rare on the X, and broadly expressed genes on X tend to be lowly expressed, indicating the trend is shaped by maximal expression not breadth. A limit to maximal expression explains biased tissue profiles of X-linked genes. Tissues with highly expressed genes (e.g., secretory, structural) are in which expression is rare on X. This trend cannot be accounted for by alternative models of biased expression. The notion that it's hard for genes on the X to be highly expressed due to transcription jams provides a rationale for features of X's content, expression, and evolution.
A recent study investigated the prevalence and population structure of Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) in Baka Pygmies, a subgroup of Pygmies from Cameroon, and compared it to non-Baka agriculturalists. Gastric biopsies were obtained from 77 Baka and 101 non-B individuals and cultured for H. pyl. Unexpectedly, Baka showed a significantly lower H. pyl infection rate (20.8%) than non-B (80.2%). Multilocus haplotypes were generated for each H. pyl isolate, but no Baka-specific lineages were identified, with most assigned to hpAfrica or hp1. The hpAfrica population, associated with the Nilo-Saharan language expansion, was divided into East and West African subpopulations, and a new hp1 subpopulation, mainly among Cameroonians, supported eastern and western Bantu expansions. An age-structured model showed low H. pyl prevalence among Baka achievable in a few hundred years, suggesting demographic factors like small size and low life expectancy led to eradication. Baka were either H pyl-free or lost lineages during past fluctuations. Coalescent simulations and phylogenetic inference showed B almost certainly acquired extant H pyl through contact with agricultural neighbors. H pyl prevalence was high in 178 Cameroonians, including 77 Baka and 101 non-B, with 46.8% Baka male and 21.8% non-B male. The population structure of H pyl infecting B and Pyies was unknown, with Bantu agriculturalists having high rates but unknown structure. H pyl from non-B of multiple ethnic groups was screened to quantify gene flow between hunter-gather and agriculturalists. H pyl from agricultural neighbors, acquired Bantu language, were tested in a genetic study of pyl infecting B, a subgroup of Western Pyies in Cameroon. B inhabit rainforests of Cameroon and Gabon, one of largest Py groups with 30-40,000 population.
Dengue virus NS5 (NS) is a highly conserved non-structural protein responsible for capping methylation and replication of the flavivirus genome, and interacts with host proteins to modulate immune responses. Although replication occurs in the cytoplasm, a characteristic of DENV2 NS is its localization to the nucleus with unclear role in replication or pathogenesis. This study examined NS of DENV1 and 2, which exhibit most difference in localization, employing combination of functional and structural analyses. Gene swapping between D1 and 2 NS identified the C-terminal 18 (C18) residues sufficient to direct protein to cytoplasm or nucleus, respectively. Low-mic affinity between NS C18 and importin-alpha (Imp) allowed complex purification and crystallization at 2.2 resolution. Structure-guided mutational analysis of this region in GFP-NS clones D1 or 2 and D2 infectious clone reveal residues for NS subcell localization. Notably, transformation by Pro884 allows Imp binding and mutating Pro to Thr, present in D1 NS, results mislocalization NS to cytoplasm without virus fitness. In contrast, mutation at R888, conserved in flaviruses, results in non-viable virus, and R mutation to severely attenuated phenotype, though NS in nucleus. R forms bond with Y conserved flavir. Data suggest conserved function C18, possibly RNA interactions critical replication, independent subcell localization.
Researchers have developed and field-tested an integrated mapping protocol for neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) called the Integrated Threshold Mapping (IT) Methodology, which aims to determine whether a threshold for public health interventions has been reached in a given area. The protocol is designed to be resource-efficient and uses World Health Organization (WHO) recommended indicators for each disease in specific age groups. The study tested the protocol by comparing it to current WHO methodologies for each disease in one district in Mali and Senegal. Results showed that IT reached the same conclusions as WHO regarding initiation of public interventions for trach, LF, and STH, but resulted in more targeted recommendations for schistosiasis. IT was practical and demonstrated cost-effective compared to standard, non-integrated WHO methodologies. This integrated tool could facilitate implementation of programs in endemic countries.

The ITM methodology does not provide prevalence figures, its purpose is to determine if a disease has reached threshold for public intervention by balancing epidemiologic rigor and practicality. It is logistically practical, cost-efficient and flexible. For schosiasis, the approach results in more targeted MDAs compared to district implementation by integrated NTD programs. The protocol uses age-specific disease indicators as recommended by WHO.

The study shows a novel integrated protocol to determine thresholds for public health interventions. The approach is practical, cost-efficient and flexible. For schias, our approach results in more MDAs compared to district implementation by integrated NTD.
In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the conserved phosphatase C14 is required for exit from mitosis and is anchored to nucleolar chromatin by the C1/Net protein until anaphase, at which time it is released into the nucleoplasm. Two poorly understood pathways promote C14 release: the FEAR (C fourteen early release network) and the MEN (mitotic network). Analysis of genetic interactions reveals a novel requirement for ubiquitination of histone H2 by the ubiquitin ligase Bre1 in cell-dependent release of C14 from nucleolar chrom when MEN is inactivated. This function of H2 ubiquination is mediated by activation of histone H methylation on lysines 4 and 79 (H3K4 and H3K79) but is not dependent on histone deacetylase (HD) Sir, which associates with C14 onolar chrom as part of the RENT complex. Additionally, a defect in C14 release is observed in cells lacking H3 lysine methylation (H3) and cells lacking HD recruited by this modification. These histone modifications represent unappreciated factors for accessibility and/or action onolar chrom of FEAR components.
Researchers have developed a new computational framework, GeneProgram, to identify and characterize functional gene expression programs in human cells. Gene addresses challenges in analyzing large datasets, including cellular heterogeneity, genetic variation, and uncertainty in sample numbers and populations, and temporal behavior. Gene uses Hierarchical Dirichlet Processes to organize tissues and genes into overlapping programs with consistent behavior, producing maps of expression sorted by generality scores. Using synthetic and real data, Gene outperformed popular analysis methods. Applied to a compend of 62 time-series expression datasets, Gene produced a map of 104 programs, many enriched for key pathways and NF-κB transcription factors. Gene discovered programs implicating surprising pathways, including Wnt and neurotransmitter receptors in response to infection. The map is expected to guide future experiments, with low generality genes as new targets and high generality maintaining physiological responses in disease. Gene is multipurpose and can be applied to novel data.
Human cytomegalovirus (CMV) drives epigenetic imprinting of the interferon-gamma (IFN) locus in NKGChi natural killer (NK) cells, a subset of innate immune cells that plays a crucial role in defense against CMV. Research showed that NKGChi NK cells in CMV seropositive individuals undergo epigen remodeling of the conserved non-coding sequence 1 (CNS1) of the IF locus, similar to memory CD8+ T cells and TH1 cells. The accessibility of CNS1 enhances IF- transcription activity in response to NKG2 and 2B engagement, leading to IF- production in NKG NK cells. Epigen imprinting of the IF locus is a hallmark and crucial mechanism driving stable IF expression in CMV-specific NK expansions, providing a basis for regulation of adaptive features in innate cells. 

NKGChi NK cells in CM+ individuals display epigen remodeling of IF CNS, similar to cytok-primed NK cells, previously described as memory-like cells, and share CNS configuration with TH1 cells. CNS is an enhancer of IF transcription in TH cells, especially in response to TCR triggering. To analyze epigen regulation of IF locus contribution to IF competence and stability in memory-like NK, NKGChi and cytok-prim cells showed open configuration at IF CNS, acting as enhancer of IF transcription in response to NKG and activating receptors engagement. Epigen imprint in CNS of IF locus is a hallmark of adaptive features and IF- in NK cells. Epigen remodeling accompanies adaptive features, demonstrating inflammatory and pathogen induce epigen remodeling NK. This strengthens idea that epigen features are hallmarks of memory NK and T cells.
Legionella pneumophila exploits the host proteasome to temporally regulate the activity of its effector protein SidH by hijacking the host's ubiquitin-proteasome system through its effector protein LubX, which functions as an E3 ubiquitin ligase. Lub specifically targets Sid for degradation, leading to its shutdown at later stages of infection. This represents a novel mechanism of temporal regulation of bacterial effectors, distinct from previously reported ubiquitin-mediated degradation of Salmonella effectors. Lub acts as a negative regulator of Sid within host cells, making it the first example of a bacterial effector that targets and regulates a cognate effector within the host, proposing the designation "metaeffector" for this class of effectors. The determinants of susceptibility are encoded in the effectors themselves, with Sid being intrinsically stable, while Lub controls Sid's instability by targeting it for ubiquination. Lub is a bona fide metaeff, regulating another effector's function within the host. Targets of bacterial E3 ligases are largely unknown, with previous studies focusing on host proteins; Sid is the first bacterial target of a bacterial E ligase effector. Future studies may reveal more bacterial effectors manipulating the ubiquitin system as metaeff coordinating effector functions spatiemporally. Lub's role at late stages of infection suggests it may target multiple host proteins, including Sid and Clk1, a previously reported substrate. Accumulating evidence suggests effectors functioning as E ubiquitinases are prevalent among plant and animal pathogens.
This study investigated the diversification of HIV-1 env sequences in 81 early subtype B infections, where the infecting virus could be accurately estimated, allowing for inference of substitution and insertion/deletion events. By integrating data from multiple acutely infected hosts, evidence of adaptive evolution of HIV-1 env was found, with 24 codons diversifying more rapidly than expected under a neutral model. Of these, 14 were in CTL epitopes verified or predicted by individual HLA or nucleotide context indicative of APOB-mediated G-to-A substitutions, suggesting APOEC may facilitate early escape. Rapidly diversifying sites not explained by CTL or APOEC hypermutation included the most mutated site in gp41. Insertions and deletions in hyperviable regions of the envelope glycoprotein were due to selection, not mutational hotspots. The study provides a detailed view of HIV-1 diversification following transmission, highlighting CTL and hypermutation's role in shaping evolution during new infections.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to study epigenetic silencing in yeast, focusing on molecular interactions between histone modifications and proteins. The model identifies essential epigenetic marks for bistability, incorporating two key chromatin marks: H4 acetylation and H3 methylation. The presence of multiple marks leads to qualitatively different behavior, with both modifications being crucial for robust epigen silencing. The model predicts a novel bivalent state, where chromatin is both active and silenced under certain perturbations, such as knock-out mutations or enzymatic inhibition. This bivalent state is stable under perturbations and results in patch silencing. Additionally, limited supply of silencing proteins can lead to counterintuitive responses. The study investigates the design of the silencing system and assesses experimental observations within a theoretical framework, discussing protein recruitment, spreading, and stability of silenced regions in mutants like Sas2 and Dot1. The model can be extended to include other silencing and active marks, informing which are essential for epigen fate and reinforcing one over another.
Researchers conducted a study to investigate the differences in gut microbiota (GM) composition between Ugandan children hospitalized with oedematous and non-oedemat severe acute malnutrition (SAM). A total of 87 children aged 6-24 months were included, with 62% suffering from oedemat malnutrition and 66% being boys with a mean age of 16.1 months. Fecal samples were collected at admission and analyzed using Denaturing Gradient Electrophoresis (DGGE) and 16S rRNA-targeted high-throughput sequencing. The results showed that non-oemat children had lower GM diversity compared to oemat children, but no compositional differences were identified between the two groups. Alpha diversity was determined by DG (p=0.031) and high-throughput sequencing (p=0.036). Beta diversity analysis did not reveal differences between GM of children with oemat and nonemat SAM (ANOS, weighted UniFrac R=-0.008, p=0.584; unweighted UniF R=0.071, p=0.011). The study suggests that nonemat SAM children have lower GM diversity than oemat children, but no clear compositional differences were found. This is consistent with previous studies linking GM to malnutrition, showing pathogenic bacteria in malnour children compared to healthy controls. A direct relationship between mal and GM was demonstrated by transplanting fecal samples from Malian twins discordant for oemat mal, kwashiork, into germ-free mice. However, it remains unknown whether GM differs between oemat and nonemat SAM. The findings justify further research on therapeutic strategies for SAM in developing countries, where mal remains a major problem, accounting for 12.6% of deaths in children under 5 years.
Researchers investigated telomere length variation in 112 wild-type Saccharomy sensu stricto isolates, finding extensive variation in S paradox isolates. Telom length correlated with geographic origin, with European strains having short telomeres (<150bp) and American isolates having telom approximately three times longer (>400bp). Insertion of URA gene near telom allowed analysis of individual telom lengths and telom position (TPE). Crossing American and European strains resulted in F1 spores with a continuum of telom lengths consistent with multiple quantitative trait loci (QTL) involvement. Variation in TPE was weakly correlated with telom length. Genotyping F1 segregants indicated several QTL associated with telom length and silencing variation, including candidate genes and regions without known telom properties. Transgressive segregation was detected for both phenotypes, validated by reciprocal hemizygosity that YU and TLC are telom-length QTL in S paradox subpopulations. Sequence divergence within Ku generated negative epistasis in allelic combinations (American-YU and European-YU) resulting in short telom.
Researchers investigated the cognitive and neural processes underlying human decision-making by examining when and how people choose, rather than just what they choose. Traditional sequential sampling models (SSMs) assume decisions emerge from a bounded accumulation process, making response times (RTs) predictable. However, these models fail when people are not forced to respond immediately but allowed to sample information sequentially, as the decision-maker may delay choice and terminate the process, a scenario not accounted for by standard SS. The study developed SSs predicting RTs from electroencephalography (EEG) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies, where participants bought or rejected fictitious stocks based on sequentially presented cues and free to respond at any time. Standard SS did not adequately describe RT distributions, but adding a mechanism for postponing decisions to the model obtained an accurate fit. Time-frequency EEG analysis revealed alternating states of de- and increasing oscillatory power in beta-frequencies (14-30Hz), indicating responses prepared and inhibited, supporting a decision to not decide. The extended model accounted for results of an adapted paradigm where participants pressed a button for sampling information. Results show computational modeling decisions and RT support understanding hidden cognition dynamics.
Researchers identified a genetic mutation in the SUVH2 gene as the cause of hereditary nasal parakeratosis (HN) in Labrador Retrievers, a condition characterized by crusts and fissures on the nasal planum. A genome-wide association study (GWAS) of 13 HN cases and 23 controls revealed a strong association on chromosome 2. Resequencing of one case's genome detected a non-synonymous variant in the SUVH gene, a histone lysine 9 (H3) methyltransferase, which mediates chromatin silencing. The variant c.972G>T is predicted to change a conserved asparagine to lysine in the catalytically active domain of the enzyme. Histopathological analysis of the epidermis in vivo suggests HN is not caused by hyperproliferation but delayed differentiation of kerocytes. SUVH is involved in epetic regulation of kerocyte differentiation, ensuring proper stratification and sealing of mammalian epidermis.
Researchers investigated the emergence of transmissible reassortant viruses during co-infection of avian and swine influenza A viruses in swine. Genomic analysis of 571 isolates from nasal samples and respiratory tissues of co-housed pigs (influenza-negative, avian H1N1 IAV-infected and swine H3N2 IAV-infected) identified 30 distinct genotypes of reassortant viruses. Viruses from lower respiratory tissues had the largest diversity, while those from turbinate and nasal fluids had the least. Reassants from lower tracts had the largest variations in growth in respiratory epithelial cells, and temperature in sw nasal cells selected the type of reassant shed by pigs. One reassant in nasal samples was consistently identified in upper, middle, and lower tract, and was efficiently transmitted between pigs. The study suggests that during mixed infections of av and sw IAV, reassortments likely occur in lower tracts and tissue tropism is a factor for selecting transmissible reassant.
A study investigated the effect of maternal Schistosoma mansoni infection and prazantel treatment during pregnancy on Schistoma mans infection and immune responsiveness among offspring at age five. Offspring of Schistoma-infected women in endemic areas may be sensitized in utero, which may influence their immune responsiveness to Schoma infection and associated morbidity. The study examined the effects of prazant treatment of S mans during pregnancy on the risk of S infection among offspring and their immune responses when exposed to S. In a trial, offspring of women treated with prazant or placebo during pregnancy were examined for S infection and cytokine and antibody responses to SW and SEA, as well as T cell expression FoxP at five. Of 134 children, 2.4% had S infection at five years based on single sample. Infection did not differ between treated or untreated. Cytokine IF, IL, IL, and IL and antibody Ig, Ig and Ig responses SW and FoxP were higher among infected than uninfected. Prazant treatment S during pregnancy had no effect on responses, exception IL to SW which was higher offspring women received prazant than did not. No evidence found maternal S and treatment during pregnancy influence prevalence or intensity S infection or immune response among at five, but observed on SW suggest maternal and treatment may affect immunoreg responsiveness in schosomias.
Researchers have discovered a new mechanism by which macrophages reprogram their endocytic machinery in response to inflammatory stimuli, switching from receptor-mediated phagocytosis to macinocytosis. This allows for the rapid transfer of internalized cargo to lysosomes in a receptor-independent manner. The key molecular switch for this reprogramming is the phosphorylation of the macrophage protein coronin 1, which activates phosphoinositol (PI)-3-kinase activity necessary for macinocytic uptake. Expression of a phosphomim form of coron 1 is sufficient to induce PI-3kin activation and macinocytosis even in the absence of inflammatory stimuli. This suggests a previously unknown mechanism for regulating internalization and degradation of infectious material during inflammation. Macrophages activated by inflammatory stimuli undergo serine phosphorylation of coronin 1, reprogramming them from phagytic to macinocytic mode. Expression of a phosphim coron 1 mutant resulted in mycobacteria being transferred to lysosomes for elimination, regardless of macroph activation state. In the absence of inflammatory stimuli, coron 1 phosphorylation is sufficient to redirect phytic cargo via macinocyt to lysosomes. Macrophages expressing a phosphim glutamic acid mutant of coron 1 internalized Ig-coated beads through macinocyt in absence interferon. Phosphorylation of coron 1 is crucial for switch from phag to macin uptake upon macro activation.
Researchers conducted a qualitative study in Arua District, North Uganda to assess community acceptance of tset baits (insecticide-treated targets) in areas where they had not been previously used. The study involved 16 focus group discussions with male and female participants in eight villages across the district. Results showed that villagers who had never seen baits before expressed fear and anxiety, associating them with witchcraft and "ghosts from the river" linked to illness, death, and misfortune. In contrast, villagers in areas where ba had been used previously had positive attitudes and were aware of their purpose and benefits. The latter group reported similar negative perceptions when tse control started a decade ago. Acceptance of ba varies between villages, related to duration of experience with tse programs. Success of community-based interventions against tse depends on engagement and sensitization campaigns reaching all communities, especially new areas. A previous study in DRC showed negative attitudes led to damage and failure. Community acceptance is vital for effective tse control. The study was conducted in an area of West, North Uganda, where ba used in government programs against Human African trypanosomiasis (HAT). Efforts enhance community participation in ba range from encouraging to active construction and maintenance. In all studies, acceptance was crucial for success. Three years before, 70 ba were deployed per parish, but not monitored, resulting in unsustainable tse control. Deployment enabled communities to familiarize themselves with ba. Sleeping sickness, caused by Trypanosoma brucei, transmitted by tse, is restricted to Africa, causing chronic form in West and Central, including the study area. Tse vectors other species pathogenic to livestock, estimated losses. In H villages, no previous tse programs, first exposure to ba was introduced. Eight villages included, four H+ and four H−, shown in Figure 1.
Researchers have conducted a comprehensive study on the recombination landscapes in Drosophila melanogaster, a species of fruit fly, to understand the fundamental biological process of recombination and its impact on evolution. They analyzed 5,860 meioses and genotyped 139 million SNPs, mapping 106,964 recombination events at a resolution of 2 kilobases. This allowed for the creation of whole-genome maps of crossing over (CO) and gene conversion (GC) recombination, as well as detailed variation in recombination among individuals. The study found extreme and punctuated variation in CO rates along chromosomes, with hotspots and coldspots, and intra-specific variation associated with hotspots at low frequency. Gene conversion rates were uniformly distributed across the genome, detectable in regions with reduced or absent CO. Local recombination events were associated with sequence motifs, occurring within transcript regions, suggesting chromatin accessibility favors double-strand breaks. The study highlights the importance of accounting for recombination variation in population models of selection and linkage.
Researchers have identified ID2 (ID2) as a component of the RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) machinery in Arabidopsis thalian, but its function in RDM remained unknown. By purifying ID2, they co-purified two ID paralogs, ID1 and ID2 (ID2PAR1 and 2). The coiled domain between the XS and X domains of ID2 is essential for ID homodimerization, whereas the ID2-terminal X domain, not coiled domain, is required for ID interaction with ID1 and ID2. Introducing wild-type ID2 and its derivatives into the id2 mutant demonstrated that the uncharacterized ID X domain is required for ID-ID1/ID2 formation and function. ID1 is required for de novo methylation, siRNA accumulation, and transcriptional silencing, while ID2 has partially overlapping roles with ID1. Unlike ID2, ID1 and ID2 are incapable of binding double-stranded RNA, suggesting roles of ID1 and ID2 are different from ID in ID-ID/ID complex and ID1 and ID2 are essential for functioning of RDM.
Exposure to Leishmania braziliensis triggers neutrophil activation and apoptosis. Neutrophils are the first line of defense against pathogens and are rapidly recruited to sites of Leishmanial inoculation. During Leish braziliensis infection, depletion of neutrophils significantly increases parasite load, whereas co-culture of neutils with L braziliensis has an opposite effect. Co-culture of infected macrophages and neutils induced parasite killing, leading to investigate neutil response to L brazili. This study focused on interaction between neutils and Lili, exploring activation and apoptotic fate. Inoculation of serum-opsonized Lili promastigotes mice neutil accumulation in vivo, peaking at 24 hours. In vitro exposure of thioglyateelic inflammatory bone neutils to Lili modulated expression of surface molecules CD18 and CD62, and induced oxidative burst. Using mCh-expressing Lili, effects were mainly observed in infected and bystander cells. Neutil activation with Lili was confirmed by release of TN-α and neutilase. Neutils with Lili displayed markers of early apoptosis. Lili induces neutil recruitment in vivo and neutils exposed to parasite in vitro through activation and release of inflammatory mediators, impacting parasite elimination at early stages.
Researchers investigated the potential benefits of vaccination as a supplementary control measure for bovine tuberculosis (bTB) in cattle. Currently, vaccination is not used in international control programs and is prohibited in the EU. Candidate vaccines based on Mycobacterium bovis bacillus Calmet-Guerin (BCG) interfere with the tuberculin skin test, used to determine if herds and countries are officially TB-free. New diagnostic tests, Differentiated Infected from Vaccinated Animals (DIV), offer the potential to introduce vaccination within eradication programs. The study used within-herd models from historical data from Great Britain (GB) to explore the feasibility of supplemental use. The economic impact of bovine tuberculosis on farmers is dominated by costs associated with testing and restrictions on animal movements. Farmers' willingness to adopt vaccination requires not only reducing the burden of infection but also the risk of restrictions imposed. The study found that under intensive testing in GB, the specificity of DIV test rather than sensitivity is the greatest barrier to herd benefit vaccination. The negative effects of vaccination could be mitigated through testing relaxation, potentially increasing hidden infection in officially free herds. The models explored the range of DIV characteristics necessary for a protective benefit. Estimated a DIV specificity of at least 99.85% and sensitivity >40% required a benefit with no increase in risk. Data from experimentally infected animals suggest this specificity could be achieved using a cocktail of DIV antigens while maintaining sensitivity 73.3% (95%:61.9, 82.9) relative post-mortem detection.
Researchers have identified a new class of compounds called dihydrobenz[e][1,4]azin-2(3)-ones that show anthelmint activity against the parasitic worm Trichis, which infects over 500 million people worldwide, causing physical and educational damage. The compounds were discovered through screening a library of 480 small molecules on Trichis mur, a model for T. trichi, and were found to paralyze adult parasites in vitro. Further screening and synthesis led to 20 active dihydrozazepones, a new class not previously implicated in nematode control. The most potent compounds had EC50 values around 25-50μM, comparable to existing anthelmint levamis, and showed low cytotoxicity against murine epithelial cells, demonstrating selectivity for the parasite. The compounds also reduced embryon T. mur eggs ability to establish infection in vivo, suggesting a potential for a therapeutic that acts in the environment, such as a spray, to interrupt the lifecycle. These results show dihydroazepones are a new anthint active against both egg and adult stages of Trich parasites, with considerable scope for optimisation to improve potency and pharmacetic properties.
Researchers revisited the concept of "date" and "party" hubs in protein-protein interaction networks, where "date" hubs have low co-expression with partners and "party" hubs have high co-expression. They found that the importance of "date" hubs to network connectivity can be attributed to a small subset of extremely central hubs, which do not display low correlation, undermining the idea of a link between quantity and function. The "date/party distinction was motivated by an approximately bimodal distribution of hub-expression, but this feature is not robust to methodological changes. Topological properties of hubs do not correlate with co-expression, but there is a significant correlation between centrality and functional similarity of interacting proteins. The authors suggest conceiving roles for protein-protein interactions rather than individual proteins is more useful. They examined the division of hubs into "date" and "party categories from different angles, demonstrating prior arguments are susceptible to data and method changes. Observed differences in network vulnerability arise from small important hubs. Properties attributed to "date and "party do not correspond with actual topological roles, which are more diverse than explained by a dichotomy. The authors analyzed modular organisation and roles of hubs in interaction, revisiting the possibility of "date/party dichotomy and found concerns. Claims of bimality in hub distributions do not appear robust, and deletion tests have not considered outlier effects.
Researchers have developed methods to reconstruct transmission trees of infectious disease outbreaks from whole genome sequences, but a limitation is the requirement for genetic diversity to occur on epidemiological timescales. This means that the position of individuals in a transmission tree can only be resolved by genetic data if mutations have accumulated between pathogen genomes. To compare genetic diversity in different outbreaks, the concept of "transmission" is introduced, defined as the number of mutations separating genome sequences from transmission pairs. Using literature values, scenarios are simulated with two evolution models to describe transmission of major pathogens. Results show that mean transmission varies between pathogens, but is generally low, with many outbreaks having genetically identical pairs. The impact of transmission on reconstructing outbreaks is demonstrated using tools R and phy, showing that rapidly evolving pathogens like viruses provide information on individual events, while pathogens like Streptoccus, Shella, and Clostrid provide little to no information. This highlights limitations of genetic data in certain scenarios and the need to expand tools to integrate other epidemiological data.
Researchers investigated the phenomenon of X chromosome inactivation (XCI) in female mammals, where one X chromosome is silenced, but some genes escape this process. They analyzed allele-specific expression and chromatin structure of X-linked genes in mouse tissues and cells with skewed CI using single nucleotide polymorphisms. A binomial model assessed allelic expression, demonstrating a continuum between silencing and expression from the inactive X (Xi). RNA-seq was verified with RT-PCR and Sanger sequencing, identifying common escape and tissue-specific genes. Few genes (3-7%) escape CI in mouse tissues, suggesting stringent silencing and escape controls. In contrast, an in vitro embryonic kidney-derived Pki cell line showed 21% escape, representing kidney-specific and cell-line escape. Alle-specific RNA polymerase II and DNase hypersensitivity at Xi promoters correlated with escape, indicating open chromatin structure. CTCF binding on Xi was denser in brain compared to Pki line, contributing to compartmentalized Xi and fewer escape in brain.

A new algorithm calculated bi-allelic versus monoallelic expression probability, identifying genes expressed from both X chromosomes in mouse tissues. Only a minority escape CI in tissue and cell-specific manner, indicating CI and escape are tightly controlled in vivo. Surveys in human/mouse cells showed 8-15% consistently escape, 10-13 variable, and 10-20 varying between lines/individuals. Escape results in sexual dimorphisms and bi-alle expression is important for normal female phenotype. Mouse 3-7 escape may differ from other mammals. Pki cells showed more escape than tissues, possibly epigenetic changes or cell property.

Escape genes distributed along X, distance from XIC did not influence Xi expression. Important genes regulate transcription and translation, dosage-sensitive, consistently escaping CI. Tissue-specific genes help understanding sex differences.
Researchers have identified and characterized a novel cyste protease, VX-4, from the malaria parasite Plasium viv, which plays a crucial role in the parasite's survival and egress from the erythrocyte. VX-4 has dual substrate specificity depending on the microenvironmental pH, with highest activity against benzyycarbonyl-Le-Arg-methyl-amide at acidic pH 5.5 and against Z-Arg-M at neutral pH 6.5-7.5. It prefers positively charged amino acids at the P1 position, with less specificity at P3 and P4, which depends on pH. Three amino acids in the S pocket were substituted in VX-4 compared to VX-2 and VX-3. Replacement of Glu180 abolished activity against Z-Arg-M at neutral pH, indicating its importance in pH-dependent preference. VX-4 is localized in the vacuoles and cytoplasm of the erythrocytic stage of P. viv, with maximal activity against actin at neutral pH, and against P. viv plasm and hemoglobin at neutral/acidic and acidic pH, respectively. VX- demonstrates pH-dependent switching, allowing for efficient cleavage of different substrates in intracellular environments. It might function as hemase in acidic foodu, matur of P. viv plasm at neutral/acid, and cytos-degrading in erythrocytos. The study contributes to understanding of P viv cystine proteases and potential targets for antimal drugs.
Researchers have developed a novel genome-scale model of metabolism and macromolecular synthesis (ME) for the acetogen Clostridium ljungahli to gain insights into its biology and improve biotechnological production. The model, named iL965ME, captures major metabolic, amino acid, nucleotide, lipid, cofactor, and vitamin pathways, as well as RNA and protein synthesis necessary for catalyzing reactions, broadening predictability. It reveals how protein allocation and media composition influence metabolic pathways and energy in acetogens and accurately predicts secretion of multiple fermentation products. Predicting overflow metabolism enables new strategies, such as glycerol production, a novel product for C. ljungahli, expanding its metabolic capability. The model also predicts changing secretion rates based on metal availability, opening fermentation optimization and knowledge about proteome and carbon flux in acetogens. 

The iLME includes all central metabolic, amino, acid, nucleotide, lipid, cofactor, and vitamin synthesis pathways, as well as RNA and protein synthesis necessary for catalyzing reactions. It also includes WLP with cofactors and mechanisms for energy conservation.
