Metabolic and expression models represent cellular processes like macrom synthesis and transcription, broadening predictability. RNA and protein abundances are explicitly predicted, allowing cofactor exploration. The model accurately predicts acetate, ethanol, and glycer secretion during carbon and metal availability, revealing protein and media influence on pathways and energy in acetogen.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) using a panel of human osteoblast (HO) cells to investigate the genetic control of transcript variation in disease-relevant signals. They performed a transcriptomic survey similar to recent studies in lymphoblast cell lines (LCL) and found distinct cell-type genes and functionally relevant pathways unique to each tissue. Cis-association analysis with SNP genotypes identified genetic variations in transcript forms, indicating differential expression in HO is partly controlled by cis-regulatory variants. These forms are regulated by variants in tissue-specific and tissue-independent manners, confirmed by RT-PCR validation. The study suggests multiple isoforms are present in both tissues and genetic may affect relative expression of one to another, rather than an all-or effect. Examination of top SNPs from GWAS of bone density showed overlap with associations in this study, corresponding to the FAM gene tested in additional clinical studies revealing a novel isoform. The approach examining transcript variation in multiple types is useful for detecting variation common to cell types and identifying cell-specific variants functionally relevant for follow-up GWAS.
Researchers studied the yeast Saccharomyces eayan, a non-cerevisiae parent of the lager-brew hybrid Sorian, to understand why it cannot utilize maltotose, a major carbohydrate in brew's wort. Unlike most evis andorian strains, eayan lacks maltotose transporter genes. However, it has four SeALT genes for α-glucide maltose uptake. The team created maltose-assimulating mutants and evolved them in carbon-limited chemostat cultures on maltose-enriched wort. An evolved strain showed improved maltose and maltose fermentation in 7 ferment experiments on industrial w. Whole-genome sequencing revealed a novel SeALT gene, resulting from introgression of three SeALT genes. The predicted structure SeALT is similar to original transporters, but overexpression sufficed to enable growth on maltose. This suggests neofunctionalization occurred. The structure resembles Sorian maltose-transporter SpY, with high identity to evis MAL1, us MAL, and e SeALT. Evolution of maltose landscape in hybridorian lagerrew strains likely involved similar mechanisms.
Researchers have established a correlation between the mortality caused by influenza virus strains and their antigenic variation, enabling the development of a method to rapidly estimate the mortality burden of influenza A (H1N) virus by predicting antigenic distance between A(H1) strains. A simplified host-virus model was proposed to explore the relationship between antigen variation and excess mortality, revealing a direct and positive correlation. The study aimed to address the challenge of timely and accurate assessment of influenza impact on human death, as current approaches rely on intensive and biased surveillance. The model considers strains of distinct antigen causing significant infection in the population, denoted as "antigen strains". A method, EAD, was developed to predict antigen distance with high accuracy, suggesting utility in rapid estimation of mortality. EAD distance of (H1) was evaluated and found to correlate with observed mortality. The method is proposed to be useful for rapid assessment of mortality of future (1) variants and applicable to antigen variants of (3) and (B) with modification.
Researchers have identified a small cysteine-rich protein, PEC23, from the Asian soybean fungus Phakora pachyri, that suppresses plant immunity. P. pachyri is an obligate biotrophic pathogen causing severe soybean epidemics, and its interaction mechanisms with host plants are poorly understood. Genomes of rust fungi encode many secreted cystine-rich proteins (SCRPs), but their roles are unknown. PEC23 interacts with soybean transcription factor GPL12, silencing GPL12 leads to constitutive immunity, identifying GPL12 as a negative regulator of soybean defenses. Data show PEC suppresses soy immune responses and physically interacts with GPL12, a negative regulator. PEC is a virulence factor. Pachri infection assays on GPL12-silenced and PEC-silenced soybeans showed no change in disease phenotypes, possibly due to redundancy of pach effector proteins. GPL acts as an immune suppressor ensuring normal growth in absence of infection.
Researchers have identified EphA2, a cell surface tyrosine kinase receptor, as a receptor for Chlamydia trachomatis, an obligate intracellular bacterium that invades host cells to replicate inside a membrane-bound vacuole called an inclusion. Chydia induces a lasting activation of the PI kinase pathway required for efficient replication. Interfering with C trachar2 binding to Eph2, downregulation of Eph2 or inhibition of Eph2 activity significantly reduced infection. C interacts with and activates Eph2 on the surface, resulting in receptor internalization. During chyd replication, Eph2 remains active around the inclusion and interacts with the p85 subunit of PIK to activate the PI/Akt pathway required for chyd development. Overexpression of full-length Eph2, but not mutant lacking the intracellular domain, enhanced PI activation and infection. Despite depletion of Eph2 from the surface, C induces upregulation of Eph through activation of the ER pathway, keeping infected cells in an apoptosis-resistant state. Engagement of a surface receptor at the membrane is a new mechanism Chy subverts host and induces resistance.
Researchers have investigated the role of active dendrites in neuronal computation, specifically their excitability through voltage-gated ion channels. Despite past efforts, the function of dendritic excitability remained unclear. A model of an active dendritic tree shows that its output is a highly non-linear function of afferent rate, achieving large dynamic ranges (up to 50 dB). The model replicates double-sigmoid responses observed in retinal ganglion cells. The study proposes that dendritic enhancement of dynamic range is its primary role. Neurons with larger dendritic trees are predicted to have larger dynamic range, and blocking active conductances lead to decreased dynamic.

The research aims to examine dendrites as a site for computation, given their ion channels supporting non-linear summation and dendritic spikes. However, spikes are a consequence of excitable dynamics. Dendritic trees without plasticity can benefit from active dendrites for enlarged operational range. Neurons have extensive dendritic trees, with morph and dynamic aspects studied. Dendritic conductances were discovered.

The proposal is that large dendrites amplify weak signals and saturate strong activity. The "dynamic range" trade-off between sensitivity and saturation is crucial for neurons, networks, organs, and organisms. Results suggest dendritic spikes under synaptic bombardment are responsible for a model prediction: the transfer function is not Hill-like, but double-sigmoid, observed in retinal ganglion cells.
Researchers investigated the inference of quantitative models of bacterial promoters from time-series gene data, a crucial for drug discovery, cancer research, and biotechnology. Current methods assume mRNA abundance represents protein concentrations and changes in gene expression are solely due to transcription factors, neglecting global effects. They measured in vivo activity of E. coli's FliFliM module, estimating protein concentrations and global effects using kinetic models. Results show correcting these assumptions improves model quality, especially for systems with longer protein half-lives and varying expression machinery activity. The study proposes using time-series data to learn regulatory network structure and dynamics, demonstrating global effects and regulation importance for Fli and FlM halfives in Fli-dependent promoters. 

A new approach for transcriptome experiments uses constitutively-expressed genes and models to reconstruct protein concentrations and integrate physiological effects into inference. Measuring global effects with a reporter driven constitutive promoter only marginally improves model fit. Estimating Fli and FlM concentrations from promoter activities and physiologically halfives yields a rich dataset for testing mRNA and protein influences on inference. The study infers regulatory and quantitative function of Fli-dependent gene, not regulated by other factors, using reconstructed concentrations and kinetic models.
Researchers conducted a study in the Agua region of Panama to investigate the spatial-temporal distribution of Oligyomys fulcens, a rodent species that serves as a reservoir for zoonotic pathogens. They analyzed data from a longitudinal study of rodent populations collected between April 2006 and December 2009, using non-spatial analyses and spatial statistical tests. The study area was divided into a 90-node grid with a total area of 6.43 km2, and the temporal dataset was divided into four periods: dry season, rainy season, and two transitional months between seasons. Results showed heterogeneous patterns in population densities and dispersion of O. fulcens across seasons and years, with the species typically absent during late transitional months and re-established in subsequent years. Spatial autocorrelation analysis indicated local populations encompassed approximately 300-600m, with suitable and unsuitable habitats sharply demarcated over short distances. O. fulens showed a well-defined spatial pattern over time, leading to shifting hotspots of abundance that explain intermittent risk transmission by this species. Variation was associated with seasonality and anthropogenic pressures from agricultural activities. These factors define occurrence, timing, intensity, and duration of synanthropic populations affected by human populations, and possible exposure to local populations.
Researchers have developed a computational method to infer the antigenic relationships between amino acid changes in the hemagglutinin protein of human influenza A (H3) viruses from 1968 to 2003. The technique, based on least-squares optimization, fits pairwise antigen distances between isolates onto an evolutionary tree, allowing for a fine-grained resolution of the antigen impact of individual changes without time and cost-intensive experiments. The method was applied to infer antigen trees representing the antigen evolution of the major protein over 35 years, with branch lengths representing antigen distances inferred from HI assay data and maximum likelihood of the HA domain. The results were comparable to antigen cartography and identified both known and novel amino acid changes with antigen impact. The technique can be applied to infer phenotype and genotype-phenotype relationships in other types of pairwise distances.
Researchers conducted a large-scale RNA interference (RNAi) screen to identify host factors required for human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV16) infection. The study revealed a cluster of mitotic genes essential for viral DNA import into the nucleus. In interphase cells, viruses were endocytosed, routed to the perinuclear area, and uncoated, but vDNA failed to be imported into the nucleus. However, upon nuclear envelope breakdown during mitosis, HPV16 infection occurred. During mitosis, vDNA associated with host chromatin on the metaphase plate. The researchers propose that HPV requires nuclear envelope breakdown during mitosis for vDNA access to the nucleoplasm. The study highlights the value of RNAi screens in investigating viral infections and provides a list of cell functions required for HPV16 infection, a resource for future virus-host interaction studies.

The study found that mitosis is crucial for HPV16 nuclear DNA import, facilitated by nuclear envelope permeability changes due to breakdown. Nuclear envelope breakdown allows subviral complex association with host chromatin on metaphase. The researchers used RNAi screens to analyze pathogen-host interactions and focused on genes suppressing HPV16 infectivity, uncovering a role for mitosis in HPV entry. The vDNA of HPV16 enters the nucleopl by possibly relying on nuclear breakdown, which removes the nucleo-cytoplasmic barrier during mitosis. The nuclear envelope disassembles during G/M transition and reassembles during telophase before cytokinesis. Certain retroviruses use this window to access the nucleopl.

HPV16 addition does not promote cell division but increases cells in prolonged mitosis, dependent on L associating with host chromatin, a mechanism for v import into nuclei. After penetration, v moves with L into nucleus and localizes to ND domains. Nuclear import of subiral complex is unknown. HPV entry requires progression into early mitosis, unclear which step influenced by cell cycle.
Black Sigat or black streak disease, caused by the Dothideomyc fungus Pseudocospora fiji (formerly Mycosphaella fiji), is a significant foliar disease of banana worldwide. Due to the lack of effective resistance, management requires frequent fungicide applications, increasing economic and environmental costs in banana production. Two strains of P. fiji were sequenced and assembled with a new genetic map. The 74Mb genome of P. fiji is expanded by LTR transposons, the largest in Dothideomyc. Electrophoretic karyotyping and molecular markers of P. fiji populations showed chromosome polymorphisms and genetic diversity. Genetic differentiation was detected using neutral markers, suggesting selection and limited gene flow at geographic scale. Frequencies of fungicide in treated plantations were higher than untreated P. fiji populations. A homologue of Cladospor fulum Avr effector, PfAv4, was identified in P. fiji genome. Infiltration of purified PfAV4 into leaves of resistant variety Calcut 4 resulted in hypersensitive response, suggesting Cal 4 carries unknown gene recognizing Pf4. The P. fiji genome will aid in fungicide treatment and banana breeding programs.
Researchers have developed a novel framework to study the evolution of lineage-specific transcription factor binding sites without relying on detailed cross-species alignments. This approach, called the "birth-death model," estimates the rate of creation of new binding sites along a specific lineage, allowing for the identification of novel regulatory elements contributing to species-specific traits. The method was applied to six transcription factors (GATA, SOX, CTC, MY, MAX, E1, and TS) in the human-mouse lineage, revealing that 58-79% of binding sites in humans originated since divergence. Over 15% of binding sites are unique to hominids, often near genes associated with specific pathways and harboring more SNPs than older sites in the genome. This supports the method's ability to identify lineage-specific regulatory elements and understand their role in gene regulation variation across species. In contrast to conservation-based approaches, this method generates predictions using lineage-specific sites or their increased rate of creation. Five of six factors produced the most significant motif prediction using this method. The method was applied to ChIP-seq data for six TFs, chosen for their diverse functions, well-documented motifs, and availability in human and mouse cell types. It determines lineage differences in evolutionary rates of a motif along a branch in the phylogeny. Despite divergence of protein-binding across species, computational models have focused on "phylogen footprinting" approaches, identifying elements by conservation. Results support this method's ability to identify lineage regulatory elements, a step towards understanding regulatory evolution's role in gene variation across species.
Researchers investigated the mechanism by which light regulates the expression of the zebraf period2 (per) gene, a key component of the vertebrate circadian clock. They identified a Light-Responsive Module (LRM) within the per promoter, which is necessary and sufficient for light-driven expression and circadian regulation. The LRM is conserved in vertebrate per genes, even in species lacking light-sensitive peripheral clocks, and can substitute for the zraf LRM to confer light-regulated transcription in zraf cells. The LRM contains E-box and D-box elements, critical for its function. The E-box mediates circadian regulation by BMAL1/CLOCK activity, while the D-box directs light-driven expression. The zraf homolog of thyroid embryonic factor binds to the L D-box and transactivates expression. Knockdown of this factor attenuates light-driven transcription from the per promoter in vivo. Results support a model where light-dependent crosstalk between E and D-box factors is central to per expression.
Researchers have investigated the role of the actin-binding protein coronin in the motility of Plasmodium berghei sporozoites, the highly motile forms of a rodent malaria-causing parasite transmitted by mosquitoes. They found that coronin regulates motility and is essential for efficient transmission from mosquitoes to mice, as parasites lacking coron show defects in salivary gland invasion but not skin migration. Coronin localizes to the periphery of sporites in a calcium-dependent but actin-independent manner and contributes to motility through actin-binding. Mutations and imaging suggest coron organizes actin filaments for motility. Using coronin-mCherry as a marker for actin filaments, protein A was found to contribute to actin disassembly. Calcium and cAMP signaling regulate a switch from motility to host invasion by differentially influencing actin dynamics. Extracellular ligands trigger intracellular calcium release followed by actin formation and coronin relocalization to the rear of the gliding sporite. Parasites lacking coron frequently detach from substrate and struggle to reattach, suggesting a function in adhesion. Actin filaments are short in Plmod and related parasites, making it speculative how they are organized. Data suggest interplay between TR-family adhesins, act filaments, and regulating adhesion for sporite migration.
Researchers have identified a novel mechanism of resistance to amphotin B, a key treatment for leishmaniasis, in four Leishmania mexicana lines. These lines exhibited altered sterol biosynthesis and hypersensitivity to pentamidine. Genome sequencing revealed a mutation in the sterol biosynthesis gene sterol5-desaturase in one line, while RNA-seq showed loss of expression of sterol24-ethyltransferase (SMT) in three lines. MT is responsible for drug resistance and altered sterol biosynthesis. Loss of milteine transporter was associated with one line. MT is encoded by two genes with different expression levels. Reduced expression was associated with loss of 3' untranslated region of dominant gene due to structural variations at locus. Regions of homology between genes and presence of SIDER retrotransposons promote these variations. In one case, loss MT expression not associated with loss of virulence in macrophages in vivo. Sequence instability known in Leish genomes, associated with major antileman drug with no fitness costs, a significant concern.
Researchers investigated how attention and prediction interact to modulate information processing in the brain during sensory encoding. They used electroencephalography (EEG) to record neural activity in humans performing a visual task where they attended to or ignored a stream of gratings with predictable, surprising, or unpredictable orientations. Results showed that surprising stimuli evoked responses were encoded as the difference between predicted and observed features, and attention facilitated this type of information in the brain. This supports a predictive coding theory that attention optimizes expectations by increasing the gain of prediction errors, suggesting attention increases selectivity for mismatch information in response to surprising stimuli. An alternative model proposes attention modulates activity of prediction neurons, suggesting a synergistic effect on selectivity for feature information. The study demonstrates attention boosts mismatch information evoked by surprising stimuli, consistent with a predictive theory that attention optimizes precision by increasing gain of errors. A significant effect of attention was found on mismatch response to surprising but not unpredictable stimuli around 150ms after onset, reaching significance at 350ms. The study aimed to determine type of information modulated in interaction between attention and prediction, using forward models to quantify selectivity for orientation and mismatch in responses to surprising and unpredictable stimuli in the oddball paradigm.
Trypanosoma brucei, a parasite of sub-Saharan Africa, is divided into three sub-species: T. b. brucei, T. rhodesense, and T. gambense. T. b. brucei is unable to infect humans due to sensitivity to trypanolytic factors (TLF) 1 and 2 in human serum. T. rhodesense and T. gambense are resistant to lysis by TLF. Two subgroups of T. gambense differ genetically and in human resistance phenotypes. Group 1 T. gambense has an invariant phenotype, while group 2 shows variable resistance. Previous data suggest group 1 T gambense is resistant to TLF due to reduced uptake of TLF mediated by reduced expression of TLF receptor, the haptoglobin-hemoglobin receptor (HbHR) gene. This study investigates if true for group 2 parasites. Isogenic resistant and sensitive group 2 T gambense were derived and compared to T bruce parasites. Both express HHR at similar levels and internalized fluorescent labeled TLF in similar to T bruce. Both resistant and sensitive group 2, as well as group 1 gambense, internalize recombinant AP1, but only sensitive 2 are lysed. Data indicate group 1 gambense avoiding TLF is resistant to main component AP1. Similarly, group 2 gambense is innately resistant AP1, possibly based on same mechanism. However, group 2 gambense variably displays phenotype and does not correlate with HHR expression or expression. Differences in human resistance mechanisms between T gambense groups 1 and 2 exist.
Researchers have investigated the role of DNA methylation in controlling HIV-1 latency, a state where the virus is dormant and not actively replicating. They found that methylation of the HIV-1 5' long terminal repeat (LTR) is an epigenetic mechanism that restricts reactivation of latent HIV-1 and determines its stability. Methylation acts as a late event during latency establishment and is not required for initial silencing. In patients with undetectable viremia, HIV-1 promoters and enhancers are hypermethylated and resistant to reactivation, while those with viremia have hypomethyl 5LTR. However, dense methylation of HIV-1 5LTR does not confer complete resistance to reactivation with histone deacetylase inhibitors, protein kinase agonists, and 5-aza-2deoxycytidine. The study proposes a two-step epigenetic control model of HIV-1 latency. Methylation of HIV-1 5LTR is an additional mechanism that prevents reactivation and determines latency stability, but is not required for initial silencing.
Researchers have conducted a comprehensive analysis of the genomic variation in Drosoph melanogaster, a model organism, to understand the relationship between genetic and phenotypic variation. They created a nucleotide catalog of single-nucleotide, multiucle, and structural variants in 39 Dophila Genetic Panel lines, identifying over 3.6 million distinct variants, including 800,000 insertions, deletions, and complex variants. The study found that single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) are more frequent than other variants, but not due to mutagenic or mutation-prone regions, but rather due to population-level processes. The researchers also mapped cis-expression trait loci (cisQTL) for over 2,000 genes, finding that insertions comprise 10% of all cisQTL and show larger effects than SNPs cisQTL. Additionally, they identified more gene associations in males than females and found most cisQ are sex-specific, revealing a decoupling of genomic architecture between sexes and importance of genetic factors mediating sex-based expression. RNA-seq-based allelic imbalance analyses in offspring of sequenced lines validated most cisQ in heterozygous individuals.
A study investigated the impact of amplitude cancellation on the association between frequency components in the neural drive to muscle and rectified EMG signal. The rectified EM signal is commonly used to estimate neural drive to muscles and infer synaptic input to motor neurons. However, loss of EM amplitude due to overlap of motor action potentials (cancellation) may distort the rectified EM spectrum and its correlation with neural drive. Analytical and computational models of motor activity, force, and EM signal showed that rectified EM without cancellation (EMnc) is superior to actual rectified EM as estimator of neural drive. Simulations confirmed this, with average coefficient of determination (r2) between neural in 1-30 Hz and EMnc (0.59±0.08) matching correlation between rectified EM and neural at low cancellation levels (<40%). Correlation decreased linearly with cancellation (r=-0.83) to r<0.2 at levels >60%. Simulations showed stronger neural drive implied stronger correlation between rectified EM and neural, with cancellation distorting mainly low-frequency (<5 Hz) components. Results indicate amplitude distorts rectified EM signal, implying valid use of rectified EM as estimator requires low levels and/or strong synaptic input to motor neurons.
Researchers investigated the molecular mechanism behind auxin's role in inhibiting root growth in response to aluminum (Al) stress in Arabidopsis. They found that YUC, a flavin monooxygenase-like protein, regulates auxin biosynthesis in the root transition zone (TZ) in response to Al stress. Al upregulates Y3/5/7/9 in the rootTZ, leading to aux accumulation and root inhibition. This regulation is dependent on ethylene signaling, as disrupting it either enhances or reduces Y upregulation in response to Al. Ethylene also enhances root inhibition under Al, which is alleviated in yuc mutants or co-treated with yucas, an inhibitor of Y activity. Eth-insensitive 3 (E3) is involved in regulating Y9 transcription. PIF4 functions as a transcription activator for Y5/8, promoting Al-inhibited growth by regulating local aux in theTZ. Al-induced P4 inTZ acts downstream of eth signaling. The study highlights a cascade for Y-regulated aux biosynthesis in theTZ mediating growth response to Al.
Researchers investigated the interaction between simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) peptides and natural killer (NK) cells in rhes macs. They found that certain SIV peptides bound to the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecule Mam-A*002 stabilize its interaction with the inhibitory killer-cell immunoglobulin-like receptor (KIR) Mam-K3DL05, suppressing NK cell activity. Twenty-eight of 75 SIV peptides bound to Mam-A002 inhibited the cytolytic activity of Mam-K3+ NK cells, including immunodominant CD8 T cell epitopes. Substitutions at C-terminal positions changed inhibitory peptides into disinhibitory, and vice versa, without altering binding to Mam002. The effects of these variants on NK responses corresponded to their effects on Mam002 tetramer binding Mam-K05. In mixtures of inhibitory and disinitory peptides, low concentrations of inhibitory dominated to suppress NK responses. Consistent with inhibition of Mam-K NK by epitopes presented Mam002, SIV replication was higher in Mam002 CD+ lymphocytes co-cultured with Mam-K NK than Mam-K cells.
Researchers investigated how the evolution of Haemophilus influenzae in response to transient nutrient limitation affects its ability to colonize and persist in the host during otitis media (OM). They hypothesized that strains adapted to nutrient limitation would be more adept at colonization and evasion of host immune responses, leading to persistence. In a preclinical model of OM, they observed that a mutant strain with decreased 3',5'-cyclic adenosine monophosphate phosphodiester activity had a significant decrease in middle ear effusion, a clinical indicator of disease resolution. However, this strain formed more intracellular bacterial communities (IBCs) than the parental strain during OM, suggesting a mucosal reservoir following disease resolution. The study provides insight into NTH evolution during nutritional limitation and demonstrates IBC in a preclinical OM model.
Burkholderia pseudomalle, the causative agent of meloidosis, modulates host iron homeostasis to facilitate iron availability and intracellular survival. Infection of primary macrophages with B. pseudalle results in downregulation of ferroport, leading to higher iron availability within macrophages. Exogenous modification of iron export by hepcin or supplementation with ferric ammonium citrate increases intracellular iron, stimulating pseudalle growth, whereas iron chelation with deferoxamine reduces bacterial survival. Iron-loaded macrophages exhibit lower NADPH oxidase, iNOS, lipocalin 2, cytokine, and caspase-1 activation. Infection of mice causes diminished ferport expression, higher liver iron retention, and lower serum iron levels (hypofermia). In vivo administration of ferric ammonium citrate promotes bacterial growth and inflammatory response, whereas iron limitation significantly ameliorates bacterial clearance, attenuates cytokine levels, and improves survival. Data indicate modulation of cellular iron balance is a strategy for pseudalle to improve acquisition and restrict antibacterial effector mechanisms, promoting intracellular growth. Changes in iron homeostasis influence susceptibility to meloidosis, suggesting iron chel drugs as a therapeutic option.
Researchers have developed a novel technique called "functional mode analysis" to identify collective motions in proteins that are directly related to their function. This method uses an ensemble of structures and a "functional quantity" that measures the protein's functional state to detect the motion most correlated with the quantity. The quantity can be a geometric, electrostatic, chemical, or other variable relevant to the protein's function. Additionally, the motion most likely to induce a change in the quantity is estimated from the ensemble. Two correlation measures are used: the Pearson coefficient for linear correlation and mutual information for any interdependence. This approach allows deriving a model for the functional state in terms of a single coordinate. The technique was applied to several biomolecules, including polyalanine-helix, T lysozyme, Trpase, and leucine-binding protein.

The method, termed "functional mode analysis" (MA), systematically identifies functionally relevant collective motions in proteins. It extracts the linear motion maximally correlated with an arbitrary quantity relevant to the protein's function. Established methods like PCA and NMA elucidate large and low-frequency modes, but do not necessarily yield motions related to function. Complementary to MD simulations, PCA and N are used to investigate collective motions. PCA extracts motions with largest variance, while N identifies low-frequency modes. Elastic models assess intrinsic motions to the structure. Many proteins function through structural transitions like motions, rotations, or reorientations. For some, it's unclear how functionally quantities relate to collective motions. The technique elucidates relations between dynamics and function.
Researchers studied the order of intron removal from transcripts of the tubA and gap genes in Euglena gracilis, which contain both conventional and non-conventional introns. Non-conventional introns do not have conserved characteristics of spliceosomal introns or complementary U1 snRNA at the 5' end, but form a stable secondary structure with exon/intron junctions. In contrast, conventional introns have conserved positions or are lost. The study found that non-conventional introns are removed before spliceosomal introns, and intermediate products of splicing were analyzed using PacBio Next Generation Sequencing. The results suggest a time gap between the two types of splicing. Non-conventional introns of Eugids are extensively studied, with about 100 described, and insert at new positions, whereas conventional introns are conserved or lost. Intermediate introns have features of both conventional and non-conventional introns. Only few genes annotated, but confirmed on genomic level. Non-conventional introns form a stable structure with exon/intron junction, not resembling self-splicing or tRNA introns, conserved to small extent.
Researchers investigated the impact of Coxsackievirus B (CV) infection on cardiac progenitor cells and postnatal heart development in mice. CVB is an enterovirus that commonly causes self-limited fever in infants, but severe cases can manifest as acute myocarditis. Chronic consequences of mild CV infection are unknown, but there is an epidemiological association between early subclinical infections and late heart failure, suggesting possible damage leading to late-onset dysfunction or ongoing injury due to inflammatory reactions during latent infection. A mouse model of juvenile infection with subclinical dose Coxsievirus B3 (CV3) showed no symptoms immediately following infection or in adult mice, but underwent cardiac hypertrophy and dilation indicative of progression to heart failure under physiological or pharmac-induced stress. Evaluation of vasculature in hearts of mice subjected to cardiac stress showed compensatory increase in CD31+ vessel formation, suppressed in juvenile-infected mice. CV3 efficiently infected c-kit+ cells, and cardiac progenitor numbers reduced in hearts of juvenile-infected mice. Results suggest exhausted progenitor pool following CV3 may impair heart's ability to increase capillary density adapt to increased load.
Researchers investigated the role of caspase-1 and cell death pathways in Burkholderia pseudalle infection of macrophages. They found that caspase-1 processing and pyptosis are dependent on NLRC, not NLRP, in the early phase of macroph infection, but later casase-1 activation and cell death are NLRC-independent. In the early phase, a pathway involving casases-9, -7, and PAR downstream of NLRC and casase-1 was identified. Casase-1 deficient macrophages showed strong apoptosis, dependent on activation of apoptotic and effector casases. The activation of casase-1 in macroph was reduced or abolished with B. pseudalle flagellin F or TSS3B mutant. The TSS effector protein B was shown to play a role in casase-1 processing. A TSS inner protein mutant failed to activate casase, had higher intracellular counts, reduced death, and IL-1 secretion in early but not late macroph infection. Intranasal infection of BAL/c mice with the mutant showed decreased mortality, lower bacterial loads, IL, myeloperoxidase, and neutrophils in bronchoalveolar lavage. The results indicate a major role of TSS in NLRC casase-1 activation pypt and contribution of casase-dependent cell mechanisms in B pseudalle pathogenesis.
Researchers investigated the role of Arabidopsis Kβ, a subunit of the SNF1-related kinase complex, in pollen-stigma interactions during pollination. They found that Arabid Kβ is localized in the cytoplasm and nucleus of vegetative cells in pollen grains and is essential for pollen germination on the stigma. A mutant Arabid Kβ pollen failed to germinate on the stigma, but germinated normally in vitro. Further analysis revealed compromised hydration of mutant pollen on the stigma, which was rescued by adding water to the stigma. The mutant exhibited defective biogenesis of mitochondria and peroxomes, and reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels. Overexpressing Arabid CATAL3, which reduces ROS, compromised pollen hydration on the stigma. These results indicate Arabid Kβ regulates ROS levels by mediating biogenesis of mitochond and peroxomes in pollen, required for pollen-stigma interactions during pollination.
In the bacterium Bacillus subtilis, the enzyme RNase III plays a crucial role in protecting the cell from the expression of toxin genes carried by two prophages, Skin and SP, through the degradation of antisense RNA. Unlike in other organisms, where RNase is not essential, in B. subtilis, its presence is necessary for survival. Two toxin-encoding mRNAs, txA and yT, from the prophages Skin and SP, are sensitive to RNase. The mechanism of RNase-mediated decay of txA mRNA paired with its antisense RNA, Rat, was explored in vivo and in vitro. RNase is not involved in ribosomal RNA maturation or mRNA turnover in B. subtil, as it is in other bacteria. The absence of prophages or toxin-encoding mRNAs, deletion of the RNase gene is possible, and growth of resulting strains is unaffected. The role of RNase in B. subtil is distinct from its function in other organisms, where it is part of a defense mechanism against viral infection.
Researchers studied the release of extracellular vesicles (EVs) by the parasitic nematode Brugia malayi, which causes Lymphatic Filariasis. They found that EVs are released by all life stages of the parasite, including microfilar, L3, L4, adult male and female worms, and are internalized by murine macrophages with no preference for stage, suggesting a uniform mechanism for effector molecule trafficking. Proteomic profiling of adult and female EVs revealed quantitative and qualitative differences in the EV proteome, defining the biogenesis of Brug EV and sexual dimorphic characteristics in immunomod cargo. Ivermect was found to inhibit EV release by all Brug life stages, also observed in the related nemat Dirofilar imitis but not in iverect-unresponsive isolate, suggesting a mechanism of action for this drug and new platforms for anti-filar drug development.
A cross-sectional survey conducted in ten rural villages in the Western Province of the Solomon Islands found a high prevalence of scabies and impigo. The total unweighted prevalence of scabies was 19.2% (95% CI 17.5-21.0) and age and gender weighted 19.2% (95 CI 16.7-21.9). The adult prevalence of scabies was 10.4% (95 CI 8.2-13.2), with the highest in infants under 1 year (34.1, adjusted ratio 3.6, 95 CI 2.2-6) and children 1-4 (25.7, ratio 2.6, CI 1.7-3.9). Scabies affected two or more body regions in 80.9% of participants and 4.4% were classified as severe. The unweighted prevalence of impigo was 32.7 (95 CI 30.6-34.8) and age and gender 26.7 ( CI 24.2-29.5). The highest was in children 1-4 (42.6, ratio 4.1, CI 2.9-5.8). Scabies was associated with impigo (ratio 2, 95 CI 1.6-2.6), with 41.1 of imp cases also having scabies.
Researchers have investigated the relationship between cellular proliferation in the hippocampus and T cells in adult mice. They found a significant correlation between the proportions of CD4 and CD8 T lymphocyte subsets and cellular proliferation in the hippocampus. This correlation is driven by genetic loci, with the exception of the H-2a locus, which influences T subsets but not neurogenesis. Knockout and repopulation of Tα-deficient mice confirmed the influence of T cells on adult neurogenesis, indicating CD4 T cells mediate the effect. The study reveals a broader impact of genetic variation on T cell development and homeostasis than previously suspected. Naturally occurring genetic variation is more physiologically relevant than knockout models. The correlation is due to sequence variants that differentiate inbred strains of mice. The findings extend previous observations that T cells contribute to adult neurogenesis. Analysis of outbred mice indicates the relationship between T cells and cellular proliferation is not an artefact of transgenic or knockout mice, but due to subtle genetic loci that contribute to variation in hippocampal proliferation. A correlation is found between cellular proliferation and relative proportions of CD4 and CD8 T cells, with higher proliferation associated with higher CD8 and lower CD4 cells. The correlation accounts for 6% of phenotypic variance.
Researchers investigated the efficacy of a multi-component DNA-prime/protein-boost vaccine (TVac2) against Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease, a major health problem in Latin America and emerging in the US. The vaccine consisted of antigens identified by computational analysis of the parasite's sequence and cytokines IL-12 and GM-CSF expression plasmids. Mice were immunized with antigen-encoding plasmids plus cytokine adjuvants, followed by recombinant proteins and challenged with T. cruzi trypastigotes. ELISA and flow cytometry measured humoral and cellular responses. TVac induced strong antigen-specific antibody (Ig2>Ig1) and moderate lymphocyte proliferation. Upon challenge, TVac-vaccinated mice expanded Ig2/Ig1 and elicited substantial CD+ T response with type 1 cytokines (IF-γ and TN-α) controlling acute parasite burden. During chronic phase, response persisted, splenic activation CD+ cells and IF-γ/TNF- cytokines subsided, and IL-4/10 cytokines became dominant in vaccinated mice. Tissue parasitism, inflammation, and fibrosis in heart and skeletal of TVac-vaccinated mice were undetectable by histological techniques. In contrast, injected vector or cytokines only responded T. cruz by elicitation mixed type 1/type 2 antibody, cell and cytok response, exhibiting persistent burden and immunology in myocardium. TVac-induced type 1 and lymphocyte responses provided resistance acute T. cruz infection, preventing chronic immunology associated parasite in chasic hearts.
Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have been successful in identifying susceptibility loci for complex diseases, but the question remains whether individual disease risk can be quantified based on genotype data for personalized prevention and treatment. Previous studies have failed to achieve satisfactory performance due to limited confirmed loci use. This study proposes machine learning approaches with ensemble markers to improve disease assessment. A Support Vector Machine (SVM) algorithm was applied to a GW dataset on type 1 diabetes (T1) and optimized a risk model with hundreds of markers. The model was tested on an independent Illumina-genotyped dataset (1,008 cases, 1,000 controls) and a separate Affymrix-genotyped dataset (1,529,1,458) with area under curve (AUC) of ∼0.84 in both. In contrast, poor performance was achieved with limited known loci in SVM or logistic regression. The study suggests disease assessment can be improved by algorithms accounting for interactions between large markers. Genotype-based risk may be feasible for diseases with notable risk captured by SNP arrays. A machine learning approach, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and logistic regression were tested for individual risk assessment of type 1 diabetes using three GW datasets. SVM achieved satisfactory performance with hundreds of SNPs, AUC ∼0.84 in several datasets. In contrast, SVM or logistic regression achieved AUC 0.66-0. A third dataset from the Genetics of Kidneys in Diabetes consortium was genotyped on the same platform as WTCCC1 and used shared markers for risk. The model can take additional predictor variables. Results from GW have enormous data for disease understanding, including risk using genetic profiles. False hits will arise, but approaches are robust with non-contributing markers and established markers.
Researchers have investigated the behavior of memory CD8 T cells, a type of immune cell that provides protection against viral infections, after they enter non-lymphoid tissues such as the skin during a secondary infection. They found that these cells traffic into the skin independently of CD62-mediated lymph node reactivation and provide robust immunity against Vaccinia virus (Vac) infection. Central memory (T) CD8 T cells, but not effector (TEM) memory CD8 T cells, differentiate into functional CD69+/CD- tissue residents following viral clearance, which is dependent on local antigen recognition in the skin environment. Memory CD8 T cells express granzyme and utilize cytolytic activity to provide immunity against Vac infection. This study demonstrates that central memory CD8 T cells become cytolytic following skin infiltration to protect against viral infection and differentiate into functional tissue residents.
Researchers have investigated the role of Myosin VI, a minus-directed motor protein, in the localization of axonal proteins in neurons. They found that Myos VI plays a crucial role in enriching proteins on the surface of axons by stimulating dendrite endocytosis, a mechanism that has been shown to underlie the localization of many axonal proteins. To test this, they engineered a non-neuronal protein to interact with Myos VI, causing it to become concentrated at the axonal surface in dissociated cortical neurons. Disruption of Myos VI function or expression led to aberrant dendritic localization of axonal proteins. Additionally, a version of Channelrhodopsin 2 engineered to bind to Myos VI was concentrated at the axonal surface of cortical neurons in mice in vivo, suggesting it could be a tool for probing circuit and function. The study indicates that myos help shape polarized distributions of both axonal and dendritic proteins, necessary for proper electrical signaling.
Researchers have identified two Doublesex (Dsx) genes, DmaD1 and DmaD2, in the freshwater branchiop crustace Daphnia magna, a species that parthenogenetically produces males in response to environmental cues. One of these genes, DmaD1, is responsible for male development during environmental sex determination. The organization of DmaD1 is similar to that of Dsx in insects, which are thought to be the sister group of branchiop crustans. However, the molecular basis of sexually dimorphic expression of DmaD1 differs from insects, as it exhibits differences in transcript abundance rather than sex-specific pre-mRNA splicing in the coding region. During embryogenesis, expression ofmaD1 is increased in males and transcripts are primarily detected in male structures. Knockdown ofma1 in males resulted in female traits, including ovary formation, while ectopic expression in females resulted in male-like phenotypes. Expression ofma2 is similar toma1 but silencing and overexpression did not induce clear phenotypic changes. These results establishma1 as a key regulator of the male phenotype. The study reveals how environmental sex determination is implemented by selective expression of a conserved genetic component in genetic sex-determining animals, inferring an ancient link between genetic and environmental determination.
Researchers have developed a trivalent HSV-2 vaccine that targets glycoproteins C, D, and E (g2, D, g2, E) to prevent genital herpes infection. The vaccine was tested in rhes macaques and guinea pigs. In rhes macques, the trivalent vaccine induced plasma and mucosal antibodies that blocked g2 and g2 immune evasion and stimulated CD4 cell responses. After vaginal challenge, a limited infection was detected in naïve but not trivalent immunized macques. In guinea pigs, the trivalent and trivalent +D groups were 97% and 99% efficacious in preventing lesions, outperforming g2 alone. Vaginal swabs showed reduced HSV-2 DNA and replication in all groups, with fewer days of shedding competent virus in trivalent g2 and none in trivalent +D. The trivalent had <1% lesions and 0.2% shedding competent virus. The vaccine has potential for preventing genital herpes in humans.
Researchers have developed a new method called Perm-se to improve the mapping of protein-DNA interactions in highly repetitive regions of the genome using chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by high throughput sequencing (Ch-se ). These regions are difficult to map due to short reads (50-100 base pairs) mapping to multiple locations in the reference genome. Standard methods discard multi-mapping reads or are prone to false positives and negatives. Perm-se uses data from DNase hypersensitive sequencing (DN-se) and histone Ch-se to allocate multiapping reads with high accuracy. It was evaluated on 64 ENCODE Ch-se datasets from GM78 and K562 cells, identifying novel protein-D interactions in segment duplications. These interactions are evolutionarily conserved and share characteristics with non-repet regions. A probabilistic model was developed to utilize DN-se priors and maps reads from repetitive regions with high accuracy. The method is versatile and can incorporate multiple data sources like histone-se for allocation.
A nested case-control study was conducted in Tanzania to investigate the effects of schistosiasis on susceptibility to HIV-1 infection and HIV-1 viral load at HIV-1 seroconversion. Approximately 40% of the population had Schistosoma mansoni infection and 2% had S. haematobium. Women with schist infections had a higher odds of HIV-1 acquisition than those without (adjusted OR 2.8 [1.2-6], p=0.019). Schist-infected men did not have an increased odds of HIV-1 acquisition (adjusted OR 0.7 [0.3-1.8], p=0.42). HIV-1 RNA levels in post-serconversion blood in HIV-1 serconverters with schistosias were significantly higher than those without schosias: 4.4 [3.9-4.6] log copies/mL versus 3.7 [3.2-4], p=0.017. Pre-existing schist infection increased odds of HIV-1 in women and raised HIV-1 viral load at HIV-1 serconversion.
Researchers investigated the variability of ribosomal DNA (rDNA) copy number and sequence in human and mouse genomes, particularly in the context of cancer. Using computational and droplet digital PCR approaches, they found that rDNA copy number and sequence can change in cancer genomes. Contrary to expectations, human cancer genomes showed a loss of rDNA copies accompanied by global copy number variation. The sequence was also more variable in cancer genomes. Genomes with lower rDNA copies had mutational evidence of mTOR hyperactivity. The PTEN phosphatase, a tumor suppressor, is critical for genome stability and negative regulator of mTOR pathway. Surprisingly, hematopoietic cancer cells from PTEN-/- mouse model leukemia had lower rDNA number than normal cells, despite increased rRNA and protein production. Loss occurred early and was associated with hypersensitivity to DNA damage. rDNA copy loss is a feature in cancers with mTOR activation, suggesting it may be an indicator of sensitivity to DNA treatments.
Researchers have developed a new approach to study the dynamics of bacterial growth, death, and spread within mammalian hosts during an infection. They used tagged wild-type and isogenic strains of Salmonella enterica, which are phenotypically identical but can be distinguished by quantitative PCR. This allowed them to estimate bacterial death rates based on the disappearance of strains over time. A multidisciplinary approach established the timing, occurrence, and control of key infection parameters in a host-pathogen combination. Analyses showed that shortly after infection, concom death and rapid bacterial replication led to establishment of independent subpopulations in organs, controlled by antimicrobial mechanisms. Later, decreased mortality led to exponential increase in bacteria spread, locally, with mixing between organs via bactemia and stochastic. This approach provides an unprecedented view of pathogenesis of S. enterica infections, illustrating spatial and stochastic effects driving disease. The method can be applied to diverse host-pathogen combinations, with modelling data, for comprehensive view of within-host dynamics.
Researchers have investigated the inverse problem of binocular 3D motion perception, which is the process by which the brain reconstructs 3D motion from visual information from two eyes. Current models of 3D motion perception, such as interocular velocity difference, changing disparity over time, and joint encoding motion and disparity, do not provide a general solution to this problem. Instead, the authors suggest that combining local velocity constraints with binocular disparity and other cues offers a more flexible framework for solving the inverse problem. In the context of the aperture problem, they derive two plausible strategies: (1) the normal prefers motion in 3D and (2) cyclopean motion based on slow in 2. Predicting motion for ambiguous lines provides an opportunity to distinguish between these strategies of 3D processing. Theoretical results indicate that velocity and disparity from tracking are necessary to solve 3 motion perception. It is plausible that motion and disparity are processed in parallel and integrated in the visual hierarchy.

Existing models of 3D motion are insufficient to solve the inverse problem of binocular 3 motion. Velocity constraints in binocular geometry demonstrate that additional information is necessary to disambiguate velocity and derive an estimate. Integration of motion and disparity with other cues can solve the inverse of local 3 motion, allowing the system to remain flexible when segmenting inputs from different stages into a 3 percept. Geometric intersection of two planes in binocular geometry defines a line in 3 velocity space. Tracking features in depth with bin velocity provides a strategy to disiguate 3 direction and solve the problem.
Researchers have investigated the role of AlgJ, a protein involved in the O-acetylation of alginate, a polysaccharide produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa during lung infections in cystic fibrosis patients. They determined the structure of Alg to 1.83 resolution and found it to be a SGN hyrolase-like protein, similar to the N-terminal domain of AlgX, but with a distinct electrostatic surface potential. A conserved catalytic triad of D190, H192 and S288 was identified, and Alg exhibited acetylease activity in vitro. Residues in Alg signature motifs formed extensive interactions critical for alginate Oetylation in vivo. Using electrospray ion mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) assays, Alg and Alg binding to alginate were compared. Alg exhibited weak or no detectable binding, while Alg bound polymannonic acid in a length-dependent manner, and utilized acetyl donor 4-nitrophenyl acetate to catalyze alginate Oety. The results suggest Alg and Alg have separate roles in alg Oetylation, with Alg as the terminal transferase.
Candida albicans, a common cause of human fungal infections and a significant source of mortality, evades detection by the innate immune system through masking its cell wall's inner layer of β(1,3)-gluc with an outer layer of heavily glycosylated mannoprote (mannan). However, mutations or drugs that disrupt the cell wall can lead to exposure of β(1,3)-glan unmasking and detection by innate cells like Dect-1, C-type lectin. The phosphatidylser (PS) synthase Cho1 plays a role in β(1,3)-glan masking, with homozygous mutant choΔ exhibiting increased exposure. Mitogen Activated Protein Kinase (MAP) pathways and upstream Rho small Gases regulate cell biogenesis and remodeling. In choΔ, C1 and M1 MAPs are constitutively activated, acting downstream of Gases C42 and R1, respectively. C42 activity is upregulated in choΔ. Activation of C42 or R1 and downstream kinases cause unmasking. Disruption of M1 does not decrease unmask inΔ, and hyperactivation R1 in wild-type increases unmask and activates C1 and M1. Hyperactivation Ste11 in wild-type leads to C1 activation and β(1)-glan exposure. Upregulation of C1 MAP causes unmask, responsible for unmask inΔ.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study of genetic loci associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related dementias using neuropathologic data from 4,914 brain autopsies. Neuropath data defined clinico-path AD or controls, coreath features of AD (neuritic plaques, NPs; neurofibr tangles, NFT), and coorbid neuropath changes: cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA), Lewy body disease (LBD), hippocampal sclerosis of the elderly (HS), and vascular injury (BI). Genome-wide significance was observed for clin-path AD, NPs, NFT, CAA, and L with variants in apolipoprotein E (APO), GAL7, ATP-binding cassette subfamily G member 1 (ABCG1), and intergenic region 9. Twelve of 21 non-APO genetic loci for clin-defined AD were confirmed in clin-path sample: CR1, BIN, CL, MS4A, PICAL, ABC, CD, TK, SOR, MEF, ZW, C4 with 9 of 12 showing odds ratio in clin-path. Correlation effect sizes for AD with NFT or NPs showed positive, while for VBI showed negative. Co-mor neuropath features showed nominal association with known loci. New associations were discovered with neuropath features and aligned genetic AD risk with specific changes in brain study of AD and dementias.
Researchers have long used urea as a denaturant to study protein unfolding, but its role in the process remains unclear: does it induce unfolding or stabilize the unfolded state? To address this, a study analyzed 30 proteins with diverse folds through molecular dynamics simulations using various force fields, deriving rules for urea unfolding valid at the proteome level. Irrespective of fold, disulfide bridges, or secondary structure, ure concentrates in the first solvation shell of native proteins with lower density than unfolded. Urea doesn't alter spontaneous vibrations, but reduces their magnitude, slowing atomic motions opposing unfolding. Urea's stickiness and diffusion are crucial for unfolding, with long molecules around hydrophobic cores stabilizing partially open structures. Simulations show ure doesn't favor open states, but actively unfolds, selecting and stabilizing partially, driving the ensemble far from native and thermal conformations.

Data indicates van der Waals drive ure accumulation on folded surfaces, but H-bonding stabilizes long-living interactions near hinges, biasing dynamics towards unfolding. Results provide a complete picture of ure's role in destabilizing folded states and mechanisms contributing to unfolding. Urea is a denatur used for decades, but its properties remain elusive. The dominant "direct" mechanism claims ure interacts strongly with exposed residues more than water. Under 8M ure at 368K, unfolding signals appear, but progress is smaller than stable proteins. Unfolding at 368 after 1µsec is independent of fold, structure, and similar with/without disulf bridges.
A systematic review was conducted to describe the epidemiology of deng disease in Colombia between 2000 and 2012. Literature searches were conducted using the terms "deng", "epemiology", and "Colia" in English and Spanish. 225 citations were identified, with 30 meeting the inclusion criteria. The epidemiology ofeng disease in Colombia was characterized by a stable annual number of deng fever cases, with outbreaks in 2001-2003 and 2010. Geographical spread ofeng cases increased, with most of the country affected by 2010. The majority ofeng cases were among those under 15 years old. Gaps in knowledge regardingeng disease in Colombia include asymptomaticeng infection, secondary infections, and underreporting. Improved understanding of factors determining disease expression is important for control and management.

The review describes national and regional trends, incidence by age and sex, seroprevalence and serotype, and other data. The review is part of a series in selected countries and Asia. It highlights non-severe deng disease reported in 201. There is a lack of information on asymptomaticeng, primary infections, severity, and underreporting in Colombia. Improved surveillance may address these gaps. Nationwide data showed a 90% increase in municipalities from 200 to 201 (424 to 743). Incidence was low in south-east Colombia, due to lowest population density.
Leishmaniasis (TL) is a disease caused by Leish parasites that affects skin and mucosal tissues. Patients with TL may concurrently carry other pathogens, which can influence the disease outcome. This review focuses on the frequency of TL coinfections in human populations, interactions between Leish and other pathogens in animal and human models, and implications for clinical practice. TL is defined as all forms of cutaneous, localized, disseminated, or mucocutaneous leishias. HIV coinfection, superinfection with bacteria, and manifestations of visceral leishias are not included. A literature search yielded 73 records: 21 studies in animals and 52 in humans, mainly cross-sectional and case studies. Reports describe Trypanosoma cruzi coinfection in TL patients in Argentina (41%) and helminthias in TL in Brazil (15-88%). Mechanisms of interaction between microorganisms are explored, but no clear answers emerge. Interactions may involve innate immunity and regulatory networks affecting quality and quantity of immune responses. Diagnostic problems occur when concurrent infections cause similar lesions (e.g., TL and leprosy), when pathogens present in same lesions (e.g., Leish and Sporothrix schenii), or similarities phylogenetically close pathogens affect accuracy tests (e.g., serology leishias and Chagas). Coinfections (e.g., helthias) reduce effectiveness of antileman treatment and combinations cause cumulative effects. In TL patients, coinfection is frequent, leading to diagnostic delays and treatment effectiveness and safety.
Researchers investigated the impact of genetic variation in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on CD4:CD lineage commitment and MHC expression in rats. They used two genetic models, the heterogeneous stock (HS) and a panel of M-recombinant congenic strains, to map quantitative trait loci (QTL) associated with variation in MHC class I and II protein expression and CD:CD T cell ratio. Ten QTL were identified across the genome, and those for individual traits colocalized within a region spanning the MHC. To identify genes underlying these QTL, a large panel of M-rebinant congenic strains was generated, and QTL refined to adjacent intervals of 0.25 Mb in the M-I and II regions. An interaction between these intervals affected M class I expression as well as negative selection and commitment of CD single-positive (SP) thymocytes. The effect was mapped to transporter associated antigen 2 (Tap) in the M-II region and classical M class gene (RT-A) in M-I. This interaction was revealed by recombination between RT-A and Tap, occurring in 0.2% of rats. Variants of Tap have been shown to influence antigenicity M class molecules by altering the class ligome. Results showed a restricted repertoire on M class molecules leads to reduced selection CD cells. This is the first study showing recombination between alleles in M influences commitment of cells.
This study analyzed hospital discharge records from Spain's National Health System's Hospital Discharge Database (CMB) to describe Chagas disease evolution from 1997 to 2011. A total of 1729 hospitalizations were identified, with rates of 18.2/100,000 and 24.2/100,000 population for the periods 1997-2004 and 2005-201, respectively. The median age was 35 years (0-87), with 74% female and 16-45 age group mostly represented (69.8%). 23.4% hospitalizations included Chagas disease with complications. Being male, aged 45-64, and hospitalization cost above 3,065 euros were associated with organ complications. Since 2005, detected infections increased in Spain, with asymptomatic patients, fertile women, and conditions associated with organ complications highlighting the need for early detection of T. cruzi.
Researchers have developed a novel approach called Blocuster to identify combinatorial interactions of genetic factors that contribute to complex diseases, such as psoriasis. This method efficiently constructs genome-wide, allele-specific networks that segregate homogenous combinations of genetic factors and tests their associations with a given phenotype, rigorously validating results using unbiased methods. Blocuster employs a correlation measure for single nucleotide polymorphisms and captures genetic heterogeneity. The team applied Blocuster to psoriasis data, discovering a combinator pattern with an odds ratio of 3.64 and Bonferr-corrected p-value 5.01×10−16. This was replicated in independent data, demonstrating the method's robustness. Blocuster improves disease prediction and understanding of psoriasis pathogenesis, and shows potential for discovering combinator genetic associations in genome-wide data, transcending "small" effects of individual markers in isolation. A Blocuster identified a bloc of 17 alleles in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) significantly associated with psoriasis, improving previous results by providing a precise allelic pattern. The odds ratio for the bloc was 3.45, compared to the highest single SNP odds of 2.41.41. Blocuster's network-based result is advantageous over conventional genome-wide association studies.
Researchers conducted a large-scale chromosomal copy number variation (CN) study in 255 patients with agenesis of the corpus callo (ACC), 220 with cerebellar hypoplasia (CBL), and 147 with polymicrogyria (PM), and 2,349 controls. They found that significantly more ACC patients had rare CNVs over 1 megabase compared to controls (p=1.48×10-3, odds ratio=3.19, 95% confidence interval=1.89-5.39), but not CBL or PM. Rare CNVs impacted at least 1% of the population. More ACC patients had CNVs over 20 genes compared to controls (p=0.01, odds=2.95, 95% CI=1.69-5.18). Independent PCR confirmation showed 9.4% of ACC patients had de novo CNVs, which preferentially overlapped with previously observed in autism disorders (p=3.06×10-4, odds=7.55, 95 CI=2.40-23). The study refined known CNs, including the 8p23.1-p.11 duplication in 2% of ACC, and found novel CNs in single patients, likely deleterious deletions and duplications. One patient with microcephaly had paternally inherited deletion 16.13 that included N1. Exome sequencing revealed recessive matally inherited mutation in non-deleted N1. This is the first systematic study of CN in congenital malformations, showing higher gene-rich CN in ACC than CBL and PM.
Researchers investigated the role of the Hippo signaling pathway effector Yorkie (Yki) in the regeneration of the freshwater planarian Schmidtea mediterrane. They found that Yki RNA interference (RNAi) animals exhibited hyperactivated and prolonged proliferative and transcriptional responses to injury, with increased stem cell proliferation and expression of wound-induced genes. Additionally, Yki RNAi animals showed expanded epidermal and muscle populations, which were hypothesized to be sources of wound-induced genes. However, Yki RNA animals failed to sense the size of an injury and correctly, and the brain, gut, and midline could not remodel to the size of the regenerating fragment. The study suggests that Y functions as a key molecule integrating multiple aspects of the injury response, including proliferation, apoptosis, injury transcription, and patterning. The results indicate that Y's effects on the wound response in planarians are due to the repression of the wound program, increasing stem cell response through extrinsic signals. Y RNAi animals displayed hyperproliferation, increased differentiation, and TUN staining, similar to Y's role in intact animals, and upregulation of key members of the transcription wound response. Y is thought to be a transcription coactivator, but has non-autonomous effects in Y RNA animals.
Researchers investigated the role of exosomes in the transmission of Enterovirus 71 (EV71), a virus that causes hand, foot, and mouth disease. They found that EV71-infected cells release exosomes containing viral RNA and microRNA-146, which is known to suppress the type I interferon response, a key part of the immune system. The exosomes also contained replication-competent EV RNA and proteins Ago2 and GW182, which allowed the virus to replicate in new cells independently of specific receptors. In recipient cells, the exosomal RNA replicated while mi-146 suppressed interferon response, facilitating viral replication. The study also found that interferon-stimulated genes, BST2/tether, regulated exosome secretion in EV71-infected cells. In vivo, exosomal RNA accumulated in tissues more than free virus particles. The findings suggest exosomes secreted by EV-infected cells package high levels of mi-146, which can be transferred and facilitate EV RNA replication in cells by suppressing interferon response.
Researchers have identified a protein, PG5, that modulates the activity of PINK, a gene responsible for early-onset Parkinson's disease, in fruit flies. PINK is a serine/threon kinase with a predicted mitochondrial sequence and transmembrane domain, while Parkin is a RING finger protein with ubiquitin ligase activity. The study found that loss of PG5 suppresses muscle degeneration, motor defects, and shorter lifespan caused by PINK inactivation, attributed to mitochondrial degeneration. However, PG5 inactivation fails to modulate phenotypes of Park mutant flies. Conversely, ectopic expression of PG5 exacerbated PINK and Park phenotypes. Results suggest PG5 regulates PINK pathway to maintain mitochondria, and acts between PINK and Park, or independently of Park downstream PINK. PINK is required to recruit Park to damaged mitochondria, promoting degradation through autophagy. Little is known how PINK regulates mitochondrial integrity through Park. Park mutations cause mitochondrial degeneration in subset of tissues, phenocopying PINK inactivation. PG5 is involved in PINK pathway, and affects in vivo phenotypes with Park mutations. Reducing mitochondrial fusion proteins or increasing fission can rescue PINK and Park phenotypes. PG5 is a PINK-binding protein, modulating PINK mutant phenotypes. Loss PG5 has little effect on lifespan of P1 RNA strain. The study demonstrates PG5 modulates PINK in flies. Further work is required to determine PG5 regulates PINK at molecular level and if manipulating PG5 provides therapeutic advantage in P1 PD.
Researchers investigated the role of interferon-γ (IFNγ) in host defense against Mycobacterium ulcerans (M. ulcer) infection, the causative agent of Buruli ulcer (BU), a chronic necrotizing skin disease. Histopathological analysis of BU lesions showed extracellular localization of acid-fast bacilli, but evidence suggests an early intracellular growth phase of M. ulcer. The study used an experimental BU mouse model and found that IFNγ is crucial for early immune defense against M. ulcer. IFN knockout mice had faster disease progression, with more tissue necrosis and edema, and higher bacterial burden after 5 weeks, indicating reduced intracellular killing of bacilli during early growth. This demonstrates IFγ's role in early defense against M. ulcer and supports the concept that tuberculosis vaccine strategies may be valid for BU. Reports of spontaneous healing and partial protection by Bacille Calmet-Guerin (BCG) vaccination in humans and mice indicate clearance of M. ulcer by the immune system, particularly before mycolone clusters form. The study shows IFγ-dependent activation of macrophage bactericidal activity helps contain infection during intracellular stages.
Researchers have investigated the mechanism of reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in mitochondria under hypoxia conditions. They developed a new methodology to mathematically analyze the process, considering all possible redox states in the electron transport chain. The model revealed two steady modes of operation (bistability) of respiratory complex III at the same conditions. Various perturbations can switch the chain from one mode to another. Normally, complex is in a low ROS producing mode, but ania can switch it to a high producing mode, which persists after oxygen return. This prediction was qualitatively validated experimentally, explaining ania-induced cell damage. The bistability of complex operation may lead to novel therapeutic strategies for oxidative stress. The model can be applied to other biological systems.
Researchers used an integrative systems approach to investigate the regulatory effect of the terminal gene huckin (Hkb) on gap gene expression in the early Drosophila melanogaster embryo. They presented quantitative data on H protein expression, enabling the inclusion of H in gap gene circuit models. Gap circuits are mathematical models of gene networks used to extract regulatory information from spatial data by fitting models to expression patterns and obtaining estimates for parameters predicting network topology. Variability in data combined with analysis significantly improved biological relevance and consistency. Models agreed with earlier results, extending in two respects: H is involved in regulation of the posterior hunch (hb) domain, but not essential for other functions. H is required for anterior shift in posterior border of domain, reproduced in models. Gap circuits reproduced terminal gene mutants, previously unable to reproduce null mutants correctly, capturing expression of posterior genes and variational properties. This is a step towards understanding developmental and evolutionary dynamics of gap network.
Researchers have developed a novel immunotherapy for Brucellos, a zoonotic disease causing significant economic losses worldwide, by using phage lysates of Brucella abortus strains S19 and RB51. Currently, no effective immunotherapy or biomarker for Bruclos is available, and treatment is ineffective, with animals remaining lifelong carriers. The live attenuated vaccine strains S19 induces antibodies, but is ineffective against intracellular pathogen, while RB induces cell-mediated immunity (CMI) but is rifampicin-resistant. Both organisms are secreted in milk, infecting humans and causing abortions in animals. Phage lysates retain immunogenicity, opposed to heat or chemical killing. The study reports successful immunotherapy of bovine Bruclos by phage of RB51 (RL) and S (SL), inducing strong antibody and CMI responses. In vitro restimulation of leukocytes from immunized cattle induced interferon production. A single subcutaneous dose of 2ml cocktail lysate (RL and SL) eliminated virulent Bruc from Bruclos affected cattle, with undetectable Bruc specific amplicons by RT-PCR and negative Bruc culture in 3 post-immunization. This is the first report on minimally invasive monitoring efficacy employing RNA specific bacteria as biomarker and use of RB phage for Bruclos immunotherapy in cattle.
Researchers investigated the role of cyclin-dependent kinase 2 (Cdk2) in the DNA damage response in human cells. They found that Cdk activity is required for cell survival after exposure to ionizing radiation, as inhibition of C2 with a specific inhibitor decreased cell survival, while C2+ cells were not affected. This suggests a specific requirement for C2 in orchestrating an effective DNA response to damage. By manipulating C2 activity with small molecules, they showed that it is needed after damage occurs, excluding the possibility of pre-existing defects in C2 mutant cells. They developed tools to identify additional functions and targets of C2 in DNA response pathways. The study challenges the idea that CD activity in response to damage is general, with no specific need for C2 to repair or resume cell cycle after repair. In vivo, phosphorylation of N1, a component of the MRN complex, occurs during S phase and is prevented by CD blockade or delayed by inhibition of C2. Mutations of N1-S432 that prevent phosphorylation increase sensitivity to cell-killing by IR, phenocopying selective inhibition C2. The study uncovered a C2-dependent pathway in DNA response of human cells.
Researchers used the formaldehyde-assisted isolation of regulatory elements (FAIRE) method to map active regulatory elements at loci associated with hematological traits, coronary artery disease, and myocardial infarction in megakarycytic and erythroblast cell lines. They found distinct patterns of open chromatin in the two cell types, with cell-specific openatin guiding the finding of functional variants. An openatin region on chromosome 7q22.3 in megaryocytes but not erythroblasts was identified, harboring the non-coding variant rs342 associated with platelet volume function. Resequencing this region in 643 individuals provided evidence that rs342 is the causative variant. The C- and G-differentially bind transcription factor EV1, affecting PI3CG expression in platelets and macrophages. A protein-protein interaction network in Pikcg knockout mice indicated PI3 is associated with pathways in platelet biogenesis and thrombus formation. This is the first elucidated variant among platelet quantitative loci. The study suggests a molecular mechanism for non-coding GWA SNP modulating plate phenotype.
Researchers simulated the effects of blocking a persistent sodium current (INa) in respiratory circuits using two pharmacological blockers with distinct mechanisms of action: tetrodotoxin (TX) and ruzole (R). TX directly blocks the sodium pore, while R shifts INa inactivation in the hyperpolarizing direction. In vitro studies using TX or R suggested IN is critical for bursting in pacemaker neurons and network generation in the pre-Betz complex. However, simulations show that R fails to block INP in the intact network due to its pharmacological mechanism and inhibitory interactions. Pre-bursting in the network is likely dependent on both inhibitory interactions and INP. TX application in the network is predicted to terminate rhythmicity. The hypothesis that INP is necessary for rhythmogenesis has fallen out of favor due to INP block by R failing to stop rhythms in intact preparations. This is based on the assumption R effectively blocks INP in vivo. The study predicts that after R, INP can be reactivated by hyperpolar perturbations due to R's mechanism. Simulated TX of INP does not yield the same effect.
Researchers investigated the role of microRNA-218 (mi-218) in the metastasis of gastric cancer (GC). They found that mi-218 expression is decreased in metastatic GC and its host gene, Slit, is also downregulated. However, mi-218 negatively regulates Robo1, a Sl receptor, establishing a negative feedback loop. Decreased mi-218 levels eliminate Rob1 repression, activating the Sl-Robo pathway through Rob1 and Sl2 interaction, promoting metastasis. Restoring mi-218 suppresses Rob1 and inhibits cell invasion and metastasis in vitro and vivo. The study reveals a Slit-mi-218-Robo regulatory circuit disruption contributing to GC metastasis, suggesting targeting mi-218 as a strategy to block metastasis. Upregulation of Rob1 in response to decreased mi-218 upregulates the Sl-Robo pathway through interaction with Sl2, facilitating cell invasion and metastasis. Rob1 is overexpressed in cancer and promotes angiogenesis and metastasis via Sl interaction. The inverse relationship between mi-218 and Rob1 was confirmed by immunohistochemistry in 40 GC cases and matched normal tissues. Rob1 is upregulated in GC, especially metastatic GC, with low mi-218 expression. Rob1 is a critical target of mi-218, an axon guidance receptor for Sl conserved in animals. Induction of Rob1 by Rob1 construct without mi-218 site reverses mi- suppression of tumor invasion, while Rob1 knockdown reduces invasion similar to restoring mi-218.
Researchers investigated the effects of plasma cholesterol-lowering on atherosclerosis development and identified a network of cholesterol-responsive genes that prevent the formation of advanced atherosclerotic plaques.
