The definition of partialanger has a transparent statistical meaning, depending on well-understood conditional variance.
Researchers have developed new methods for inferring local ancestry in individuals with mixed ancestry, such as Latinos, using genome sequencing data. Current methods for local ancestry inference are often designed for genotyping arrays and do not utilize the full spectrum of data from sequencing. Haplotype-based approaches are computationally demanding and time-consuming for large sample sizes. The new methods leverage continent-specific variants (CSV) to improve performance in sequenced genomes. A key feature is incorporating admixed genomes with public datasets like 100 Genomes to improve CSV calling. Simulations show the approach attains accuracy to computationally intensive haplotype approaches with decreased runtime. The method recovers local ancestries as 100 Gen consensus calls in admixed individuals from  Gen Project. The approach is extended to low-coverage sequencing, showing accurate ancestry can be attained at low coverage. CSV is generalized to sub-continental-specific variants (s) and can determine sub-ancestry for chromosomal segments based on s. 

The study presents an approach for local ancestry in sequenced admixed individuals using continent-specific variants (CSV). CSV density is high across the genome for fast and accurate inference. A study of 15,000 African Americans and 30,000 African recombination are examples. Sequencing catalogues larger variants, many being continent-specific. The concept is extended to sub-population variants (s) for ancestry assignment admixed from same continent. As sequencing costs decrease, computational accuracy becomes critical for local inference. The approach iteratively re-estimates CSV from inferred regions in admixed samples, first using external haplotype panels, then local ancestry, and re-CSV using confidently called segments. The variants are modeled within hidden Markov models to achieve efficient local inference (LancCSV). The model accounts for low-sequencing errors and finite reference panels.
Researchers have developed a new method to identify circadian oscillation in gene expression in mammals by applying digital signal processing algorithms to gene profiles. Traditional statistical analysis of periodicity is limited by small dataset size and noise, but this approach identifies circadian oscillation in almost 100% of expressed genes. The method involves converting single gene profiles into a continuous stream to reduce noise and enhance signal, then applying digital processing to identify patterns. This suggests oscillation is a natural feature of nearly all biological pathways, with genes displaying daily variation affecting the system as a whole. However, previous methods only considered one gene at a time, lacking power to identify circadian in more than a small percentage of genes. The new approach combines statistical tests for periodicity with digital processing to reveal circadian baseline in almost all genes. Changes in gene expression due to mutations or environmental factors should be considered in context of amplitude and phase changes of oscillations. The method was applied to murine liver data, identifying circadian deteriorating point at p=0.05 confidence level. Results show amplitude of core circadian genes does not differ significantly among tissues, and perturbations in oscillating systems depend on circadian time and wave properties of pathways.
Researchers used whole-genome resequencing to study recombination in a three-generation pedigree of collared flycatchers (Ficed albicollis) to map crossover and non-crossover events with high resolution. They identified 325 crossovers at a median of 1.4 kb, with 86% localized to <10 kb, and 267 non-crosso events. Crossover rates were higher in males (3.56/Mb) than females (2.28/M) and increased towards chromosome ends in males but not females. Crossovers were non-randomly distributed, with hotspots in genic regions, highest in promoters and CpG islands. Non-crosso locations were associated with crosso. A significant bias (0.18) favored 'G' over 'A' alleles at non-c events, indicating GC-bi conversion in avian system. This approach can be applied to other species, providing a comprehensive recombination landscape.
Researchers have studied the folding properties of repeat-proteins, which consist of repeated 20-40 amino acid stretches that fold into non-globular, elongated structures stabilized by interactions within and between repeats, but lack contacts between distant residues. They analyzed the folding landscape as a quasi-one dimensional problem due to inherent symmetries in sequence and 3D structure. A general description of repeat-protein energy was developed using an Ising-like treatment of elementary interactions between foldons, treated as spin variables. The overall properties of a complete domain (stability and cooperativity) can be derived from this description. The one-dimensional model implies simple relations for observables: free energy (ΔG) and cooperativity (m-value), not applicable to globular proteins. Parameters for coarse-grained description in foldon variables were extracted from detailed simulations on funneled landscapes. A case study of tetratricptide (PR) repeat proteins was presented, relating results to experimentally observed transitions. Single mutations significantly affected folding behavior, suggesting natural proteins are poised at particular ratios of inter/intra-element energetics, allowing transitions in physiological conditions, related to biological functions.
Researchers have investigated the role of the stress-regulated transcription factor CHOP in the development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), a type of liver cancer associated with viral hepatitis, obesity, and alcoholism. They found that CHOP is overexpressed in human and mouse models of HCC, and that CH-null mice are resistant to chemical-induced liver damage and fibrosis, a key risk factor for HCC. Gene expression profiling showed that CH deletion reduces basal inflammatory signaling in the liver. The study suggests that CH contributes to HCC by promoting inflammation, fibrosis, cell death, and compensatory proliferation, implicating CH as a common factor in H development in various liver diseases. CH is associated with liver injury and upstream of fibrosis, and its expression in CH-null mice differs from wild-type in a way that accounts for greater susceptibility to fib and oncogenesis. CH is placed upstream of fib and tumorigenesis, as CH-null animals are partially protected from both. The progression from CH to liver tumors occurs in a stepwise fashion, consistent with H etiology. Understanding CH mechanisms, direct and indirect, will have implications for other cancers beyond H. The study reveals an unexpected link between H and stimuli that predispose to it, suggesting points for therapeutic intervention. CH expression characterizes H tumors and impacts inflammatory expression and fib relevant to H.
A systematic review of clinical studies on the treatment of cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) caused by Leishmania aethopica in Ethiopia was conducted to identify potentially effective medications for clinical trials. 24 records reporting 506 treatment episodes of CL due to Lethopica were identified, with antimonials (201), pentam (150), and cryotherapy (103) being the most commonly used. However, only two small, poor-quality randomized trials and two non-randomized studies on cryotherapy, antimonials, and pentam were found. Cryotherapy showed 60-80% and 69-85 cure rates, while pentam was effective against complicated and non-responsive CL cases. All studies had methodological limitations. Data on milfosine, paromycin, and liposomal amphotin B were scarce, with few on DCL. Antimonials with parom or pent combination seemed effective, but not evaluated. The evidence for CL treatment of Lethica is limited, with antimonials the most available, but efficacy and safety in CL should be defined. Alternative treatments like milfos or paromycin should be explored. High-quality trials on Leth are needed to evaluate options in parallel.
Researchers have reconstituted a biochemical oscillator in vitro with three purified proteins, KaiA, KaiB, and KaiC, that displays salient properties of circadian rhythms, including self-sustained 24-hour periodicity and temperature compensation. They analyzed the biochemical basis of this oscillator by quantifying time-dependent interactions among the proteins using electron microscopy and native gel electrophoresis to elucidate the timing of complex formation among the proteins. Data were used to derive a dynamic model that accurately reproduces rhythms of Kai complexes and KaiC phosphorylation and is consistent with biophysical observations of individual protein interactions. Fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) confirmed monomer exchange among Kai hexamers. The model demonstrates function of monomer exchange may maintain synchrony among Kai hexers in reaction, sustaining high-amplitude oscillation. Perturbations of in vitro oscillator using temperature pulses reset phase of Kai oscillator, testing resetting characteristics unique circadian.
Researchers investigated the relationship between trial-to-trial variability in brain activity and behavioral performance in a visual detection task using electrocorticography (EG). They found an inverted-U relationship between trial-trial brain activity and performance, where higher variability in broadband EG activity near the trial mean was associated with higher hit rates and faster reaction times. This relationship was observed in both post-stimulus-evoked and pre-stimulus spontaneous brain activity, suggesting anticipatory dynamics. The findings support the presence of stochastic noise in the brain and attractor network theories, which propose the brain settles into a confined state under performance and proximity to the target is associated with better performance. Variability can be decoupled from trial-averaged activity and correlated with behavior, predicting a U or inverted relationship between trial-trial brain and performance. The study provides evidence for this phenomenon in human brain using EG recordings from patients undergoing neurosurgical treatment.
Researchers studied the mating-type loci (MAT) in 24 species of the Trichporales, a group of fungi closely related to the pathogenic Cryptococcus. They found that the MAT loci are fused into a single gene in each mating type, similar to the pathogenic Cryptoccus, but with different HD and P allele combinations. This suggests that the fusion of MAT loci occurred independently in Trichporales and pathogenic Cryptoccus, supporting the hypothesis of convergent evolution towards fused regions. Unlike other fungi, the content and order of genes within the fused loci are conserved in Trichporales, and there is no suppression of recombination extending to adjacent chromosomal regions. This indicates different mechanisms for evolution of linked MAT loci in these groups. The ancestral state of basidiomycetes is considered tetrapolar, with two unlinked MAT loci controlling mating at the haploid stage, but some species have bipolar systems through linkage of HD and P loci or loss of P locus function. Fungi are models for studying evolution of genomic regions involved in mating and type determination.
Chagas disease is the most important vector-borne disease in Latin America, with residual insecticide-based initiatives controlling domiciliated vectors in many regions. However, nonomiciliated vectors remain responsible for significant transmission and control is now a key challenge. A mathematical model was developed to predict temporal variations in abundance of nonomic vectors inside houses. Demographic parameters were estimated by fitting the model to two years of field data from Yuc peninsula, Mexico. The model accurately predicted field data in absence and presence of insecticide. Pyreth spraying was effective at 50mg2 applied yearly within two-month matching immigration season, achieving >80% reduction in abundance. Larger doses or more frequent interventions decreased efficacy, while different timing and lower frequencies drastically reduced. Insect screens reduced abundance proportionally to immigration rate. Control nonomic vectors by insecticide requires yearly application and understanding immigration pattern. Screens offer an effective, sustainable alternative for integrated control of neglected vectororne diseases.
Feather patterning in avian skin relies on a coordinated interaction between fibroblast growth factor (FGF) and bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) signalling, along with mesenchymal cell movement, in a reaction-diffusionaxis system. This system is partly mechanochemical, with mechanical-chemical integration through a positive feedback loop centered on FGF20, which induces cell aggregation, compressing the epidermis to intensify F20 expression. The travelling wave of feather formation is imposed by expanding expression of ectodysplasin (E), which initiates F20 expression. The E wave spreads across mesenchym cell gradient, triggering pattern formation by lowering the threshold of mesenchym cells to begin feather bud formation. These waves and precise arrangement of primordia are lost in flightless emu and ostrich, though via different developmental routes. The ostr retains arrangement of birds in general but lays primia without wave, akin to hair follicle formation in mammalian embryos. Embryonic em lacks cells to enact formation, causing failure, instead entire skin gains primia through later process. This shows reaction-diffaxis system, integrated with mechanical, generates feather array in flight birds. Key role EDA/Ectysasin receptor (EDAR) pathway in vertebrate patterning has been reactivated in quasi-1 manner, imposing highly ordered formation.

Feather patterning system relies on epithelial FGF to attract mesenchym cells form aggregate, absence F20 in scale mutant leads failure primium formation, demonstrating epider role in avian patterning. High-density dependence feather likely rests rapid mesenchal condensation stabil F20 than distinct cell phenotypes. Skin chicken, duck, ostr, and em embryos have pronounced differences arrangements. F20 elevated contracted tissue, supporting aggregation activation F production. Other genes analysed (AX2, BMP,4, E, ED) not alter conditions. Results operate reaction-diff system patter.
A systematic review of 33 studies on the presence of Ebola and Marburg virus in body fluids of infected patients and survivors was conducted. The aim was to determine the likelihood of active virus presence in human fluids (viral RNA). Eligible infections included Marburg virus (MARV) and Zaire, Sudan, Ta Forest, and Bundibuyo species of Ebola. Studies were screened for laboratory confirmation of infection through tissue culture or RT-PCR tests, or clinical history with subsequent filirus antibodies or inflammatory factors. 683 articles were found, with 33 eligible. Most fluid types had insufficient data to draw conclusions, with variable positivity prevalence. Fluids taken >16 days after onset were usually negative. RT-PCR tests for filirus RNA gave positive results 4 times more often than tissue culture. Filirus was reported in most fluid types, but not every sample from confirmed patient. Apart from semen, non-blood RT-PCR samples likely negative and possibly low risk. Contact with blood and blood-stained fluids major transmission risk due to high viral loads in blood.
Researchers have developed a new mathematical model, called the fractional leaky integrate-and-fire model, to describe the timing of neuronal spikes in the brain. This model takes into account the power-law behavior of the membrane voltage, which cannot be characterized by a single time constant, due to correlated conductance processes. The emergent effect of these correlations is a non-Markian process, modeled with a fractional derivative. A fractional derivative is a non-local process where the value is determined by integrating a weighted voltage trace, or memory. The model varies the exponent of the derivative from 0 to 1, with 1 representing a normal derivative. As the exponent decreases, the weights of the voltage increase, making the value correlated with the past voltage trajectory. The model reproduces upward and downward spike adaptations in cortical pyramidal and tectal neurons in vitro. It also produces spikes with longer first-spike latency and interpike variability with power-law distribution. The model analyzes adaptation and responses to noisy oscillatory input, generating reliable spike patterns in response to noisy input. The spiking activity of the fractional model deviates from Markov model, reflecting accumulated membrane dynamics affecting response to external stimulation.
Researchers identified six superoxide dismutase (SOD) isoforms in the genome of Paracidioides, a genus of pathogenic fungi. These enzymes counteract reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced by host immune cells, allowing the fungus to survive. The study analyzed gene expression of SODs in different stages of Paracoides life cycle, including yeast, mycelia, and conidia, as well as under oxidative stress and phagocytic cell interaction. Results showed increased expression of PbSOD1 and PbOD3 during transition, exposure to oxidative agents and phagocytic cells, suggesting these proteins combat superoxide radicals during host-pathogen interaction. Knockdown of PbOD1 and Pb3 showed involvement in response to host effector cells, particularly oxidative stress, in mouse infection model. Protein analysis and knockdown strains suggest Pb3 linked to extracellular activity while Pb1 to intracellular. Data indicate Paracoid responds to endogenous radicals and oxidative burst by inducing SOD isoforms.
Researchers investigated the relationship between intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) and chaper binding in various species, including E. coli, S. cerevisiae, and metazoa. They analyzed high-throughput interaction data and found that predicted disorder by the IUP algorithm negatively correlates with chaper binding, indicating that IDPs tend to avoid chaper. This effect is observed across prokary, unicellular eukary, and metaz species. The presence of ordered domains, such as Pfam, may contribute to this effect. Chaper binding to disordered proteins is often accompanied by binding to other proteins, suggesting that ID use chaper for assembly with partners rather than folding. In all three taxonomic groups, non-chone-binding proteins have higher disorder than chone-binding proteins. Predicted disorder does not distinguish between proteins with or without glob domains, so the authors selected chone binding of proteins with at least one glob domain. ID that bind chone are more likely to bind other proteins than ordered ones. There is overlap between chone and nonone-binding proteins, so the authors compared disorder of those that only bindone and those that bindone and other proteins. Results show a difference in disorder between the two groups.
In Drosophila melanogaster, the Spalt (Salm) and Spalt-related (Sal) zinc finger transcription factors are regulated by the Decapentaplegic (Dpp) signaling pathway in the wing imaginal disc. These genes are required for cell survival and proliferation in the central region of the disc and vein patterning in the lateral regions. To understand the genetic control of growth and patterning by Dpp, identifying direct Salm and Sal target genes and analyzing their functions is crucial. Candidate Salm/Sr targets were identified by comparing sal/sr knockdown wing discs with control discs in microarray experiments and in situ hybridization of genes whose mRNA levels varied, revealing a complex transcription landscape regulated by Sp in the disc. Targets include genes with expression turned off and on by Salm/Sr, and loss-of-function analysis indicates a fraction requirement for growth and pattering. This opens a new avenue to reconstruct the genetic structure of the wing, linking Dpp activity to epithelial tissue development.
Researchers have identified two protein phosphatases, GSP-1 and GSP-2, and their regulators I-2Y-2 and SDS-22, as key regulators of ZYG-1 levels in Caenorhabditis elegans. ZYG-1 is a homolog of the human Plk4 protein, which is required for centri duplication. The study found that downregulation of PP activity either directly or mutation of I-2Y-2 or SDS-22 rescues the loss of centri duplication associated with a zyg- hypomorphic allele. This is achieved through an increase in Z-1 levels, indicating PP regulates Z- through post-translational mechanism. Moderate inhibition of PP activity restores centri duplication in z- mutant, but strong inhibition in wild-type leads to centri amplification via production of more than one centri. The study defines a new pathway limiting number of daughter centri produced each cycle. PP activity is a critical regulator of Z- levels and centri duplication, previously implicated in regulation of centrosome separation at mitosis.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in the municipality of Campinas, southeastern Brazil, to investigate the transmission of visceral leishmanias (VL) in an environmentally protected area (EPA). The study aimed to determine the presence of Leishmania spp. infection in domestic dogs, wild mammals, and sand flies using molecular and serological techniques. Canine seroprevalence of 1.5% and 1.2% were observed in 2013 and 2015, respectively. Six species, confirmed or suspected vectors or transmitters of Leish, were identified, including the main L. (L) infant vector in Brazil, Lutzia longipal, captured in the EPA. Natural infection by L. (L) infant was recorded in one Expillatia firm specimen and Pintia montola. Infection by L. (L) infant and Leish subgenus Viia was detected in white-eared opossum (Didel albivent), a known reservoir of VL. Geographical coordinates of each sampling infected animals plotted on a map of the EPA demonstrated proximity between animals, human residences, including dogs positive VL, and forest areas. The EPA has an active VL focus. The risk of establishing and maintaining disease foci in similar scenarios, i.e., wild areas undergoing modifications, is evident. Different epidemiological profiles of VL must be included in prevention and control measures considering the particularities of each area.
Epstein-Barr virus (EB)-encoded microRNA miR-B9 promotes tumor metastasis by targeting E-cadherin in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. MicroRNAs (mi) are small RNA molecules that regulate gene expression and play critical roles in cellular processes. EB, an oncogenic virus, is associated with nasaryngeal carcinoma (NPC), a highly metastatic tumor in Asia. Previous studies found viral proteins promote migration and invasiveness, but not all tissues express these oncoproteins, suggesting other mechanisms contribute to tumor behavior. Our sequencing revealed high mi-B9 in EB-positive tissues. We investigated mi-B9 in EB-negative and EB-positive cells using gain and loss-of-function approaches. mi9 promotes migration and invas in vitro and metastasis in vivo. Computational analysis revealed mi9 targets Eadher, pivotal in cell junctions and epithelial phenotype. Biochemical and functional analysis confirmed mi9 inhibits Ead to induce mesenchymal phenotype and promotes migration. Results indicate mi9 a promastatic viralRNA and high levels in EB-positive cells contribute to aggressiveness.

The abundance of mi9 coupled with downmodulation cellular mi-200 in EB tumors drives epithelial to mesenchal with enhanced motility and metastasis. mi9 and mi-200 share sequence, critical for interaction. Studies shown mi-200 significantly downmodulated in tumors. We demonstrated EB-encoded mi9 highly in tissues mi9 directly targets Ead to mesenchal and migratory in cells. Sequencing revealed mi9 most abundantly expressed EB in tumors. Taq-based PCR confirmed majority tissues mi9 higher than oncogenic mi21. Depletion mi9 increased luciferase activities indicated suppression mi9 activities 50-70 with treatment lentiviral-mi9 expressing cells. Ectopic mi9 physiological promotes migration capability EB-negative cells confirmed mi9 promatory viral. Unlike LMP and L proteins, transcripts consistently detected all cases indicate mi9 significant contributor migr and invasive EB-infected cells.
Researchers have developed a command-line tool called gashimi for visualizing splicing events across multiple samples. Given a genomic region, gash creates sash plots for individual RNA-seq experiments and aggregated plots for groups of experiments, a feature unique to this software. Unlike existing tools, gash uses bioinformatics formats, is annotation-independent, and visualizes splicing for large regions by scaling genomic segments between splice sites. gash is available on GitHub and implemented in Python, generating R code for plotting.

A tool for drawing sash plots was initially part of the MISO software, quantifying alternative splicing from RNAq experiments. Current implementations include a standalone utility for sash plots for M-index splicing and built-in IGV. Visualization of RNAq data is crucial for exploratory analysis, but splicing visualization is not integrated in common browsers or standalone software and is annotation-dependent. Visualizing splicing is challenging as events occur between regions, not contiguous on the genome, distant tens or hundreds of kilobases.

For comparison, the genomic region containing splicing was represented using gash and sash in IGV. gash aggregated samples through the same group and shrunk intron lengths, enhancing visualization. The sash representation splicing is a standard, but current implementations have limitations narrowing its application. gash solves many issues, eliminating specialized formats and supporting hundreds of samples.
Researchers have developed a probabilistic model to predict and align cis-regulatory modules (CRMs) across species, addressing limitations of existing sequence alignment methods for conserved non-coding sequences. The model captures evolution of transcription factor binding sites (TFBS) and background sequences, including gains and losses of TFBS, a crucial for regulatory evolution. A computational framework uses this model to solve CRM alignment and prediction problems, improving over existing methods. The approach is similar to statistical alignment but uses conserved sites to improve alignment and deals with uncertainties of binding annotations and sequence in a probabilistic framework. Simulated and real data demonstrate the method's superiority over state-of-the-art methods. Alignments were used to study genome-wide binding of transcription factors in Drosophila blastoderm, revealing: (i) factor-bound sequences are under evolutionary constraints even if neighboring genes are not expressed, and (ii) distal sites are more conserved than proximal. The approach is implemented as software EM (Evolutionary Model cis-regulatory Module) for broad application.
Research on the Drosophila piRNA pathway has revealed distinct functions in genome maintenance and telomere protection. The piRNA pathway silences transposons in the germline, but its role during development was unclear. Mutations in genes arm, aub, ago3, and rhi led to extensive fragmentation of the zygotic genome during cleavage stage embryonic divisions. a and arm showed defects in telere resolution during meiosis and cle divisions, while mutations lig-IV, which disrupts non-homous end joining, suppressed fusions. By contrast, lig-IV enhanced chromosome fragmentation. Chromatin immunoprecipitation showed a and arm mutations disrupted telere binding of HO, a component of the telere protection complex, and reduced expression of 19-22 telere-specific piRNAs. Mutations r and ago did not block HO binding or production of theseRNAs. These findings uncovered separable functions for the Dophila pi pathway. a, arm, r, and ago silenced transpos and maintained chromosome integrity during cle-stage embryonic divisions, while a and arm had additional function in assembly of the telere complex. a and arm were required for T recruitment, consistent with ligation of chromosome in mutant embryos. a and arm had function in telere protection not shared ago or r. Drosila chromosome breaks can be converted to stable teleres, terminal deletions with additional copies of teleric elements He-A and TART. Terminal deletions passed in heterozygous for a or pi gene showed increased T repeats.
Researchers have identified a new Ebola virus species, Bundibugyo ebolavirus, responsible for a hemorrhagic fever outbreak in Uganda. The outbreak occurred in November 2007 in Bundibyo District, Western Uganda, with 149 suspected cases and 37 deaths reported. The new virus is distantly related to Côte'Ivo ebolavirus, found in western Africa, despite the large geographic distance between the two countries. Initial investigation used classic antigen capture, IgM and IgG ELISA, and a newly developed random-primed pyrosequencing approach to identify the virus. Evidence of Ebola infection was detected in eight specimens using a broadly reactive ebavirus capture assay and IgM assay. The Ugandan Ministry of Health was notified on November 28, 2007. Bundugyo ebavirus diverges significantly from previously recognized ebaviruses, suggesting antigenic and pathogenic differences. Current ebavirus vaccines, Zaire and Sudan, may not protect against this new virus. Cross-protection studies are needed to assess vaccine efficacy. Retrospective analysis of case, epidemiologic, and laboratory data from the Bundugyo outbreak show a lower fatality rate (36%) compared to Zaire (80-90%) and Sudan (50-55%). Studies in non-human primates are needed to compare pathogenicity. Antigen-capture, Ig, Ig, and real-time PCR assays were transferred to the Uganda Research Institute for rapid case identification and control. The outbreak continued through December 2007, resulting in 149 cases and 37 deaths.
Researchers analyzed a large dataset of 648 Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients with an average 4.78-year follow-up to quantify the heterogeneity in disease progression. The Global Deteration Scale (GDS) and Functional Staging (FAST) procedures characterize seven stages from normal to severe dementia, with published mean durations but unknown variances. Calculations for DS/FAST stages 4-6 revealed standard deviations comparable to mean durations, indicating large variations among patients. This heterogeneity is consistent with subgroups differing in decline patterns. A longitudinal analysis showed significant variation in DS/FAST 4-6 durations, with standard deviations similar to mean values, indicating cognitive and functional decline variability. The study suggests AD is a heterogeneous disease, supported by literature. Temporal variability in AD progression ranges from months to decades, with biological correlates investigated but underlying reasons uncertain. A combination of factors may contribute to variability. This study's finding large heterogeneity in DS/FAST durations aligns with reports, using a 23-year dataset representing stages 4-7 AD. The Functional Staging (FAST) procedure, based on DS, describes 16 stages from normal to severe AD, enumerated with some differences. A 5-year follow-up study associated severe frontal lobe involvement with rapid AD, and a 15-year study examined progression patterns.
Researchers have extended a model of adult neurogenesis in the hippocampus to include realistic spatially driven input patterns from grid cells in the entorinal cortex. They compared network performance across three adaptation strategies: conventional plasticity, turnover, and additive neurogenesis. Additive neurogenesis was found to be superior, allowing the network to adapt to changing input statistics while preserving earlier representations. A more biologically plausible neurogenesis rule incorporating cell death and plasticity of new granule cells outperformed individual strategies. This rule can be tailored for short or long-term memory. The model was also used to examine adult neurogenesis over an animal's lifetime under different rearing conditions, showing distinct profiles that could be tested experimentally. Place cells emerged in a realistic manner due to sparsification by the dentate gyrus layer. The model is based on rodent literature and provides a starting point for comparative analysis as more data becomes available. The hippocampal circuit was examined across environments with realistic input from grid cells, confirming additive neurogenesis superiority over conventional plasticity and turnover. A multidimensional Gaussian distributions modeled input patterns at the entorinal layer.
African trypanosomes express three identical cytosolic glutathione peroxidase (Px)-type enzymes, which detoxify lipid-derived hydroperoxides. Previous studies have shown that Trypanosoma brucei lacking mitochondrial PxIII exhibit a weak and transient proliferation defect, while parasites lacking cytosolic PxI and PxII undergo rapid lipid peroxidation and lysis. The phenotype can be rescued by supplementing with α-tocopherol derivative Trolox. This study reveals that the lysosome is the origin of cellular injury. Feeding PxII knockout parasites with Alexa-conjugated dextran or LysoTracker in presence of Tro yields discrete lysosomal staining. Upon withdrawal of antioxidant, the signal spreads over the whole cell and is lost. T. bruce acquires iron by endocytosis of transferrin. Supplementing medium with iron or transferrin induces, while iron chel deferox and apo transferrin attenuates lysis of PxII knockout cells. Immunofluorescence with MTracker and lysosomal marker p67 shows disintegration precedes mitochondrial damage. In vivo experiments confirm negligible mitochondrial peroxidase role: infected PxIII cells display slightly delayed development compared to wild-type. Data demonstrate lysosome, not mitochondrion, is primary site of damage in African trypanosomes. Cytosolic trypanione/tryparedin peroxides protect lysosome from iron-induced peroxidation. This is linked to high endytic and iron acquisition in infective stage T. bruce. Cytos PxII knockout in procyclic form is viable in Tro-free medium.
Researchers have investigated the role of the protein PMEL in melanosome formation and pigmentation in mice. PMEL is an amyloid protein found in melanocytes that forms fibrils within melanosomes where eumins are deposited later. It is conserved across vertebrates and variants in several species are associated with reduced eum in epidermal tissues. However, the effect of these variants is unclear and no complete loss-of-function has been reported in mammals. A mouse line was created with the Pmel gene inactivated (P−/−). These mice are viable, fertile, and display no developmental defects. Melanosomes in P−/− melanocytes are spherical, unlike the elongated shape in wild-type. This was observed in skin-derived melanocytes and retinal epithelium melanocytes. Inactivation of P has a mild effect on coat color in different backgrounds, most notable in brown/Tp mice. This is similar to the silver mutation, suggesting other alleles are dominant-negative. Despite mild effect on pigmentation, P− led to reduced eum in hair, showing PMEL's role in efficient epidermal pigmentation.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of environmental methods for deng vector control. Nineteen studies were eligible, with sixteen contributing to the meta-analysis. The methods evaluated were: (a) container covers with insecticides, (b) waste management and clean-up campaigns, and (c) elimination of breeding sites by rendering mosquito breeding sites unusable. Quality was highest for container covers with insecticides, followed by waste management without direct collection and elimination of breeding sites. Both review and meta showed a weak effect on larval populations, with no differences between individual results. Meta-analysis showed container without insecticides (BI: -7.9, DOE-5) and waste with garbage collection (BI: -8.83, DOE-6.2) achieved strongest reductions for BI, whereas P results were opposite with covers insect (P: -0.83, 0.09) and elimination (P: -0.95, -0.83). Each method showed effectiveness in reducing larval and pupal densities Aedes mosquitoes. However, high-quality studies are needed to strengthen evidence. A previous studies concluded environmental management was effective on vector indices, and a combination of community-based management and container covering water reduced deng risk. This study aimed to review and meta-analyze effectiveness of environmental methods. Searches were finished May 2017, but no further studies altered results or published. Both review and meta showed environmental interventions reduced lar and pupal densities Aedes.
Researchers have identified small molecules that selectively inhibit protein synthesis by stalling the ribosome, a potential strategy for therapeutic development of compounds. Compounds that inhibit PCSK9, a regulator of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, have been shown to reduce LDL in preclinical models and affect translation of few off-target proteins. However, the impact on cell physiology and ribosome control pathways is unknown. A genome-wide CRISPR screen was used to identify proteins and pathways that modulate growth in presence of PCS9 translational inhibitor PF-06303 (PF3). The most potent genetic modifiers of fitness in presence PF3 were ubiquitin binding protein ASC2 and helicase ASC3, which bind to ribosome and protect from toxic effects of high concentrations. Surprisingly, translation control proteins Pelota (PE) and H1 sensitize cells to PF3 treatment. Genetic experiments showed ASC3 acts with ASC2 and downstream of H1. These results identify connections between ribosome control pathways and provide insights into selectivity of compounds that stall translation, aiding development of next-generation compounds to treat disease.
Researchers have discovered that the Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSH) protein, SO, induces widespread destruction of cellular messenger RNA (mRNA) in host cells to evade immune detection and block gene expression. However, the mechanism of SO-induced mRNA turnover remained unknown, despite its lack of intrinsic ribonuclease activity. The study found that SO stimulates cellular RNA turnover through a novel mechanism involving aberrant polyadenylation, where SO-expressing cells exhibit extended poly(A) polymerase-generated poly(A) tails and polyaden-linked mRNA turnover. Polyaden changes correlate with RNA function, and inhibition of poly(A) tail formation blocks SO activity. Both nuclear and cytoplasmic poly(A) binding proteins are critical cofactors for SO function, with the latter undergoing striking nuclear localization by SO. SO-induced turnover represents a new mechanism of host shutoff and a model to probe poly(A)-stimulated mRNA turnover in mammalian cells. The study reveals a link between polyadenylation and RNA surveillance, as yeast mutants defective in RNA processing accumulate hyperadenylated transcripts, and analogous pathways may function in higher eukaryotes. Polyadenated precursors to RNA have been detected in mammalian cells.
Researchers investigated the role of type III interferon (IFλ) in the immune response to bacterial pathogens, specifically Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, in the lung. They found that IFλ is induced during bacterial infection and promotes inflammation by inhibiting microRNA-21 (miR21) regulation of PDC4, a protein that promotes inflammatory signaling. In mice lacking the IFλ receptor, IL-28, or PDC4 had improved clearance of airway pathogens and reduced pulmonary pathology with lower levels of inflammatory cytokines. IFλ and P4 are conserved elements in the response to airway pathogens with differential effects on innate immunity. The expression of IL-28, more abundant on epithelial cells than immune cells, may be important in specific cytokine responses to pathogens. Mice lacking IL-28 had increased miR21 levels and reduced inflammatory cytokines in the airway, while those with IL-28 reduced mi21 at 18 hours post-infection correlated with prolonged P4 expression. The study concludes that inhibiting IL-28 signaling reduces lung inflammation and improves bacterial clearance.
Researchers conducted a retrospective study on 781 cases of advanced-stage 2 human African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) admitted to the National Center for African Trypanosomias in the Democratic Republic of Congo between 1989 and 2012. The study aimed to investigate mortality trends and risk factors. Death was the outcome variable, and age, gender, duration of disease, location of trypanosomes in body fluids, cytology, protach, clinical status, and treatment regimen were predictors in logistic models. Death rates were 17.2% in the meloprol schedule, 12.1 in short melrol, 5.4 in eflorine, 9.1 NECT, and 36% in severely affected patients given eorine. After adjusting for treatment, death odds ratios were 10.40 for clinical dysfunction on admission, 2.14 for protach, 1.99 for parasites in CSF, and 1.7 for cytach. Multivariate analysis retained clinical status and protach as predictors of death. An algorithm for clinical assessment used in the study may serve as basis for development of standardized tools for H management and epidemiological reports.
Researchers have developed a computer vision pipeline to study the effects of isolation on social dynamics in Drosophila melanogaster, a model organism for studying small-scale, temporary social behavior. The pipeline includes an improved tracking system to follow large groups of flies and an algorithm to quantify changes in social networks in response to isolation. The study found that isolation significantly enhances individual and local network parameters, depicting near-neighbor relationships. Genome-wide molecular correlates of behavioral changes showed gene expression alterations on day one, mostly in metabolic genes, verified by increased lipid content in isolated flies. A reliable tracking pipeline was established for large groups to unravel behavioral, molecular, and physiological impact of isolation on social dynamics in Drosila. 

The pipeline was applied to study effects of isolation on social dynamics, correlating changes with genome-wide expression. Results show strong effects on social dynamics, gene expression, and physiology. The toolset for social analysis includes molecular, genetic, individual, grouped, and behavioral analysis. Dophila melanaster is a model for studying behavior and its mechanisms. Behavioral and expression changes initiated early, while alterations lasting, gene levels transient. Data suggest after one day of isolation, flies alter physiology, promoting interactions with neighboring flies. Walking distance is an individual parameter changing persistently. The approach differs in classification strategy and dataset extraction. A previous study generated unweighted networks, concluding isolation had no effect on networks.
A clinical pilot study was conducted in rural Bangladesh to evaluate the impact of a smartphone adaptation of the World Health Organization's (WHO) diarrheal disease management guidelines, including a modality for age-based weight estimation. The study consisted of a 6-week pre-intervention and 6-week intervention period with 10-day post-discharge follow-up. A total of 841 patients were enrolled (325 pre-intervention, 516 intervention). During the intervention, the proportion of prescriptions for intravenous (IV) fluids decreased at both district and sub-district hospitals (p < 0.001) with risk ratios (RRs) of 0.5 and 0.2, respectively. However, when IV fluids were prescribed, the volume adhered to recommendations. The proportion of prescriptions for the antibiotic azithromycin increased (p < 0.001; district p= 0.035 sub-district) with RR of 6.9 (district) and 1.6 (sub-d) while prescriptions for other antibiotics decreased; zinc adherence increased. The study demonstrates that a smartphone tool can improve guideline adherence.
Researchers investigated the impact of temperature on host-parasite interactions using a mechanistic model of within-parasite dynamics in Daphnia magna and its microidian parasite Ordpora collata. The study aimed to integrate temperature dependencies of host and parasite traits, such as survival and virulence, into models of disease dynamics. A metabolic theory of ecology (MTE) was used to specify relationships between host mortality, parasite growth, virulence, and abundance. The model effectively predicted host survival, parasite growth, and infection cost across temperatures with fewer parameters than discrete models. Results demonstrated the potential of linking M-based models with mechanistic host-parite framework to predict temperature responses of parasite dynamics at the within-host level. 

The study analyzed data on host and parasite across a temperature gradient using an M-based model of within-parite population to capture thermal dependencies of aging and virulence. A mathematical model was fitted to experimental data on Daphnia and Ordpora to examine effects of temperature on traits, interactions, and dynamics. Nine temperatures spanned the range of D, quantifying lifespan for exposed and unexposed, and parasite abundance at death.
Researchers investigated the role of inhibitory neurons, specifically GABAergic interneurons, in shaping the activity of excitatory pyramidal cells (PCs) in the brain. They found that three types of interneurons, parvalbum (PV), somostatin (SOM), and vaso intestinal (VIP), play a crucial role in controlling the distribution of somatic and dendritic inhibition onto PCs. PV interneurons primarily target the soma and basal dendrites of PCs, while SOMneurons target the apical dendrites and inhibit other interneurons. VIPneurons connect to SOMneurons, creating a disinhibitory circuit for distal dendrites of PCs. The researchers proposed a network motif consisting of SOM and VIP interneurons to control PV-mediated redistribution of somatic and dendritic inhibition. Using a computational model, they showed that the properties of the circuit support this hypothesis. They demonstrated that the SOM-VIP motif allows the circuit to switch between two processing modes, either integrating or cancelling top-down inputs onto apical dendrites of PCs. The study suggests that this subnetwork optimizes control of different input streams and processing modes.
Microbiome-wide association studies (MWAS) aim to link specific microbes to host phenotypes by comparing microbial abundances between two groups of samples. However, abundance differences reflect not only direct associations with the phenotype but also indirect effects due to microbial interactions. Researchers found that interactions can generate a large number of spurious associations providing no mechanistic insight. Using techniques from statistical physics, they developed a method to remove indirect associations and applied it to the largest dataset on pediatric inflammatory bowel disease. The method corrected inflated p-values in association tests and showed only a small subset is directly linked to disease. Direct associations had higher accuracy in separating cases from controls and pointed to immunomodulation, butyrate, and brain-gut axis as factors in inflammatory disease.

The study found that realistic interactions produce spurious associations between microbiome and phenotypes, many of which can be removed by a procedure based on maximum entropy models from statistical. This approach, dubbed Direct Analysis (DAA), was applied to a case-control study of Crohn's disease. Traditional MWAS lost power to identify the link between phenotype and microbiota, and an unbounded number of detections were observed, suggesting previously reported associations could be indirect. The study estimated the contribution of indirect to MW and isolated direct associations, showing interactions generate detectable changes in abundance not linked to host.
Researchers compared the effects of Wolbachia infection on the replication and transmission of two flaviviruses, Dengue (DENV) and West Nile (WNV) viruses, in Aedes aegypt mosquitoes using two Wolbach infection models: stable transfection and transient infection. Stable Wolbach infection has been shown to inhibit various pathogens, including DENV, CHV, WNV, and Plasium, but some studies suggest Wolbach can enhance pathogen replication under specific conditions. In this study, Wolbach had similar blocking effects in both stable and transient models, but the magnitude was lower in transiently infected mosquitoes. No enhancement of DENV or WNV Kun strain infection was observed in Wolbach infected Ae.egypt, supporting Wolbach as a safe means to restrict transmission. Wolbach density was correlated with pathogen blocking in Wolia hosts, and lower densities in transient mosquitoes explain reduced D blocking. Experiments were repeated with WNV Kun strain, with similar results. Wolbach density was lower in transient compared to stable infected.
In Caenorhabditis elegans, cilia are microtub-based organelles that mediate signal transduction and are organized into structurally and functionally distinct compartments: the basal body, the transition zone (TZ), and the cilium. In vertebrates, the protein Invers localizes to a portion of the cilium adjacent to the TZ, termed the Invers compartment (Inv). The mechanisms that establish and maintain the Inv are unknown. In C. elegans, the cilia of amphid and phasm sensory cilia are subdivided into regions by different microtub ultrastructure: a proximal doublet region adjacent to the TZ and distal singlet region. It has been suggested that C. elegans cilia possess an Inv, similar to mammalian primary cilia. This study explored the biogenesis, structure, and composition of C. eleg ciliary double region and Inv. The Inv is conserved and distinct from the double region. n-2 (C eleg Invers hom) and double region genes l-13, l-11, and unc-119 are redundantly required for cili. Inv and double region can be sorted into modules n-2p-11 and l-13-119, which are antagonized by hd- deacetyl. The genes modulate the sizes of N- Inv and A- double region. Glutlation, a tub-trans modification, is not required for ciliary of Inv and double components; rather, glut is modulated by-2, -13, and-119. The ciliary and localization of N-, A-, and UNC does not require TZ, double region and Inv-associated. N- requires its calcium EF domain for targeting Inv. The C eleg Inv is distinct from double region, and components interact to regulate cili via placement, ciliary microtub ultra, and protein.
Researchers have identified a crucial role for the polarity protein Scribble in myelination and remyination in the central nervous system. Scribble is expressed throughout oligodendrocy development and is upregulated in mature oligodrocytes, where it localizes to developing and mature myelin sheaths. Knockdown of Scri expression in cultured oligodrocy results in disrupted morphology and myelination initiation. Conditional elimination of Scri in myinating glia of transgenic mice disrupts myelination in CNS during development and following demyelination, and myelin sheath extension is disrupted at later stages. Scribble acts to regulate myelin thickness by suppressing extracellular signal-related kinase (ER)/mitogen-activated protein (MAP) kinase pathway and localizes to noncompact myelin flanking the node of Ranvier, where it is required for axo-glial adhesion. Scri function is compartmentalized through interactions with different protein complexes at radial or longitudinal growth sites. Scri plays a role in oligodrocy morphological differentiation, myelin initiation, and myelin regulation, and also in myelin regeneration. Scri is restricted to noncompact myelin membranes, localizing to axo-gl adhesion sites. Oligodrocy differentiation is not affected in Scri knockdown conditions, but myelination is disrupted. In vivo, myelination in CNS is disrupted in Scri cKO mice. Myelin thickness is increased in developed tracts in ScriKO oligrocy, but not in remyelination. Small diameter axons lack myelin sheaths in Scri c CNS.
Researchers have identified a novel peptide, Listerin S, associated with a subset lineage of Listeria monocytogen, a Gram-positive pathogen responsible for listeriosis. Listerin S is a hemolytic and cytotoxic virulence factor, contributing to the pathogen's virulence in murine and human polymorphonuclear neutrophil-based studies. This finding expands the family of modified virulence peptides (MVPs) and reveals the genetic basis for enhanced virulence in a proportion of lineage L monocytogen. Until now, modified virulence peptides have been rarely reported, and S-like cytolyins were exclusively associated with Streptoccus sp, including group A and G streptocci and Siae, a fish pathogen. However, gene clusters encoding S-like factors are present in other Gram-positive pathogens, including L monocogen, Staphylococcus aureus, and Clostridium botulin. The L monocogen cluster encodes an inducible cytotoxic and hemolytic peptide, Listerin S, which plays a role in path survival in PMNs and contributes to virulence in mouse model. The Listerin-associated cluster is variable, present in subset isolates from lineage I, associated with majority of epidemics of this fatal pathogen. In silico analysis demonstrates gene clusters encoding S-like factors in notorious Gram pathogens, including monocogen, aureus, and botulin.
A study was conducted to investigate the expression of interleukin-17 (IL-17) and matrix metalloprotease-9 (MMP-9) in mycetoma granuloma, a persistent granulomatous inflammatory disease caused by fungi or bacteria. The disease is characterized by the formation of macroscopic structures called grains, surrounded by a massive inflammatory reaction. The study aimed to determine if IL-17 and MMP-9 expression correlated with the severity of the disease, independent of the causative agent. Biopsies from 100 patients with myetoma were obtained and IL-17 and MMP-9 expression evaluated immunohistochemically. IL-17 was mainly expressed in Zones I and II, and less in Zone III, while MMP-9 was mainly in Zones II and III, with least in I. MMP-9 was highly expressed in Actinadura pelletii and Streptomyces somensis biies compared to Madura myetatis biies. MMP-9 levels were directly proportional to IL-17 (p=0.001) and correlated with disease duration (p<0.001). There was no correlation between IL-17 and patients' characteristics. The study demonstrated IL-17 and MMP-9 presence in myet granuloma, with IL-17 more in larger lesions and longer duration. A positive correlation was found between IL-17 and MMP-9 levels. Immunohistochemistry showed IL-17 and MMP-9 presence, but not formation time. Further studies are needed to determine IL-17 and MMP-9 roles in granuloma formation and myet immunogenesis.
Researchers investigated the molecular recognition mechanism of intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs), specifically the transcription activation domain of the Ewing Sarcoma oncoprotein family (E), which exhibits features of "fuzziness", a phenomenon characterized by polyvalency, sequence insensitivity, and dynamic disordered bound-state conformations. They hypothesized that E-target interactions involve polyc-π contacts between disordered E residues and basic target cations. Experimental and theoretical studies of E variants support the c-π model, with trends captured by a coarse-grained E model and analytical interaction between E aromatics and cations. E-target binding is driven by a balance between E conformation entropy and favorable c-π contacts. This versatile recognition mode offers a framework for promiscuous target by polyval IDPs.
Researchers investigated the functions of two ATP-dependent proteases, Lon-1 and Lon-2, in Borrelia burgdorferi, the bacterium responsible for Lyme disease transmitted by ticks. Previous studies showed that Lon-1 is upregulated in response to blood exposure, while Lon-2 is not. This study aimed to clarify the roles of these proteases in B. burgorferi. Phylogenetic analysis revealed Lon-1 and Lon- cluster separately due to differences in substrate binding domains, suggesting distinct specificity. Recombinant Lon-1 exhibited ATP-dependent chaperone-protease properties but did not complement E. coli mutant, while Lon2 corrected Lon-mut phenotypes. The study concludes that B. burgorfer Lon-1 and-2 have distinct functions. Lon-2 functions like canonical Lon in cellular homeostasis, while Lon-1, induced by blood, may be important in host adaptation from arthropod to warm-blood host. The presence of Lon-1 as a feature of Boria indicates its relevance to arthrop-transmitted pathogens. B. burgor Lon-1 may function in host adaptation where it could be a protease during rapid spiroete proliferation during bloodmeal with protein increases. The ability of- and Lon- to complement dysregulate cps implies differential capacity to degrade RA and supports Lonc-like role for- in Boria.
Researchers investigated the role of antibody-dependent phagocytosis (ADP) in controlling HIV-1 infection, a mechanism thought to be involved in controlling other viral infections. They measured the ability of HIV-specific polyclonal and monoclonal antibodies to mediate the internalization of HIV-1 virions and HIV-1-decorated cells by phagocytes. Using a green-fluorescent protein-express molecular of HIV-1JR, an R5 clinical isolate, in combination with polyclonal HIV or monoclonal antibodies, they found minimal or no AD of virions with any antibodies. However, coating virions with gp41 or gp-derived peptides gp41, but not gp120-specific antibodies efficiently mediated phagocytosis. A minimum of a hundred gp41 molecules were needed for successful phagytosis, similar to the number of envelope spikes on viruses phagocosed, such as influenza. Fluorescence correlation spectroscopy showed a clear association between virus aggregation and AD. In contrast, vir-decorated cells were targets for AD orgocytosis in presence of HIV antibodies. Findings indicate AD of vir may not play a role in preventing infection due to paucity of trimers and inability of vir-bound antibody to cross FcRs on phocytes. However, AD orocyt could play in clearing infected cells on verge of infection.
A global study estimated the economic and health burden of hookworm infection in 2016 from a societal perspective, using a computational model. The results showed that hookworm infection resulted in 2,126,280 Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) using 200 disability estimates and 4,087,803 DALYs using 201 estimates, excluding cognitive impairment. Including cognitive impairment did not significantly increase DALs worldwide. Productivity losses varied with anemia calculation method, ranging from $7.5 billion to $138.9 billion using Gross National Income (GNI) per capita as a proxy and from $2.5 to $43.9 billion using minimum wage as a proxy. The study found that hookworm's economic burden exceeded estimates of diseases with more attention, such as rotavirus. Countries transitioning to higher income, like Brazil and China, still face considerable hook burden. The Global Burden of Disease (GBD) 2010 reported 3,230,800 DALs annually due to hook among all ages in 21 regions, including disability weights for hook outcomes and anemia, but not cognitive impairment. Assuming median anemia, hook infections resulted in productivity losses $11.1 billion (95%: $5.5-18.5) using Method 1, $87.9 (95: $1.7-302.3) Method 2, and $23.1 (95:11.4-38.4) Method 3. Using minimum wage, global burden was $3 billion.
Researchers investigated the effects of hypoxia on the developing brain in vertebrates, specifically zebraf (Danio rerio), and found that it disrupts axon pathfinding in forebrain neurons, leading to commissural axons failing to cross the midline. This occurs through activation of the hypox-inducible transcription factor (HIF) pathway, mimicked by chemical inducers of HIF or expression of constitutively active Hα. Blocking transcriptional activation of Hα prevented guidance defects. EphrinB2 was identified as a target of H pathway activation, with knockdown of EphB rescuing guidance errors and receptor EphA expressed in a pattern complementary to misrouting axons. Constitutively active EphB targeted to neurons mediated errors via reverse-signaling. Magnesium sulfate, used to improve neurodevelopment outcomes in prebirths, protected against errors by preventing upregulation of EphB. These results demonstrate evolutionarily conserved pathways regulate changes in CNS response to hypox, supporting a neuroprotective role for magnesium.
Researchers conducted a study to investigate pulmonary abnormalities in mice with paracidiomycosis using high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and histopathological findings. Paracidiomycosis is a fungal disease that affects the lungs and can spread to other parts of the body. The study aimed to define patterns and intensity of lung lesions in infected mice by comparing HRCT and histopathology. Male BALB mice were inoculated with Paracoides brasiliensis conidia or PBS. HRCT was done every 4 weeks to determine lung lesions, density, and structure. Lungs were analyzed by histology and histometry. Three lesion patterns were found: nodular-diffuse, confluent, and pseudo-oral. Lesions were mainly around the hilus and affected the left lung. At 4 weeks post-challenge, 80% of infected mice had peri-bronial consolidations with increased lung density compared to controls. After 8 and 12 weeks, consolidation progressed to middle regions. Histology showed consolidation as confl granulomatous reaction, nodules as compact granomas. At 16 weeks, confl granomas formed pseudooral masses obstructing bronchi. Discrete fibrosis was visible around granomas but only by histology. This study showed HRCT is useful for evaluating and quantifying damage in experimental paridiomycosis.
Researchers conducted a proof-of-concept study to evaluate the interferon-gamma release assay (IFN-γ) as a marker for latent Leishmania donovani (L. donov) infection in visceral leishmaniasis (VL) endemic areas. They modified a commercial kit, QuFERON, with five Leish-specific antigens: H2, H2-PS2, H-Le12, crude antigen (CSA), and soluble Leish antigen (SL) L. don to detect cell-mediated response in VL. The study included 13 active VL patients, 15 cured patients, 11 non-endemic controls, and 19 healthy controls. The assay based on SL had 80% sensitivity (95% CI 54.81-92.95) and 100% specificity (95 CI 74.12-100). Results suggest a whole-blood SL-based QuFER assay can measure cell response in L. don infection. Positive IF-γ response to Leish antigen in VL patients contradicts conventional non-proliferative antigen response in peripheral mononuclear cells, requiring further research.
Researchers have discovered that the CNFY toxin, a virulence factor produced by Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, plays a crucial role in the bacteria's ability to establish a persistent infection in the host. The toxin enhances the translocation of anti-phagocytic effectors, leading to inflammatory responses, tissue destruction, and alteration of the intestinal microbiota, and bacterial clearance suppression. However, suppression of CNFY function increases interferon-mediated responses, non-inflammatory antimicrobial activities, and tolerogenesis, allowing the bacteria to reprogram its transcriptional response towards persistence. This adaptation gives the bacteria a fitness advantage against host responses and facilitates a commensal lifestyle. The study demonstrates that removal of a single virulence factor, CNFY, is sufficient to dampen inflammation and evade the host's defense, favoring Yers persistence. The mechanisms behind this process are unclear, but the impact of CNFY suggests a set of immune responses, including IL-6 levels, immune modulators, bactericidal activities, and anti-inflammatory factors, which contribute to this process. Suppression of CNFY shifts the balance of bacteria-triggered inflammation and clearance towards immune suppression, promoting establishment of asymptomatic infection.
Researchers have identified a novel pathogenic gene, DES1, in the fungus Magnaporthe oryza, which plays a crucial role in suppressing the basal defenses of the host plant during colonization. The gene was discovered through screening for pathogenic-defective mutants in a T-DNA insertional mutant library. Bioinformatic analysis revealed that DES encodes a serine-rich protein with unknown biochemical properties and homologs conserved in filamentous Ascomyc. Targeted deletion of DES had no effect on developmental morphogenesis, vegetative growth, conial germination, appressium formation, and appressium-mediated penetration. However, conial size of mutant was smaller than wild type, but mutant showed no defects in cell wall integrity. The Δdes mutant was hypersensitive to exogenous stress and activity and transcription of extracellular enzymes, including peroxidases and lacc, were decreased in mutant. Additionally, ferrous ion leakage was observed in Δdes mutant. In interaction with susceptible rice cultivar, cells inoculated with Δdes exhibited strong defense responses, including brown granules in primary cells, accumulation of reactive species (ROS), generation autofluorescent materials, and PR induction in neighboring tissues. Δdes displayed significant reduction in hyal extension, causing decrease in pathogenicity. Suppression of ROS by treatment with dipheniodium (DPI), inhibitor of NAD oxidases, resulted in significant reduction in defense in tissues challenged with Δdes. Furthermore, Δdes recovered normal growth in DPI-treated tissues. Results suggest DES functions as novel pathogenic gene regulating activity of proteins, compromising plant defense.
Researchers evaluated the accuracy of a predictive model-based (MB) approach for mapping schistosomiasis prevalence in Ghana by comparing it with empirical data from school-based surveys. The study found that using the predicted values alone, 21 out of 25 schools determined to be high-risk for Schistosoma haematium infection would have been undertreated, and 20% of schools would have been treated despite empirically-determined absence of infection, resulting in 28% of children being undertreated and 12% receiving unnecessary treatment. The predictive map was not adequate for guiding the national program when aggregated to the district level, but assessing each school in potentially endemic areas is not feasible; modeling should be a complementary to empirical assessments. The study suggests predictive mapping should be an iterative process incorporating empirical testing and refining to create updated versions meeting disease control managers' needs.
Researchers have investigated the mechanisms guiding motile sperm through the reproductive tract to oocytes in Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that oocytes synthesize sperm-guiding prostaglandins from polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUA) precursors in yolkoprotein complexes. Using genetics and electrospray ion tandem mass spectrometry, they partially delineated F-series prostland metabolism. Omega-6 and omega-3 PAs, including arachid and eicosapentaic acids, are converted into more than 10 structurally related F prostagland, which collectively and redundantly promote sperm guidance. Disruption of omega-3 PU synthesis triggers compensatory upregulation prostagins from omega-6 PAs. C elegans prostland synthesis involves biochemical mechanisms distinct from mammalian cycxygen-dependent pathways, yet PG2 stereomers are synthesized. A conserved cytochrome P450 enzyme, whose human homolog is implicated in Bti Crystine dystrophy, regulates prostland synthesis. Results support the model multiple cycxygen-independent prostland function to promote sperm motility for fertilization.
Researchers have developed a new approach to design biotherapeutics with reduced immunogenicity, a major barrier to their clinical application. They used algorithms to optimize proteins for low T cell epitope content and high function, revealing a spectrum of designs that trade off between immunogenicity and function. The Pareto frontier, a set of undominated variants with no single better performance in both criteria, was constructed and experimentally evaluated. Eighteen variants were produced and analyzed for performance, correlating with computational predictions. This work outlines a design-based approach to functional deimmization of biotherapeutic candidates. Next-generation protein deimmization tools integrate epitope prediction with in silico analysis of functional consequences, enabling global design on a compressed scale. Predictions correlated with experimental function, showing incremental T epitope deletion leads to concomitant loss of function. Tradeoffs were borne out in real analyses. The Pareto designs reveal an inverse relationship: greater deimmization at expense of reduced function. To assess implications, 18 enzymes were recombinantly produced and characterized for stability, activity, and immunoreactivity with human MHC proteins.
Researchers investigated the effect of elevated temperature on meiotic recombination in Arabidopsis thalian, a plant species that undergoes sexual reproduction through meiosis. Meiosis relies on the exchange of DNA between homologous chromosomes, known as crossovers (CO), to ensure proper chromosome segregation. The frequency and distribution of COs are regulated by intrinsic and extrinsic factors, but more is known about the molecular mechanisms governing the former than the latter. The study found that elevated temperature increases meiotic recombination in Arabidopsis and used genetic analysis of mutants in recombination pathways to demonstrate that extra COs are derived from the Type I interference pathway. This pathway is sensitive to interference, whereas the Type II pathway is not. The study also showed that heat-induced COs are not due to an increase in double-strand breaks and the hyperrecombination phenotype is specific to thermal stress rather than a generalized response. The findings provide insight into how environmental cues modulate plant meiotic recombination and may offer practical applications.
Researchers have developed a novel computational approach to navigate the vast and rapidly evolving landscape of biomedical literature, particularly in molecular medicine, by creating a knowledge-based system that combines reading, reasoning, and reporting to facilitate data analysis. This system, called Hanalyzer, extracts information from external resources, structured or unstructured data using natural language processing, and tracks provenance. Reasoning enriches the knowledge by noting genes annotated to the same ontology or database and combines sources into a network representing relationships between genes, calculating a reliability score. Reporting combines the network with congruent constructed from experimental data and visualizes in a tool for knowledge-based analysis. Hanalyzer was demonstrated on a large-scale gene array dataset relevant to craniofacial development, identifying roles of four previously uncharacterized genes, validated by further work.

The system includes a plugin, Coscape, tracing provenance links and accessing sources (Figure 2), and exploiting inferences not in individual sources. To present relevant knowledge, sub-networks are selected and presented comprehensively, visualizing with fidials or generating sub-networks. A more effective method is creating a data network from experimental results and combining in various ways. In this application, a data was constructed from gene expression experiment relevant to cranfac.
Helminth parasites, specifically Fasciola hepatica, secrete extracellular vesicles (EVs) that can be internalized by host cells, modulating the host's immune response. While the cargo of EVs has been characterized in many parasites, little is known about the surface-exposed molecules that participate in ligand-receptor interactions with host cells to initiate vesicle docking and internalization. This study used membrane-impermeable biotin reagent to capture proteins on the outer surface of two subpopulations (15k and 120 EV) released by adult F. hepatica, describing 380 proteins including virulence factors, membrane proteins, and molecules involved in EV biogenesis/trafficking. Proteomics and immunohistochemical analysis showed 120 EVs have endosomal origin and may be released via the protonephial excretory system, while larger 15 EV are from gastrodermal epithelial cells lining the gut. Lectin microarray strategy profiled surface oligosaccharides of intact fluorically labelled EV, showing identical glycoconates on 15 and 120 EV but distinct from parasite tegument, predominated by mannose sugars. EV were resistant to exo and endoglycosases, but glycosidase PNG remodelled surface and blocked uptake by macrophages. Pre-treatment with antibodies from infected hosts or purified against EV surface proteins significantly enhanced internalization.
Researchers have identified a cycling DOF transcription factor, C2 (CDF2), which plays a crucial role in regulating microRNA (miRNA) biogenesis in plants. miRNAs are first transcribed as stem-loop primary miRNAs (pri-mi) by RNA polymerase II and then cleaved into mature miRNAs by Dicer-like 1 (DCL). CDF2 interacts with CL and regulates the accumulation of a population of miRNAs by binding directly to the promoters of some miRNA genes, acting as a transcriptional activator or repressor. It also binds preferentially to pri-mi regulated by itself and affects CL-mediated processing of these prii. Genetically, C2 works in the same pathway as mi156 or mi172 to control flowering. C2 regulates a group of prii at both transcription and post-transcription levels to maintain proper levels of mature miRN to control plant development. This regulation is achieved through coordination of transcription and processing of a group of prii. C2 also regulates expressions of components involved in mi biogenesis, potentially affecting biogenesis by regulating levels of these components.
Researchers have identified a crucial role for geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GG) in the establishment of communication between oocytes and granulosa cells in the ovary, a process essential for folliculogenesis and female fertility. GG, a metabolic intermediate in protein geranylation, increases in oocytes during early follicular development. Depletion of GG in oocytes impairs granosa cell proliferation, primary follicle transition, and female fertility. Mechanistically, GG depletion inhibits Rho GTPase geranylation and GTP activity, leading to accumulation of junction proteins in oocyte cytoplasm and disrupted oocyte-granosa contact. GG also blocks Rab27 geranylation, affecting secretion of oocyte materials such as G9. Administration of GG restores defects in o-granosa contact, granosa proliferation, and primary follicle transition in Gpps mice. This study demonstrates GG-mediated geranylation contributes to o-granosa communication and regulates primary follicle transition, a key phase of folliculogenesis.
Researchers have created a structural model of the RNA polymerase II (Pol II) elongation complex with a complete transcription bubble to understand how nucleoside triphosphate (NTP) substrates enter the active site of the enzyme. Despite previous biochemical and biophysical studies, it was unclear whether the secondary channel was the only route for NTP entry or if the main channel could be an alternative. Crystallographic structures of Pol II have provided insight into the basis of transcription, but the conformation of the unpaired non-template part of the transcription bubble (TB) was unknown. The researchers used molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and structural analysis to shed light on NTP pathways. They found that both channels have enough space for N loading, but the percentage of conformations with space for N loading through the secondary channel is twice that of the main. Energetic simulations with N loaded in channels revealed diffusion through the main is disfavored by electrostatic repulsion between N and negatively charged nucleotides in non-template DNA. Results suggest the secondary channel is major for N entry during Pol transcription.
Dengue is a reportable disease in Thailand and Cambodia, but the reported incidence underestimates the true burden of the disease. Researchers used laboratory-confirmed outpatient and inpatient cases from prospective studies to estimate the magnitude of deng underrecognition and establish accurate burden estimates for these countries. Cohort studies were conducted among children under 15 years of age from a deng field site consortium over two deng seasons. Age-specific multiplication factors (MF) were computed by comparing cohort data to national surveillance in the same province and year. In Thailand, 14,627 person-years of cohort data were obtained in two provinces and 14,493-years from one in Cambodia. Average incidence of laboratory-confirmed deng was 23/1,000 and 25/1,000 in Thailand, and 41/1,000 in Cambodia. Calculated MF in provinces varied by age and year (0.4-29). Average age-specific MF applied to country data indicated in Thailand 229,886 (210,612-331,236) deng cases annually 2003-2007 and 111,178 (80,452,357,135) in Cambodia. Underrecognition total inpatient deng cases 8.7 and 2.6 in Thailand, and 9.1 and 1.4 in Cambodia. During high incidence 2007, over 95,000 in Thailand and 58,000 in Cambodia estimated hospitalized due to deng. Calculating MF comparing cohort to surveillance is one approach to assess burden. Data indicate deng reported many countries underestimates true disease. 

A study demonstrated non-hospital patients deng represent substantial burden. D has been major health problem in Thailand and Cambodia, children under 15 especially affected. Both DF notifiable.4 (0.02) underestimation inpatient in 2003-07. Estimates 111,178 (80,452,357,135) symptomatic d occurred each year maximum 58,118 in 2007. Age-specific and application nationally data shown Table 3.7 and 1.1. Incidence over periods 2.6/1,000 Kameng and 4.5/1,000 Ratchuri. Applying average 8.7 (0.13) underrec total symptomatic in each year. Country factors derived studies or capture useful national data assess burden economic. Estimating under on provincial (1) and ratio (2) showed variation years and age within sites.
This study investigated the role of natural killer (NK) cells in promoting CD8 T cell responses against cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. Researchers used congenic or mutant mice and genetically engineered viruses to examine the consequences of NK cell defects on antiviral CD8 cell responses. The results showed that NK cells accelerate CD8 cell responses in vivo by limiting immunosup IF-α/β production, which reduces plasmacyoid dendritic cell (pDC) cytokine production, preserves conventional dendritic cell (DC) compartment, and accelerates antiral CD8 cell responses. Conversely, exogenous IF-α administration in animals ablates DCs and delays CD8 cell activation in the face of NK control viral replication.
