The study demonstrates that NK cells' ability to respond early to CMV infection critically contributes to the balance of innate responses, dampening immunopathology and promoting initiation of antiral CD8 cell. The findings indicate that NK cells serve as regulators of immune defenses against viral infections, controlling pDC functions and modulating cytokine milieu early after challenge, and accelerating effector antiral CD8 cell generation.
Researchers investigated the role of the nucleolin protein (NUC1) in regulating the expression of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) genes in Arabidopsis thalian plants. They found that disruption of the NU1 gene affects the expression of specific rRNA variants, with some being induced and others repressed or unchanged. Notably, the most highly represented rRNA variant, inactive in wild-type plants, is reactivated in NU1 mutants. The study shows that pre-rNAs originate from RNA polymerase I transcription and are accurately processed. Disruption of the NU1 gene leads to loss of symmetrical DNA methylation without affecting histone epigenetic marks on r genes. The results reveal a novel mechanism for r gene transcription regulation, with NU1 playing a major role in controlling active and repressed r variants. The study also found that NU1 localizes with approximately half of r loci in the nucleus and associates with transcriptionally active r genes. The accumulation of pre-r in mutants is likely due to higher RNA I transcription from intergenic spacer regions. NU1 binds to r promoter sequences and directs transcription from transcription initiation site.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) proteins UL29 and UL38 interact with the histone deacetylase 1 (HDAC1) and components of the nucleosome remodeling and deetylase complex (Nu) to promote the accumulation of immediate-early RNA. A study identified HD1-interacting proteins in the context of infection using immunoprecipitation and mass spectrometry, confirming the interaction of UL29 and UL38 with HD1. HD1 is present in various complexes, including Nu, REST, and Sin3. UL29 and UL38 associated with the M2 component of Nu, and RNA-mediated knockdown of RBP and CH4 constituents of Nu inhibited CM immediateearly and viral DNA accumulation. This suggests that multiple Nu components are needed for efficient CM replication. The growth of UL29- or UL38 deficient viruses could not be rescued by treating cells with the deetyl inhibitor trichostatin A. Transient expression of UL29 enhanced the CM major early promoter in a reporter assay, regardless of UL expression. Importantly, induction of the major early reporter by UL29 required Nu components, consistent with inhibition of early RNA accumulation after knockdown of RBP and CH4. The study proposes that UL29 modifies the Nu complex to stimulate early RNAs.
Researchers investigated the antibody responses to Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) in children following primary infection and its evolution through adolescence and adulthood. Whole-genome-fragment display libraries (GFPDL) were used to identify linear and conformational epitopes in the RSV fusion (F) and attachment (G) proteins in infant sera before and after infection. F-GDL showed modest changes in anti-F epitope repertoire post-infection, while GDL revealed a 100-fold increase in G-reactive epitopes spanning the N- and C-terminus of G ectodomain, with increased reactivity to conserved domain CCD. Panels of F and G antigen sites were synthesized to evaluate sera from children, adolescents, and adults in real-time assays. A steady increase in RSV epitope repertoire from children to adults was observed using peptides and proteins. Novel epitopes were identified in pre-fusion F and immunodominant in F27. Antibody to preusion was 2-3 folds higher than postusion. R-G responses were high early in children but declined in adults using proteins or peptides. This study shows unlinked evolution of anti-F and G responses and evidence for immune driven R-G evolution.
Researchers investigated the mode of action of emodeide, a veterinary anthelmint, against adult Brug malayi, a species causing lymphatic filariasis. Whole-paras motility and patch-clamp studies showed emide potently inhibits motility by activating voltage-gated potassium channels, with males being more sensitive than females. RNAi knockdown suggested emide targets S-1 channels. Expressed slo-1 isoforms with alternatively spliced exons at the RCK domain were heterologously expressed in Xenopus lae oocytes. The slo-1 iso found in males was more sensitive to emide than slo-1a found in females, and RNAi of slo-1 in females increased emide potency. Onchercovulus, causing river blindness, had two isoforms with homology to B-S-1 and B-F at R1 domain. In silico modeling identified an emide binding pocket in R1 region affected by splicing variations. The study shows emide has potent macrofidal effects and splicing in R1 binding affects potency.
Researchers investigated the cross-reactivity of Loa loa antigens with lymphatic filariasis rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) to understand the obstacle to lymphatic filariasis elimination in Loa-endemic areas. They used the D6.5 antibody to immunoaffinity purify Loa antigens from sera of individuals with positive Loa RDT results. Immunoblot analysis revealed many AD/DH.5-reactive antigens, and proteomic analysis identified multiple Lo proteins in Loa R-positive sera, including secreted and somatic proteins that may be released by Loa adult worms and microfilariae. Unlike the high molecular weight W. bancroft circulating antigen, Lo antigens appeared transiently present in blood of a subset Loa persons. The differences between antigens of W. bancft and Lo can be used to differentiate results of both species, leading to improved tests for Loa and W. bancft. Loa antigens occur by process different from W. banc CFA, likely due to Loa death and adult worms releasing multiple AD glycoproteins into circulation and imbalance between release and clearance of antigens accounts for detection in circulation of Loa patients. Serum from Lo R-negative individuals, including those previously W bancft R positive, were negative for AD antig by western blot. Immunoaffinity-purified antig from sample 355 and pooled sera were analyzed by protease digestion and LC/MS/MS, matching spectra to Loa genomes.
Researchers used the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans to identify new genes associated with primary cilia, which are sensory and signalling devices extending from the surface of eukaryotic cells. Defects in these organel cause human disorders such as retinitis pigmentosa and Bard-Bied syndrome (BBS), affecting multiple physiological and developmental processes across organs. Whole-organ RNA-Seq libraries revealed a signature profile highly enriched for known ciliary transcripts, including FAM161, CC104, and RP1. From a list of 185 candidates, orthologues of MAP, YAP, CC149, and R28 were conserved cilium components. C elegans R-28, associated with autosomal-recessive cone-rod dystrophy, is a small GTPase exclusively expressed in ciliated neurons, dynamically associating with intraflagellar transport (IFT) trains. Inactive GDP-bound R-28 shows no IFT and diffuse localisation, while GTP-activated R-28 concentrates at the periciliary membrane in BBS-dependent and undergoes bidirectional IFT. Overexpression of GDP or GTP locked R-28 variants perturbs cilium and sensory morphogenesis. This study presents a new approach for identifying ciliary proteins and unveils R28, a GTP closely related to B protein R4/IFT, as I-associated with BBS-dependent cell and non-autonomous functions at the ciliary base.
Researchers investigated how the brain represents the external world using neural responses without direct access to external stimuli. They used hippocampal place cells as a model and found that knowing which groups of cells fire together reveals structure in the stimulus space, enabling the brain to construct its own representations. The study showed that knowing which groups of hippocamp cells fire is enough to extract global features of the environment and reconstruct an accurate geometric representation of space, including the animal's position. This is different from previous approaches that required knowing place fields or other neural responses relating to position. The research found that simple knowledge of groups of hippocamp cells can infer topological features of a two-dimensional environment and geometric reconstruction of physical space, including the animal's position, without assuming place fields or prior measurements of position. This challenges the idea that place fields are necessary for reconstructing position from cell activity. The study identified minimal aspects of neural activity that yield an accurate representation of space, showing that coarse population spiking features can provide a great deal of information about the environment.
Researchers investigated the role of the NLRP inflamome and IL-1β in viral fulminant hepatitis (FH), a severe liver disease with high mortality due to excessive inflammation. Wild-type mice infected with murine hepatitis virus-3 (MH-3) showed severe disease and high mortality associated with significant IL-1β elevation in serum and liver. In contrast, IL-1 receptor deficient (IL-1R-/-) or IL-1 antagonist (IL-Ra) treated mice had reduced virus replication, disease, and mortality. IL-1R deficiency debilitated virus-induced fibrinogen-like protein-2 (F2) production in macrophages and CD45+Gr1 neutrophil infiltration in liver. The release of reactive oxygen species (ROS) by infected macrophages suggested plausible initiation of NLR3 inflamome activation. Mice deficient in p47phox, a nicotin adenine dinucleotide (NAD) oxidase subunit controlling ROS production, had reduced NLR inflamome activation and IL-β secretion during infection, showing resilience to FH. Viral animals deficient in NLR and caspase-1, inflamome components, had reduced IL-β and ameliorated hepatitis. The ROS/NLR3/IL-β axis is an essential pathway causing severe liver disease during infection, shedding light on treatments for human FH and inflammatory diseases.
Researchers conducted a study in Malawi to investigate the role of hookworm infections in severe anemia and iron deficiency in pre-school children. Using multiplex real-time PCR, they found that 34.1% of severely anemic children and 27.0% non-severely anemic controls had hookworm infections, whereas microscopy detected 5.6%. Ancylostoma duale and Necator americanus DNA were present in 26.1% and 4.9% of children, respectively. Moderate to high A. duale infections were associated with severe anemia (adjusted odds ratio 2.49, 95% CI 1.16-5.33 and 9.04, 95 CI 2.52-32.47) and iron deficiency (odds ratio 3.63, 95 CI 1.18-11.20, 16.98 95 CI 3.88.74.35 and 44.91 95 5.23-385.77 for low, moderate and high load). This is the first study to assess hook load and species with anemia and bone iron deficiency. The study found a higher than expected prevalence of A. duale and significant association with anemia and iron in pre-school children in Malawi, highlighting the need for species-specific screening. Multiplex real PCR is a powerful tool for public health to combat severe anemia and iron deficiency in resource settings.
Researchers have identified a protein called COM-1 in the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans that plays a crucial role in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) during meiosis. Meiosis is a process of cell division that occurs in reproductive cells to produce gametes. DS can be repaired via two ways: homologous recombination (HR) or non-homous joining (NHE). Only HR can generate interhom crossovers (COs) needed for meiotic segregation. COM-1-deficient cells repair DS via error-prone NHE, resulting in lack of CO, chromosomal aggregation, and near-complete embryonic lethality. Unlike its yeast counterparts, COM-1 is not required for Spo11 and initiation of meiotic DS repair, but promotes meiotic recombination by counteracting NHE complex. Animals defective in both COM1 and Ku are viable and proficient in CO formation. COM1 acts parallel to nuclease EX-1 to promote interolog HR at early pachytene stage of meiotic prophase and safeguards CO formation. Both nucleases are dispensable for RAD-51 recruitment late pach stage when hom-independent pathways predominate.
Researchers studied the immune response of goats to Burkholderia pseudallei, a bacterium causing meloidosis, a severe pneumonia and sepsis in Southeast Asia and Australia. They used an aerosol infection model to mimic human infection and characterized the humoral immune response to identify immunogenic proteins for diagnostics and vaccine candidates. Outbred goats were used instead of inbred mice to better mimic human infection. Antigen proteins from infecting strain MSH511 were analyzed by ELISA, western blot, and mass spectrometry. Results showed a greater humoral response with IgG antibodies in breadth and quantity compared to IgM. Pre-infection sera showed multiple immunogenic proteins reactive for IgG (7-20) and IgM(0-12) despite no previous exposure. After infection, IgG reactive proteins increased as disease progressed. Early infection (day 7) showed reaction to chaper proteins Gro, EL, EFu, and Dna, detected in all samples with Gro immunodominant. Six antigens were selected for ELISA, Gro1 elicited strongest antibody response. Most showed IgM peak at day 14, IgG increased as disease progressed. MSH511 proteomic comparison with human sera showed common reactive proteins between goats and humans with meloid.
Researchers have investigated the activation of cyclin B–cyclin-dependent kinase 1 (Cdk) in mitosis, a key event that initiates mitotic entry. They used a novel approach to determine the temporal development of cyclin B–dk activity in single cells, quantifying dephosphorylation of C and phosphorylation of the anaphase-promoting/cycome 3. The study found that cyclin B–dk continues to be activated after centros separation and can be maintained in the cytoplasm even when cyclin B translocates to the nucleus in prophase. The data were fitted into a model describing cyclin Bdk activation in human cells, revealing a resemblance to a bistable circuit. The results indicate that mit cyclin Bdk activity needs to increase after mitotic entry and pass a threshold before metaphase to allow mitotic progression and exit. Distinct thresholds for cyclin Bdk activity control successive mitotic events. Cyclin Bdk is activated in late G2 and increases between centros separation and prometaph. Reducing C1 levels affects mitotic progression, with a threshold that autocatalyzes further cyclin Bdk activation and entry into mitosis. Cyclin Bdk contributes to centros separation in G and is initially detected on centros before they separate in G or pro.
A study examined the neutralizing antibody responses in 21 Kenyan women who were superinfected with HIV-1 subtypes A, C, and D after a median of 1.07 years following initial infection. Plasma samples were collected at a median 2.72 years post-superinfection. The study focused on 4 main epitopes on the HIV-1 envelope, including the CD4 binding site, V1/V glycan, N332 site in V3, and membrane proximal external gp41. Epitope mapping and computational analyses showed no dominant response to these epitopes in any of the superinfected women's plasma. In contrast, 72-94% of singly infected individuals with broad and potent responses develop antibodies targeting these 4 epitopes. The study suggests that superinfection with diverse subtypes promotes a polyclonal response, supporting vaccine designs using multivalent immunogens to elicit diverse neutralizing antibodies.
Congenital human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection is a leading cause of neurological disabilities in children, but the underlying mechanisms are not well-defined. CMV dysregulates the Notch signaling pathway in human neural progenitor cells (NPCs). Hairy Enhancer of Split 1 (Hes) is essential for NPC fate and brain development as a downstream effector of Notch signaling. This study reports that CMV downregulates Hes protein levels in NPCs. The CMV 72Da immediate-early 1 (IE1) protein is involved in Hes degradation by assembling a ubiquitination complex, promoting Hes ubiquitination as a potential E3 ubiquitin ligase, followed by proteasomal degradation of Hes. SpA, a component of PML bodies, is another target of IE-mediated ubiquination. The C-terminal region of IE, amino acids 451-475, is required for IE/Hes interaction and IE-mediated Hes ubiquination, but dispensable for IE/SpA interaction and ubiquination. This study suggests a novel mechanism linking downregulation of Hes protein to neurodevelopment disorders caused by CMV infection, complementing knowledge of herpesviruses by identifying IE as the first CM-encoded E3 ubiquitin ligase.
Researchers investigated the divergence of transcription factor binding and gene expression in Drosophila embryos across four species: D. melanogaster, D. yak, D. pseudoobscura, and D. virilis. They compared gene expression levels measured by mRNA-seq to genome-wide binding measured by ChIP-seq of four transcription factors involved in anterior-posterior patterning. Results showed that mRNA levels are more conserved than individual factor binding events, and changes in gene expression were poorly explained by changes in factor binding. However, highly bound sites in regions bound by multiple factors and near genes are conserved more frequently, suggesting weak or non-functional factor binding not subject to purifying selection.

The study found extensive divergence of transcription factor binding within the Dophila genus, with few regions bound by factors in all four species. Comparing divergence to divergence, only 3-7% of variance in binding between species was explained (21% if phylogenetic inertia not considered). mRNA-seq from embryos at end of cellularization showed highly correlated levels between species, decaying with phylogenetic distance. Divergence of mRNA was lower than TF binding, as measured by variance along Dila tree.

Two sources of binding divergence were identified: alterations of B, HB, GT, and KR motifs driving a portion of divergence. ChIP log-transformed values were normalized for comparisons of gene expression, showing highly correlated levels between species, decaying with phylogen distance. Divergence of mRNA was lower than TF binding, as variance along Dila tree.
Epidemiological Assessment of Eight Rounds of Mass Drug Administration for Lymphatic Filariasis in India: Implications for Monitoring and Evaluation

A large-scale epidemiological study was conducted in two primary health centers in Thanjav district, India, endemic for bancroftian filariasis, which had undergone eight rounds of mass drug administration (MDA). The study aimed to address issues with the current monitoring and evaluation process for lymphatic filariasis elimination, including transmission surveys (TAS) that assess antigenemia (Ag) in children who have completed at least five rounds of MDA with > 65% coverage and microfilaria (M) <1% in monitored sites. The study found prevalence and intensity of M (per 60µl) were 0.2% and 0.004 respectively in the survey covering >70% of 50,363 population. Corresponding values for Ag were 2.3 and 17.3 Ag-units. Ag-preval ranged from 0.7 to 0.9 in children (2-10) and 2.7 to 3.0 in adults. Although M-levels in survey and sentinel spot sites were <1 and Ag-level <2 in children, seven "residual" M-preval ≥1, irrespective of Ag-status in children and 17 "transmission" at least Ag-positive child during MDA hotspots were identified. Antigenemic persons were clustered at household and site levels. An Ag-preval of ~1 in children equivalent 0.4 M-preval as possible threshold for stopping MDA.

The study suggests that transmission in the area has reduced to <1 Ag-preval in children, supporting decision for stopping M in the area. However, several sites with potential for resurgence and clustering of infections were identified, indicating the need for developing strategies detecting hotspots, evidence-based sampling, and evaluation size for TAS.
This systematic review assessed the effectiveness of temeph, an organophosphate laricide, in controlling deng vectors and deng transmission when used as a single intervention or in combination with other methods. A comprehensive literature search of six databases and grey literature was conducted, and 27 studies were included. Eleven single-intervention studies showed temos reduced entomological indices, while 11 of 16 combined intervention studies showed temos with other chemical control methods reduced entom indices, but this was not sustained in five studies. The effectiveness of temos was dependent on factors such as delivery quality, water rate, type, and environmental factors like debris, temperature, and sunlight. Timing of tem deployment and reapplication, application reluctance to drinking water, cost, supplies, time, and labor were limitations. As a single intervention, temos was effective in suppressing entom indices, but not when combined with other interventions. No evidence suggests temos use reduces deng transmission. This review highlights the effectiveness of temos varies greatly, and lack of data on entom indices to d transmission remains a gap in deng epidemiology and control.
Researchers have investigated the role of the Ctf19 kinetore complex and the replication factor C3 in establishing cohesion at the pericentere, the region surrounding the centromere. They found that these two factors act through distinct mechanisms, with the C19 complex directing the association of cohes with the pericere and C3 ensuring its functionality in holding sister centeres together. Components of the C19 complex, Iml and Ch4, were shown to increase cohes association with the pericere during mitosis and meiosis, while C3 is dispensable for cohes enrichment in the perere but essential for its functionality. Cells lacking C3 showed additive cohesion defects with mutants in the C19 complex. Delaying replication rescued the defect in cells lacking C19 components but not C3. The study proposes that the C19 complex loads cohes at the centere prior to replication fork passage, ensuring its incorporation through a process requiring C3. The C19 complex and C3 are conserved, and their mechanism may operate in organisms with perenteric heterochatin attracting cohes.
Researchers conducted a study on the serum metabolome and lipidome of adult patients with deng fever/deng hemorrhagic fever (DF) to understand the underlying molecular mechanisms of deng pathogenesis. Using liquid chromatography and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, they analyzed serum samples from 44 patients across three stages of infection: early febrile, defesc, and convalescence. The study identified 60 differential metabolites, primarily in fatty acids, acylcarnines, phospholids, and amino acids, which perturbed pathways such as fatty acid biosynthesis, β-oxidation, phosphid catabolism, and steroid pathway. These changes suggest a multifactorial host response to DENV infection. Analysis of phosphids and sphingids revealed temporal trends associated with lymphocytes and platelets, which normalized at convalescent stage, indicating potential as prognostic markers. DENV causes distinct serumome and lipidome changes, with many metabolites involved in inflammatory responses. The study shows early anti-inflammatory responses modulate pro-inflammatory processes, preventing excessive or prolonged inflammation. This is the first omic approach to reveal concurrent, dynamic host responses to DENV, providing physiological insights into why DF is self-limiting.
Researchers analyzed 26,833 publications on neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) published between 2002-2012 to identify German contributions to NTD research. They used bibliometric data from Scopus, OpenRef, OpenStreet, and Gephi to create co-author networks. 1,187 (4.4%) of publications had at least one German affiliation, with 4,007 authors and 863 institutions extracted. Most co-authors were from high-income countries, Brazil. Collaborations with African countries were scattered. NTD research in Germany was distributed among 220 institutions. Strong performers were identified by publication number, h-index, and network centrality. Network characteristics varied between diseases. NTD publications with German affiliations were half of other medical fields, highlighting the need to identify and expand German research efforts. Spatial analysis of collaborations abroad supports capacity strengthening, particularly in low-middle income countries less involved than high-income. Identifying knowledge within researcher networks complements traditional indicators for collaboration opportunities.
In Haiti, a mass drug administration (MDA) program targeting lymphatic filariasis (LF) and soil-transmitted helmin (STH) has been implemented since 2000, led by the Ministry of Health and its international partners. By 2012, the program reached national scale with high epidemiological coverage, allowing for treatment cessation of LF in most of the country. Key elements of success included community awareness through evidence-based education, voluntary distributors, community trust through training and supervision, directly observed treatment, easy access, and data-driven strategies. High coverage (100% in 2012) and significant reduction in infection (45 communes reached LF threshold) demonstrate effectiveness. International support enabled steady progress toward LF elimination and foundation for STH control. 

The likelihood of taking treatment was associated with knowledge, disease understanding, transmission, strategy, risk, and side effects in other studies, but not in Haiti, where knowledge was low and not associated with MDA participation. In Grand'An department, prevalence declined less than others, remaining at 55%. Results show progress addressing STH, but highlight post-MDA support challenges. A successful campaign was launched in 200 with high rates, progress toward LF elimination, with more rounds in high prevalence areas and fewer in low. A foundation for STH control was established. Factors determining treatment were knowing MDA and ease of access. Direct observation increased participation in other settings. MDA reaching stopping, Haiti turned to morbidity efforts, building on hydrocele and lymphema support.
Researchers investigated the role of the master regulator Ctr in Sinorhizob meli, an alphrotebacter that forms a symbiotic relationship with legume hosts. In this symbiosis, S. meli undergoes cellular differentiation, resulting in genome amplification, cell elongation, and loss of reproductive capacity. The study found that depletion of Ctr causes cell elongation and genome amplification, similar to nitrogen-fixing bacteroids. Cell cycle proteolytic degradation of Ctr is essential in S. meli, suggesting a mechanism of Ctr depletion in differentiated bacteroids. Using ChIP-Seq and gene microarray analysis, S. mel Ctr regulates similar processes as C cresus Ctr, but through different genes. Ctr does not control Fts complex for cell division timing, but negatively regulates septum-inhibiting Min system. This study provides insight into conserved networks evolving to fit diverse lifestyles of bacteria. The model of Ctr cell regulation in S mel will elucidate bacterial cycle modulation by plant factors during symbiosis.
Francisella tularens is a highly infectious bacterium that causes tularemia, a zoonotic disease. Its ability to multiply and survive within macrophages is crucial for its virulence. Researchers screened a library of Himar transposon mutants of the F. tularens vaccine strain L to identify intracellular growth-deficient mutants and isolated a mutant in a gene encoding a putative glutamyl transpeptase (GT). This gene, F_076, was designated ggt. The ggt mutant showed impaired intracellular multiplication and was attenuated virulence in mice. The study demonstrates that GT activity of F. tulns allows utilization of glutathione (GSH, γ-glutyl-cystyl-glycine) and γ-glutyl-cystine dipeptide as cystine to ensure intracellular growth. This is the first demonstration of the role of a nutrient system in intracellular multiplication of F. tulns. SH is the most abundant source of cystine in host cytos. The capacity of this intracellular pathogen to utilize available SH as cystine host cytos constitutes a paradigm bacteria-host adaptation.
Researchers investigated the interaction between two species of Leishmania parasites, Leishmania amazonensis and Leish major, by infecting macrophages in culture. Leish amazonensis amastotes occupy large parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) containing many parasites, while Leish major amastotes lodge in small, tight PVs that undergo fission as they divide. To determine if PVs of these Leish species can fuse, macrophages were infected with non-fluorescent Leish amazonensis amastotes and 48 hours later superinfected with fluorescent Leish major amastotes or promastigotes. Fusion was investigated by time-lapse acquisition of living cells and inferred from colocalization of parasites of the two species in the same PVs. Results showed that PV containing Leish promastigotes fused with established Leish PVs, but PV containing Leish amastotes did not. In chimeric vacuoles, Le promastigotes remained motile and multiplied but did not differentiate into amastotes. In contrast, in doubly infected cells, unfused PV contained Le promastigotes, which were destroyed or differentiated into proliferating amastotes. This indicates PVs, presumably by Leish amast or promigotes, differ in ability to fuse Leish PV, and species-specific PV is required for Leish differentiation.
Researchers investigated the ability of native, membrane-expressed HIV-1 Env trimers to elicit broad neutralizing antibodies (nAbs) in a vaccine setting. Potent nAb titers developed in 2 of 8 rabbits immunized with virus-like particles (VLP) expressing trimers (trimer V sera) and 1 of 20 immunized with DNA expressing Env trimer followed by protein boost (DNAimer sera). All sera neutralized quatern epitopes exploiting gaps in the glycan shield of the conserved region of JRFL gp120. Specifically, trimer V sera took advantage of the absence of glycan residue 197, present in 98.7% Envs. Removing N197 gly with loss of tier 2 phenotype rendered 50 or 16.7% (n=18) clade 2 isolates sensitive to trimer V sera, showing neutralization via surface masked by N glycan. Neutral sera targeted epitopes overlap with CD binding site, consistent with role of N gly in "gly fence" limiting access. Bioinformatics suggested features of trimer V sera and monoclonal PG consistent with tr dependency. Neutral DNAimer took advantage of absence gly residue 230, proximal to CD site, suggesting epitope similar to monoclonal ANC, lacking 2 breadth. Data show strain-specific holes in gly fence allow tier 2 neutral antibodies native spikes. Cross-neutralization occur absence gly. Observations inform future neutral antibody vaccine development.
Researchers investigated the use of immunohistochemistry to monitor wound healing in patients with Buruli ulcers (BU) treated with antibiotics. Traditionally, surgery has been the primary treatment for BU, but a combination of oral rifampicin and intramus streptomycin has improved outcomes and reduced recurrence rates. However, managing extensive lesions after successful therapy remains a challenge, particularly in rural areas with high disease burden. The study aimed to identify markers to monitor wound progression. Specimens from eight patients with plaque lesions before and after chemotherapy were analyzed for connective tissue neoformation, tissue remodeling, and epidermal activation markers. Several proteins were found suitable to monitor healing. α-smooth muscle actin positive myofiblasts were not present in untreated lesions but emerged during healing, producing extracellular matrix proteins like pro-collagen and tenascin. After treatment, many cells, including myoflasts, showed activated phenotype with ribosomal S6 phosphorylation, a translation marker. Wounds also showed dermal remodeling by apoptosis and increased cytokeratin 16 in the epidermis. A set of markers was identified to monitor healing in treated BU lesions by immunohchemistry. Studies with this panel may help understand disturbances in wound delays observed in some patients. Activated myoflasts are involved in wound contraction and produce ECM proteins fibronin, tenasc, and proollagens, building granulation tissue for successful healing. Enhanced cytokeratin 16 in lesions after treatment is likely dermal response to antibiotic and mycolone clearing. Each wound phase is characterized by specific cells, proteins, and tasks.
Researchers investigated the relationship between impulse conduction and mitochondrial transport in adult mammalian peripheral nerves in vivo. They used confocal imaging of saphous nerves in anaesthetized mice to study mitochondrial trafficking along resting and electrically active axons. Electrical stimulation at low frequency increased anterograde and retrograde mitochondrial traffic in myelinated and unmyinated axons. Higher frequency conduction (50 Hz) significantly increased anterog, but not retro, mitochondrial traffic by increasing mobile mitochondria number and velocity. Capsaicin application to innervated saph nerve increased mitochondrial traffic in both myinated and uninated axons. Mitochondria in conducting at higher frequency became shorter, supplying additional mitochondria to the population through fission. Recruited mitochondria did not accumulate at Nodes of Ranvier but continued anterograde. This pattern suggests peripheral terminals of sensory axons have high metabolic demand during high frequency conduction. Increased antog traffic may ensure uniform mitochondrial density along axons during high load, supporting metabolic demand by sustained conduction.
A study investigated the role of Filamin B (FLNB) in the development of spondylocarparsal synostosis (SCT), an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by progressive vertebral fusions. FLNB acts as a scaffold linking the actin cytoskeleton to signal transduction systems, but the mechanisms of SCT remain unclear. Employing Fln knockout mice, the study found morphologic and molecular evidence that intervertebral discs (IVDs) of Fln-/- mice undergo rapid degeneration during postnatal development due to abnormal cell changes in the IVD, particularly the annulus fibros (AF). In Fln-/- mice, AF cells lose fibroblast characteristics and acquire molecular phenotypic signature of hypertrophic chondrocy, characterized by hallmarks of endochond-like ossification, including collagen expression, apoptosis, and ossification of tissue. The conversion of AF into chrocy is coincident with upregulated TGF signaling via Smad/3 and BMP induced p38 as well as activation of canonical and non-canonical genes p21 and Ctg. These findings indicate FL is involved in attenuation TGF/BMP signaling and AF fate. The study demonstrates IVD in Fln/- mice resemble degenerative discs, providing insights into molecular causes vertebral and degeneration.
Researchers have identified a new mechanism by which the orthomyxovirus Thog virus (TH) uses to evade the immune system by targeting a general transcription factor called TFI. The virus causes TFI to be relocated from the nucleus to the cytoplasm, creating a TFI-depleted environment. Although this would be expected to broadly impact gene expression, only a limited number of genes are affected. The study found that TFI is crucial for the recruitment of the polymerase II to promoter sites, but not required for expression from paused promoters. Many immune genes require de novo recruitment of polymerase II, making TH's targeting of TFI a mechanism to affect immune responses while keeping other transcriptional activities intact. Interfering with TFI activity may be a favorable for therapeutic intervention to control undesirable inflammation. 

The innate immune system is a network of cytokines and antiviral effector molecules, essential for antiral defense. The study found a mechanism involving viral targeting of single transcription factor TFI, perturbing the immune at a scale with minimal influence on other transcription. Mimicking TH using its inhibitory domain to target TFI, modulates pro-inflammatory cytokines and effector molecules requiring novo recruitment of polymerase without affecting general expression of genes for homeostasis, growth, stability, metabolism, and signaling. Targeting TFI by viruses is beneficial for infection, as pro-inflammatory cytokines required for antiral response are inhibited, while negative regulators and tissue factors are expressed.
Human parvirus B19 (B19) infection of primary erythroid progenitor cells (EPCs) induces cell cycle arrest at both late S-phase and G2, containing 4 DNA. The virus induces a DNA damage response (DDR) that facilitates viral replication but is dispensable for cycle arrest at G2. A putative C-terminal activation domain (TAD) within NS1 is responsible for G2 arrest. To understand the mechanism of B19 NS-induced G2 arrest, doxycine-inducible B19-permissive UT/E-S cell lines were established that express NS or NSmT2, and the function of T2 during G arrest was examined. Results confirm the NS T2 domain plays a role in NS-induced G arrest Mechanistically, NS activated gene expression through T, which was responsible for ATR (ataxia-telated and Rad-related) activation. Activated A phosphorylated CDC25 at serine, which inactivated cyclin/CDK complex without affecting nuclear import. Importantly, the A-CHK-CDC25-CD1 pathway was activated during B19 infection EPC, and A played a role in BV-induced G arrest. B19 infection induces DDR is essential for DNA replication, although has no effect on cycle at G-phase. The mechanism of B19 NS-induced true G arrest, particularly the role of NS T2 in cell cycle dysregulation, was investigated. B19 NS protein is a factor disrupting cell cycle via T domain, and viral replication DDR not necessary for cycle of cells containing DNA. B-infected cells arrest at S and G contain DNA. Results confirmed A activation plays in G arrest of EPC expressing NS, mediated by T of NS protein, and the A-CHK-CDC-1 pathway activated in cells at G.
Dengue virus (DENV) non-structural protein 1 (NS1) has been shown to induce endothelial hyperperability in a mouse and human endothelial cells by disrupting the endothelial glycocalyx layer. This study investigated the role of inflammatory mediators and endothelial-intrinsic pathways in this process. In vivo, DENV NS but not West Nile virus NS triggered vascular leak in the dermis of wild-type C57/6 mice. In vitro, human dermal endothelial cells exposed to DENV NS did not produce inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-8) and blocking these cytokines did not affect DENV-induced endothelial hyperability. Furthermore, DENV induced leak in TLR- or TN- receptor-deficient mice at similar to wild-type levels. Blocking DENV-induced leak in vivo using glycocal disruption inhibitors. These results indicate D NS-induced endothelial-intrinsic vascular leak is independent of inflammatory cytokines but dependent on glycocal components. This suggests potential targets for therapeutics inhibiting glycocal degradation for severe deng treatment.
In budding yeast, the assembly of a septin ring at the site of bud emergence is crucial for proper cytokinesis, spindle positioning, and the spindle position (SPO) checkpoint, which delays mitotic exit and cytokinesis until the anaphase spindle aligns with the division axis. The PO signalling requires Kin4 kinase and Kin-regulating Elm kinase, which also controls septin dynamics. This study shows that redundant ubiquitin-lases Dma1 and D2 control septin dynamics and PO by promoting efficient recruitment of Elm to the bud. Dma1 D2 mutant cells have reduced Elm at the neck and Elm-dependent Kin4 activation. Artificial recruitment of Elm to the bud neck rescues normal septin ring, spindle positioning, and PO in Dma D2 cells. Data indicate septin and PO function are linked, supporting the idea that bud integrity is crucial for PO signalling. The study also implicates D1 and D2 in septin ring, spindle, cytokinesis, and PO regulation. Constitutive recruitment of Elm at the bud through chimera rescues septin and PO defects in Dma D cells, indicating the defect is due to Elm association with the neck.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide scan to identify genetic adaptations to climate-mediated pressures in humans by analyzing single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) with the strongest correlations to climate variables across 61 worldwide populations. They found a significant enrichment of genic and nonsynonymous SNPs relative to non-genic SNPs among those strongly correlated with climate variables. Notably, several signals overlapped with those from genome-wide association studies (GWAS), including SNPs associated with pigmentation and autoimmune diseases. The study also found enrichment of strong signals in gene sets related to UV radiation, infection, and cancer. The results suggest that climate adaptations shaped the spatial distribution of human variation. The analysis detected selective pressures likely mediated by climate, as many signals coincided with SNPs associated with diseases of immune response in GW studies. A subset of SNPs with large effect sizes for climate were strongly associated with traits from GWAS, including pigmentation and autoimmune diseases. The study used allele frequency data from Hancock et al. (2010) to test adaptations to climate at genome-wide level and identified loci underlying adaptations. Genome-wide scans have been conducted in humans, but only two used environmental information to detect selection on a scale. Plots of strongest signals for climate in subsets exhibited patterns restricted to specific regions. Despite smaller populations, a significant enrichment for genic SN with climate relative nonic SN in subsets was found.
A study investigated the arrhythmogenic mechanisms in the delayed rectifier K+ current (IK)-linked SQT1 variant of short QT syndrome (SQTS), a genetically heterogeneous condition characterized by abbreviated QT intervals and increased susceptibility to arrhythmia and sudden death. Markov chain (MC) models were found to be superior to Hodgkin-Hux (HH) models in reproducing experimental data effects of the N588 mutation on KCNH-encoded hERG channel. Ionic models were incorporated into ventricular action potential (AP) models and 1D and 2D idealized and realistic transmural ventricular simulations and 3D anatomical model. In single cell models, the N588 mutation abbreviated ventricular AP duration at 90% repolarization (AP90) and maximal transm voltage heterogeneity (δ) during AP, resulting in decreased transm heterogeneity AP90 and effective refractory period (ERP). However, with consideration of transm heterogeneity IK density in intact tissue based Tusscher-Noble-Noble-Pfil ventricular model, N588 mutation led to QT shortening and increased T-wave amplitude, but augmented δ in some regions ventricular tissue, increasing vulnerability to uni-directional conduction and reentrant excitation. In 2 and 3D models, N mutation facilitated reentrant excitation due reduced substrate sustaining re-entry size. The study substantiates causal link between N588 mutation QT shortening and increased susceptibility reentrant arrhythm in S1.
Researchers have developed a deep neural network model to study the collective behavior of zebraf, a type of fish, in groups. The model is designed to be both predictive and insightful, meaning it can accurately forecast the motion of individual fish in a group while also providing a clear understanding of the underlying rules governing their behavior. The model is composed of two parts: a pair-interaction network, which describes the interaction between a fish and its closest neighbors, and an aggregation network that combines these interactions to determine the fish's movement. The pair network takes 6 variables as input and outputs 128 values, while the aggregation network reduces this to a single output. The model was trained on simulated data and validated on real trajectories of 60-100 zebraf. The results show that interactions between fish can be described as repulsive, attractive, or aligning, but only at low speeds. At high speeds, interactions are alignment or repulsion at close distances. The model also found that each fish decides where to move by aggregating information from neighbors, with higher weights for those close, in collision, or moving in frontal and lateral locations. The number of interacting individuals is dynamic, typically 8-22, with 1-10 most important. This suggests each fish selects information from the collective dynamically.
Researchers employed a phylogenetic approach to quantify the fitness of HIV-1 drug resistance mutations in a Swiss cohort of antiretroviral-naive patients. The study aimed to understand the dynamics of transmitted drug resistance, as around 10% of ART-naive patients in Europe are infected with drug-resistant HIV-1. The approach used stochastic birth-death processes to model the transmission of sensitive and resistant strains, allowing the quantification of fitness as the ratio of transmission rates of infected by resistant to sensitive strains. Six mutations in the reverse transcriptase and one in the protease gene were analyzed. The 90 mutation in the protease was found to have higher fitness than sensitive strains, while the reverse transcriptase mutations 67, 70, 184, 219 were less fit than sensitive. The remaining mutations had no significant effect on transmissibility within the cohort. This study presents a novel phylogen approach to estimate transmission cost of resistance, which may be useful in resource-limited settings where resistance testing is possible but epidemiological and clinical data are missing.
A study investigated the role of the Elong complex, specifically the histone acetylase Sin3/El3, in the translation of stress-induced mRNAs in fission yeast. Elong was previously known to interact with RNA polymerase II and be essential for transcription, but also mediates modification of tRNAs, affecting translation efficiency. The study found that Sin/3El3 is crucial for oxidative stress survival, as the transcription program governed by Sty1-Atf1-P1 is affected in mutant cells, but not severely. Cells lacking Sin3/3 cannot modify the uridine wobble nucleotide of certain tRNAs, and other tRNA activities like Ctu-C2 are essential for normal tolerance to H2O. A plasm overexpressing tRNALUU complements the stress-related phenotypes of Sin3El3 mutant. The study determined that H2O-dependent genes, including transcription factors At1 and P1, are highly expressed mRNAs with a biased lysine codons. These mRNAs are poorly translated in stress cells lacking Sin3 or C2, whereas mutated At1 with AAG codons is efficiently translated in all backgrounds. The study shows that lack of functional Elong results in stress phenotypes due to tRNA modification and translation inefficiency of stress-induced mRN.
Researchers have discovered a new function of the HIV-1 protein Nef, which makes the virus resistant to two potent neutralizing antibodies, 2F and 4, that target the membrane-proximal region of the envelope protein gp41. This resistance was observed in various HIV-1 and SIV isolates, including CCR5 and CXCR4-tropic viruses, and clade B and C viruses, as well as primary isolates. Analysis of Nef mutants revealed that this activity requires myristoylation, but is separable from other Nef functions such as enhancing infectivity and downregulating CD4. Glycosylated gag substituted for Nef in conferring resistance to 2 and 4, indicating this activity is conserved in a retrovirus that does not encode N. N and Glycosylag decreased the efficiency of virion capture by 2 and 4, but not other antibodies. This study demonstrates Nef protects lentiviruses from one of the most broadly-acting classes of neutralizing antibodies, with implications for anti-HIV immunity and AIDS pathogenesis.
Researchers investigated the gene expression changes in the snail host, Bithia siam gomphos, of the liver fluke Opisthoris vivini, which causes cholangiocarcinoma in the Greater Mekong region of Thailand. They used high-throughput Illumina sequencing and bioinformatic analysis to compare the transcriptomes of uninfected and O vivini-infected B siomphos. The study identified 7,655 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) associated with 43 biological pathways, including immune mechanisms against parasites. Protease-encoding genes were downregulated in infected snails, while heat shock proteins and actins were upregulated. This study lays the foundation for understanding genes and products involved in parasite colonization of snail host. The dataset provides a resource for susceptibility and resistance mechanisms of siomphos to vivini and comparative analysis with other snail hosts of platyhelmin, including schistosomes.
Researchers investigated the role of complement receptor 1 (CR1, also known as CD35) in the susceptibility to leprosy, a public health issue in Brazil. They analyzed polymorphisms, gene expression, and soluble CR1 levels in a case-control study with 213 lepro patients (47% multibillary) and 297 controls. Nine polymorphisms were hapyped by multiplex PCR-PCR in 213 lepro patients and 297 controls. mRNA levels were measured by qPCR and CR1 by ELISA in 80 samples. Individuals with the most common recombinant haplotype harboring rs926*T in intron 21 and rs700*T in exon 26 presented twice higher susceptibility to lepro (OR=2.43, p=0.017). Paibillary patients with these variants had lower CR1 levels, reducing anti-inflammatory response (p=0.040 and p=0.046). The most haplotype increased susceptibility to multib clinical form (OR=3.04, p=0.01) and presented intronic rs343*G allele, associated higher gene expression (p=0.043), increasing internalization of parasite. An inverse correlation was found between CR1 and mannose lectin (initiator of lectin pathway complement, recognized by CR) (R=-0.52 p=0.007). The study suggests regulatory role of CR1 polymorph on mRNA and CR1 levels, haplotype effects increasing lepro, probably enhancing phagocytosis and inflammation.
Researchers conducted a study to investigate sex-specific differences in serum metabolite concentrations and their genetic determinants. They analyzed data from over 3,300 individuals from the KORA3 and K4 cohorts, measuring 131 metabolites including amino acids, phosphatidylchines, sphingomyins, acylcarnines, and C-sugars. Linear regression revealed significant differences between males and females for 102 out of 131 metabolites (p-value < 3.8×10^-4, Bonferr-corrected threshold). Genome-wide association studies showed genome-wide significant differences in beta-estimates for SNPs in the CPS1 locus (carbamyl-phosphate synthase, significance: p <3.8×10^-10, Bonerr-correct threshold) for glycine. The study found metabolite profiles of males and females are different, and specific genetic variants in metabolism-related genes depict sexual dimorphism. The study provides new insights into sex-specific regulatory processes and underscores the importance of considering sex-specific effects in study design and interpretation. A meta-analysis of K4 and K3 revealed 113 metabolites with significant sex effect (Bonerr-correct meta-significance: <3.8×10^-4). The study investigated groups of metabolites pairwise correlations, similar effects, and sex-specific propagation through the metabolic network. A partial correlation between metabolites, age, sex, and BMI was calculated. A subpopulation of 180 participants from K4 (Gen-K4) was used to identify genetically determined metabotypes. Replication was done in an independent subsample K4 (Rep4) and subsample K3 (Rep). Sex-strat genome association adjusted for age and BMI was performed for logarithized concentrations all metabolites. Significant effects of gender were found in 102 of 131 metabolites (p below Bonerr-correct significance 3.8×^-4).
Researchers have developed a new method called Minimization of Metabolites (MiBl) to simulate genotype-phenotype relationships in metabolic networks by decoupling stoichiometry from the formulation of objective functions. Current methods use linear combinations of fluxes, which are sensitive to stoichi representation, leading to different results when using numerically equivalent but biochemically equivalent stoichi representations. This makes biological interpretation ambiguous. MiBl uses metabolite turnovers instead of fluxes to formulate objective functions, making results unambiguously linked to biological interpretation. The method was tested on Saccharomyces cerevisiae, expanding the scope of metabolic modeling to elucidate mechanistic basis of genetic interactions. Metabolic networks have a large solution space, requiring optimization approaches to predict active states under specific conditions. The objective function used in optimization is linked to biological hypothesis, making it crucial for successful modeling. A new formulation is proposed to account for stoichi in objective by mapping flux into metabolite space.
Researchers investigated the relationship between the distribution of plague and the genetic structure of the black rat (Rattus rattus), the main reservoir of plague in Madagascar. They conducted a comparative study of seroprevalence and genetic (microsatellite markers) in rat populations from four areas with different topography, covering 150-200 km within the Madagas plague focus. Seropreval levels in rat populations mirrored those reported for humans. Rat populations showed a marked genetic structure with increasing relief, but the relationship between seropval data and structure differed, suggesting plague distribution not related to rat dispersal. Genetic estimates suggested plague epizootics had a weak impact on rat population sizes. In highlands, plague cannot be accounted for solely by rat dispersal; human activities may also spread disease in rat and human populations. The study aimed to determine if plague seropval distribution differed between plateau and mountain areas in rats, and if fine-scale genetic structure was higher in mountains than plateaus. Topographic relief influences gene flow in many species, including rodents. The study investigated rat dispersal's role in plague spread by comparing seropval levels and genetic structure in four areas with different topographic profiles.
Researchers investigated the Schistosoma mansoni Ly6 (Sm6) family, a group of proteins on the parasite's surface, to understand host-parasite interactions. They identified 11 members, including 3 new ones, and confirmed Sm29 as a unique double PAR/Ly domain-containing protein. Sm6 proteins are likely surface-bound due to cysteine residues, signal peptides, and GPI sites. Immunoglobulin G (Ig) responses to Sm6 members were studied in a cohort of S mans-infected Ugandan males before and after prazant treatment. Pre-treatment IgG prevalence for Sm6A and SmB was 7.4% and 25.3% respectively, higher than IgG for sub-surface antigen SmAL. Post-treatment IgG levels for SmA and SmB dropped significantly compared to rising Ig for SmAL. This study expands the number of Sm6 proteins and shows SmA and SmB elicit immunological responses during infection in endemic communities.
Researchers have developed a computational model to simulate the morphology of epithelial tissue in the Drosila retina, focusing on the role of the adhesion protein cadherin. The model minimizes the interfacial energy between cells and reproduces the geometries of wild-type and mutant cells, distinguishing features of cadin dynamics, and emphasizes the importance of adhesion proteinogenesis and its timing with respect to cell remodeling. The simulations indicate that cadin protein is recycled from inactive to active interfaces, modulating adhesion between cells. 

The model incorporates salient features of morphogenesis, including the timing of cadin expression and its relationship to cell contact remodeling, without additional parameters. It demonstrates that cadher goes beyond cell sorting, determining details of geometric shapes in tissues like the Drosila retina. Experimental data for normal and mutant cells lacking or misexpressing cadin can be explained by the model. The model reproduces characteristic changes in mutants and distinguishes different mechanisms of cadin levels control.
Researchers have developed a computational model to study the role of MT-MMP, a protease involved in cancer cell invasion, in degrading the extracellular matrix (ECM) at invadodia, specialized membrane protrusions. Fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) experiments showed rapid recovery of tagged MT-M at invodia, approximated by double-exponential plots with time constants 26 and 259 seconds, primarily dependent on vesicle transport and not lateral diffusion. A computational model based on these kinetics reproduced the FR experiments. Inhibiting vesicle transport blocked ECM degradation and simulations showed no significant degradation. The degree of reduction in ECM degradation depended on the degree of reduction in MT-M turnover. Simulations suggested synergistic contributions of proteolytic activity and MT-M turnover to ECM degradation, with a nonlinear reduction in degradation when both factors were reduced. The model provides a tool to design intervention strategies for cancer invasion.
Researchers conducted a spatio-temporal assessment of simian/humanodeficiency virus (SHIV) evolution in macaques to understand how drug-resistant HIV-1 arises and spreads within an individual. They infected four macques with RT-SHm027, a simian immunodeficiency virus encoding HIV-1 reverse transcriptase, and treated them with RT inhibitors. Viral DNA and RNA were isolated from blood, peripheral blood mononuclear cells, lymph nodes, and vagina at four time points, and characterized via single-genome sequencing. The results show a dynamic process where vRNA rapidly acquires drug resistance across compartments through multiple mutations, with fast migration of viral genotypes across compartments but not immediate equilibration of frequencies. Blood and lymph nodes were found to be compartmentalized, while blood and lymph were more different from mucosal tissues. The study suggests that sampled blood does not fully capture viral dynamics in other parts of the body, especially the gut, where vRNA turnover was faster and vDNA retained fewer wild-type viruses. The findings of compartmentalization across tissues may explain previous conflicting results in HIV-1 compartmentalization studies.
Feedback regulation of cell lineage progression plays a crucial role in tissue homeostasis, but its role in tissue morphogenesis is unclear. This study uses mathematical modeling to show that feedback in stem and progenitor cells can lead to bistable growth behaviors, ultrasensitivity to external cues, growth-driven budding, self-elongation, and self-organization in the form of lamellar fingers. These behaviors arise through regulation of cell cycle speeds, not renewal. Spatial patterns result from interactions of diffusible factors with antagonistic effects, but morphogenesis is not Turing-type instability.

 Feedback regulation of stem progenitor renewal leads to bistability and ultras switching between high and low or zero growth states, requiring simultaneous positive and negative feedback. In vivo phenomena include bistability, ultrasensitivity, and feedback-regulated morphogenesis. Positive and negative regulation of renewal by diffus signals leads to emergence of spatial dynamics, manifesting as localized growth differences. Conditions for bistability, ultras, and selforganization are mathematically defined, driving formation of induced or spontaneous bulges and fingers, morphogenesis building blocks. Patterns arise from opposing diffible interactions, not Turing patterns.

Tissue morphogenesis occurs rapidly relative to cell lifespan, final models may represent lineage dynamics during morph, even in self-renew tissues. Feedback in final-state effects are explored.
Researchers conducted the largest genome-wide association study to date on myopia, a common eye disorder characterized by elongation of the eye, in 45,771 European participants. They analyzed age of onset and identified 22 significant associations, 10 of which replicated earlier associations with refractive error. Ten novel associations replicated in a separate cohort of 8,323 participants who developed myopia before age 10. These associations explain 2.9% of variance in myopia onset and suggest multiple mechanisms behind its development. One association is in PRSS56, linked to abnormally small eyes, one in LAMA, part of extracellular matrix, two in regeneration 11-cis-retinal RGR and RDH, two in growth retinal ganglion cell guidance ZIC and SP1, and five in neuronal development. Findings indicate multiple factors in my development and complex interactions between extracellular remodeling, neuronal, and visual retina signals.
Researchers investigated the role of curvature feedback in the energetics and dynamics of lamprey swimming using a closed-loop model. The lamprey, like other animals, have a central pattern generator (CPG) circuit that activates locomotion and adjusts to sensory inputs from the environment. Feedback is crucial for responding to perturbations, but also active during unperturbed swimming, influencing the baseline pattern. The study evaluated different forms of body-based feedback and their effects on swimming energetics and kinematics, as little is known about curvature feedback form. The CP was modeled as coupled oscillators, pairs representing left and right segments along the lamprey body, activating muscles to move through a simulated fluid using Navier-Stokes model. Emergent curvature served as input to the oscillators, closing the loop. Two feedback forms were considered, consistent with experimental results on lamp proprioceptive receptors. Directional feedback excited or inhibited oscillators on the same side, opposite on the other, affecting duration but not frequency. Magnitude feedback provided a symmetric effect on both sides, increasing frequency and reducing cost when gain was high. Both types resulted in similar curvature magnitude, indicating different forms of feedback can cause distinct performance differences.
Researchers investigated the dynamics of HIV epidemics in populations, focusing on the competition between different strains of the virus. They hypothesized that the strain that first colonizes a population has an advantage over subsequent strains, slowing the spread and diversification of the epidemic. A stochastic modeling framework was developed to simulate epidemics on contact networks, introducing a second strain into a population where the first strain had established a steady-state. Simulations were parameterized with empirical data, testing scenarios with varying prevalence levels. Results showed the second strain spread slower than the first, with a 25% transmission advantage needed to become dominant over decades. Interference mechanisms, such as inhibition, superinfection, and depletion of highly connected nodes, contributed to the effect. Simulations confirmed a first-mover advantage in HIV competition, explaining global phylogeography and influencing pandemic evolution.

A model of sexually transmitted HIV epidemics was developed to monitor competition of strains with varying transmission rates. Without specific conditions, the most transmissible strain drives others extinct, a principle of competitive exclusion. The model was parameterized with data from heterosexual epidemics in Africa, adaptable to other transmission routes and epidemics. Mechanisms can slow invasion, but the pandemic is dynamic, with shifts between lineages occurring. The expansion of HIV-1 at the expense of subtype D in Eastern Africa was used to estimate the required transmission advantage.

A stochastic, individual-based model tracked HIV spread over a network of heterosexual contacts, consisting of males, females, and female sex workers. HIV is transmitted over a limited subset of possible contacts, not a "free mixing". An individual-based simulation tracked dynamic contacts and transmission along network links to detect effects from structure.
Researchers have investigated the self-organization of muscle structure and function at multiple scales, from the sarcomere to the muscle bundle. To address this multiscale problem, they constrained muscle cells in microenvironments that potentiate intracellular organization. They hypothesized that boundary conditions in the extracellular space potentiate the organization of cytoskeletal scaffolds for sareregenesis. A quantitative model of the cytoskeleton of neonatal ventricular myocytes was developed with respect to geometric cues in the extracellular. Numerical results and in vitro assays showed that distinct cytoskeletal architectures arise from temporally-ordered processes: interaction between actin fibers, myofibrils, and focal adhesions, as well as cooperative and parallel bundling of nascent myofils. A hierarchy of mechanisms regulate the self-organization of the contractile cytoskeleton, and a positive loop is responsible for initiating break symmetry, potentiated by extracellular conditions, to polarize the contractile cytoskeleton.

A computational model recapitulated the protein choreography of sarere assembly, where proteins assemble repetitively along the actin template. Myofils mature in force-dependent, suggesting contractility may play a role in polarizing myofillar network. In nonmuscle cells, cytos architecture becomes polarized with increasing traction forces. A model of myill patterning was developed to show sensitivity of intracellular architecture to extracellular space, to understand assembly and organization of contract apparatus in myocytes.
Researchers investigated the invasive potential of Wolbachia, a symbiotic bacterium being trialed as a biocontrol agent to reduce dengue transmission, in Brazilian Aedes aegypt mosquitoes. They characterized the phenotypic effects of the wMel strain in laboratory and found it causes cytoplasmic incompatibility, high maternal transmission rate, and no detrimental effect on host fecundity or fertility. To understand the effects of urban landscapes on mosquito survival, mark-release experiments were conducted in two areas of Rio de Janeiro where Wolia will be deployed. Mosquito populations were characterized in relation to socio-demographic conditions at these sites and three future release areas. Mathematical models were constructed using laboratory and field data to describe the influence of environmental conditions on the likelihood of Wolia infection reaching 100% following release. Results show the w strain will successfully invade five field sites, with conditions varying greatly between sites and influenced by local mosquito population size. Laboratory and field data indicate the strain possesses characteristics to spread in urban-dem environments, including release sites of the Eliminate Dengue Program. Field sites in Rio are complex, supporting mosquito populations of different sizes, affecting Wolia dynamics, but inter-site differences do not impede overall success. The most influential factor on Wolia spread was local mosquito abundance, with data reinforcing the need to release Wolia-infected mosquitoes in higher sites with larger wild populations.
Researchers have identified a protein, JMJ703, as a histone lysine demethylase that specifically reverses all three forms of histone H3 lysine methylation (H3me) in rice. This epigenetic modification plays a crucial role in regulating chromatin structure and gene expression, and is involved in plant development and stress adaptation. Loss-of-function of the JMJ gene affects stem elongation and growth, possibly due to increased expression of cytokinin oxidase genes. The crystal structure of the catalytic domain of JMJ revealed similarities with mammalian and yeast JM2 proteins, but also showed specific features essential for demethyl activity. Key residues interact with cofactors Fe(II) and N-oxylglycine and methylated H3 peptide were identified. These residues are conserved in known H4 demethylases, suggesting specificity for H4 demylation. J703 is essential for cell division and elongation, and demethylates mono, di, and trimethyl H3 in vivo and in vitro. Demylation of three forms implies J is important for gene expression. Phenotype caused by T-DNA insertion and RNAi increased CK genes suggest J may regulate hormone metabolism, distinct from J14 that functions in floral, DNA methylation, and silencing.
Researchers have identified a shared interface on the HIV-1 capsid protein that is lost upon disassembly, which is targeted by multiple host and pharmacologic ligands. This interface is formed within hexamers, a multi-unit structure of the capsid, and mediates binding to cellular cofactors NUP and CPS6 and antiviral compounds PF74 and BI-2. Each ligand binds to a phenylalanine-glycine (FG) motif in the N-terminal domain of one monomer, with BI-2 also interacting across the N-terminal C-terminal (NTD) interface of a second monomer. Dissociation of hexamer into monomers prevents high-affinity interaction with CPS6 and PF74 and abolishes binding to N153. The interface is conformationally dynamic, but binding of N153 or CPS6 is accommodated by one conformation. N153 and CPS6 have overlapping sites, but make unique interactions when mutated, perturbing cofactor dependency. The study reveals that multiple ligands share an interface in HIV-1 caps that is lost upon viral disassembly.
Researchers have improved the assembly of the genome of the mosquito Aedes aegypt, a vector of diseases such as dengue and yellow fever and chikunya viruses, by generating a genetic map of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in recombinant progeny from a cross between two strains. This revealed a high rate of misassemblies in the current genome, where sequences from different chromosomes were found on the same scaffold. Correcting these errors allowed assignment of 60% of the genome to chromosomes and ordering of scaffolds along chromosomes. Large regions of suppressed recombination were found around centromeres, extending up to 47% of chromosome. The new assembly was used to map a gene making Ae. aegypt resistant to the parasite Brugia malayi and identified candidate genes affecting the trait. The Ae. aegi genome is 1.38 gigabases, organized into 4,758 scaffolds, with 31% preliminarily assigned to chromosomes using physical and genetic markers. Syntenic relationships with Anopheles gambiae chromosomal arms were used to correct the assembly. Chromosomal scaffolds were used to map Ae.egi resistance to filarial nematode B. The genome organization of the host is essential to identify genetic components of vector competence. The Ae.egi and Cule quinqueascatus genomes are highly fragmented, with large scaffolds not ordered and oriented. The new assembly facilitates mapping of genes affecting disease transmission. A resistant and susceptible strains were crossed, backcrossed, and progeny fed infected and dissected to examine worm development.
Aedes aegyti, the primary vector of deng and yellow fever viruses, is a key target for vector control programs in tropical countries. Traditional larval surveys are still widely used despite the availability of new trapping devices. This study compared entomological indices generated by larval surveys and four alternative traps (BG-Sent, Adultrap, MosquiAP, and ovitrap) in terms of sensitivity to detect mosquito density variation. The study was conducted in five cities representing tropical climate variations. Simultaneously, lar surveys were performed. Positivity and density indices were calculated and regressed against meteorological variables to characterize seasonal patterns of infestation. The House Index was low in most cities, with median 0, while traps produced indices, indicating greater sensitivity to Ae.egti presence than lar surveys. Positivity and density agreed on seasonality in all cities. Mosquito seasonality was associated with temperature, not precipitation, even in areas with small temperature variation. All traps performed better than the Index in measuring seasonal abundance and should be considered complements or alternatives to lar surveys. Traps should consider differences in cost and ease-of-use.
Human cytidine deaminase APOECG3 (AG) is a potent inhibitor of retroviruses and transposable elements, capable of deaminating cytidines to urines in single-stranded DNA intermediates. The protein contains two cytidine deamin domains (CDAs), with only the C-terminal one known to mediate deamination. Using the crystal structure of tetrameric APOEC2, residues in AG were identified to mediate oligomerization. Yeast two-hybrid assays, coimmunprecipitation, and crosslinking showed tyrosine-124 and tryptan-127 in the enzymatically inactive N-terminal CDA mediate AG oligomer, coinciding with packaging into HIV-1 virions. Oligomerization is also shown to be RNA-dependent. Homology of AG onto A2 structure indicates accumulation of positive charge in a putative dimer interface. Substitution arginine residues 24, 30, and 136 in this pocket resulted reduced virus, virion, and oligomer. Consistent with RNA central role, oligomer-deficient AG associated less with cellular molecules. We propose occupation positively pocket by RNA promotes oligomer, packaging virions, and antiral function.
Researchers have identified the genetic factors contributing to a major-effect quantitative trait locus (QTL) in Drosophila melanogaster, specifically the bric-br locus, which affects cuticular pigmentation. By leveraging the species' high sequence variation and low linkage disequilibrium, they dissected the effects of causative variants within a single locus. Polymorphisms near regulatory elements, including a promoter, tissue-specific enhancer, and Polycomb response element, cumulatively impact bric-br alleles with large effects on cuticular pigmentation. Analysis of allele-specific expression at the br-br locus confirms these polymorphisms modulate transcription at the cis-regulatory level. This study demonstrates a QTL can act through multiple mechanisms, with sequence variation in flanking experimentally validated elements having significant effects on transcriptional activity and phenotype. The findings have implications for both basic and medical genomics.
Streptococcus pneumoniae, a persistent cause of invasive mucosal disease in humans, has adapted to widespread antibiotic and vaccine use through genetic adaptation. This adaptation is facilitated by the uptake and incorporation of new genetic material from the surrounding microbial community, controlled by a regulated quorum sensing system triggered by extracellular accumulation of competence stimulating peptide (CSP). This study demonstrates CSP stimulates production of diverse bacteriocins through increased secretion of bacterioc pherone BlC and requires a functional competence system. A conserved motif in the promoter of BlC operon mediates upregulation by CSP. Accumulation of BlC results in activation of Bl locus. Using biofilm organisms as a model for competition and genetic exchange on mucosal surface, DNA exchange is enhanced by bacterin secretion, suggesting co-stimulation of bacterins provides an adaptive advantage. Bl and regulatory pathways diverged in a pneumoccus ancestor, yet maintained connection promotes competition and adaptation by targeting a wide range of competitors while providing incorporation DNA. The competence system is controlled by quorum sensing regulated by extracellular CSP. Dedicated transporter ComAB processes and secretes CSP. Amino acid sequence preceding mature CSP is recognized by Com and cleaved at double glycine while peptide transported out. Strains with disrupted BlA demonstrate activation bacterin with competence, but Bl pherone secreted ComAB only during competence. Bacterin increases efficiency in dual biofilms suggesting liberation through pneumin contributes adaptability.
Researchers investigated the role of cellular protein SR20 (SRp20) in poliovirus infection, specifically its localization and interaction with protein PC2 (PC2) in recruiting ribosomes to the viral RNA for translation. In poliovirus-infected neuroblastoma cells, SR20 localized from the nucleus to the cytoplasm, where it partially co-localized with PC2, corroborating previous in vitro data. SR20 was associated with PC2 bound to polirus RNA, indicating interaction on the viral RNA. A mutated SR20 lacking the RNA recognition motif (SR20ΔM) localized similarly and co-localized with PC2, but expression resulted in a 100-fold decrease in polirus yield, suggesting a dominant-negative effect. Co-sedation of SR20 and PC2 with 40S ribosomal subunits in poliov-infected cells suggests they function in translation complex formation for polirus IRES translation. Studies provide evidence for PC2-SR20 interaction in cells during polirus and a model where PC2 bound to viral RNA interacts with SR20 to recruit translation complex to RNA, possibly with additional protein-protein or protein-RNA interactions.
Researchers conducted an ENU mutagenesis screen to identify genes regulating neural crest (NC) development, a population of embryonic cells giving rise to glia, neurons, and melanocytes. They used a mouse model sensitized for NC defects, Sox10ac/+, and analyzed 71 pedigrees, identifying four heritable loci, modifier of Sox expression 1-4 (m1-4), altering NC patterning. In homozygous m1 embryos, Sox10ac expression was absent in cranial ganglia, nerves, and sympathetic chain, but other Sox-expressing cells unaffected. Linkage analysis, sequencing, and complement testing confirmed m1 as a new allele of receptor tyrosine kinase Erb3, Erb3m1, with a single amino acid substitution in extracellular region. The E-induced mutation did not alter protein expression, but impaired ER3 signaling, causing embryonic defects in m1 resembling Er3 null alleles. Biochemical analysis showed ER3 expressed on surface, but ligand phosphorylation reduced by m mutation, highlighting importance of residue for ER3 function. This study demonstrates utility of E mutesis in identifying pathways regulating NC and dissecting protein domains contributing to gene function in development.
Researchers conducted a study in a Ugandan community to investigate factors influencing Schistosoma mansoni infection, a parasitic flatworm causing schistosomiasis. They examined the impact of age, sex, and ethnicity on susceptibility to reinfection after antiparasitic treatment, using individual cercarial exposure scores to account for environmental and behavioral heterogeneities. The study found ethnic and sex-related variations in S. mansoni reinfection were due to cercarial exposure, not biological differences in susceptibility. Age-related differences in reinfection were not explained by exposure, but linked to IgE and IgG responses to tegument antigen SmAL (Sm22.6), associated with resistance to reinfection. The study highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach in complex settings to understand population ecology and draw robust conclusions.
