The study used data from a multidisciplinary reinfection study in a Ugandan fishing community highly endemic for schosomiasis to investigate S. mansoni rein. Individual cercarial exposure scores were used to adjust for variations in exposure, supported by epidemiological studies on exposure and reinfection patterns in schosias-endemic communities. Genetic studies identified genes associated with susceptibility or immunity to infection. Microepidemiological studies on Schos infection are limited by lack of individual cercarial exposure data, using proxy markers such as distance to infective water may not accurately reflect exposure. The study found age-infection profiles typical of schos-endemic communities, infection greatest in children, lower in adults. Exposure scores investigated roles of age and sex in susceptibility, Alur ethnic group speculated more susceptible. Schosome Ig or Ig4 immune responses accounted for remaining susceptibility variation.
A study investigated the correlation between the number of eggs per gram of feces (EPG) and the worm burden of Clonorchis sinensis in humans. A total of 60 residents, 50 egg-positive and 10-negative, in Sanche-gun, Korea, participated in the study from 2006-2009. They were diagnosed by egg positivity in feces using the Kato-K method. After administration of prazantel, they were purged with cathartics the next day, and discharged worms were collected from feces. EPG ranged from 0 to 65,544. Adult C. sin were collected from 17-positive, and the number ranged from 1 to 114 each. A correlation between EPG and numbers was demonstrated (r= 0.681, P<0.001). Recovery rates were 9.7% in EPG 1-1,000 and 73.7% in EPG over 1,000. No worms were detected from egg-negative. Maximum count per worm per day was estimated 3,770 in subject EPG 2,664 and collected. The numbers of worms were significantly correlated with egg in Cloniasis. It estimated at least 110 worms in human with EPG around 3,000 and productivity a worm per day around 4,000.
Researchers have developed a novel approach to combat the growing concern of antifungal drug resistance by harnessing synthetic lethal interactions in a model organism. They conducted an unbiased genome-wide screen in Saccharomyces cerevisiae expressing a Candida glata P1 gain-of-function allele, which is a mediator of fluconazole resistance in the human pathogen. Eighteen synthetically lethal S cerevisiae genetic mutants were identified, one of which was histone acetylase G5. Deletion or drug inhibition of G5 caused a lethal phenotype in C glata expressing P1 alleles and inhibited the emergence of fluazole-resistant glata isolates in evolution. The study provides proof of concept that synthetically genetic screens can identify novel proteins therapeutically targeted to treat drug-resistant infections. The researchers confirmed the lethal interaction between G5 and P1 in C glata by inducing P1L280 in a glata g5 null mutant, resulting in loss of viability. Chemical inhibition of G5 also rendered both species inviable, supporting the proposition that targeting synthetic interactions offers a new treatment paradigm for resistant infections. The study demonstrated that targeting G5, a synthetically interacting partner of P1 identified in cerevis, renders both species and ortholog glata inviable. Additionally, the emergence of gain function in P1 was prevented in glata g5 mutants in the presence of fluazole.
Researchers investigated the dynamics of phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate (PI4) during poliovirus (PV) infection to understand its role in genome replication and assembly. They used two mutants, EG and GG, with aberrant proteolytic processing of the P3 precursor, which delays genome replication and assembly, to study the pathway of PV-induced membranous structures. PV changes in the PI pool were observed as early as 30 minutes post-infection, and remodeling occurred in the presence of guanidine hydrochloride, a replication inhibitor, accompanied by membrane tubules throughout the cytoplasm. Vesicles appeared in the perinuclear region at 3 hours post-infection, too late for replication. Delays in onset replication for EG and GG were similar to delays in PI remodeling, suggesting PI serves as a genome-replication organel marker. GG was unable to convert virus-induced tubules into vesicles, explaining nearly 5-log reduction in virus production. Results indicate PV induces distinct membrous structures for replication (tubules) and assembly (vesicles). The pace, spatiemporal dynamics, and efficiency of replication-to-assembly organel conversion may be set by P3 processing rate and capacity to yield 3 and 3 proteins.
Researchers developed a multi-step strategy to identify new compounds with trypanocidal activity against Chagas disease, a neglected tropical disease caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. They used virtual screening of the ZINC database, a collection of commercially available compounds, followed by enzymatic assays, X-ray crystallography, and structure-activity relationship (SAR) studies. From 23 selected compounds, 12 non-peptide, non-covalent cruzain inhibitors with low micromolar affinity (3-60µM) were identified, acting through competitive inhibition. The binding mode of cruzain inhibitor Neimed176 was confirmed by X-ray crystallography. Cruzain, a validated target for chemotherapy, shares similarity with mammalian cathepsin L, linked to invasive properties and metastatic cancer. Inhibitors from the library were assayed against catheps L, showing similar affinity (4-80µM) and poor selectivity towards cruzain, raising possibility of investigating their effect on cell proliferation. The most potent cruzain inhibitors were tested against T. cruzi-infected cells, two showing trypanidal activity. Compound Neimed42 was used to establish SAR, identifying the 2-acetamthiophene-3-carbox group essential for enzyme and parasite inhibition. The IC50 for Neimed against T. cruzi trypomastote was 10.6±0.1µM, tenfold lower than benznidazole, a positive control. A smaller compound, Neimed, with lig efficiency 0.33kcal/mol-atom-1, was highlighted as a non-peptide, nonvalent cruzain trypanidal candidate for optimization.
Researchers have developed two non-viral DNA-based vaccine formulations to protect against yellow fever, a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in tropical regions. The formulations encode the full-length envelope protein of the yellow fever virus (YF) or the envelope protein fused with lysosomal membrane protein LAMP-1 (L). The vaccines were tested in mice strains C57/6 and BAL/c, corresponding to C57/6 and BAL/c mice, respectively. Both induced strong T-cell responses against all epitopes generated by the YF17 vaccine, with pLFE performing best. Additionally, pFE stimulated high titers of anti-Y neutralizing antibodies comparable to those elicited by the 17 vaccine. Importantly, pFE conferred 100% protection against Y virus in intracereally challenged mice. These results indicate pFE is an excellent candidate for further development. 

The study characterized T and humoral responses to the envelope of Y in C57/6 and BAL mice immunized with DNA expressing the full-length F protein, either wild-type or fused L. Responses were compared to the standard immunization using Y17. The ability of vaccines to provide protection against lethal challenge was also evaluated. An optimized Y17 immunization protocol and IF-gamma ELISA conditions were used to characterize T responses to peptides of Y proteins in C57/6 mice. Total splenocytes identified 11 antigenic peptides from the F protein. Immunization with DNA expressing the envelope resulted in recognition of three peptides not produced by Y17. T response to E169 generated by pFE and pLFE was significant, and to E413 and E431 higher in immunized pFE than pFE. Although Y17 produced higher neutralizing titers, DNA encoding entire protein also protected mice against challenge.
Researchers have identified the nucleoid protein SlmA as a direct transcriptional activator of chitio utilization in Vibrio cholera, a pathogen that requires chitin for persistence and horizontal gene transfer in the marine environment. The ch operon, responsible for chitin uptake and degradation, is regulated by the sensor kinase ChiS, but the downstream mechanisms of Chi activation were unclear. An unbiased transposon screen revealed SlmA as a regulator of the ch operon, a novel role for a TetR family protein, typically transcriptional repressors. In vitro, SlmA binds directly to the oper promoter, and in vivo, this interaction is required for transcriptional activation and chio utilization. Mutations disrupting SlmA functions show DNA binding, not nucleoidation, is critical for transcription activation. This study identifies SlmA as a transcriptional regulator in V cholera, in addition to its established role as a cell licensing factor.
Researchers have developed a scalable nonlinear programming framework for solving parameter estimation problems in dynamic biological systems, which are computationally challenging due to highly nonlinear and stiff differential equations, many parameters, and experimental data sets. The proposed framework uses cutting-edge modeling and solution tools that are computationally efficient, robust, and easy-to-use. It employs a time-discretization approach that avoids repetitive model simulations, enables algebraic model computation of derivatives, and uses computationally efficient nonlinear point solvers that exploit sparse and structured algebra. The framework is demonstrated by solving synthetic gut microbiome models with 156 parameters, 144 equations, and 1,704 data points in under 3 minutes, while an off-the-shelf solution requires 7 hours. Large instances show the framework can solve up to 2,352 parameters, 2,304 equations, and 20,352 points in 15 minutes. The framework is flexible, easy-to-use, and can be applied to dynamic biological systems, enabling estimation, uncertainty quantification, observability analysis, model selection, and outlier handling.
Researchers used the nCounter, a high-throughput digital gene expression system, to study the inflammatory response to West Nile virus (WNV) in the Swiss Webster (SW) mouse model. The study aimed to understand gene expression changes following infection and viral dissemination. Mice were injected intraperitoneally with NV and tissues (spleen, lung, liver, and brain) analyzed over nine days. The nCounter Inflammation gene kit, containing 179 inflammation-related genes, was used to analyze expression changes. Protein levels of cytokine/chemokine genes were determined using multiplex detection (Biolex) and compared to RNA levels. Results showed Ccl and Ilb were differentially expressed in all tissues except kidney. Stratification of infected (NV+) versus non-infected (-) tissues allowed differentiation of systemic gene response from tissue-specific responses. Significant decrease in C1 was found in (-) spleen, while Il was upregulated, Il downregulated in (-) lung, and M2 downregulated in (-) liver. In (+) livers, Stat, T2, chemok Ccl, C, C, C, C, Il, Il, Il, and Il were upregulated. In (-) tissues, C and C were upregulated. Gene and protein kinetics for C, C, C, C, and C correlated with virus presence. The study demonstrated the utility of nCounter for rapid identification of gene changes in mice associated with NV infection.
An outbreak of rabies occurred in Maputo and Matola cities, Mozambique in 2014, prompting an investigation into the epidemiology, clinical features, and risk factors of human and animal bites. Between April and August 2014, 14 cases of human rabies were detected, all with a history of recent dog bites, and only one of the 14 rabid dogs was immunized. 819 animal bites were registered, with 64.6% from Maputo City, and dogs responsible for 97.8% of bites, but only 27% were immunized. Factors associated with human rabies were age <15 years, bite by stray dog, deep wound, bite to head, by unimmun dog, no soap use, and no post-exposure prophylaxis.

The study aimed to determine clinical and epidemiological features of human rab cases, risk for developing rab, and animal bites in Map and Matola. The findings will contribute to formulating strategies to control rab in Mozambique. This is the first investigation of rab outbreak and epidemiology of bites in Mozambique, where procedures are irregular, resulting in frequent outbreaks. Maputo City health authorities alerted a possible outbreak in July 2014, with several patients admitted with rab in a short time. Reliable data on rab burden and factors is a challenge for policies and strategies, a major cause for underinvestment in control.

Demographic and risk factors were compared between animal bites and human rab to determine predictive variables. Age <15 (OR:4.8, p=0.05), bite stray (OR:13.6, p=0.002), deep wound (p=0.02), head (p=0.001), unimmun (p=0.01), no soap (p=0.001), and postexposure (p=0.01) were associated.
Researchers identified a new gene, SCN9, encoding the Nav1.7 sodium channel, as a cause of febrile seizures (FS) in a large family with significant linkage to chromosome 2q. A mutation in a conserved amino acid, p.N641, in the cytoplasmic loop between transmembrane domains I and II was found in 21 affected members, but not in ethnically matched controls. To establish a functional role, the mutation was introduced into the murine Sc9 ortholog using homologous recombination. Compared to wild-type, homozygous Sc9/N mice exhibited reduced thresholds to electrically induced clonic and tonic-clonic seizures and increased kindling acquisition rates. This supports SCN9 as disease-causing in the family. SCN was also analyzed in 92 unrelated FS patients, finding highly conserved Nav.7 missense variants in 5%. One child with FS later developed Drav syndrome, a severe myoclonic epilepsy, and SCN1 was sequenced, revealing a heterozygous frameshift. Analysis of 109 Drav patients yielded 9 Nav.7 missense variants, 8%, in conserved amino acids. Six Drav patients with SCN miss variants had either miss or splice SCN1 mutations or no SCN mutations. This study provides evidence for SCN in human epileps, both as cause and partner SCN mutations.
Researchers have proposed a new framework, called the Polarised Tissue (PT) framework, to explain how complex tissue shapes arise through growth. The PT framework views tissue as a continuous material where regional factors under genetic control interact and propagate polarity. Polarity is established through signals that anchor in regions termed tissue organisers, also under genetic control. Rates of growth parallel or perpendicular to polarity are specified through a regulatory network. Growth depends on specified patterns within tissue constraints, leading to features like curvature not specified by networks. Resulting growth influences spatial arrangements and orientations, allowing complex shapes to emerge from simple rules. Asymmetries emerge through polarity interactions. The PT framework was applied to a growing Snapdragon flower, illustrating how hypotheses can be tested by simulation. Combinatorial interactions between orientations and growth, a feature of polarity systems, have been exploited to generate observed shapes.

A series of models studied interactions between tissue polarity and growth in shape generation. Each model had a phase with initial shape and distribution of identities and signalling factors, and components. Simplified models illustrated growth and polarity combinator during morphogenesis generating forms. Results highlighted specifying orientations independently of stresses in complex shapes. Theoretical foundations for modelling were provided. The polarity system accounted for global changes, growth patterns, and clones without large polarity organisers, demonstrating its validity.

In 2D, deformations were considered. A feature of polarity is orientation and growth can be specified and combined. Combinatorially, unlike stress system where orientations depend on stresses. Shapes reflect interactions, growth, and mechanical constraints. Depending on organisers and polarity dynamics, tissue can reinforce or antagonise curvatures or generate curvature in uniform growth. Combinatorial interactions within the plane were considered.
Researchers investigated the consequences of interference between multiple CD8+ T cell escape mutations in early HIV infection. During HIV infection, CD8+ T cell responses are elicited simultaneously, exerting selective pressure on different parts of the virus's genome, leading to mutations that escape recognition and are beneficial to the virus. Some studies show that later escape mutations emerge, the slower they go to fixation. This pattern of escape rate decrease (ER) can arise from distinct mechanisms, particularly in populations with high mutation rates among escape strains, resulting in delayed fixation times of beneficial mutations compared to sexual reproduction. The study developed a multi-locus Wright-Fisher model of HIV dynamics with selection, mutation, and recombination as a null model for interference, and an interference-free model assuming neutral evolution before immune response. Interference between equally advantageous mutations generated the ER pattern. The number of loci and recombination rates affected ER, explained by exponential decline of escape rates over time. ER in HIV individuals is consistent with both interference-free and interference effects. Results confirm interference should be considered when analyzing escape mutations. Estimation of escape and selective coefficients by interference cannot be overcome by sampling sizes due to fundamental shortcomings of current techniques under interference regimes.
Researchers developed a mechanistic model to estimate the in vivo efficacy of cisplatin-based chemotherapy in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCL) patients. The model incorporates cancer cell proliferation, heterogeneity, hypoxia, and treatment resistance mechanisms. It uses tumor volumetric data from two time points before and during treatment, accounting for tumor microenvironment and cell repopulation effects. Sensitivity analysis identified growth rate and fraction as key features for accurate estimates. The model was applied to 13 NSCL patients receiving cisplatin with gemcitab, vinlb, or docetax in neoadjuvant context. Input values were guided by literature on cancer kinetics. Latin hyper sampling compensated for patient uncertainties. The study provides a framework for estimating in vivo cell killing of chemotherapies, correlating estimates with patient molecular profiles for personalized predictions.
Researchers investigated the mechanisms of antibiotic tolerance in bacterial biofilms, specifically focusing on the fluoroquinoloneloxacin, a type of antibiotic. They used transposon mutagenesis to identify mutants in Escherichia coli that formed biofilms with increased tolerance to the antibiotic. The study found that biofilms formed by amino acid auxotrophic mutants exhibited higher tolerance to fluoroquinoloxacin than their planktonic counterparts. Amino acid starvation was shown to significantly increase biofilm tolerance to the antibiotic. Biofilm heterogeneity creates specialized niches where bacteria respond to local cues, leading to genetically and metabolically distinct subpopulations with high tolerance to extracellular stresses like antibiotics. The researchers isolated mutants with decreased ability to form biofilms and found that biofilms formed by amino auxotrophic mutants displayed high antibiotic tolerance. They demonstrated that amino acid starvation increased antibiotic tolerance in biofilm bacteria. Biofilm tolerance to fluoroquinoloxacin was dependent on the SOS response to amino and carbon source, and partially on the stringent response to leucine starvation. However, bio-specific tolerance did not involve SOS-induced toxin-antitoxin systems associated with highly tolerant persisters. Bio tolerance was induced as a function of biofilm age, dependent on SOS response. The study shows that SOS response in nutrient-deprived biofilm environments is a mechanism for bio-specific tolerance to fluoroquinoloxacin.
Researchers have identified cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) as a key regulator of Plasium falcumeroite invasion of human erythrocytes, a critical step in the development of malaria. Invasion of erythrocytes by P. falcumeroites requires specific interactions between host receptors and parasite ligands localized in apical organelles called micronemes. The study found that exposure of meroites to a low potassium environment, typical of blood plasma, activates a bicarbonate-sensitive cytoplasmic adeny cyclase, raising cytosolic c levels and activating protein kinase, which regulates micron secretion. Additionally, c regulates meroite cytosolic calcium levels via an Ep pathway and increases in both c and Ca are essential to trigger micron secretion. The identification of elements in c-dependent pathways regulating micron secretion during invasion provides targets to inhibit blood parasite growth and prevent malaria.
Strongyloides stercis, a soil-transmitted nematode, is one of the most neglected tropical diseases (NTDs). A review of 20 years of studies on S. stercis global prevalence in populations and risk groups was conducted. A literature search of PubMed articles from 1989 to 2011 was performed, including studies on infection prevalence. Bayesian analysis was carried out to obtain country-specific estimates and compare disease ratios in risk groups, accounting for diagnostic sensitivities. 354 studies from 78 countries were included, with 62.4% community-based, 34.2% hospital-based, and 11% refugee/immigrant studies. World maps with country data are provided. African, Asian, and South American resource-poor countries lack S.ercis information. Meta-analysis showed association between HIV/alcoholism and Sercis (OR 2.17, CI 1.18-4.01; OR 6.69 CI 1.47-3.8). High prevalence in selected countries and regions, Sercis prominent in risk groups. Adequate information lacking from many countries, underscoring Serc not to be neglected. Further socio-economic and ecological assessments and integration into global health warranted.

The study aimed to obtain country-wide Serc infection risk and assess association with risk groups. High rates in South Asia, refugees, and immigrants reported. In developed countries, strongyloidis an issue for immigrants, tourists, and military returning from endemic areas. This has implications for medical services and systematic screening before immunosuppressive treatment. Serc infection rates patchy, incidence non-existent. Strongloides stercis world-wide, excluding north, south, prevalence estimates often guesses. Data required for countries, socio-cultural settings. Large-scale population surveys, sensitive methods would narrow gap. Comprehensive collection global Serc rates, information missed due to language, databases.
Researchers have investigated the role of stochastic noise in circadian rhythms, specifically how it affects the entrainment of cells to external cues and generation of autonomous rhythms. However, few studies have examined the impact of circadian perturbations on stochastic noise due to the difficulty in measuring single-cell noise. This study demonstrates that population-level bioluminescence damping can serve as an accurate measure of stochastic noise, applicable to high-throughput circadian screens. Using fibroblast data, higher single-cell noise results in faster population damping, and small molecule modulators change damping in a dose-dependent manner, explained by single-cell noise using a mathematical model. The method was applied to a genome-wide siRNA screen, revealing stochastic altered independently of period and phase. The unperturbed clock is optimized for robust rhythms, few perturbations increasing amplitude and lowering noise. This study highlights the importance of considering circadian perturbations on stochastic, particularly for small-molecule circadian therapeutics development.
Researchers have identified the bacterial protein Fts as a promising target for developing new antibiotics to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria. The protein FZ is essential for bacterial cell division, and an allosteric inhibitor, PC723, has shown in vitro and in vivo activity against Staphylococcus aureus. However, the mechanism of action and effect on FZ in other species is unclear. This study examined the structural environment of the PC723 binding pocket using Pocket, a method that scores similarity between small-molecule binding sites based on 3D structure and molecular dynamics simulations. Results show species and nucleotide state significantly impact the binding site, with disparate environments for non-Staphlococcus species. Pocket analysis of S aureus FZ bound to GTP with resistance mutations predict PC723 strongly binds Staphlocus in nucleotide state. Simulations of FZ dimer indicate polymerization enhances PC723 binding. The study demonstrates the drug pocket can vary across species, genetic variations, and polymer states, providing information for FZ inhibitor development.
Researchers have determined the crystal structure of the N-terminal and catalytic core domains (NTD and CCD) of HIV-1 integrase (IN) in complex with the binding domain (IBD) of lens epithelium-derived growth factor (LEDGF), a protein essential for lentiviral replication. The structure reveals charge interactions between the NTD of IN and IBD, including a constellation of acidic residues on NTD characteristic of lentiviral IN and positively charged residues on IBD. These contacts are critical for stimulating lentiral DNA integration by LED in vitro and during early steps of HIV-1 replication. The findings enabled engineering of a mutant HIV-1 IN that functions only with a complementary LEDGF mutant, providing a basis for lentiral IN-LED interaction and paving the way for LED-based therapies. Deletion of HIV-1 NTD or mutation destabilizing zinc within this domain reduced interaction with LED. A homolog LED, hepatoma growth-related protein 2 (HRP2), interacts with HIV-1 IN and stimulates enzymatic activity in vitro, but its role in lentiral integration is unclear. Lentiral IN is a tetramer and a tetramer model proposed for apoenzyme based on two-domain HIV-1 IN structure. Lentiral integration depends on LED, which associates with chromatin and regulates gene expression, epigenetic modifications, and apoptosis. LED binds lentiral to chromatin in nucleus and directs PIC to active genes during integration.
Researchers investigated the evolution and phenotypic selection of cancer cells in relation to tumor progression. They found that cells from different organs have intrinsic kinetics that influence their behavior, which are inherited by cancer cells and determine initial tumor dynamics. Genetic and epigenetic alterations can change these kinetics, leading to favorable alterations that increase fitness and accelerate progression. A cellular automaton model was developed to track the evolution of cancer stem cells, which can initiate and sustain tumors. Traits such as migration, spontaneous death due to genetic mutations, symmetric division, and telomere length were explored. The study suggests proliferation is the strongest modulator of growth, with increased potential yielding more non-stem cells that compete with stem cells, while reduced potential loosens inhibition and facilitates stem division. The stem cell population becomes heterogeneous, varying from dormancy to progression. Clonal diversity in single biopsies represents a small proportion of total phenotypes.
Researchers investigated the emergence of novel infectious diseases in humans, focusing on the role of spatial heterogeneity in the human population. They used mathematical models to describe adaptation scenarios with reference to spatial heterogeneity and derived analytical expressions for the probability of emergence, waiting time to emergence, and outbreak size distribution. The study found that for typical connection strengths between communities, spatial heterogeneity has a weak effect on outbreak distribution and risk of emergence. For example, a village connected to a city by 10 commuters a day is effectively part of the city in terms of emergence and outbreak distribution. Empirical data showed most communities are at least this interconnected. For plausible ranges, effects of heterogeneity are dominated by host biology adaptation. The study suggests only remote communities are subject to epidemiological isolation. Factors like human patterns and host heterogeneity also shape risk and speed of emergence. The research focused on spatial structure of the host population, which has received little attention in adapting pathogens. The modelled spatially separated communities with varying connections, such as a village and city. The biology of the pathogen determines emergence and outbreak sizes according to reproductive number. The effective village size is due to absent commuters. A threshold exists where heterogeneity does not matter. Previous research depends on interconnectivity allowing spread between communities. The approach allows insights without specifying infectious hosts migrating. Analytical results were validated with stochastic simulations of village-city models.
Researchers analyzed genomic data from 287 avian influenza A virus (AIV) samples collected over a 34-year period of continuous surveillance in North American migratory birds. They used a Bayesian framework to test hypotheses of viral migration, population structure, and genetic reassortment patterns. Results showed that Charadriiform birds in Delaware did not significantly contribute to North American IV diversity, while Anseriform in Alberta represented AIV diversity. IV may be restricted to short-term migratory flyways, but long-term persistence was independent of flyways between populations. Analysis of long-term data provides insights for predictive models for pandemic preparedness and livestock protection. Avian viruses were isolated annually in Alberta and Delaware, with 287 genomes sequenced. Full genome data characterized reassment, spatial patterns, and evolutionary genomics of IV in America over 25 years from migratory birds. Methodological advances enabled large-scale assessment of spatiotemporal viral movement between bird populations. 20 regions in North America were identified where viruses were collected from wild birds to determine population structure according to migratory fly and rates of gene flow between populations. The goal was to understand migration and diffusion of IV in natural hosts using 30 years of surveillance. Results showed that Alberta, with convergence of four migratory fly, captured majority of North genetic diversity. Breeding birds in this region facilitated spread and generation of virus diversity, indicating importance of Anseres social behavior in persistence. Delaware was identified as hotspot for AIV, where thousands of Charadiform stop to feed in dense congregations. Long-term persistence of IV in wild may be independent of migratory fly.
Researchers have developed a novel monoclonal antibody, MAb S/1391, that targets a common antigen site on the hemagglutinin (HA) of influenza A viruses. This antibody shows heterosubic cross-reactivity, meaning it can neutralize and inhibit multiple subtypes of influenza A viruses, including H1, H2, H3, H5, H9, and H13. MAb S/1 was found to be effective against particular strains of H, H, H, and H subtypes of influenza viruses. Mutant viruses that escaped neutralization by MAb/1 were analyzed and found to have amino acid substitutions at positions 156, 158, and 193 of the HA gene. Molecular modeling revealed these amino acids are located on the globular head of HA and form a conformational epitope adjacent to the receptor-binding domain. Passive immunization of mice with MAb/1 provided heterosubic protection. The study demonstrates M/1 binds to a shared antigenic site among various HA subtypes and neutralizes infectivity in vitro and in vivo by affecting viral attachment to cells. This supports the notion that cross-reactive antibodies play a role in heterosubic immunity against influenza virus infection and highlights the potential utility of cross-reactive antibodies in therapy.
A three-year cohort study was conducted to assess the effectiveness of ivermectin treatment on Strongyloides steralis infection in an Australian Aboriginal population and the validity of using a lower ELISA cut-off for diagnosis. Two hundred and fifty-nine adults living in a remote community in northern Australia were tested for S. stercis using a commercial ELISA kit with a lower threshold than recommended. Follow-up was conducted at 6 months and 3 years after ivermect treatment. Results showed a significant decrease in prevalence from 35.3% to 5.8% (McNem's chi2 = 56.5, p<0.001). The use of a lower ELISA threshold for treatment was deemed valid in this setting. Follow-up identified a small group with persistently positive ELISA serology despite treatment. Control of S. stis in this cohort appears feasible through pharmacological treatment alone. Three years after treatment, prevalence fell to 1.4%. This study provides evidence that control of chronic S. stis in an Aboriginal population can be achieved through case-finding and treatment using current guidelines.
Researchers investigated whether long-incubation period prion strains can interfere with each other when co-infected in animals. They found that co-infection of long-incation strains did not show evidence of interference, suggesting that the lack of interference is not due to failure to target the same cells but an inherent property of the strains. Protein misfolding cyclic amplification assays (PMCA) indicated that both strains amplified independently, consistent with animal bioassay studies. Importantly, PMCA reactions seeded with longation strains contained relatively higher levels of PrC compared to seeded with shortation strain. This suggests that abundance of Pr is not limiting in vivo or in vitro in pr strains with low conversion efficiency to amplify independently. This changes the paradigm of prion strain interactions and has implications for interspecies transmission and emergence of pr strains from mixture. Pr strain interference occurs when Pr abundance is limiting, and strains compete for Pr, which is necessary for prion formation. Overexpression of Pr can lead to emergence of strains not identified when Pr is at physiological levels. The study suggests that subset of Pr convertible by both strains may influence interference more than total Pr abundance.
Researchers have proposed a comprehensive model to compare the roles of ordered and disordered proteins in alloster regulation, challenging the previous assumption that intrinsic disorder is favorable for alloster coupling. The model reveals that the Monod-Wy-Wyman-Change (MWC) pathway, which involves order-to-disorder transition, has a higher probability of alloster effect than the Ensemble Allost Model (EAM) pathway, which involves disorder-to-order transition. This suggests a more complex role of intrinsically disordered protein regions (ID/IDRs) in regulatory proteins. An analytical formula for maximal alloster coupling shows that stable or unstable states are unfavorable for alloster, aiding in designing alloster drugs. The Ensemble Allost Model (EAM) previously explained the prevalence of ID/ID in alloster regulation by high alloster intensity and probability of disordered states. However, it lacks the order-to-disorder transition, present in the MWC model for ordered proteins. A comprehensive model considering both transitions shows order-disorder (E) is less competitive than order-order (M) in affording alloster, especially strong alloster. The prevalence of ID/ID in alloster regulation is more complicated than thought. The model does not provide a complete answer, but offers discussion. ID/ID alloster effect without ordered structures is related to a new view of alloster based on protein structure landscape, where ligand stabilizes states and shifts conformation. The EAM used this view to explain ID alloster. The prevalence of ID/ID in alloster is determined by advantage, not only alloster capacity. Combining experimental and bioinformatics would compare ordered and dis importance in alloster.
β-Caten plays a crucial role in prostate development and cooperates with PTEN loss to drive invasive carcinoma. Prostate cancer is a leading cause of death in Western countries, but few genetic alterations driving prostate initiation and progression have been identified. β-Caten is essential for developmental processes and implicated in tumorigenesis in many tissues, including prostate. However, studies on human cancer samples are unclear on this protein's role. In vivo studies in embryo and adult extended understanding βaten's role in normal and neoplastic prostate. Gene deletion revealed prostate epithelial βaten required for embryonic growth but dispensable in adult. During development, βaten controls progenitors in epithelial buds and regulates discrete genes, c-Myc and Nk3.1. Deletion βaten in PTEN model castration cancer demonstrated dispensable for progression. Complementary overexpression, in vivo stabilization showed βaten promotes squamous epith during development absence androgens. βaten overexpression with PT loss drove invasive carcinoma with squamous metaplas. These demonstrate βaten essential for prostate and inherent high levels drive squamous differentiation.
Researchers conducted a study to understand the factors influencing informed consent in a biomedical study in a low-income setting, specifically in southern Ethiopia, among people with podoiosis (non-filar elephantiasis). They adapted a rapid assessment method validated in The Gambia. The study was qualitative, involving focus groups and in-depth interviews with podoiosis patients, non-patients, community workers, researchers, NGO staff, and community leaders. Results showed that the use of everyday language, addressing participants' expectations, and information presentation techniques impacted comprehension. Approaching patients via trusted individuals and preceding community sensitization were optimal communication means. Poverty, absence of treatment facilities, and trust in NGO were barriers to genuine consent. Researchers should evaluate consent processes to provide information in a comprehensible manner and support decision-making on a study-by-study basis.

The community believed podoiosis is genetic, using terms like 'passed from parents and grandparents' and 'blood' to express disease. Most participants did not favor written consent forms. Fieldworkers and researchers suggested monetary compensation might induce participation due to poverty, stressing 'kel yoneiminet' (voluntariness) should be part of the process. Participants advised approaching patients through local intermediaries like MPA fieldworkers, as they are respected. Local gatherings, group discussions are usual information modes. Important ethical guidelines: research purpose, researchers, affiliations, biological sample, confidentiality, and findings were considered in the consent process.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to study the dynamics of T cell proliferation in the immune system, specifically in the thymus and spleen of mice. They used single-cell flow cytometry to analyze the incorporation of thymidine analogue during pulse-chase-pulse experiments in vivo and DNA content. The model, based on Ordinary Differential Equations (ODE), simulates the evolution of single cell behavior through various durations of labelling, allowing data fitting and estimation of proliferation rates and cell cycle durations in subpopulations. The model is simple, flexible, and validated with other pulse-chase experiments. Results show T cell proliferation is highly heterogeneous, with specific signatures depending on genetic origins, cell stages in thym and sple, and altered with age. The model infers proliferation rates and cycle durations from EdU data, revealing cell heterogeneity and signatures. The study assesses the impact of genetics and aging on the immune system by investigating T lymphocyte dynamics across differentiation in thym and sple. It provides a detailed quantification of cell proliferation in subpopulations along differentiation from thym to sple and aging. The model allows comparison of effect of age and genetics on lymphocyte dynamics from early thym to final maturation sple. Fitting data was done by simulating cells through cycle labelling over bi-dimensional parameters, constraining parameters with biological hypotheses. Proliferation rates were compared for thym and sple, abstracting phenotypic heterogeneity T cells in young and old B6, F mice.
Researchers have identified a mitochondrial tRNA mutation in mice that recapitulates the molecular hallmarks of a disease-causing mutation in humans. The mutation, a G>A transition at position 9 in the mt-T gene, leads to abnormal folding of the tRNA that cannot be charged with isoleucine. Cells harboring the mutant tRNA show exacerbated mitochondrial biogenesis triggered by an increase in ROS production as a compensatory response. This response partially compensates for the deficiency. The study demonstrates the implication of ROS-mediated biogenesis in the expression of tRNA mutations found in patients. Mitochondrial tRNA mutations, particularly those in t genes, are scarce but intriguing for understanding human pathology and can serve as models for evolution and fixation of mitochondrial mutations. To date, sources of this type of mutations have only been found in humans. The study proposes that the pathogenic mechanism combined with compensatory mechanism explains the penetrance pattern of this mutation, allowing for evolution of tRNAs where two deleterious alleles can proceed in steps not requiring simultaneous mutation of both. This contrasts with mutations affecting protein-coding genes, where biogenesis is detrimental rather than compensatory.
Researchers investigated the regulation of the active X chromosome in human triploid cells, where dosage compensation is achieved by doubling X-linked gene expression in both sexes and X-inactivation in females. They used expression arrays to compare X-linked and autosomal gene expression in human triploid cells. The average X:autosome ratio was about 1 in normal diploid cells, but lower (0.81-0.84) in triploid with one active X and higher (1.32-1.4) in triploid with two X's. X-linked expression in triploid does not strictly respond to autosomal nor is adjusted to balance. Unbalanced X:aut ratios may contribute to abnormal phenotypes with triploidy. Autosomal expression per gene copy was similar in triploid versus diploid, indicating no global effect on autosomal. In trip with two X's, data support doubling X-linked expression. However, in trip with single X, X-linked expression adjusted by epigenetic sensing X/aut ratio. A mechanism may act on subset genes with dosage relation autos critical. A range of X-linked expression in relation ploidy was found, with subset (~7%) genes proportional autos sets.
The dN/d ratio, a measure of evolutionary pressures on proteins, was originally developed for distantly diverged sequences. However, it is often applied to sequences from a single population, where differences represent segregating polymorphisms. This study examines the expected d/d ratio for samples from a single population under selection and finds it is relatively insensitive to the selection coefficient. The hallmark of positive selection, d/d>1, is violated within a population. The relationship between selection and d/d does not follow a monotonic function, making it impossible to infer pressures from d/d. This has implications for interpreting d/d measurements among population-genetic samples. 

The relationship between selection and d/d is different for samples from a population compared to divergent lineages. Standard tests for selection based on d are sensitive to divergent lineage assumption violations. In single population samples, differences represent polymorphisms, not fixation events along lineages. The study analyzes the population genetics of d/d. Simulations confirm theoretical analysis d/d. The relationship between selection and d/d is described by Equation 2 when comparing divergent lineages. However, within a population, the relationship is different. Negative selection induces low d/d, while divergent lineages produce extreme d. Results have implications for inferences of selection based on d among conspecific samples. Even independently evolving populations, d's power to detect selection is low when majority sites evolve purifying.
Researchers investigated the effect of natural selection on neutral divergence between closely and distantly related species. They found that neutral divergence between closely related species, such as humans and primates, is negatively correlated with functional content and positively with recombination rate. Similarly, divergence between distantly related species, such as humans and rodents, is negatively correlated with functional and positively with estimates of background selection from primates. These patterns persist after accounting for confounding factors. Coalescent models indicate that background selection in the ancestral population can explain a large proportion of variance in divergence across the genome. The study suggests that natural selection can indirectly affect neutral divergence between both closely and distantly related species, contrary to previous intuition. The findings have implications for understanding genome evolution and interpreting genetic variation.
Researchers investigated the role of the CK2 kinase in the regulation of the Drosila circadian clock, specifically targeting the CLOCK (CLK) protein. They found that CK2 phosphorylates and stabilizes CLK, reducing its activity, contrary to the previously known effect of CK1, which promotes CLK degradation. Downregulation of CKα, the catalytic subunit of CK, leads to CLK degradation, even in the absence of PER and TIM. Unexpectedly, the regulatory β subunit of the CK holoenzyme is not required for CLK regulation. Downregulation of CKα decreases CLK phosphorylation and increases PER and TIM transcription, indicating CK inhibits CLK degradation while reducing its activity. This suggests a counteracting effect of CK1 and CK2 on CLK stability and transcriptional activity. Temporal phosphorylation of clock proteins is a key feature of the transcription-translational feedback loop in the Dila circadian clock. The study aimed to determine if CK was involved in control of CLK phosphorylation and its effect on circadian function. Findings define the first kinase of Dila CLK involved in degradation and hyperphosphorylation. CKα inhibition stabilizes strongly active CLK, joining the club of circadian transcription factors with similar to the W complex in Neuroora. Results indicate CK might be key in mechanism, promoting stability and decreasing activity. It remains to be seen how CK and DB-dependent activities interact to set CLK activity in the circadian cycle.
Researchers investigated the role of cruzain, a cysteine peptidase, in the interaction between Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, and its invertebrate host Rhodnius prolix. They found that treatment with anti-cruzain antibodies or cystine peid inhibitors significantly decreased parasite adhesion to the insect midgut, except for one inhibitor, CA-074-OM. Cystatin, a cystine peid inhibitor, showed a dose-dependent reduction in adhesion. Comparison of adhesion among T cruzi isolates revealed that one isolate with low levels of active cruzain adhered less than others. Transgenic parasites overexpressing an endogenous cruzain inhibitor, chag, had reduced levels of active cruzain and adhered 73% less than wild-type. Adhesion of ch parasites was partially restored by addition of exogenous cruzain. In vivo experiments showed low levels of ch parasites compared to wild-type after passage in insect presented enhancement of surface cruzain expression.
Researchers have identified 20 genes in Caenorhabditis elegans that, when reduced in function, can suppress the effects of a cytoplasmic dyin heavy chain mutant. Cytoplasm dyin is a microtubule-dependent protein essential for mitotic processes such as centrosome separation, chromosome congression, anaphase elongation, and segregation, as well as interphase vesicle transport and organel positioning. The 12 of the 20 suppressor genes do not exhibit sterile or lethal phenotypes when their function is reduced in wild-type worms. Many of the suppress proteins, including dyin light chains, localize to subcellular sites that overlap with those reported for the dyin heavy chain. Knocking down one of four putative dyin accessory chains suppresses the heavy mutants, suggesting some chains negatively regulate heavy function. Additionally, 29 genes, when reduced in function, suppress not only dyin but also loci for unrelated processes. The study suggests conserved non-essential genes contribute to dyin during mitosis.
In the ciliate Paramecium tetra, programmed genome rearrangements (PGR) occur during somatic differentiation, where DNA double-strand breaks (DSB) drive the process. The germline nucleus is transmitted to the progeny, but the somatic nucleus, essential for gene expression, is destroyed and a new somatic nucleus differentiates from a copy of the germline. In P. tetra, the development of the somatic nucleus involves massive GR, including the elimination of at least 45,000 germl sequences (Internal Eliminated Sequences, IES). I excision proceeds through a cut-and-close mechanism: domestic transposase PigMac is essential for cleavage and DSB at excision involves Ligase IV, a component of non-homous endjoining (NHE) pathway. To understand how cleavage and DSB are coordinated during GR, researchers focused on Ku, the actor of HE-mediated repair. Two Ku70 and Ku80 paralogs are encoded in the genome of P. tet: Ku70 and Ku80 are produced during sexual processes and localize in developing somatic nucleus. Using interference, the development-specific Ku70/Ku80 heterodimer is essential for recovery of functional somatic nucleus. Strikingly, PigMac-dependent cleavage is abolished at IES in cells depleted Ku80, resulting IES retention in somatic genome.
Researchers investigated the early mechanisms of pathology in prion disease by analyzing the transcriptional dynamics of hippocampal CA1 neurons in infected mice. They used laser microdissection to isolate neurons and found that gene expression is dynamic, characterized by distinct phases, with a major cluster of genes altered preclinically returning to basal levels or reversing during clinical disease. This cluster contains a signature of N-methyl-aspartic acid (NMDA) receptor and neuroprotective pathways. Genes involved in neuronal projection and dendrite development were also altered, leading to a decline in synaptic protein expression. Deregulated miRNAs, such as mi-132p, mi-124p, mi-16, mi-26, mi-29, and mi-140, followed concomitant patterns. The study is the first to describe the preclinical response of hippocal neurons to prion replication. Findings suggest prion stimulates a programmed response, mediated by NMD receptor, promoting survival and neurite remodeling, but terminated before clinical symptoms, pointing to a critical juncture in disease.
Researchers have developed a computer model, called a Petri net, to simulate the formation and function of granulomas, which are clusters of immune cells that form in the liver in response to infection with the parasite Leishmania donovani. The model was validated with data from experiments in mice and showed that it accurately represented the progression of the disease and changes in the granoma composition over time. The model revealed a previously unknown level of diversity in the granoma's ability to fight the parasite and found that IL-10 produced by Kupffer cells, a type of immune cell, plays a key role in controlling the parasite load within the granoma. The model does not account for IL-10's effects outside the granoma, such as on T cell differentiation in other tissues, which could affect the quality and quantity of cells entering the granoma. Studies in mice and humans with Leishmaniasis show that granulomatous inflammation is a sign of protective immunity and T cells are key to fighting the parasite. Depletion of T cells in the model led to high parasite burden and non-healing infection, as seen in T-deficient mice.
Researchers have viewed the transcriptional machinery of a gene as a computational device with transcription factor concentrations as inputs and expression levels as output, raising the question of what kinds of computations are possible. They show that different parameterizations of a simple kinetic model of transcription regulation can approximate arithmetic operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and equality, as well as inequality operations. This contrasts with studies emphasizing logical or digital notions of computation in biological networks. The accuracy and precision of these approximations depend on different sets of parameters and are independently tunable. Networks of "arithmetic" genes can be combined to accomplish more complicated computations by designing a network that detects significant elevations in a time-vary signal. Approximating analytic functions can be achieved by allowing multiple transcription factor binding sites on the promoter. These observations are important for interpreting naturally occurring networks and designing synthetic networks. Theoretical analysis and simulations demonstrate that "arithmetic" genes can be combined to compute sophisticated functions, such as tracking the mean and standard deviation of a time-vary signal and detecting when it is significantly elevated. A model of a gene regulated by a single transcription factor with multiple binding sites on the promoter is also considered. Simple models demonstrate the possibility of arithmetic at transcriptional regulation. Other functions, such as exponentiation, logarithms, and trigonometric functions, can be computed by combinations of arithmetic. However, this would be energetically wasteful and require many genes. A more efficient approach is approximating directly using complicated machinery.
Researchers sequenced the genomes of Chikungunya virus (CHV) from a recent outbreak in Northeast Brazil and found that two genotypes, Asian/Caribbean and ECSA, are cocirculating in the region. The study used an in-house Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS) protocol to directly detect multiple CHV genotypes from clinical samples. The results show that both genotypes expanded their range and reached cocirculation in Northeast Brazil. Additionally, the data supports simultaneous infection by two genotypes, suggesting coinfection might be more common than thought in endemic areas. The study sequenced 132 CHV cases out of 263 samples initially screened for Dengue (DENV) and Zika (ZIK) viruses, showing CHV displaced Zika outbreak in Brazil between May 2015 and 2016, but genotypes were not determined. This study is the first to show two CHV genotypes cocirculating in same region and evidence coinfection of ECS and AsianCar CHV genotypes in naturally infected individuals. CHV has caused health and economic burden worldwide due to continuous spread in Brazil in 2014, rapidly in naive population. Limited information exists on epidemiology and evolution of CHV after entrance in Brazil.
The bacterial modulator HNS plays a crucial role in regulating horizontally acquired and core genes in the bacterial genome. HNS targets both horizontally transferred (HGT) and core genes, silencing their expression in response to external stimuli such as osmolarity and temperature. Research shows that HNS discriminates and differentially modulates GT and core DNA. For example, plasmid R27-encoded HNS has evolved to silence GT genes without interfering with core regulation. In contrast, chromosomal H requires a helper protein, Hha, to silence GT DNA, while core genes are modulated by H homodimers. The presence of H-like proteins is restricted to Enterobacteraceae, and conjugative plids encoding HNS variants have been isolated only from this family. The HNS system in Enterobacteria presents unique features, enabling selective discrimination between GT and core DNA, potentially maintaining horizontally transmitted DNA silent and giving bacteria a competitive advantage in adapting to new environments, including host colonization.
Researchers compared the gene expression profiles of three Leishmania species (L. major, L. infantum, and L. braziliensis) in their intracellular amastigote stages, which are responsible for causing disease in humans. Genome sequencing revealed conserved gene content and synteny across the genus, but only a small number of genes were differentially distributed between species. Customized oligonucleotide microarrays confirmed that these differentially distributed genes were expressed in intracellular amastotes, with few regulated at the RNA level. In a large-scale study of L. brazili, ~9% of genes were regulated in RNA expression during its life cycle, consistent with other Leish species. Comparing amigote expression between species confirmed Leish transcriptomes undergo little regulation, identifying conserved genes differently regulated between species in host. Immune competence was investigated by comparing L. major amigotes from wild-type (BAL/c) or immunocompromised (Rag/−/γ−) mice. Dissemination was enhanced in Rag−/−γ− background, but RNA profiles unperturbed, suggesting Leish amigotes are pre-adapt for intracellular survival with little RNA modulation.
Researchers have developed a novel loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) assay, named LPhimerus, for detecting Amphimeris DNA in human stool samples. Amphimer is a fish-borne disease caused by the liver fluke Amphimer spp, which has been reported in the Pacific coast of Ecuador with high prevalence in humans and animals. Current diagnosis relies on stool examination for parasite eggs, but lacks sensitivity and morphology may be confused with other liver and intestinal flukes. No immunological or molecular methods have been developed. The LPhus assay targets Amphimer internal transcribed spacer 2 region and was optimized using adult worm DNA from animals. Conventional PCR was performed with outer primers F3 to verify amplification of Amphimer DNA sequence. LAMP was optimized with different mixtures and temperatures, set as LPhus. Sensitivity and specificity of PCR and LAMP were evaluated, with detection limit 1 pg genomic DNA. Field testing was done with 44 stool samples from endemic areas, 25 were positive for Amphimer eggs. Molecular testing PCR3 was ineffective with fecal DNA, but Lus showed 76.67% sensitivity and 80.77% specificity. A specific and sensitive LAMP for Amphimer in stool was developed, named Lus, with potential for field diagnosis and surveillance in endemic areas.
Researchers have identified a novel role for the SNARE protein Ykt in autophagosome-lysosome fusion in Drosophila. Unexpectedly, Ykt forms a complex with Sy17 and Snap29 to promote autophag-lysosome formation, and its loss leads to large-scale accumulation of autophagosomes unable to fuse with lysosomes. Ykt localizes to lysosomes and autophagosomes, and forms a SNARE complex with Sy17 and Snap, but can be outcompeted by Vamp. Overexpression of Vamp rescues the fusion defect in Ykt loss-of-function cells. A mutant Y6 with an R amino acid change in the zeroionic layer retains autoph activity and restores viability, unlike palmitylation or farnesylation mutants. Ykt and V7 are mutually exclusive subunits in the Sy17-Snap complex, suggesting V7 is involved in membrane fusion and Y6 acts as a non-conventional SNARE. Y6 is essential for autoph clearance in Doph larval cells and not functionally non-redundant with V7.
Nontable Haophilus influenza (NTH) is a common inhabitant of the human nasopharyngeal mucosa, but can cause opportunistic infections in the upper and lower respiratory tracts. The bacterium's virulence is partly due to its ability to evade host-derived antimicrobial peptides (AMPs). The Sap sensitivity to antimicrobial peptides ABC transporter enables NTH to resist AMP, but the underlying mechanism was unknown. Researchers previously found that periplasmic protein SapA bound AMPs and was required for NTH virulence in vivo. This study demonstrates that Sap functions to counter AMP lethality during NTH infection by delivering AMP to the inner membrane for transport into the cytoplasm. AMPs localize to the cytoplasm of NTH and are susceptible to cytoplasmic peptase activity, but accumulate in the perasm of bacteria lacking a functional Sap complex. This supports a mechanism of Sap-mediated AMP import, reducing periplasm and inner accumulation of host defense peptides. Host AMPs are amphipathic, cation innate molecules targeting bacterial membranes, disrupting transmembrane potential and triggering cytoplasm leakage in bacterial death. NTH must acquire nutrients and defend against host immune strategies, including AMP production in response to infection. Altered AMP expression impacts colonization ability to colonize host. Defins and cathelicin are abundant in neutrophils, epithium, and secreted by lung and trache epithelium, limiting bacterial mucosal colonization. This study shows Sap contributes virulence by conferring protection from AMP lethality in vivo. A novel mechanism of inner transport of AMP via Sap transporter to cytopl for degradation is described.
Researchers investigated how the degradation of the MarA transcription factor, a key regulator of stress response genes in E. coli, affects its coordination of downstream targets. MarA has a short half-life of 1-3 minutes due to Lonase activity and regulates 60 genes involved in antibiotic resistance, including efflux pumps and stress proteins. The study used CRISPR to modify Mar's half-life and found that increased half-life enhances maximum coordination between downstream genes, but decreases the rate of coordination. In contrast, decreased half-life increases the rate of coordination but reduces maximum. This trade-off suggests that perfect fidelity and instantaneous coordination cannot coexist. The study suggests that degradation allows for responsive and agile signaling, enabling rapid phenotypic diversity in response to challenges.
Researchers investigated the role of MAP kinase phosphatase 2 (MK-2) in the immune response to Leishmania major infection in C57/BL mice. In a previous study, MK-2 deficient mice were found to be more susceptible to Leishmania mexicana infection due to increased Arginase-1 levels and reduced NO activity in macrophages and a diminished TH1 response. However, in this study, MK-2 deficient mice showed a similar healing response to Leish major infection as wild-type mice, with similar lesion size and parasite numbers. Analysis of immune responses revealed a reduced TH1 response in MK- mice with lower parasite specific IgG2 levels, lower frequency of IF-γ and TN-α producing CD4 and CD8 T cells, and lower stimulated spleen IFγ production compared to wild-type. Despite this, MK- mice also had reduced antigen spleen and lymph node IL-4 production and parasite-specific IgG in serum, indicating a general cell hypo-responsiveness. The TH1/TH balance was unaltered in MK- mice compared to wild-type. MK- macrophages were more permissive to Le major growth than wild-type macrophages, but LPS/IF-γ was equally effective in controlling parasite growth in both. The absence of TH/TH switch in MK mice, no change in disease phenotype was observed.
Researchers have investigated the development of the ductal network in the pancreas, a branched organ that does not exhibit stereotypic branching patterns like most glands. They found that the network undergoes a transition from unconnected micumen to a mesh and finally a treelike structure, a process poorly understood on microscopic and macroscopic levels. The study quantified network properties at different developmental stages and discovered stereotyp traits at each stage, with changes towards optimized delivery of exocrine products into the duodenum. Using in silico modeling, they deconstructed steps of network development into simple rules likely conserved for other glands. Early network formation is explained by noisy, redundant connections as micum form, while later transition is attributed to pruning based on fluid flux through the network into duod. The study shows that although branches are different between mice, the network is stereotyp at stages E12.5 and E.18.5, with transition from interlinked to treel structure reflected in changing properties. Stereotyp traits at each stage and remodeling quantified by standard measures, in sil modeling deconstructed main development into simple rules. Early formation from E.10 to E.12.5 explained by noisy, duct as new micum form, but detailed description of micum formation is missing. Remodeling from plex to ramified treike is less understood, but Villenor colleagues provided insight with anatomical description. The study reveals previously unknown features of development, relevant to glands with micumen, such as saliv gland and glands secreting fluid. Proposed rules differ from deterministic branching or random in mammary gland.
Researchers have mapped the structural and dynamical features of kines motor proteins, which drive intracellular transport by coupling ATP hydrolysis to conformation changes that mediate movement along microtubules. A comprehensive analysis of 114 experimental structures and molecular dynamics simulations identified three distinct conformation clusters: ATP-like, ADP-like, and Eg5-inhibitor-bound. These groups differ in the orientation of key elements, notably microtub binding α-α5, loop subdomain and α2-β-4β-β-7 motor tip. Group membership does not correlate with nucleotide state, but with groupings coincide with necker orientations. Accelerated simulations of ATP, AD, and Eg5 indicate all states sample majorlogically observed conformations, with differences in distal site coupling evident. In ATP bound simulations, necker, loop, and α-5 sub display motions absent in AD bound. Dissection of these couplings reveals a network between active, microub interface, and necker via loop and loop7. Simulations show mutations G325 and G326 in loop reduce flexibility and disrupt couplings. Results indicate ATP and AD conformations are intrinsically accessible regardless of nucleotide, supporting a model where necker docking tightens microub and nucleotide regions. Simulations highlight critical conformation changes and alloster coupling between dist sites.
Researchers have developed a new approach to interpret bioluminescent data from the Lux system, a gene reporter used in bacterial and eukaryotic cells. The Lux system is fast, sensitive, non-destructive, and enables high-frequency measurements, but correct interpretation of biolumines data is limited due to its nonlinearity and molecular dynamics. The new approach is based on a mathematical model of Lux activity, including LuxAB, LuxC, and Fre, with improved mechanisms for reactions and protein synthesis and turnover. The model is calibrated with experimental data from Photorhabdus luminescens, the source of modern Lux reporters, and literature data for LuxC. Importantly, it shows evidence for previously unreported inhibition of the Lux reaction by FM2. Simulations predict biolumcent profiles can differ from gene expression, with peaks of light output similar to some experimental data. By incorporating the model into a Bayesian scheme, promoter activity can be inferred from biolumcence. Examples show a decrease in biolumcence is better interpreted as promoter off, and increase in biolum as longer expression. This approach benefits Lux technology users.
Researchers have elucidated the crystal structure of Coxsackievirus A16 (CVA) in complex with a capsid binder G3 (G3), which inhibits the replication of enterovirus 71 (EV) and Coackievirus A16, major causes of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) in children. The study clarifies the role of key residues involved in interactions with the inhibitor. Based on this model, in silico docking was performed to investigate interactions with next-generation capsid binders NLD and AL, showing potent inhibitors of a panel of enteroviruses with potential pharmacological properties. A meta-analysis was performed using available information to gain insight into structural features required for capsid binders to interact effectively and confer broad-spectrum enteriv activity.

The study used in silico protocol docked two designed capsid binders into CVA structure, demonstrating similar binding mode. Structural in silico results were analyzed in context antiv activity against a range enterir, showing potency and broad-spectrum antiv activity. Inhibitors were tested against a panel enterir (Table 2). Structural comparisons (Fig 9) used meta-analysis correlated features with antiv activity, reinforcing NLD as a candidate for HFMD drug.

Canyon-like depressions encircle 5-fold axes are receptor sites for attachment. Uncoating process, capsid opens to release genome into host cytos to initiate replication is key enterirus infection. Analysis revealed 60 VP proteins in enterid contain hydrophobic factor. Expulsion factor required for infection, molecule replaces factor with higher affinity serves antiral acts before virus replicate. Crystal CVA with capsid binder 3 (4-pyrid-2-imazinone (G3) was presented, energy compound/protein interaction calculated using in sil docking.

Anti-poliov activity observed for capsid bind, highest EC for PV with Leu at bottom, reducing energy compared PV and PV with Phe. Hydrophobic below canyon VP still target for novel inhibitors early enterirus infection.
Researchers have identified the cells and receptor responsible for the uptake and degradation of the Necrot serpin in Drosila melanogaster, a protein that regulates the immune response to fungal and Gram-positive bacterial infections. The serpin is synthesized in the fat body and rapidly degraded, but its site of degradation was unclear. Using a temperature-sensitive Dynamin mutation, they demonstrated that Necrot is removed from the hemolymph by two groups of cells: glial and pericardial macrophages. Necrot uptake increases rapidly after 30 minutes and peaks at 6-8 hours. The serpin is processed through multivesicular bodies and delivered to the lysosome, where it co-localizes with the ubiquitin-binding protein HRS, but not Rab11, indicating it is not re-exported from macrophages. Mutations blocking late endosome/lysosome fusion (dor and car) cause accumulation of Necrot-positive endosomes even without infection. Knocking down the Drosila ortholog of the mammalian LDL receptor with dsRNA identifies Lp1 as an enhancer of the immune response uptake of Necrot from hemolymph is blocked by chromosomal deletion of Lp1.
In sea urchins, Nodal signaling prevents the formation of the left rudiment on the right side, but the opposing pathway to Nodal signaling during left-right (LR) axis establishment is unclear. Researchers found that BMP signaling is activated in the left coelomic pouch, specifically in the veg2 lineage, but not in small micromeres. By perturbing BMP activities, they demonstrated that BMP signaling is required for activating the expression of left-sided genes and formation of left-sided structures. On the other hand, Nodal on the right inhibits BMP signaling and LR asymmetry and apoptosis of small miceres. This suggests that BMP is a positive signal for left-sided development in seaurchs, indicating that opposing Nodal and BMP roles in LR asymmetry are conserved in deuteromes. BMP is symmetrically expressed in skeogenic miceres, but signaling is asymmetrically activated in left-derived HC. Results support the hypothesis that BMP is required for proper patterning and expression of left genes in aboral veg descendants. Nodal functions on right to prevent rudiment formation in seaurchs, so the relationship between Nodal and BMP during axis was examined. Increasing BMP signaling results in loss of nodal expression, suggesting BMP is required for right nodal expression in seaurch. This positive role of BMP on nod has been observed in vertebrates. In absence mouse embryonic BMP4, nod is lost in LPM. No asymmetrical expression of BMP antagonists, such as chordin, nog, follatin, dan, or gremlin, was detected in seaurch embryo. A second mechanism for mutualism between Nodal and BMP is direct competition for common effector Smad.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection is strictly synchronized with the host cell cycle, with infected G0/G cells supporting immediate early (IE) gene expression and proceeding to the G1 boundary, where they arrest. In contrast, S/G cells can be infected but block IE expression, and this inhibition is relieved when cells divide and re-enter G1. During latent infection, IE expression is also inhibited, and reactivation requires overcoming this block. We show that the IE block in S/G can be overcome by genotoxic stress and DNA replication inhibitors, indicating checkpoint-dependent pathways control. Checkpoint rescue of IE requires p53, and absence mimicked by proteasomal inhibition in a p53-dependent manner. Cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitor p21 is downstream of p53, suggesting a role in IE repression in S/G. Treatment with CD inhibitor roscovine alleviates repression independently of p53. Importantly, CD inhibition also overcomes block in quiescent, latent NT2 cells. Timely CD activity secures cycle specificity of HCM IE program and prevents establishment of latent state.
Researchers investigated the role of innate immune responses in dendritic cells (DC) in facilitating HIV-specific T cell immunity in HIV elite controllers (EC), a subgroup of individuals who control HIV-1 replication without treatment. They found that exposure of DC from EC to HIV-1 leads to rapid and sustained production of type I interferons and upregulation of interferon-stimulated effector genes. This innate immune response was associated with induction of SAM1 and LEDGF75 and accumulation of viral transcripts, but was inhibited by pharmacological blockade of reverse transcription or siRNA silencing of cytosolic sensor cAS. Importantly, innate recognition of HIV-1 in DC from EC translated into stronger ability to stimulate and expand HIV-specific CD8 T responses. The study suggests an important role of innate type I interferon secretion in dendritic cells for induction of HIV-specific CD8 cells and may be beneficial for eliciting T immunity against HIV for preventative or therapeutic purposes. Data indicate innate recognition of viral products in EC facilitated by upregulation of cAS, leading to rapid and sustained IFN secretion, functionally supporting HIV-specific CD8 responses. Results suggest previously unknown mechanisms of HIV recognition contribute to cell-mediated control of HIV. Understanding induction of HIV-specific cells by dendritic cells is critical for developing immunologic approaches for HIV treatment and prevention, as most vaccine candidates rely on dendritic for HIV-specific responses.
Researchers have developed a buoyancy-based screening method to identify Drosophila larvae with increased levels of stored fat, resulting in the identification of 66 genes, including Sir2, a sirt family member. Sir regulates carbohydrate and lipid metabolism by deacetylating key proteins, but its role in energy homeostasis under normal feeding conditions is unclear. Knockdown of Sir in larval fat results in increased fat, and genetic mosaic analysis shows Sir restricts fat accumulation in individual cells autonomously. Changes in metabolic enzyme expression in Sir mutants indicate a shift from catabolism. Surprisingly, Sir is upregulated under starvation, but mutants survive better than wild-type under amino-acid starvation as long as sugars are provided. Findings implicate Sir in a pathway activating catabolic response to amino-ac starvation regardless of sugar content. Characterization of Sir mutants shows excessive fat accumulation, Sir functions in Doph fat autonomously to regulate storage, via regulation of key metabolic enzymes. Studies implicate Sir as key in switch from ingested to stored energy source.
Researchers studied the first embryonic division of 42 nematode species related to Caenorhabditis elegans to understand the evolution of mitotic spindle behavior during asymmetric cell division. They recorded the division of 128 strains from 27 Caenorhabitis and 15 non-Caenorhabitis species and found variations in the degree of cell asymmetry and spindle movement parameters, including oscillation, elongation, and displacement. Notably, these changes occurred without a clear direction in species phylogeny, except for transverse oscillations, which were an innovation at the base of Caenorhabitis genus. Importantly, spindle elongation, displacement, and oscillation evolved independently. This contrasts with expectations based on C elegans studies and reveals unrecognized changes in spindle mechanics. The essential process of asymmetric cell division has been conserved over nemode evolution, but spindle parameters combine in various ways.
Researchers studied the evolution of the Omp regulon in Salmonella Typhimium and Escheria coli, two closely related bacteria with identical Omp proteins but distinct responses to acid stress. They found that Omp mRNA and protein levels are elevated in S. Tyimium at low pH but not in E. coli, due to differences in the promoter regions of the omp genes. The E coli ompR orthologue can be made acid-inducible by introduction of sequences from S. Tyim. The Omp regulon in S. Tyim overlaps with E coli at 15 genes, including horizontally acquired virulence genes E coli does not have. Omp binds its targets in higher abundance when DNA is relaxed, occurring in S. Tyim as a result of acid stress, a requirement for optimal virulence gene expression. The targets do not share a strong nucleotide consensus; O's ability to recruit genes arises from modest specificity for relaxed DNA, allowing cooperation with topology-based allostery to modulate response to acid stress. S. Tyim low pH results in elevated O protein and binding throughout the genome. E coli's O expression is regulated differently; introducing the S. Tyim promoter into E coli results in acid-indible expression. The molecular mechanism of this difference is due to the omp promoter region, Env protein structure, and function.
Researchers have identified a novel effector protein, N, secreted by the intracellular pathogen Chlamydia trachomatis, that targets mammalian histones in the host cell nucleus. The protein, named Nuclear Effector (N), contains a SET domain characteristic of histone methyltransferases and is translocated to the host nucleus via a type III secretion mechanism during infection. In vitro assays confirmed N's enzymatic activity as a histone methyltransfer, modifying histones H2, H3, and H4, as well as itself through automethylation.
