Immunization with irradiated sporozoites is the most effective strategy against malaria liver stages, but the mechanisms behind its success are unknown. Researchers found that CD8+ T cell development requires prolonged antigen presentation. Using transgenic cells specific for the circumsporozoite protein, a vaccine candidate, sporozo antigen persisted for 8 weeks after immunization, despite irradiated sporites' inability to replicate and differentiate beyond liver stages. Persisting antigen was detected in lymphoid organs, dependent on CD11+ cells. Prolong antigen enhanced CD8 T response in several ways: reducing primed cells' exposure time in vivo reduced memory size, fully developed cells expanded in immunized mice but not transferred naïve, and primed naïve cells, including thymic emigrants, to become effector cells eliminating parasites. Optimal CD8 immunity against malaria liver stages depends on prolonged sporite antigen presentation.
Researchers investigated the potential of polymyxin B (pol) as a treatment for leishmaniasis, a disease caused by Leishmania parasites, by encapsulating it in biodegradable nanocarriers (PBCPs) to enhance its internalization in infected macrophages. PBCPs were fabricated using anionic polymerization and characterized by Dynamic Light Scattering, size, ζ-potential, Nanoparticle Analysis, size/concentration, diffusion rate, drug release, and in vitro cell viability. Nanoparticles coated with pol (PBCp-pol) had a size of 261.5 ± 25.9 nm, low polydispersity index (PDI) of 1.79 ± 0.17, and stable for 45 days. The drug release from Pp was 6 times slower than free pol, favoring a prolonged release profile. In vitro, pol alone reduced amastigote infection in macrophages at 10 μg/mL without complete elimination at higher concentrations, limiting its application. The nanocar P also presented leishicidal effect surpassing pol activity, but no antimicrobial activity was detected. Pol maintained activity against E. coli, Pseudomonas, and Kleiella, adding antimicrobial properties to nanoparticles. This delivery system demonstrated antileishial and antimicrobial properties for the first time, aiding conitant prevention/treatment of secondary infections caused by cutaneous L. amazon, ending disfiguring or disabling lesions.
This study investigated prognostic factors for death from visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in Belo Horizont, Brazil, using data from the Reportable Disease System-SIN (Brazilian Ministry of Health) from 2002-2009. The analysis identified variables associated with a higher risk of death from VL were weakness, Leishmaniasis-HIV co-infection, and age ≥60 years in Model 1 (2002-2009), and bleeding, other infections, jaundice, and ≥60 years in Model 2 (2007-2009). A prognostic score was developed using variables from the latest SIN version of ANA (Model 2), with a predictive performance of 71.4% sensitivity, 73.7 specificity, 28.9 positive predictive value, and 94.5 negative predictive value, and 75.6 area under the receiver operating characteristic curve. These findings are consistent with the Brazilian Ministry of Health, which associated death from VL with age <6 or >65, jaund, and co-morbidities including bacterial infections. Leishiasis-H co-infection and other infections can act synergistically worsen the condition of co-infected patients. The study highlights the importance of considering these factors in clinical management to lower mortality.
Researchers studied the regulatory receptor-like kinase B1 (RLK) BAK in plants, which plays a crucial role in hormone responses, innate immunity, and cell death. They identified a novel allele, bak-5, which differentially regulates three BAK-dependent pathways. BAK1-dependent innate signaling mediated by FLS and EFR is severely compromised in bak-5 mutants, but bak-5 mutants are not impaired in BR signaling or cell control. FLS and E have low kinase activity and cannot phosphorylate BAK in vitro, and kinase activity is not required for ligand-induced heteromerization with B1 in planta. The suppression of F2 and E-dependent signaling in bak-5 is due to B1 interaction with the ligand-binding but requires B1 kinase activity. Results show phosphorylation-dependent control of growth, immunity, and death by BAK, revealing differences in mechanisms underlying regulation of ligand and non-ligand RKs. BAK interaction with F and E is not a consequence of detectable phosphorylation, unlike BRI. B1 activity is required for lig-induced formation with B in planta. B1 dictates specificity of downstream signaling, as B5 nearly blocks F2 and E-mediated PT signaling but barely influences death and BR signaling. Heterization with B in innate immunity is targeted by bacterial effector AvrP to block PT signaling. Function of B in death and immunity is independent of BR signaling.
Researchers have developed a new computational approach to model the heterogeneous response of cancer cells to anticancer treatments. Current methods only capture the response in a single cell cycle, but the new approach considers responses across multiple cycles and generations. The method combines time-lapse cell microscopy and flow cytometry data to render the proliferative process through the cell cycle and subsequent generations during treatment. It models the effects of treatments with modules describing the activity of main pathways causing arrest, repair, and death in each phase. A framework was created to apply different modules in each phase and test at the complexity justified by data. The method was challenged with time-course measures in parallel with cytometry and microscopy in X-ray treated human cancer cells, spanning a range of doses. A model was built combining modules with a strategy fitting all data and platforms. The model provides the first complete in silico rendering of the process following X exposure, providing quantitative measures of G1, S, and G2 checkpoint activities in generations, reconciling radiation effects and new insights.
Coenzyme Q (Co) deficiency caused by a mutation in the Pd2 gene leads to renal disease in mice. Co is an essential electron carrier in the respiratory chain, and its biosynthesis involves a multi-step process requiring enzymes encoded by PD1 and PD2 genes. Homozygous mutations in these genes in humans result in severe neuromuscular disease and nephrotic syndrome in PD2 deficiency. This study shows that kidney disease in mice with a missense P2kd genotype is due to a Co biosynthetic defect. Co9 and Co10 levels in kidney homogenates from P2kd mutants were lower than in controls. Disease originates in glomer podocytes, as seen in Podincre P2loxPlox knockout mice, but not in conditional knockouts targeted to tubular epithelium, monocytes, or hepatocytes. Liver conditional PAlbcre P2loxPlox mice have no disease despite undetectable Co levels, impaired respiratory capacity, and altered metabolism. Data suggest disease manifestations of Co deficiency relate to tissue-specific capacity, with glomer podocytes most sensitive to P2 impairment.
Researchers have investigated the relationship between developmental lineages and phenotypic robustness, a characteristic of life that allows organisms to withstand environmental and genetic perturbations. They found that determinative developmental lineages of protostomes and deuterostomes are robust to cell deaths, with minimal impact on organismal composition. Features such as lineage shallowness, topology, early ontogenic appearance of cells, and non-clonality of cell types contribute to this robustness. Simulations demonstrate that this robustness arose as an adaptation to random cell deaths during development, revealing general principles of determinative lineages and a new mechanism of phenotypic robustness. This has implications for development and evolution. 

Phenotypic robustness is crucial for life, but its mechanisms and origins are unclear. The study shows determinative lineages are robust to necrosis and division failure, representing environmental and genetic disturbances. Analysis of three lineages provides testable hypotheses on lineage organization and opens door to characterizing complex lineages, an area with theoretical and applied value in evolution, development, and carcinogenesis. Findings reveal a new mechanism of phenotypic robust and its evolutionary origin, distinct from previously studied mechanisms acting at subcell or cellular levels. Lineage robust manifests at supracellular level, unique to multicellular organisms. Ontogenesis contributes to phenotyp robust, especially in species with fixed cell fate. Lineage robust with regulative development complements sub and cellular mechanisms against environmental and genetic perturbations common in nature.
Researchers have developed EmbryoPhen, an open-source high-throughput platform for phenomics in aquatic embryos. This platform consists of an Open Video Microscope (OpenIM) that captures high-resolution videos of multiple embryos under controlled environmental conditions, and a Python package Embryo Vision (EmbCV) that extracts phenomic data for morphological, physiological, and behavioral traits during embryonic development. EmbryoPhen demonstrates its broad applicability in assessing chronic, acute, and multistress responses to environmental changes in temperature and salinity in over 30 million images of 600 embryos of two species with different development patterns. The platform can acquire and process data capturing functional, temporal, and spatial responses in the earliest, most life stages, potentially changing those studying development and phenomics widely. EmbryoCV extracted phen-level data from 95% of 30 million images acquired, producing high-dimensional data describing morphological, physiological, and behavioral responses. EmbryoPhen is versatile, demonstrated in a range of experimental designs from 2-week to 24 experiments, and applied to two species. EmbCV is a package for automated analysis of video to extract and integrate large data to biologically relevant phen-level measurements. OpenIM can images of numbers developing at different scales. The resultant sequence can visualize short-term changes in physiology and behavior. EmbPhen can whole-organism responses with scale, diversity and quality to study embryonic in phenomics, comparing molecular technologies.
Researchers have investigated the metabolic changes that occur in the malaria parasite Plasium during its life cycle in the mosquito and human host. They found that the parasite's metabolism changes from a glycolytic to tricarboxylic acid (TCA) metabolism in the mosquito stages. Using stable isotope labeling, metabolomics, and genetics, they mapped stage-specific changes in Plasium berghei carbon metabolism and determined the significance of these changes on parasite survival in the blood and mosquito stages. Glutamine serves as the primary input into T metabolism in both asexual and sexual stages and is crucial for gametogenesis. Glut catabolism and key reactions in intermediary metabolism and CoA synthesis are essential for ookin tooc transition in the mosquito. These findings extend knowledge of Plium metabolism and suggest possible targets for transmission-blocking strategies. They also highlight metabolic differences between Plium species not anticipated by genomics or transcriptomics, emphasizing the importance of integrating metabolomics with other platforms for drug discovery and design.
Researchers have identified a common motif in biological signaling pathways, known as inherent feedforward loops (ILFs), which enable cells to differentiate between pulsatile and sustained signals in regulating gene expression. These loops simultaneously activate an output and an inhibitor of the output, allowing for temporal adaptation and desensitization to sustained inputs. This property distinguishes signals with varying temporal profiles. A quantitative modeling study examined the ILFs ability to process oscillatory signals, revealing two constraints: kinetics of IL components dictate the input range for decoding pulsatile dynamics, and a match between network parameters and signal characteristics is required for optimal counting. 

ILFs are found downstream of divergent signals in amoeba and mammalian cell differentiation, despite differences in dynamics. The motif's ability to respond to transient but not sustained signals relies on temporal adaptation response to sustained signals. The model provides insights into natural decoding systems and network perturbations. 

ILFs are ideal for decoding oscillatory signals, reacting to foldanges rather than absolute input concentration. They are a core topology driving temporal adaptation, generating a pulse response to sustained.
Researchers have developed improved methods for the quantification, propagation, purification, and long-term storage of Orientia tsutsamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, a leading cause of serious febrile illness in rural Southeast Asia. The bacterium is an obligate intracellular and can only be cultured in mammalian cells, requiring specific methodologies for propagation and analysis. A clinical isolate of O. tsamushi was grown in mouse embryonic fibroblast (L) cells and bacterial growth measured using O. tsam-specific qPCR. Conditions for improved viability and growth were monitored in terms of effect on bacterial number after cultured in mammalian cells. A standardised method for comparing viability of O. tsam after purification and propagation under various conditions was presented. Data supported improved techniques for propagation, purification, and storage of this organism, useful for clinical isolation and in vitro biology experiments. 

Orientia tsam is a leading cause of CNS infections in hospital in Laos and associated with miscarriage and poor neonatal rates in pregnancy. It is an obligate Gram-negative bacterium, member of Ricketiaceae, differing from Ricketia in genome, morphology, and phenotyp properties. The study aimed to develop experimental toolkit for research into neglected pathogen O. tsam. A simplified assay was used to compare growth across conditions, useful for comparing antibiotic sensitivity isolates. Optimised assay showed growth of O. tsam was quantified by extracting DNA and measuring genome copy number using primer/probe specific to O. tsam 47Da single gene. This is a concern as culture cannot be used diagnostic tool, reducing isolates for research diversity and resistance. Methods were set to improve quant, propagation, purification, long-term of O tsam
A study investigated the safety and efficacy of the antiparasitic drug praziquel (PQ) in children aged 1-5 years, who are currently excluded from schistosomiasis control programs due to lack of P data on its safety in this age group. Zimbabwean children aged 1-5 (n=104) were treated with P tablets and side effects were assessed by questionnaire administered to caregivers within 24 hours of treatment. Efficacy was determined 6 weeks post-treatment through schosome counts in urine. Pre-treatment S haobium infection in 1-5 olds was 14.6 eggs/10 ml and prevalence was 21%. Of 104 children, 3.8% reported side effects within 24 hours of P treatment, including stomach ache, loss of appetite, lethargy, and inflammation. P treatment significantly reduced schosome levels in 1-5 olds with an egg reduction rate (ERR) of 99% and cure (CR) 92%, comparable to 6-10 olds where ERR was 96 and CR 67%. P is safe and efficacious in 1-5 olds as in 6-10 olds, the drug of choice for schosomiasis control.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide functional screen in Drosophila to identify genes involved in Ras-driven epithelial tumorigenesis, a common in ~30% of human cancers. They discovered multiple evolutionarily conserved pathways and novel tumor suppressor genes, including Tetrasin 29b, which regulates EGFR signaling, epithelial architecture, and restrains tumor growth and invasion. Human orthologs of the hits were significantly downregulated in thousands of primary tumors, revealing prognostic markers for epithelial tumors. Among the top 100 candidate genes, 80 were validated in secondary Drosila assays, including known and novel genes that cooperate with Ras-driven tumenesis. Low expression of confirmed hits correlated with KRAS12 mutation and poor prognosis in pancreatic cancer. The study provides a starting point for identifying novel genes and pathways in tumor suppression and metastasis of Ras-driven epithelial cancers.
Researchers have identified a gene, wtf13, in the fungus Schizosaccharomyces pombe, as a meiotic driver that kills spores that do not inherit it by producing a diffusible poison and spore-specific antidote. They found that another gene, wtf-2, arose in the lab and encodes an antidote that rescues only spores that inherit it, selfishly gaining transmission advantage while dampening w13 drive. This establishes a novel paradigm for meiotic suppressors and provides insight into drive systems. Four w genes were previously identified as meiotic drivers in different S. pombe isolates, all killing spores that do not inherit them. At least one, w4, causes drive by poison and antidote mechanism. The w13 antidote rescues spores that inherit w13. The researchers predicted w-2 would act similarly, rescuing only spores that inherit it. This is a departure from prevailing hypothesis that suppressors indiscriminately rescue gametes. Three intact w genes failed to cause drive, suggesting some encode antidotes that act as suppressors. The study shows w13 is poison-antoteiotic driver and w-2 encodes protein suppressing w13 via molecular mimicry of w13 antidote. Results are consistent with an ancestral w gene being dual-transcript-iotic driver. Duplications of this driver to unlinked loci could be selected for driving and protecting from ancestral poison.
Researchers have developed an algorithm to predict gene expression levels in individuals based solely on their genetic information, specifically single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the vicinity of the gene. The algorithm was trained on expression and genotype data from a set of individuals and tested on unseen individuals from different populations, showing robust predictions that agreed between training and test sets. Although the number of predicted genes was relatively small, the predictions were robust, indicating that genetic factors such as environment and sequence variation were ignored. An extension of the algorithm incorporated heterogeneous genomic annotations to weigh the importance of SNPs, assigning higher weights to those near genes and regions with high GC content, improving predictions. Predicted genes had higher expression and variability across individuals, providing insight into characteristics of genes that can be predicted from genetic variation. The algorithm performed well even when trained on data from different populations than the predicted individuals, suggesting shared sequence variation across populations may be difficult to capture using only same population data. Gene expression variation plays a role in disease susceptibility and phenotypes, with some linked to genetic variation among individuals. A goal is to predict expression changes based on genetic variation.
Researchers investigated the competitive interactions between virulent and avir clones of Plasmodium chaudi in mice using dynamical Bayesian inference. They tested whether suppression of avir clone AS by vir clone AJ was due to clone-specific differences in immune clearance of meroites and parasitized red blood cells (RBCs), loss of meroites and parasitized RBCs, RBC preference, R infection rate, burst size, and within-R interference. Models were parameterized and fitted to experimental data, revealing that only the ratio of background loss of meroites to invasion of mature RBCs was clone-specific. This ratio was the same in single-clone infections but different between clones in mixed infections, largest in immunocompetent and smallest in immunodef mice. Suppression was alleviated in immunodef mice. Suppression occurred early in infection, before peak parasitemia. Results suggest innate immune clearance of mites most likely mediates competitive interactions between virulent and avir clones. In mixed infections, an interaction between clones and innate response induces changes in clearance of mites. This interaction is unknown, but future refinement of model with other datasets may reveal it.
Researchers have proposed a new model, Origin-Dependent Inverted-Repeat Amplification (ODIR), to explain the generation of interstitial inverted duplications, a type of genetic variation that occurs when a segment of DNA is copied and inserted back into the genome in reverse orientation. This model suggests that replication errors at existing short, interrupted inverted repeats in the genome create an extrachromosomal, autonomously replicating dimer, which integrates into the genome through homologous recombination, creating an inverted duplication without losing distal chromosomal sequences. To test this, researchers used in vitro and in vivo approaches in yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. They found that the proposed replication error, where leading and lagging strands are ligated to create a closed fork, can occur in vitro at short interrupted repeats. This results in a hairpin-linear duplex that replicates in vivo to create an inverted dimer plasmid, which integrates into the genome through homolog recombination, creating an inverted duplication. This model can also explain human de novo inverted amplicons with 2:1 mixture of sequences from homologues, a feature not explained by previous models.
Researchers investigated the process of translation initiation in cells infected with the influenza virus. They found that the virus can initiate translation at non-canonical start codons in response to stressful stimuli in mammalian cells, and that viral and anti-viral responses alter translation initiation sites, leading to production of novel epitopes. The study systematically analyzed the extent of alternate initiation in cells infected with influenza and used ribosome profiling with the inhibitor lactomycin to experimentally delineate initiation sites in a human epithelial cell line. They identified several candidate sites of alternate initiation in influenza mRNAs, all occurring at AUG codons downstream of canonical codons. One of these sites truncates 14 amino acids from the N-terminus of the N neuraminidase protein, resulting in loss of its cytoplasmic tail and transmembrane domain. The truncated neuraminase is expressed on the surface during infection, enzymatically active, and conserved in N1 lineages. No globally higher levels of alternate initiation on host transcripts were detected upon infection or antiiral response, but a subset induced by antiiral was enriched for alternate sites. The study maps the landscape of initiation during influenza infection and sheds light on evolutionary forces shaping this landscape.
Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHE) causes severe diarrhea and potentially fatal hemolytic uremic syndrome, a disease with no effective treatment or prophylaxis. HE and other enteric pathogens, such as enterogenic E. coli (EPEC), Salmonella, Shella, and Yersinia, utilize a type III secretion system (TSS) to inject virulence effectors into host cells. This study presents evidence that E. coli O157:H7 nH and nH2 genes encode TSS effectors that bind human ribosomal protein 3 (R3), a subunit of nuclear factor kappa-light-enhancer of activated B (NF) transcription complexes. nH and n2 localize with R3 in cytoplasm, not nuclei. The N-terminal of n and n was required for binding to N-terminus R3. n and n are autophosphorylated/Thr protein kinases, but binding R3 is independent of kinase activity. n repressed transcription of R3/NF-dependent reporter, but not R-independent reporters. In contrast, n stimulated R-dependent, as well as AP-1 reporter. A region of n (40-45) is responsible for inhibitory activity toward R3. Deleting n from E. O:H produced hypervulent phenotype in gnotic pig model Shiga toxin E infection. This suggests n disrupts host immune responses by binding cofactor host transcription complexes.
Researchers have developed a novel approach to model transcription factor (TF) binding to DNA, called feature models (FMs), which improves upon the traditional position-specific scoring (PS) method that assumes independence between binding positions. FMs use log-linear models to represent TF binding specificities, where each feature can span multiple positions, capturing complex dependencies and higher-level features. A mathematical formulation and algorithm for learning features from binding data were devised. A discriminative finder was developed to discover new FMs enriched in target sequences compared to background. Evaluation on synthetic and chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) data showed FMs explain TF binding better than PSMs. FMs were applied to high-throughput ChIP data from mouse and human, revealing features present in binding specificities of mouse and human TFs, and outperforming PSMs.
Researchers investigated the regulation of the sympathetic nervous system in humans and chimpanzees, focusing on the adrenergic α2 receptor (AD2) gene, which is an inhibitory modulator of the sympathetic nervous system. Knockout mice for this gene exhibit physiological and behavioral alterations associated with the fight-or-flight response. Evidence suggests positive selection on this gene during chicken domestication. The study found lower expression of AD2 in humans and chimpanzees compared to other primates. Using three-dimensional chromatin structure, a cis-regulatory region was identified with accelerated sequences in humans and chimpanze. Active histone marks were present in rhes macaque but not human and chimpanzee, while repressive marks were enriched in human brain samples. This region contains neuron-restrictive silencer factor (NRS) motifs, each harboring a polymorphism. Genotyping analysis of population data showed both polymorphic alleles reached fixation in humans and chimpanze but not bonob, while the ancestral allele was present in macques. CRISPR/Cas genome editing and reporter assays showed derived nucleotides repressed AD2, likely increasing NRS binding. Signatures of positive selection for lower AD2 expression in humans were also detected. The study used transcriptomic, epigenomic, and genomic data to identify regulatory variants responsible for human and chimpan-specific repression of inhibitory modulator of sympathetic activity. Variants arose in population and reached fixation, with one possibly arising recently in humans and chimpanze. Chromatin immunoprecipitation-sequencing data showed active histone marks in macques but absent in chimpanze. Different mechanisms of repression were observed, with DNA methylation in humans and H3me3 in chimpanze. Two segregating variants in humans reflected positive selection for lower AD2 expression. Population and functional analysis in chimpanze shed light on different repression mechanisms. A cis-regulatory regions contributing to human and chimpan-specific repression of AD2 were identified, including a topologically associating domain harboring AD2. Derived sequences were fixed in human and chimpan.
Researchers have studied the evolution of C4 photosynthesis, a complex trait that allows plants to increase productivity by 50% in tropical and subtropical areas, by comparing gene expression in two independent lineages, Cleomeandra and Zea mays, which diverged 140 million years ago. They identified 3,335 conserved genes in leaf and photosynthetic development, and found that genes encoding C cycle proteins are recruited into photosynthesis networks. Despite independent origins, both species use homolog transcription factors to induce C photosynthesis and maintain specific gene expression. A molecular signature associated with leaf photosyn maturation is shared by angiosperms from common ancestor of monocots and dicots. Deep comparisons reveal insight into convergence of complex phenotypes and parallel evolution of transactors underpinning C photosynthesis. Exploiting natural variation can identify regulators and transcription factors shared by C lineages are targets for engineering C pathway into C crops like rice.
During the 2013-2016 Ebola virus (EBO) epidemic in West Africa, the virus spread to Europe and North America, infecting several healthcare workers (HC). To understand EBO infection patterns in different body compartments and develop countermeasures, researchers longitudinally explored EBO-specific negative genomic RNA (neg-RNA) and positive RNA (posNA), including replication (intermediateRNA) and messenger (mRNA) molecules in upper and lower respiratory tracts compared to plasma in a HC infected with EBO in Sierra Leone, hospitalized at the National Institute of Infectious Diseases "Lazz Spallani" IN, Rome, Italy. The study found persistence of pos-R and negRNAs in longitudinally collected lower respiratory specimens after viral clearance from plasma, suggesting local replication. The study aimed to enhance knowledge on EBO features contributing to human-to-human transmissibility and develop effective strategies. Results showed decay of EBO total RNA, neg-R and posNA overtime, significantly different in plasma compared to respiratory samples. Detection of EBO RNA in respiratory merely reflects stability cannot be ruled out; however, detection of pos-R with negNA until day 9 and 10 of stay supports active replication within respiratory rather than plasma-over or RNA stability. Detection of markers in respiratory with absence of detectable negNA in plasma day 5 while negNA still detected in respiratory can be explained active EBO replication in lung. The hypothesis EBO can replicate in human airway is supported by a review of post-mortem examinations of fatal filiral infections, including EBO, showing viral presence in lung tissues and nucleic acids in macrophages.
Researchers studied the Machupo virus (MAC), a New Worldnavirus that causes Bolivian hemorrhagic fever, and its relative Jun virus (JUN), which causes Argentine hemorrhagic fever. They created a recombinant chimeric MAC (rMAC/Cd1-G) expressing the glycoprotein from the Candid1 (Cd1) strain of JUN, which was found to be attenuated in a murine model and protected animals from lethal challenge with MAC. However, a single mutation in the transmembrane domain (TMD) of G, equivalent to the attenuating mutation in Cd1G, was not sufficient to fully attenuate JUN. To investigate the requirement of different domains of CdG for attenuation, they rescued rMAC expressing the ectomain of G from Cd1 alone (MC1), with the TMD substitution (MC2), or the T of Cd (3). All rMAC exhibited similar growth in cultured cells. In mice, MC displayed significant reduction in lethality compared to rMAC. MC was detected in brains and spleens of MC-infected mice, associated with tissue inflammation. On the other hand, animals survived MC and MC3 infection without detectable virus in organs, producing neutralizing antibodies against Cd. The study suggests the indispensable role of each G domain in full attenuation and immunogenicity of rMAC/Cd-G.
Researchers investigated the function of centromere histone 3 (CH3, also known as CEN-A) in Arabidopsis thaliana, a plant species essential for sister chromatid segregation during mitosis and meiosis. To define CH3 constraints, they complemented a null allele with various mutant alleles, each introducing a single amino acid change in conserved residues of the histone domain. Many transgenic lines displayed wild-type growth and fertility on self-poll, but exhibited postzygotic death and uniparent inheritance when crossed with wild-type plants. The failure of centromes marked by these mutations in the histone domain of CH3 reproduces the genome syndromes with chimeric CH3 and CH3 from diverged species. A single mutation is sufficient to generate haploid, providing a simple method for identification of non-transgenic haploid inducers in mutagenized collections. An in silico search identified a point mutation in CH3 in an Arabidopsis line, which, while fertile on self-poll, produced postzyotic and unarent hapids when crossed with wild-type.
Researchers investigated the role of alternative splicing in the differentiation of human embryonic stem cells (hESCs) into cardiac precursors. They modified the H9 hESC line to allow for the selection of pluripotent ESCs by neomycin resistance and cardiac progenitors by puromycin resistance. Exon microarray expression data from undifferentiated ESCs and cardiac and neural precursors were used to identify isoforms with cardiac-restricted or common/neural differentiation patterns. Splice events corresponded to pathways of cytoskeletal remodeling, RNA splicing, muscle specification, and cell cycle control as well as genes with ser/threon kinase and helase activity. Using AltAnalyze, novel changes in protein and microRNA site architecture were predicted to affect function and expression, including enrichment of isoforms opposing cell arrest in ESCs and promoting signaling and development in cardiac precursors. Genome-wide predictions combined with functional annotations suggest mechanisms influencing lineage commitment and ESC at the level of isoforms and regulation.
Researchers investigated the essentiality of the trehalose-6-phosphate phosphatase Ots2 (Ots2) enzyme in Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M. tuberculosis) in vitro and in mice. Trehalose biosynthesis is a potential target for developing antimicrobials against fungal, helthic, and bacterial pathogens, including M. tuberculosis. The common biosynthetic route involves trehal-6-phosphate (TP) synthase O and TP phosphatase O that generate trehal from AD/UDP-glucose and glucose-6-phosphate. To assess the drug potential of TP phosphat, a conditional mutant of M. tuberculosis was generated allowing regulated silencing of the TP phosphat gene O2. The study found O2 is essential for growth of M. tuberculosis in vitro and the acute phase in mice following aerosol infection. However, O2 is not essential for chronic infection in mice, highlighting remodelling of trehal metabolism during M. tuberculosis. Blocking O2 resulted in accumulation of its substrate TP, which appears toxic, leading to self-poison of cells. Blocking TP in ΔA mutant abrogated O2 essential. TP accumulation elicited upregulation of over 800 genes, possibly from increase in RNA stability by neutralization of ribonuclease activity.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease, affects 11-18 million people worldwide. Current treatments have limited efficacy and safety profiles. Research has identified T cruzi proline racemase (TPR) as a potential therapeutic target. Conformation changes associated with substrate binding to TPR expose residues that elicit a mitogenic B-cell response, contributing to parasite persistence and immune evasion. Characterizing TPR conformation states requires long-time motions inaccessible by standard dynamics. Accelerated molecular simulations extended simulation time and captured large motions. Conservation and fragment analyses identified conformation epitopes near transient binding pockets. Newly open TPR conformations revealed, along with closed-open conversion mechanism, advance understanding TPR function. Results and strategy contribute to rationalizing mitogenic B response and future structure-based drug discovery.
Researchers have developed an inducible and reversible gene knockout (iKO) system in mice, allowing for efficient and precise control over gene expression. The system, named iKO, enables the target gene to be turned on or off by treating mice with doxycycline. It consists of two genetically modified lines: a) a knockout (KO) line with a tetracycline-dependent transactivator replacing the endogenous gene, and b) a line with tetrcline-inducible cDNA of the gene inserted into a tightly regulated (TRE) genomic locus, providing low basal expression and high inducibility. This locus occurs infrequently in the genome, and a method was developed to introduce genes into TRE of mouse embryonic stem (ES) cells by recombinase-mediated insertion. Both KO and TRE lines were engineered for high-throughput, large-scale and cost-effective production of iKO mice. As proof of concept, iKO mice were created in apolipoprotein (ApoE) gene, allowing sensitive and quantitative phenotypic analyses. Results demonstrated reversible Apo transcription, plasma levels, cholesterol, and atherosclerosis regression.
Researchers investigated the genetic response of the placenta to Trypanosoma cruzi infection in a mouse model, comparing two different strains of the parasite: K (a non-lethalotropic strain) and V (isolated from a human case of congenital infection. Functional genomics analysis showed that the "secretory granule" pathway was downregulated in both infected placentas, while "inmate immune response" and "response to interferon-gamma" pathways were upregulated in V infection but not K. Gene set enrichment analysis revealed downregulation of metabolic and macromolecular transport processes in infected placentas, with opposite regulation of signaling pathways in V and K groups. The V strain showed stronger tropism to the placental organ, detected by parasite DNA and RNA. This study is the first to describe the genetic response of the placental environment to T cruz infection, suggesting a strong parasite-dependent immune response that may prevent congenital transmission.
Sindbis virus (SINV) polyarthritis, also known as Ockbo disease in Sweden and Pog disease in Finland, has been recognized in northern Europe for approximately 50 years. The virus is primarily found in tropical and subtropical regions, but has been suggested to cause recurring outbreaks in northern Europe. A seven-year cycle of SINV outbreaks has been reported, based on human cases. To identify an objective outbreak signal, mosquito abundance and SINV prevalence in vectors from an endemic area in central Sweden were evaluated. Mosquitoes from the Riveräl floodplains were collected in 2001, 2002, and 2003 and assayed for virus on cell culture. Obtained isolates were sequenced and nucleotide sequences analyzed using Bayesian clade and joining analysis. One SINV strain was recovered in 2001, four in 200, and 15 in 200, with increased infection rates in both enzotic and bridge vectors in 200. Maximum likelihood infection rates were 1.0/1000 in enotic Cx torrentipiens and 0.62/100 in bridge Aedes in 200, compared to 0.9/100 and 0/100 in 1 and 0/100 and 0.32 in 3. Sequence analysis showed all isolates belonged to SINV genotype I (S-I). Genetic analysis revealed maintenance of four S-I clades in Riveräl floodplains over years. Findings suggest increased S-I prevalence in vectors constitutes valuable marker for scrutinizing hypothesized seven cycle S-I outbreaks and mechanisms.
Researchers investigated the interaction between coding mechanisms and plasticity in the locust olfactory system, which transforms dense, synchronized spike trains of antennal lobe (AL) neurons into a sparse representation in the mushroom body (MB), a region associated with memory. Recordings in vivo from the MB showed highly specific responses to odors in Kenyon cells (KCs), with typically only a few KCs from the population responding reliably to a specific odor. Different odors induced different responses in KCs. A biologically plausible model explored the possibility of plasticity controlling synaptic weights to ensure KC specificity to familiar odors. Plasticity at synapses between AL and MB efficiently regulated tuning to selectively filter AL output and condense to sparse in MB. Activity-driven plasticity drove specificity, reliability, and persistence of odor representations, suggesting a role in processing and making testable predictions about plasticity at AL-MB synapses.

The study focused on the effects of plasticity at synapses between antennal lobe projection neurons (PNs) and Kenyon cells (KCs) in the calyx. The locust olfactory system is a favorable model for studying interplay of codes with plasticity and learning, as sparseness is a strategy exploited by different modalities across organisms. The study is consistent with recent results supporting pre-synaptic plasticity between KC and mushroom extrinsic neurons in olfactory memory. Intracellular recordings in vivo revealed synapses from KC onto targets undergo STDP on a/−25 timescale.

The locust system is ideal to study interaction of coding with plasticity and mechanisms due to well-characterized spatio-temporal input to MB. In the antennalobe, oscillatory synchronization is a feature of population coding during odor presentation, transient ensembles participate encoding.
Researchers conducted the Stockholm Atherosclerosis Gene (ST) study to identify functionally associated genes involved in coronary artery disease (CAD) development. They analyzed transcription profiles of liver, skeletal muscle, and visceral fat tissues from 66 patients and atherosclerotic and unaffected arterial walls from 40 patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery, resulting in 60 clusters of 3,958 genes. Two clusters, atherosclerotic lesion and visceral fat, segregated patients into groups differing in coronary stenosis extent (p=0.008 and p=0.000). Associations with atherosclerosis were validated by carotid atheros expression profiles. One cluster relating caridosis (p=0.04) and 27 genes relating coronaryenosis (p<0.001) were confirmed. Genes in transendothelial migration leukocytes (TE) pathway were overrepresented in three clusters, referred as atherosclerosis module (A). A-module was found genetically enriched in CAD by 1.8-fold (p<0.004) in independent cohorts. Transcription-factor LIM binding 2 (L2) was identified as A-module regulator, supported by subnetwork analysis, cellular and expression L2, and TE genes in L2-deficient arterial. A-module appears important in atherosclerosis, with L2 in CAD research.
Researchers have investigated the molecular mechanisms of the circadian clock in the cyanobacterium Synechococcus, focusing on the KaiC protein, a central component of the circadian clock. They found that KaiC undergoes different phosphorylation states during the day, but it was unclear which state promotes or suppresses transcription of its own gene, kaiBC. A new model, the TT/PT, was developed, considering four phosphorylation states of Kai and transcriptional/translational feedback. Among 32 tested combinations, only one two-loop mechanism reproduced experimental observations, including effects of knocking out or overexpressing kai genes. Phosphorylated KaiC activates and unphosphorylated Kai suppress kBC transcription. The model suggests peak ratio of positive and negative components of kBC expression determines response to removal or overexpression of k genes. The TT/PT model and two-loop structures found in mammalian clock are discussed. The study supports different phosphorylation states of Kai govern timing of cyanobacterial circadian oscillator and output gene expression. Kai promotes kBC expression and represses it, but unclear which state is involved in activation or suppression. Regulation of kBC plays a role in cyanobacterial clock. In Synechoccus, kA, B, and C genes are adjacent, with kB and C as a dicronic operon and kA with own promoter. kA is rhythmically abundant but not protein. Activation and repression of kBC is accompanied by transcription inhibition of clock genes. In Syoccus, 30-64% of transcriptome is circadian, while kBC and proteins exhibit cycles. Overexpression of kC resets rhythm. Existing reports on k regulation are inconsistent.
A study investigated the distribution of HIV-2 reservoirs in peripheral blood cells of individuals with non-progressing HIV-2 infection. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) were sorted into subsets: monocytes, naive (TN), central-memory (TCM), transitional (TM), and effector-memory (TEM) cells. HIV-2 was undetectable in monocytes and quantifiable in TM cells from 4 individuals (median: 2.25x10^6 cells) but only in TC from 1 individual (1.75x10^6 cells). HIV- levels in PBMC (median:1.94x10^6) correlated with TM (r=0.66, p=0.01) but not TC. HIV reactivation was observed in cells from 3 individuals. CCR5 co-receptor was distributed similarly in populations. TC had lower CXCR transcripts (p=0.002) and higher TRIM transcripts (p=0.004) than TM. HIV-2 reservoirs differ from HIV-1 by lack of monocytic infection and limited TC infection associated with lower CXCR and higher TRIM expression. This sheds light on HIV-2 pathogenicity suggesting mechanisms similar to attenuated HIV/SIV models.
Researchers have developed a new model called the Attention Routing Circuit (ARC) that provides a mechanistic explanation for selective attention processing in the cortex. The model is implemented at the level of individual spiking neurons, with computations for selective attention mapped to specific neuron types and laminar circuitry. It simulates attention studies in macaques and quantitatively matches several forms of attentional modulation. The model demonstrates that shifts in spatial attention result in shrinking receptive fields, increased responses without changes in non-spatial feature selectivity, and that contrast-response functions are better explained by response-gain than contrast-gain. Unlike previous models, ARC unifies forms of attention modulation, consistent with a wide range of data and makes specific predictions. The model overcomes past limitations by providing a unified explanation of attention effects, implemented in spiking neurons, defining attention modulation across cortical areas, comparing to physiological data, and making testable predictions. ARC's mechanisms predict spatial attention affects selectivity without altering selectivity other dimensions, distinguishing it from normalization model. It qualitatively, the model's prediction is that forms of attention modulation are consequences of single selective routing mechanism. A functional mechanism for attention routing is described in a hierarchical model, with biological plausibility demonstrated by spiking implementation accounting for attention effects. The model suggests proportion of neurons in higher cortical areas show modulation, as a result of switching from default to selective state during attention tasks, with magnitude increasing in higher areas.
A large-scale whole-exome sequencing study of 1,734 individuals with atrial fibrillation (AF) and 9,423 controls from the Framingham Study, Atherosclerosis in Communities Study, and NHLBI Exome Sequencing Project found no significant associations between coding variants and AF. The study examined 99,404 common variants and 37 suspected AF genes, but none remained significant after adjusting for multiple testing. A missense variant in SYNPOL (rs262, p.Pro707Leu, odds ratio 1.27, 95% CI 1.13-1.43, P=6.6x10-5) was the most associated variant, located at a known AF locus and in linkage disequilibrium with a prior marker. No significant associations were found between rare variants and AF in gene-based tests. Individuals with AF did not display enrichment for common or rare variation in implicated genes. The study suggests large-effect coding variation is not the predominant mechanism underlying AF, and a variant in SYN2 requires further evaluation for causality. Efforts to identify biologically meaningful variation may require larger sample sizes or populations with large effects.
Between 1990 and 2011, a total of 121 cases of alveolar echoccosis (AE) were diagnosed in Poland, with 83.6% classified as confirmed, 16 as probable, and 22 as possible. The number of cases increased over the two decades, with a mean age at diagnosis of 47.7 years and a male to female ratio of 0.86:1. The disease was fatal in 19% of patients, with a mean age at death of 54.1 years. Aggregation of AE was found in 4 foci involving 9 patients, with 76 cases diagnosed in an advanced stage. The liver was the primary location in all cases, with 24.8% showing spread to other organs. 94 patients were treated with albendazole and 73 underwent surgery, including 15 liver transplants. The study confirms AE as an emerging disease in Poland, the 4th in Europe with over 120 cases, indicating a need for a national screening program in high-risk areas (northern Poland) and public awareness of E. multular and training of primary physicians for early detection.
Researchers investigated the molecular mechanism of the zinc-sensing zinc uptake regulator (Zur) protein in Escheria coli to understand how microorganisms respond to dynamic changes in zinc availability. They solved the structure of zinc-loaded Zur bound to the PnuABC promoter and found that the metalregulatory protein represses gene expression by cooperative binding two dimers to the core of regulated promoters. Cooperativity requires a pair of salt bridges between Arg and Asp that connect independent dimers. Analysis revealed a new member of the regulon, plG, which is directly regulated by Zur in a zinc-responsive manner. The plG forms complexes with one or two dimers with less cooperativity than other regul promoters. Comparison of in vitro Zur-DNA binding at four regulon promoters shows a 10,000-fold variation in binding constants. The degree of repression in vivo parallels this trend, with a 100-fold difference in transcript copy number between wild-type and Δur strains. The number of ferric uptake regulator (Fur) dimers that bind varies significantly, and the thermodynamic profile of Zur-D interactions correlates with physiological response at different promoters. This study supports the idea that thermodynamics of protein-DNA interactions play a dominant role in gene regulation and opens the door to understanding how zinc availability fine-tunes responsive expression across promoters.
Rift Valley fever (RV) is a vector-borne zoonotic disease that causes significant morbidity and mortality in ruminants. In 2008-2009, a RV outbreak affected the whole island of Madagascar, including the Anjorobe district in the highlands. An entomological survey showed absence of Aedes among potential RV virus (RV) vector species in the area, and low mosquito abundance due to unfavorable climatic conditions during winter. Serological and virological signs of infection were not observed in wild mammals, suggesting absence of RV virusRV reservoir. However, three serological and virological follow-up in cattle showed recurrent RVV circulation. A spatial deterministic metapulation model combined with cattle trade network was designed to understand determinants of this transmission. Three scenarios were analyzed: (i) RVV overwintering due to direct transmission between vemic cows, vector absent during winter, (ii) low vector circulation during winter due residual population without transmission, (iii) combination of both. Multi-model inference resulted in incorporating low RVV winter-borne transmission and direct between animals. Predictions satisfactorily reproduced observations, 84% attributed to vector-b transmission, 16 to direct. Results were robust to sensitivity analysis. Interactions between agricultural fields, vector seasonality, and cattle practices are key to understanding RVV circulation in Madagascar highlands.
Researchers investigated the historical and contemporary genetic structure of the Asian tiger mosquito, Aedes albopictus, in the Indo-Pacific region using 13 microsatellite loci and mitochondrial COI sequences from 911 individuals. Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) was employed to test competing invasion routes of Ae. albict within the Southeast Asian/Australian region. Results showed Ae. albict was likely introduced to New Guinea via mainland Asia, colonizing the Solomon Islands via Papua New Guinea or Asia, and the recent incursion into northern Australia's Torres Strait was seeded from Indonesia. A colonized population in the Torres Islands underwent rapid genetic changes, possibly due to genetic drift or a secondary invasion from an unknown source. High genetic structure and gene flow were found between geographically distant populations, driven by human dispersal. The species' structure favors a dispersal pattern. This study provides a wider distribution of the species' range, revealing more spatial structure than previously shown. The invasion history of Ae. albict in the Australasian region was analyzed using ABC. Populations from the Indian Ocean, Fiji, Naur, and USA were not included due to insufficient sampling. COI and microsatellite loci were analyzed using ABC in DIY v2.1.0.0. Populations from Naur, Torres Islands, Australia, and USA, and Asia were included for broader analysis.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in Mwan Region, North-West Tanzania to investigate the effect of Schistosoma mansoni (S. mans) infection on morbidity in 572 school-aged children. The prevalence of S. mans infection was 58.7% with a mean intensity of 207.3 (95% CI 169.2-245.4) eggs per gram. Most infections were light (56.5%), while 16.4% had heavy infections. Girls had significantly higher mean intensities than boys (247.4 (95% CI 189.2-305.6) vs 153.2 (110.6-195.8); P=0.004. A total 30.1% were anemic with no sex difference. Stunting and wasting were found in less than 10% of the population. There was no association between S mans prevalence or intensities and anthropometry, anemia, or spleen pathology in univar or multivar linear analyses. However, in univar analyses, children with S mans infection had significantly lower emotional Peds (95% CI) than uninfected (77.3 (74.5-80.1) vs 82.7 (79.9-85.5); P=0.033 and infected had higher VO2 (95 CI) compared uninf (51.4 (51.0-51.8) vs 50.8 (50.3-51.3); P=0.042. In multivar regression, age, S mans, hemoglobin, and VO max were predictors for emotional PQL while predictors for VO max were PQL, height, age, and hemoglobin. S mans was not retained in multivar regression on VO max. The study found S infection had significant effect on emotional quality of life but not physical fitness.
Researchers investigated the effects of subcutaneous and mucosal inoculation routes compared to the intraperitoneal route on Leptira infection in adult rats. Leptira is a zoonosis caused by spirochete, with wild rodents, including the brown rat (Rattus norvegicus), as asymptomatic reservoirs. Infection characteristics were studied using Leptira isolation, serology, and histological analyses. Lept infection was asymptomatic regardless of inoculation route and caused similar antibody production. Renal colonization rates were 8/8, 5/8, and 1/8 for intraperitone, mucosal, and subaneous inoculation, respectively. Mucosal inoculation was more efficient for renal colonization with urinary excretion than subaneous and induced slower infection than intraper route. These results facilitate understanding of infection modalities in rats, unlike epidemiological studies in wild rats. The intraper route is nonatural Lept infection in rat colonies, transmission details between rats unknown. Natural routes could explain heterogeneity carriage rat colonies same region by Leira kinetics. Lept infection has asymptomatic forms regardless inoc routes (M, SC, IP). Response chronic infections lower than acute, no relation to colonization.
Researchers have identified a novel role for Annexin A2 (AnxA) in modulating the inflammatory response during polymicrobial sepsis, a disease characterized by excessive inflammation, tissue injury, and organ dysfunction. In a sepsis model, An2- mice exhibited increased pro-inflammatory cytokines, neutrophil infiltration, and decreased bacterial clearance, and survival. An2 deficiency led to increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) and IL-17 levels. Site-directed mutagenesis revealed cysteine 9 of An2 was crucial for ROS regulation. ROS was responsible for elevated IL-17 and exaggerated response. Depletion of IL-17 via CRISPR/Cas KO downregulated inflammation and conferred protection in An2- mice. An2 functions as a putative ROS inhibitor in seis progression, with cystine 9 most important for oxidation. An2 may mitigate seis severity by modulating ROS and IL-17 levels. Neutrophils in seis may be a therapeutic target. An2-induced neutrophil infiltration contributes to local and distant injury and mortality in seis mice. IL-17 is regulated by ROS, and inflammation reduced after IL-17 knockdown. Increased IL-17 correlated with ROS in An- mice, and IL- KO inhibited response in seis mice. An2 is an intracellular protein involved in cytoplasmic membrane processes, including immunity, endosome function, and inflammation. Overall, An2 plays a critical role in inhibiting inflammatory response by regulating ROS and IL-17 in seis.
Researchers investigated the role of microRNA-155 (miR-155) in the anti-HIV-1 effects of Toll-like receptor (TLR) stimulation in macrophages. They found that polyinos-polycidylic acid (poly I:C) and lipopolysaccharide (LPS), ligands for TLR3 and TLR4, respectively, decreased HIV-1 infection in monocyte-derived macrophages (MDMs) by abrogating CCR5-using macroageotropic HIV-1 and vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein-pseudyped HIV-1 virions. However, TLR2, T7, or T9 agonists only partially reduced infection to varying extent. Suppression of infection did not correlate with differential effects on CD4 or CCR expression, type interferon induction, or pro-inflammatory cytokine production. Integrated viruses were detected in unstimulated T7 and T9-stimulated cells, but not T3 or T4-stim MDMs, suggesting alteration of post-entry preintegration events. Microarray analysis and reverse transcription PCR found increased mi-155 levels in MDM upon T3 but not T7 stimulation, and mi-155 inhibitor partially restored infectivity in poly I-stimulated MDMs. Ectopic mi-155 expression diminished HIV-1 in primary MDM and cell lines. Poly I-stimulation and ectopic mi-155 resulted in accumulation of late RT products and undetectable or low integrated viruses 2TR circles. Reduced mRNA and protein levels of HIV-1 factors AD10, TN3, N153, LED/p75 were in poly-stim and mi-transfected MDM, and reporter suggested authentic mi- targets.
Researchers investigated the relationship between the circadian clock, light, and plant growth-promoting hormone pathways in Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings. They found that a group of hormone-associated genes are co-expressed at the time of maximal hypocotyl growth, which correlates with the overrepresentation of a cis-acting element (CAT) in hormone gene promoters. This element is sufficient to confer diurnal and circadian expression in vivo. Using circadian and light mutants, they showed that internal phytohorm signaling and external coincidence with darkness are required for wild-type growth. The circadian clock indirectly controls growth by permissive of light-phytohorm transcript levels at the proper time of day. This integration of pathways allows plants to fine-tune phyh responses for seasonal and shade-appropriate growth. The study suggests that the circadian clock mediates changes in chromatin modifications, and the gated model provides a time framework for understanding the relationship between the circadian, light, and phyhorm-regulated growth. The circ transcriptional regulation of the IAA-signaling pathway plays a role in IAA-mediated growth, and the circadian controls the abundance of 90% of Arabidopsis genes. A transcription module associated with growth increase rate is regulated by coordination of internal phyh pathways with external dark-light transition at dawn. The circadian acts upstream of light to gate phyh gene expression in the evening. The circadian and light pathways interact to coordinate biosynthetic, catabolic, and receptor genes from multiple phyh pathways.
Researchers have developed a novel approach to control Chagas disease vectors, such as Rhodnius prolix, by genetically modifying their gut microbiota to deliver RNA interference (RNAi) molecules. They used Escherichia coli HT115(DE3) bacteria expressing dsRNA for Rhodni heme-binding protein (RH) and catalase (CAT) to feed nymph and adult triatomine stages. RH is an egg protein and CAT an antioxidant expressed in all developmental stages. The RNA interference was systemic and temporal. Concentrations of E. coli115(DE) above 3.35 × 10^7 CF/mL produced significant RH and CAT gene knockdown in nymphs and adults. RH expression in the body was reduced by 99% three days after feeding, returning to normal levels 10 days after. CAT expression was reduced 99% and 96 in ovary and posterior midgut, respectively, five days after. Mortality increased 24-30 in first instars fed RH and CAT. Molting rates reduced 100 in first and 80 third instars fed bacteria RH or CAT RNA. Oviposition reduced 43 RH and 84 CAT. Embogenesis arrested 16 RH and 20 of eggs. Feeding 105 CF/mL natural symbion Rhodoccus rhodii expressing RH-specific RNA reduced RH by 89 and oviposition. Modifying insect microbiota to induce RNAi R. prolix may result in paratrans strategy for sustainable control.
A study was conducted to investigate the causes of fever in pregnant women on the Thai-Burm border, where malaria was previously the leading cause of death in pregnant women in refugee camps in the 1980s. Artemisinin therapy reduced malaria incidence, but remaining causes of fever are not well-documented. Pregnant women attending antenatal care with routine malaria screening were invited for comprehensive clinical and laboratory screening if they had fever. Women were hospitalized, treated, and followed until delivery. Convalescent serum was collected on day 21. Outcomes were recorded. Fever episodes occurred in 5.0% (409/8,117) of women from Jan-2004 to May-2006. Malaria was the main cause in 55.5% (227/409). A cohort of 203 (49.6%409) had fever investigations. Arthrop-borne (malaria, ricketial, deng, and zoon disease leptospi) accounted for nearly half of febr illnesses 47.3 (96). Coinfection was observed 3.9 (8) mostly malaria ricketia. Pyonephritis 19.7 (40) was also common. Once malaria pyoneph and respiratory excluded, one-third febr infections were ricket or leptpi. Scr and murine typhus were associated with poor outcomes including stillbirth and low birth. One died with no lab tests. Malaria remains leading cause fever in Thaiurm border. Scr and murine typh important causes poor outcomes. Febr pregnant Thaiurm not malaria pyone or respiratory should be treated azithrom for typh and leptpi.
Researchers investigated the relationship between maternal age and recombination in humans by analyzing over 600,000 genotyped markers in 69 French-Canadian pedigrees. They found a significant decrease in recombination rates with advancing maternal age, driven by chromosome-specific effects, particularly in the middle sections of chromosomal arms and subtelomeric regions. The study suggests that recombination's protective effect against non-disjunction becomes less efficient with age, contributing to higher aneuploidy rates in older women. A model reconciles findings with associations between maternal age and recombination in trisomies. Further analysis of 68 French-Canadian families revealed a genome-wide decrease in recombination rate with maternal age, consistent with previous studies. Chromosome-specific effects may vary among populations due to genetic differences in regulating recombination machinery. Results support this hypothesis, with significant decay on nine chromosomes in the French-Canadian cohort and two in Hutter. Maternal age is a major factor in chromosomal anupidy, but little is known about age-related non-disjunction causes. Recombination initiated in fetal development, but age still influences recombination. Not all trisomies are equally affected by maternal age, and mechanisms may not apply to anup conceptions. Data highlight distinct selective, mechanistic or structural constraints on recombination across generations.
Researchers have developed a novel immunization strategy to induce innate immunity in macrophages in vivo by priming them with interferon-gamma (IF-γ) against Cryptococcus neoformans, a pathogen that causes opportunistic infections in immunocompromised patients. Unlike traditional trained immunity models, this approach generates a memory-like phenotype in macrophages that persists for at least 70 days post-immunization and provides complete protection against secondary challenge in the absence of adaptive immune cells. RNA-seq analysis revealed rapid upregulation of IF-γ and STAT signaling pathways following challenge, with enhanced cytokine recall responses dependent on histone methylation and acetylation and increased STAT binding to anti-fungal immunity genes. This method selectively targets IF- associated genes while preserving TLR and CLR functions for host defense. The study demonstrates an alternative mechanism to induce macroage innate memory in vivo facilitating pathogen-specific vaccine responses.
Researchers investigated the role of Polycomb repressive complexes (PRCs) in regulating gene expression and development in Arabidopsis thaliana. PRs are crucial for transcriptional repression and developmental regulation in both plants and animals. Depletion of PR components causes overlapping and unique phenotypic defects, but the underlying mechanism determining specificity and diversity is not fully understood. The study quantitatively compared trimethylation of H3K27 in Arabidopsis mutants of key PR components. CURL LEAF (CL), a major catalytic subunit of PR2, coordinates with PR1 members in suppressing distinct developmental programs. Flower development genes are repressed in seedlings via non-redund role of CL, associated with LIKE HETCHROMIN PROTEIN1 (LHP). In contrast, embryo development genes are repressed by PR-catal coreunits AtBMI and AtRING with PR-catal enzymes CL or SWINGER (SW). CL context-dependent role corresponds with H3me3 profiles and is associated with differential occupancy of transcription factors (TFs), including MADS and ABA factors. Different PR combinations regulate distinct developmental programs and specificity is modulated by TFs.
Researchers have conducted a high-resolution study on the RNA polymerase II trigger loop (TL) of Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a crucial for substrate selection, catalysis, and translocation in multisunit RNA polymerases. They quantitatively phenotyped nearly all single TL variants, revealing three classes of mutants linked to transcription defects or stress, with distinct residue distributions. Disrupting the intra-TL hydrophobic pocket, proposed for substrate-trigger TL folding destabilization, conferred phenotypes consistent with increased catalysis. Genetic interactions among TL and TL-proximal residues support the funnel and bridge helices (BH) contribution to TL dynamics. The study incorporates structural and phenic data for high-resolution dissection of transcription mechanisms and evolution, applicable to other essential yeast proteins.

The phenic landscape sheds light on TL residue contributions to dynamics, catalysis, and evolutionary constraints. It expands existing mutational studies and can be generalized to most yeast proteins. The study advances a genetic framework to dissect Pol II mechanisms, assessing TL residues in S. cerevisiae under multiple conditions. Data indicate intra-T interactions and TL with nearby domains (e.g. BH, funnel helices) are critical for TL. Coupled structures of folded TL states support a multi-step folding model for catalysis. Many GOF and LOF TL variants were identified, some predicted to confer epist interactions (e.g. F6 and V9). TL is critical for translocation to DNA, an essential for nucleotide addition. Additional TL states are implicated in transcriptional pausing, structural observations, and cleavage. TL's multiple conformations and state conversion are critical for functions. Previous studies demonstrate TL is delicately balanced, perturbations result in increased or decreased activity and altered dynamics. Distinct consequences manifest as LO and G phenotypes in vivo.
Researchers investigated the pathogenesis of rabies virus (RV) by inoculating mice intramuscularly (i.m.) or intravenously (i.v.) with dog-associated DOG and silver-haired bat-associated SB strains. The study aimed to determine if RV can invade the central nervous system (CNS) via hematogenous spread from the periphery. In contrast to i.m. infection, where both strains caused lethal encephalopathy, only i.v. infection with SB resulted in lethal encephalopathy. Quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) showed no significant differences in virus loads in spinal cord or brain after i.m. or i.v. infection of SB, but immunohistochemistry revealed i.v. administered SB directly infected the brain, specifically the hypothalamic nuclei connected to circumventricular neurohypophysis and median eminence. Data suggest hematogenous spread of SB can lead to fatal encephalopathy through retrograde invasion of CNS at neurointerface of hypothalamus-hypysis. This alternative mode of spread has implications for post-exposure prophylaxis of rabies, particularly silver bat-associated RV.
Researchers studied the evolutionary history of the H1N1 subtype of the influenza A virus, which has caused significant morbidity and mortality in humans since the 1918 pandemic. They analyzed 71 complete genome sequences from 191 to 2006 and found that segmental reassortment played a key role in the virus's evolution. Specifically, an H1 isolate from 1947 acquired novel PB2 and HA genes through intra-subtype reassortment, which may explain the virus's abrupt antigenic evolution. The 195 epidemic may have also been associated with reassortant H1 viruses. Intra-subtype reassment appears to be a significant process in the epidemiology of H1 influenza virus than previously thought. Segment reassort between different species can generate pandemic viruses, as seen in H2 and H3 strains in 1957 and 196. The H1 genome exhibited congruent evolutionary patterns, but distinct reassment events affected specific segments. The study analyzed 71 whole-genome sequences from 17 countries on five continents. Few studies have examined reassment frequency in H1 viruses. H1 is thought to experience less antigen evolution than H2, with infrequent vaccine updates. H1 circulated in humans 1917, then 197, had significant impact.
A computational model of the ventral tegmental (V) circuitry and nicotinic acetylcholine (nACh) receptor function was used to investigate the pathway of nicotine's action in the V. The study aimed to determine whether nicotine stimulates dopamine (DA) cells directly through nACh activation or inhibits through desensitization of nA on GABA interneurons. The model illustrated that αβ-containing nChRs on DA or GABA cells mediate the acute effects of nicotine, accounting for in vitro and in vivo data and predicting conditions for direct or inhibition to be the origin of DA increases. The rate of endogenous acetylcholine crucially determines the evoked DA response for both mechanisms. Results suggest the V mediates the acute rewarding properties of nicotine and propose an acetylch dependence for reinforcement. The study used a novel mesoscopic modeling approach extending a population representation of V DA and GABA neurons to describe nCh responses, clarifying the interplay of nicotine's pharmacodynamics and dopaminergic signal in V. Critically, low cholinergic input is necessary for direct stimulation, while high cholinergic is crucial for inhibition to observe DA activity. Experimental results support the role of GABA cells in nicotine's action. The model captures in vitro modulation of excitatory and inhibitory inputs to DA neurons and in vivo emphasizes direct activation of β-containing nCh on DA neurons.
A randomized, double-blinded phase II trial was conducted in Kabul, Afghanistan, from 2004 to 2008, to evaluate a novel therapeutic approach for cutaneous leishmanias (CL) caused by Leishmania (L) trop infection. Two hundred patients with CL lesions were treated with bipolar-frequency electrocauterization (EC) followed by daily moist-wound treatment (MWT) with polyacrylate hydrogel (group I) or without (group II) pharmaceutical chlorite (DAC-055). The primary outcome was time for complete epithelialization. Biops for parasitological and immuno histological analyses were taken before EC, after wound closure, and 6 months later. The mean time for wound closure was 59.1 days in group I and 54.2 days in II (p=0.83). Patients with Leish-positive biops DAC-055 caused rapid epithialization 37.2 vs 58.3 days (p=0.08). Superfections occurred in both groups at 8.8%. Except one patient reccerations 10.2 in I 18.5 II (p=0.158) were confined to cases with high parasite loads after healing. DAC-055 showed leishicidal effect on pro and amigotes. Compared to intraional injections, EC plus M led to rapid closure and lower relapse rate.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide RNAi screen in Drosila cells to identify factors impacting RAS-MAP signaling. The screen led to the identification of 101 validated hits, most of which were previously associated with the pathway. Epist experiments determined the position of individual candidates relative to core components, revealing new factors acting at different steps, including a protein modulating RAF activation. Unexpectedly, most hits worked downstream of ME and influenced MAP expression, consisting of constitutive splicing factors, suggesting splicing plays a role in establishing MAP levels. Two representatives were characterized and found to regulate map alternative splicing. This study provides a comprehensive view of factors modulating R-MAP signaling in Dila, indicating pathway output relies not solely on classical events, such as RAF activation, but also MAP regulation. Additionally, splicing components can impact alternative splicing.
A study was conducted to investigate the genetic diversity of Cryptococcus neoformans/C gatt species in Thailand, analyzing 498 isolates from clinical, environmental, and veterinary sources. The majority (68.9%) were from males, aged 37.97 years, with 88.5% of C neoans and 37.5 of gatt from HIV patients. U5-RP and M PCR fingerprinting revealed 94.8% of isolates were C neoans type V, regardless of source. Multilocus Sequence (ML) analysis identified 20 sequence types (ST) in Thailand, with ST30 gatt and ST82,83,137,141,172,173 neoans unique. Most gatt isolates were STII, identical to the virulent Vancouver outbreak strain, indicating Thailand as a stepping stone for global spread. The study found greater diversity and range of molecular types amongst Thai cryptococcal isolates than previously reported. C neoans was common in HIV patients, while gatt in immunocompet patients, consistent with global studies. Environmental and veterinary sampling would help fill gaps. Despite HIV treatment, cryptoccos remains a major opportunistic infection in Thailand, further studies on epidemiology and virulence necessary for management.
Researchers investigated the role of transcription factor (TF) variation in the evolution of regulatory networks across 12 Drosophila species over 45 million years. They focused on the largest class of metazoan TFs, C2-H2 zinc finger (CH-Z TFs, and found that a significant fraction of CH-Z 1-1 orthologs exhibit variations affecting DNA-binding specificities. In addition to loss and gain of CH-Z domains, diverging DNA-contact residues were found in 44% of shared between D melanogaster and other species. These diverging residues, found in 70% of D melanaster CH-Z genes and 26% all annotated melan TFs, showed evidence of constraint, being conserved across phylogenetic clades and evolving slower than diverging residues. Variations were rarely found as polymorphisms in a D melanaster population, indicating rapid fixation. Predicted specificities of these domains changed across phylogen distances, suggesting stepwise evolutionary trajectories for TF divergence. Proteins with conserved CH domains were enriched in developmental functions, while varying domains showed no enrichments. The study suggests a subset of dynamic and understudied TFs are a source of regulatory variation in Dophila and metazoa.
Researchers have developed a new PCR (polymerase chain reaction) assay to detect and differentiate between Salmonella enterica serotypes Typhi and Paraty A, the causative agents of typhoid and paratyphoid fevers. These serotypes are difficult to diagnose due to the lack of typing sera in some cases and the need for culture. The new assay targets a family of DNA sequences called CRIS (clustered regularly interspaced palindrom repeats) that are specific to each serotype. The conventional multiplex PCR and EvaGreen real-time PCR assays were validated on 188 serotype Typhi and 74 ser Paraty A strains from diverse origins and time periods, and 70 strains of other bacteria including 29 Salmonella and 38 other species. The assays showed 100% sensitivity and specificity. The CRIS targets can be used to develop assays for clinical samples with modifications. The serotype PCRs facilitate rapid and accurate identification in clinical and public laboratories with PCR access. A unique conserved region of the Salmonella genome was identified for each serotype, demonstrating stability and specificity in a large collection of strains. CRPR regions can be used for specific PCR development of Salmonella serotypes with unique spacers.
Researchers investigated the role of Notch signaling in the differentiation of CD4+ T helper 1 (Th1) cells during infection with Leishmania major, a protozoan parasite. Notch receptors Not1 and Not2 are expressed on CD4 T cells, but their implication in Th1 differentiation is not well understood. Mice with T-cell specific deletion of Not1, Not2 or both (Not2CD4) were infected with Leish major. Not2CD mice on C57/6 background developed unhealing lesions and uncontrolled parasitemia, correlating with impaired IFN secretion by lymph node CD T cells and increased IL-5 and IL-13 cytokines. Single inactivation of Not1 or Not in T cells was resistant to infection and developed a Th1 response, showing CD T expression of Not or Not is redundant in Th differentiation. Not signaling is required for IF secretion by Th cells, independent of CSL/RBP, major effector of Not, since infected mice with R deletion in T were able to develop IF Th cells, kill parasites and heal lesions.
A study investigated whether pre-existing Schistosoma mansoni infection increases susceptibility to systemic SHIV C infection in rhes macaques after mucosal exposure. Two groups of rhes macques, one infected with the parasitic worm and the other not, were challenged with decreasing doses of R-tropic clade C simian immunodeficiency virus (SH-C). Systemic infection occurred in parasitized rhes at viral doses that remained sub-infectious in normal hosts, with a 50% infectious dose 17-fold lower in parasitized compared to controls (P < 0.001). Coinfected rhes had higher peak viral loads than controls (P < 0.001) and increased viral replication in CD4 central cells (P = 0.03). This is the first evidence that schosomias significantly increases risk of de novo virus acquisition, suggesting control of helth infections may be a public health intervention to decrease HIV-1 spread.
