A biophysical model of cortical cholinergic modulation demonstrates how changes in neural excitability and network structure create distinct functional regimes: localized, asynchronous, traveling, and synchronous. These regimes qualitatively match experimentally observed cortical activity during slow wave sleep (SWS), REM, and waking states. During SWS, traveling patterns of activity occur in the cortex, while in other states, stationary patterns do. The model consists of Hodgkin-Hux type neurons with M-current regulated by acetylcholine (ACh). Regulation of ACh level accounts for dynamical changes between regimes. Reduction of this current recreates reduction in spike-frequency adaptation (SFA) and shift from type 2 to type 1 phase response curve (PRC) observed in presence of A. When FA is minimal (waking or REM state, high A), patterns are localized and easily pinned by network inhomogeneities. When FA is present (decreasing A), traveling of activity arise. Further decrease A leads to high synchrony within waves. The level of A determines network sensitivity to heterogeneity. These regimes have functional significance: stationary may encode external input as memory, while traveling could lead to regularization. Experiments show in vivo stimulation cholinergic induces transition from WS to REM activity. Low ACh in model creates waves of high frequency states and quiet down, reminiscent of SWS. EEG analysis identifies slow S as traveling from frontal to posterior. Our results indicate large spatio-temporal dynamics by A mediated S and networks highly excitable responsive to heterogene.
Researchers investigated the impact of mutations in the Toll-like receptor (TLR) pathway on the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC). They analyzed whole-genome sequencing data from 171 EAC patients and found that non-synonymous mutations affected the TLR pathway in 25/171 (14.6%) of tumors. TLR mutant cases were associated with more proximal and metastatic disease, indicating clinical significance of these mutations. Rare mutations were identified in Barrett's esophagus samples. The findings were validated in an external EAC dataset with non-syn TLR pathway mutations in 33/149 (22.1%) tumors. TLR4 was the most mutated gene with eleven in 10/171 (5.8%) E tumors. TLR mutants E439, S, I, F, and R were confirmed to have impaired reactivity to bacterial lipopolysaccharide with marked in luciferase reporter assays. The study suggests that TLR genes are recurrently mutated in E and TLR mutations may play a role in disease in a subset of patients.
Researchers investigated the role of Hes in taste cell differentiation in mice by combining in silico and in vivo analyses. They found that Hes colocalized with taste receptor molecules (TRMs) in developing circumvallate papillae (CVP) and used computational analysis to identify Hes as a common regulatory factor for TRM transcription. Expression analyses revealed decreased nuclear Hes correlated with type II taste cell markers. Hes−/− mutants displayed over 5-fold more TRM-immunactive cells than wild-type littermates. The study suggests Hes plays a role in orchestrating taste cell differentiation in developing buds.
Researchers investigated the interaction between ethylene and auxin in rice seedling root development, a process distinct from dicot Arabidopsis. They found that transcriptional activation of OsIL on YUC8RE7 and indole-3-pyric acid (IPA)-dependent auxin biosynthesis is required for ethylene-inhibited root elongation. Using a YUC activity inhibitor, which regulates auxin biosynthesis via conversion of IPA to indole-3-acetic acid (IAA), they showed ethylene-inhibited primary root elong is dependent on Y-based auxin biosynthesis. A rice ethylene-insensitive mutant, rein-1, was identified with Y8RE7 truncated at its C-terminus, resulting in reduced auxin biosynthesis and enhanced ethylene sensitivity in roots. Y8RE catalyzed IPA to IAA conversion, with C-terminal truncation reducing enzymatic activity, indicating YRE is required for IPA-dependent auxin biosynthesis and eth-inhibited elong in rice seedlings. Ethylene induced YRE expression and promoted auxin accumulation in roots, while low IAA rescued eth response in rein-1, demonstrating eth-in elong depends on IPA-dependent auxin biosynthesis. Genetic studies revealed YRE-mediated aux biosynthesis functions downstream of OsIL, directly activating YRE expression.
A nationwide epidemiological study in Saudi Arabia investigated the trend of non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NT) diseases, which are reportedly increasing globally. The study collected 527 isolates over 24 months and identified 34 NT species, including 17 rare ones, with M. simiae (22.6%), M. fortuitum (18.1%), and M. absus (17.8%) being predominant. New cases of M. riyense, a rare species, were also found. The study showed rare events like mycobacteremia, abscess, peritonitis, and ascites caused by M. wolii, M. hatic, M. duii, and M. monence. Diabetes and previous tuberculosis history were risk factors associated with NT diseases. NT disease and pathogen diversity is a challenge in Saudi Arabia. A plan for mycobacterial control is needed. Globally, pulmonary and extrapul infections by NT are increasing, despite immunosup illnesses being a major factor. NT diseases are not considered a public threat, but neglected. Isolates were identified using probe assays and sequencing of 16S rRNA, 16-23 ITS, rpo, and h65 genes. 75.1% isolates were pulmonary with 44.7% clinical significance. 76.5% were Saudi citizens, 34.2% elderly, and 65.3 male.
Yeast cells enter a quiescent state when starved of glucose or other macronutrients, acquiring characteristics similar to those of quiescent cells. The molecular determinants of quies entry and lifespan are not well understood. Using starvation-specific reporters, a subset of the yeast deletion library encoding signaling proteins was screened. Apart from previously characterized Rim15, Mck, and Yak1 kinases, the SNF/AMP complex, cell integrity, and cell cycle regulators were necessary for quies establishment and extension of chronological lifespan (CLS). Quies requires integration of starvation signals via multiple pathways. CL of mutants and single, double, and triple mutants of Rim, Yak, and Mck correlates with carbohydrate accumulation but not cell cycle status. Removal of glycogen and trehalose biosynthetic genes, especially GSY and T1, abolishes accumulation and severely reduces CL. Overexpression of G2 and T1 or supplementation of trehal to medium ameliorates CL defects of mutants. Yak, Rim, and Mck kinases mediate TOR-regulated accumulation and CL extension. Data support metabolic reprogramming to accumulate energy and antioxidant systems are coordinated by Yak, Rim, and Mck to ensure quies entry and lifespan.
Researchers have discovered that the influenza A virus's hemagglutinin (HA) glycosylation plays a crucial role in compensating for fitness defects resulting from escape from anti-HA neutralizing antibodies. By using a method of error-correct viral sequencing, they found that antigen-free propagation selected viruses with mutations that modulated receptor binding avidity through the addition of N-linked glycans to the HA globular domain. This suggests that glycosylation can increase the fitness of antigenic escape variants by restoring optimal receptor interactions, even in the absence of antibody pressure. The study expands understanding of viral mechanisms maintaining fitness during antigen evolution, including glycan addition, and highlights the power of high-definition virus sequencing in revealing novel adaptive mechanisms. The findings indicate that glycos can play a role in compensating for antigenic novelty and transmissibility, a proposed explanation for the discord between high mutation rates and Ab selection in vitro and slow population evolution in vivo.
Researchers conducted a comprehensive analysis of ventricular myocyte models to investigate the phenomenon of rate dependence, a property of antiarrhythmic drugs that prolong the cardiac action potential (AP). They simulated populations of myocytes with varying properties and analyzed results to predict rate-dependent effects on multiple parameters, testing 40 parameters in each model at slow (0.2 Hz) and fast (2 Hz) rates. The study identified various forward rate-dependent (FR) ionic perturbations and specific mechanisms, such as an increase in L-type calcium current FR accompanied by indirect rate-dependent changes in delayed rectifier potassium current. Inward rectifier potassium and sodium-potassium currents were found to be the most likely to produce FR prolongation. Statistical analysis showed models with minimal rate changes in AP shape have little FR potential, while those with large changes have considerable FR. This explains differences between species and ventricular types. The study provides insights into determinants of AP duration dependence and a strategy for designing beneficial antiarrhythmic drugs.
Researchers developed a new method to perform Phenome-Wide Association Studies (PAS) based on ICD-10 codes and biological test results, using a quantitative trait as a criterion. They applied this approach to thiopurine-methyltransferase (TPMT) activity in patients treated with thiopine drugs. Two methods for ICD-10 code aggregation were developed: ICD-10 hierarchy and mapping to existing ICD-9-CM PheAS codes. Eleven biological results were analyzed using discretization algorithms. Data from a French hospital's clinical warehouse between 2000 and 2013 were analyzed, with 442 records representing 10,252 ICD codes and 71,711 test results. Concordance between I-9M PheAS and I-10 codes validated phenotypes. Iron-deficiency anemia and diabetes mellitus were associated with high TP activity (p=0.0004 and p=0.001, respectively). This is the first PheAS using I-10 classification, previously published PheAS were based on I-9-C. Temporal data for thiopine prescriptions and TP assays were considered, restricting analysis to events after initiation. Biological results validated phenotypes from I codes. A method to perform PheAS on quantitative trait using I-10 codes and test was developed, identifying associated phenotypes in pharmacogenomics.
A systematic review and meta-analysis of animal studies on stem cell transplantation in spinal cord injury found that allogenic stem cell treatment improved motor function by 27.2% (95% CI 25.0-29.4) in 5,628 animals and sensory function by 26.3% (95 CI 7.9-44.7) in 473 animals. Heterogeneity between experiments was mainly due to stem cell biology, differentiation, implantation route, and delivery method. Stem cell implantation did not improve sensory outcome in females and was enhanced by isoflurane anesthesia. A dose-response relationship supported biological plausibility. For motor outcome, heterogeneity was due to experimental design and outcome measure. Location, injury method, and immunosuppression impacted results. Reporting bias was higher than in neuroscience but still suboptimal. Motor studies without blinded outcome assessment gave inflated efficacy. Extensive preclinical literature suggests stem-cell therapies may offer promise, but internal validity and bias likely lower efficacy.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to assess the patterns and dynamics of soil-transmitted helminth (STH) reinfection after treatment. The review included 154 studies, with 51 providing STH rates pre- and post-treatment and 42 determinants of predisposition to reinfection. At 3, 6, and 12 months post-treatment, Ascaris lumbricoid prevalence reached 26% (95% CI: 16-43), 68 (95% CI 60-76), and 94 (95 CI 88-100) of pretreatment levels, respectively. Trichuris trura reinfection prevalence were 36 (95 CI 28-47), 67 ( CI 42-100), and 82 ( CI 62-100), and hookworm 30 ( CI 26-34), 55 CI 34-87, and 57 CI 49. Prevalence and intensity of reinfection were correlated with pretreatment status. S reinfections occurred rapidly after treatment, particularly for A. lumbricoid and T. trura. Frequent anthelmint drug administrations are needed to maximize benefit of preventive chemotherapy. Integrated approaches emphasizing health and sanitation are required to interrupt transmission of STH.
Researchers investigated the deregulation of metabolic processes in nonalcoholic liver disease (NAFLD) using a new method called Minimum Enrichment Analysis (MiA) applied to mouse and human omics data. NAD is a spectrum of diseases from simple steatosis to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. Traditional pathway analysis requires predefined maps, which can be biased due to different annotations and cannot capture complex interactions. MiA generates minimal networks (Mi) of reactions for a target metabolite from genome-scale metabolic (G) networks. The authors applied MiA to deregulated Mi and identified key regulators in NAD phenotypes, such as fatty liver and inflammation in humans and mice. Key deregulations were found in cholesteryl ester, cholesterol, and hexadecate synthesis, and regulators of hydrogen peroxide synthesis differed between humans and mice. Specific Mi demonstrated characteristics of NAD phenotypes were identified. MiA is applicable to any G and target metabolite, making it flexible for studying metabolism in any disease or organism.
A model of primacy coding, where the identity of an odor is encoded by the types of receptors that respond earliest, provides a compact and informative representation that can be efficiently interpreted by the brain. Numerical simulations and statistical analysis show that the encoded information depends strongly on the number of receptor types in the prim representation, but weakly on the size of the receptor repertoire. The representation is independent of odor intensity and the information is useful for performing olfactory tasks close to experimentally measured. Interestingly, smaller receptor repertoires can be advantageous for discriminating odors. The model suggests that overly sensitive receptors can dominate the response and make the array useless, allowing prediction of receptor adaptation to environmental changes. Primacy is more useful than binary and normalized coding as the sparsity of representations is independent of odor statistics, unlike alternatives. It provides an efficient representation independent of intensity and helps identify odors in olfactory cortex.
Researchers investigated the neutralization profiles of broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (bnMA) targeting different regions of the HIV envelope (Env) protein. They found that bnMA targeting the V2 apex and gp41 regions of Env were more likely to display non-sigmoid neutralization curves with plateaus below 100% neutralization, while those targeting the high-mann patch were less likely to do so. CD4 binding antibodies also showed this behavior infrequently. The phenomenon of incomplete neutralization was observed in a peripheral blood mononuclear cell-grown virus panel derived from patient samples. Additionally, bnMA were tested against a panel of molecular clones produced in 293 cells and PBMC and assayed in TZ-bl cells, with examples of plateaus below 90% seen in both types of virus with no consistent patterns. The study suggests that incomplete neutralization and nonigmoid neutral curves are possible for all bnMA against a range of viruses produced and assayed in cell and primary cells, with implications for use in therapy and vaccine design.
Researchers developed a computational model of human metabolism to investigate how cancer cells utilize glucose and glutamine to produce energy and biomass. They simulated various scenarios with different glucose and glutamine uptake rates and found that in a subset of proliferating cells, glucose was converted to lactate even in the presence of oxygen. High glutamine utilization decreased glucose oxidation and increased lactate production from glutamine when oxygen was limited. This metabolic pattern was optimal for biomass and ATP production, requiring a branched TCA cycle and glutamine-dependent reductive carboxylation for lipid and protein production, sustained by redox-controlled reactions. Experimental validation in a K-ras cell line showed glutamine-induced metabolic changes consistent with the model. The findings suggest a metabolic reprogramming underlying cancer growth, where competition between glucose and glutamine may play a role. The Warburg effect, aerobic glycolysis, and glutamine utilization are hallmarks of cancer cell growth. A constraint-based approach was used to evaluate metabolic wirings for biomass formation from glucose and glutamine under varying conditions. The study identified conditions promoting cancer metabolic rewiring, where glucose is redirected to lactate in the presence of oxygen. Glutamine utilization decreased glucose oxidation and increased lactate production from glutamine when oxygen was limited. This pattern was optimal for biomass and ATP production, requiring branched TCA and glutamine reductive carboxylation for lipid and protein production, sustained by redox reactions.
Researchers investigated the interactions of the prion protein (Pr) and its mammalian paralogs, Doppel (PrPnd) and Shadoo (Spr), in a cell culture model permissive to prion replication. They found that the three prion family members populate similar molecular environments in neuroblastoma cells and interact with each other. Direct interactions were confirmed between Pr and the neural adhesion molecule lamin, Na+/K-ATPase, and protein disulfide isomerases (PDI), reconciling previous findings. Experiments showed Pr interactions with PDIs extend beyond the endoplasmic reticulum and may play a role in PrSc accumulation. A hypothesis proposes that Pr organizes its environment through binding adhesion molecules with immunoglobulin-like domains, recognizing oligann-bearing membrane proteins. The study suggests biochemical interactions among prion family members exist.
During influenza virus infection, a type 1 pro-inflammatory cytokine response is typically induced, but type 2 cytokines are also produced. Type 2 cytokines are linked to asthma exacerbation, but may also provide protection. Interleukin-5 (IL-5) is a type 2 cytokine essential for eosinophil maturation and egress from the bone marrow. In a mouse model of influenza infection, IL-5 was released into the airways and eosin accumulated in the lungs, particularly during recovery. The source of IL-5 was group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC) in the infected lungs. IL-5 production by IL2 was enhanced by interaction with NKT cells and alveolar macrophages (AM), which produced IL-33. This interaction led to abundant IL-5 production by IL2 and eosin accumulation during recovery. IL-5 was previously reported in the lungs during IAV infection, with a peak release at 4-8 days post-infection. In this study, IL-5 was detected in bronchoalveolar lavage at 4 days post-infection, peaking at 7 days post-infection. IL-5 is essential for eosin generation and egress, and local production in the lungs can cause eosinophilia, exacerbating asthma. IL-5 continued to be produced during recovery, responsible for eosin accumulation.
Invasive non-typhoidal Salmonella (NT) infections are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in children and HIV-infected adults in sub-Saharan Africa. However, the epidemiology and clinical manifestations of NT disease in Asia are not well-documented. This study retrospectively identified 102 cases of NT infections in an infectious disease hospital in Southern Vietnam between 2008 and 2013. Clinical records were accessed to evaluate demographic and clinical factors associated with NT infection and identify risk factors with death. Multi-locus typing and antimicrobial testing was performed on all organisms. 71% of NT patients were HIV-infected, 90% were adults, 71 were male, and 33 reported intravenous use. 26/92 (28) patients had known outcome; HIV was associated with death (p=0.039). Enteridis Sequence (ST) 11 and Typhimium (ST 19, 34, 154) were the most identified serovars. Tyim was more common in HIV-infected (p=0.003). Isolates from HIV-inf patients exhibited reduced susceptibility to trimethoprim-sulfamox than HIV-negative (p=0.037). NT disease is severe in Vietnam with high mortality. In sub-Saharan, HIV was factor for death, majority burden in population HIV-inf adult.
Researchers have developed a method using Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) to identify viral and phage structural proteins, which are crucial for the survival and pathogenicity of viruses. These proteins are difficult to detect due to low sequence conservation, few conserved catalytic sites, and limited data. The ANNs were trained on amino acid frequencies and correctly classified a large fraction of test cases with high specificity and sensitivity. Adding protein isoelectric point as a feature improved accuracy, especially for major capsid and tail proteins. Electron microscopy validated predicted proteins with no similarities to known sequences self-assembled into virion structures. The ANNs are a new tool for identifying phage and prophage proteins difficult to detect by bioinformatic analysis. They will be valuable when in vitro propagation is not practical or possible.
Researchers have identified a protein called interferon-stimulated gene oligoadyl synthase-like (OAS) as an interaction partner of Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSH) protein ORF20. ORF20 is a member of the herpesviral UL24 family, but its function and role in the viral life cycle were not well understood. Three isoforms of OR20 were localized in the nuclei and nucleoli of transfected cells. Quantitative purification coupled to mass spectrometry (q-AP-MS) identified specific partners of OR20, including ribosomal proteins and AS. Both endogenous and transiently transfected AS co-immunipitated OR20, and this interaction was conserved among OR20 isoforms and OR20 homologs in other herpesviruses. Characterization of AS interacting partners by q-APMS identified a similar interactome to OR20. OR20 and AS copurified with 40 and 60 ribosomal subunits and associated with polysomes. OR20 did not have a global effect on translation, but enhanced RIG-induced expression of endogenous AS in an IR3-dependent but IFN-independent manner. AS has antiv activity against some viruses, but its role in gammaherpesviruses was unknown. OR20 and AS expression were induced early after reactivation of latently infected HuLT-rSH.219 cells. Intriguingly, AS enhanced KSH infection. During KSH OR20 mutant, AS-dependent infectivity was lost.
A study was conducted to determine the prevalence and presentation of Lassa virus disease (LVD) in febrile children with and without convulsions in an endemic area of Nigeria. A total of 913 feile children aged 1-15 years were admitted to the Children's Emergency of Irrua Teaching Hospital over a year. 373 (40.9%) had fever, of which 108 (29%) presented with convuls. The overall prevalence of LVD was 13/373 (3.5%; 95% CI 1.9,5%) in feile admissions, 3/108 (2.8%) in Cases and 10/265 (3.8) in Controls. The odds ratio of LVD in Cases versus Controls was 0.73 (95 CI 0.2,2). Only vomiting and bleeding were significantly associated with increased prevalence of L. L is an important cause of undifferentiated fever in children in endemic areas but not associated with convuls in feile children. Its prevalence and lack of clinical differentiation underscores the importance of high suspicion in diagnosis. Screening feile with undifferent fever in endemic for L could be an important public health measure.
Researchers investigated the role of the karri receptor KINSENSITIVE2 (KAI) in drought resistance in Arabidopsis thalian. They found that mutations in the KAI gene result in hypersensitivity to water deprivation, leading to increased water loss, cell damage, and stomatal aperture, and cuticular permeability. Transcriptomic and biochemical analyses revealed reduced anthocyan biosynthesis and hypersensitivity to abscisic acid (ABA) in K2 plants. Genome-wide analysis identified genes associated with these changes, suggesting crosstalk between ABA and KAI signaling in drought responses. Comparison with strigolone receptor mutant d14 (DWAR14) indicated strigones also contribute to drought adaptation, but not through cuticle development. The study suggests chemical or genetic manipulation of KAI and D signaling may improve drought resistance. K2 is activated by binding KAR or an unknown ligand, regulating downstream genes in cuticle, stomatal, anthyan biosynthesis, and membrane integrity, contributing to drought adaptation.
Researchers have investigated the role of insulin signaling in the growth and development of Schistosoma japonicum, a parasitic flatworm that causes schistosomiasis in humans. They focused on the insulin receptors (SIR) of S. japonicum, which they had previously cloned and characterized. Using a technique called biolayer interferometry, they showed that human insulin binds to the L subdomain of recombinant SIR1 and SIR2 produced in Drosophila cells. They then used RNA interference (RNAi) to knock down the expression of SIR in S. japon in vitro and found that, in addition to reduced transcription, the levels of other downstream genes in the insulin pathway associated with glucose metabolism and schosome fecundity were impacted. A significant decrease in glucose uptake was observed in SIR-knockdown worms compared to lucase controls. In vaccine challenge experiments, recombinant SLD and SLD depressed growth, intestinal granuloma density, and faecal production in S. japon in mice with low challenge. These results emphasize the potential of SIR as vaccine candidates against zoonotic schosomiasis in China and the Philippines.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a significant cause of disability in the Pacific region, affecting over 96% of the 1.7 million population at risk of infection. Mass drug administration (MDA) has reduced lymphatic filariasis prevalence, but vector biology complicates the MD strategy in some regions. Obligate mosquitoes provide targets for breaking the LF cycle, but existing methods are ineffective for controlling the primary vector, Aedes aegypti, in the South. Researchers demonstrate that interspecific hybridization and introgression results in Aedes aegypt (CP strain) stably infected with endosymbiotic Wolbachia from Aedes albopictus. The CP strain is bi-directionally incompatible with naturally infected mosquitoes, resulting in female sterility. Laboratory assays show CP males are competitive, resulting in population elimination when introduced into wild Aedes aegpt populations. The findings demonstrate feasibility and encourage field tests of the vector strategy as a supplement to ongoing MD efforts.
A study was conducted in Uram District, Tanzania to estimate the burden of Rhodesian trypanosomiasis (HAT) in terms of Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) and financial costs. Data from 143 patients admitted to Kali Health Centre in 2004 for HAT treatment were analyzed. Direct and indirect costs incurred by patients and health services were calculated. DALs were estimated using the Global Burden Project methods and previous H estimates, assuming 45% under-reporting. The DALs for H in Uram District without and with weighting were 215.7 (95% CI: 155.3-287.5) and 281.6 (95% CI 209.1-362.6) respectively. With 45% underreporting, results were 622.5 (95 CI 155.3-109.9) and 978.9 (95 CI 201.1-187.8). The cost of treating 143 patients was $15,514, with patients paying $3,673 and services $11,841. Indirect non-medical costs for 143 were $9,781. The study shows H imposes a significant burden on rural communities in Tanzania, highlighting the need for location-specific estimates in settings like Tanzania where diseases are focal and concentrated. The re-emergence of H in Uram continues to burden health systems and communities. The study used hospital records and estimated underreporting T. b. rhodesi H in the district. The disease is neglected and not a priority in endemic districts. This is the first H assessment for Tanzania and second for Africa. Previous studies on neglected diseases and zoon have been conducted in Tanzania, including brucellos, showing high burden on health and communities.
Researchers studied mice with a genetic mutation in the Ngly gene, which codes for a de-glycosylating enzyme Ng1, and found that they were embryonically lethal in C57/BL6 background. However, deleting the Eng gene, which codes for another de-glycosylating enzyme that leaves GlcNAc at glycosylated Asn residues, partially rescued the lethality of Ng1-deficient mice. Additionally, changing the genetic background of C57/BL6 mice by crossing with an outbred ICR mice also partially rescued embryonic lethality of Ng1-deficient mice. Viable Ng1-deficient mice in C57/6 and ICR background showed a severe phenotype reminiscent of symptoms of Ng1-deficiency, which were strongly suppressed by deleting Eng in C57/6 and ICR background. Defects in Ng1/Eng-deficient C57/6 and Ng1-def C57 and ICR mice resembled symptoms of patients with Ng-deficiency. These findings suggest Ng1 or Ng1/Eng-deficient mice as valuable models for studying pathogenesis of Ng-def and cytoplasmic ENG as a potential therapeutic target for this disorder. The lethality of Ng1-def mice was mainly due to de-glycosylation function, as it was partially suppressed by deleting Eng. The study characterized the function of Ng gene in mice, consistent with reports on Ng-def human subjects. The lethality of Ng1 mice was partially rescued by deleting Eng or changing genetic background.
Researchers studied how the gene expression of the hunch (hb) gene in fruit fly (Drosophila) embryos is controlled by a maternal gradient of the Boid (B) protein. Gene expression is subject to noise, which can produce variability, but this must be constrained for reproducible and coordinated development. They characterized the dependence of hb mRNA and protein output on promoter structure and transcription dynamics using a model of the hb promoter with variable B and self-regulatory binding sites. Parameters were fit to data from wild-type, self-regulatory mutant, and lacZ reporter constructs. Results indicate that wild-type self-regulatory hb noise is dependent on transcription and translation dynamics, not B fluctuations. Constructs lacking self-regulation show that multiple B binding sites in the promoter play a role in buffering noise. The model is robust to variation in B binding site number across species. This study identifies ways promoter structure and dynamics reduce noise, applicable to many genes with multiple sites, cooperativity, and self-feedback. The results contribute to understanding of reproducibility and determinacy in early development.
Researchers have quantified the strength of selection against Neanderthal ancestry in modern humans by developing a novel method to estimate genome-wide strength and density of selected sites using Neander allele frequencies in modern human genomes. They found that East Asians had higher initial Neander ancestry than Europeans, even after accounting for selection. The bulk of purifying selection against Neander ancestry is attributed to weakly deleterious alleles, which were effectively neutral in Neander but became selected against in humans due to larger population size. These alleles imposed a heavy genetic load on early human-Neander hybrids. The study suggests effective population size plays a significant role in shaping introgression levels, more than previously thought. The approach is one of the first to estimate strength of selection against autosomal Neander alleles in anatomically modern humans. The results enhance understanding of selection's impact on Neander contribution to human genomes and shed light on Neander-human hybridization. Patterns of Neander ancestry in humans are consistent with genome-wide purifying selection of weakly deleterious alleles. The bulk of selection against Neander may be due to accumulation of neutral alleles in Neander, purged by selection in humans due to larger population size. Weakly deleterious alleles in Neander had a profound effect on Neander introgression levels. The study suggests differences in population size and neutral dynamics determine introgression levels across species and genome.
Researchers have investigated the control of stochastic gene expression by host factors at the HIV promoter, specifically the long terminal repeat (LTR), which orchestrates various aspects of the viral life cycle, including gene expression and replication, and establishment of a latent state. In a model of HIV-1 provirus, L-GFPRESat, bimodal gene expression is dynamic, with cells switching between active (Bright) and inactive (Off) modes, contributing to establishment and maintenance of proviral latency. The HIV promoter contains cis-acting Sp and NF-κ elements that regulate expression via recruitment of activating and repress complexes. Mutations in Sp and NF-κ elements were introduced in lentivirus variants, and flow cytometry, mRNA quantification, pharmacological perturbations, and chromatin immunoprecitation revealed significant differences in contributions to viral regulation. Sp sites stabilize both Bright and Off states, promoting gene expression and histone acetylation deacetylation. NF-κ sites exhibit distinct properties, with κ site serving a stronger role than site II. Sp site plays a role in recruitment of p300 and Rel to promoter. Analysis of 362 clonal cell populations with variants showed mutations in Sp sites yield 6-fold higher frequency of clonal bifcation compared to wild-type. Each Sp and NFκ site differentially contribute to regulation, Sp functionally "amp" transcription noise and modulate frequency and maintenance of viral latency.
A comprehensive study was conducted to evaluate the performance of 11 orthology projects and methods, including COG, KOG, Inparan, Ortho, Ensembl, Com, Homene, Round, EggNO, OMA, and two standard methods, bidirectional best and reciprocal distance, in terms of phylogenetic and functional analysis. The results showed that OMA and Homene performed best in phylogen tests and functional analysis with high specificity, while OrthoCL outperformed Ensembl and Inan at lower specificity but higher coverage. EggG provided the largest coverage for broad functional grouping but was not specific for phylogen or detailed analysis. In terms of methodology, Ensembl's complex reconciliation approach was outperformed by pairwise methods in phylogen tests, and bidirectional best-hit outperformed more complex algorithms. The study provides guidance for orthology users, introduces methodology for verification, and sets standards for current and future approaches. Phylogen tests showed OMA and Homene best performance, also in functional tests with high specificity. OrthoCL outperformed Ensembl and Inan at lower specificity but higher coverage. Egg provided largest coverage for coarse-grained functional categories. The study compared 11 projects on both phylogen and functional definitions, obtaining consistent results for objective comparison.
Researchers have developed a computational drug repurposing pipeline to discover new therapeutics for schistosomiasis, a neglected disease caused by parasitic helmin infection. The current treatment, praziquel, is 40 years old and mass administration is leading to drug resistance. The pipeline used phenotyp screening to identify protein kinases as new targets, essential in parasite biological processes. Focusing on this class, the kinome of Schistoma japonicum was elucidated, and updated kinomes of S mansoni and haobium compared to the human kinome. Potential targets of existing inhibitors unique to Schos species were identified, suggesting novel and approved drugs that inhibit them, including bosutin, dasatin, imatinib, vetan, saratin, tidegl, alvid, dinlib, and 22 new targets CHK, CDC, WEE, PAK, ME1. Primary and secondary targets in Schos of approved drugs were also suggested for novel therapeutics development.
Researchers studied the folding and binding mechanism of the pID domain of the transcription factor CREB to the K domain of coactivator CB. Using a topology-based model, they predicted a coupled folding and binding mechanism with the existence of partially bound intermediates. Transition path and Φ-value analyses showed that the binding state resembles the unstructured state in solution, implying CREB becomes structured after committing to binding. The change in structure following binding is reminiscent of an induced mechanism, contrasting with models where binding occurs to pre-structured conformations existing in the unbound state. Increasing the amount of structure in unbound pID reduced the rate of binding, suggesting a "fly-casting-like" process. Inclusion of non-native interactions formed non-specific complexes enhancing the rate of binding but not changing the mechanism. The study explains how unstructured can confer an advantage in target recognition. Simulations agree with a recent NMR study and aid interpretation of binding kinetics.
A systematic review was conducted to analyze the prevalence and intensity of Schistosoma mansoni infection in children in Latin America and the Caribbean countries (LAC) between 1942 and 2014. The study aimed to assess the progress towards the World Health Assembly's 2012 resolution to eliminate schistosomias by 2020. A total of 132 articles were included, providing 1242 prevalence and intensity data points, mostly from Brazil (69.7%). Studies published after 2000 showed 'hotspots' of high prevalence in Brazil, Venezuela, Suriname, and Saint Lucia, requiring updated epidemiological status to redesign national programs. Antigua and Barbuda, Dominican Republic, Guadeloupe, Martinique, Montserrat, and Puerto Rico may have interrupted transmission, but follow-up surveys are needed to verify status. Heterogeneity in methodologies made cross-national comparisons difficult. The burden of chronic infection may persist even in countries with eliminated transmission. Standardization of monitoring and evaluation is recommended, using WHO guidelines. Meeting the elimination goal requires improved epidemiological data by age and sex.
Researchers investigated the characteristics of HIV-1 viruses transmitted during heterosexual transmission by sequencing 167 full-length genomes and generating 40 infectious molecular clones from six transmission pairs. They found that transmitted/founder (TF) variants, selected during transmission, did not have increased replicative capacity or interferon resistance compared to non-transmitted (NT) variants from the same pairs. In vitro assays, TF variants did not show higher infectivity, replicative capacity in peripheral blood mononuclear cells or monocyte dendritic cells, or resistance to antiviral effects of interferon-α (IF-α) compared to NT variants. This suggests that within-host evolution of HIV-1 in response to immune responses reduces transmission potential. 

The study used single genome amplification to assess genetic selection during transmission and cloned TF along with NT variants to evaluate in vitro fitness, including particle infectivity, neutralizing antibody resistance, replicative capacity, and IF-α resistance. Unlike previous studies, this research examined full HIV-1 proteins from both partners and evaluated genetic and phenotypic signatures during transmission. HIV-1 transmission was not mediated by viruses with higher interferon resistance, indicating factors other than IF-α resistance determined fitness in these pairs. In vitro assays with exogenous IF-α, previous studies found subtype B and C TF variants resistant to IF-α compared to chronic or NT from same individual. This suggested selection during transmission for variants escaping innate immunity, specifically IF-α effects.
Lymphangiogenesis and lymphatic remodeling induced by filarial parasites have significant implications for the pathogenesis of lymphatic filariasis. In mouse models without an adaptive immune system, lymphatic dilation occurs due to filarial infection, but severe lymphedema and elephantiasis require an intact immune response in human infections. Human lymphatic endothelial cells exposed to filarial antigens, live parasites, or infected serum showed significant proliferation and differentiation into tube-like structures in vitro. Live parasites or filarial antigens induced LEC proliferation and differentiation. Serum from microfilar positive patients and those with chronic lymphatic obstruction showed increased LEC proliferation compared to uninfected individuals. Differentiation of L into tube-like structures was associated with increased matrix metalloproteases and TIM inhibitors. Gene expression by live parasites in LEC compared to parasite-exposed LEC showed filarial altered expression of genes involved in cellular organization and junction pathways, decreasing transendothelial transport. Filarial parasites directly induce lymphogenesis and differentiation, providing insight into lymphatic pathology in filariasis.
Researchers have developed a method to amplify and sequence the genome of a single bacterial cell using a microfluidic device with 60-nanol reactions. This technique, called Multiple Displacement Amplification (DA), eliminates the need for culturing the bacteria in a laboratory. The device isolates individual Escherichia coli cells and amplifies their genomic DNA in a small volume, reducing nonspecific synthesis from contaminant DNA and primer interactions. The quality of the amplification was assessed by qPCR and compared to standard 50-μl volumes, showing favorable results. Amplification bias was greatly reduced in nanol volumes, providing a more even representation of all sequences. Single-cell amplicons from both microl and nanol volumes provided high-quality data by high-throughput pyrosequencing, demonstrating a straightforward route to sequencing from single cells.
Researchers investigated the dynamics of hantavirus transmission in the Atlantic Forest biome, focusing on the role of rodent hosts and landscape structure. They analyzed 283 rodent capture records and used geographically weighted models to test predictors of havirus host proportions. Results showed that havirus host proportions were positively influenced by landscape diversity, not specific habitat or agricultural type. Local mammal diversity also positively correlated with pathogenic havirus host proportions, suggesting habitat quality may be more important than competition with native species. Sugarcane plantations increased rodent host proportion, while defaunation did not correlate with pathogenic havirus genotypes. The match between hotspots and human vulnerability was 17%, coldspots 20%. Spatial land use influenced havirus hosts across the Atlantic Forest. Findings suggest disease surveillance should be reinforced in southern and southeastern regions with high host and vulnerability. Rodent community interactions with disease may be more complex than hypothesized.
Researchers investigated the role of BCL family proteins in the survival of cells infected with flaviviruses, such as Japanese encephalitis virus, Dengue virus, and Zika virus. They found that the survival of infected cells depends on BCL, a pro-survival B2 protein, due to suppression of the expression of another pro-surival protein M1. Treatment with BCL inhibitors or deficient BCL gene expression induced BAX/BA-dependent apoptosis upon flavivirus infection. Flivirus attenuated protein synthesis, leading to reduction of short-lived proteins like M1. Inhibition of BXL increased phagocytosis of virus-infected cells by macrophages, suppressing viral dissemination and chemokine production. The study also examined the role of BXL in death of JEV-infected cells in vivo. Deficiency of BXL or administration BH mimetic compounds increased survival after J infection and suppressed inflammation. Results suggest BXL plays a crucial role in survival of cells with flaviruses, and BXL may be an antiviral target to suppress Flavidae viruses.
A study estimated the economic impact of canine rabies in Vietnam from 2005-2014, incorporating direct and indirect costs of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), dog vaccination, livestock losses, and disability-adjusted life years (DALYs. Data from interviews, literature, reports, and primary collection were used. The total economic impact of canine rabies was $719 million over the 10-year period, with 92% being P-related costs. Canine rabies created 36,560-45,700 DALs and 914 human deaths were reported, with a rate of 0.11 deaths/100,000, lower than Asian countries. The cost per dog vaccinated was $1.75. Results indicate that rabies impacts in Vietnam are consistent with Asia, with large P expenditures and small investments in vaccination. 

The majority of rabies costs in Vietnam are associated with P and minimal with vaccination. Livestock losses are insignificant, but may be regionally significant. Comparing prevention and control measures, Vietnam is consistent with other Asian countries, spending more on P than preventing through vaccination. P compose 92% of burden while vaccination is 6%.
The Type II Secretion System (TSS) is a molecular machine responsible for secreting fully-folded substrates across the bacterial outer membrane. A key component of the machinery is the secretin, a multimeric outer membrane protein that forms the secretion pore. Researchers have identified three forms of TSS based on the characteristics of their secretin pores, with the Klebsella and Vibrio types being distinguished by the pilot protein that mediates transport and assembly into the outer membrane. The crystal structure of the novel pilot Asp from Vibrio cholera was determined, showing convergent evolution where Asp is functionally equivalent yet structurally unrelated to pilotins in Klebsella and other bacteria. Asp binds to a specific sequence in Vib-type secretins, enhancing secretin assembly, and homologs of Asp are found in Vibrio species and few Escheria Shella with Vib-type TSS. In Vibrio and Shella species with Vib-type TSS depend on Asp pilot to assemble a functional TSS. The correlation between Vib-type secretins, Asp-pilotins, and substrates in diverse bacteria may be due to acquisition of a complete secretin-pilot-substrate unit with the TSS operon. The structure of Asp shows no similarity to Pul-Out family proteins, but biochemical analysis demonstrates binding to S-domain in Vib-type secretins, distinguishing S-domains of Klei and Vib secretins.
Researchers have identified a protein, Omp37, on the surface of pathogenic Leptira bacteria that binds to human elastin, a protein found in skin and blood vessels. This binding is a crucial step in the bacteria's ability to adhere to and colonize host tissues during infection. The study used enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay to test the binding capacity of Omp36, O37, and O47 to various host components, and found that O37 binds to elastin with high affinity, as well as fibrin, fibrinogen, fibronectin, and laminin. The binding to elastin was enhanced by antibodies against O37, suggesting that the protein plays a role in the bacteria's attachment to elastin-rich tissues. O37 was also recognized by sera from patients with acute leptospi and infected hamsters. The protein was detected in pathogenic Leptira but not saprophytic Leptira, indicating its involvement in virulence. The researchers hypothesize that O37 facilitates the bacteria's initial attachment to skin through its strong affinity for elastin, a key step in the infection process. Further investigation is needed to understand the protein's role in virulence and the development of diagnostic and protective antigens for leptpi.
Researchers have developed a model to estimate the probability of broadly neutralizing antibodies 4E10 and 2F disabling the gp41 trimer after cell-HIV adhesion. These antibodies, isolated from HIV-1 infected individuals, recognize epitopes in the membrane proximal external (MP) region of gp41, which are transiently exposed during viral entry. The model calculates the probability of an antibody disabling the epitope before fusion is complete, given the antibody concentration. When 4E or 2F bind the MP, a conformational change results in a stably bound complex. The model predicts that for these antibodies to be effective, the time to disable epitope must be shorter than the time bound in conformation, about five minutes or less for 4E and 2F. The study investigates the role of avidity in neutralization, showing 2F IgG is more effective than 4E, attributed to 2F interacting more stably with viral membrane. The model elucidates parameters determining ability to disable epitopes and extends to analyze neutralization data, predicting dependencies on antibody binding rate, fusion rate, and number of gp bridging virus and cell. Analysis indicates a small number of gp bridges must be disabled to prevent fusion.
A longitudinal study was conducted in three hyperendemic foci in Mali and Senegal to assess the effectiveness of 15-17 years of annual six-monthly ivermect treatment in controlling onchercias infection and transmission. The study aimed to determine if treatment could safely be stopped after 5 years. Skin snip surveys were conducted in 131 villages, examining 29,753 people and 46,600 blackflies for Onocerca volulus larvae using a DNA probe. Results showed a declining infection and transmission trend after treatment, with two sites reaching zero microfilar and vector infectivity 3-4 years post-treatment. The third site, with high pre-treatment infection, showed a decline to low levels 3-5 years post-treatment. Infection and transmission indicators were below elimination thresholds. The study established proof-of-principle onocercias elimination with iverectin treatment in some African endemic foci. The results informed the shift from onercias control to elimination in Africa.
Researchers have investigated the role of the capsid protein VP4 in the entry of human rhinovirus, a non-envelop virus that causes the common cold, into cells. They produced a recombinant version of VP4 with a histidine tag and found it induced permeability in liposome membranes. Studies showed that VP4 forms a multimeric pore with a size consistent channel for single-stranded RNA transfer. The permeability was influenced by pH and similar to that induced by infectious virus. This provides a mechanism for VP's involvement in entry and a model for exploring it as an antiviral target for the picornavirus family. VP is myristoylated at its N-terminus, a feature of proteins with membrane binding properties. Previous studies showed VP's role in picavirus entry and membrane permeability, with mutations affecting virus ability to deliver genome into cells. This suggests VP as an antiral target for the family.
Francisella tularens (Ft) is a highly infectious, Gram-negative bacterium that causes tularemia, a disease classified as a class A select agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Human isolates of F. tularens produce lipid A similar to Francisella novicida (Fn), a pathogen of mice. Researchers identified three enzymes required for lipid carbohydrate modifications: mannose (m1), galactamine (m2), or both (mK). Mutants lacking galactamine (m2) or galosamine/mannose (m) were attenuated in mice by pulmonary and subcutaneous routes of infection. Aerosolization of mutants (m2 and mK) provided protection against wild-type (WT) Fn, while subcutaneous administration of mK provided protection from WT Fn. Infection of alveolar macrophage line by mK induced higher levels of tumor necrosis-α (TN-α) and macrophage inhibitory-2 (M-2) compared to WT Fn. Bone-derived macrophages (Bø) from Toll receptor (TLR) and TLR/4 knockout mice infected mK produced higher amounts of interleukin-6 (IL-6) and M-2 than Bø infected WT. However, production IL-6 and M-2 was undetectable in Bø from MyD- mice infected either. My- mice were susceptible to m infection. The ability of m to activate pro-inflammatory cytokine/chem production and innate responses mediated by My signaling may be responsible for attenuation, leading to induction of immunity by this mutant. Lipid of Francisella differs from classical enteric bacteria in structure and biological activities, with tetra-acyl chains of 16-18 carbons length and phosphate at 4 position removed by L phosphatase. This can be modified by addition galosamine onto 1-phosphate. Activation of innate system and induction pro-inflammatory via My-mediated were essential for clearance m and possibly protection.
Researchers investigated the role of Era, a ribosome-associated GTPase, in Staphylococcus aureus. Era is a conserved across domains of life and essential in many species, but its function in ribosome assembly is unclear. The study found Era is not essential for S. aureus growth, but important for 30S ribosomal subunit assembly. Era interacts with 16S rRNA endonuclease Y and DEAD-box helicase C. Both Era and C are required for rRNA processing and growth at suboptimal temperatures. Era and C also interact with ppG synthase Rel, with Rel positively impacting Era's GTP activity but negatively affecting C's helicase activity. In its G-bound form, Era acts as a hub on the ribosome, directing enzymes in r processing and subunit assembly. The stringent response, induced by ppG, inhibits Era's activity, contributing to slowed growth phenotype. Era's interactions with Y and C are crucial for rRNA homeostasis and growth at low temperatures. Era and C also interact with pp synthase/hydrolase Rel, with rRNA processing controlled in stringent-dependent manner. The stringent response impacts RA-Gase function through Rel's interactions with Era and C. Era acts as a guide for r/rib maturation enzymes to substrates.
Anthrax lethal toxin (LT) induces vascular insufficiency in experimental animals through unknown mechanisms. This study shows that neuronal nitric oxide synthase (NOS) deficiency in mice causes strikingly increased sensitivity to LT, while deficiencies in other NOS enzymes (iN and eOS) have no effect on LT-mediated mortality. The increased sensitivity of N- mice was independent of macrophage sensitivity to toxin or cytokine responses and could be replicated in N-sufficient wild-type (WT) mice through pharmacological inhibition of the enzyme 7-nitindazole. Histological analyses showed LT induced changes in heart morphology of N- mice with rapid appearance of inter-fiber spaces but no apoptosis of cardiocytes. LT WT mice had no histopathology observed at light microscopy. Electron analyses of LT mice revealed pathological changes in hearts of both N and WT mice varying in severity and timing. Endothelial necrosis and degeneration, interocyte edema, myament degeneration, and sarcoplasmic reticulum alteration were observed in LT WT and N mice. Furthermore, biomarkers of cardiac injury myoglobin, cardiac troponin, and fatty acid protein were elevated in LT mice rapidly by 6 hours after injection and reached rarely in mice. Cardiac protective therapy and allopurin had no beneficial effects in LT mice. Surprisingly, nitric scavenger carbox-PT showed some protection against LT. Echocardi on LT mice indicated reduction in fraction following treatment in N and WT, indicative of contractile in heart. The heart is an early target of LT in mice and a protective role for N against cardiac damage.
Researchers have developed a method to introduce targeted gene disruptions in parasitic nematodes using CRISPR-C9. They used this method to disrupt the twitchin gene (unc-22) in the human parasitic worm Strongyloides stercalis, resulting in nematodes with severe motility defects. The mutations were heritable and passed through generations. A similar approach was used to disrupt the unc-22 gene in the rat parasitic nemode Strongyloides ratti. The study demonstrates the applicability of CRPR-C9 to parasitic nemodes, enabling future studies of gene function in medically relevant but previously intractable parasites.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to describe the effects of ribosome drop on translation and ribosome density along the mRNA. Ribosome drop is a phenomenon where ribosomes terminate prematurely during translation, affecting protein expression efficiency, particularly under stress conditions like amino acid starvation or high recombinant protein expression. The model shows ribosome termination leads to non-intuitive ribosome profiles, such as increased density from the 5' to 3' end. Importantly, it predicts ribosome drop's effects on translation are mRNA-specific and quantifies resilience to drop, showing mRNAs with ribosomes are less affected than those without. Among mRNAs without ribosomes, resilience to drop correlates with elongation rate, fast codons being less affected. Genome-wide analysis in S. cerevisiae reveals mRN coding proteins involved in translation machinery, using fast codons, are resilient to ribosome drop. In physiological conditions, mRN coding regulatory stress proteins are less resilient to ribosome drop. The model explains variations in translational efficiency by accounting for ribosome behaviors and mRNA variations in rib density from ribosome studies.
The World Health Organization's strategy to combat soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections in children is based on morbidity control through routine deworming of school and pre-school children. However, transmission persists due to reservoirs of infection in untreated individuals and the environment, necessitating continued deworming for extended periods or until socioeconomic and environmental conditions interrupt transmission. The feasibility of interrupting transmission using mass administration (MDA) is uncertain due to challenges in sustaining high coverage across communities. The DeW3 trial tests the feasibility of interrupting STH transmission, with three years of treatment followed by two years of surveillance. Given reinfection rates, a two-year treatment period is considered adequate to assess bounce or interruption. This study investigates criteria to determine interruption at earlier points. A stochastic individual-based model simulates De3 community cluster-randomized trial, comparing control (annual treatment of children with MDA) to intervention (community-wide biannual with M). Simulations were run for Ascaris lumbricoides and hookworm (Necator american) at six months after last MDA and impact of M coverage to assess likelihood of bounce or elimination. Results suggest clusters should be assessed after two years unless interruption can be ruled out through low coverage. Models indicate homogeneous prevalence following high M across clusters do not allow discrimination between bounce or interruption within 24 months.
Researchers evaluated a conjugate vaccine for cholera made from Vibrio cholera O1 O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) and recombinant tetanus toxoid heavy fragment (Tc). Mice were immunized intramuscularly on days 0, 21, and 42 with OSP:Tc or OSP only, or with or without dmLT, a non-toxigen immunoadju derived from labile toxin Escheria coli. Significant IgG antibody responses to OSP were detected following single immunization in mice receiving OSP:Tc with or without adju. Anti-PS responses were detected following second immunization in these cohorts. No OSP or anti-PS responses were detected in animals receiving unjugated OSP or without immunju, and animals receiving immunju alone. Responses were highest in immun with adju. Serum-OSP and antiPS were detected in mice OSP:Tc with or withoutju, and unconjug OSP. antiPS and vibriodal responses were in all cohorts except immunju alone. No Ig antiOSP or antiPS developed any group. Administration OSPc and adju induced memory cell targeting OSP and 95% efficacy in mouse lethality cholera model. A protectively immunogenic cholera conjugate in mice is described. Development cholera conjug vaccine could induce long-term immunity, especially children poorly respond polysac antigens.
Researchers investigated the interaction between the fungus Candida albicans and the bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a neutropenic mouse model of gastrointestinal colonization and dissemination. They found that Candida albicans inhibits the virulence of Pseudomonas aeruginosa by suppressing the expression of the pyelin and pyoverine genes, which play a critical role in iron acquisition and virulence. Deletion of the pyelin and pyine genes attenuated Pseudas virulence. Heat-killed Candida alb had no effect on Pseud, whereas Candida secreted proteins directly suppressed Pseud pyine and pyelin expression and inhibited Pseud virulence in mice. Interestingly, suppression or deletion of the pyelin and pyine genes had no effect on Pseud's ability to colonize the GI tract but decreased Pseud's cytotoxic effect on cultured colonocytes. Oral supplementation restored Pseud virulence in Pseud and Candida colonized mice. The findings provide insight into how bacterial-fungal interactions modulate bacterial virulence in the intestine, highlighting a novel mechanism of fungal inhibition of bacterial effectors critical for virulence but not colonization.
Researchers investigated the rate of reversion to wild-type (WT) virus from escape mutant (EM) virus in Simian Immunodeficiency Virus (SIV) and Simian/Human Immunodeficiency Virus (SHIV) infections. EM virus evades CD8+ T cell recognition and is often observed in HIV-1 and SIV infections, and is less replicatively fit compared to WT virus, as demonstrated by reversion to WT upon transmission to a naive host and association with lower viral load in vivo. The rate of reversion is highly variable. Researchers quantified reversion to WT of SIV and SHIV viruses containing minor amounts of WT in pig macaques using PCR. Infection with mixes of EM and WT containing ≥10% WT results in rapid outgrowth of WT at SIV G CD8 cell epitopes within 7 days of infection. In contrast, biologically passaged SH229 viruses with smaller proportions of WT or molecular pure EM239 demonstrated delayed or slow reversion. WT was detectable ≥8 days after inoculation and ≥ weeks to become dominant quasis. Delayed reversion associated with lower loads. The diversity of infecting inoculum determines timing reversion to WT, which predicts infection outcome. Delayed reversion of fitness-reducing CD8 cell escape suggests opportunities to reduce pathogenicity during early infection.
Researchers studied yeast populations from Evolution Canyon, Israel, and found that some strains exhibit high tolerance to the heavy metal cadmium. They discovered that cadmium resistance is primarily caused by enhanced function of the metal efflux pump PCA1. Molecular analysis showed that this enhancement is due to mutations in the promoter region, while mutations in the coding region have a minor effect. Experiments demonstrated that single nucleotide substitutions in the PCA promoter quantitatively increase its activity and enhance cells' cadmium resistance. The critical nucleotides found in EC strains are conserved and functionally important for cadmium resistance in other species, suggesting they represent an ancestral type. However, these nucleotides diverged in Saccharomyces cerevisiae populations, giving cells advantages under cadmium low or absent conditions. The study suggests a selective sweep in yeast populations driven by tradeoff metal resistance.
Researchers have identified three major oncogenic pathways in gastric cancer (GC) that are significantly related to patient survival: proliferation/stem cell, NF-κB, and Wnt/β-caten. These pathways are deregulated in over 70% of gastric cancers. The study used an in silico strategy to map patterns of oncogenic activation in 301 primary gastric cancers and functionally validated these predictions in a panel of gastric cancer cell lines. Patient stratification by oncogenic pathway showed reproducible and significant differences in survival in multiple cohorts, suggesting that pathway interactions play a role in disease behavior. Gastric cancer can be taxonomized by oncogenic activity into biologically and clinically relevant subgroups. Predicting pathway by expression permits study of multiple pathways simultaneously in cancers at scale not achievable by other platforms.

The study developed an in sil method to map pathway activation in complex tumor profiles and validated pathway classification using breast cancer examples. The method was applied to eleven oncogenic pathways implicated in gastric carcinogenesis, including RAS, p53, BRCA, W/βaten, E, SRC, MYC, NFκ, histone deacetylation, and stem cell signatures. The strategy involves four steps: defining pathway signatures, mapping signatures onto cancer profiles, validating predictions, and applying to primary GC. Gastric cancer is the second cause global mortality, with most patients diagnosed advanced. Deregulation of oncogenic pathways such as E, KAS, p, and W/βaten occur in GC, indicating molecular heterogeneity.
Researchers used the concept of stress-induced DNA duplex destabilization (SIDD) to analyze the Escherichia coli K12 genome and found that strongly destabilized sites occur preferentially in intergenic regions known or inferred to contain promoters, but rarely in coding regions. They investigated whether genes in different functional categories have characteristic IDD in their upstream regions and found that strong IDD sites in E coli12 are statistically overrepresented in upstream of genes encoding transcription regulators, particularly those responding to physiological and environmental stimuli. If a pathway is controlled by a transcription regulator whose gene has a destabilized 5' flank, the genes (operons) in that pathway usually contain strongly destabilized IDD sites in 5' flanks. This association was observed in 38 of 43 free-living bacteria genomes but only 4 of 18 endosymbion or obligate parasitic bacteria. The study suggests IDD sites 5' to genes may be involved in transcriptional responses to environmental changes known to alter superhelicity, proposing they are active participants in superically mediated mechanisms governing gene expression in response to physiological or environmental changes.
In the fungus Podospora anserina, a network of high-mob group (HMG) transcription factors regulates the sexual cycle, with 11 out of 12 HMG genes involved in this process. The HMG proteins are DNA-binding proteins characterized by the H-box motif and play crucial roles in genomic functions and control of genes in developmental and metabolic pathways. Systematic deletion analysis of uncharacterized HMG genes revealed none are essential for viability, but seven involved in sexual cycle. Two H-box display striking features: PaMG5, an ortholog of Ste11 from Schizosacomyces pombe, is a pivotal activator of mating-type genes in P. anina, whereas PaMG is a repressor of several specific to stationary phase, notably hyphal anoses. Transcription analysis of H-box in H-box strains indicated PaMG is the hub of a network of H-box that regulate mating-type and mating target genes. Genetic analysis revealed this network also controls fertility genes not by mating transcription factors. PaMG and Ste are conserved regulators of mating genes, although P and S diverged 550 million years ago. Two H-box, SOX and upstream S, play role in sex determination in mammals. P and S mating genes and upstream form a module H-box analogous S/SOX, revealing common sex regulation in animals and fungi.
During the 2013-2016 West African Ebola virus epidemic, there was a lack of data on the persistence of Ebola virus in survivors' body fluids and the risk of transmission, including sexual transmission. To address this, an observational study was implemented in Sierra Leone to determine the persistence of Ebola in survivors' body fluids. The study was conducted in two phases: the first phase assessed Ebola virus persistence in semen of 100 adult men within five months of protocol initiation, and the second phase evaluated persistence in multiple fluids (semenstrual, blood, breast milk, urine, rectal fluid, sweat, saliva, tears) of 120 men and 120 women. Data informed national and global guidelines in real-time, demonstrating the need for semen testing among Ebola disease survivors. The study accelerated implementation of such programs in virus-affected countries and informed persistence of Zika virus studies. Research is crucial in responding to poorly characterized epidemics, with adequate resources needed to answer critical questions to inform efforts. Prior to the epidemic, data on Ebola virus persistence in survivors' body and transmission risks was limited, with World Health Organization and Centers for Disease Control guidelines recommending abstinence or condom use for three months post-discharge. During the epidemic, clusters of sexual transmission from survivors occurred, leading to concern about virus transmission from semen and other fluids. The Sierra Ebola Virus Study commenced enrollment within five months of discussions and published baseline results within 10 months, leading to community and public demand for understanding EBO persistence after recovery.
Researchers have used fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) experiments to study the chemotaxis sensory system in Escheria coli and predict the chemical gradients the bacteria encounter in their natural environment. By analyzing dose-response curves, they found that the cells typically experience exponential gradients, which lead to log-normal stimuli and maximal velocity. This is the first step in deciphering the chemical nature of complex, experimentally inaccessible microenvironments, such as the human intestine. The study used a multidisciplinary approach, combining information theory, simulations, and swimming measurements to show that maximizing information implies maximizing alignment of cell trajectories with the chemactic index and velocity. The chemaxis system has evolved to maintain perception in these gradients, as indicated by the Weber-Fech law, which focuses on perception changes in concentration as useful for the cell. To fully characterize the environment, the study matched statistical properties of stimuli to cellular responses, assuming optimization criteria. The chemaxis enables bacteria to detect and migrate in gradients of nutrients and toxins, with a simple system of few components well understood at the molecular level. The study connected phenomenological laws to information at the molecular level, showing a link between transmission and drift.
Researchers have investigated the lifespan of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs), which are responsible for the long-term supply of blood cells, and found that their lifespan varies among identical cells within the same animal exposed to the same environment. This raises the question of what controls the lifespan of HSCs. A new model based on reliability theory explains the diversity of lifespans of Hs using clonal repulation experiments and computational-mathematic modeling. The model shows that repulation failure of Hs is largely anti-persistent or mean-reverting processes, where failure rates increase during population division events and are counteracted by repair processes, leading to a crossover from anti-persistent to persistent behavior. This crossover is due to an increase in mean failure rate of self-renew, leading to clonal extinction, suggesting Hs repair capacity is self-limiting. Lifespan of each H depends on amplitudes and frequencies of fluctuations in failure kinetics, with shorter and longer-lived Hs differing in pre-programmed ability to dissipate perturbations. This implies lifespan is determined by preprogrammed differences in repair capacity.
Researchers have identified a novel mechanism by which antibodies prevent tissue damage caused by migrating helmin larvae. Approximately one-third of the world's population suffers from chronic helmin infections, with no effective vaccines available. Antibodies and alternatively activated macrophages (AAM) play a crucial role in protective immunity against helmin infections. However, the mechanisms by which antibodies target these multicellular parasites were unclear. This study demonstrates that helmin-specific antibodies induce the trapping of migrating helmin larvae and prevent tissue damage following infection with the murine parasite Heligomosomoides polygyrus baker (Hp). Mice lacking antibodies (J−/−) or activating receptors (cγ/−) harbored highly motile larvae, developed tissue damage and accumulated Arginase-1 expressing macrophages around larvae. Antibodies with helmin larvae reprogrammed macroph to express wound-healing genes, including Arginase, and Argase product Lornine directly impaired larval motility. Antibody-induced Argase expression in vitro and in vivo occurred independently of IL-4α signaling. A novel IL-α-independent mechanism of macroage activation is antibody-dependent, mediating anti-helmin immunity and preventing tissue disruption by larvae. Macrophages were reprogrammed by helmin antibodies without IL-α signaling, indicating a novel pathway of macroage differentiation. Antibodies in helmin antigens elicited a subtype ILα-independent activated macroages, referred to as helmin-antib activated macroages (HAM).
Researchers have developed a new, non-invasive method to visualize DNA dynamics during the early stages of double-strand break (DSB) processing in living cells. This method, called ParBINT, uses oligomerization to form visible foci, allowing for real-time analysis of resection in single cells. By applying it to the HO cleavage of the MAT locus on Saccharomyces cerevisiae chromosome III, they provided the first-time analysis of resection in living cells. Monitoring the dynamics of chromatin next to DSB revealed transient confinement of damaged chromatin during early resection, consistent with the need to keep DNA ends in contact. Resection in y70 mutant began ∼10 minutes earlier than wild-type, defining the period of commitment to homology-dependent repair. This new method will be applicable to fine-scale analysis of genome dynamics and function in normal and pathological contexts.
Researchers developed an epidemiological model to study the transmission of Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, in humans. They aimed to estimate the frequency and timing of reinfections in people living in areas with active vector-borne transmission. Using a stochastic agent-based model, they analyzed data from Argentinean villages where 56% of humans were infected with different genotypes of T. cruzi. The model predicted 0.032 (0.008-0.042) annual reinfections per individual, with 98.4% occurring in the chronic phase. Parasites escaped the adaptive immune response in 20% of re-infections. Low reinfection rates were attributed to inefficient vector transmission rather than immune response. Estimated risks of reinfection during chronic disease were 14-18% and 21-70% after 5 and 30 years, with individuals reinfected 1-3 times. This study provides insights for vaccine development and understanding of chronic disease risk in endemic areas.
A study investigated the relationship between pre-existing immune responses to deng virus (DENV) and the outcome of subsequent infection in a cohort of Thai school-aged children. Blood samples were collected from children who experienced subclinical DENV infection or developed deng illness, and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) were stimulated in vitro with DENV to measure cytokine secretion. Significant differences were found in cytokine production based on the type of D used for stimulation and occurrence of illness. Secretion of IL-15 and MCP-1 was higher in PB of subjects who developed symptomatic D infection, while IL-6 was produced by PB from all who developed symptomatic versus 59% with subclinical. Secretion of IL-12, IL-2, MIP-α, RANT, GM-CSF, and TNα was lower in PB from symptomatic subjects. These findings demonstrate differences in pre-existing responses to D associated with clinical outcome. Higher levels of some cytokines in symptomatic and higher of others in subclinical support existence of both protective and pathologic profiles. Clinical-immun correlations may be useful for evaluating responses to deng vaccines.
In the Drosila wing imaginal disc, Hedgehog (H) forms an extracellular gradient that organizes patterning along the anterior-posterior axis and specifies at least three different domains of gene expression. However, a direct correspondence between the borders of these patterns and H concentrations has not been demonstrated. This study provides evidence that interpretation of H signaling depends on the history of exposure to H and proposes that a single concentration is sufficient to support multiple outputs. Mathematical modeling predicts that at steady state, only two domains can be in response to H, suggesting the boundaries of two or more gene patterns cannot be specified by a static H gradient. Computer simulations suggest a "overshoot" of the H gradient, a transient in which H is expanded compared to the H-state. Temporal examination of H target expression shows patterns expand initially and then refine, providing in vivo evidence for the overshoot. The H gene architecture suggests overshoot results from H-dependent upregulation of Patched (Ptc). Altering the network such that P is no longer upregulated in response to H-signaling, patterns of expression, distinct in wild-type discs now overlap. Results support a model where H gradient dynamics, from P upregulation, play an instructional role in establishment of patterns.
Researchers have identified a new mouse mutation, Lightweight (Lwt), which disrupts the homolog of the Caenorhabditis elegans (C. eleg) unc-79 gene. Lwt/L homozygotes are perinatal lethal, while Lightweight heterozygotes are hypersensitive to acute ethanol exposure. Experiments in C. elegans demonstrate a conserved sensitivity to ethanol in unc-79 mutants, extending to related unc-80 and nca-1;n-2 mutants. Lightweight heterozyotes exhibit altered response to anesthetic isoflurane, similar to unc invertebrate mutant phenotypes. They are hyperactive in novel environments, smaller than wild-type, and have increased food consumption with lean body composition. Lightweight heterozyotes voluntarily consume more ethanol than wild-type littermates. The hypersensitivity and increased ethanol consumption in Lightweight heterozy mice, combined with hypersensitivity in C. elegans unc-79, unc-80, and n-1;n-2 mutants, suggest a conserved pathway influencing alcohol behaviors in humans. Whole-genome sequencing confirmed absence of confounding mutations in the 1.4 Mb interval. Behavioral alterations in Lightweight heterozy to ethanol and anesthetics are qualitatively similar to C. eleg and Drosila, but differences exist. The dominant phenotype of Lightweight results from a nonsense mutation in the mouse unc-79 homolog. Heterozygotes are hyperactive and altered to ethanol inhaled anesthetics, consistent with conserved mammalian unc-79 function. C eleg-79, unc-80, and n-1;n-2 mutants are hypersensitive to acute ethanol, suggesting this pathway determines sensitivity in vertebrates.
Researchers have identified the Anopheles gambiae's immune response to Plasmodium falciparum, the parasite responsible for malaria, as a potential source of anti-malaria mechanisms. One such mechanism is the Imd pathway, a conserved signaling pathway with anti-P. falcum activity.
