Silencing Cas, a negative regulator of Imd, or overexpressing REL2, an I-controlled NF-kappa transcription factor, confers a resistant phenotype on A. gambiae that involves immune effector genes. However, unexplored features of this mechanism are essential for malaria control implementation. Using RNA interference to silence Cas and Imd components, genes participating in anti-Plmod signaling regulated by Cas were identified, representing targets for pathway overactivation. Imd is potent against ookin stage, with reasonable activity against early oocysts and lesser against lateocysts. Cas silencing alone induces robust anti-P response in absence of gut microbiota. Imd components TEP, APL, and LR1 in infection-dependent defense were established, shedding light on laboratory versus natural intensity models. Results highlight considerations for I pathway manipulation in A. gambia to limit malaria transmission and reveal nuances in I-directed response P. falcum.
Researchers investigated the anti-fibrotic potential of bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (BMMs) in a mouse model of pulmonary fibrosis caused by Paroccidioides brasili infection. BMMs were isolated from BAL/c mice and administered intravenously to mice infected with P. brasili at 8 weeks post-infection. An additional group was treated with itraconazole (TC) two weeks before BSC administration. Animals were sacrificed at 12 weeks post-infection. Histological examination showed increased granulomatous areas in BSC-treated mice, with significant increases in fibrocy count, soluble collagen, and collagen-1, T-β, MMP-8, and MMP-15 expression. Combined therapy BSC/TC reduced TIM-1 and MMP-13 expression. Human fibroblasts stimulated with lung homogen from infected BSC-transplanted mice showed higher collagen expression. The study found that BSC infusion did not have anti-frotic effect, possibly due to interaction with fungus promoting collagen expression and tissue remodeling. Treatment with TC alone or combined with BSC induced collagen expression in humanroblasts similar to non-treated mice. Soluble collagen was reduced in lungs of TC-treated and BSC mice. Lung homogen from infected and BSC-treated mice induced higher collagen expression in humanroblasts compared to non-treated mice.
A recent study investigated the seasonal dynamics of phlebotine sand fly species that transmit Leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania infant in the Mediterranean region. The study found that the expansion of these vectors in the area is attributed to climate change, and their activity is typically seasonal. Data from 2011-2013 entomological investigations in 8 countries provided a baseline for understanding of fly population dynamics that may impact future transmission scenarios. 99,000 specimens were collected, describing the seasonal dynamics of 56,000 sand flies from 6 species: P. periciosus, P. aasi, P. neglect, P. tobi, P. balicus, and P. kaki. Time of fly appearance and disappearance differed between sites, and densities varied. Significant correlations were found between latitude and annual temperature and first fly appearance (April-June) and density (July-August). A 3-modal trend was recorded for P. bi in Cyprus, a novel for L. infant vector. Adult activity ended September-November, without correlation with latitude and temperature. The period of exposure to L infant in the region, inferred from adult densities, was a bell-shaped curve with a peak July-September, and May-October for 99% values. No transmission risk occurred December-March. A nocturnal activity peaked 11-2 am, with annual variations. Multiple collections provided homogeneous patterns of behavior, proposing sentinel areas for monitoring. Higher risk L infant transmission June-October (97% density), but not equally distributed, with earlier and more frequent in southern territories.
Orientia tsutsamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is an obligate intracellular bacterium that primarily infects endothelial cells, but also replicates in monocytes isolated from healthy donors. Microarray analysis revealed that O tsugamushi altered the expression of over 4,500 genes, with significant upregulation of type I interferon, interferon-stimulated genes and M1 macrophage polarization associated genes. Otsamushi induced apoptosis-related genes and promoted cell death in a small percentage of monocytes. The type I interfer response and M-associated cytokines were indispensable to the transcriptional changes in mononuclear cells from patients with scrubus. Microarray analysis revealed upregulation of 613 genes, including interfer-related and M polarization features in patients, similar to Otsamushi-stimulated monocytes in vitro. This is the first demonstration that monocytes are polarized in vitro and ex vivo following exposure to Otsamushi. The study improves understanding of scrubus pathogenesis, where interferon activation of monocytes and subsequent M1 polarization are critical. 

Otsamushi induced a specific M1 phenotype and type I IF response in monocytes, with sustained upregulation of inflammatory genes related to increased pro-inflammatory cytokines in patients. Type I and II IF and M signatures were found in PBs from patients with scrubus, suggesting association with inflammatory complications. Activated monocytes play a major role in pathogen dissemination, hypothesizing a similar phenomenon in scrubus. Oam upregulated expression genes in polarized responses, including IL-6, IL-12, IL-23, GM-CSF, and CCL20. Monocytes with live Oam produced IF-β, while heat-killed unable to produce IF-β, demonstrating live Oam induced sustained I response. Approximately 15% of upregulated genes were cytokines or chemokines. Oam upregulates type I pathway and apoptosis genes. In vitro results related to expression in patients scrubus, highlighting IF-mediated monocyte role in scrubus pathogenesis.
Researchers have investigated how ants use visual memory to navigate complex environments, focusing on the insect brain's mushroom body (MB) circuit, previously studied for olfactory tasks. A spiking model of the MB developed for fruit fly (Drosila melanogaster) olfactory learning was applied to desert ants (Catagis vel) route learning, demonstrating its ability to rapidly learn routes through natural environments. The model's key principles, including one-shot learning of sparse codes, enable the MB to store hundreds of images. 

A spiking model of Drosila MB olfactory learning was adapted for ant route memory, using realistic stimuli from field experiments. The focus was on visual route learning, not olfactory cues. The MB's neural architecture can form the basis for Badley's algorithm. The MB has been extensively studied in olfactory learning, crucial for insects. A spiking model of adultros MB olfactory used three stages: olfactory inputs produced a spatio-temporal pattern in antennal lobe, consistent with flies and ants. The MB implements the familiarity algorithm for route following in simulation, learning 80-route images from real ant habitats and distinguishing from similar off-route images. The network, developed for simple olfactory learning, required minimal modification for complex navigation. Ants and bees have enlarged MB compared to flies.
Researchers have developed a system to study how Arabidopsis thaliana plants respond to bacterial infection by shedding leaves as a defense mechanism. They infected Arabidopsis leaves with Pseudomonas syringae, a pathogen lacking a type III secretion system, which failed to elicit abission response, suggesting abission is triggered by effectors. Key genes HAESA/HA2, INFRESC, and NES are required for pathogen-triggered abission to occur. Plants with mutations in phytoalexin, disease susceptibility, salicylic induction, and senescence genes fail to abise leaves normally. Bacteria contacting abission zones trigger strong abission, but long-distance signals from infected tissue alert abission of danger. A model proposes a threshold regulating leaf defense where minor infections are contained, but when out of control, leaves are shed. Salicy acid regulates both pathogen and drought-triggered abission. 

A Pseudas syring pv tomato DC0 was used to infect Arabid leaves to understand defense mechanisms. The system builds on a well-studied pathosystem where roset leaves from non-flowering Arabid are infected. A new model for pathogen-trigger abission in Arabid is defined. The abission pathway regulates floral abission for all forms of inducible abission in Arabid. Previous work showed Arab leaves can be shed in response to drought. This study shows Arab uses abission as a defense against bacterial infection. Abission is robust and triggered by disease or ET. Defense and abission pathways are connected, multiple components necessary for pathogen abission. Salicy is necessary for full pathogen and drought abission.
Researchers investigated the mechanism of direction selectivity in starburst amacrine cells (SACs) in the retina, which play a crucial role in detecting image motion. They found that SACs generate larger dendritic Ca2+ signals when motion is from their soma towards dendritic tips than in the opposite direction. To study this, they measured electrical responses to expanding and contracting circular visual stimuli via somatic whole-cell recordings and quantified using Fourier analysis. Fundamental and harmonic components were larger for expanding stimuli, indicating nonlinearity. Harmonic amplitudes and potential relationship suggest voltage-gated channels activation. Ca2+ changes in SAC dendrites by voltage monitored by two-photon microscopy showed distal dendrite tonically depolarized relative to soma, due to resting currents mediated by tonic glutamgic input and high-voltage Ca+ channels. Compartment modeling concluded that dendritic DS in SAC can be computed by dendrites relying on voltageated channels and dendritic gradient, providing spatial asymmetry for direction discrimination.

The study used CF and CP wave stimuli to evoke DS somatic and dendritic Ca+ responses. Dendritic Ca+ responses were seen in a minority of cells, while electrical responses were present in all. Inhibitory blockers showed DS can be generated by dend-intrinsic mechanism, independent of lateral interactions. Blocking GABA, GABA, and glycine receptors was required to block dendritic Ca+ signals, indicating GABA and glycine lateral inhibition contributes to DS SAC. Pharmacological data showed DS persists when GABA receptor connections are blocked, indicating SAC generate DS by themselves. VGC, Ca channels and dendritic gradient are involved. Optical recordings showed strongest Ca+ increases in distal dendrites near synapses.
Researchers investigated the relationship between the mechanisms of pathogenesis, infective dose, and virulence in 43 human pathogens from diverse taxonomic groups. They found that pathogens using locally acting molecules require a lower infective dose than those using distantly acting molecules. Contrary to the prediction, pathogens with distantly acting immune modulators were not more virulent. Instead, virulence was negatively correlated with infect dose and higher in pathogens infecting skin compared to ingested or inhaled. The study suggests that broad comparative analyses can explain variation in parasite traits such as infect dose and virulence, highlighting the importance of mechanistic details. Pathogens with distantly acting immune mod had significantly higher infect doses than locally acting molecules. However, no significant relationship was found between virulence and mechanism of pathogenesis. Case fatality was negatively related to infect dose, with pathogens infecting skin resulting in higher fatality than ingested or inhaled.
Researchers studied the role of microRNAs (miRNAs) in the development of the parasitic worm Schistosoma mansoni, which causes schistosomiasis, a disease affecting 200 million people worldwide. They used a bioinformatics tool to analyze the 3' untranslated regions (3-UTR) of differentially expressed transcripts between juvenile and adult stages and found that the miR-277/498 family was significantly enriched in the transition from juvenile to adult. A novel miRNA, sm-mi-498, was identified, located proximal to smi-277, suggesting a miRNA cluster. Hairpin structures were proposed for both miRNAs compatible with the miRNA pathway. Expression of smi-277/498 was upregulated in adults, while their targets were downregulated in adults but not in immature females. smi-498 was expressed in tegument cells near the oesophagus and throughout the male body. The study suggests mi-277/498 plays a role in post-transcriptional regulation during juvenile development and sexual maturation of females. A combined approach, including mi-target finder, was applied to schistosomes for the first time, providing evidence for the role of miRNAs in intra-malian development. The study identified a group of genes regulated by mi-277.
Researchers conducted a 5-year surveillance of SARS-related coronaviruses (SARS-CoV) in a cave inhabited by horseshoe bats in Yunn Province, China, discovering 11 new strains with full-length genomes. Analysis of these strains, along with previous findings, revealed high diversity in the S, OR3, and OR8 genes. Notably, strains with high similarity to SARS-CoV in the hypervar N-terminal (NTD) and receptor-binding domain (RBD) of S1, OR3, and OR8 regions were found. Additionally, S-CoVs with similarity to human S-Co in OR3 and split OR8a,8 were discovered. Recombination analysis showed frequent events within S and around OR8 between S-Co. It is hypothesized that the direct S-Co progenitor may have originated from sequential recombination between S-Co precursors. Cell studies demonstrated three identified S-Co with different protein sequences can use human ACE as receptor, indicating close relationship to S-Co. This study provides insights into S-Co origin and highlights preparedness for future S-like diseases.
Researchers have examined the potential impact of density-dependent fecundity on the faecal egg reduction test (FECRT), a method used to detect drug resistance in human hookworms. Density-dependent fecundity refers to the phenomenon where female worms increase egg production in response to relaxation of density constraints, such as drug treatment. This can lead to underestimation of drug efficacy in FRT, as worms that survive treatment may increase egg output compared to pre-treatment levels. The degree of underestimation depends on worms' ability to increase egg output, which is constrained by their pre-treatment output. As worms in different hosts have varying densities, effects on efficacy may vary within groups. To improve measurements, cases with heaviest infections may be omitted from FRT, as they have greatest potential to increase output upon density relaxation. This highlights the need for new resistance methods, such as in vitro assays or genotypic changes, to monitor drug effects on isolated worms. In humans, anthelmint efficacy may not meet livestock criteria, suggesting suboptimal dosing, and constraints may be removed as density decreases. A study on canine hookworms showed increased output coincided with drug reduction, indicating density-dependent fecundity. Given its occurrence in human STH, this phenomenon likely applies. FRT may be distorted by density fecundity, making apparent drug changes difficult to identify amidst dynamic worm biology.
Researchers investigated the role of heparan sulfate (HS) in regulating Sonic Hedgehog (SH) signaling during lung development. They found that deletion of HS synthase1 in epithelial cells resulted in expanded branching tips and reduced branching, associated with mesenchymal defects. FGF10 expression and FGF signaling were increased in mutant lungs, suggesting a non-autonomous mechanism. Reduced SH signaling was observed, responsible for suppressing F10 expression. Reactivating SH in mutant lungs rescued tip dilation and attenuated F signaling. Importantly, biologically active SH proteins were reduced in mutant epithelium and wild-type mesenchym cells. The study highlights HS as a key player in dictating SH signaling for lung morphogenesis. Decreased SH activity led to elevated F10 expression, contributing to dilated tips. Production of biologically active SH was reduced after HS loss in epithelium. HS is crucial in SH-producing epithelial cells for SH activity and lung morphogenesis. Epithelial HS deletion caused branching defects, including enlarged tips, decreased branching, and F10. SH signaling was reduced, essential for HS dictating SH-F10 cascade. Prior studies examined HS function in lung morphogenesis. HS synthase ablation in epithium resulted in reduced biologically SH particles on epith and mesyme, and reduced activity in receiving cells, causing F expression, leading to expanded tips and branching.
Paired-end sequencing is a technique used to detect genome rearrangements and structural variations on a genome-wide scale, particularly for copy-neutral rearrangements such as inversions and translocations, which are common in cancer and produce novel genes. Researchers investigated how much sequencing is required to detect rearrangement and localize them using theoretical models and simulations. A formula was derived for the probability of a fusion existing in a genome given paired sequences. This formula was used to compute fusion probabilities in breast cancer samples, finding accurate predictions with a small number of large fragments. The ability to detect fusions depends on gene length distribution and sequencing parameters impact breakpoint detection, localization, and gene detection, even with errors suggesting false rearrangements. These results are useful for calibrating future sequencing efforts, especially large-scale cancer studies enabled by next-generation technologies.

Paired-end sequencing detects rearrangement breakpoints, where non-adjacent coordinates in the reference are adjacent in the cancer genome. Breakpoints were extended to examine fusion detection. Next-generation technologies will provide reliable and precise fusion detection, enabling systematic analysis of genomic events leading to cancer. Maximizing fusion probability with least sequencing depends on factors including end-sequenced clones, fused gene length, and breakpoint errors. Theoretical and empirical formulae elucidate design trade-offs for current and next-generation technologies, making clones more reliable for multiple samples with limited paired reads. Paired sequencing errors include artifacts, assembly, sequence mis-mapping, leading incorrect fusions or false positives.
Researchers have proposed a mathematical model to explain the behavior of chemotaxis, a process by which cells sense and move towards chemical gradients. The model consists of three modules: motility, gradient sensing, and polarization. The motility module is an excitable network that responds to uniform and gradient stimuli, while the gradient module is a local excitation-inhibition network that biases direction. The polarization module is linked to the motility network through the cytoskeleton, allowing cells to move persist and acquire front-back sensitivity. Simulations using a mechanical model of the cell cortex show that the modules recreate behaviors of chemotactic cells. The model demonstrates that adaptation is not required for chemaxis, as cells without it perform less efficiently. However, adaptation allows cells to adjust sensitivity when the midpoint of the gradient is raised. The model also shows that polarized and unpolar cells can coexist in a population and acquire polarity during migration. The LEG-B model simulates movement under various scenarios, illustrating the complexity of chemactic machinery. Experiments have shown that chemaxis pathways have redundancy at the biochemical level. The model proposes that chemaxis is an excitable network activity biased by chemoattract stimuli, with motility achieved through pseudodial protrusions.
Tudor domain-containing protein 6 (TD6) is a male-specific protein essential for chromatin body (Ch) structure and elongated spermatid development and fertility. In meiotic prophase I spermatocytes, TD6 interacts with protein arginine methyltransferase PRMT5, supporting splicing. TD6 also associates with spliceosomal protein Sm in the absence of RNA and arginine methylation-dependent manner. In TD-/-diplot spermatocytes, PR5 association with Sm and arginine methylation of Sm are reduced. TD deficiency impairs assembly of spliceosomes, featuring 3.5-fold increased U snRNPs in the nucleus. These deficiencies in splice maturation correlate with decreased numbers of SM-positive bodies and Cajal bodies involved in snRNA maturation. Transcript analysis of TD-deficient diplot spermatocytes reveals high numbers of splicing defects such as aberrant intron and exon usage as well as aberrant splice junctions. This study demonstrates a novel function of TD6 in splice maturation and mRNA splicing prophase I spermatocytes.
Researchers have developed a new Bayesian model to study the acquisition and clearance of bacterial colonization within a host, which improves upon previous methods that relied on a fixed genetic distance threshold to determine whether isolates are the same or different. The model provides probabilities of whether two strains should be considered the same, enabling the determination of bacterial clearance and acquisition from sampled genomes over time. It explicitly models within-host population variation using genetic simulation and uses Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) and Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) for inference. The method was validated through simulations and applied to a collection of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) isolates from a longitudinal study. The model does not rely on a heuristic distance threshold, unlike previous approaches, and provides uncertainty estimates for relevant quantities. The study of colonization dynamics is based on inferring whether bacteria from collected over time represent the same or distinct events, allowing calculation of acquisition and clearance rates. Whole-genome sequencing provides a measure of genetic distance between isolates, used to infer their relationship. The model defines'strain' as a population of closely related isolates.
Plants generate new organs through the activity of stem cells called meristems. The shoot apical meristem initiates leaves and flowers, and lateral merist in highly ordered, spiralled or whorled patterns via phyllaxis. It is accepted that the transport of the hormone auxin plays a major role in this process. Current hypotheses propose that hormone transporters of the PIN family create auxin maxima at precise positions, which would lead to organ initiation. To explain how transporters could create flux to regions within the plant, concepts have been proposed. A hypothesis, canalization, proposes transport act by amplifying and stabilizing existing flux, which could be initiated, for example, by diffusion. This explains organized auxin flux during vein formation, but shoot apical meristem a hypothesis proposed, hormone would be transported to areas with highest concentrations. This implies coexistence of two different mechanisms for allocation in membrane, based on sensing and on concentration. Patterning processes require interaction of hundreds cells, impossible to estimate on intuitive if scenario plausible or not. Therefore, modelling provides means to test hypothesis. Using computer tool, show flux-based hypothesis explain auxin at meristem, providing unifying concept for control in plant. Experiments required to distinguish flux-based and other hypotheses.
Researchers have developed a new approach to refine wet lab experiments using in silico searches to identify diagnostic peptides for visceral leishmaniasis. They combined high-quality genome sequences and bioinformatic tools with lab experiments to create improved point-of-care tests for early detection and surveillance. Previous studies showed IgG as a biomarker for clinical status in rapid tests using crude antigen, but replacing it with specific antigens led to more robust tests. Immunoblots revealed L donovani proteins detected by IgG from patients. Mass spectrometry identified antigens and searched for constitutive expression and accessibility to B-cells. Epitopes were mapped in silico and screened in peptide arrays. The most promising candidate was tested in RDT prototypes with VL and non-emic control sera, showing 90% sensitivity with Sudanese sera. Over 90 proteins from immunobl did not meet criteria and were excluded. Predicted epitopes from shortlisted identified the most reactive for IgG, 84% (95 CI 60-97) with VL sera. In sil searches reduced lab experiments, focusing on candidates with protein features, predicted epitopes were screened in arrays, identifying the most promising for IgG and specificity. This strategy can be applied to develop robust IgRDTs for monitoring status in VL.
A study of 317 patients with cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) from six countries, including Syria, Pakistan, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Ethiopia, Iran, and others, found that 61.5% of cases had granulomas, with 25.2% being caseating, 4.6 suppurative, and 70.2 tuberculoid without necrosis. Caseating and tuboid granuloma groups differed significantly in geographical distribution, with more cases in Saudi Arabia (p<0.0001). Histologically, both groups differed in distribution of Ridley's pattern (p<0.000), with doubling 3 in caseating granulomas (31% vs 15%) and 5 in tuboid granuloma (38 vs 19%). Time to healing was shorter in tuboid vs case (4.0 vs 6.2 months). Parasitic index, species, and other variables did not differ between granuloma groups. An 18.2% of all cases had caseating granulomas, suggesting CL should be considered in differential diagnosis for caseating granulomas in endemic regions. Cases with caseating granulomas showed slower healing, no association with species, possibly due to worse immune response or aggressive leishmania strains.
Researchers have identified a gene, Zfp69, a zinc finger transcription factor, as a candidate for the diabetogenic effect of QTL Nidd/SJ, which is associated with obesity and type 2 diabetes in mice. The gene is located on distal chromosome 4 and was identified through interval-specific congenic introgression of SJ into diabetes-resistant C57/BL6 and subsequent cross with NZO mice. Analysis of genes in the critical interval by sequencing, qRT-PCR, and RACE-PCR revealed allelic variance of Zfp in NZ and C57/6, disrupted by a retrotranson IAP1 in intron 3, resulting in a truncated mRNA lacking KR and Znf2 domains, whereas diogenic SJ, NON, and B alleles generated normal mRNA. The diogenic ZfpSJ allele produced hyperglycemia, reduced gonadal fat, and increased liver triglyceride levels when combined with B6-Vob background. The human orthologue ZNF642 mRNA was increased in adipose tissue from type 2 diabetes patients. Zfp is likely the candidate for diogenic effect of NiddJ and retrotranson I1 contributes to genetic heterogeneity of strains. Expression in adipose tissue may play a role in pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes. Positional cloning of diabetes genes may provide insights into pathogenesis of obesity-associated diabetes. A QTL Nidd on dist chromosome 4 was previously identified in NZ and SJ outcross, exhibiting high LOD for blood glucose and doubling diabetes in NZxSJ backcross. Zfp was identified as likely candidate for diogenic effect of Nidd and aggravating obesity diabetes in NZ and hyperglycemia in B6ob mice.
Researchers have developed a comprehensive model to predict cell differentiation in the vertebrate hematopoietic system, a complex system with many branching pathways and cell types. The model integrates regulatory and signalling pathways controlling cell differentiation, using qualitative data and logical formalism for dynamical analysis. To handle the network's size and complexity, an original reduction approach and state identification algorithm were used. Simulations were performed in various environments to assess the effects of heterogeneity on cell differentiation, revealing stable states corresponding to Th1, Th2, Th17, and Treg subtypes, as well as transient hybrid cells co-expressing combinations of Th, Th, Treg, and Th17 markers in environment-dependent fashion. The model highlights the nature of these types and their relationships with canonical subtypes, and can be used to explore novel pathways in silico.
Researchers used a thermodynamic model to investigate the mechanisms controlling genome-wide patterns of transcription factor binding during early Drosila development. They evaluated the contribution of different biophysical forces to the binding of five regulators of embryonic-posterior patterning. Predictions based on sequence and protein-DNA affinities achieved a correlation of ∼0.4 with experimental measurements in vivo. Incorporating cooperativity and competition among factors and spatial patterning modeling had little effect on accuracy. A major source of error was prediction of events not occurring in vivo, attributed to reduced chromatin accessibility. Experimental measurements of genome-wide DNA accessibility improved predictions to ∼0.6-0.9 for various factors across target genes. The model was used to quantify roles of sequence, accessibility, and cooperativity. Results showed binding in open chromatin can be predicted by sequence specificity of individual factors with minimal interactions. A combination of experimentally determined chrom accessibility and computational models may predict binding of any transcription factor with precision.
In Drosophila imaginal discs, the basic helix-loop helix (bHL) transcription factors Daughterless (Da) and Extramacchaetea (Em) regulate cell cycle progression through transcriptional control of the Cdc25 phosphatase string. During epithelial cell development, the G2/M transition and proliferation are controlled by Em via Da. Ectopic expression of string in cells with reduced Em or high Da levels rescues proliferative defects in mutant cells. Da acts as a transcriptional repressor of string. In Drosila, Em is required to downregulate Da, triggering mitosis via transcriptional activation of the conserved cell cycle component C25. Em and Da are essential proliferative factors for various cell types, expressed in addition to nervous precursors. The interaction between these proteins and other bHL factors determines cell fate in developmental contexts. In Drosila, Da and Em are the sole representatives of classes I and VHL, facilitating functional studies.
Researchers have developed a comprehensive pipeline to analyze phosphoprote data from interventional experiments to identify key proteins and signaling networks involved in cell growth and development. Phosphoproteomics is a tool to determine relative phosphorylation levels on a large scale, but differs from proteomics due to limited detectable sites per protein. The pipeline includes phosphopeptide analysis, correlation, network analysis, and causal discovery, and compensates for missing data issue in proteomics. The dataset was generated using SILAC (Stable Isotope Labeling Amino acids in Cell) with kinase-dead mutants. The pipeline was applied to Saccharomyces cerevisiae filamentous growth, identifying 5 high-confidence proteins and 19 hub proteins, all involved in stress responses. Nine have direct or indirect involvement in filament growth. Four predicted proteins were validated by phenotypic experiments, showing differential growth. The pipeline presents a systematic way to discover signaling networks using phosphrote data and suggests candidates for investigation. The methodology is applicable to other interventional studies via different platforms.
Researchers investigated the regulation of the X chromosome in Drosophila melanogaster male germl to determine if it undergoes dosage compensation or meiotic inactivation. They found that X-wide dosage compensation is absent in most of the Doph male germl, contradicting previous reports. Microarray analysis showed no evidence for X-specific inactivation during meiosis. The expression of transgenes driven by autosomal spermatogenesis promoters was reduced when inserted on the X versus autosomes, but this difference was established premeiotic and persisted in meiotic cells. The magnitude of the X-autosome difference in transgene expression could not be explained by dosage compensation, suggesting a previously unknown mechanism limits expression from X during sperogenesis in Doph. These findings resolve conflicting reports and have implications for genome evolution and speciation in Doph.
Citrobacterium infection in mice is a model for human diarrheal disease caused by enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC). The pathogenesis of both species depends on forming epithelium-adherent microcolonies, known as "attachment/effacement" (A) lesions. These microcolonies must be dynamic and self-renew by refection of rapidly regenerating epithelium. Research shows that colonic epithelial A microies are clonal populations and depend on clonal growth to persist. In wild mice, microies are established within 18 hours of infection, shaping intestinal infection geography and severity. Mechanistically, resistance to A lesion formation is mediated by TLR-My88/Tr-dependent signaling and induced by virulent C. rodium in a virulence-dependent manner. Establishment of C. rodium pathogenesis is restricted to a short window determining disease severity. 

The development of colonic C. rodium pathogenesis is dependent on early-host interactions. A lesions determine severity from single-bacterial epithelial events within 18 hours. The study focused on early A development shows initiation is limited to a stage. Established clally-renew A lesions trigger innate response protecting epith from de novo formation by luminal bacteria, determining disease outcome. Colonic A lesions depend on cell-to-cell spread, not continuous seeding from plankic luminal colonizers compensating epith shedding. Data reveal epith-adherent C. rodium from a small population (bacterium per micro) subject bottleneck.
Researchers have developed a new method to estimate the overlap between two populations, such as species or genes, when only a fraction of each population is sampled due to data collection or sequencing limitations. Current methods for estimating overlap from incomplete samples are biased and uncertain. The new method, based on Bayesian inference, accounts for sampling rates and provides unbiased Bayes-optimal estimates of overlap and quantifies uncertainty. This approach is relevant in ecology and epidemiology, particularly for malaria, where the number of species or genes in each population is known. The method can be used to study the trade-off between sampling effort and uncertainty. It differs from existing non-probabilistic indices and metrics, which assume complete species counts, leading to bias. The approach can be extended to other cases by changing assumptions or sampling statistics. The method was tested on a scenario of two Plasmodium falciparum parasites with 60 types each, estimating the true overlap from samples sharing types. The goal is to quantify uncertainty in estimates when sampling is stochastic. The method underestimates overlap when samples are small, but can be improved with whole-genome data as prior. This opens analysis of Plasmod spp multigene families and β-divers in multig families with fixed or sampled sizes.
Researchers have investigated the mechanisms regulating the active state of eukaryotic kinases, enzymes that phosphorylate proteins through a conserved catalytic core. Using cAMP protein kinase as a model, they employed biochemical, biophysical, and computational techniques to identify conserved electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions that harmoniously regulate the active mechanics. A salt bridge between lysine from the β-strand and glutamate from α-helix, and electrostatic interaction between phosphorylated loop and α-helix and hydrophobic residues of Regulatory Shell were found to be crucial. Contrary to previous thought, the conserved lysine in β-str was not required for phosphorylation but essential for active state. 

The α-phosphates interact with lysine in β-str, forming a salt with glutamate αelix. Initially, it was assumed lys was for ATP binding and glutamate for stabilizing lys. In absence of salt and electro interaction, active mechanics can be regulated through Shell. Enhancing hydrophity of from leucine to phenylane connected β-region and α-h through hydro interaction between Sh2 and Sh from β-region and RS αelix. Replacing lys with glutamine rescued catalytic activity by repositioning lys onto loop. Hypothesized inefficient catalysis due to hydroph clamp, lobe twisting, and misaligned ATP. Breaking salt by mutating glutamate to alanine destabilized active associated with Shell, unable to undergo autophosphorylation, transphosphorylation, or catalysis. However, Shell assembly was partially restored by coexpressing with, introducing interaction between phosphorylated loop and αelix. Despite not required for phosphorylation, lys is structural sensor facilitating state by coordinating β-region with αelix.
American Samoa conducted seven rounds of mass drug administration (MDA) from 2000-2006 under the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (LF). The World Health Organization recommends post-MDA surveillance using Transmission Assessment Surveys (TAS) for epidemiological assessment of LF. This study compared the effectiveness of two survey designs for post-M surveillance: a school-based survey of children aged 6-7 and a community-based survey of people ≥8. In 2016, a systematic school-based TAS was conducted in 29 elementary schools and a cluster survey in 28 villages on two islands, collecting data on demographics, risk factors, and blood samples for circulating filarial antigen (CA) using Alere Filariasis Strip. The school TAS (n=114) identified 9 antigen-positive children with an adjusted CA prevalence of 0.7% (95%CI: 0.3-1.8), while the community survey (n=7,711) identified 102 antigen people with an adjusted CA of 6.2% (95%:4.5-8.6). C prevalence increased with age and was higher in males. The school TAS had limited sensitivity (0-23.8%) and negative predictive value (25-83.3%) but high specificity (83.3-100%) and positive value (0-100%) for identifying villages with ongoing transmission. The community survey identified antigen individuals of all ages and foci of high prevalence. Both confirmed recrudence of LF transmission.
In zebraf, sex determination is a complex and polygenic, influenced by multiple genetic and environmental factors, with germ cells, particularly oocytes, playing a crucial role in female development. Recent studies have shown that oocytes are required throughout adult life to maintain the female phenotype, but the mechanism is unknown. This study investigates the role of two oocyte-produced signaling molecules, Gdf9 and Bmp, in female sex determination and maintenance in zraf. Mutations in Bmp result in females developing normally but switching to males during mid-to-late juvenile stage and becoming fertile. Aromatase c19a1 mutations show estrogen production is necessary for female development, and Bmp's function in sex maintenance is linked to regulating estrogen biosynthesis via promoting estrogen-producing granulosa cells in the oocyte follicle. Bmp mutant females initially develop normally, but oocytes degenerate at early stages and premeiotic cells switch to sperogenic, transforming the gonad to a testis. The study provides insights into oocyte regulation of sex maintenance in zraf. The hypothesis is that o-somatic gon interaction stabilizes c19a1 expression and estrogen production by the somatic gon. Consistent with this, the somatic gon expresses probable Bmp receptors. Cypa1 functions as a switch determining female vs male in zraf and medaka, animals lacking oocytes develop as males, regardless of genotype, and oocytes are required in adult zraf life to maintain sex. This study identifies genes c19a1 and Bmp required for female development and maintenance, establishing a pathway for sexual development and maintenance inraf conserved in fish.
Hox proteins play a crucial role in controlling morphogenesis along the anterior-posterior body axis of animals by regulating target genes within their broad expression domains. To achieve high regulatory specificity, it is proposed that H proteins co-operate with other transcription factors to activate or repress their targets in a context-dependent manner. However, few of these factors have been identified. This study analyzes the regulation of the death gene reaper (pr) by the H protein Deformed (D) and suggests that activation of pr expression in the anterior maxillary segment is achieved through a combinatorial interaction of D with eight functionally diverse transcription regulators on a minimal enhancer. Context-dependent combinations of H proteins and other factors on small H response elements (HRE) could be responsible for spatio-temporal expression of H targets. Eight transcription regulators, Apt, G, Gcm, E, En, Sl1, Br, Doc, and Disco, are required in addition to H protein D to regulate pr expression in a subset of maxillary cells. D is active throughout the maxillary, whereas pr is found locally, suggesting additional factors contribute to D-dependent pr expression. Proper spatio H target regulation is achieved by combined action of multiple regulators: H proteins and structurally diverse factors. Studies on Ex and H revealed H regulation includes complex formation between H and co-regulatory factors. The ability of a broadly H protein to regulate a gene in spatial and temporal context is achieved H-independent recruitment of context-specific factors to cis-sequences in H.
Researchers investigated the genetic requirements for signaling from an autoactive Arabidopsis thaliana NB-LRR protein, ADR-L2, which functions upstream of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation in defense responses. ADR-L2 acts as a "helper" to transduce specific activation from sensor NB-LRs and its activity does not require an intact P-loop. ADR-L and two related members are required for unregulated cell death in lsd mutant. An autoactive mutation A1-LD484 was generated in a homology motif M, leading to dwarf plants with increased resistance and high SA levels. The phenotype requires intact P, suggesting A-L484 phenotypes reflect canonical NB activation. A-L484 was used to define signaling requirements. Signaling from A-L484 does not require NAD oxidase and is regulated by E1 and At1. Transcription of A484 is correlated with phenotyp outputs, both SA-dependent and-independent. Requirements for A484 resemble SA-dependent signal amplification and death observed in LSD. Importantly, A484 autoactivation is controlled by E and SA separable but linked pathways. A model provides insight into SA feedback loop including A2.
Researchers investigated the components of the RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) pathway in Arabidopsis and their interaction with the MOR6 protein, which mediates transcriptional silencing. They found that SUVH and SUV9, previously thought to be components of the RDM pathway, interact with MOR6 and contribute to transcriptional silencing. SUV2 and SUV9 can act in the same pathway as MOR6 or synergistically with MOR6 to mediate transcription silencing. ID2, another RDM component, interacts with MOR6 and mediates silencing of a subset of MOR6 target loci. Other RDM components, including Pol IV, V, R2, and DRM2, are also required for transcription silencing at subset MOR6 loci. MOR6 was previously shown to mediate silencing through heterochrom condensation. The SWI/SNF chrom-remodeling complex components SW3, SW3, and SWD interact with MOR6 and SUV9 and mediate silencing. These results suggest RDM components are involved not only in methylation but also in MOR6-mediated heterrom condensation. This study links methylation to heterrom condensation and enhances silencing at methyl genomic regions. The interaction between SUV9 and MOR6 suggests SUV9 binding to methylated DNA is required for MOR6 recruitment to chromatin. MOR6 interacts with ID2 and SW/S complex to mediate heterrom cond. Components work together to link methylation and heterrom cond, enhancing silencing at methyl regions. MOR6 functions in silencing loci targeted by RDM components. Whole-genome methylation and RNA-seq data show release of silencing in mor6 not associated with loss methylation.
Researchers investigated the role of heat shock protein 90 (Hsp) in modulating phenotypes in vertebrates, using zebraf as a model. Hsp is a molecular chaperone that buffers genetic variation, potentially accounting for the variable penetrance and severity of heritable developmental malformations. Inhibition of Hsp did not induce a heat shock response or perturb phenotype in wild-type strains, but increased the severity of recessive eye phenotypes caused by paxb and su mutations. A previously unobserved spectrum of severe eye malations, including anophthalmia, microphthalm, and nanthalmia, was uncovered by limited Hsp inhibition. Breeding offspring from unaffected parents led to elevated malformation frequencies, revealing oligogenic nature. Unlike Drosila, Hsp inhibition decreased developmental stability in zraf, indicated by increased asymmetric presentation of anophia, microphthalm, and nanthalm phenotypes. Analysis of paxb mutation suggests a mechanism for buffering by Hsp. Zraf studies imply that mild perturbation of H at critical stages may underpin variable penetrance and expressivity of developmental anomalies where genotype and environment interact.
Researchers have identified and characterized N-terminal acetylation in Drosoph melanogaster, a common protein modification found throughout the tree of life where the N-terminus of a nascent polypeptide becomes co-translationally acety after the removal of the initiating methion residue. Analyzing amino-terminal peptides from Drosila K167 cells, they detected over 1,200 mature Ntermini and found N acylation occurs with similar frequency in insects as humans. A sole determinant of N acylation is the X rule, which indicates acylation under all circumstances. This rule was used to genetically engineer proteins to study biological relevance of presence or absence of acetyl group, creating a generic assay to probe importance of N acylation. The assay was applied by expressing mutated transgenes in cell lines and flies. A straightforward strategy to study relevance of N acylation in cells and organisms is presented. The X rule seems conserved in lower and higher eukaryotes, proposing its use to study acylation in all species.
Researchers investigated the termination mechanism of RNA polymerase III (RNAP III) in Saccharomyces pombe, a crucial for tRNA production during cell proliferation and cancer. They used a tRNA suppression system to identify mutants with gain and loss of termination phenotypes, mapping 122 mutations to a 3.9 Å structure of the RN III elongation complex. Mutations cluster in the active center helix, loop, and pore, and funnel, indicating involvement of the cleavage domain of subunit C in termination. Purified RN III from a readthrough mutant exhibited increased elongation rate, supporting a kinetic model where elongation inversely relates to termination efficiency. Mutants showed correlations in vitro and in vivo, surprisingly synthesizing more RNA than wild-type cells, not accounted for by increased elongation. Activity was unrelated to the III repressor M1. Results show center elements of RN III, including C, are termination determinants, activating overall transcription. Mutations in cancer suggest an unforeseen mechanism of III activation in disease.
Researchers have developed a method to predict protein-protein interactions mediated by SH2 domains using the structure of SH-phosphope complexes and the FoldX algorithm. This approach was shown to perform similarly to experimentally derived consensus and substitution matrices in predicting in vitro and in vivo targets of SH2 domains. The method was used to provide a set of high-confidence interactions for human SH domains with known structure and phosphorylation state. Predictions were validated using literature-derived SH interactions and a probabilistic score from naive Bayes integration of coexpression, conservation, interaction in other species, shared partners, and functions. The predictions led to a new hypothesis for SH domains in signaling.

The method's portability to other SH domains remains to be shown, but FoldX was shown to predict in vitro thermodynamics of protein-phosphope complexes for nine SH domains, indicating applicability for genome-wide predictions. Structure-based prediction of SH-mediated protein-protein interactions has been addressed once. Future methods should account for biophysics and biology of SH domains. FoldX predicted in vivo interactions for nine SH-containing proteins and annotated with supporting information, providing a resource for experimental testing. Fold performed as well as consensus or substitution matrices in prediction in vitro and in vivo interactions. With phosphorylation and structure, Fold gave accurate predictions novel-protein interactions.
Researchers have identified a protein called cyclophilin 40 (Cy40) that can dissolve toxic amyloid proteins, which are a hallmark of neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's disease. These proteins, like tau, are intrinsically disordered and enriched with proline residues that regulate their structure and aggregation. Cy40, a cis peptid-proly isomerase (Pase), interacts with tau at proline-rich sites and dissolves amyloids in vitro. In a mouse model of tau accumulation, overexpressing Cy40 reduced oligomers and tangles, preserving neuronal health and cognition. Nuclear magnetic resonance revealed Cy40 interacts with tau at proline-rich sites. Additionally, Cy40 disaggregated other aggregating proteins with prolines, but lacking Pase activity prevented disaggregation. A unique property of Cy40 allows it to disaggregate energy-independently. This study introduces a novel protein disagase and demonstrates its capacity to dissolve intracellular amyloids. Overexpressing Cy40 in tauopathic brains suggests strategies to halt or rescue cognitive deficits associated with neurotoxicloids.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to study the formation and maintenance of heteroc patterns in cyanobacteria filaments, a type of cellular differentiation in multicellular organisms. The model combines the genetic circuit of a single cyanobacter with the diffusion of nitrogen along the filament, capturing the development and sustainment of heteroc patterns. This approach bridges the gap between macroscopic and microscopic processes of heteroc formation under nitrogen deprivation. The model simulates the behavior of a single cyanacter under different conditions and the dynamics of cyanobacteria filaments by coupling their genetic circuits via diffusion. Results show that including diffusion and noise in the model reproduces the main features of heteroc formation and sustainment in cyanobacteria as observed experimentally. The model connects the regulatory network of cyanobacteria with the machinery of systems biology, capturing the development and maintenance of heteroc patterns. It reveals that noise plays a crucial role in the onset of differentiation, enabling characteristic heteroc patterns for various parameters. The model consists of a filament of cyanobacteria, each with a dynamical circuit, interacting through protein diffusion.
A study was conducted in Cameroon to investigate the association between people's perceptions of the Community Directed Treatment with Ivermect (CTI) program and oncherciasis, and their adherence to iverectin in three regions with high onchias prevalence. A cross-sectional survey was carried out in three districts, with 30 participants randomly selected per district. Adherence toiverect was comparable in Bang and Bafia (55.0% and 48.8%, respectively) and lower in Yab (40.7%). Perceptions of the program and disease were studied, and perceptions of the program were most determinant of adherence toiver. People with a "positive" opinion ofiverect distribution were more compliant than those with a negative opinion (40% vs 55 in Bang, 48 vs 62 in Bafia). Misconceptions about onchias transmission included lack of hygiene in Bafia and Yab, and high sugar consumption in Bang. Perceptions ofiverect distribution were strongly associated with adherence.
This study investigated the contribution of genetic and epigenetic variations to protein biomarkers for cancer and cardiovascular disease by combining DNA methylation and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) data with protein measurements. A total of 121 biomarkers were analyzed in relation to DNA methylation at 470,000 positions and over 10 million SNPs. Epigenome-wide association study (EW) and genome-wide association study (GW) analyses were performed on 698 and 103 samples, respectively. The study identified 124 and 45 loci associated with biomarkers, with effect sizes up to 0.22 units per 1% change in DNA methylation and 4 units per copy of the allele. Most GW loci were cis-regulatory, while EW loci were in trans. Eleven EW loci were associated with multiple biomarkers, including NL5 with CX11, CX9, IL12, and IL18. EW signals overlapping with GW loci were driven by genetic variants, while EW signals were confounded by smoking. Cis-regulatory SNPs for biomarkers had effect on DNA methylation, but not vice versa. Associations between biomarkers and methylation at numerous loci in the genome likely reflect genetic, environmental, or secondary effects of disease pathogenesis.
Researchers investigated how varicella zoster virus (VZV) affects natural killer (NK) cells, a type of immune cell that fights viral infections. They found that VV directly impairs NK cells' ability to respond to stimulation, leading to reduced cytotoxic and cytokine responses. Not only VV-infected NK cells were affected, but also NK cells exposed to VV in culture were inhibited. This impairment was dependent on direct contact between NK cells and V-infected cells. Profiling NK surface receptors showed expression was stable, but cells were still capable of releasing cytotoxic granules when signaling was bypassed. Key components of degranulation signaling were also perturbed. IFN-γ and TNF production were repressed in V-culture, especially in V-infected NK cells. Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) also infected NK cells and made them unresponsive to stimulation, but differently regulated cytokine production compared to VV. The study reveals a new strategy for VV to evade the immune system by inhibiting NK function.
Researchers investigated the neural mechanisms underlying apparent motion (AM), a phenomenon where two stimuli presented at different locations evoke a perception of a stimulus moving between them. They found that AM has a distinct effect on detection of gratings, limiting performance at high contrast levels, strongest when target orientation matches inducers. A population model of early visual processing, based on contrast normalization, predicts AM-related activation in visual cortex is too small to cause masking or perceived motion. Instead, suppression of early responses during AM is consistent with predictive coding, where higher-level motion predictions "explain" lower-level sensory input. AM induces responses in V1 cells tuned to locations and properties of inducers, interfering with actual stimuli perception. However, masking doesn't necessarily imply V1 activation. Predictive models suggest responses along AM path are suppressed when predictable, matching features and timing of moving stimulus. The study examined AM's influence on low-level processing by investigating detection of gratings along path, finding impairment when target matches inducers' orientation. A previous study reported masking at single stimulus level, maximum performance reduction not linked to uncertainty. A population model of V1 captures results, but can't rule out effects in other early cortex areas.
Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1) oncoprotein Tax plays a crucial role in the transformation of CD4+ T cells by promoting cell proliferation and survival, primarily through the activation of the NF-κB pathway and induction of NF-κ target genes. To understand the underlying mechanism, it is essential for understanding HTLV-mediated transformation. Studies have suggested multiple mechanisms for Tax-induced IK activation, mainly due to blending of primary Tax-induced IK events and secondary IK events induced by cytokines secreted by Tax-induced IK-NF-κ activation. In a cell-free system, Tax-stimulated IK activation was reconstituted to dissect essential components for IK activation by Tax. Tax was found to be a putative E3 ubiquitin ligase, with Ubc2, Ubc5, or U7, catalyzing assembly of mixed-link polyubiquitin chains. These mixed-link polyubiquitin chains are responsible for IK activation by binding to the NEM subunit of IK. The biochemical function of Tax in IK activation was revealed, utilizing minimal ubiquitination components for NF-κ activation.
Researchers conducted a systematic review of the relationship between the number of individuals introduced individuals (propagule pressure) and the success of alien species establishment. They used Bayesian meta-analytical methods to evaluate this relationship across various taxa, including invertebrates, herbaceous plants, long-lived trees, and terrestrial and aquatic vertebrates. A positive effect of propagule pressure on establishment was found in all tested hypotheses, but success was most dependent on a range of 10-100 individuals. Heterogeneity in effect was primarily associated with analytical approaches, with larger effect sizes in animal introductions compared to plant introductions. No variation was accounted for by study scale (field to global) or methodology (observational, experimental, or proxy). The study reveals consistency in the relationship between propagule pressure and alien establishment.
Interleukin-17 (IL-17), a cytokine implicated in chronic and severe inflammatory diseases, enhances the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by attenuating the decay of encoding mRNAs. The decay of these mRNAs depends on proteins (AUBs) that target AU-rich elements in the 3'-untranslated region of mRN and facilitate either decay or stabilization. A novel ribonucleoprotein complex assembles in the presence of microRNA (miR16), leading to degradation of target mRN. IL-17 attenuates miR expression and promotes binding of stabilizing Aps over destabilizing Aps, reducing decay. mi16 independently directs competition between degrading and stabilizing Aps for mRN. Aps affect about 8% of the human transcriptome and mi16 is ubiquitously expressed, IL-17 may affect other processes besides inflammation.

IL-17 modulates interactions between Aps, mi16, and target mRN largely on specific sequences and structural restraints. Besides IL-17, IL-1 attenuates mRNA degradation. Epithelial and fibroblast IL-17 with TN- attenuates degradation mRN encoding inflammatory mediators, resulting in hyper production pro-inflammatory mediators. We report degradation mRN encoding IL-8, IL-6, and G-CS by AMD pathway, depending concerted Aps and mi16. Findings show modulation Ap-mi16 regulation by IL-17 on specific target, mi16 usage and Aps participation.

IL-8 degradation inhibited AUF absence mi16, IL-17 attenuated mi16 binding complex, and promoted IL-8 AUF, stabilizing IL8. Similar other ARE-mRN, variousps compete binding target, balance regulated IL- likely mi16. IL-17 inhibition mi16 and mi using LNA resulted attenuated decay. Stable mi expression lentiviral constructs mi16 (Utrecht, Netherlands) enhanced degradation.
A study was conducted in Uganda to examine the relationship between Trypanosoma brucei infection in humans and cattle in villages with and without reported cases of sleeping sickness. The study found that villages with reported cases of sleeping sickness had a higher odds of Trypanosoma brucei infection in cattle compared to villages without cases (OR: 2.94, 95%CI: 1.38-6.24). Cattle age was also a significant factor, with cattle between 18-36 months and over 36 months old having higher odds of Trypanosoma bruce infection than under 18 months old (OR:3.51, 95CI:1.63-7.51 and OR:4.20,95:2.08-8.67 respectively). Village sleeping sickness status had a significant effect on the detection of Trypanosoma rhodes in cattle, with higher likelihood in case villages (OR:25,95:1.2-520.71). A higher average Trypanoma bruce prevalence in a herd was associated with higher likelihood of Trypan rhodes detection (OR:25,95:1.2-520.71). The study suggests a strong association between high Tryoma bruce levels in a village and likelihood of detecting Try rhodes and village sleeping sickness status. This could be used to determine risk at village or parish level in endemic districts in Uganda.
Researchers have investigated the role of the NS complex in regulating housekeeping genes in Drosophila. The complex is composed of proteins NS1, NS3, MBD2, MCR2, and MOF, and is involved in the regulation of chromosomal and autosomal genes. While the function of the MSL complex as a dosage regulator is well understood, the role of the NS complex is poorly characterized. A comprehensive ChIP-seq analysis of the four NS complex members throughout the Doph melanogaster genome revealed that 85.5% of NS-bound genes are constitutively expressed across cell types. NS-targeted genes have increased histone modifications H4ac, H3me, Hme, and Hac in promoter regions, and well-defined nucleosome-free regions and broad transcription initiation patterns. ChIP-seq of RNA polymerase II in NS1 and NS3-depleted cells showed that both proteins are required for efficient recruitment of II to NS-target promoters. The II reduction coincides with compromised binding of TBP and TFI to promoters, indicating the NS complex is required for optimal recruitment of the initiation complex on genes. Genes with most loss of II upon NS knockdown are enriched in Replication Element. The findings show the MO-containing NS complex regulates housekeeping genes by modulating II transcription initiation.
Researchers have developed a transgenic mouse model to study facioscapulohumeral dystrophy (FD), a progressive muscular dystrophy caused by decreased epigenetic repression of the D4 macrosatellite repeat and ectopic expression of DUX, a gene encoding a germline transcription factor. The model recapitulates epigen and D4 expression seen in patients and controls, including high D4 expression in germline, incomplete epigen repression in somatic tissue, and FD-specific variegated D4 expression in sporadic muscle nuclei associated with D4 chromatin relaxation. The study suggests somatic epigen silencing of D4 is conserved and contracted D4 arrays are silenced less efficiently, leading to varieg expression of D4 protein in skeletal nuclei. Ch and DNA methylation analyses indicate chrom relaxation of D4 repeats in D4-2.5 mice compared to D-12.5 mice, concord with observed D4 expression, modeling difference between FD patients and individuals. In muscle, D4 activates gerine and stem programs while suppressing innate response genes. The model may serve therapeutic studies targeting D4 expression in muscle, as detrimental effects can be reversed by RNA interference. Somatic derepression D4 has been associated with changes D4 chrom structure, characterized decreased methylation and lower CS. The D- pattern suggests locus-intrinsic property of D repeat, conserved between mouse and human.
Researchers developed a malaria vaccine candidate, Apical Membrane Antigen-1 (AMA1), to induce protection against Plasmodium falciparum, but it only works against strains closely related to the vaccine. To overcome this limitation, they studied the structural basis of cross-strain invasion and developed a vaccine containing four diverse AMA1 allelic proteins, Quax or Q, which elicited polyclonal antibodies that inhibited invasion of four vaccine and non-vaccine strains. Comparing polyclonal anti-Q with strain-specific monoval, 3D AMA revealed Q induced higher levels of broadly inhibitory antibodies associated with conserved domain-3 and reduced domain-2 responses. Inhibitory monoclonal antibodies against Q reacted with a cross-reactive epitope at the rim of hydrophobic domain-1, mapped to conserved AMA1 and encompassing the 1-loop. Monoclonal antibodies to the 1-loop (1,4,8,11) were 10-fold more potent than previously characterized AMA-inhib m and mode of action was inhibition of AMA binding to ligand R2. Unlike epitope of previously 3D-specific mAb,1, the 1-loop inhibitory epitope was conserved across strains. Novel mAb10 bound domain-3, was broadly inhibitory and blocked proteolytic processing of AMA. mAb10 was weakly inhibitory but synergized with previously strain-transending m,4, which binds to hydroobic on conserved and inhibits R2 binding AMA. Novel susceptible regions and epitopes identified can improve antigen breadth and inhib response of AMA vaccines. Vaccination with diverse proteins may provide universal coverage by redirecting response to conserved epitopes.
Researchers have discovered a previously unknown mechanism that regulates the timing of mitotic spindle displacement in cells, which is crucial for unequal cell division. The mechanism involves the anaphase-promoting complex (APC), its activator Cdc20/Fizzy, its target cyclin, and cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK). In Caenorhabditis elegans zygotes, mitotic spindle displacement begins at a precise time after chromosomes congress to the metaphase plate. Reducing the function of the proteasome, APC, or C20/Fizzy delayed spindle displacement, while inactivating CD in metaphase caused the spindle to displace early. Experimentally unlinking spindle from this mechanism resulted in premature displacement of incompletely assembled components of the mitotic spindle. The study found that the timing of spindle displacement is precisely regulated in C. elegans and that the proteome and APC time spindle through their roles inactivating CD. Displacement is not required for anase timing in C. elegans, instead CD activity affects spindle and anase independently. Regulation of CD by proteome F-1 and APC serves as a timer for mitotic displacement, resulting in a 60-90 delay that allows spindle assembly to complete before being pulled away from the cell center.
Researchers conducted a genome scan to identify genes showing evidence of adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia in Tibetan and Andean populations. High-altitude populations exhibit unique circulatory, respiratory, and hematological adaptations, but the underlying genetic basis is unknown. The study looked at each chromosome for genomic regions with unknown function regarding altitude phenotypes and examined genes in oxygen metabolism and sensing. Four population statistics were used to detect signatures of natural selection, identifying candidate genes and regions in each population separately. Tibetan and Andean adaptation patterns are distinct, with evidence of selection in different genes or regions. One gene, EGLN (PH2), known for oxygen sensing, shows selection in both populations, but variation differs between them. Key H-regulatory and targeted genes are responsible for adaptation in Andeans and Tibetans, and chromosomal regions implicated in putative response. Data suggest genetic role in high-altitude adaptation and basis for genotype-phenotype studies to confirm selection-nominated genes and regions.
Double-strand breaks (DSBs) in DNA can result from environmental interactions or cellular processes and are a major source of genetic instability. Efficient repair of DSBs is crucial for cell survival, but faulty repair can lead to mutations and chromosomal rearrangements. The choice of repair pathway is important to maintain genomic integrity. Inverted repeats (IRs) near DSBs can channel repair from accurate gene conversion to break-induced replication (BIR) pathway, leading to instability. IRs form unusual structures in single-strand DNA formed by DSB resection. They can form two types of structures: intermolecular single-strand annealing (SSA) leading to inverted dimers and intramolecular SSA to fold-back (FB) structures. Both interfere with accurate repair and channel DSB into BIR, promoting destabilization. Protein complexes process FB with short (12-b) versus long (1-k) loops: MR-Sae2 and Rad1-Rad10, respectively. Studies uncover mechanisms of destabilization from DSB repair by IR. Given IR abundance in the genome, findings contribute to understanding IR-mediated destabilization associated with human disease.
Researchers developed a Drosophila melanogaster model to study Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilm infections in vivo. Pseudas aerugin is an opportunistic pathogen causing acute and chronic infections in susceptible hosts, with chronic infections thought to be caused by biofilms. Biofilms are structured, multicellular microbial communities encased in an extracellular matrix enabling long-term survival in the host. The model allowed in vivo study of P aerugin biofilms in Dophila. At 24 hours post-infection, P aerugin biofilms localized and were visualized in Dila crops, with characteristic structure and extracellular matrix composed of DNA and exopolysacide. aerugin cells from vivo biofilms had increased antibiotic resistance relative to planktonic cells. Biofilm formation was dependent on expression of exopolysacide genes, as pel:: mutant failed to form biofilms. The:: mutant was more virulent than PA1, while hyperbio strain (Z3) demonstrated less virulence than PA1, indicated by survival of infected at 14 postinfection. Bio formation by PA1 and Z3 in crop was associated with induction of dipteric, cecin A and antimicrobial gene expression 24 postin. Infection with non-bio forming resulted in decreased gene expression.
Researchers investigated the contribution of the proximal 5' flanking sequence and microsatellite variation on vasopressin 1 receptor (Av1) gene expression and behavior. The Av1 gene exhibits diverse expression patterns within and between species, influencing vasopress-mediated behaviors. The study used homologous recombination in mice to reveal that the proximal 5' flanking sequence modestly contributes to species-specific vasopress receptor 1 (V1R) distribution and confirmed that V1R variation impacts stress-coping in the forced swim test. The Av1 microsatellite structure was found to contribute to Av1 expression in the amygdala, thalamus, and hippocampus, mirroring inter and intra-species differences in V1R patterns in voles. This is the first evidence that polymorphic microsat elements near behaviorally relevant genes contribute to diversity in brain expression, providing a mechanism for generating diversity at individual and species levels. However, results suggest that species-specific patterns are mediated by elements outside the 5' flanking region of the gene.
Researchers have developed a yeast system to study the mechanisms of genome instability caused by impaired ribonucleoprotein (RNP) biogenesis and Activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID) in mammalian cells. They found that ID induces double-strand breaks (DSBs) in immunoglobulin switch regions and c-MYC sequences in yeast mutants impaired in R biogenesis, leading to chromosomal translocations via Non-homous End Joining (NHE). ID-induced translocations were enhanced in R biogenesis mutants, suggesting that ID-mediated DS depend on loop formation. The study provides new insights into the role of bi in preventing genome rearrangements and the mechanism of ID-mediated instability, and shows that uracil residues produced by ID deamination are processed into DS and chromosomal rearrangements by conserved DNA repair functions in yeast and mammalian cells. The yeast system offers a validated assay to study mechanisms leading to DS at regions and c-M oncogene, such as those occurring in cells responsible for switching or translocations associated with Burkitt lymphomas.
Researchers investigated how Escheria coli cells partition their chromosomes during asymmetric cell division when the cell division plane is not properly positioned. Using time-lapse imaging, they found that the protein Fts can pump up to 80% of the 3.7 Mb chromosome between daughters at an average rate of 1700-800 bp/s, with rare pauses and no reversals. The majority of DNA movement occurs at late stages when the division protein ZipA has dissociated from the septum and the septum is closed to a narrow channel smaller than 250 nm. This suggests the constriction is necessary for effective DNA translocation by Fts. The study demonstrates E. coli can reposition their chromosomes when division is not localized, contradicting the common view that accurate positioning is essential for viability.
Researchers have developed a mathematical framework for selecting the optimal set of peptides for epitope-based vaccines using integer linear programming. Epitope-based vaccines have various applications, including therapeutic and prophylactic approaches for infectious diseases and cancer. The development of an epitope-based vaccine relies on knowledge of target-specific antigens from immunogenic peptides, called epitopes, which form key components of the vaccine. Due to regulatory, economic, and practical concerns, the number of epitopes in a vaccine is limited, and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) binding epitopes are highly polymorphic, every patient has a set of MHC I and II molecules differing specificities. A combination effective for one person can be ineffective for another, making optimal epitope selection important. The framework selects the set of epitopes with the maximum likelihood of eliciting a broad and potent immune response from a user-defined or experimentally determined epitopes. The integer programming approach allows formulation of various vaccine design problems and efficient identification of optimal epitopes. Immunological requirements, such as coverage of epitopes per antigen, coverage of MHC alleles, and avoidance of epitopes with high mutation rates, can be translated into constraints or modifications of the objective within the framework. The implementation outperforms a greedy strategy and evolutionary algorithm with runtimes of seconds for typical problem sizes. The framework is flexible to account for variants of the problem, including personalized vaccines, and is the first to find provably optimal epitopes.
Researchers investigated the role of interleukin-7 (IL-7) in facilitating HIV-1 transmission to the cervico-vaginal tissue in an ex vivo system. IL-7 is a cytokine present in high concentrations in the semen of HIV-1-infected individuals, and its effects on HIV-1 replication in isolated cells and infected individuals have been reported. The study simulated an in vivo situation by depositing HIV-1 on cervico-vaginal tissue with IL-7 concentrations comparable to those in HIV-1-infected semen. Results showed IL-7 significantly enhanced HIV-1 replication in cervicoaginal tissue and lymphoid explants. Analysis of infected cells revealed IL-7 reduced CD4+ T cell apoptosis and increased expression of anti-apoptotic protein B-cell lymphoma (Bcl-2). IL-7 also increased the fraction of cycling CD4+ cells. High IL-7 levels in semen may contribute to the survival of HIV-1-infected cells in the cervicoaginal mucosa, promoting local infection expansion and dissemination. The study demonstrates IL-7 facilitates HIV-1 male-to-female transmission, suggesting high IL-7 in semen may make the female genital mucosa more susceptible to HIV-1 acquisition.
Researchers studied the interaction between the Zika virus (ZIK) and the RNA interference (RNA) response in Aedes aegypt cells, the primary mosquito vector for ZIK transmission. They found that ZIK induces the production of virus-specific small interfering (si) RNAs and PI-interacting (pi) RNAs, although the piRNAs lack the characteristic signature of typical small RNAs. The siRNAs were loaded into the Ago2 protein, but silencing this protein did not enhance virus replication, and increased replication was observed in Ago2 knockout cells, indicating an antiviral role of the exo-si pathway. ZIK-specific piRNAs were detected, but lacked the piRNA ping-pong motif and were bound to Ago3, not Piwi or Pi6. Silencing Pi proteins showed that knockdown of Ago, Pi5, or Pi6 did not enhance ZIK replication, but Pi4 displayed antiv activity. The study also found that ZIK capsid protein amplified replication of a reporter virus, unlike yellow fever protein, which inhibits the exoRNA pathway.
A study was conducted in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil to investigate the association between Sporothrix species and clinical manifestations of sporrichosis. Fifty patients with different clinical manifestations were analyzed, and their isolates were studied using phenotypic and genotypic methods. The results showed distinct clinical and therapeutic responses between Sporoth brasili (n=45) and Sporoth schenii sensu stricto (n=5). Sporoth brasili was associated with disseminated cutaneous infection, mucosal infection, and hypersensitivity reactions, whereas Sporoth schii presented less severe and localized disease, similar to previously described sporrich cases. Sporothili-infected patients required shorter itraconazole treatment (16 weeks) compared to Spor schii (24 weeks). This suggests Sporoth species are linked to different manifestations of sporrich and Sporili is effectively treated with itraazole. This is the first study to demonstrate genotypic identification of Sporoth species and clinical aspects of sporrich. The findings add to knowledge on Sporili disease and support careful speciation of Spor isolates for clinical care. Sporili has been reported in Brazilian states other than Rio Janeiro, but frequency is lower than Spor schii. Sporili caused typical forms of sporrich (lymphocutaneous and cutaneous) but disseminated in one case. Spor presentations of sporrich by Spor spp are variable and poorly understood.
Recent studies have suggested that a significant portion of the mammalian genome is transcribed beyond annotated genes, but the nature and quantity of these transcripts remain unclear. This study used single-end and paired RNA-Seq and tiling to assess the quantity and composition of Poly+ RNA in human and mouse tissues. Relative to tiling, RNASeq identified many transcribed regions outside known exons and non-coding RNAs, with most being introns, suggesting they are pre-mRNA fragments. Chromosomal locations of intergenic regions in RNASeq are near genes, consistent with alternative splicing, polyadenylation, and promoter-terminator transcripts or new exons. Reads bridging splice sites identified 5,544 new exons, affecting 3,554 genes. Remaining seqags correspond to single reads displaying random sampling or low background or small transcripts (median 111bp) at higher levels, displaying conservation and originating from open chromatin. Bonaide intergenic transcripts exist, but their number is low compared to exons, and genome not pervasively transcribed as reported.
