The majority of intergenic and intraseqags have low coverage, exemplified by 70-80% of transcribed regions detected by single RNASeq in one sample, consistent with random placement. Tiling arrays are ill-suited to detect low-expressed transcripts. Noncoding in RNASeq is associated with genes, including new exons and promoters. Increased seq coverage in intergenic regions correlates with gene transcripts across 11 Poly+ RNASeq samples. Reads in intergenic display high correlation with neighboring genes or associated with 10,000 novel exons. Genome analysis revealed 2,789 uncharacterized fragments no overlap exons, 1,259 in intergenic. Intergenic transcribed consist of coding and noncoding.
Researchers have developed a computational and experimental method to increase the thermostability of the flavin mononucleotide-based protein Bacillus subtilis YA LO domain by 31°C, making it suitable for use in thermophilic systems. The method involves five steps: single mutant screening to identify thermost candidates, experimental evaluation to confirm positive selections, computational redesign around thermost regions, experimental reevaluation, and multiple mutations combination. This method is simple and effective, applicable to proteins where other methods fail, and provides a tool to improve therability. 

A previous study mutated C62 to alanine, increasing E. coli fluorescence tenfold, but the engineered YLO (FFP) has moderate therability. A more therable FFP is desired for anaerobic microorganisms, especially thermophilic ones. The 62% success rate highlights the effectiveness of screening. Locations of thermost sites are shown in Figure 2, with five from the dimer interface, suggesting stronger interactions increase therability. Among tested, V120 has highest (54.2°C). Proteins with stability are desirable. Three engineering methods exist: evolution, consensus, and design. Each has strengths and weaknesses, used to improve therability with success.
Researchers conducted a study on the diversity of Lutzia sand flies and their infection rates of Leishmania and Wolbach species on Barro Island, Panama. Lutzia sand flies are the primary vectors of the protozoan disease Leishmanias in the world. The study aimed to determine which Lutzia species are present, their relationships, and how they are infected by Leish and Wolbach, to mitigate the impact of the disease on humans. DNA sequences were used to determine the diversity and phylogenetic relationships of Phleominae in the understory of Barro Island. The CO1 DNA barcode gene supported morphology-based species determinations, revealing two "cryptic" species, Lu. sp. vespilion within the Vespilion group and Lu. gzi within Lutzia-crata. Leish DNA was detected in 43.3% of Lu. trapi, 26.3% Lu. gzi, and 0% of other sand species. The ITS-1 sequence obtained from Leish infecting Lu. trapi and. gzi was 93% similar to Leish viannia naiff in GenBank, a previously unknown in Panama but recognized as cutaneous Leish vector across northern and central America. Distinct Wolbach strains were detected in three sand species, including Lu. trapi, co-occurring with Leish. Two species, members of separate clades, carried Leish at high frequency and are likely vectors of Leish to humans or mammals. A single Leish, identified as. naiff, was carried by both. naiff is known to cause cutaneous in America but not reported in Panama, suggesting its range may have expanded or introduced.
Researchers have investigated the mechanisms of human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) reactivation in dendritic cells (DC) and found that mitogen-activated kinases (MSK) co-operate with the transcription factor CREB to induce immediate early gene expression from latency. CREB binds to the major early promoter (MIE) and recruits MS, which phosphorylates histone H3, promoting histone demethylation and exit from latency. This interaction is crucial for chromatin remodeling and viral gene expression. Inhibition of this interaction could be a therapeutic strategy. Biochemical studies showed chromatin bound to the c-fos promoter is resistant to MS-mediated phosphorylation, but CREB binding promotes histone phosphorylation. An adenovirus vectors were used to study the ER-MS-CREB-histone H3 relationship and IE expression from latency. MS binding to MIE before reactivation supports this. IE expression in DCs is sensitive to MS inhibition and HCV reactivation involves histone phosphorylation at latent MIE. MS phosphorylation is dependent on concurrent CREB binding to MIE. Histone phosphorylation is associated with rapid genes, promoting hyperacetylation in a MAP and MS-dependent manner, influencing HCV reactivation.
Researchers have identified a crucial role for the protein NOL11 in ribosome biogenesis and craniofacial development in vertebrates. N11 is expressed in the developing cranial neural crest (CNC) of amphibians and mammals, and its knockdown in Xenopus results in impaired pre-rRNA transcription, increased apoptosis, and abnormal craniofacial cartilage development. Inhibition of p53 rescues the skeletal phenotype but not the ribosome biogenesis defect, indicating an evolutionarily conserved mechanism to remove ribosome-impaired craniofac cells. Excessive activation of this mechanism impairs craniofac development. N11 is required for optimal pre-r transcription and pre-r processing in Xenopus, and its knockdown leads to nucleolar stress, p53 stabilization, and craniofac phenotype. N11 expression is strongly associated with CNC, required for differentiation and development of craniofac cartilages, but not in other cell populations. Co-depletion of p53 and N11 partially rescues craniofac phenotype but not pre-r transcription. This study reveals a novel requirement for N11 in craniofac development and conserved relationship between ribosome factors and CNC survival.
Researchers developed a high-density protein microarray to identify seroreactive proteins of Leptira interrogans serovar Copenhagen, a bacterium responsible for leptospi, a zoonotic disease worldwide. The study aimed to find new diagnostic markers for the disease, as current tests are limited, especially in early stages when treatment is most effective. The microarray consisted of 2,421 proteins, 61% of the bacterium's proteome, and was tested against IgG from 274 individuals, including acute, convalescent, and healthy subjects from regions with high, endemic, and no transmission. A nitrocellulose blot validated the results, finding 16 antigens distinguishing acute cases from healthy individuals in endemic regions and 18 distinguishing convalescent cases. Some identified antigens, such as Lip32, non-identical domains of Lig, Gro, and Lo22, are known to be recognized by human sera, validating the serodiagnostic approach. Novel antigens, including hypothetical LIC15, showed good sensitivity and specificity for both acute and convalescent patients. This study is the first large-scale evaluation of immunodominant antigens associated with naturally acquired leptiral infection and identified known seragnostic leptiral antigens recognized by sera of leptpi cases. The novel antigens may be used in new tests and improving current assays for this neglected disease. Further research is needed to assess their utility in deployable platforms.
Researchers investigated the role of melanization in mosquito immunity against the entomopathogenic fungus Beauveria bassiana, using the malaria vector Anopheles gambia as a model. They found that melanin formed on all stages of the fungus, including conidia, germ tubes, and hyphae, but rarely aborted growth and mycelium continued to grow despite melanization. Silencing TEP and CL8, key regulators of melanization, abolished melanization on hypha but not germinating conidia or tubes. Detection of a layer of hemocytes surrounding germinating conidia but not hypha suggested melanization of early stages is cell-mediated, while late is humoral dependent on TEP and CL8. Microscopic analysis revealed association of T1 with hypha surfaces and requirement of both T and CL8 for phenoloxidase recruitment. Fungal proliferation was more rapid in T and CL8 knockdown mosquitoes, exhibiting increased sensitivity to B bass infections. Melanization significantly retards B growth and dissemination.
Researchers investigated the potential of four compounds, bafilomycin (BAF), myopholic acid (M), castanospermine (CAS), and deoxojirimycin (DN), to inhibit dengue virus (DENV) infection in the mosquito vector Aedes aegypt. The compounds were administered through various methods, including injection, sugar feeding, and blood feeding, and RNA interference (RNAi) silencing of target genes. Injection of 5µM BAF and 25µM M prior to feeding on virus-infected blood inhibited DENV titers in the midgut at 7 days post-infection by 56% and 60, and in the saliv gland at 14 post-infection by 90 and 83, respectively. Treatment with CAS or DN did not affect susceptibility to virus. Ingestion of B and M through sugar or blood meal resulted in various degrees of virus inhibition. RNA-mediated silencing of vPase subunit and IMP gene reduced DENV, indicating B and M-mediated inhibition likely occurred through inhibition of these factors. Route and timing of B and M administration was essential, treatment after exposure diminished antiviral effect. The study provides proof-of-principle that chemical or RNA-mediated depletion of vPase and IMP can suppress DENV in adult aegi, which may reduce transmission.
Researchers investigated the role of cell volume in neuronal dynamics, particularly in relation to seizure, spreading depression, and anoxic depolarization. They incorporated cell swelling, ion concentrations, and oxygen supply into the Hodgkin-Hux spiking dynamics model, demonstrating a transition between seizure and spreading states in response to osmotic pressure changes. The study revealed a dynamical definition for the physiological ceiling separating seizure from spreading depression, and a second ceiling demarcating spreading from anoxic depolarization. The model highlighted the neuroprotective role of glial buffering against seizures and depression, and provided insights into anoxic depolar and cell swelling during ischemia. The results suggest a unified framework for understanding a range of neuronal behaviors, relevant to developing interventions for pathological states.
Researchers investigated the role of the NLR3 inflamome in response to Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, the causative agent of paracoccidiomycosis, a prevalent in Latin America. They found that murine bone marrow-derived dendritic cells responded to P. brasiliensis yeast infection by releasing IL-1β in a Syk, caspase-1, and NLR family member NLR3 dependent manner. P. brasili-induced NLR inflamome activation was dependent on potassium efflux, reactive oxygen species, phagolysosomal acidification, and cathepsin release. Using mice lacking IL-1 receptor, they demonstrated IL-1 signaling plays a role in killing P. brasili by murine macrophages. The study suggests the NLR inflome senses and responds to P. brasili yeast infection and plays a role in host defense against the fungus. Further studies are needed to determine IL-1 and NLR inflome components' role in vivo and how IL-1 activates macrophages for killing activity.
Toxoplas gondii, a brain-tropic parasite, primarily infects nucleated cells, including astrocytes and neurons in vitro. However, in vivo, Toxoplas is predominantly found in neurons. Research suggests that interferon-stimulated astrocytes, not neurons, clear intracellular parasites, indicating neurons are persistently infected due to their inability to clear intracellular parasites. A novel Tooplas-mouse model capable of marking and tracking host cells interacting with parasites, even transiently, reveals Tooplas shows a strong predilection for interacting with neurons throughout CNS infection. This predilection remains in the setting of IF-γ depletion, infection with parasites resistant to the mechanism by which murine astrocytes clear parasites, or when injecting parasites directly into the brain. Findings, combined with prior work, suggest neurons are not incidentally infected, but Tooplas's primary in vivo target.

Tooplas invades both astrocytes and neurons in vitro, but predominantly interacts with neurons in vivo. Studies imply Tooplas primarily encysts in neurons because neurons cannot clear intracellular parasites, but no studies have directly addressed this in vivo due to lack of techniques to identify cells with transient interactions. A Tooplas strains were generated to inject Cre recombinase into host cells, revealing neurons as the majority of GFP+ parenchymal CNS cells, regardless of time or infecting strain. This contradicts the "astrocy-killing" model of CNS-Tooplas interactions, expanding findings to define parenchymal cells interacting with parasites in vivo. Neurons consistently make up the majority of GFP+ parenymal CNS, regardless of time or infecting strain.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to explain the behavior of cells undergoing lamellipodial motility, a type of cell movement characterized by the extension and retraction of the cell boundary. The model, based on the interaction between actin and myosin, accounts for isotropic contraction, viscous stresses in the actin network, and adhesion. Contraction generates a spatially graded actin flow, which reinforces contraction via myin redistribution and retraction of the lamip boundary. Actin protrusion at the boundary counters retraction, balancing protrusion and retraction shape the lamip. The model shows that motility initiation depends on three dimensionless parameters: myosin contractility, viscosity-adhesion length, and actin protrusion rate. When contractility is strong, cells break symmetry and move steadily along straight or circular trajectories, and motility is sensitive to boundary conditions. Analysis of the parameter space shows that contractile motility supports cell turning in conditions with short viscosity-adhesion and fast protrusion causing myin accumulation in a small region at the rear, destabilizing cell symmetry.
Researchers have developed a novel technique to assess the confidence levels of interactions in protein-protein (PPI) networks obtained from experimental studies. The method, called geometric de-noising, utilizes the geometric model of protein-protein networks to detect false positives and false interactions and predict novel ones. It achieves a specificity of 85% and sensitivity of 90. The technique was applied to the human protein-protein interaction network downloaded from BioGRID, predicting 251 interactions, a statistically significant fraction of which correspond to protein pairs sharing common Gene Ontology (GO) terms. A statistically significant portion of the predicted interactions were validated in the Human Protein Reference Database (HPRD) and BioGRID's newer release. The method outperforms existing protein-protein network processing techniques in terms of false positive and false rates for the largest component of the network.
Researchers have developed a Drosila model to study myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM), a neurodegenerative disease caused by noncoding CT repeat expansions. They tested the role of interactions between expanded CTG and CAG transcripts and found enhanced toxicity in flies co-expressing both repeats. Expression of the transcripts led to the generation of 21-nt repeat-derived siRNAs that targeted C-containing genes, such as Ataxin-2 and T binding protein (TBP), which have C repeats in both flies and humans. These findings suggest that triplet-derived siRNAs may enhance toxicity in repeat diseases with antisense transcription.

 Studies showed that noncoding CT repeats confer length-dependent toxicity in brain and muscle flies, similar to mammals. Expanded CT transcripts accumulated in nuclei and affected splicing, recapitulating key features of DM. To understand CUG toxicity, transgenic flies were created with pure CT expansions in the 3'UTR of a protein. These recapitulated major features of C RNA diseases. Given 70% of genes have antisense transcription, the effect of co-expressing CT and CAG transcripts was tested. Co-expressing CAG with CT repeats resulted in enhanced toxicity and generation of repeat-derived siRNAs.

Triplet repeat expansions in noncoding regions cause several human diseases, including DM, fragile X, spinocerebellar ataxia, and Huntington's disease. DM, SCA, and HD2 are caused by CT expansions. Antisense occurs widely in the genome, defining potential roles and impact on repeat diseases may provide insight into pathogenesis. Drosila has been used to study neurodegenerative diseases relevant to humans.
Researchers have re-examined the phylogeny and virulence of the soft rot pathogen Pectacterium sp. SCC3, isolated from a diseased potato in Finland in the 1980s. Genomic approaches revealed that SCC3, previously classified as P. carotorum, is now accurately classified as P. wasiae. The revised phylog of P. carorum and P. wasiae strains indicates P. wasiae has been present in potato fields worldwide. A combination of genomic and in planta experiments identified features that separate SCC3 and P. wasiae from other soft bacteria, including the absence of a type III secretion system contributing to virulence in other soft species. Experimentally established virulence determinants include a putative transcription regulator SirB, two redundant type VI systems, and horizontally acquired clusters Vic1 and Vic, containing vir genes. The genome also revealed traits related to life in planta or environmental conditions, such as a benzoic acid/salicy acid carbox methyltransferase of eukary origin. This work indicates soft bacteria have a reservoir of unknown traits used in the poorly understood stage in planta. The genomic comparison of SCC3 to sequenced Pacter strains, including P. was, provides a basis for further investigation of virulence and phylog of soft bacteria and potentially other.
Researchers investigated the changes in mitochondrial protein expression in cells with depleted of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) using network analysis of gene expression data. They found that proteins involved in typical mitochondrial functions were down-regulated, while proteins responsible for mtDNA repair and regulation and protein transport were upregulated. A comparison of proteome and transcriptome data showed that cells attempted to compensate for mtDNA depletion by modulating protein expression and transport. The study demonstrates that protein composition changes remodels mitochondrial networks in response to dysfunctional states, providing a framework for understanding how cells respond to mitochondrial dysfunctions. Mitochondrial dysfunction caused by mtDNA damage is involved in many diseases and likely drives aging and apoptosis. The study analyzed systemic alterations of protein expressions using integrative network analysis. A data-integrative approach was used to select reliable proteins for network analysis, applying isotope-coded tag quantitative analysis to compare protein abundances in mitochondria from normal and mt-depleted osteosarcoma cells. Downregulated proteins were associated with basal functions such as energy production, metabolism, and protein folding in mitochondria. Results suggest expression of control proteins in different modules is regulated under dysfunctional states. Cells can monitor and respond to changes in conditions through nuclear expression alterations.
Researchers have developed a method to deduce the kinetics of protein synthesis in vivo from transition rates measured in vitro. The method involves two components: introducing the kinetic distance, a concept to compare kinetics of multistep processes in different environments, and minimizing the kinetic distance between in vitro and in vivo processes. The kinetic distance is logarithmically related to transition rates and can be interpreted in terms of free energy barriers. To demonstrate the method's power, it was applied to protein synthesis by ribosomes, a key process of gene expression. The process was described by a cod-specific Markov model with three pathways corresponding to initial cognate, near-cognate, and non-cognate tRNA. Transition rates were determined in vitro and then predicted in vivo by constrained minimization, validated by three sets of in vivo data: cod-dependent speeds, cod-specific dynamics, and missense frequencies. Agreement was found between theory and experiment without adjusting parameters. Deduced in vivo rates led to smaller frequencies than in vitro, primarily due to improved initial tRNA selection. The method is relatively simple computationally and can be applied to biomolecular processes with detailed in vitro kinetics.
Researchers estimated the short-term mutation and recombination rates of Helicobacter pylori by sequencing 39,300 bp in 78 gene fragments from 97 isolates, including 34 pairs of sequential samples and 29 single isolates from 10 families. The accumulation of sequence diversity increased with time in a clock-like manner in sequential isolates. Approximate Bayesian computation estimated short-term mutation rate 1.4×10^-6 to 4.5×10^-6 per nucleotide per year, with three times as many substitutions introduced by recombination as mutation. Long-term rate over millennia 5-17 fold lower due to purifying selection of non-synonymous mutations. Short-term rates vary in bacterial species, spanning several orders of magnitude, e.g., 4.10^-9 per year for Escherichia coli and Salmonella divergence. H. pylori short-term rates 1.4×10^-6 to 4.5×^-6 per year. Long-term rate 5-17 fold lower due to purifying selection.
Researchers have discovered that melanopsin, a pigment found in a subset of retinal ganglion cells, plays a significant role in visual perception beyond driving reflex responses such as circadian entrainment and pupillary movements. Using reporter lines, they found melanin projections extend to the dorsal geniculate nucleus, the origin of thalamocortical neurons, and support physiological responses in the visual cortex in mice lacking rods and cones. Chromatic stimuli isolated melanin responses in mice with intact visual systems reveal melanin input to 40% of neurons in the geniculate nucleus show sustained activation to light. Melanin input increases firing rate of these neurons, indicating melanin encodes irradiance. This is confirmed in melanin knockout mice. The study establishes melanin-based photoreception as a source of sensory input to the thalamocortical system, providing irradiance information, allowing responses in the absence of rods and cones. Melanin is a potential origin of visual perception and may support vision in retinal degeneration.
HIV-1 infection leads to a significant depletion of mucosal CD4+ T cells, which play a crucial role in regulating isotype switching and transepithelial transport of antibodies. This study investigated the impact of CD4+ cell depletion on humoral responses to mucosal antigens in HIV-1-infected individuals. A comprehensive analysis of systemic humoral responses to intestinal microbiota revealed reduced IgG responses to antigens from Proteobacteria and Firmutes, but not Bacteroidetes. Intestinal secretions of antiretroviral-treated HIV-1-infected individuals showed significant elevation of IgM and decreased IgA/Ig and IgG/Ig ratios to various microbial and food antigens. The findings indicate reduced mucosal B cell competence for class recombination from IgM to other isotypes, limiting their capacity to react to gut antigens. Decreased microbiota-specific IgA and IgG may contribute to microbial translocation across the mucosal barrier and systemic dissemination, driving chronic inflammation in HIV-1-infected individuals. The study found elevated total and antigen-specific IgM in intestinal secretions, reduced IgG/Ig and IgA/Ig ratios to microbial and food antigens, reduced Ig to Proteobacteria and Firmutes in plasma, and a negative correlation between CD4 counts and Ig levels. Altered mucosal humoral responses in HIV-1-infected may be due to depleted or altered CD4+ TF and TFR cells, warranting further investigation. The study shows low interdependence of Ig responses between intestinal and systemic compartments. ART-treated HIV-1 individuals exhibited increased IgM and decreased Ig/Ig and Ig/Ig ratios to mucosal antigens, indicating lack of help for class recombination. Altered isotype response may promote local inflammation and mucosal damage. HIV-1-infected individuals with low CD4 counts showed reduced Ig to Proteob and Firmutes.
Researchers propose a new model for population dynamics in ecosystems, where growth of one species is balanced by reduction of others due to availability of resources. Unlike traditional models, this mechanism is driven by abrupt collapse of a single species, freeing resources for others. This is relevant for communities with strain-specific collapses, e.g. by bacteriophages or infectious diseases. The emergent dynamics is characterized by 'diversity waves' triggered by collapses, with diversity peaking at beginning and decreasing exponentially afterwards. Species have bimodal time-aggregated distribution with lower peak by recently collapsed or introduced species and upper not yet collapsed. Waves have self-organized peak structure with long memory across waves, resulting in scale-free distribution with exponent 1.7. The model is robust to variations in rules such as diffusion, growth and extinction rates, and bet-hging strategies. Simulations preserve patterns of collapse dynamics and time-aggregated distribution for most species. The fitness definition of a species by long-term growth rate is inappropriate, as growth is zero in this model. Population dynamics in saturated environments is described by neutral community models with deterministic differences in resource utilization. This model introduces episodic collapses with species sharing same environment, limiting growth. A collapsed population is replenished by individuals diffusing from other environments, with collapse probability increasing with population size. Growth results in steady state at carrying capacity, with diversity waves at longer timescales.
Researchers have re-examined the chemotaxis of Escherichia coli, a well-studied paradigm of simple behavior, and found an additional mechanism of navigation. Chemotaxis is the ability of bacteria to follow chemical gradients, which is crucial for their survival and evolution. E. coli follows gradients by comparing chemector concentrations along its run, a strategy efficient for its size and speed. Concentration differences are detected by a sensory system and transmitted to modulate flagellar rotation, decreasing tumble probability and reorientation if change is positive. This regulation is sufficient to explain chemactic drift up the gradient, assumed only mechanism of E. coli chemaxis. However, simulations predict an additional mechanism: tumbling probability and reorientation also depend on swimming direction along the gradient. The difference in tumbling angles up and down the gradient is small, but results in enhanced cellular velocity along the gradient. A new level of optimization in E. coli chemaxis arises from flagellar switching and fine-tuning tumbling. This strategy is likely used by other peritously flagellated bacteria, indicating another level of bacterial chemaxis development.
Researchers have found that the Stat3 signaling pathway plays a crucial role in the development and maintenance of medullary thymic epithelial (mTE) cells, which are essential for establishing tolerance by presenting self-peptides to autoreactive thymocytes and diverting them to the regulatory T cell lineage. Activation of the NFκB pathway in TE precursors is necessary for TE maturation and proliferation, but Stat3 signaling also contributes to TE homeostasis. Constitutively active Stat3 in the TE compartment increases TE cellularity and bypasses the need for positive thymocyte signals, while conditional deletion of Stat disrupts medullary architecture and reduces TE cells. Stat does not affect TE proliferation, but promotes survival of immature MHCloCDlo TE precursors. In contrast, alterations in the TE compartment do not affect cortical epithelial cellularity or organization. The study demonstrates that, in addition to NF, Stat3 signaling is essential for regulating TE cellularity and medull homeostasis.
Researchers used an in silico approach to identify 511 small non-coding RNAs (sRNAs) in the genome of Clostridium difficile, an emergent pathogen and common cause of nosocomial diarrhea. In parallel, RNA-seq and 5-end RNA-seq were used to globally identify C difficile RNAs and their transcription start sites at three growth conditions: exponential phase, stationary, and starvation. This approach identified 251 putative RNAs, including 94 intergenic regulators, 91 cis-antisense RNAs, and 66 riboswitches. Expression of 35 RNs was confirmed by gene-specific approaches. Some RNs, including antisense involved in C difficile autolytic activity, showed phase-dependent expression. 16 c-diMP-responsive riboswitches were detected, with evidence for regulatory control of motility and biofilm formation. Abundant RNs encoded by C CRIS loci may be important for C survival in bacteri-rich gut communities. This study provides a basis for future characterization and identification of molecular mechanisms of RNA-based regulation in emergent enterogen.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) core protein downregulates the abundance of liver-specific microRNA mi-122 by promoting its destabilization via inhibition of GLD-2, a non-canonical cytoplasmic poly(A) polymer. This decrease in mi-122 expression results in dysregulation of its functions, including its proviral activity for HCV. High-throughput sequencing of small RNAs from liver biops reveals that 22-nt prototype mi-122 is modified at its 3' end by 3'-non-templated and templated nucleotide additions. The proportion of mi-122 bearing a single nucleotide tail is decreased in liver specimens from HCV patients. Single-nucleotide-tailed mi-122 isomers display increased miRNA activity and stability compared to 22-nt prototype mi-122, with 3-terminal extension catalyzed by unique nucleotidyl transfer activity of GL-2. HCV protein specifically inhibits GL-2, and interaction with GL-2 in cytoplasm is responsible for mi- downregulation. Inhibition of GL-2 by HCV protein affects multiple miRN, including mi-122, by decreasing proportion of mono-adenylated isomers. Sequencing of small RNAs from liverops reveals among top 50 abundantly expressed miRN in tissues, six mi exhibit decrease in 3-end adenylated isomer levels upon H infection. mi-122 levels in human liverops from healthy and H patients are analyzed, showing decreased mi-122 in specimens from patients (66.3%, 72.7%, and 74.1% in H-1, H-2, and H-3 respectively) compared to normal N. Results demonstrate decrease of 23- and 24-nt mi-122 bearing single or dinucleotide in liver from H patients. Non-templ addition of adenyl residues, major modification of mi-122, is inhibited by H.
Researchers have discovered a pattern of acquired immunity to Trypanosoma brucei infection in wild lions in the Serengeti ecosystem. The prevalence of T. brucei infection decreases with age, consistent with an increase in cross-immunity following exposure to the genetically diverse species T. congolense latu, the causative agent of human sleeping sickness. T. bruce rhodesense disappears by 6 years of age in response to cross-immunity from other trypanosomes, including non-pathogenic subspecies T. bruce bruce. This suggests novel pathways for vaccinations against trypanosomias, despite the complex antigenic surface proteins of these parasites. 

Sereni lions are co-infected with multiple trypan species, including T cong, bruce, and bodesense, and are exposed to cong, kil, viv, and sim. Tryosomes switch surface glycoproteins every 3-5 days to avoid host recognition. This is the first epidemiological evidence of acquired immunity to trypan in any host. It's unlikely innate immunity is responsible, as the pattern is seen only in T bruce and not cong. Observations are consistent with immunity mounted against cong, allowing lions to clear T bruce by 3-5 years and eliminate bodes by 6. Frequent exposure by tse bites accelerates onset and extent, prevalence should be lowest in high-exposure areas, as seen in wood lions compared to plains and bodes regions.
Researchers used mathematical modeling and sensitivity analysis to explore the idea that mechanistic models of human coagulation cascades, despite uncertainty, can be computationally screened for points of fragility, which could serve as therapeutic targets. They tested this hypothesis on a well-studied coagulation cascade model, validated with 92 proteins and 148 protein-protein interactions, using 21 published datasets from different in vitro coagulation models. The model simulated platelet activation and thrombin profiles in presence and absence of anticoagulants were consistent with measured values, with a mean correlation of 0.87 across trials. Sensitivity coefficients, measuring robustness or fragility of a mechanism, were calculated using Monte Carlo. In absence anticoagul, and surface factor X/activated factor (Xa) and thrombin-mediated platelet activation were fragile, while IX/IX and V/VIII activation and activity were robust. Anti-Xa and thrombin inhibitors, classes of anticoagulants, have FDA approval for prevention of venous thromboembolism following surgical intervention and treatment deep venous thromosis pulmonary embolism. In vitro and vivo evidence supports prediction IXIX activity robust. Results support hypothesis computationally derived points of fragility human cascades as basis for target selection despite uncertainty.
Researchers investigated the dynamics of bacteriophage (phage) interactions with Campylobacterium jejuni, a foodborne pathogen, and a virulent phage in an in vitro system. They combined experimental and modeling approaches to examine the non-linear kinetics of phage-bacteria interactions. Phage-insensitive populations of C. jejuni arose, the first phage study to test against in vitro models of ph-bacteria incorporating ph-insensitive bacteria. A simple model fit the data well, confirming inundation and proliferation thresholds are crucial for phage therapy. The model was fit to time series data to estimate thresholds and rate constants, revealing culture-density dependent phage infectivity features. The study demonstrates how empirical insights can be enhanced by kinetic models, emphasizing the importance of in vitro studies for understanding in vivo phage therapy.

A theoretical framework for non-linear properties of ph as self-replicating pharmaceuticals is needed. A PKD model of ph-bacteria was tested against experimental data for C. jej and a virulent ph. Characteristics in vitro may differ from in vivo, but in vitro testing is a necessary step for applying PKD theory in clinical and in vivo settings. Most ph-b studies have focused on ecological and evolutionary aspects, rather than treatment effectiveness. Approaches should be recast in terms of ph therapy to contribute to advancing therapeutic goals. Partially-resistant cells may cause bacterial resurgence, highlighting the need for threshold understanding ph-b interactions. Cells resistant to ph are expected above a certain size, ph is a selective treatment.
Researchers have identified a Toll-like receptor (TLR) in the snail Biomphalaria glabra that plays a crucial role in the snail's immune response to the parasitic flatworm Schistoma mansoni, which causes schistosias. This disease affects over 260 million people worldwide, mainly in tropical and subtropical regions. The snail is an intermediate host for S. mansoni, a trait shared among all digene trematodes. The study found that the TLR, named BTL, was more abundant in snails resistant to S. mansoni infection and its expression increased when challenged with the parasite. Knocking down BTL in resistant snails made them susceptible to infection. This is the first functional characterization of a gastropod TLR and demonstrates BTL's importance in snail immune response to S. mansoni. The study contributes to understanding the sn-schosome relationship, crucial for disease prevention and control efforts, as the World Health Organization aims to eliminate schos by 2025.
Researchers developed an ELISA test to detect and quantify IgG antibodies against saliva proteins from the salivary glands of Aedes aegypt and Aedes polensis in human populations exposed to these mosquitoes. A cross-sectional study in Tahiti and Moore islands, where both species are present, found that 98% and 68% of individuals had IgG against Aegypt and Aepolensis salivary gland extracts, respectively. In contrast, ELISA on a cohort from metropolitan France, not exposed to Aedes, showed 97% had no Ig against saliv gland proteins. Analysis of cohorts from different entomological contexts showed no cross-reactivity between Aegpt and Aolensis saliv extracts. The Ig response to saliv gland proteins is a valid biomarker of human exposure to bites of Aegpt and Aolensis. This immunological tool will enhance understanding of exposure to mosquito bites, identify areas of high disease risk, and evaluate vector control efficacy in Pacific and tropical settings.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) pathogenicity is linked to its ability to adapt to the intracellular environment of macrophages, which involves interference with the host cell's metabolic machinery. Temporal profiling of metabolic flux in infected macrophages with virulent mycobacterial strains confirmed this, identifying a subset of host reactions targeted by the pathogen. The goal of regulation is to integrate macrophage survival with mycobacterial sustenance, converging host and pathogen factors to determine pathogenicity. Macrophage survival sensitizes TB susceptibility to glycemic status, while pathogen ensures virulence contributes to pathology. 

The study examined time-dependent modulations in macroph metabolism after infection with mycobacterial strains varying in genotype and phenotype, confirming M pathity linked to regulation of host metabolism. Pathogenic strategies employed by M were aided by a mycobacterial panel with manifold virulence traits. Glycemic levels contribute to pathity by influencing macroage apoptosis, revealing an additional facet to the relationship between diabetes and TB. Immunity is a determinant of disease susceptibility, but glyc status also impacts innate defense against M infection. The study highlights metabolic dictates pathology of TB, supporting revisiting paradigms for understanding M pathity.
Researchers investigated the role of ZHP-3, the Caenorhabditis elegans ortholog of the yeast ZIP3 gene, in meiotic recombination and synaptonemal complex (SC) assembly and bivalent formation. Z-3 is required for crossover recombination, and its localization is dynamic during meiotic prophase, shifting from the length of the SC to asymmetric on the SC and eventually to foci marking crossover events. A Z-3::GFP transgene partially complements a null mutation, promoting wild-type levels of recombination but high aneuploidy among progeny, indicating defects in meiotic segregation. The bivalent structure is perturbed in this mutant, suggesting segregation defects result from inability to remodel chromosomes in response to crossovers. smo-1 mutants exhibit similar phenotypes at higher temperatures, and smo-;Z-G double mutants exhibit more severe meiotic defects, consistent with a role for SUMO in SC assembly and bivalent differentiation. Z-3 coordinates recombination with SC assembly and bivalent formation, a conserved role in Zip3/Z-3 coupling recombination with SC morphogenesis. In C. elegans, Z- remains at crossover sites to restructure bivalent and regulate chias function, suggesting conserved function in coordinating crossover with SC morph. In S. cerevisiae, ZIP3 couples recombination with synaps initiation. C. elegans chromosome undergoes one recombination during meiosis, directing SC disassembly in diplot/diakinesis. Z- foci may correspond me crosso, tested in mutants defective crossover formation. Z- localizes to crossover sites in late pachene and diplot, marking reciprocal exchange.
Aedes aegyptus, a tropical mosquito species, has invaded temperate regions of Europe and the US, posing a public health concern due to its ability to transmit arboviruses and nuisance due to its aggressive daytime biting behavior. This study investigated eco-climatic factors affecting Aeegus abundance in metropolitan and suburban areas in Rome, Italy, which was colonized in 1997 and is one of the most infested areas in Southern Europe. Longitudinal monitoring was conducted along a 70km transect across the urban and densely populated area. Fine spatiotemporal datasets were used to analyze the effect of climatic and socioenvironmental variables on Aeeg abundance. Results showed association between anthropized habitats and high abundance in metropolitan and suburban areas, with "green" islands" of abundance in metropolitan areas, and bim seasonal dynamics with a peak in autumn due to heavy rains and permissive temperatures. Increase in vegetation cover was negatively associated with mosquito abundance in both environments. Temperature and rainfall during the sampling period showed Aeeg dynamics in metropolitan and suburban environments. The analysis highlighted a complex relationship between landscape and mosquito abundance, with sticky traps monitored for 18 weeks on a weekly basis. A fine spatiotemporal dataset was built to analyze the effect of climatic and socioenvironmental variables on Ae abundance in 21 stations. The study provides indications to prioritize mosquito control measures in urban areas with high human-mos contact and arvirus transmission risk, and highlights public health risks after summer months with high densities.
Researchers have investigated the role of phthiocer dimoceros (DIM) in the virulence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) during the early stages of infection, specifically when the bacteria encounter macrophages. They found that DIM participate in the receptor-mediated phagocytosis of Mtb and prevention of phagosome acidification. The effects of DIM require changes in membrane fluidity, as demonstrated by experiments with cholesterol-depleting drugs that abolished the differences in phagocyt efficiency and phosome acidification between wild-type and mutant strains. Insertion of a cholesterol probe in living cells showed that the polarity of the membrane hydrophobic core changed upon contact with Mtb, while lateral diffusion of cholesterol was unaffected. This effect was dependent on DIM and consistent with the observed changes in membrane model. The researchers propose that DIM control invasion of macrophages by Mtb by targeting lipid organization in the membrane, modifying its biophysical properties, favoring receptor-mediated phocytosis of M and contributing to phagomal pH driving bacilli in a protective niche.
Researchers have developed a novel analysis method to study the dynamics of small neural networks composed of a few neurons, which is not well described by mean-field approximations. These approximations are useful for large networks but fail to capture the behavior of small networks, leading to differences between mean-field and real network behavior. Many neuroscience problems involve studying mesoscopic networks of tens of neurons, but methods describing small networks are rare, hindering progress in understanding dynamics at intermediate scales. The new analysis is analytically tractable and numerically determines bifurcations in small networks of homogeneous excitatory and inhibitory neurons. For strong inhibition, networks exhibit complex dynamics through spontaneous symmetry-breaking, forming multiple solutions in neural equations. This change is a finite-size effect, revealing differences between mesoscopic circuits and mean approximation. Symmetry-breaking enables mesoscopic networks to regulate heterogeneity, reducing detrimental noise effects on information processing. 

The analysis differs from mean-field with strong inhibitory weights, undergoing a pitchfork bifurcation with multiple solutions emerging. New bifcations occur, enriching complexity. The dynamics of small networks was pioneered by Beer, studying bifurcations with symmetric weights and asymptotic approximations. Most literature deals with 2-4 neurons, while methods for tens of neurons are limited. The work extends analysis to biologically plausible networks with exact bifcation manifolds and less constraints. A finite-size model with excitatory and inhibitory populations is considered. Mean-field provides an approximation, neglecting phenomena like transitions and correlations.
Researchers investigated the presence and viability of Leishmania parasites in extralesional sites of dermalishias patients using Leish 7RNA as a target. They evaluated the feasibility of discriminating parasite viability by PCR of Leish 7RNA in relation to luciferase activity of transfected intracellular amastigotes in dose-response of Glant cytotoxicity assays. Monocytes, tonsil swabs, and skin aspirates of 28 cutaneous and mucocutaneous leishias patients were screened by DNA amplification/Southern blot. Positive samples were analyzed by quantitative PCR of Leish 7RNA genes and transcripts. 7RNA amplification coincided with lucifer activity, confirming parasite viability. Of 22 patients presenting DNA in extraional samples, Leish 7RNA genes or transcripts were detected in one or more DNA samples in 100% and 73% patients, respectively. Gene transcript number amplified from extraional tissues were comparable to lesions.7RNA were detected in 13/19 (68%) monocytes, 5/12 (42%) tonsil sw, 4/11 (36%) normal aspir, and 22/25 (88%) lesions; genes were quantifiable 15/19 (79%) monocytes, 12 (92%) tons sw, 8 (73%) normal aspir. Viable parasites present in extraional sites, including monocytes, tons, and skin of dermalias patients. Leish 7RNA is informative for clinical and epidemiologic investigations of leishias. The correlation number of 7RNA transcripts with dose-dependent reduction of parasite in response to Glant substantiates the validity of this target as a viability marker.
Researchers investigated the relationship between chromatin features and DNA replication timing in Drosila using a comprehensive dataset of 95 chromatin-binding proteins (CBPs) and histone modifications (HMs). They found that combinations of CBPs and pairwise interactions between HMs can predict DNA replication timing with high accuracy across the genome and cell types. A simplified model of the relationship between chromatin landscape and replication was derived using independent feature importance analysis, achieving 80% of the full model's accuracy with six terms. Pairwise HMs also predicted differential replication timing across cell types. The study supports the existence of combinatorial HM patterns for DNA replication and identifies cell-type key elements for further investigation.
Researchers investigated the spread of Dengue virus serotypes 1, 2, and 3 in Brazil using a statistical framework of complete genome sequences. They found that new lineages of all three serotypes were introduced within 7-10 year intervals, likely from the Caribbean to North and Northeast regions of Brazil, and dispersed at a rate of approximately 0.5 km/day. Joint analysis of evolutionary, epidemiological, and ecological data indicated that transportation of humans and/or mosquitoes, rather than Aedes aegypti infestation or geographical distances, determined Dengue virus spread in Brazil. The study used 178 Brazilian genome sequences to determine factors of Dengue dispersal on a country scale using GL spatial model. Predictors of viral spread included geographic distances, air traffic, Aedes aegypt infestation, human densities, and spatial area of each location at regional level (k=5). Results supported a human role in spread of Deng through transportation of humans/or vectors. Introduction of new lineages was followed by epidemic amplification in 7-10 cycles. Periodic Dengue ser-specific incidence peaks coincided with introduction of new line in Brazil every 7-10 years.
Researchers investigated how differences in the organization of receptive fields (RF) across three parallel sensory maps in weakly electric fish influence correlations between activities of electrosensory pyramidal neurons. Using a model based on anatomical differences in RF center size and overlap, they initially predicted large differences in correlated activity across maps. However, in vivo electrophysiological recordings showed that electrosensoryram neurons across all three segments displayed nearly identical correlations. To explain this result, they incorporated RF surround effects into the model, varying both RF gain and size relative to center, and found multiple structures gave similar correlations. Incorporating physiological RF differences between maps in the model resulted in similar correlation levels. This suggests RF overlap alone does not determine correlations, important for understanding RF's influence on neural activity. The study is the first to quantify and compare correlations between pyram neuron activities across all three maps, using a combination of modeling and electrophysiology. In vivo recordings revealed identical levels of correlation across all segments. The antagonistic center-surround organization of RF was considered to explain the result. Other studies have focused on spiking nonlinearity's influence on correlation, while less is known about RF's effect on activity. This study in sensory systems with well-characterized RF and anatomical structure aids understanding of RF's influence on correlations. Different RF-surround combinations gave identical correlations in the model, with sign and magnitude determined by positively and negatively correlated inputs. Pyram cells in maps display antagonistic center-surround RF, similar to retinal ganglion cells in the visual system.
This study investigates the impact of noise correlations between neurons on population coding performance in a general setting with no assumptions about tuning curves or heterogeneity. The results provide insights into the role of noise in population coding, summarized in the form of theorems and illustrated with numerical examples. The main contributions are: (1) the "sign rule" (SR) states that if correlations between neurons have opposite signs to signal correlations, performance improves compared to independent case, holding for different metrics and levels of heterogeneity; (2) SR is not a necessary condition for good coding, and diverse correlation structures can improve performance, some violating SR; (3) a set of necessary and sufficient conditions for performance in noise to be as good as without noise. A mathematical setup investigates how performance changes with varying correlations, making no assumptions about curves or heterogeneity. The results provide general insights into population coding. An example illustrates distinct regimes with properties of noise leading to optimal coding. The "sign rule" states that correlations opposite to signal improve performance, demonstrated in literature and formally for homogenous correlations. Theorem 1 establishes SR for pairwise neurons with consistent signal correlations, holding for heterogeneous populations. Conditions for chosen correlations to yield performance as good as deterministic responses are identified, satisfied with high probability for large populations.
Researchers investigated the impact of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on the susceptibility of Staphylococcus aureus to antibiotics in chronic coinfections. They found that Pseudas aerugin alters S. aureus susceptibility to bactericidal antibiotics in a strain-dependent manner and identified three interactions that either antagonize or potentiate antibiotic activity against S. aure. Pseud aerugin Las endopeptase potentiates vancomycin activity by facilitating proton-motive-independent uptake, while 2-hepty-4-hydroquinoline N-oxide (HQ) induces multidrug tolerance in S. aure through respiratory inhibition and ATP reduction. The production of these factors varies between clinical isolates and corresponds to their capacity to alter S aureus antibiotic susceptibility. Vancom treatment of S aure mouse burn infection is potentiated by the presence of Las-producing Pseud aerugin population. The study demonstrates that susceptibility is complex and dependent not only on the pathogen genotype but also on interactions with other microorganisms in the environment.
Researchers investigated the mechanism of thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) in patients with deng virus (DENV) infection, which can lead to complications such as bleeding and plasma leakage. They found that patients with deng had higher levels of von Wille factor (VWF), a protein involved in blood clotting, and platelets bound more VWF to their surface. The amount of VWF on platelets correlated with plate count. Sialic acid, a molecule on plate surface, was reduced in deng patients, assessed by lectin binding. Sial acid is neuraminidase-labile, but deng virus has no neuraminidase activity. No neuraminase activity was detected in deng plasma and transferrin was not desialylated. In contrast, VWF binding to glycoprotein 1 on platelets using V-activating protein resulted in sial removal by plate neuraminase to plate surface. Neuraminase inhibitor oseltiv reduced V-induced plate desial. The study shows excessive V binding to platelets in deng results in neuraminase-mediated desial and clearance.
Researchers have identified a new regulatory mechanism in the human genome called bidirectional promoters, where two adjacent genes with opposite transcription start sites are controlled by a shared regulatory region called a bidirectional promoter. These promoters are often associated with genes involved in DNA repair and may play a role in cancer development. Using a database of expressed sequence tags (ESTs), they found the most comprehensive collection of human genes under bidirectional promoters and discovered new promoters that function as alternative or novel transcripts. A significant enrichment of bidirectional promoters was found in somatic cancer genes, including breast and ovarian cancer. The use of this structure in the genome suggests it regulates co-expression among groups of genes. Microarray data from 79 human tissues verified regulatory networks controlled by bidirectional promoters, with subsets containing similar transcription factor sites including conserved ETS, ERBB, FCD, and BRCA. The regulation of genes in co-expression, especially in cancer, is a step toward defining molecular events contributing to disease.

A new algorithm was developed to map bidirectional promoters in the genome using ESTs. The set of bidirectional elucidates relationships among regulated by promoters through co-expression. A subset of promoters regulating breast and ovarian cancer genes contain common transcription sites. Misregulation of bidirectional, especially with common sites, is a plausible scenario for cancer development. Experimental data confirmed expression of flanking transcripts for 91%, 58%, and 65% of promoters in Genes, mRNA, and EST datasets. Enrichment of bidirectional with DNA repair genes implies a link to cancer pathways. Data confirm association with somatic cancer and indicate type relevant. Bidirectional associated with uter and ovarian cancers were examined. Expression-clustering suggested bid should not be classified as one network or divided into pairs. Ovarian genes showed intermediate relationships between extremes.
Researchers conducted a whole-genome analysis of 37 fly species from 22 different Diptera families to uncover hidden diversity in sex chromosome karyotypes. They found over a dozen different sex configurations, with the dot chromosome repeatedly used as the sex chromosome, reflecting the ancestral kary of higher Diptera. Some species have undifferentiated sex chromosomes, others replaced the dot as sex, or incorporated up to three chromosomal elements into sex, and some have female heterogamy (Z sex) chromosomes. Transcriptome analysis showed dosage compensation evolved through upregulation of single X in males, but X chromosomes have gene deficiency with male-bi expression, possibly due to sex selective pressures. This diversity provides a resource to study sex biology in a comparative manner, showing similar forces shaped unique sex chromosomes in fly taxa.
Researchers investigated the presence of Zika virus (ZIK) antibodies in mothers who gave birth to babies with microcephaly and those who gave birth to healthy babies in Hawaii between 2009-2012. They tested maternal blood for ZIK IgM and IgG antibodies using commercially available ELISA kits. Blood from one mother who delivered a baby with microaly tested positive for ZIK IgM (16.6%) and three tested positive for ZV IgG (50%). ZV showed a trend with microaly. ZV IgG positive mothers were more likely to deliver babies with microaly than those negative for Z IgG (OR=11.0, 95% CI=0.8-147.9, p=0.083). Similarly, ZV IgM positive mothers were more likely to deliver babies with microaly than those negative for IgM (OR=6.8, 95 CI=0.2-195.1). Data suggest a link between ZV infection and microaly and presence of Z cases in the US as early as 2009.
Researchers investigated the transmission of Mycobacterium ulcerans (MU), the causative agent of Buruli ulcer (BU), in the Ashanti region of Ghana by tracking infections to specific water bodies using Variable Number Tand Repeat (VN) typing. Environmental samples from 10 water bodies in four endemic communities were genotyped with four VN loci from the MU99 genome, and compared to 14 confirmed BU patient samples. Polymorphism was confirmed by sequencing. MU was found in three types of water, significantly higher in biofilm. Four genotypes, W, X, Y, and Z, were typed in both human and environmental samples. Other genotypes were only found in water. A mouse with characteristic BU lesion was infected with MU. The study suggests patients were infected from community water bodies and that small mammals within communities may be susceptible to MU. Transmission may involve contact with environments and water acting as vehicles for disseminating strains.
Researchers analyzed a comprehensive database of 27,723 records of 971 alien bird species worldwide to investigate the global distribution of alien species richness and its drivers. They found that the origins and identities of introduced birds were largely driven by European colonialism, mainly from Britain, but recent introductions involve more species and countries, driven by increasing economic activity. Global bird species richness is highest at mid-latitudes and determined by anthropogenic factors, notably the number of introduced species, "colonization pressure". Environmental factors also play a role, with native and alien species positively associated. Colonization pressure is key to understanding species richness, areas with high native species resistance to alien colonization at a global scale, emphasizing ongoing threats from species introductions. The study uses birds as a model, underpinned by a database of alien species worldwide, combining colonization with abiotic, biotic, and anthropogenic variables to identify determinants of variation in species richness. Global patterns of species are determined by human and biotic factors. Regions with high species richness are located in temperate mid-latitudes, former colonies, developing countries, high GDP, and high colonization pressure.
Upstream Binding Factor (UBF) is a multi-HMG-box protein that plays a crucial role in RNA polymerase I (RPol I) transcription, but its DNA sequence selectivity and ability to form nucleosome-like protein complexes suggest a broader function in chromatin structure. Depletion of UBF reduces the number of actively transcribed ribosomal RNA (rRNA) genes, but has little effect on rRNA synthesis or cell proliferation, leaving its requirement for R I transcription unclear. Using gene deletion mice, U is shown to be essential for embryo development beyond morula. Conditional deletion in cultures reveals U is essential for rRNA transcription and defines chromatin conformation of both gene and enhancer sequences. Loss U prevents formation of SL/TIFB initiation and recruitment RPI-R3/T1 complex, accompanied by H3K9, histone H1, and HPα, but not de novo DNA methylation. Genes retain p-acetyl4 and H2, suggesting rRNA can maintain potentially active state. In contrast, histone H1 binding is dependent on U, suggesting positive role in activity. Unexpectedly, rRNA synthesis does not suppress transcription 5, tRNA or snRNA, or expression hundred genes in ribosome biogenesis. Loss U induces formation of large subnuclear structure resembling nucleolar body (NPB) of oocytes and embryos. These somatic NPB contain rRNA synthesis factors but not associate r gene loci (NOR).
Research on the role of Wingless/Wnt in adult intestinal compartmentalization in Drosophila has revealed a new understanding of its long-range action in tissue patterning. Contrary to the conventional model that secretion and movement of Wingless from its source are essential for patterning, a membrane-tether form of Wingless produced viable adults with normal morphology, suggesting dispensability of secretion and movement. In the adult intestine, Wingless gradients demarcate major boundaries between compartments, and its critical roles include regulation of target gene activation, boundary formation, stem cell proliferation, epithelial cell specification, muscle differentiation, gut folding, and signaling with Decaplegic pathway. Tethering Wingless disrupts these roles, indicating direct long-range action of Wing in pattering is required. This is supported by previous studies in larval wing, and has implications for development, homeostasis, and Wnt-driven disease. The adult gut forms through distinct mechanisms during metamorphosis and faces functional demands, including epithelial turnover and regeneration. W pathway activation in the intestine was controversial, but resolved by studies on conserved pathways Wingless and Decaplegic. W pathway inhibition in epithelium indicates W secretion and movement are critical for proper W activation during gut development. This identifies a context where direct and long action of Wing in patter is unambiguous.
Researchers investigated the role of urokinase plasogen activator (uPA) in the pathogenesis of Group A streptococcus (GAS), a bacterium responsible for significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. They found that uPA contributes to plasmin recruitment and invasive disease initiation in vivo. In the absence of host plasogen activators, streokinase was required for surface plmin acquisition by GAS. However, in the absence of streokin, uPA was sufficient to promote surface plmin acquisition by strain 544 during incubation with plmin or human plasma. GAS also activated zym pro-uPA in human plasma. To assess u's contribution to invasive disease, a transgenic mouse model was employed. C57/BL/6 and AlbG mice expressing human plmin transgene were more susceptible to invasive disease than u− mice. Decreased virulence in u− mice correlated with reduced dissemination and surface plmin by GAS. These findings have implications for understanding GAS pathogenesis and targeting plmin activation in bacterial infections.
Helicobacter pylori exploits a unique repertoire of Type IV secretion system components for pilus assembly at the bacteria-host interface. Colonization of the stomach by H. pylori is a risk factor for gastric cancer development. The H. pylori pathogenic island (cPAI) encodes components of a Type IV system (T4) that translocates the oncoprotein Cag into gastric epithelial cells, and Cag is a component of cTSS that binds host αβ1 integrin. A mass spectrometry-based approach revealed co-purification of Cag, C (integrin-binding protein), and C (protein with sequence similarity to C). These proteins are encoded by contiguous genes in cPA and detectable on the bacterial surface. All proteins are required for C translocation into host cells and H. pyl-induced IL-8 secretion by gastric epithelial cells; however, proteins are not homologous components of T in other species. Scanning microscopy analysis shows these proteins involved in pilus formation between H. pyl and epithelial cells. Δag and Δ mutant strains fail to form pilus, whereas Δ strain exhibits hyperiliated phenotype and produces elongated pilus compared to wild-type. This suggests pilus dimensions regulated by. A conserved C-terminal hexapeptide present in, C, C, and C. Deletion motifs abrogates C translocation and IL-8, and motifs C-terminal C and are for pilus formation.
Researchers conducted a study to identify biomarkers of protection against bovine tuberculosis (bTB) in cattle using global transcriptome analysis. They vaccinated calves with Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) or a heterologous BCG prime-adenoviral vectored subunit boosting protocol and challenged them with Mycobacterium bovis (M. bo). Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) from vaccinated-protected, vaccinated-unprotected, and unvaccinated control cattle were analyzed by RNA sequencing, revealing 668 differentially expressed genes. Cytokine-cytokine interaction was the most significant pathway, with Interleukin-22 (IL-22) identified as the dominant predictor of protection, alongside Interferon-gamma (INF-γ). The study confirmed the importance of IL-22 as a predictor of vaccine efficacy in an independent set of PB samples from BCG vaccinated and unaccinated calves. BCG vaccination induced protective immunity in some calves, with resolution of M. bo infection, similar to humans with Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Promising strategies have improved upon BCG, but it remains the prototype to judge novel vaccine efficacy. Predicting success after vaccination before pathogen exposure is crucial for vaccine development. Previous studies showed BCG induced cell-mediated immunity with strong INF-γ production. Several strategies improved B efficacy, including subunit, DNA, protein, and recombinant vaccines. No reliable immunological correlates of protection exist.
Researchers investigated the role of centrosomal microtubule components, specifically the γ-tubulin ring complex (γ-TRC) and AIR-1/AurA, at the apical microtub organizing center (MOC) in Caenorhabditis elegans embryonic epithelial cells. They found that G-1, a core component of γ-T, is required to recruit other γ-T components, including MZ-1, to the apical MOC. In contrast, AIR-1 and MZ-1 are necessary to recruit γ-T to the centrosome but not to the apical MOC. Surprisingly, microtules remain organized at the apical MOC upon γ-T and AIR co-depletion and depletion of other microtule regulators. However, loss of G-1 removes a subset of dynamic microules, and the remaining microules grow faster. These results suggest distinct microule centers use different proteins for function and the apical MOC is composed of γ-T-dependent and -independent microules competing for limited resources.
Researchers compared 11 different methods for phasing human genomes, which is the process of determining the parental origin of each nucleotide of the 23 pairs of homologous chromosomes. Most sequencing initiatives do not phase the genome due to costs and complexities. They used the publicly available GIAB version of the NA78 genome as a standard. The methods included laboratory-based assays and computational approaches that reconstruct phase from sequencing data or population haplotype information. Metrics included error rates, haplotype lengths, proportion of fully-resolved genes, and phasing accuracy between SNVs. A hybrid approach combining population phasing, genome sequencing data, and reference haplotype frequencies provided fast and accurate phasing. Population phasing was enhanced with genome-wide data, and parental genotypes reduced phasing errors by up to tenfold. A majority voting scheme for consensus haplotype construction improved performance and coverage. Regions with phasing errors were identified, including low polymorphism and SNV density.
Researchers have investigated the type-III secretion system in Salmonella enterica, a process used by gram-negative pathogens to secrete virulence factors and flagellum components into host cells. They found that flagellar type-III secretion can occur without ATPase activity, increasing proton motive force and flagellar substrate levels. The study shows that increased proton force bypasses the need for the Salmonella pathogenic island vir-associated type-III ATPase for secretion. This suggests that type-III ATPases enhance efficiency under limited substrate concentrations and are dispensable in the type-III export process. Type-III secretion involves substrate recognition, chaperone release, and unfolding in an ATP-dependent manner. The study demonstrates ATP activity is not necessary for protein export via type-III systems. The proposed function of the TSS-associated ATP complex is to deliver substrates to the apparatus and ensure efficient unfolding. Increased proton motive force assists export of late substrates, overcoming the requirement for the FliJ ATPase complex. This has implications for the evolution of bacterial flagellum and type-III systems. The flagellar biogenesis in Salmonella is mediated by a flagellar type-III system, with core components evolutionarily related to virulence type-III systems. Elimination of proton force inhibits flagellar type-III secretion, while ATP hydrolysis energizes chaper release and secretion.
Researchers employed chemical reaction network theory to investigate the capacity for bistability in over 40,000 simple gene regulatory networks (GRNs) consisting of two transcription factor (TF)-coding genes and their associated proteins. They found that approximately 90% of these networks exhibited bistability, including some without the typical cooperativity associated with bistable systems, and most of which could only be identified through subnetwork analysis. The two-gene family of networks was topologically sorted based on the presence or absence of biochemical reactions, revealing eleven minimal bistable networks (i.e., bistable networks not containing smaller bistable subnetworks). The large number of previously bistable topologies suggests switch-like behavior in GRNs arises easily and is not easily lost through evolution. The study integrated publicly available protein-protein interaction, protein-DNA, and gene expression data from Saccharomyces cerevisiae to identify GRNs predicted to behave in bistable fashion. A comprehensive parameter-free survey identified 36,771 bistable GRNs out of 40,680, including eleven without TF cooperativity associated with switch circuits. The two-g bistable network can be understood as a set of eleven minimal bistable networks, rendered monostable by removal of one or more reactions. 36% of 40,680 networks are bistable for some parameters, 9% have multiple steady states, and 6.5% monost regardless of parameters.
Researchers have identified mutations in the HY2 gene as a cause of orofacial clefting, a common birth defect with both genetic and environmental components. The HY2 gene encodes hyaluronidase 2, which degrades extracellular hyaluron, a component of the developing heart and palatal matrix. Transfection assays showed that mutations destabilize the molecule, reducing HY2 protein levels. Consistent with clinical presentation, investigations of Hy2- mice revealed craniofac abnormalities, including submucal cleft. Additionally, triatum sinister and hearing loss were found in a proportion of Hy- mice, also incompletely penetrant features in humans. These findings identify a new genetic cause of oracialing in humans and mice, and the first molecular cause of triatum in humans, highlighting the importance of HY2 and hyuron turnover for normal and development.
Researchers have investigated the molecular mechanisms underlying mechanosensory regeneration in auditory hair cells, specifically focusing on the tip links that connect stereocilia and convey force to transduction channels. Current models propose a static composition of the tip, with protocadherin 15 (PCD15) at the lower end and cadherin 23 (CD23) at the upper end. However, these links are subjected to sound-induced forces throughout an organism's life and can regenerate, but the molecular details of this process were unknown. A novel implementation of backscatter electron microscopy was used to visualize immuno-gold particles and stereilia, showing that functional mechanotrans-mediating links have at least two compositions: PCD15/CD23 or PCD15PC15. During regeneration, shorter links with nearly equal amounts of PCD15 at both ends appear, mediating mechanotrans currents of normal amplitude but abnormal Ca2-dependent decay. The mature P15CD23 link composition is re-established, concomitant with complete recovery of adaptation. The study provides a mechanism for regeneration and maintenance of mechanens function in postotic auditory cells and identifies components of the mechanotrans machinery.
Researchers conducted a mass spectrometry-based metabolomic analysis of sera from adult patients with deng fever (DF) and deng hemorrhagic fever (DHF) at the critical and recovery phases of infection. They identified 29 differentially expressed metabolites between DF and DH, including bile acids, purines, acylcarnines, phospholipids, and amino acids. Bile acids were up to 5-fold higher in DH compared to DF patients and correlated with higher levels of aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT), indicating liver injury in DH. Uric acid, the most abundant antioxidant in blood, was 1.5-fold lower in DH compared to DF, suggesting decreased capacity for endogenous defense and elevated oxidative stress in DH. In the recovery phase, eight metabolites remained significantly higher or lower in DH, including chenodeoxycholic acid, a bile acid observed in the critical phase, indicating prolonged liver impact from DENV in DH patients. The study revealed metabolic pathways linked to DH in the critical and recovery phases of deng infection, providing insights into host and DENV interactions between DF and DH.
Researchers have identified and characterized the guanosine 5'-monophosphate reductase (GMPR) enzyme in Trypanosoma brucei, the causative parasite of African trypanosomias. GR catalyzes the conversion of guanos 5'-ophosphate (GMP) to inosine 5'-ophosphate (IMP, a key step in purine nucleotide metabolism. Unlike mammalian and bacterial GRs, T. bruce GR has a unique insertion of cystathion synthase (CBS) domain and is localized to glyosomes. Recombinant T. br GR showed distinct enzymatic properties, including increased activity with monovalent cations K+ and NH+ and inhibition by ribavir, a purine analog. These findings suggest a distinct mechanism of GR in T. br compared to its host organisms. Inhibitory effect of ribavir on T. br proliferation was demonstrated in a dose-dependent manner, indicating potential for ribavir as a therapeutic agent against trypanomias.
Researchers used molecular simulations to study how two sodium channel-blocking drugs, benzocaine and phenyto, interact with the bacterial voltage-gated sodium channel NavAb. The study aimed to understand how these drugs enter and bind to the channel, which is crucial for developing next-generation drugs that target specific types of sodium channels in the body. The researchers found that both drugs have two binding sites in the pore, characterized by non-specific hydrophobic interactions: one above the activation gate and at the entrance to the lipid-filled fenestrations. Three methods independently confirmed these sites, with binding to the gate being slightly more favorable than the fenstration. The drugs can pass through the fenestrations with small energy barriers, suggesting this may be the proposed hydrophobic route for entry. The study highlights the importance of specific residues in directing drugs into the fenestr and forming binding sites.
MyD signaling in dendritic cells and intestinal epithelial cells plays a crucial role in controlling immunity against intestinal infection with C. rodium. MyD-deficient mice are highly susceptible to various bacterial infections, but the cell-specific contribution of MyD in intestinal immunity is poorly understood. A novel murine knock-in model enabled cell-specific reactivation of functional MyD in My-deficient mice. MyD signaling in CD11+ dendritic cells was sufficient to activate dendritic cells and induce group 3 innate lymphoid cell response as well as colonic Th17/Th cell response to C. rodium infection. Restricting MyD signaling to other cells, including macrophages, T cells, or innate lymphoid cells did not induce intestinal responses. However, MyD expression in intestinal epithelial cells partially protected mice during infection, associated with epithelial integrity and antimicrobial peptide RegIII and acute protein SAA expression. Data suggest MyD signaling in DC and IEC is essential to induce host responses upon C. rodium infection.
Researchers explored the relationship between the prevalence of anti-Ov16 IgG antibodies in children one year after mass drug administration (MDA) and the duration of MDA, microfilaria (mf) prevalence in the population, and the probability of onchocerciasis elimination through mathematical modeling. The ONOSIM model was extended to include Ov antibody seroconversion, assumed to be triggered by the first worm establishing in the host, with seroconversion occurring before or after maturation or after the start of mf production. The study focused on seroconversion in children, ignoring the possibility of seroreversion. Yearly MDA reduced parasite acquisition in humans, decreasing sero rate in newborns and children, while those serconverted remained positive. Microfilaria prevalence in individuals aged 5 and Ov antibody in children under 10 declined with increasing M duration. The association between indicators and predicted probability of elimination was influenced by endemic levels, serconversion trigger, and test sensitivity and specificity. Understanding Ov antibody dynamics is crucial for accurate interpretation of seropre data and endpoint MDA estimation. The study found that endpoint will depend on endemic levels, which should be considered in guidelines for stopping MDA.
Researchers have found that prion strains can change properties when propagated in different environments. When swain-sensitive prions were propagated in PK cells in the presence of swain, drug-resistant variants emerged. This suggests that prions comprise a quasi-population of variants with different properties, where the fittest are selected in a particular environment. Even after cloning, prion populations remain heterogeneous, indicating mutation-like processes occur at the conformation level. Brain-derived 22 prions are naturally swain-resistant, so it was not surprising that pr became sensitive after propagation in cells could revert to resistance.
