R pr, both propagated in brain or PK cells, are swain-sensitive, so it was investigated if possible to select swain-resistant by propagation in presence of drug. Interestingly, this was not possible with standard PK cells, but certain PK sublines allowed swain-resistant, even swain-dependent (propagated more in presence drug) to be isolated. Once established, could pass indefinitely in PK cells, absence drug without swain dependence. Misfolded pr (P) associated with swain variant was rapidly cleared PK cells than drug-sensitive counterpart, indicating structural differences misfold Pr underlie pr properties. Propagation pr in presence inhibitory drug selects drug-resistant pr, even stable variants propagate efficiently presence drug. Conformation changes abnormal pr protein underlie adaptations.
Researchers conducted an exhaustive analysis of the genotype-phenotype space for 101 central metabolisms that encode all possible subsets of 51 reactions in carbon metabolism. They used flux balance analysis to predict viability on 10 different carbon sources, resulting in 102 potential phenotypes. Viable metabolisms with one phenotype comprise a tiny fraction of genotype space, but their numbers exceed 109 for phenotypes. Metabolisms with one phenotype form a network of genotypes extending throughout genotype space, where two genotypes can be reached through single reaction changes. Minimal genotype distance between different phenotypes is small, allowing metabolisms to reach novel phenotypes on new carbon through few genic changes. Exceptions exist for metabolisms with complexity near minimum viability threshold. Increasing complexity enhances conservation and innovation potential.

They analyzed neighborhoods of metabolisms on same carbon for novel phenotypes and found that accessibility depends on genotype location in space. Randomly sampled 1000 pairs of metabolisms differing in reactions, representing phenotypes as binary strings of viability or inviability on carbon. A change in genotype is innovation if leads to new carbon viability. A modest genotype space of 101 variants was used due to carbon's role in energy extraction and limited viability on 10 sources.

Metabolisms can differ greatly and reside in connected networks. They analyzed viability on multiple carbon sources, sampling 1000 metabolisms from each network. Representing phenotypes as binary vectors, they asked if multiple novel phenotypes exist in neighborhood.
Researchers analyzed the genetic variation and phylogeography of the Triatoma dimata complex, a group of triatomine bugs that transmit Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite causing Chagas disease, across Mexico and the Neotropics. They analyzed two fragments of the ND4 gene to determine haplog specificity and found lowest genetic diversity where there is most anthropic modification and T cruz infection is highest. Haplog 1 and 3 had higher T cruz prevalence, while hap 2 had lower. There was a significant difference in DT and DTI frequencies in hap 1 and 3, but not in 2. All haplogs had moderate to high haplotype diversity, with greatest differentiation between 1 and 3. The complex diverged from its most recent common ancestor 0.97-0.85 million years ago, with primary divergence of hap 2 and 3. Effective population size of hap 1 and 2 increased 0.02-0.03 million years ago. This study supports the ecological origin of the complex around the Tehante Isthmus and recent divergence of three dimata haplogs with differential T cruz infection and DT specificity, important for vector capacity.
Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFR) is a rod-borne disease caused by hantaviruses, primarily Hanta virus and Seoul virus, in China. Environmental factors significantly affect the risk of contracting hant infections, mainly through their impact on rodent dynamics and human-rod contact. This study aimed to clarify environmental factors favoring rod-to-human transmission, providing evidence for effective FR prevention and control strategies. Ten-year (2006-2015) field data on rod hosts, havirus, epidemiology, and environmental data from satellite and meteorological stations, and rod-to rates were used to quantify relationships among environmental, rod species, and FR occurrence. The study included 709 FR cases. Rod species in Chhou, havirus hotspot, mainly Rattus norvegicus, Musculus, R flavius, and others (R lose and Microtis calamorum) played different roles across land types, all associated with transmission. Some species were with FR in forest and water, R norveicus and flavi with in grassland, M and mus and flavi in built. Rod community was associated with environmental variability. Predictive models based on significant factors validated a good fit: cultivated land predicted highest FR incidence, accords statistics 2015. Spatial FR heterogeneity may be influenced by rod community, associated local conditions.
Researchers have identified a new germline mutation in the HRAS gene, c.35_36>T, in a 12-year-old boy with attenuated Costello syndrome (CS). Analysis of the HRAS DNA showed high levels of exon 2 skipping. Using wild-type and mutant HR minigenes, they confirmed that c.35_36>T results in exon 2 skipping by disrupting a critical exonic splicing enhancer (ESE) and creating an exonic splicing silencer (SS). The HR exon 2 is vulnerable due to a weak 3' splice site, making it dependent on splicing proteins like SRS2 for inclusion. Most cancer and CS-causing mutations are located here, affecting splicing differently. The study shows that CS and cancer phenotypes are not only determined by mutant HRAS transforming potential, but also by exon 2 inclusion efficiency from different mutations. A splice oligonucleotide (SO) that blocks the critical SE causes exon skipping and halts cancer cell proliferation, revealing a potential for new anti-cancer therapies. The most frequent CS mutation, c.34>A, has a modest negative effect on exon inclusion and is high in both CS and cancer due to high mutation rate and modest transforming potential. Other splicing factors like SRS, S3, and S6 are potent oncogenes, underscoring dysregulated splicing in cancer. HR exon 2 is vulnerable and dependent on splicing proteins for inclusion. Mutations in codons 12 and 13 impact exon inclusion differently and splicing efficiency is tissue-specific. Germl mutations in HR cause CS, a congenital disease with growth retardation, tumor predisposition, developmental delay, and heart and skeletal abnormalities. 75% of CS is caused by heterozygous c.34>A mutations in HR.
Researchers have investigated the role of methyltransferase-like 3 (METTL3) in the development of the cerebellum, a region of the brain responsible for motor coordination and balance. They found that inactivating MET3 in mice leads to severe developmental defects, including cerebellar hypoplasia, a condition where the cerebellum is underdeveloped. This is caused by enhanced apoptosis, or cell death, of newborn cerebellar granule cells in the external granular layer. MET3 depletion results in loss of N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modification, a common RNA modification, leading to extended half-lives and aberrant splicing of mRNAs. This causes dysregulation of transcript-wide gene expression and premature cell death of cerebell granule cells. The study reveals MET3 as a critical regulator of cerebell neurogenesis and transcript-wide gene expression, highlighting its importance in mammalian cerebell development.
Researchers have investigated the role of transcription factors OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG in regulating gene expression in embryonic stem (ES) cells. These factors are essential for maintaining the cells' ability to differentiate into any cell type in the developing embryo. The study found that the combination of OCT, SO2, and NANOG binding is strongly associated with the localization of a coactivator, H3ac and increased expression of nearby genes in ES cells. They observed that loci bound by OCT, SO2, and NANOG in ES cells frequently drive expression in early embryonic development. A comparison of mouse and human ES cells showed that less than 5% of individual binding events for OCT, SO2, and NANOG are shared between species. However, about 15% of combinatorial binding events and 53-63% of combinator binding at enhancers active in early development are conserved. The analysis suggests that the combination of OCT, SO, and NANOG is critical for transcription in ES and likely plays a role in embryogenesis by binding conserved developmental enhancers. The study also found that evolutionary rewiring of regulatory networks mainly affects individual binding, whereas "regulatory hotspots" bound by multiple factors and active in multiple tissues early development are under evolutionary constraints.
AML/ETO, a fusion protein resulting from a chromosomal translocation involving chromosomes 8 and 21, initiates acute myel leukemia by recruiting co-repressor complexes to DNA. A1ETO interferes with the function of its wild-type counterpart, A1, by targeting A1 binding sites. However, transcriptional regulation by AETO likely relies on a complex network, as the protein interacts with multiple transcription factors, including E-proteins, and targets other DNA sites. Genome-wide chromatin immunoprecipitation and expression profiling identified AETO-dependent transcriptional regulation. AETO was found to co-localize with A1, demonstrating the fusion follows the binding pattern of the wild protein but does not primarily displace it. The binding of E-protein H was rearranged upon AETO expression, and the protein co-localized with A1 and H on many regulated targets. The level of H was increased in primary cells and cell lines expressing AETO. The results suggest a major role for the interaction of AETO with A1 and H in transcription regulation by the protein.
Researchers investigated the role of the Leishmania donani histone acetyltransferase H2 (H2) in regulating gene expression. They found that H2 acetylates histone H4 in vitro and in vivo, and is essential for cell growth and survival. Using real-time PCR and DNA microarray analyses, they showed that downregulation of cyclins CY4 and CY9 caused cell cycle defects in H2-depleted cells. Leish genes are arranged in unidirectional clusters, with genes coordinately transcribed as polyc units from divergent strand regions (dSRs), which initiate transcription bidirectionally on opposite strands. Investigating CY4 and CY9 expression in H2-de cells, they found these cyclins have own specific promoters, activated in a cell-dependent manner. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and real-time PCR suggested these promoters are activated at specific cell stages. Two tiers of regulation exist: transcription of polyc units initiates at SRs, likely constitutively, while a subset have own promoters, some activated cell-dependently. The second tier is sensitive to H10 acylation, resulting in downregulation in H-de cells. This study shows cell-specific activation of promoters in trypanoids, uncovering new facets of regulation in this family.
Researchers investigated how humans infer the intentions of others in social interactions using a game where 16 pairs of volunteers played a probabilistic reinforcement task, with one as "player" and the other as "adviser". The adviser received more information and issued a recommendation, with incentives to provide helpful or misleading information varying over time. A Bayesian modeling framework found that players' behavior was best explained by hierarchical learning, inferring the adviser's intentions to optimize predictions of advice validity. Volatility estimates also affected trial-by-trial decisions, with reliance on advice increasing when intentions were perceived stable. The model predicted players' interpersonal reactivity (IRI) scores and adviser helpfulness ratings. Results suggest humans employ hierarchical models to infer changing intentions, use volatility in decision-making, and integrate advice with non-social information. A subset of players with changing adviser intentions showed more pronounced hierarchical learning, indicating volatility updated beliefs about advice accuracy. A model comparing alternative models found hierarchical learning best explained behavior, predicting accuracy and stability of adviser intentions. Players' belief-updating reflected advisers' policy, with stable intentions weighted more in decision-making. Those with helpful advisers perceived stable intentions weighted advice more, reflected by reduced volatility and increased values.
Scrub typhus, a disease endemic in Asia, has shifted from a rural to urban setting in South Korea, particularly in Seoul, the country's largest metropolitan city. From 2010 to 2013, national notifiable disease data identified indigenous scrub typh in Seoul, with 88 cases reported. Clinical features of patients from one hospital were analyzed and compared to a control group. Chigger mites were collected in the city using a direct chigger-collecting trap and identified by phenic and 18S rDNA analyses. Infection with Orientia tsutsugushi was confirmed by 56-kDa antigen sequencing. Possible sites of infection were mountain areas (56.8%), city parks (20.5%), vicinity of own residence (17%), and rivers (5.7%). Eighty-seven chigger mites were collected in Gak mountain, one of the suspected sites in Seoul, and 76 (87.4%) were identified as Helenula miagawai and 9.2 as Leotridium scutare. Pooled DNA from miag mites yielded O tsugushi Bong strain. Twenty-six patients showed low APACHE score (3.4 ± 2.7), low complication rate (3.8%), and no hypalemia. The study confirmed presence of indigenous scrub in Seoul and a subgroup with mild features. Chigger H miag infected O tsug within the city found in endemic area. Scrub ty needs to be considered a differential disease and target for prevention.
Researchers investigated the impact of the Caenorhabditis elegans HEN1 RNA methyltransferase homolog, HENN-1, on the RNA interference (RNAi) pathways in the nematode. They found that H-1 has differential effects on two pathways that employ methylated RNA molecules, the 26 and 21 pathways. In the germline, the stability of 21 RNAs, C elegans piRNAs, is mildly affected by loss of methylation and introduction of artificial 21 target RNA does not destabilize non-methylated 21 RN. In contrast, 26 RN display reduced stability and respond to loss H- by increased 3-uridylation. Within the 26 class, ER-1-bound 26 RN are modified by H- while AL-3/4-bound 26 are not. Global expression analysis of h- mutants reveals mild effects, including downregulation of gerine-expressed genes. The study refines understanding of endogenous RNAi in C elegans and roles H1 enzymes in pathways.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) and high-throughput glycomics analysis on 2,705 individuals from three populations to investigate the regulation of protein glycosylation. They found that variants in the Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1 (HNF1) and fucyltransferase genes FUT6 and F8 influence N-gly levels in human plasma. NF1 and its downstream NF4 regulate the expression of fucyltransfer and fucose biosynthesis genes. NF1 is necessary and sufficient to drive expression of these genes in hepatic cells, revealing a new role as a transcriptional regulator of multiple stages in the fyl process. This has implications for regulation of immunity, embryonic development, and protein folding, as well as understanding of molecular mechanisms underlying cancer, coronary disease, heart, and metabolic disorders. Acute proteins have altered fyl in diseases and changes in levels of fylated glycans are associated with several pathological processes, including cancer. NF1 and NF4 are transcription factors that regulate gene expression in liver and pancreas and are key regulators of metabolic genes. The study confirmed role of NF in biosynthesis of GDP-fucose and analyzed NF and NF in regulation of fyltransfer (FUT) genes in HepG and Panc cell lines to assess whether hep factors regulate other stages of fyl. NF knockdown regulated expression of all UT genes except UT8, which was induced upon loss of NF. Identified genes UT, F, UT, and NF are involved in fyl, indicating addition of unusual sugar may be rate-limiting in Nly synthesis.
Researchers have investigated the role of single-stranded RNA in stabilizing the binding of Centromere Protein C (CPC) to centromeres, which are attachment points between the genome and cytoskeleton. Contrary to expectations, the DNA sequence of centrom has little role in recruiting kinetoches. Instead, RNA transcribed from centrom remains within the kinetoch region and is thought to be part of the epigenetic system. The study found that maize CPC, a key kinetoch protein, binds DNA through a localized 122 amino acid region, which is exquisitely sensitive to single-stranded RNA. Long single-stranded nucleic acids promote CPC binding to DNA, and types of RNAs that stabilize binding match those present in kinetocho in vivo. Removal of the binding module with HIVase domain causes partial delocalization of CPC in vivo. Data suggest centrom RNA recruits CPC to kinoch by altering DNA characteristics. Maize centrom repeats are undermethyl transcribed and produce stable RNAs bound to chromatin. Centrom RNAs are 40-200 in length, transcribed from both strands and maintained single-stranded, proposed to serve as structural template for kinoch proteins. In vitro and vivo studies show CPC has DNA and RNA-binding capacities, with DNA/RNA domain localized to exon region and required for centere localization. RNA facilitates CPC binding to DNA, providing biochemical mechanism for involvement in centrom specification. Single-stranded RNA has strong effect on binding, suggesting centrom serves as epetic mark mediating final assembly. CPC is recruited to kin by protein contacts then converted to functional by centrom RNA.
Researchers conducted a study to investigate the genetic regulation of the placental transcriptome and its role in determining birth weight and childhood obesity risk. They analyzed genome-wide association study (GWAS) variants associated with birth weight (BW), childhood obesity (CO), and body mass index (BMI) and found that the placenta, a critical organ for fetal development and postnatal health, plays a significant role in these traits. The study examined placental transcript and expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) mediating genetic causes of BW, CO, and CBMI using integrative analysis (colocalization and MetaX) and found that GWAS loci associated with BW, CO, and CBMI were substantially enriched for placental eQTL (6.76, 4.83, and 2.26, respectively). Importantly, compared to eQTL of adult tissues, placental eTL contribute significantly to anthropometric outcomes at birth (BW) and childhood phenotypes (CO/CBMI). Eight, six transcripts colocalized with BW, CO, and CBMI risk loci, respectively. The study reveals that placental transcription in utero likely plays a key role in determining postnatal size and may hold new possibilities for therapeutic interventions to prevent childhood obesity. 

The study found extensive enrichment of placental eTL for GW hits and discovered hundreds of transcripts controlled by genetic variants influencing anthropometric traits, demonstrating that placental transcription and functions defined by identified genes play roles in BW, CO, and CBMI. The placenta is highly relevant for determining not only weight at birth (BW) but body in childhood (CO and CBMI). Identifying genes mediating genetic predisposition for BW, CO, and CBMI is crucial for understanding mechanisms controlling traits and developing prevention. Integrative genomics is a powerful tool to mine GW results. The study showcases influence genetically controlled in utero patterns linked BW, CO, and CB supporting hypothesis.
A study was conducted in Malda district, West Bengal, India to determine the burden of post-kala-azar dermal leishiasis (PKDL) in an endemic area and compare three diagnostic tools for PK detection and lesion regression after treatment. PK is a chronic, non-life threatening disease, but relevant to visceral leishiasis (VL) elimination, with no standard guidelines for diagnosis and treatment. The study detected 26 PK cases with a prevalence of 27.5% among leishmanial antibody positive cases. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was highly sensitive (88.46%) for confirmation. Majority of skin lesions persisted after treatment, disappearing 6-12 months post-treatment, with reappearance in two cases after 1.5 years of miltefosine treatment. A significant number of PK patients remained undiagnosed without active surveys, required in other endemic areas for VL elimination. PCR is helpful for PK diagnosis, referral at district or state level. A well-designed study with more samples is essential to determine if PK patients are free from parasites after treatment and which need longer treatment. PK occurs in 10-20% of treated VL cases in India, 50-60% in Sudan, and 2% of PK cases with no kalaazar history. Unlike VL, PK is not life-threatening, cosmetic values not bothering patients not seeking care, maintaining parasites in population.
Pneumoccal competence development in liquid cultures of Streptoccus pneumoniae is a collective behavior that depends on an exported signaling peptide, Competence Stimulating Peptide (CSP), which generates a positive feedback loop. However, the coordination of this population switch is unclear. Monitoring competence in real-time during growth of four pneumocococcal lineages reveals that the shift relies on a self-activated fraction that arises via a growth-dependent mechanism. CSP remains bound to cells during this event, and the rate of competence corresponds to propagation between activated and quiescent cells. A two-step cell-sensing mechanism is validated by measuring development during co-cultivation of strains altered to produce or respond to CSP. Membrane protein Com retains CSP, limiting diffusion in the medium. Competence cells originate stochastically in response to stress, forming a subpopulation that transmits CSP by cell contact.

Competence propagation from cell to cell provides efficient CSP-based feedback in all progeny. The ability to convert population to competent is restricted to pneumoc and relatives. Pneumoccal competence is a two-step process: a fraction initially switches to CSP-expression; these induce competence in whole. The second step occurs by CSP transmission between cells via cell-cell collision. Spontaneous development at single cell level is interesting to explore stochastic autocrine development. CSP is retained on competent cells of distinct pneumoc line, a feature of pneumoc and central to cell-sensing. Combination promotes gene transfer and pneumoc genome plasticity.
Human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV) L2 protein acts as a chaper to facilitate the trafficking of the viral genome (vDNA) from endosomes to the trans-Gol network (TGN) and eventually the nucleus, where replication occurs. To reach the nucleus, the L2/v complex must translocate across intracellular membranes. The details of this process are poorly characterized. A system based on subcellular compartmentalization of BirA and its cognate substrate was developed to detect translocation of L2 from incoming virions. L translocation requires transport to the TGN and is strictly dependent on entry into mitosis, coinciding with mitotic entry in synchronized cells. Cell arrest causes retention of L/v at the T; only release and progression G/M enables trans across the membrane and infection. Microscopy of Ed-labeled vDNA reveals a rapid shift in v localization during mitosis. At G/early vgress from the T to pericent location, accumulating through metaphase where it begins to associate with chromosomes. By metaphase and anaph the v is bound to mitotic, ensuring distribution into daughter. Mutations in a defined chromatin binding of L blocked trans, suggesting trans dependent on chromatin during metaphase.
Researchers have developed a mathematical framework to estimate the transmissibility of one strain of a pathogen compared to another, using data from competitive mixtures experiments in animals co-infected with two strains. The method is demonstrated using influenza experiments in ferrets and has applicability beyond influenza to other viral and bacterial pathogens. The transibility of one strain to another is crucial in three contexts: within human populations where novel strains compete for susceptible hosts, during pandemics where a novel type competes with existing strains, and with neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) that exert selective pressure promoting resistant strains. The framework also estimates the size of the transmitted inoculum, a key for epidemiological models considering emergence and spread of resistant strains. The method improves competitive mixtures experimental design by using multiple donors and estimates the number of infecting units transferred from donor to recipient, aiding parameterization of transmission models. The approach is applicable to other pathogens, requiring consideration of within-host dynamics and competitive effects of co-infection.
Researchers investigated the convergence of light and abscisic acid (ABA) signaling on the ABI5 promoter in Arabidopsis thaliana. They found that BBX21, a B-box protein involved in seedling photomorphogenesis, also plays a role in ABA signaling. Genetic data showed BB21 acts upstream of ABI5 and HY5 in ABA control of seed germination. BB21 interacts with HY5, which activates ABI expression, and negatively regulates ABI expression by interfering with HY binding to the ABI promoter. Additionally, ABI directly activates its own expression, while BB21 negatively regulates this activity by interacting with ABI. The study indicates BB21 coordinates with HY and ABI on the ABI promoter, integrating light and A signaling in Arabidopsis. HY regulation of ABI represents integration of light and A during germination and seedling development. Accumulating evidence shows BB proteins work with HY in photomorphogenesis. Since HY activates ABI, it was investigated whether BB proteins are involved in A signaling. Multiple factors in the light pathway regulate A responses by ABI expression. This study shows BB21, a regulator in seedling photorph, negatively regulates ABI by interfering HY binding to the promoter. Light and A are environmental and hormonal cues controlling germination and seedling development. The integration of external with internal pathways is vital for survival.
Researchers investigated the role of the Mediator complex, a co-regulator of RNA polymerase II, in the pathogenic fungus Candida albicans. They focused on the Med31, Med20, and Srb/M13 subunits and found that C. albicans shares some functions with model yeasts Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Schizoscharomyces pombe, such as response to certain stresses and Med31's role in Ace2-regulated genes. However, C. albicans has additional roles in transcription of virulence genes, including morphogenesis and adhesin families. Med31,20, and S/M13 contribute to virulence attributes of C. albicans, including filamentation, biofilm formation, and ALS1 is a biologically relevant target of Med for biofilm development. Med also affects virulence of C. alb in the worm model. The study found that Med and S/M13 regulate cell adhesion genes differently between S. cerevisiae and C. alb, repressing FLO genes in S cerevis and activating ALS in C. alb. This suggests Med subunits regulate adhesion in distinct manner between two distantly related species.
Researchers investigated the factors contributing to the increased antibiotic tolerance of Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms compared to their planktonic counterparts. Using a genome-wide functional profiling of a complex mutant population of P. aeruginosa MPA1 in biofilm and plankic growth with tobramycin, they quantified the contribution of each locus to antibiotic tolerance in both states. The study revealed large sets of mutations contributing to tolerance in biofilm or plankic settings, providing insights into differences and similarities between biofilm and plankic antibiotic tolerance. A mixed population experimental design recapitulated natural biofilm complexity, unlike previous studies, and showed emergence of quorum-deficient mutants. The study found a substantial contribution of cellular state to biofilm antibiotic tolerance, providing a foundation for novel therapeutics against P. aerugin bio-associated infections.
Researchers have developed a new algorithm called Flexible Algorithm for Model Selection (FoS) to analyze complex biological systems with many interacting components and limited information about their dynamics. Traditional model selection algorithms compare a few models or exhaustively search the entire space, which is impractical due to the vast number of possibilities. FoS uses local and non-local search methods to prevent getting stuck in local minima and account for structurally similar processes. It was tested on simulated and experimental data, showing flexibility in handling various structures. The algorithm analyzed cell proliferation of CD4 and CD T cells under different conditions, indicating reduced proliferation in tissue-like 3D cultures compared to suspension. FoS is applicable to various biological problems and useful for data-driven model evaluation of complex spaces. Improved model search and selection algorithms handle large spaces, contributing to research questions. FoS was designed for complex dynamics in large spaces and diverse structures, allowing unbiased inference of parameters and processes. It efficiently searches large spaces to provide systematic description of observed dynamics.
A 12-month follow-up study was conducted in Bolivia to evaluate the efficacy of benznidazole (BN) treatment in children infected with Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite causing Chagas disease. The study included 103 seropositive children, 73 of whom completed the treatment with some interruptions due to side effects. Serology, conventional PCR, and real-time PCR were performed on blood samples taken before and after treatment, and Th1/2/Th17 cytokines levels were measured. Results showed that 11% of children had both PCR+ and qPCR+, 42% had PCR- but q+, and 47% had both PCR- and q-. IL-17 levels were significantly higher in seropitive children before treatment and decreased to normal levels after one year. IL-17 levels were positively correlated with parasite counts by qPCR. At 12 months, IL-17 levels in non-reactive subjects were higher than reactive or ambiguous, suggesting IL-17 as a potential biomarker for detecting reactivity to BN treatment. Plasma IL-17 levels may indicate persistent T. cruzi infection and chronic inflammation.
Neisseria meningitidis, the primary causative agent of bacterial meningitis, has a genome rich in repetitive DNA, with approximately 2% occupied by a diminutive transposon called Coria. Bioinformatic analysis identified eight subtypes of the element with four distinct transcriptional ends. Transcription analysis using PCR and lacZ reporter revealed two particular ends encode strong promoters. The strongest promoter activity is dictated by polymorphism Y128 at the right end of the element. Examples of elements drive transcription of adjacent genes, while others express non-coding RNAs. Pairwise comparisons between meningocococcal genomes show more than two-thirds of Coria elements maintain subtype at particular locus due to recombinational switching between elements in single strain. Upon switching, new allele spreads through population by natural transformation, a hitherto unrecognized mechanism for variation in meningococcus. Strain-to-strain variability of Coria and number of strong promoters allows widespread effects within population. Defining strength of promoters by subtypes Cor ends provides resource to predict transcription effects of subtype at locus.
Researchers have identified two genes, Chae and Vel, in the maize pathogen Cochliobolus heterostus, which regulate the production of a toxin, Txin, that promotes virulence in maize. Txin production is increased in the dark and decreased in mutants lacking Chae and Vel. Expression of the Txin biosynthetic gene Tox1 is also upregulated in the dark in wild type but reduced in mutants. Overexpression of Vel increases Txin production in the dark and Chae in light. Chae and Vel mutants show altered virulence on Tms and normal cytoplasm maize, indicating Txin mediated virulence is affected. Deletion of Chae or Vel reduces tolerance to H2O2. Expression of CAT, a catalase, is reduced in Vel mutant. Chae and Vel mutants show decreased hyphal growth, asexual sporulation, and sterility. Chae OE are sterile while Vel OE are more fertile. Chae and Vel repress melanin biosynthesis genes, and melanization is enhanced in mutants and reduced in OE. Chae and Vel regulate Txin biosynthesis, pathogenicity, virulence, oxidative stress, development, and hyal growth, and control melanin biosynthesis and asexual differentiation.
Researchers have investigated the mechanism of asymmetry in bacterial Nav channels, which have been characterized as functionally asymmetric, but the underlying mechanism unclear. They combined non-equilibrium simulations with two-dimensional unperturbed landscapes generated by umbrella sampling and Weighted Histogram Methods to study ion permeation through the selectivity filter of NavAb channel. Non-equilibrium simulations showed that two or three extracellular K+ ions can block the selectivity filter in the presence of inward forces, but not outward. The block occurs in an unstable local minimum of the unpurbed free-energy of K+ that can be locked in place by applied forces. In contrast, Na+ move through the selectivity as a unit in a "knock" mechanism in both directions, with no local minimum in the free-energy of Na for block. The non-equilibrium simulations predicted work to break the K block is equivalent to experimentally measured for Nav to induce inward K currents. These results illustrate the inclusion of non-equilibrium in simulations provides information on ion selectivity mechanisms missing from structures or equilibrium landscapes. The mechanism of selectivity in Nav differs from those from structures or landscapes and is consistent with electrophys measurements. Non-equilibrium simulations suggest a "pass" configuration for K in forces can block selectivity and prevent K permeation at negative voltages inward, though unstable in equilibrium. This coincides with experimentally applied potentials for Nav to induce K currents. Molecular simulations predicted unpurbed-free barriers for Na and K permeation of 1-3 kcal/mol, consistent with PNa/PK ratio 20-40 from reversal potentials.
A study compared the intracellular spread of rabies virus in the paralytic and furious forms of canine rabies in a cohort of naturally infected, non-vaccinated dogs. The results showed that the furious form had more rapid viral colonization of the cerebral hemispheres, measured by viral antigen within neuronal bodies and RNA. In contrast, the paralytic form had slower intracellular transport of the virus, resulting in slower viral propagation. The study quantitatively assessed the amount of rabies antigen in cell processes and bodies at different levels of the spinal cord, brain, and cerebrum, and found greater amounts in processes in furious compared to paraly at all levels. This difference was evident even when comparing similar amounts of antigen, percentages of involved neurons, and anatomic levels with 100% positive neurons. The findings suggest host-specific differences in intracellular transport, possibly mediated by cytokines, as previous studies documented greater inflammation in the paraly form. The study extends previous results on neuronal bodies and RNA levels, demonstrating caud-rostral polarity of viral distribution in both forms, with greatest at brainstem and spinal levels in furious.
Researchers have investigated the role of the zinc finger protein CTC in regulating gene expression in Drosophila. CTC is known to act as an enhancer-blocking factor in vertebrates, but its function in Dophila was only recently characterized. One endogenous CTC binding site was previously identified in the Fab-8 insulator at the Abdominal-B locus in the Bithax complex (BX). Chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled with microarray analysis was used to identify CTC binding sites in representative regions of the Doph genome, including the 3-M Adh, BX, and Antennedia complex. In vivo CTC binding enabled the construction of a CTC binding consensus sequence. CTC sites in BX mapped to known insulators Mc, Fab-6, and Fab-8, and three additional presumptive insulators Fab-2, Fab-3, and Fab-4. CTC is associated with all known or predicted insulators in BX except Fab-7, suggesting a common CTC-dependent mechanism. Comparison with Polycomb target sites and histone modification supports the BX regulation model. ChIP-array analysis of CTC sites was used to investigate regions of the D genome, focusing on BX. CTC is associated with Fab8 and other boundary elements Fab6 and Mc. Mutation of CTC sites in Fab8 reduces its insulating activity, demonstrating CTC-dependent insulating. ChIP analysis of CTC and Su(Hw binding sites was compared. CTC can form clusters and mediate chromatin loop formation, partitioning regulatory elements into domains. CTC is required for Fab8 insulator function in BX. CTC binds a core sequence in Doph and vertebrates.
Researchers have elucidated the mechanism of induced-fit conformational changes in the enzyme peptidyl deformase, a metal-dependent enzyme, upon binding of a slow and tight inhibitor, actin. Crystal structures of the initial and final states, as well as intermediate snapshots during the process, were solved. Ligand-induced reshaping of a hydrophobic pocket drives closure of the active site, followed by additional interactions. Biochemical and computational analyses reconstructed the sequence of events from encounter to key binding. A "movie" of the process can be extrapolated to catalysis. This study integrates biophysical, computational, and kinetic analyses, providing a comprehensive understanding of the slow-binding mechanism, applicable to broader receptor-lig interactions.
Researchers investigated the role of the thalamus as a gateway for sensory information transfer to the cerebral cortex, focusing on the interaction between cortical and thalamic cells. Using dynamic-clamp techniques in thal slices, they simulated a hybrid retino-thalamo-cort pathway and mimicking cortical synaptic bombardment through a mixture of excitatory and inhibitory conductances. The study found that the efficiency of sensory transmission depends on three factors: the number of thalamocort cells, corticothal synaptic statistics, and correlation between thal relay cells. Counterintuitively, retoc signal efficiency increased with decreased correlation between thal cells, suggesting desynchronized cells amplify transfer. This mechanism could direct attention to specific thal subsemblies and select input to cortex based on cortically-defined priorities. 

At the cell level, input transfer efficiency was measured by spiking probability to excitatory retinal inputs. Combined in vitro and comput approaches proposed decorrelation of thal background activity optimizes retoc signal transfer. A possibility is recording extracellular thal cells, an alternative is intracellular recording to unravel correlation. Several mechanisms contribute to permissive sensory transfer, but cortical control by tunable excitatory inhibitory activity presents advantages over neuromodulation: dynamic and precise. Systematic exploration defined excitatory inhibitory conductances led to an optimal noise. Stochastic facilitation at thal level enhances sensory transfer with decorrelated cortogenic feedback. This may be basis for attentional modulation at thal level.
Researchers have investigated the role of the putative demethylase NM-1 in regulating DNA replication and repair during meiosis in Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that nmad-1 mutants have reduced fertility and defects in prophase I meiosis, leading to reduced embryo production and increased incidence of males due to chromosomal segregation errors. Analysis of the nmad-1 germline revealed reduced DNA replication and DNA damage response genes during meiosis, coupled with delayed replication, impaired repair, and apoptosis of maturing oocytes. Immunoprecipitation and mass spectrometry identified NM-1 binding to proteins regulating DNA repair and replication, including topoisomerase TOP-2, which co-localizes with TOP-2 on chromatin. The majority of TOP-2 binding to chromatin depends on NM-1, suggesting NM-1 functions at replication sites to regulate DNA and repair during meiosis. NM-1 binds same sites on chromatin as TOP-2 and physically interacts with TOP- in vitro and in vivo, indicating NM- acts on chrom to regulate these processes in meiosis. NM-1 deletion and catalytic mutants have impaired fertility, increased males, RAD-51 foci, and replication rates, suggesting NM- demylation at DNA central to its role meiosis. NM- identified as 6 DNA demase and conserved in Bomby mori and mice.
Researchers have identified adipocyte plasma-associated protein (AAP) as a novel modulator in the early stage of human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection. CMV is a ubiquitous pathogen that can cause serious diseases in newborns and immunocompromised patients. The study found that AAP is necessary for CMV infection in epithelial cells and fibroblasts, and knockdown of AAP expression significantly reduced CMV infection in these cells. Interestingly, ectopic expression of AAP in cells refractory to CMV infection, such as canine MDCK and murine NIH3T cells, promoted CMV infection. Biochemical studies of AAP and CM proteins suggest AAP participates in CM infection through interaction with glycoprotein complexes at low pH and mediates translocation of tegument pp65. Results indicate AAP plays a role in early CM infection. CM entry into different cells may rely on different receptors and routes, and AAP was identified as a modulator in early CM infection. In vitro interaction AAP and CM proteins supported AAP may participate in CM through glyprotein complexes low and mediate translocation pp65. AAP is a cellular factor augmenting CM infection at early viral stage. Overexpression of AAP promoted CM in human cells and non-human types susceptible to CM entry, canineCK and murine NIH3 cells. Reduced early gene transcription and delayed translocation tegument pp were detected in AAP-deficient cells at CM infection.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model that combines intrinsic and extrinsic factors to understand how hematopoietic progenitor cells commit to a specific lineages. The model suggests that cytokine-mediated receptor feedback can induce a switch-like response to external stimuli during multilineage differentiation, providing robustness to bipotent and committed states while protecting progenitors from noise-induced decommitment. The model supports both instruct and stochastic theories of commitment: cell fates are driven by lineage-specific transcription factors, but cytokine signaling can bias lineage by regulating inherently noisy cell decisions with complex behaviors such as ligand ultrasensitivity and multistability. Simulations show that differentiation kinetics to a mature state depend on progenitor state and commitment route chosen. The model agrees with lineage receptor expression kinetics from microarray experiments and provides a framework integrating classical and alternative paths in hematopoies observed.
Researchers have used electron cryo-microscopy to study the ultrastructure of the Bunyamwera virus, a prototypic member of the Orthunavirus genus within the Bunyaviridae family. The virus particles are pleomorphic in shape but display a locally ordered lattice of glycoprotein spikes, each protruding 18nm from the membrane. Upon introduction to an acidic environment, the spikes become disordered. Using subtomography, a 3D model of the trimeric glycoprotein spike was derived at 3nm resolution. The glycoprotein consists of a putative class II fusion glycoprotein with a unique tripod-like arrangement. Protein-protein contacts occur between spikes at membrane-proximal regions and intra-spike at membrane-dist regions. This trimer deviates from previously observed fusion glycop arrangements, suggesting a greater repertoire of viral glycoprotein oligomerization. The study reveals a pH-dependent conformation change during orthunaviral entry into host cells and provides a blueprint for the structure of this emerging group of pathogens. The glyprotein sequences of Bunyamwera virus are conserved with more pathogenic relatives, sharing 54 and 53% similarity with SBV and ORO, respectively. The study addresses the paucity of information on orthunavirus structure, providing a detailed 3D analysis and model for this medically important group.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) on anterior chamber depth (ACD) to discover genes associated with primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG) in a population of 5,308 individuals of Asian descent. The study found a significant association with a variant in the ABCC5 gene (rs199), with a per-allele effect size of -0.045mm and a P-value of 8.17x10^-9. This variant was also associated with an increased risk of PG in a separate case-control study of 4,276 PG cases and 18,801 controls, with a per-allele OR of 1.13 (95% CI 1.06-1.22, P=0.000). The association was strengthened when a subgroup of controls with open angles were included in the analysis. The study suggests that increased PG risk could be mediated by genetic variants influencing anterior chamber dimensions. AB5 is expressed in ocular tissues relevant to PG such as the iris, ciliary body, and lens. The study provides clues to genetic mechanisms underlying this major cause of blindness.
Researchers have identified developmental enhancers, called bilaterally conserved regulatory elements (BREs), which are conserved between deuterostomes and protomes. These enhancers show sequence and gene synteny conservation, reflecting conserved patterns of transcription factor binding sites. Bres are predicted to act as response elements to signaling pathways and drive expression of transcriptional repressors in the vertebrate central nervous system. The study presents the first examples of enhancers conserved between deuteromes and protomes, and suggests that more will be discovered as understanding of cis-regulatory logic and bilian genomes improves. Bres are developmental enhancers that encode complex patterns of transcription factor binding, with Bore being an enhancer of Id. Binding analysis predicts it functions as a BMP responsive element, and experimental evidence supports this. In vertebrates, Bore drives expression in the central nervous system during early differentiation. The study implies extensive cis-regulatory rewiring between protome and deuterome clades, and questions what makes Bres unique.
Researchers conducted a study to investigate the impact of vaccination on the diversity of H3N2 influenza viruses within individuals. They analyzed 166 cases of H3N influenza over 3 seasons and 19 years, using next-generation sequencing to obtain whole genome data for 119 samples. Phylogenetic analysis of hemagglutinin and neuraminase sequences showed no stratification by pre-HAI and post-vaccination titers. The study found that most intrah single nucleotide variants were rare and few were found in more than one individual, with most samples having fewer than 15 nucleotide variants across the genome. The level of diversity did not vary by day of sampling, vaccination status, or pre-antibody titer. Contrary to expectations, the results indicate that seasonal vaccination has little impact on intrah diversity in natural infection and vaccine immunity may be a minor contributor to antigen drift at local scales.
Researchers investigated the efficacy of live attenuated Leishmania donovani parasites (LC-/-) in inducing a protective immune response against visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in aged mice compared to young mice. Previously, LC/- was shown to induce a strong innate and adaptive immune response in young mice. In this study, LC/- mediated modulation of innate and adaptive response was analyzed in 18-month-old (aged) and 2-month-old (young) mice. Analysis of bone marrow-derived dendritic cells (BMDCs) from both aged and young mice upon LC/- infection showed significant enhancement of effector responses, augmenting CD4+ Th cell function compared to wild-type (WT) infected BMs in vitro. Similarly, splenic dendritic cells from LC/- infected young and aged mice revealed induction of pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-12, IL-6, IF-γ, TNF) and downregulation of anti-inflammatory (IL-10) genes compared WT infected mice. Immunization with LC/- induced IgG2 antibodies, lymphoproliferative response, pro-inflammatory responses, and splenocytes heightened leishicidal activity with nitric production in young and aged mice. Upon virulent Leish challenge, LC/- immunized mice from both groups displayed multifunctional Th-type CD4 and cytotoxic CD8 cells correlating reduced parasite burden in spleen and liver compared naïve mice. However, LC/- induced response in dendritic cells showed no difference between aged and young, but adaptive T and B cell activation in aged was reduced compared young, correlating less protection in old compared young.
Researchers created chimeric viruses by exchanging the capsid proteins between Enterovirus D68 (EV-D68), a respiratory virus, and Enterovirus D94 (EV-D94), an enteric virus, to investigate the role of capsid proteins in viral tropism, acid sensitivity, and optimal growth. The study found that capsid proteins are necessary and sufficient to determine acid sensitivity and tropism in respiratory cells and tissues, as well as optimal growth temperature. In contrast, non-structural proteins modulate the innate immune response. Chimeric viruses with EV-D68 capsid could not adapt to higher temperatures, while EV94 relied on mutations in VP1 for temperature adaptation. Additionally, EV68 maintained infectivity after acid treatment, whereas non-structural proteins modulated the immune response. This study clarifies the biophysical and immunogenic roles of capsid in EV pathogenesis and may guide therapeutic targets.
Herpes Simplex Virus 1 (HSV-1) glycoprotein gE-I is a transmembrane receptor found on the surface of infected cells and virions that binds human immunoglobulin G (Ig). It also participates in antibody bridging (ABB), a process where antigen fragments (Fab) of IgG bind viral antigen while Fc binds to gE-I. IgFc binds g-E at basic, not acidic pH, suggesting Ig bound extracellularly by surface g-E would dissociate and degrade in endosomes/lysosomes if endocytosed. The fate of viral antigens with g-E bound Ig was unknown: could remain surface or endocyt with Ig. An in vitro system was developed to study ABB and trafficking of complexes using 4-D confocal imaging with transferrin epidermal growth, characterized intracellular markers. Data showed cells expressing g-E and viral HSV-1 endocyt anti-D Ig and g in g-E dependent, resulting lysosomal localization. Results suggest g-E can mediate clearance of infected surfaces of anti-viral host Ig and viral antig to evade Ig-mediated responses, a mechanism for viral evasion and pathogenesis.
Researchers have analyzed the transcriptome of the protoscoleces (PSC) stage of Echinococcus granulosus, a parasite that causes cistic hydatid disease in humans and animals worldwide. They used Roche 454 sequencing and in silico analysis to explore the excretory-secretory proteins (ESPs) released by the parasite. The study generated 26,514 non-reduant sequences, of which 22,910 (86.4%) were mapped to the published E. granus genome and 17,705 (66.8%) were in coding sequence (CDS) regions. Of the 2,280 predicted ESPs, 138 were involved in carbohydrate metabolism, 124 in protein metabolism, and 11 in glycolysis/glucone (GLN) pathways. Additionally, 44 antigenic proteins, molecular chaperones, and proteases were identified. Many proteins were enriched in development-related pathways, such as TGF receptor and insulin pathways. This study provides valuable information on parasite adaptation to hosts, aiding novel intervention targets for hydat treatment and control.
In the fungus Aspergillus nidans, the transcription factor NirA plays a crucial role in regulating the assimilation of nitrate, a major nitrogen source in soil. When nitrate is present, NirA accumulates in the nucleus and activates transcription of nit assimilatory genes. However, the interaction between Nir and the exportin Kap/CRM1 is disrupted, leading to rapid nuclear accumulation of Nir. Researchers used mass spectrometry to find that in the absence of nit, Nir is predominantly cytosolic and methion 169 in the nuclear export sequence (NES) is oxidized to methion sulfox (Metox). This oxidation depends on Fmo, a flav-containing monooxygen which uses methion and cystine but not glutathione as substrates. The function of Fmo cannot be replaced by alternative F proteins in A. nidans. Exposure to nit led to rapid reduction of Nir-Met169 to Met; this being independent of thiorexin and methion sulfox reductases. Replacement of Met byoleucine, sterically similar but not oxidizable, led to partial loss Nir activity and insensitivity to Fmo-mediated export. In contrast, replacement of Met by alanine transformed the protein into permanently nuclear and active factor. Co-immoprecipitation of Nir-Kap interactions and subcell localization of Nir mutants provided evidence that Met oxidation leads change Nir conformation.
Researchers investigated how functional constraints shape the evolution of mammalian voltage-gated sodium channels, which are crucial for propagating action potentials. Since Hodgkin and Hux's mathematical models, sodium channel properties must be tightly constrained for action potential to propagate. Nine mammalian genes encode voltage-gated sodium channels, with many being over 90% identical in sequence, suggesting similar function and tight constraints. However, the multiplicity of genes raises why there are so many. Theoretical constraints on sodium diversity, membrane excitability and unique resting potential, directly constrain channel properties. Data from 172 sets of measurements on mammalian channels, wild-type and mutant, under various conditions, obey excitability constraint, while channels in muscle obey unique potential, but not in neuronal tissue. Excitability distinguishes channels into four groups consistent with phylogenetic analysis. Calculations suggest functional differences between groups.

The study explores how constraints bound evolution through mammalian voltageated sodium channels. Primary function is to propagate action potentials. Hodgkin Hux models suggest sodium properties must be constrained for action to propagate. Nine mammalian genes encode sodium channels, many over 90% identical sequence, suggesting similar function and constraints. Multiplicity raises why so many. Theoretical constraints on sodium diversity, membrane excitability and resting, directly constrain properties. Data from 172 measurements, wild-type and mutant, under various conditions, obey excitability while channels in muscle obey resting, not neuronal. Excitability distinguishes channels into four groups consistent phylogen. Calculations suggest differences between groups.

Researchers analyzed how functional constraints shape mammalian voltageated sodium channels, crucial for action potential propagation. Hodgkin Hux models suggest sodium properties must be constrained for action to propagate. Nine mammalian genes encode channels, many over 90% identical, suggesting similar function and constraints. Researchers have identified the endonuc domain of the influenza H1N1 (2009) polymerase as a potential target for antiviral drugs due to its role in transcription and replication of the viral genome. The unique cap-snatching mechanism of transcription can be inhibited by targeting the PB cap-binding or enduc domains. High-resolution X-ray crystal structures of the enduc domain with specific inhibitors, including diketo compounds and green tea catechin, have been obtained. These compounds chate two manganese ions in the active site of the enzyme. The binding modes of different compounds and a mononucleotide highlight how substituents on the metal scaffold can bind in distinct subockets and the active cavity's plasticity. This information will aid in designing more potent inhibitors targeting the enduc activity of influenza polymerase. The study provides the first detailed structural information on inhibitor binding to the enduc and will guide medicinal chemistry optimization of lead compounds for efficient inhibition.
Researchers have developed an effective immunization protocol to produce potent polyspecific antiven against three medically important vipers in Thailand and neighboring countries: Cryptelytrops alabris (White-lipped viper), Caloselasma rhodoma (Malayan viper), and Dabo siensis (Russ's viper). The protocol, known as 'low dose, low multi-site immunization', was used to immunize four horses with a mixture of the three venoms, resulting in a rapid rise in ELISA titers and plateau at the 8th week post-immunization. The antisera showed high in vivo neutralization potency against the venoms, exceeding the minimal limits set by the Queen Saoh Memorial Institute. The polyspecific antisera also effectively neutralized the procoagulant, hemorrhagic, necrotic, and nephroxic activities of the venoms. This immunization protocol is useful for producing potent polyspecific antiven against snake venoms and equine antis against tetanus, diphtheria, and rabies.
Salmonella enterica, a bacterium that causes systemic infections, can persist in the body for long periods despite a strong immune response. Chronically infected individuals are asymptomatic and transmit the disease to naive hosts through fecal shedding, serving as a reservoir for the disease. The effector protein SI, translocated into host cells by the Salmonella Pathogenic Island 2 (SPI) type III secretion system, is required for Salmonella typhim to maintain long-term systemic infection in mice. SI inhibits normal migration of primary macrophages and dendritic cells (DC) in vitro, and this inhibition requires host IQG1, a regulator of cell migration. S binds IQ1 and localizes with it at the periphery. The C-terminal of S is similar to PM/ToxA, a toxin with cysteine residue critical for activity. Mutation of corresponding in S eliminates S function in vitro and vivo, but not IQ1 binding. Infection with wild-type S typhur suppressed migration to spleen in S-dependent manner. Examination of spleens from infected with WT tyur revealed fewer DC and CD+ lymphocytes compared to infected ΔI tyur.
A mobile genetic element SCCm-encoded p-mec RNA suppresses translation of agr and attenuates MRSA virulence. Community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (CA-MRSA) is a problematic pathogen that infects healthy individuals, causing severe disease. CA-MRSA is more virulent than hospital-acquired-MRSA (HARSA). The mechanism of high virulence of CA-MRSA is unknown. The product of the p-mec gene, located in the mobile element SCCm of HA-MRSA but not CA-M, suppresses expression of phenol-solysin alpha (PSMα), a cytolytic toxin of S. aureus. Here, we report p-m RNA inhibits translation of agr gene encoding a transcription factor for PSα via binding to agr mRNA. 25% of 325 MRSA isolates had a mutation in p-m promoter attenuating transcription and 9% had no p-m. Most p-mutated or p-m-deleted HARSAs had increased PSα compared to strains with intact p-m and some produced high amounts of PSα comparable to CA-MRSA. Deletion of p-m from HARSAs with intact-m increased expression of Agr and PS and virulence in mice. p-m RNA suppresses MRSA virulence via inhibition of agr translation and absence of p-m in CARSA causes high virulence property.
Researchers have investigated the phenomenon of antibody-mediated disease enhancement (ADE) in type I interferon-deficient mice, which occurs when maternal antibodies from a previous deng infection enhance the severity of a subsequent infection with a different deng virus serotype. In a previous study, 5-week-old type I and II interferon-deficient (AG) mice born to DENV-immune mothers showed increased disease severity upon DENV2 infection, characterized by high virus titers and vascular leakage leading to death. To replicate this in a less immunocompromised background, the researchers used type I interferon-deficient A129 mice. Five-week-old A129 mice born to D1-imm mothers succumbed to D2 infection within 4 days, whereas those born to naïve mothers survived. Clinical manifestations included hepatocyte vacuolation, vascular leakage, lymphopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Anti-TNF therapy protected mice and correlated with healthy hepatocytes, while blocking IL-6 did not impact virus titers or outcome. This A129 model of ADE may help dissect mechanisms in deng pathogenesis and evaluate vaccine/therapeutic candidates.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to identify factors associated with Leishmania infantum infection in humans in the Americas. Fifty-one studies were reviewed, and meta-analysis of effect sizes were used to pool information on each variable. Male sex was associated with visceral leishiasis in studies using the leishman skin test, but not with serological diagnosis. Young individuals were less frequently infected but more prone to illness. Presence of dogs at home, higher seropositivity nearby, lower socioeconomic status, and vegetated areas were associated with L. infant infection, but not presence of chickens or nutritional status. Ecological studies showed dog seropitivity associated with human VL, emphasizing dogs as a marker of visceral leishias occurrence. This is the first review on factors associated with visceral leishias in Latin America, clarifying disease dynamics and raising questions. However, results cannot be applied to other contexts due to disease characteristics. A review of risk factors in Asia showed spatial clustering, household conditions, vegetation, and poverty. In Brazil, case-fatality rates varied 4.2-10% in treated patients. Diagnosis uses hypersensitivity, parasitological, serological, and molecular methods.
Inhalation of Francisella tularens (Ft) causes acute and fatal pneumonia, with the lung cytokine environment favoring bacterial replication. However, the mechanisms underlying pathogenesis and lethality remain unclear. Research reveals that an innate cellular response, rather than bacterial burden or cytokine production, drives tissue pathology and mortality. Lethal infection elicits medullary and extra-medullary myelopoiesis, recruiting immature myeloid and myeloid suppressor cells (IM/MD) to the lungs, which fail to mature, leading to necrotic lung damage, loss of function, and death. This process is partially dependent on Ly6+ cells. Acceleration of this process may account for rapid lethality with Schu4. In contrast, sub-lethal infection with LVS shows a predominance of mature neutrophils and monocytes, required for protection, suggesting a threshold for lethal infection. Eliciting a mature phagocyte response provides transient protection against Schu4. The study suggests the nature of myoid response determines host mortality versus survival in Francisella infection.
Aedes albopictus, the Asian tiger mosquito, is an invasive species that poses a global concern due to its rapid spread and potential for infectious disease transmission. As a vector of important arboviruses such as chikungunya (CHV), dengue (DENV), and Zika (ZIK), understanding its colonization pattern is crucial for mitigating its spread and disease risks. Classical genetics and Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) approaches were used to disentangle the demographic history of Aedesopopus populations from Southeast Asia and recently colonized areas. In Southeast Asia, low differentiation and high co-ancestry values among China, Thailand, and Japan indicate native populations maintain genetic connectivity, revealing a common origin in China. Outside Asia, invasion in La Reunion, America, and the Mediterranean is supported by chaotic propagule distribution, maintaining high diversity in adventive populations. Independent transcontinental introductions may have facilitated establishment through admixture of unrelated genomes, resulting in intra-population variability. This may extend to mechanisms controlling vector competence. In the invasion context, ancestry and admixture create conditions for efficient arvirus transmission and outbreak.
Researchers investigated the factors that contribute to the fitness of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in chronic wounds, a type of bacterial infection that can be difficult to treat. They found that isolates from human wounds often lacked virulence functions and biofilm formation capabilities, which are typically associated with bacterial pathogenicity. However, these functions were not necessary for bacterial fitness in mouse wounds. Instead, genes involved in anaerobic growth, metabolism, energy production, and membrane integrity were critical. This suggests that bacteria in wounds may be stressed by their own high-density growth, rather than host conditions. The study sheds light on bacterial functions in chronic infections, stresses in wounds, and potential therapeutic targets to prevent infection.
A prospective study was conducted at the Center for Teaching, Research, and Referral for Bancrofilariasis (NEF) to evaluate the occurrence of intrascrot lymphangiectasia, appearance/consistency of the testis, and efficacy of complete excision hydrocele in patients in a bancrofilariasis endemic area. A total of 968 patients with unilateral or bilateral hydrocele (Group 1) and 218 patients from the same area who had undergone hydrocele-sparing hydrocelectomy elsewhere (Comparison Group) were enrolled. Twenty patients from Comparison with hydro recurrence were reoperated at NEF and constitute Group 2. In Group 1, 1128 hydrolectomies were performed (mean age 30.3yr, mean follow-up 8.6yr). Hydro recurrence rates in Group 1 and Comparison (age 31.5) were 0.3% and 19.3, respectively (p<0.001). There was no recurrence in Group 2 (age 25.1, mean follow 6yr). Surgically leaking or dilated lymphatic vessels were seen in inner/outer hydro sac or surrounding tissue, particularly retrotesticular, in 30.9 and 46.3% patients Group 1/2 (p=0.081). Testicles were abnormal shape, volume, consistency in 203/128 (18%) and 10/28 (35.7) patients Group 1/2 (p=0.025). Lymph fluid from ruptured dilated lymphatic is an important component chronic filarial hydro fluid threatening test integrity in adult population bancfilari endemic areas. To avoid recurrence, authors advise complete excision hydro sac when leaking or dilated vessels suture or excised.
Researchers have identified a deubiquinating enzyme, Ts37, in the parasite Trichella spiralis, a zoonotic nematode that causes trichlosis, a disease found on all continents except Antarctica. The enzyme is a cystine protease, orthologous to the human protein UCH5, and interacts with the proteasome, a complex responsible for protein degradation. This interaction has been conserved throughout evolution. The study used an activity-based probe, HA-Ub-V, to identify deubiquinating activity in T spir larvae lysate, and immuno-blot and imm-precipitation to identify potential deubiquating enzymes. LC/MS/MS analysis yielded peptides with sequence homology to conserved human deubiquating enzymes. The gene encoding putative UCH5 homologue, Ts37, was cloned and recombinant protein expressed and purified. Deubiquinating activity was verified by Ub-AM assay. Co-precitation of recomant Ts37 showed association with proteome components, including yeastpn homologue ADR1. Inhibitor LD-44 exhibited specific inhibition of recomant Ts37 and reduced viability of cultured larvae. This study reports the first T spir deubiquating enzyme and suggests interaction with proteome has been conserved.
Researchers have investigated the anti-trypanosomal activity of nitrile-based cystine protease inhibitors as a potential treatment for Chagas disease, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. The study focused on two scaffolds associated with cathepsin K inhibition and found that three compounds showed anti-tryosomal activity in the 0.1-1 μM range against the CL Bre strain of T. cruzi, with two compounds having EC50 values of 0.12 and 0.25 μM, significantly lower than their Ki values against cruzain, a recombinant form of cruzain. This suggests the anti-tryosomal activity may not be solely due to cruzain inhibition, indicating a putative polypharmacological profile towards cystine proteases. The study also evaluated cathein K inhibitors on a cyclohexane dicarbox scaffold, observing anti-tryosomal activity greater than expected from cruzain inhibition. cruz is a validated target for therapeutic intervention in Chagas disease, supported by oral activity of cystine inhibitor K777 in animal models and efficacy of analogs in a murine Chagas model. Potent dipeptyl nitr inhibitors of cruz showed no anti-tryosomal activity, questioning the relevance of potency in kinetic assay as predictor. The results suggest anti-tryosomal effects of potent compounds may be due to inhibition of unidentified cystine proteases, such as cruzain-2, or a polypharmac profile targeting isoforms of cruzain or other cystine proteases in the parasite. The cystine inhibition profile suggests a new antag target may share characteristics with cathein and phenic screening for antag agents should include potent inhibitors of this enzyme.
Researchers have constructed a physical map of the maize genome that covers 93.5% of the genome, with 86.1% aligned to the genetic map. The map contains 25,908 genic markers, enabling 73% of the genome to be anchored to the rice genome. Sequence tags correlate with recombination patterns, with 1 kb in rice corresponding to 3.2 kb in maize. Maize has a 6-fold genome size expansion due to polyploid origin, with most regions corresponding to two in maize. Inversions account for majority of chromosome variations during diploidization. Ancient duplication predates divergence of maize and rice progenitors. Reconstructing paleobotany indicates progenitors contained 10 chromosomes. Alignment sheds light on chromosomes contributing to polloid, rearrangements and diploid, and homologous regions. RFLP mapping shows two maize sets align with one rice and sorghum chromosome, a whole duplication event. Table 3 summarizes primary and secondary duplications in maize. Average 3 copies per over (Table 2) supports tetraploid emergence. Duplications in rice not limited to ancestor. Bands from fingerprint, not simulated, size similar to rice map. A saturated genetic map was developed to anchor contigs along chromosomes. Multiple events contribute to complex pattern, recent duplication easier than ancient. Synteny shows rearrangements since maize and rice divergence.
Researchers investigated the de novo generation of infectious prions, the proteinaceous agents responsible for transmissible spong encephalopathies, in vitro. They aimed to mimic the early etiology of sporadic disease, the most common form of human prion disease, which appears to originate from a low-frequency spontaneous misfolding event generating the first PrSc particle that propagates as the infectious form of the disease. The study used protein misfolding cyclic amplification (PM) procedure to analyze the possibility of spontaneous generation of PrSc. Under standard PM conditions and precautions to avoid cross-contamination, de novo generation of PrSc was not observed, supporting its use for diagnostic applications. However, PM was modified to generate PrSc in the absence of pre-existing PrSc in different species at a low and variable rate. De novo generated PrSc was infectious when inoculated into wild-type hamsters, producing a new disease with unique clinical, neuropathological, and biochemical features. The results provide additional evidence for the prion hypothesis and a model to study sporadic prion disease, suggesting prion diversity is not restricted to known forms, and new infectious foldings may produce novel phenotypes.
Researchers have developed a novel neural model, the Angular Velocity Unit (AV), to estimate angular velocity in bees, accounting for previously unexplained behaviors in visual odometry and corridor-centering. The model is based on electrophysiological data and tested with behavioral data, suggesting AV can be considered an extension of the optomotor response. The detector is tested behaviorally simulated with the corridor-center paradigm, where bees navigate a corridor with gratings (square or sinusoidal) on walls. When combined with existing flight control, the detector reproduces invariance of flight path to spatial frequency and contrast of gratings, including deviations from centering behavior found in real bees. The detector's response to distance along corridor is constant for a range of grating frequencies, demonstrating it can be used as a visual odometer.

The model, Angular Detector Unit (ADU), reproduces behavioral patterns including unaccounted for in corridor-center response: deviation of flight path from center due to spatial frequency differences in sinusoidal gratings and deviations from center for square and sinusoidal gratings. Identified detectors respond to temporal frequencies 10-100Hz, lower than experienced in bee experiments. Additional circuitry for AV estimation must be present. Neural recordings from ventral cord found distinct responses to moving patterns in bee's view. Odometry is unaffected by environment frequency, suggesting AV neurons could estimate distance by summing output over visual field. The model tested this relationship, results show wide range of frequencies (0.1-10)
Untreated infections by Trypanosoma brucei gambense, the causative agent of African trypanosomiasis (AT), have long been considered invariably fatal. However, this study reports on a 15-year follow-up of 50 AT patients from the Ivory Coast, 11 of whom refused treatment after initial diagnosis. Using sensitive diagnostic tools, parasite clearance was observed in 10 out of 11 who continued to refuse treatment, with 7 displaying serological responses, becoming negative to trypanosome antigens (Li1.3, 1.5, and 1.6). Two alternative progressions of AT were observed: aparasitemic and asymptomatic infection with long-lasting serological responses, and spontaneous resolution with negative parasitological and PCR results and dropping antibody titres. This study does not estimate the frequency of these courses, but notes that field programs encounter subjects with positive serological results but negative parasitological tests, indicating some display these infection courses. Recognizing trypanotolerance in humans, as accepted in animals, is a step for future research in AT. 

Human trypaniasis (AT) is caused by Trypanosoma bruce (T.b) gambense and T.rhodesi, with T.b gambense causing 95% cases. The disease evolves from haemolymphatic to meningeal phase when parasites invade central nervous system leading neurological disorders. This study combines clinical, serological, molecular, and parasit investigations, using sensitive tools, the most comprehensive on Tryosoma bruce gambense in humans. Two alternative progressions to fatal observed: aparitem and asymptomatic and spontaneous resolution with negative parasit and PCR and dropping titres.
Researchers investigated whether ionizing radiation selects for p53-deficient hematopoietic progenitors in vivo using mouse models. They found that p53 disruption does not provide a selective advantage in an unstressed hematopoietic system or previously irradiated BM allowed to recover from irradiation. However, upon irradiation, p53 disruption confers a selective advantage, leading to long-term expansion of p-deficient clones and increased lymphoma development. Selection for cells with disrupted p53 is attributed to protection from irradiation-induced elimination of progenitor cells, prevention of irradiation-induced loss of clonogenic capacity for stem and progenitor cells, improved maintenance of progenitor fitness, and elimination of competing p-type progenitors. These studies indicate that the carcinogenic effect of ionizing irradiation is partly explained by selection for cells with p disruption, which protects progenitor from immediate and long-term reductions in fitness following irradiation.
Researchers have identified a serine protease inhibitor, SmKI-1, in the parasite Schistosoma mansoni, which plays a crucial role in the parasite's survival and development. The study found that the recombinant Sm-1 and its Kunit domain, but not the C-terminal region, possess inhibitory activity against tryp and neutrophil elastase (NE). Molecular docking studies revealed that Sm-1's Kunit domain blocks NE's active site. Sm-1 also inhibited the capacity of NE to kill schistosomes. To investigate Sm-1's role in the parasite, specific siRNA was used to knockdown Sm-1 in S. mansoni, resulting in a robust impact on parasite development in vitro and in vivo. Sm-1's ability to interfere with neutrophil function was tested in murine models of inflammatory diseases. Treatment with Sm-1 rescued acetaminophen (AP)-mediated liver damage, reducing neutil recruitment and elast activity. In a model of gout, Sm-1 reduced neutil accumulation, IL-β secretion, hyperiception, and pathological score. Sm-1 inhibited early events triggering neutil recruitment in pleural cavities of mice in response to carrageenan. Sm-1 is a key protein in S. mans survival and has the ability to inhibit neutil function as a therapeutic against inflammatory diseases.
Researchers have developed a novel method for accurately modeling transmembrane helical (TM) protein structures from distant homologues with distinct loop and TM conformations. The method was tested on a benchmark of 50 TM protein pairs with diverse topology, size, and sequence identity, and achieved near-atomic prediction accuracy in membrane-embedded regions. The technique was validated in two blind predictions, including the adenosine A2 and chemokine CX4 receptors, and ranked first in the GPCRDOCK prediction contests for receptor accuracy. Unlike starting templates, the models are suitable for computer-based protein engineering and redesigned X-ray structures exhibit similar interactions. The method should be useful for atom-level modeling and design of structurally uncharacterized TM proteins from a range of homologues.
Listeria monocytogen, the causative agent of listeriosis, a foodborne disease that poses risks to fetuses, newborns, and immunocompromised individuals, has been found to switch from an active, motile lifestyle to a state of persistence in vacuoles in human hepatocytes and trophoblast cells during several days of infection. Upon intracellular spread, bacteria stop producing actin nucleating protein Act and become trapped in lysosome-like vacuoles termed Lister-Containing Vacoles (Lis). Subpopulations of bacteria resist degradation in Lis and enter a slow/non-replicative state.
