Population data was combined with models to estimate the population at risk and requiring treatment in 2009. Results showed high endemicity below 20% in most areas, with areas ≥20% around Lake Victoria and coast. Comparison of 198 and 2009 distributions showed STH prevalence decreased over time. The model estimated 2.8 million school-age children in districts warranting mass treatment. Bayesian-space geostat models can estimate combined STH prevalence and suggest a quarter of Kenya's school children live in high-prevalence areas warranting treatment. Control reducing infection, updated models can refine decision-making in helth control.
Researchers investigated the role of innate lymphocytes in immunity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. They found that splenocytes from uninfected mice produced interferon-γ when cultured with M-infected macrophages, suppressing bacterial replication. This control was dependent on CD1-restricted invariant NKT (iKT) cells, which required CD1 expression by infected macrophages and IL-12 and IL-18. iKT cells, even in limiting quantities, restricted M replication. Adoptive transfer of primary iKT cells from uninf mice significantly reduced bacterial burden in the lungs of mice infected with virulent M by aerosol. iKT had a direct bactericidal effect, independent of synthetic ligands. This is the first evidence that CD-restricted N cells mediate protection against M in vivo. Innate lymphocytes, including NK cells, play a role in resistance to various infections, but their contribution to M immunity is controversial. Following M infection, NK cells are activated and rapidly produce interferonγ, a critical for macrophage activation. Blocking IL-12 or IL-18 abrogated control of replication, indicating iKT activation and control was dependent on IL-12 and IL-18. Splenocytes restricted mycobacterial growth dependent on iKT. CD-restricted N cells were tested using mice lacking N cells; CD1−/− lack both invariant and CD-restricted NKT, while J281/− are deficient in iKT. Absence of CD-restricted cells did not alter tuberculosis outcome in previous studies.
Researchers investigated the regulation of Bacillus subtilis spore coat transglutaminase (Tgl), an enzyme responsible for cross-linking proteins in the spore coat. Unlike other transglutases, T is produced in an active form and catalyzes amine incorporation and cross-linking in vitro without additional requirements, raising questions about how its activity is controlled during spore assembly. The study found that substrates assembled onto the spore prior to T production govern its localization to the sp surface, and identified glutamyl (Q) and lys (K) docking sites crucial for this process. The first step in the reaction, interaction with substrates and formation of acyl-enzyme intermediate, determines T localization. Consistent with T exerting "spotting" activity, cross-linking pre-assembled complexes, T forms high molecular weight oligomers in vitro and becomes part of cross-linked products. The dependency on substrates controls time, location, and extent of T's activity, directing coval fortification of pre-as complexes at sp surface. This mechanism ensures proper temporal and spatial control of spore protein cross-link and specificity of T's action.
A cross-sectional parasitological and questionnaire survey was conducted in 51 villages in Champas province, Lao PDR in 2007 to investigate the distribution and risk factors of Opisthorchis vivini infection. The study found a 61.1% prevalence of O. vivini among 3,371 participants with complete data. Geostatistical models identified age, Lao ethnic group, educational attainment, occupation (farmer, fisherman, animal breeder), and unsafe water source as risk factors for infection, while history of praziquel treatment, access to sanitation, and distance to freshwater were protective. Spatial patterns of O. vivini were governed by environmental factors, with predictive modeling identifying two risk profiles: low in mountains and high in the Mekong corridor. The study provides the first map of O. vivini infection in Champas province, important for targeting control efforts. Infection with O. viv appears associated with exposure to intermediate host, human behavior, culture, and transmission sustained by lack of sanitation.
In Dar es Sala, Tanzania, the presence of Anopheles and Cule larvae, vectors of lymphatic filariasis and malaria, is a significant concern due to the city's extensive network of drains with inadequate flow, often blocked by waste, causing flooding after rainfall. A study analyzed data from the Urban Malaria Control Program (UMCP) and a special survey in 2006 found that more than 70% of larval habitats in Dar Sala were human-made, with aquatic habitats associated with agriculture having the highest proportion of Anophe and Cule presence. Drains, however, comprised 42% of habitats and 43% of all culicine and 33% of anopheline habitats. The odds of finding Anophe and Cule larvae were 8.8 and 6.3 times larger in drains with stagnant water compared to flowing water. A positive association was found between vegetation and mosquito presence. The proportion of habitats with larvae was spatially correlated. Restoring and maintaining drains in Dar Sala has potential to eliminate over 40% of mosquito larval habitats treated with laricides by UMCP. Human-made larval habitats for both diseases highlight the need for synergy between control efforts.
Dengue virus (DENV) infection leads to an increase in HMG-CoA reductase (HMGCR) activity through the impairment of AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) phosphorylation. This results in a cholesterol-enrich cellular environment favoring viral replication. Studies using enzymatic assays, ELISA, and Western blotting found higher MG activity in DENV-infected cells associated with AMPK inactivation. Metformin, an AMP activator, declined MG activity, suggesting AMP inactivation mediates enhanced MG. Reduced AMP phosphorylation activity was observed in DENV-infected cells at 12 and 24 hours post-infection. MG and cholesterol co-localized with viral proteins NS3, NS4A, and E, indicating a role in DENV replicative complex formation. Metform and lovastatin, an MG inhibitor, altered co-localization as well as replicative complex formation, supporting active MG required for formation. Metform prompted dose-dependent antiviral effect in DENV-infected cells, while compound C, an AMP inhibitor, augmented viral copies and infected cells. PP2 activity, a modulating MG phosphatase, was unaffected by D infection. Data demonstrate elevated MG activity in DENV cells mediated AMP inhibition, not increased PP activity. Inhibition showed antiral effect in MG-independent manner. Results suggest D infection increases MG through AMP inactivation leading to cholesterol endoplasmic retic for replicative formation.
Researchers used all-atom molecular dynamics simulations of the 70S ribosome to investigate the kinetics and energy landscape of tRNA translocation. They found that the process can be decomposed into slow, large-scale collective movements and rapid local fluctuations, with specific regions of the ribosome undergoing coordinated displacements. The study identified collective coordinates that capture 30-body rotation, 30-head swivel, and tRNA displacements, which are essential for substrate translocation. These findings provide a bridge between kinetic and energy measurements, allowing for the estimation of free energy barriers associated with translocation. The analysis was performed for a specific kinetic scheme, but the framework is general and can be applied to other energetic and kinetic descriptions. The study establishes a foundation for understanding tRNA translocation in the ribosome, providing a unifying interpretation of available data.
Researchers investigated the genetic landscape of medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) by analyzing 84 sporadic MTC samples and 36 paired normal thyroid tissues using the Ion AmpliSeq Cancer Panel. They identified 101 mutations in 18 genes, with the most common being in the RET proto-oncogene, occurring in 47 cases, followed by mutations in genes encoding Harvey sarcoma viral oncogene homolog, serine/threon kinase 11, v-Hardyuckerman 4 feline sarcoma viral oncogene homolog, mut homolog 1, Kiest ratcoma viral oncogene hom, and MET-oncogene. Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) rearrangement was evaluated by immunohistochemistry and break-ap fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), with 2 of 98 cases positive for ALK. Targeted sequencing identified Glutaminefructose-6-phosphate transaminase 1 (GF1)-ALK and echoderm microtubule-associated protein 4 (E4)-ALK fusions. PCR and Sanger sequencing confirmed the GF1-ALK fusion, indicating an intra-chromosomal translocation or deletion. A metastatic M case with E4ALK showed a dramatic response to AL inhibitor crizotin. The study found several mutations in MTC and first identified AL fusions in M, suggesting E4ALK may be a driver and target for AL inhibitors, and GFALK a candidate for molecular therapy.
A study was conducted in Malda district, West Bengal, India to evaluate the role of asymptomatic Leishmanias in the transmission of visceral Leishias (VL) and post-Kala-azar Dermal Leishias (PKDL) in the region. A total of 289 individuals were screened for Leishial antibody using R-39 rapid diagnostic kits, and 185 were found positive. Of these, 96 had a history of VL/PK and 89 did not. 79 were classified as asymptomatic Leishias and 10 as active VL with a ratio of 7.9:1. Among asymptomatic cases, 2 were lost to follow-up as they moved to other places. Progression to disease among asymptomatic individuals occurred up to 3 years after baseline. Seroconversion in 62/77 (80.52%) and disease in 8/77 (10.39%) were noted. 7 (9.09%) remained seropositive after 3 years. The prevalence of asymptomatic Leish infection was 3.16% (79/97), lower than 5.62-13.8% in other studies in Bihar. The ratio of asymptomatic to symptomatic cases was 7.9:1. Individuals with no history of VL/PK but positive for Leishial antibody were classified as asymptomatic. Those who became seronegative during follow-up were referred as seroconversion and developed symptoms of VL/PK as progression.
Researchers used a technique called Multiplex Ligation-Dependent Probe Amplification (MLPA) to analyze genetic rearrangements in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae genome caused by the presence of the Ty retrotransposon Ty. They found that the distribution of translocations induced by Ty was random and the majority were mediated by six specific targets on four chromosomes, despite 254 potential targets in the genome. The majority of Ty-mediated translocations resulted from RAD-dependent recombination, but a number of non-recipro translocations were mediated by RAD-independent recombination between Ty elements. RAD-independent trans did not require Rad51 or Rad59 homolog proteins or Rad1-10 endonuc complex. Defects in ASF-RT109-dependent acetylation of histone H3 lysine 56 resulted in increased Gs and whole-chromosome duplications and aneupidy. MLPA is a versatile technique for rapid analysis of Gs and facilitates genetic pathways that prevent and promote Gs and aneupidy.
Researchers have developed a new method for protein docking, called Semi-Definite-based Underestimation (SD), which uses stochastic minimization of funnel-shaped energy functions in the space of rigid body motions (SE(3) to account for flexibility of interface chains. The method underestimates a set of local energy minima and uses the resulting underestimator to bias sampling, effectively minimizing functions with funnel-shaped basins. However, applying SD to rotational and translational space (SE(3) is challenging due to its geometry. To address this, a strategy separates variables for side-chain optimization, center-to-center distance, and five angular descriptors of relative orientations is introduced. Removing the center-to-center distance improves efficiency, as the five-dimensional space exhibits a well-behaved energy surface for underestimation. The algorithm explores the energy surface spanned by encounter complexes corresponding to local energy minima, similar to macromolecular association through collisions. Results show the free energy landscape is a funnel in a broad neighborhood of the native state, and SD generates predictions with less than 5Å ligand interface root-mean-square deviation, achieving a 20-fold efficiency gain compared to Monte Carlo methods. The application of SD to protein-protein docking validates the funnel assumption of the energy landscape, but direct application in SE(3 fails to yield underestimators due to energetically favorable distances when proteins are in contact but not overlap. The method discovers broad funnels, generates quality predictions, and substantial efficiency compared to Monte Carlo.
